This is trash.Initial impressions bellow--------------------------------------------------------------------------This is an episode one review, so the show is given leniency the other reviews have shrugged away from. I like the "isekai" format more than the pure fantasy or alternate history formats. It usually has more expansive answer to "what if...?" Like in Overlord, "what if you were stranded in a world full of NPCs (the humans) you cared little for?" Pretty lonely existence for Ains, isn't it? Or in How not to Summon a Demon Lord, "what if you were in another world without any social skills?" Yeah, Diablo gets to do some pretty pervy things, but he's constantly under huge pressure. If you were even a little socially awkward, you do feel for the guy. In Tanya the Evil we get an office worker to not only fight a war, but also an entity with near limitless power. Can't be a fun time, even with Tanya's extra oomph. So, what does this anime offer? It's a group of 7, so they're not lonely. They are all exceptionally outgoing, so they aren't socially awkward. There is no war that they have to fight, there may be a war, but they aren't forced into it. There isn't a God pestering them, and they weren't summoned by some king to fight some sort of wave. There is a bad dragon, but that can't be too bad of an enemy if the story teller got laughed at.Oh, there's a nuclear reactor at their disposal. You get me one of those and dirt, I'll give you guns in a week, m777 howitzers without the electronics in a month, with the electronics in 6-7 months, and I'm just an engineer who hasn't built his own space lab. I'd be building main battle tanks in a year, tops. Who's gonna stop me? Oh, they do have the engineer in the pink dress on the cover. She better build a furnace and a lathe within the week or I'm calling Dr. Stone to ridicule her back into orbit.They had the master politician create a national incident and attempt to cover it up, poorly, on his very first encounter with a corrupt soldier. Something tells me he's not gonna do well unless engineer girl manages to procure him the equivalent of the USA armed forces by next month. So he better get to recruiting, I hope the master merchant can get him the budget he'd need for salaries, or the master magician Prince will have to pull them out of his...hat? What's an illusionist doing here? They couldn't fit in a physicist? Does the science girl do everything? Math, physics, engineering, biology, chemistry...? OK, I get it, prodigy, Dr. Stone does it, so why not? I don't like Dr. Stone either, arrogant p.... Anyway.This show has no appealing characters. We have overpowered people, who by all accounts were simply born that way, start trouble in another world. I don't know where the other reviewers got, "we'll take your women, because we're better" or "elitism" from, but I get the dislike of the characters. They are Mary Sues and quite annoying, especially ninja and samurai girls. I get taking out 2 guys each without armor, but four fully armored soldiers going down without a sound of struggle or hits, is too much. I get it, they are OP, but how do you knock out someone in a full helmet without making noise? Come on show! I'm not asking for reality, but at least enough for me to suspend disbelief ? A little bit? 90 pound girls taking down trained veterans, cool, I'll buy it, make the armor ding a bit? Bop? No? Nothing? OK, bye bye silly show.

Could be interesting take on the tad overcrowded Isekai genre, a group of seven prodigies instead of the sole protagonist. Based on first episode it is okay, doesn't seem to take any risks with our super genius High Schoolers thrust into a medieval fantasy world. I'm hoping there will some interesting plot twists and some badly needed characterization (as it stands our Heroes are walking caricatures). It reminds "Astra Lost in Space", except this anime give the impression of being a lot more shallow. For what it is, it's fine, a nice way to wile away 24 minutes without much conflict or 'easy' viewing.

Honestly is not bad as many one star people rated as. Though the starting episode actually bland but is well animated and directed. They were able to setup what they needed. Also keep in mind this is a work of fiction and fantasy, so things can be whatever the author write. It seem to me people are disliking this story was because of the absurd profession these kids are at a young age. I agree, however even irl thing like this can still happen; for example, the recent 9 years old electrical engineer graduate! I actually enjoy the story so far and would recommend those who enjoy isekai and management story. 5 stars for now!

We know they're op and prodigies, it literally tells us so, so why is everyone throwing fits? I didn't watch this anime until today because of the reviews, but it's actually pretty good and refreshing. The way they're trying to fix the place up and bring freedom to the people kinda reminds me of 'That Time I Got Reincarnated To A Slime', in that it's nice to watch them start from the beginning, then work their way up to make the town a better place

People getting upset that the characters in the anime having it too easy just makes me laugh. y'all didnt read the title of the anime huh. High school prodigies have it EASY. This is just something to mindlessly enjoy. Kick back and relax your shoulders, relax your jaw, BREATHE. How about you all take it easy?Despite all that, as I said, if you're looking for some easy going, reformative and op characters, then you're at the right place.If you're looking for some painstakingly serious, end of the world threats, then look elsewhere. It's all in the title.

Unlike other isekai anime out there who has whiny, woe-is-me, weak, dumb, goody-two-shoes protagonists, the main characters in this anime are strong-willed, can adopt to new environment, talented and can make decisions quickly (living up to their prodigy title, of course) also kind-hearted but bad-asses. Each of the characters might have sad pasts but i like how they choose to either set it aside or learn from it instead of living in constant self-pity like most anime characters do. They try their best to help the inhabitants; sharing their knowledge and showing them ways to make their lives better and daily lives easier whilst teaching them how not to be pushed around by the wealthy and powerful. This is how it should be. Please don't change it. Don't mind the haters.

None of the characters have any real development or introduction, nor any given motivation for their goals. I can deal with powerfantasy isekai, as overdone as it is, but 7 cardboard cutouts going around being the supergreatest at everything forever isn't a fun watch. What exceptionally little personality the characters display is nothing but grating and annoying. There's zero explanation for how or why they're the best at their given field, it just is. One kid can fly and levitate his decapitated head. This is never explained, even slightly. That's actually sumarized the anime pretty well. It's never explained, even slightly. Why do they want to return to earth? No explanation. Why can a highschooler do complicated surgeries? No reason. And to top it off, they put gratuitous fanservice directly next to the fattest most disgusting slob in the show. I don't even mind elf jiggles, but to cut between an elfs breasts and a fat pigs face is just an extreme display of bad taste, and entirely out of place in an anime about highschool kids.

I think this show makes up for the typical genre tropes with the abundance of humor. Not every isekai show is supposed to be The Rising of the Shield Hero or Saga of Tanya the Evil, sometimes a show just has to go off the deep end and be almost a parody of a genre, and this show delivers the goods. If you desire a good natured funny isekai show, then this is it. It is absurdly humorous in a parody kinda way and good natured.

Many of the bad reviews here are after 1-2 episodes. The first episode did itself no favors with some pretty eye rollingly blatant fan service right away. I was also really tempted not to continue.However, by the third episode, it began to take on a very Log Horizon feel. Of course the main characters seem to easily overcome everything, but then we all love One Punch Man, and he literally doesn’t even try, so I think we can cut these guys some slack. Each character has their own unique talents, and by the most current episode, we start to see those talents DO have their own burdens. It takes several episodes, but you begin to see the other dimensions of several of the characters.Their overall mission also reminds me a bit of Shield Hero, in that they are ultimately poised to be saviors. I find it really interesting how they decide to go about it, and again it reminds me of Log Horizon, which I really enjoyed.In short, some people judged harshly very fast, and I think the anime needs a second look. Some anime are slow to build. They can’t all be strong out of the gate like Sword Art Online... then again most will remember how hard that one crashed and burned about 12 episodes in. This one may also shape up poorly, but I’m willing to watch til the end.

Seems like people are over reacting a bit, I understand the genre is getting to saturated with this kind of stuff but it's honestly not that bad. Though I absolutely hate the illusionist character since what he does might as well be magic. I find it stupid to rag on the 1D characters since I wasn't expecting them to be complicated with a lot of good backstory. I do think this anime as a whole could be improved but the idea of this pack of mary sues entering another world is interesting enough for me which is why I'm giving it an average score. Good concept, there's good scenes, but the writing can be a bit too bland.

This is definitely somewhat different if compared to other anime. Many say that the missing sense of real danger due to the overpowered main characters renders this show boring and I could agree to that if not for one thing.This show seems not to be build around a plot of danger but one of builiding. In other words this anime´s plot is not about the characters overcoming a certain challenge but them building a new world within this fantasy world. If you like such storys this anime is certainly worth a look. But if you want to see a challenge and powerful villains with complex story´s then you should probably spend your time with something more productive ;).

Isekai anime just keeps getting worse, and High School Prodigies Have It Easy In Another World is proof of that. There are multiple aspects of the story that I have major problems with. First of all, the protagonist is one of the most generic characters I have seen in an anime. Not only is he a politician in his high-school days, he is able to get all the ladies. The females in this show had the potential to easily become top tier waifus, but the show has messed all of them up as new episodes are released. I do not understand why this anime is as popular as it is, nor can I even begin to comprehend why people would actually enjoy this. If it were possible, I would give this show a 0\5.

I only post reviews for shows I have watched completely to the last episode and I will never recommend an anime to every person because frankly, what I like may not be the same for another person. People who might enjoy this anime are fans of battle-heavy series.Plot development : Right from the beginning we know what the entire series is about: a boy who wants to be the Hokage, or the best ninja in his village. The entire show, therefore, focuses on his development from "drop out" status to a ninja worthy of respect. Plot wise, the first few episodes were very slow, but is probably necessary because of the uniqueness of this anime. You are literally brought in to a whole new world and very appropriately, you are slowly introduced to what Konoha is like. Then as Naruto gains experience, he leaves the village and we learn along with him what the world of Naruto is like from his missions and journeys. As a series, Naruto truly is a series about Naruto growing up and gives audiences a glimpse into this amazingly well conceived world. The sequel, Naruto: Shippuuden develops upon the plots in Naruto and like all kids who grow up, they discover that the world isn't as bright as they once thought. This is highly reflected in the higher amounts of bloodshed, pains and sorrow in this sequel. But that's for a different review. On another note, I'm glad there is little fillers compared to Shippuuden.Character development : I would argue that Naruto has one of the best "child development" plots I have ever read or seen. I say this because Naruto as a character is very multilayered. He can be smiles and pranks, yet sorrowful and lonely in the next. His determination is simply admirable and I think it's because of these qualities that he is able to relate to and act as a catalyst that changes others. Hyuuga Neji is probably the best example. From fate-obsessed arrogant prodigy, we see an almost 180 degrees change to a more humble self-driven, still somewhat arrogant boy. Frankly, Naruto's actions constantly surprise his peers, teachers, and readers. But what still surprises me about him is his sincerity in his actions and words.Artwork : I personally prefer the artwork in the manga. At times when manga are made into anime, they are "cleaner" and lack the gruffness that can only be seen in the manga. Despite this, I still really enjoy the swirl designs that is almost ubiquitous in the world of Naruto. As a fantasy ninja story, all the bright colors is just like a kid's fairy tale, which is very appropriate. I think the clothing designs are ok, but what I truly love in terms of artwork are the designs and layouts of the villages, Konoha especially since it is shown the most often. Music : I like a few opening and ending themes, but I think the in-series music takes the cake here. Very rarely will you have a mainstream show with good in-series music and most have simply unimpressive scores and theme songs, but Naruto is surprisingly refreshing. Not only are the scores pleasant and fit the occasion, but the instruments and percussions used are the instruments I would imagine to exist in Naruto.Originality : In terms of artwork and music, this is as original as it gets. However, in terms of plot and character development, it is sometimes archetypical since the protagonist will and does end up being a praise worthy person through n number of trials. However, the organization and planning that goes into the trials that Naruto has to face is unlike any other protagonist. Other anime treat friendship as if they were made of titanium and gold once forged, but I really like how this series shows how strong, weak and most importantly, how rare friendship truly is. Friends can so easily become acquaintances and then strangers and trying to rekindle a friendship is always harder than making a new one. Score : 5/5 I don't normally give 5 stars and when I do, it's when I truly believe that the anime or manga is simply a masterpiece.

Naruto, is a series about a boy who takes on challenges for himself. He has hopes and dreams of becoming his village's leader. Overall, Naruto has its ups and downs. The story line is deep, with a plot that follows the manga. Naruto also has several filler arcs which lead away from the main plot. The music is great, and matches up with scenes well. The characters of Naruto, are well thought out.. they all have details about them and are interesting to watch. Animation is excellent. Fights are very detailed, you know how far away the characters are, and there are great camera angles.This series has gone on for along time and is really popular, If you don't know what Naruto is your missing out.Naruto is a great anime series that you should defintly consider watching

Naruto is a great anime.I grew up watching Naruto ever since I was 13 years old and now I'm 23. It was my first anime along with One Piece, both of which brought me to other animes. It is a very special anime that is full of life lessons, one that taught me a lot ever since I started watching it. Naruto is a series full of action, fights, feels, friendship, beliefs, and most importantly, BONDS, and I grew up attached to these points and more to the characters.Ever since it started, it always focused on the power and the importance of believing in one's self. The anime is a great storyteller, from it's darkest backgrounds to it's cool developments until the end. It also has a lot of amazing and interesting characters that feel so realistic.My complaints would be something like some episodes with very low quality animation, and some fillers that were bad or that killed the hype of the canon parts. Other than that, the story, the characters' developments and the characters themselves are great, the original soundtracks are even greater, among the best I've heard.

To me, Naruto is the most emotional, unpredictable plot their is in the anime universe. Naruto mostly appeals to me because of all its multiple conflicts to be solved in the story, a favorite being how team seven turned out almost exactly like Tsunade, Jiraya, and Orochimaru (Relationship wise). The un-ordinary and original system of fighting styles and clans the characters contain themselves to are another feature that grabs my attention but the thing i like the best is  all the emotion expressed by the characters and the captivation this brings to the viewer. This is mostly achieved by this Anime containing a feature that a lot of old American comics and anime have seemed to avoided: both good people and bad people die. It makes you get emotionally evolved with how every one of the individual characters are thinking instead of just your favorite hero. The story of Naruto is highly unpredictable, making more and more people (especially myself) become attached to the series and the characters that make it up.

Best stories and characters of any anime I've ever seen. The narrative creates a real emotional connection with the people in the stories. Everything progresses clearly and with continuity. It's embarrassing, but these stories often bring a tear to my eye.Excellent music, too!Fillers are ok at times but frequently pretty lame and hamper the story's smooth progression. A necessary evil, I guess.

Given the voracity of the backlash against the “not-so-bad” rating that Naruto received upon initial viewing by a fellow reviewer, I am certain that many readers eagerly anticipate a reviewer that, upon broader viewing (or even being of dissimilar gender from the original critic), will vindicate their pristine opinion of this title. Unfortunately you, the reader, are stuck with me. While I don’t think poorly of this title by any stretch of the imagination, the buzz pervading Naruto is plainly more hype than substance.So where does the hype begin you ask? Right off the bat. From the very beginning of episode one this title more or less pronounces itself to be of the cookie-cutter Shonen Jump variety, and only a somewhat above average one at that. The character for which the show is named, Naruto, is quickly introduced, and even before the end of the first episode the viewer is completely aware of the ultimate direction of the plot: Naruto will someday become the strongest ninja of his village and receive the highly coveted title of Hokage. But knowing the end of the plotline isn’t as much of a killjoy as one would expect. It is the ride that counts after all. However, in the case of Naruto the ride is tantamount to that of an old, wooden roller coaster: sometimes thrilling and often nostalgic, yet still quite a bit rickety and easily outdone in terms of excitement and quality.The characters, like the plot, are mostly OK while being admittedly cliched. Uzumaki Naruto, our primary character, is much like the leads of many of the most popular fight-styled anime. Like Goku (of Dragon Ball fame), Naruto is headstrong, motivated (mostly to become stronger), and cares deeply about his comrades. Like Yuusuke (of Yu Yu Hakusho fame), Naruto is rambunctious, brash, and a bit of a slacker. Despite his being particularly formulaic, Naruto at least combines the finer qualities of his predecessors. Such can not be said of his archrival Sasuke, a figure for whom blandness knows no depth. In fact, many of the characters fall somewhere in-between Sasuke’s blandness and Naruto’s charisma and coolness. You will come to care for the cast of Naruto for sure, just not at any deep or meaningful level.The animation, much like the characterization and plotting, is spotty. At times great while at other times shoddy, the quality of the animation here lacks any real consistency. During the arcs in which the animation is still on the minds of the animators, the viewer is treated to a fluid frame-rate and artistic renderings that leave little to be desired on the part of fans of the manga. Nevertheless, when the animation is bad it is painful. At these times the once faithful renderings degrade to craptastic levels. It is as if you can feel the framerates slipping before your very eyes. Like most aspects thus far examined, the animation of Naruto is a mixed bag indeed.It is perhaps a bit unfair though to judge a fight/action anime based upon factors such as characterization and plotting. True to its genre, it is in fight/action scenes that Naruto receives is highest accolades, though that isn’t saying a whole hell of a lot. Despite very wide employment, the fight scenes manage to remain remarkably fresh. With such a large extended cast, invigorating and unique fighting styles/techniques manage to continuously infuse action sets with life. Additionally, the background music manages to add some tension to these scenes quite effectively. There are some negative aspects to the action sets however. One is the overemployment of certain special techniques, particularly Naruto’s Shadow Clone technique, a move in which he creates multiple clones of himself. When a character uses the same move over and over and over and . . . well, things get bland and repetitive. Another detriment is that the sheer number of fights impedes the potency of plotting. Still, the combat stages are pretty intense and there are plenty of scenes for action fans to get pumped about.How one feels about Naruto probably depends, in good part, on their anime viewing mileage. As a person that has been watching anime for a decade and a half, there isn’t too much here that I haven’t seen done better elsewhere. However, it has managed to get better as it progresses. Although uneven in most aspects, this show is a good introductory title that will likely bring many newcomers into the fold of anime fandom.

I have been watching Naruto since it began airing in CN back in 2005, but at the time, it was on in the dub English version. I liked it, but it was not as good as it turned out to be in the original Japanese version! I love the voice actors, the music, the characters, and the storyline. It is an anime that is not only original and in its own class, but it will make you either cry, laugh, and/or smile when every episode is over. It is really great, and one of the best anime out there. It offers so much if you would give it the opportunity to demonstrate its worth. I love it now, and am currently watching the Naruto Shippuden series, and there are no words to describe it except: sugoi! Arigato, Mr. Masashi Kishimoto. You are the best for bringing my beloved Naruto into my life, as well as in many others. ^.^

When I first started watching, I wasn't at all impressed.  However, it was interesting enough that I didn't drop it during the introduction arc.  The Land of Waves arc really got me hooked though.  It remains the most interesting part of the entire series (including what I've seen of Shippuden, which I'm up-to-date on).  The Chuunin exam arc kept things going strong.  However, the show goes into a rather steady decline after that.  I'm not even sure how to describe what went wrong.  This is partially because it's been so long since I watched it.  The non-stop filler that takes up the last nearly 100 episodes with was just terrible and why I took away half a star from the Overall, Storyline and Character scores.  Any sane person should completely skip episodes 136+ and go straight to watching Shippuden or drop it entirely.  Personally, I wish I had dropped it after the Chuunin Exam arc but I have this crazy determination to see it through to the end.  I don't really expect to be rewarded for this, I just don't know how to convince myself to stop.I'd easily recommend that anyone watch it at least to the end of the Land of Waves arc(episode 19).  I can even recommend that anyone who enjoyed that much to go as far as episode 80.  However, the further you go beyond that the harder it is to recommend watching.  The plot itself hits a real nose dive around episode 107 that it still hasn't really recovered from(even in the manga up to chapter 497).  I wouldn't even recommend episodes 136-220(the dreaded filler arcs) to my worst enemies.It really makes me sad to think about how much I liked this show back in the early days.The opening and ending themes have been off and on terrible or mediocre.  However, the use of music during the show has been rather effective at times.  As the show drags on, the use of music seems to be getting repetitive though.  This is why I gave it a low score.  It's too bad I can't give a varied score.  Depending on which episodes you talk about, my scores would vary a great deal.

Naruto is a story about a boy named Naruto who wants to become the most powerful ninja in his village. With the help of new comrades and friends, Naruto begins to learn his way of the ninja. Will he become hokage, or will his fate end in dispear?This Anime is exactly like the Manga. There are fillers add in the Anime, but it helps show the relatonships between the ninjas. There is a second part of Naruto called, Naruto Shippuuden. I love it.As of 9/10/09, there are 463 chapters of Naruto. There are 220 episodes, 4 OVAs, and 3 movies for this first part of Naruto!From wikipedia:The series centers on the adventures of Naruto Uzumaki, a young, excitable ninja of Konohagakure. He is accompanied by fellow ninja Sasuke Uchiha, one of the last members in the Uchiha clan; Sakura Haruno, an intelligent and fiery kunoichi; and Kakashi Hatake, the Jōnin sensei of the three. Throughout the series, Naruto encounters numerous foes, including the Sunagakure ninja Gaara, the S-class criminal Orochimaru, and the mysterious criminal organization Akatsuki.From Onemanga:Twelve years before the events at the focus of the series, the nine-tailed demon fox attacked Konohagakure. It was a powerful demon indeed; a single swing of one of its nine tails would raise tsunamis and flatten mountains. It raised chaos and slaughtered many people, until the leader of the Leaf Village - the Fourth Hokage - defeated it by sacrificing his own life to seal the demon inside a newly-born child, whose origins are as yet unknown. That child's name was Naruto Uzumaki.

This is a series beloved by many, both rookies and anime veterans. Very justly so. The story, animation, mood, and music of Naruto are of a quality nearly unmatched in modern anime selection. That is of course, when they are actually following the story.As fantastic as the Naruto story is, this series has more filler than literally any other I have personally seen to date, and the filler is, with remarkably few exceptions, terrible. You watch an incredible plot of growth and perseverance culminate in a tear jerking cathartic release one moment, the next, the cast is inexplicably somewhere different, chasing a foulmouthed ninja duck and its irksome hijinks. The brakes on this train of awesome are far too frequently thrown.tl;dr:Naruto is a competent, thought-provoking, and thrilling series, when they actually stick to the story.

Yep. I know. You see the review title and totally cringe right? You probably want to correct me about it not being about ninjas, but instead shinobis. Yes. You're probably right. Except the fact that ninja = shinobi. :DBut anyway. It's hard to review this anime since it's been a long running one. By the time, you most likely already know if you're a Naruto fan or not. Just remember. If you like Naruto... watch Shippuden too. (I liked it. I like Shippuden even more though ^^)



Naruto is the best anime a teen or older can watch, its so awesome it has everything a action/adventure person without the romance would ever want. Has lots of comedy and humor, lots of fighting, and the coolest ninjas you can ever see. This is a must see for all people who are new to anime or just want to watch awesomeness. Watch Naruto first, then Shippuden, then Boruto: Naruto next generations to get the whole idea, its like a sequel so don't skip anything.

Frankly it's the best show in the genre since Dragon Ball and Dragon Ball Z. If you feel like embarking on an epic adventure with great story, compelling characters and great action, this is for you !The ninja techniques are great, seeing Naruto learn and evolve is exciting and makes you want to watch episodes after episodes without stoping. Plus there is a whole lot a fantastic characters and background stories.The only drawback is that you will want to have a reference website so you can skip the filler-episodes which to me are really a bother and loss of time.Appart from that, just go and watch it !I'm pretty sure you won't regret it !

There's nothing like the original. I started watching Naruto many moons ago, which got me addicted to this series. I love the story plot, the characters, and how they slowly grow throughout the series. You get to learn about many different characters. I'm not one for a lot of action in anime, but this one is unique. I also find the series uplifting, and it shows us that even though we may have had a hard life, you are capable of absolutely anything.

I have to say honestly that if you feel like you hate this show, you probably haven't given it a good enough shot. While Naruto might be a little bit of a pest in the beginning the truth and depth that is revealed is beyond expectations. Of course there is a flow of the seasons and some filler episodes occur, but those season finales almost always have me in tears. Naruto is such a brave and inspiring character, we should all strive to live more like him!

Naruto is the story of battling ninjas, sure, but on the more personal level, it's a story of growing up. At the start, the main three characters, Naruto, Sakura, and Sasuke, are very much children. They go to school, have classes, and are assigned to their very first team as apprentices to a master ninja. Then the story transitions into their learning to be a team and facing conflicts in their local area before moving on to steadily grander threats.Over the course of the approximately five years of the story (some of which are skipped in their entirety), all three struggle to overcome their respective pasts. For Naruto, it is a battle against all that comes with having been a lonely outcast for so long. For Sasuke, it is his inner battle with his need for revenge—to hunt down and kill the one who killed his entire clan. For Sakura, it's dealing with overcoming her feelings of love in order to do what is necessary. It's through facing these internal conflicts—as well as many external ones—that they enter into the realm of adulthood.Better still, their growth toward maturity is always a gradual change and never a light switch. The events and revelations of the manga build on one another to shape the characters—especially when it comes to Sasuke. The main story of Naruto covers everything from life in a ninja school, ninja training, and a ninja tournament to an attack from ninja terrorists, a ninja kidnapping, and a giant ninja war. However, it's outside of the main plot that Naruto does its best work.Free from the constraints of the main story, the side-story flashbacks are dark tales of life before Naruto's generation. The histories of Kakashi, the Fourth Hokage, the First Hokage, the Sannin, and Pain are all excellent little tales that pack more emotional punch than any part of the main plot. These are stories that carry far more in the way of tension and danger as, unlike in the main story, the worst can and often does happen—leaving friendships broken and friends dead.What's even more interesting is how these tales not only flesh out the supporting cast but several also serve as a mirror tale to the lives of Naruto, Sasuke, and Sakura. Many deal with a love triangle of ninjas—a team of two boys and a girl. Some then deal with one of the three going down a dark path. Most include a loving mentor character who takes the three under wing to train them. Through these past tales, we are able to see how badly the relationship between Naruto, Sakura, and Sasuke could get without ever having to—necessarily—take it there.Of course, it's not just the characters in the flashbacks that really shine in Naruto—the supporting cast is also full of awesome characters. There are ninjas that can fly, ninjas that can take over other people's bodies, ninjas that can heal grievous wounds, ninjas that can copy other ninjas' skills, ninjas that can raise the dead, ninjas that can turn into paper, ninjas that can control the sand or water or shadows or insects. Hell, there's even a ninja who is basically a superpowered Bruce Lee. With 700 chapters, there’s time for nearly every single character to be given a distinct personality and background—especially the ones that come into direct conflict with Naruto at one point or another.Unfortunately, these characters are often established and then simply forgotten about as the story once again refocuses on Naruto, Sakura, or Sasuke. This is a bit of a double-edged sword as, more often than not, the side characters are more interesting than the main three—especially more so than Naruto himself.Naruto had its ups and downs over its run. However, what is most important when it comes to making a final judgment on a work is to understand what it was trying to be. In this case, I think it's no stretch to say that Naruto strives to be an exciting, action-filled shonen fighting manga. And in that, it succeeds in grand fashion. It builds a colorful world full of ninjas with unique powers and personalities. It has battle after battle where the fate of our heroes (if not the world) seems in question—leaving us enthralled as we wait to see how, exactly, they come out on top. It also does some darn good storytelling in its character backstory arcs.It is not without its faults—mainly those stemming from its pace, length, and reliance on shonen fighting manga tropes—but in end, if you're looking for a meaty manga full of fighting and adventure, Naruto is for you.

Naruto's plot centers around a knuckle-headed, yet moral ninja named Naruto Uzumaki. Naruto lives in the Hidden Leaf Village(Konoha), but there are also many other Hidden Villages as well! The story is very original and has a few very amusing jokes as well! The plot is thoroughly thought out and creative. Naruto is story of hardship and courage. It has many funny, sad, and touching moments. It is certainly one of my favorite anime ever!P.S. There are many fillers as well, but if you truly love the plot, it will be no problem!

Ive never been so addicted to a television show in my lifetime. I immediately was engaged in the story, the characters, the epic fights, and Narutos growth as the series went on. My only problem was the last 90 episodes or so are filler so id recommend just reading a synopsis, watching maybe the last arc [Totally optional] and jumping straight to shippuden. But other than that, this anime has virtually no flaws and i could almost guarantee it'll be someone you'd greatly enjoy.

At first I was turned away by the age of Naruto and his friends. But then was introduced to every other character and it becomes a great village I want to be apart of. I think it's a perfect anime for anyone to jump into if they are into ninjas. I also love how the characters grow, but also age. Naruto is easily one of my favorite anime series of all time. Would recommend to any casual or serious anime fan.

It's hard to give this show the justice it deserves, so I'll just simply say that it kicks the crud out of anything I've watched! If you're not watching Naruto now, you should definitely start! There's lots to enjoy, and it's guaranteed that you'll get addicted to this show, in fact, you'll get so addicted that if you stop watching it for an extended period of time you will undoubtedly experience severe withdrawal. Get into it, but be warned..... Once you're in, you'll never be able to leave.

Naruto is one of my "hall of fame" series, and a MUST see for everyone.  It is the prelude series to Naruto Shipuden, which is an excellent continuation of the saga founded in Naruto.Three facts that will tempt you to stop watching Naruto, but shouldn't stop you because you will miss out on great content if you do:1.  It starts slow.  I almost lost interest in the series because the opening episodes didn't do it for me.  I'm so glad I stuck it out.  Naruto gets GOOD.  If you find the series slow, I STRONGLY encourage you to stick it out for several episodes.  You will "get into it" as the story begins to unwind.2.  It's not amazing graphically.  The series is high production, as well as shippuden is.  They got to roll one out every week and being able to draw it fast and roll out the story takes higher priority than some other animations out there that specialize in "eye candy".  Naruto is not where you go for stunning drawings, but the storyline and voice acting is excellent.  The series really delivers.3.  The protagonist, Naruto, you may find unlikeable.  I did.  As the series unfolds, I assure you this won't be a problem.  There are plenty of other characters that get lots of screen time for you to enjoy, even if you're not a fan of Naruto himself.  The type of person Naruto changes into may make him more appealing later on.  If you don't like the brat in the orange jumpsuit, that's OK -- there are plenty of things to enjoy about Naruto.I'm giving it a 5. Like I said at the top of my review, its one of my "Hall of Fame" series.  If you can work past the three obstacles I mentioned, I think you will really enjoy Naruto and its amazing story.

This series –all 9 seasons– is the only anime I have watched and read the manga to, it is also the only one that I have watched religiously for many years now, and even at my age of 38 I still love this series.As a professional creative I appreciate the well developed storyline and narrative that gets more solid with each episode, and as the world of Naruto grows within your heart and mind you will find yourself overflowing with admiration for this brat that would be Hokage...which upon viewing all 9 seasons you will naturally gravitate to Naruto Shippuden to quench your thirst.There are great ethical stories and other life lessons within this series, making it a great watch for kids to learn that family and friendship are the most important things one can ever hope to achieve above all in this world.

GREAT character development, especially with Naruto. Naruto has his flaws and past, so he needs to overcome them.Love the concept about trying hard. These ninjas don't always have good genes; they train hard to become the best, even when they fail.Naruto goes through quite an adventure, and he's very likeable, so you just wanna see him do well. There's not much of a focus on antagonists, but the characters have to go through some internal conflicts and ninja battles which show their true colors.BUT:There's a bunch of fillers.

Naruto is absolutely amazing! I was hesitant when I first started watching it, but did so because my husband liked it, but within a couple episodes you get so unbelievably hooked! I've now watched it through a couple times (some arcs more than others ^_^) The music is amazing (in my mind the music from Naruto is much better than Shippuden) and the characters are so complex and well defined. Every time I have a favorite character, something makes me love another even more. The storyline is also amazing, and so well written, so it can be heartrendingly emotional that I cry and then so comedic I laugh for hours. Sometimes the episode storylines get very redundant (repeating scenes from earlier episodes over and over) but as the series is serial I understand it (it must be very different waiting for a new episode each week rather than watching all at once as I prefer). Overall, it's definitely my favorite anime - I love it!

This show is awesome and I love everything about it. It is great to see how much Naruto tries and never gives up. He in a way is an inspiration and shows never to give up and always do the right thing no matter what. Doing the right things all the time can be painful and sometimes really scary but always does more than doing the wrong thing. It shows in all the things naruto does. When he actually listens to kakashi sensei, he does better. when he listens he gets better.

I think over all the story line is great, there were some pretty boring fillers at the end, but in general an amazing series. I learned quite a handful of japanese phrases from this series and that just makes my day. The music is awesome, and the characters are amazing as well. My personal favorite is Kimimaro with his kekkai genkai. The animation was very well done, and I would recommend this title to anyone.

I honestly love this show. There are all sorts of twists that you wouldn't expect. The whole idea of supernatural ninjas just excites me and i wish i could live in Konaha along with the characters. I can relate to the characters and laugh with them, cry with them and hurt with them. There have been times where i have burst out laughing and times when i really did cry.The story line is well written with flash backs to help you remember stuff that happened in the past.Overall this is my favourite anime show!

Naruto is a boy who left his previous village and went to a school in a new village in order to get people's respect. He is funny, sweet, and trust worthy. He is always determined to do something when he says he's going to do it, no matter how long it takes him. While going to an Academy for Ninja's, he meets an amibitious girl named Sakura (who he quickly falls in love with) and a mysterious boy named Sasuke (who he quickly begins to hate automatically). Sakura is a young girl who takes really good care of her long flowing pink hair in order to win Sasuke's heart. Every girl is told that Sasuke only likes girls with long hair so everyone including Sakura is wearing their hair long. Sakura is competing with every girl, that is true enough, but her biggest rival is a girl named Ino who also has long hair but it's blonde. They are always fighting, but the secret that they refuse to admit to is that they are still good friends deep inside their hearts. Sakura is deeply in love with Sasuke and is determined to win his love no matter what. She is also determined to understand Sasuke more, but soon finds that it is hard to do. And this is exactly why Naruto hates him. Sasuke is a boy with kind of long jet black hair and shocking black eyes to match. He gets annoyed easily and is just as competetive as Naruto, though he won't dare admite it. Sasuke has a violent past. His parents are killed in a battle and Sasuke blames his self because of it. Sasuke left his village because he wanted to become stronger than he already is so he can return to his village and avenge his family. Sasuke also has a secret demon power deep inside him that he does not know about until later on their journey, he accidentally uses it and is unable to control the demon within him. But Sakura refuses to think of Sasuke as a demon. Each of them not only learn how to be ninja's, but they also learn more about themselves and each other as well. Through their journey, one of them end up missing. And no one know's if it's for good or not. Which one is it?

I have known about this anime for a long time, and never watched it because i have heard about it from everyone, and I thought " I am not going to watch it, it is to mainstream, but   my brother was watching an episode, and instantly I got hooked.  Everything about it is amazing, even the filler episodes, and the music, story, characters, just everything in general. I love how you are able to feel several emotions while watching this, whether it be happy, suspense, fear, sad, or any other emotion, it really gets you to feel, and for me, an anime that has that ability to do that, is truly amazing.  I binge watched the entire 9 seasons within 3 months, and as I was on the last episode, i was thinking to myself "come on just end already" because I wanted to start Shippuden. A few people will say Naruto is a childish, slow, and boring anime but the majority and myself included will always love this show. Naruto is a pretty great character and watching the original right here preps you for Shippuden, which is even better. Naruto and Sasuke also make for what is probably the best rivalry in anime history which by itself makes the show amazing. As for the filler, yeah it usually sucks so just look up what is and isn't and skip it.

I watched all 220 epsiodes and despite the incredible amount of filler, especially towards the end, I very much enjoyed it all. Overall I enjoyed the characters each having their own unique abilities and the pacing worked pretty well regardless of the filler areas. The filler even added some episodes with more supporting cast for more face time which was great seeing as Naruto was not my most favorite character. Anyways I watched it in roughly 10 weeks breaking up each season with a random anime of my choosing. It was well worth it and I look forward to Part 2.

I use to be a huge fan of this anime and manga, but I've begun to realize different things about this series. It's got a pretty interesting storyline, but it seems to go by much too quickly and there were too many fillers between the first series and Naruto: Shippuden. And typical of a lot of animes, the Characters tend to grow more mature throughout the series, but these characters were much too annoying to begin with and plenty were still a pain in the neck by episode 200. The music wasn't all that impressive, and the anime was average. It was an okay show and it can be somewhat interesting.

Naruto was born the son of Minato Namikaze, the Fourth Hokage, and Kushina Uzumaki. Before his birth, they had decided to name him after the main character in Jiraiya's first book, hoping their son would be as great a ninja as the character was. This made Jiraiya Naruto's godfather. Soon after his birth, however, the Nine-Tailed Demon Fox attacked Konohagakure. To save the village, Minato engaged the Nine-Tails in mortal combat and sealed it into Naruto's body, believing his son would someday have use for it. Minato died afterwards, leaving Naruto to grow up knowing nothing of his parents. He received his mother's last name since Hiruzen Sarutobi, the Third Hokage, felt that it was best that nobody knew he was related to the Fourth Hokage. Before Minato died, he asked that the villagers of Konoha view Naruto as a hero who had helped to stop the Nine-Tails. Few did as he asked, however, instead openly resenting him for containing the monster that had destroyed their home. In light of this, the Third Hokage decreed that nobody should ever speak of the Nine-Tails sealed within Naruto, hoping that their children would not resent him as they did. The children, however, followed their parents' lead, despite not knowing why. Naruto was forced to live confused over why the villagers hated him so, and strived to win their recognition. Iruka Umino would be one of the few exceptions, who was always compassionate to Naruto's plight. For this, Naruto came to view Iruka as the father-figure he never had. PersonalityBefore graduating from the Academy, Naruto had a craving for acknowledgement. During his days as an academy student, Naruto would play pranks all around the village in an attempt to be recognized by its inhabitants. He would also tell everyone who doubted him on a near-constant basis that he would one day become Hokage. As he told Iruka, he wished to achieve this rank in order to be recognized by those around him, and to have the responsibility of defending them. Even after graduating, Naruto was still determined to be recognized, and became the "Number One Loudest, Unpredictable, Hyperactive Knuckleheaded Ninja of Konoha", as described by Kakashi Hatake. As the series progressed, with Naruto making more and more connections with others, his reasons for wanting to become Hokage underwent a change, having less to do with the desire for recognition, and more to do with wanting the strength to protect his home and the people close to him. Naruto's exuberant personality and fiery desire for self-improvement strongly impacts the lives of those around him. At the beginning of the series, Naruto befriended Konohamaru Sarutobi, the grandson of the Third Hokage, and it is through his brief tutelage that Konohamaru learned that the path to success is through plenty of hard work. Kakashi described this as Naruto's "unique power", as he seems to change the world views of everyone he meets, and inspires courage for the future within them. This is most prominently shown when Naruto earned the trust of Nagato, the leader of Akatsuki, and one of the main antagonists of the series. As mentioned above, Naruto is characterized as being hyperactive; he is typically exuberant, easily excitable, impulsive, and suffers from a short attention span. This is supported by Asuma Sarutobi in the 'Fire Temple' arc in the anime, describing Naruto as being the type who doesn't think before acting, similar to Sora. Asuma also identifies Naruto's personality type and fighting style, like Sora's, as being a 'power type'--types that are best suited to 'charging straight in'--and are best effective in battle when sent in first, in the front to 'clear a path' through the enemy's defensive line, making a way in after them for the rest of the team. While raw power is one of his strengthes, Naruto has begun to learn in recent chapters that it is something that he needs to temper with focus in order for it to become truely effective. According to Kakashi, Naruto is someone who learns through his body. Naruto is relatively naive, being slow to understand a jutsu's principles, and often requiring a dumbing-down of an already dumbed-down analogy in order to grasp what is being explained to him. This assumes he is able to keep his attention long enough, as he commonly seeks to change the subject in light of his ignorance, outwardly insisting that he already gets the concept. Though he retains this confidence in himself to great degrees, loudly proclaiming that he will master whatever technique he is learning in a fraction of the usual time, Naruto will not hesitate to ask for help if he needs it. As an extension of his naivety, Naruto has a number of childish traits. His pajamas always include a comical black nightcap with eyes and teeth, and he keeps his money in a chubby, green-frog wallet he affectionately calls "Gama-chan". He almost exclusively eats ramen, and is a frequent customer at the Ichiraku Ramen Bar. He has a natural affinity for perverted ideas and jutsu, something he tends to be reprimanded for by Sakura, and which is only brought to new levels after meeting Jiraiya. He also smiles near-constantly, which, during his childhood, was to mask the sadness of his lonely life. Those who are closest to him are able to recognize when his smile isn't genuine. However, when the situation calls for it, typically when someone dear to him is in trouble, Naruto can be very serious, and will instantly come to their aid. This is most commonly seen in the series through his interactions with his teammates, Sasuke Uchiha and Sakura Haruno. With Sasuke, Naruto views him as a brother, and throughout Part II strives to bring him back to Konoha, despite his willing defection from the village. With Sakura, Naruto has a long-standing crush on her, and will do all in his power to make her happy, even if it is at the expense of his own happiness. Recently, Hinata Hyuga confessed her love for Naruto. He was greatly angered when she was seemingly fatally wounded afterwards, and was relieved to hear that she had survived, but it is unclear whether he now has feelings for her. After talking with his father, defeating Nagato and having a truce with him and Konan, Naruto came to understand the downside of revenge, and desired to stop Sasuke from it even more. Also, Naruto tried to stop the Kumo-nins from exacting their revenge against Sasuke, for this would only create a cycle of hatred.

The reason why I stated this title like and a Star Wars quote it is simple.When people talk about ninjas and the magic that comes within the normal ninja genre of TV show you'd think of those black marshal arts clothes with the black tight eye opening hood over the ninja's head and face, but this turns the game in it's head.For you see the way it does that is how it is shown to the viewer, it is not as simple as throwing down a smoke bomb and there is a ninja after the fact but that trope is still there but it not just blindings and mystic tactics as well.This anime is filled with references to dragonball, normal street wear and real world SWAT gear plus games like snake-toad-slug a eastern version of rock–paper–scissors with wichcraft in the forms of the Ninjutsu, Genjutsu & Taijutsu with the allowance of nature elemental forces to be involved as well with fire, water, earth, wind and lighting commonly found in various Chinese and Japanese cultures.I personally enjoy this even with the filler episodes. Something that has always fascinated me about Naruto is the way it tackles social isolation and the effect it can have on kids' development. Various characters are shown to face difficult emotions due to circumstances they cannot control. However, all three of these characters choose to react to this adversity in different ways. -Naruto becomes the village idiot to use rebelliousness and comedy to mask the pain he feels inside, as the village shuns him for his literal inner demon. -Rock Lee procures insane determination to prove himself to the world to the point where it becomes toxic to his own health, as he cannot use ninjutsu like the other children.-Gaara, facing a similar situation as Naruto, lashes out against the world and refuses to even allow his siblings to reach out to him when they express concern.-Sasuke, despite being beloved by just about everyone for being a cool prodigy, is obsessed with revenge, preventing him from developing bonds with his friends and mentors.-Neji, in a similar vein to Sasuke, obsesses over his lineage, and resents Hinata for the position she was born into.-Hinata, having been entrusted with immense responsibility from birth, lacks the courage and self esteem to be assertive and stand up to Neji.-Sakura, despite being a talented leader, student, and ninja, focuses too much on trivial matters like impressing/surpassing her friend Ino and the distant Sasuke, instead of pursuing her own dreams.As the show progresses, we see how these characters reach out to each other inspire and to overcome their weaknesses. Naruto's greatest strength is his ability to empathize with his peers and rivals. Ultimately, Naruto is about the power of empathy, and how friendship can help almost anyone overcome their deepest of fears.Skip the filler though.

Naruto is one of my favorite animes. It may have started off a bit slow but if picked up as it went on and got better and better. Though it may be lengthy, I would recommend Naruto to anyone. It has great characters with great personalities, quirks, and overall characteristics that make you drawn to certain ones, like Kakashi for example, and make you hate others. There are very few bad things I could say about this Anime. My favorite section of the entire show was the fight between Zabuza and Kakashi. It's the first real fight and one of the best, in my opinion. There are some filler episodes. If they weren't placed at the worst possible places in the seasons, they wouldn't be that bad.

Naruto's got a decent story. It's about love, loss, jealousy, and arrogance. I wouldn't diss it for the world; it's got some strong characters. But the filler really uses those characters for something that isn't so "end-of-the-world" stakes, and as a result, many of the best episodes are found in the filler; if you want to have favorite characters in this show, go through the filler, for sure.The sequel is where most of the plot ends up happening.

At first I thought it was a bit young. But, holy crap! As the characters get older it builds up and blows you away!! TOTALLY, worth watching!!I truly believe this should be mandatory television for American tweens/teenagers. It has ALL the learning lessons and morality that is missing in todays programming!  The depth of the characters and situations go to a level that I've NEVER experienced in American television. As an Adult, I thoroughly enjoyed it! And, you should continue with Shippuden it is EPIC.

I'll admit, I'd been an anime fan for a while before I finally got around to watching Naruto. My main reason for finally watching it was simply to understand all the memes floating around the internet, and I'm really glad I did. I'm in Season 7, and am totally invested. It is a great series! Hilarious and full of interesting action as well as plot... even the filler episodes aren't too bad. (and there are a TON of filler episodes) I can't wait to see where this series goes! (and am even happier that I don't have to wait for anything to be released since it's all already out!)  If you're a fan of Fairy Tail and Bleach, then I think you'll love this series too. Naruto and Natsu are practically the same person.

I've seen a lot of anime throughout the years. I've seen what people call the 'good stuff', I've seen the 'bad stuff'. In time, I realized and accepted that not everyone is going to like something, or dislike it. No matter what the anime (or movie, or book, or game, etc.) it boils down to personal preference. So, how do you know if you'd like something you've never seen but heard so much about? When I first started Naruto, I saw the potential in it. From the first episode, they presented a distinct setting with distinct characters. Sure, archetypes were being followed (the boy dreaming of becoming big, the old grandfatherly figure, the teacher, the rival). The first episode showed emotion and depth to its main character and what he will struggle with, along with the dynamics of his interaction with other characters and their quirks.Cut about ten episodes later, the plot arc currently being followed felt to me like it was not going to matter much to the main story. Some episodes had drawn out battles, and I got that feeling that the anime would be the type where they would go from different area to different area, developing their skills and learning moral lessons and such, but there would be no grand plot, no B story, that tied the series together. I also worried it would fall into mediocrity. Without giving anything away, by the end of that arc (about 19 episodes in), my mind was changed.Having seen all of the series up to the current episodes, I can say at least for myself that at its best Naruto is a deeper anime than some give credit to, and can be quite addicting. A strong focus is on its characters as they develop throughout the series and there are moments of real emotion, tragedy, intensity and even just amusement. It's not perfect, as there are slow times in the series (and the cartoon suffers from tricks to get as many episodes out of the original story as they can), and I won't say everyone will end up liking it but I can say it had unexpectedly become one of my favorite anime.

But that didn't stop me from absolutely loving this anime. It isn't just about baseball; it's about so much more. That being said, the series has taught me a lot about the game that I never really could understand or appreciate before, and I have a deeper respect for it now. I think that in itself is a great compliment you can give to something; where it changes your opinion on what you previously thought was a boring sport.But besides that, what really makes this show is the character development, story, and execution of that story. The quality of animation, music, and directing really makes this series shine. It feels top notch, you really get into each character and become a fan of the team yourself.In the most recent episodes, the series has really shown itself to go far beyond what I had ever expected; and for that I will say this is now a must watch series. You are going to have a lot of feels watching these characters grow, and you'll never expect where things turn out.I'm excited to see where the series goes, and I can't wait for the new episode each week. It has me totally hooked. I highly recommend checking this out, sports fan or not.

Fantastic anime, but more importantly one of the most accurate depictions of baseball in any media I've watched.  Having played on a high level American high school baseball team in the past, I'm shocked at how closely Seido's practices (especially all of the running and sprinting) mirror what our team used to do in high school.  Even more importantly, as a former pitcher for many years, I'm incredibly happy with the show's depiction of the pitcher-catcher battery, and the strategic mindset.  The pitcher-catcher battle with the batter is truly what makes baseball one of the most intense sports to play.  Can't wait to the see this show continue to play out!  As of episode 18, it's my favorite sports anime of all time!  Sawamura's gonna need to learn a change-up pretty soon though, haha.

Well when I started this anime, which was when it was 8 episodes in, I didn't expect much. Just this baseball anime with cool animation. I have never been so wrong in my life. This anime is thrilling, competitive, and non-stop (baseball) action! Each week I am left with despair, however, as I must wait for the next episode for an ENTIRE WEEK. Pretty painful. Regardless, I recommend this anime to everyone, baseball fan or not, sports anime fan or not. You will definitely enjoy it, or at least get a good laugh at Sawamura's (the main character) stupidity.

This series starts off a little slowly and a bit differently from your typical sports anime, but the excitement and competition ramp up like crazy soon enough! What sets "Daiya no Ace" apart from other baseball anime is that, usually, the heroes are a small underdog team that takes down the big teams that dominate Koushien. But this time, DnA is about one of those big, elite teams, and the excitement comes from the competition within the team to get one of the 9 spots on the first-string starting team. This allows for an unprecedented level of individual rivalry (which, c'mon, is the best part of sports anime~). Our hero Sawamura is a diamond-in-the-rough pitcher with a lot of promise but no proper training. He is lured away from his close-knit (if bumbling) team out in the countryside to Seido High's elite baseball team by the charismatic prodigy catcher Miyuki, whose insightful strategies and ability to draw out pitchers' potential have made him the starting catcher on the first-string after only one year on the team. Miyuki sees massive potential in Sawamura and it seems a perfect battery is on its way to being formed--until the appearance of another first-year pitcher, Furuya, whose quiet personality belies a monstrous strength. For years, Furuya's pitches have been so powerful that no catcher has been able to catch them (which is why no one had heard of Furuya's insane ability--he was never allowed to play since no one could catch his pitches). He came all the way to Seido from Hokkaido in the hopes that he'd finally meet a catcher who could catch his pitches and Miyuki does not disappoint. As a result, our two talented first-year pitchers are in competition for their catcher, in addition to facing the many challenges (hazing, politics, traditions, etc) of breaking in to such an elite, historied team. That said, the high energy, comedy, rich character drama, and Sawamura's infectious optimism and disarming kindness make this a very watchable journey, with many interesting characters and some very exciting matches even within the first 13 episodes. Definitely worth the watch, whether you're a sports anime fan or general shonen anime fan. Check it out!

Watch this anime.It's been since the last season ended and I'm hazy on character names and plot specifics.... But I remember all the emotions and the character's personalities/abilities. The best thing about sports anime is that it can often present grounded human ability. But's it's still anime, so it has creative ways for you to enjoy, through metaphor, how extraordinary these "for-granted" human-honed skills are. That, plus the fleshing out of a cast that's worth caring about over time... sunk me. Good anime. It's the reason I'll be continuing to look into and discover more sports anime. Wouldn't have hopped on Hinomaru Sumo immediately(thank God I did) if it weren't for this.

I'm an MLB fan and I find this anime a good reflection of Japanese baseball compared to Major. It's more realistic to see an Eijun than Goro in the MLB. Anyway, as I watch the anime in progress, I appreciate how the role of other players are shown. In MLB or baseball in general, pitchers wont be able to do many feats without the support of his fielders. Take for example Yadi Molina (StL) and Buster Posey (SF), the success of their pitchers are based on their game calls and pitch out plays. Miyuki Kazuya sure does a good job drawing out all the pitchers' potentials while on the mound. The superb plays of the seniors in Seidoh is a classic example of paid off hard work. All players entering MLB are outstanding players in the minors yet they had to go through secondary priority, lots of training, losses, injuries and boos before earning their rightful places as starting member. MC Eijun Sawamura had to go through a lot before earning his place and it takes time, especially that he has a formidable rival within his team. Of course, I would understand coach kataoka not making him as starter because his role doesn't fit him currently. Mariano Rivera is one one of Yankees all time best pitchers, not as a starter but a closer. With over 50 episodes and over 390 chapters, it may seem that the mangaka is making Eijun suffer so much. I'm not sure about the author's intention but I would be very surprised if he becomes the ace given the fact that he's still polishing his skills and there are Furuya and Kawakami who can pitch like him. The take for example Adam wainwright, during his minors, he was always the starter. When he stepped up in the big leagues, he had to go through being reliever, closer then eventually the ace. It took him at least 7 years before he Became the Ace of Cardinals. Of course, HS baseball is much shorter, but given only five months in the entire timeline of the manga, it is but proper that Eijun has his current order as mid reliever. If he were real, he needs another six full months to master his signature pitches. Well, their former ace Tanba took three years and two potential pitchers to compete before he finally understand what is meant to be an ace.BUT HE IS THE MAIN CHARACTER! Yeah obviously, but I don't want to watch another Goro Shigeno in a different anime. We're done with the "only pitcher in team" story-line. Hey, I love Major and have watched it until the end. Let's be patient with Eijun and try to study how baseball really works, you will appreciate DnA more than ever.Here's more to appreciate in this series:Baseball terms and plays both offensive and defensive, it's worth researching.Individual stories of supporting charactersCollective skills and talents properly sorted to players not only of Seidoh but also of their opponents.The feels of each team's struggles to win.OSTsIndividual talents such as Miyuki Kazuya, Mei Narumiya, Yuki Tetsuya, Kominato Haruichi, and many more.Hey, DnA is also promoting Mizuno brand.

Just as a note, I'm writing this review based off season 1 and the first 33 episodes of season 2.This series is, overall, an enjoyable watch--especially the 1st season. The characters are lovable, the animation is great--what's not to love? The second season doesn't start off bad, either. Sawamura--the protagonist--ends up suffering from a little bit of a psychological struggle after an accident messes with his energetic self-confidence. Throw in a new, (boarder-line) malicious coach only focused on results, and you see how the protagonist's future on the team becomes uncertain. This seems like the moment the series would really be picking up--only, it's around here that you start to see the protagonist being phased out.Then, episode 11 of Season 2 concludes--and the show seems to suddenly leave its protagonist behind for 22 episodes, focusing instead on the less developed and somewhat flat "rival" Furuya while Sawamura just makes cameo appearances (even the original team mates, for the most part, seem to forget the protagonist as anything other than a loud cheerleader). Furuya works somewhat well as a little developed supporting character. We don't know much about him since we know little to nothing of his past and he rarely ever talks. In fact, even when we're allowed into his thoughts, he rarely expresses anything except for the silent but raging desire to want to be ace. After 30 episodes of season 2 (on top of 75 episodes of season 1)--we still don't know enough about him for most people to care WHY he wants to be the ace of the team or have any sort of deep emotional connection to his character. More obscure pitchers with fewer scenes on rival teams manage to be more empathetic than him. So, Furuya starts to feel like an "insert generic, moody, and undeveloped rival here" sort of character with the added twist of making that character the fill-in protagonist for a large part of Season 2.When Sawamura finally does make his appearance again, those watching the anime feel second-hand embarrassment for him since, in usual form--he flops. He's the most nerfed protagonist I've seen--especially considering how big a deal they made about his potential and raw talent in the first few episodes of season 1.Now, that being said, I have no problem with main characters being the underdog. I don't mind seeing them struggle to climb up. I even don't have a problem if the protagonists fail to meet their goals entirely as they envisioned them. But, at the end of the day, I still want the protagonist to be the protagonist. I want to see THEIR struggles and how THEY are tackling those problems to grow, or how THEY ultimately fail (that's what it means to be the protagonist--to be the character experiencing the conflict).  I don't want to see the protagonist in 5 second intervals in the background, cheering and warming up for over 5 months-worth of episodes only to see him flop as-per-usual when finally getting a chance to shine.Still, I feel like this is probably due to somewhat awkward pacing of the anime. So, I plan to keep watching, because eventually they're bound to get back around to the protagonist's plot-progression in the story. Right?

In a genre that has recently been undergoing an evolution with the likes of Baby Steps and Kuroko no Basuke I find it very difficult to recommend Ace of the Diamond. If there was a book explaining in step-by-step detail how to make a sports anime AotD would be following it to a ‘T’. For this reason it’s still watchable, it doesn’t do anything grievously wrong but it also doesn’t do a single thing different from every other sports anime before it.We’ve got our bog standard underdogs, facing our generic antagonists, and going through the usual ups-and-downs as they exceed all odds to come out on top. Now of course even the best sports anime follow this formula but they tend to throw something in to differentiate themselves from the pack. Whether that be unique character traits, special abilities, or perhaps even parts of the show that don’t focus completely on sports and give us reasons behind the sports to like there characters. But there’s none of that here, every single character is as cliché as they get, as are the antics they find themselves in.The animation is of a decent level but not enough to make up for the utter banality of it all. The only reason I can imagine choosing it over superior examples is if you have a serious love for baseball over the other sports on offer, but if you come to the sports genre for the tension and break from the typical epic sword battles of other anime that permeates the genre there are far better choices to pick from.All the same if you do love baseball or have simply exhausted your other options you could do worse than Ace of the Diamond, but don’t expect to find anything special.

After watching this anime i have become inspired to become a baseball player, you might think this is a joke but i was actually really moved by this anime, If you ever see the name Andy weir on the billboards it means i made it. only problem is i want to be a pitcher but im 5'5", what ever that wont stop me, ill practice 100 times harder to make up for my short height. what im trying to get at is that this is an absolutely fantastic anime.

Ace of the Diamond is the best baseball anime I've ever seen, hands down (even including Oofuri, if only slightly). It doesn't fall into the traps of so many other sports anime - which is, either 1) only focusing on the main character, shafting the other members of the team, and some dumbass rival; or 2) repeating the trope of a superstar lone player reviving a underdog team and taking them to nationals. It's an anime about a boy who doesn't quite know what he's getting into, but is led by other members of a team who all equally love the sport. It's about growing up without any of the stupid pitfalls and traps of other sports anime. Ace of the Diamond's really strong point is in its varied cast of characters - they're all very individualized, and it really makes you bond with the team and want to root for them. This anime gets me excited like no other.

An interesting anime that draws me into baseball which i don't particularly like! There are many characters in this show, which is not surprising since baseball is a major team sport. Pros:Loyalty, teamwork, trust, courage are common themes in the show. It is also rather realistic and easy to connect w/ the the characters. Despite the vast number of characters, I feel like each are given a good amount of screen time+ depth and are likable. Cons: The only exception (development wise), unfortunately, is our main character. I feel like he is not given enough screen time which is a shame since he IS the main character. He seems to be fading a little and I wish more time is spent on HIS growth :/  (so I hesitate over a 4 or 5 star). I hope this changes as more episodes come in.  Other than that, I adore this show so check it out!

Ace of Diamond, an anime produced by Production I.G (Kuroko no Basket) & Madhouse (Hajime no Ippo). Both of these animation companies are very knowledgeable in the sports genre as seen in their previous titles. This eventually lead to the creation of this amazing show. This series isn't rushed, it's paced very well and supported by amazing animation. There are a wide variety of characters to enjoy, each is given a certain amount of time to develop. The comedy in this show is just amazing, I found my self laughing almost every episode. I don't know how long this anime will air for but i've heard rumors that it will air for 52 episodes? I guess we'll find out soon. Anyway, this anime is an amazing sports anime to watch, it has great animation, story, OSTs and Openings. I would rate it 10/10 and mark it as a much watch!

So I really love this anime. I really like sports anime, and Diamond no ace is just spectacular. The story is, yes about baseball, (TBH i don't like sports in general and don't like to watch baseball games) But Diamond no ace is great at capturing the audience. As a person who hates baseball this anime has made me care more. The games are long, but i felt like if i skipped anything, i felt empty and i HAD to watch the whole game.The characters, let me say are awesome. Their personalities are each unique and they all have their own story but bond as a team. However, I felt like could have been beter as was just never as good as he wanted to be. I feel that Sawamura should have been better and i wish for him the best. BUT I still feel as though he was amazing in his own way. His personality as determined but still an idiot (by anime standards). The other characters, lets me just say ARE SO AWESOME TOO!!!! (Especially Miyuki XD) Its got a lot of humor but also is serious and pretty emotional.

This is about the Act II. The animation feels so bad compared to the Act I. Its not like it was awesome or something before, but important scenes were animated nicely. Now the characters dont even open their mouth properly while talking, or we only see their backs most of the time or some background shot while they are talking. I miss the 'acting' by the characters. Now they don't show much facial expressions. And so many white screens for the background!! Many more still shots than in the previous seasons. I miss the 'movement'. Like we dont see much of the whole 'winding up' part when Sawamura's pitching, just a close-up of him throwing, which is repeated for all his pitches. Its just manga images colored!!Why is there narration all the time? I hate that. Hasn't the character Yuuki left for university? Why is he narrating like an oracle or something. There was no narration in Act I. Instead of using characters to talk or act, they just use the narrator!!I keep rewatching Act I to feel the movement or see proper acting, and then I get bored or tired because I want to see the new scenes in Act II, but those are disappointing. So now I am stuck!!!!

I had my hesitations despite some recommendations to watch this show. However, I am so glad that I picked it up because it was exhilarating and rewarding. I am so impressed with the animation, humor, and camaraderie in this show. They did a great job bringing out emotions and being able to have so many characters play such an important role. I highly suggest watching this show! It seems like it will be a while before a third season could be released, but I really want it and will continue to watch this. This show has also made me want to start reading the manga, which isn't something that I do, just to continue on with this story. 10/10 would absolutely recommend.

I made a video: https://youtu.be/zPZvl4K0P-oVideo Script:Ace of the Diamond (8/10): Huzzah for rating systems, if you want to know more about my luxurious rating system check the description down below. Now it is about time I sprinted toe first into this review.I finally did it, I made it through all 126 episodes of Ace of the Diamond!
