It is, by far, not the best thing I've ever seen, the art-style is awful and I really wish they worked on this anime more thoroughly as the animation quality isn't the greatest either. On a good note, however, I did enjoy watching it even though I had read the manga and the first volume of the Light Novel. This show is just "OK".

First and foremost I have read the novels, and I have read the manga.I am not 100% up to date on either, nor will I ever strive to be.  The story itself is cute, entertaining, fluffy, and good for a way to relax.  These are the kinds of stories you use to unwind and just smile.To that end the Anime succeeds, it is fluffy enough to bring a smile to my face.However for those who wanted to see an anime adaptation of the source material this is not that.  This is one of the most butchered translations I've seen, another victim alongside Danmachi and many others.  Entire story arcs, characters, and so on are abandoned or ignored in favor of a faster paced and streamlined story.This anime is not for the fans of the material, and the fans of this anime will be shellshocked when they try to read the source.

日本に住んだ後、私はこのアニメシリーズについて次の結論に達しました。 1.この物語の主人公が人生で有意義で興味深いことをしている限り、このアニメシリーズのオリジナルマンガがどのように進んだかは本当に重要ですか？ 2.私は個人的に、日本の女性は男性の欲求を満たすために存在する物のように扱われていると感じています。このアニメシリーズは、日本の男女間の不平等な状態に何らかの形で挑戦する可能性があるため、重要だと思います。 3.このシリーズの主な女性主人公は、日本では非常に知能があり、能力の低い女子高生以上のことをすることが嫌いだったので、平均になりたいと思っています。その後、彼女は別の世界で生まれ変わり、再び平均以上の能力を持ちます。たぶん、このアニメシリーズは、野心的であることは良いことであり、意図的に他人を傷つける目的ではない限り、人間はトップに登ろうとすることをやめてはならないことを日本の女の子に教えるでしょう。おそらく、この女の子は、他の人が特別であることを意図的に避け、彼女を追放することを決めないなら、平均を上回っていても快適です。このアニメシリーズが本当に面白いと判断し、ポイントを長く価値があるものにするかどうかは、時間だけがわかります。それか、それとも同じ間抜けな、愚かな、不適切な性的ジョークと、権力を持つ女性が怖いという決まり文句に頼るでしょう。

There's nothing particularly innovative here. Not that it's a bad show by any means because of it. The famous truck hits the protagonist, and they are transported to the fantasy medieval world. The main difference is that our protagonist is a girl and is incredibly self-aware of what's happened (given how she was literally BORN into the new world and has grown up there, albeit retaining memories of her past self.) There's a quality amount of Kawaii and some wall breaking in reference to our world, with humor that works more often than it doesn't (CATCHPHRASES). In a world saturated by shows of this nature, you could do a lot worse, but I doubt INCREDIBLY LONG TITLE will endure beyond the next season or two in memory. Worth a watch if you'd like something light and amusing.

I find this more similarly in the vein of reincarnated as a slime. The protag is quickly developing and it doesn't seem like it'll be likely caught in the forever a young girl trap. The focus quickly shifts to the building of the party and party members, and I think this has some really good potential. The first episode is slightly rough and doesn't seem like it's going anywhere good. Solid 3 episode rule on this one.

I haven't read the novels and don't plan on reading them at all actually, and I saw another review saying how different they are to each other, but I still like this. It's got some good meta jokes and shots; the action is pretty satisfying. It's a welcome change to have the main character of an isekai female since there are so many male ones. Also worth noting that the "animal familiar" that mile has doesn't have an annoying voice unlike GRANBLUE FANTASY. It didn't really feel cringe but, the MC is nervous almost all the time and shows off her power without thinking at all, contradicting how she wants to be normal. Good show so far, only hope is that it gets a little less humorous and more... purposeful.

First off i am not a big LN/manga reader, i hope to get into more in the future but, right now my brain is fried with my college texts. With that being said, i'm coming at this from a purely anime perspective. Usually, when i see titles like this i tend to brows over them even when i'm caught up with my current anime and need something else to watch. But, I've been getting really desperate so i barely waited tell this title had at least 3 episodes out and decided to watch it (in my opinion three episodes is just the right amount to really get a feel for the show). I can honestly say out of all the second rate anime that I've had to pain through just to wait for a new goodie to come out, that this anime here genuinely caught my attention and doesn't deserve to be roped in with the rest. I laughed, i smiled, and it killed an hour of my time unwinding at the days end before i even knew it was gone. i'll definitely keep watching this anime.

. . . hardcore fans of the original work probably won't like it.This is definitely an adaptation that is meant to get us to a story arc. They didn't spend much time on Mile's backstory and left out a lot, which I thought set up the character relationships really well. I can't speak much to the novel, but I have read the manga and I feel that they could have easily done the manga's version of events and it would have fit into the first three episodes. As it is now, I feel like it somewhat changes the genre to have done the first three episodes as they have. It feels like it is going to be much more parody and slapstick than character driven action comedy.That said, I actually like what they did in the anime and I liked their approach. The first episode needs to go off like a bang and this first episode gets right to the point, i.e. she's super strong, a ditz, wants to be normal, and is going to be in a party. Now I am hoping that the first three episodes are building to a story arc and that it won't continue to be an episodic slap stick fest. Just because I like how they did act one, doesn't mean that that is a sustainable pace. It needs more meat on the bone, but I get why they went the direction they did and I was thoroughly entertained.

I haven't read the light novel for this show, but I love the manga.  As someone who was looking forward to one of his favorite manga being adapted, I am going to be very biased in my opinion of this anime.That said, in just two episodes, they have made it very clear that they do not care about the source material at all.  Everything that made the manga stand out was rewritten and replaced with the usual tasteless garbage.  The stakes are gone, characters have been rewritten, dramatic scenes have literally been turned into bad jokes, and it's seriously just on episode 2.  I have no hope for this anime, and it makes me sad to see something so good turned into just another generic cgdct show.

Short version: if you're coming in from the light novels or manga, lower your expectations, but still give it a shot.So I'm another one coming from the light novels and manga prior to seeing this. I'm still looking forward to watching it unfold, but I was disappointed with the first episode. My best friend and I watched the first episode since I've been recommending the series ever since I stumbled on it. She just kind of tuned out on her phone because she felt it wasn't very engaging, and I can't say she was wrong. The animation itself was pretty, but we didn't really see much beside Mile wandering the city.I'll only really comment on one change: The addition of Nano-chan as a visual representation of the nanomachines was jarring, as well as completely necessary. You kind of need that in visual media. It's why ghosts are often transparent instead of invisible to the viewer, even when the characters can't see them. I like the floating robot design of the manga, but Nano-chan is also cute, and so I can forgive it.As for general commentary... We don't really get a feel for any of their personalities, and the initial plot is similar to something that happens later in the series. Enough so that it feels like it will either rob the later story of any tension by making it feel rehashed, or the anime will cut out a really good character development story for the crew to avoid that feeling. Neither option is terribly appealing.Still, as I noted originally, this is coming from a person who really enjoys the source material. If it were a pilot episode of something I'd never heard of, I might have been more invested in seeing how it played out. Objectively, the story shown isn't what I was looking forward to seeing, so of course I'm disappointed. It's entirely possible that they will take it in a direction that I get just as excited about, or find a way to get it back on the same track the author took in the LN. The manga also cuts ahead to about the same point as the end of the first episode after an intro chapter, so I don't feel this is an unreasonable expectation.

I loved the books, a nice simple life which feels more like flavor of the week. Its never been a fantastic series looking at it objectively, but I do enjoy it a lot. That said, I do have some gripes with the way this first episode went. It was an entirely anime orginal entry, and while at first I disliked that, over all I feel like as a good introduction it is better for them to start here, then at the actual beginning. Ep 1 does not cover book 1, but instead starts around the time book 2 happens. Which to be quite honest is when the story started to get more focused. Book 1 was a mess of a book with no clear indication of what the author wanted, they even admitted as such in the afterword of the book. That said, the anime adaption is certainly not without the flaws. I feel like some of the injections of exposition, least in EP1, are rather spontanious. The first one made sense placement wise, but the second does not. As well having her reveal how powerful she is in Ep1, it largely goes against her character in those early days where she does everything she can to avoid large displays of power. Since she actively wants to apper normal even when she got angry in the books. So while its comedic, I feel it took away a little of the suspense. Another thing that will bother me till the end of days is their depiction of the Nanomachines. In the books, far as I remember, the nanomachines had no form. It was more so just a voice she talked to. While I understand why they gave the nanomachines a form, the end design honestly looks like they were trying too hard to give her a cute mascot companion when Milie is supposed to be the mascot of the series. Over all, personal Bias would give the books a 8 or 9 out of 10. Anime adaption I give a 7 or 8 out of 10 currently. Objectively though, as I know this series flaws, I would have to say the average person would probably give it a 6 out of 10.

Im sure the manga or Light Novel was much better, but this is so average and flat in so many ways. The delivery of world building is so terribly organized and explained where your wondering what is happening and then explained like 5 min later, the concept is a decent idea but the delivery on the premise and all is pretty lack luster. The art is alright, but the background, the character design, their personalities, everything is just so mediocre and unappealing. Its a 3* personally at best, but I give it a two because for someone whose usually easily entertained, this felt more like a chore then relaxing to watch. Just dont do it, move on, when you see a CGI scene is already a bad look on anime typically, but when its in the first 30 seconds, you should know better and turn away.

Only one episode available at time this is written. In all categories; artwork, music, character design, story, cuteness, comedy, voice acting, in every way not special. OTOH you won't be offended. Definitely you can find something better to watch. If you just want to kill some time watching something light then it's okay.I would give it two and a half stars but I'll round down for this one to just two stars.

In a market with an over abundence of OP Isekai main characters this anime brings a lot of comedy and even some feels along the journey. It would have been nice to get more story from the manga translated over to the anime but the characters back stories are very well laid out and they all get plenty of character development along the way. As comical as the entire show it, it does a great job sowing in serious undertones. While most of the show focuses on slice of life stuff, the finale leaves the show in a "playtime is over" mode. While I wouldn't go as far as to say I was disappointed with the last episode, it felt rushed. It felt like they missed some great opportunities to include more plot from the manga and choreograph a better final battle. Had the finale not felt rushed I definitely would have rated this anime 5 stars. I looked forward every week for this show and I hope it gets a second season!

From the standpoint of this being an anime, the animation is good, the characters are cute, the opening is fun, but the story is only loosely based on the source material. It has a lot of filler for some reason, and for a 12 episode season that seems...bad.From the standpoint of this being an adaptation of a very good light novel, it fails horribly.I've read the light novel, and I've read what there is of the manga, and the anime does a poor job of adapting either of them. For starters, the entire plot of the first episode is made up. It's not in the LN or the Manga. There are filler episodes that don't need to exist when there's perfectly usable content to use instead. Makes no sense.SPOILERS FOLLOW: some of this is covered in the first couple episodes and some of it is stuff that's covered later in the anime very briefly.For starters, the anime begins around chapter 6 of the first volume of the LN. The manga starts around the same place, and fills in the backstory later, so I can sort of forgive that. The skipped chapters include the first arc of the story where Mile is still using her original name, and is at a normal school. Her immense power is found out, she flees the country, and decides to join the Hunter's Guild. Due to a mistake while joining the guild, Mile starts as an F rank, when she should have started at a C or B rank. Guild rules state that you cannot skip ranks once registered, and so Mile would have to spend years on years working her way up the ranks. Instead, they decide to send her to a special prep school for hunters that's supposed to do in six months what would normally take years of work with the guild, and guarantees a D rank upon exiting, with the potential for C rank. That is how Mile gets to where she is at the start of the anime.The little girl at the Inn in episode 1 is a character from the LN, but she's not part of any huge story beats like she is in the anime. She has some screen time in the books (page time?), but she's never involved in any huge stuff. The entire plot of going off looking for her, people kidnapping kids, and meeting her three roommates before going to the hunter school is made up for the anime. In the LN, Mile meets the other three girls for the first time at the prep school when they find they're all in the same room together. The group of "bad guys" and their leader is made up. In fact, the light novel doesn't even have any type of real villain in the first volume, it's just Mile and friends at school.Those "villains" are also my biggest issue with the first part of the anime. They're completely made up. It's just adding conflict to a story that doesn't need it. Also, the leader is some kind of creepy lolicon pedophile, which is such a weird thing to completely fabricate for a series that doesn't need something like that.Later episodes of the anime seem to have a lot of filler content that wasn't in the novels. I can understand skipping over stuff if you want to spend your time telling other parts of the story, but if you're skipping over actual source material to make up your own stuff, you're no longer adapting a story, you're writing fan fiction. There is absolutely no reason to have filler episodes in a 12 episode series, especially when you skip HUGE parts of the source material to put them in.In my original review, I said that the anime is fine in its own way, but now that it's over I can say that overall, as an anime, it's meh. Even if you ignore the fact it's based off a previous work, the added filler at inappropriate times makes it seem like they weren't really sure what to do next, or how to transition to the next story arc. The filler stuff felt out of place. Knowing that this is based off of something, and that it barely follows it at all, kind of sucks. It makes the filler episodes even more frustrating, because they already have everything they need to tell the story, but instead decide to make something else up, something far less interesting. All I'm saying is, for a trailer that touted how many page views the web novel got, and how many copies the light novels sold, you would think they would at least TRY to follow the story. What makes it worse, is that this season also had an adaptation of a story called "Ascendance of a Bookworm". That adaptation is incredibly well done, and it makes me kind of sad that this series didn't get the same treatment.Anyway, as far as story accuracy goes... the names are the same, so they get points for that I guess. It gets a 2/5 because the opening is good, and the animation is nice. It's a really bad adaptation of a really good story, and I highly recommend the light novels to anyone who's interested.

The original story this is based on is.. okay. It's just another Isekai, after all. It has interesting points, but maybe I'm just burned out on the genre.The anime adaption here though is significantly worse than what I'd already consider a B-grade story.The animation itself is not great, and the studio chose to cut out a lot of stuff, add in a lot of new plot and dialogue that wasn't all that well done, and rearrange a bunch of other stuff.At first my thought was that they may have done this to fit more of the story into a 12 episode run, but then after the second episode I realized that, if you ignore the disjointed starting point they chose, it actually makes up more stuff that wasn't originally there than it takes away. Basically the entire first episode was non-canon, and that's a lot of time wasted if their aim is to get through it quickly.Just taken on its own merits, my main issues would be the poor animation, and the strangely disjointed and poorly paced plot (which happens because it is, in fact, disjointed. They took a bunch of stuff from different parts of the story, moved it around and clumsily mashed it together).A lot of stuff is VERY poorly explained in the story as well, if at all.

Good:- Cute designs- Smooth animation- HumourBad:- Trope-filled- Genre-aware / breaking the fourth wall narration (if your name isn't Deadpool, just don't)- OP MCAs for me,- Yes, I'm hooked on it- This is after episode 1- YMMVSpoiler Alert! Click to show or hideShe's not average (aka 'mean', below), which has a formal definition in maths.  We may have to come up with a different term, such as 'midpoint', to explain how her OP power level is halfway between the level-0 of an NPC and level-max of the dragon, but it's not the average of the power levels. Terms to indicate some mathematically significant terms in a range are:- Mean: sum all values, divide by number of samples- Median: sort all values, then take the one in the middle of the row.- Mode: group all values, select the value that occurs most frequentlyI am addicted to the cuteness of this show, but that one bit of dialog makes my maths makes me want to scream.

So, as many others have said, this doesn't follow the books at all. It skips over, summarizes, or completely ignores the first book of the series which is very important for building Mile's character and explaining why she decides to become an adventurer. It ignores how these four characters actually meet and become friends (ie. they don't meet before becoming roommates). It's very strange... especially the inclusion of an actual mascot character to represent nano-machines. To sell plushies I guess? I'm not going to give the series 1 or 2 stars for being so divergent from the source material, as I did enjoy the episode, but I also am concerned about what that might mean for the rest of the series. To be clear, I LOVE the light novels (one of my favorite LN series in print now). I just hope this series does them justice.

I haven't read the light novel and honestly I liked the first episode but I did notice that the MC felt a little loosely put together and that the cat thing was super out of place and seemed like a cheap attempt at a mascot. I found out from other reviews that a significant amount of the books have been removed from the the beginning of the series and that the cat thing is something the anime made up which makes me expect that will go down hill quickly.

I have read the light novels and mangas and yes the anime starts at around book 3 and skipped past the first 2 books and none of the scenes in the first episode took place but I'm looking forward to seeing how this pans out as an anime. In the light novels, none of the fights and action stuff really took place until book 3, so I'm hoping the reason they skipped this far ahead is to skip the slow start to the series and get into the action and just use flashbacks to slowly fill in miles past. Hopefully, it gets better with the next episodes.

First episode review:Where do I start? This show is the definition of 'mediocre isekai' nothing (and I truly do mean nothing) stands out about it so far. The main character isn't even given proper introduction in to the world, in fact we don't know how long she's even been there for as it mentions something about "12 years" but fails to elaborate any more than that. The plot is best summed up as: the plot holes in this show are so deep they make The Mariana Trench look like a pothole on the sidewalk. I seriously do not believe they could've made the plot more nonsensical than they did, and have explained less than they did. The first episode of an isekai [should] follow the general guideline of explaining basic rules of the new world, explaining in fairly good detail how the character(s) got there, and what their initial reactions to their newfound environment are. Needless to say, this show utterly fails in all three of those areas, and leaves the viewer with more questions than answers, but not in a good way. All in all, 4/10, wouldn't recommend so far. However, I'll update this review at the show's conclusion to give a better more solidified review.

They start the anime the same way they started the manga which is by skipping the entirety of the first arc, which sets the tone of why she wants to be "normal" and why she ran away from her home country and all the relationships that she has built up. Then it adds in this crappy thing about those kidnappers tarnishing what would have been a cool B rank adventure team. they even leave out an important character that mile trains to make herself seem more normal. If you have read the LN i suggest skipping this but if you haven't there might be some redemption somewhere in this show but my bias will most likely forever cloud my vision in seeing it.

What makes this story so special for me is the respect that it pays the other world characters.  It's relatively easy to find a story of this type where the reincarnated Japanese brings civilization to a medieval fantasy world.  In those stories, everyone in the world lacks the common sense of an everyday modern citizen and it's really just about the ego trip.  Much of what we know from our lives wouldn't apply in a fantasy world, and it's interesting to see a character be humbled by that.  All the characters are good at what they do, and decades of life experience can't be trumped by someone who's seen a documentary once.  I also enjoy the way that after reincarnating into a child's body, the main character often acts like a child.  She fully assumes her new role, instead of just fulfilling wishes from her previous life.However, the anime is a little lower budget than I was hoping.  If technical quality is important to you, this title is only average.  Its strengths lie elsewhere.  I hope that after watching you are interested in the light novel or manga.

Hey, you like books? Well, this is the Animu for U. They got books, they got reading and most of all they got friendship and at da end of da day, that's all that matters. You know I remember thinking back to my youth of anime watching and I can only remember like one anime that had books, and that was the one about a grown man pretending to be in high school. He hung out with a baby with blonde hair, Zach bell I think it was called. That show was a fever dream. Now this anime is only a little bit of a fever dream and thats why I give Bookworm and the bois 5 star.

Alright yes, it is another isekai in the torrent of isekais, the character animation is meh, the voice acting is passable, and the smiles... *shiver*… But what this anime lacks in production value, it more than makes up for in originality. While I said it was an isekai, it is far from your typical power fantasy isekai that you can find just about anywhere, instead going for slice of life anime with a character who is the opposite of overpowered. Instead of the grand adventure to do good, it's all about making books and enjoying life with friends. Plus, while the character animation is on the poorer side, the background art is really good and emulates a lived in medieval town decently well. If you're done with isekai by now, don't worry, this is not THAT kind of isekai.

I will come back and edit this and re-rate it as the series continues but, so far, it's very promising.Myne is an interesting character, the premise of a world without books except for the rich  is completely believable, and the people in it are much more than just one-dimensional -- so not the usual isekai series.The animation is lovely, the world building is well done and quite detailed and the OP is still stuck in my head.Overall, I enjoyed the first episode and am dying to see where it goes next.

I was so disappointed to see yet another isekai anime, but 3 ep in, so far so good. It doesn't look like your typical isekai anime. It's about young woman who loves books and is devastated to be isekai'd into a world without any, and as an adorable frail little girl there isn't much she can do about it yet. As a huge book lover this has my heart so far and I completely understand her passion. I'm excited for this anime every week. The story is engaging, wholesome, and I care about the main character.

So what kind of isekai is this? Most would say it's nothing like a normal isekai, but I say that both is and isn't true at the same time. The protagonist is in the abnormal role of being an isekai character reincarnated into a fantasy world and living a relatively normal life in a normal household in a mostly normal medieval city. The protagonist is OP, but she doesn't have access to her OPness yet nor is she or anyone else even aware of it other than the viewers. This means that while the character isn't going on any world saving quests (and probably won't throughout the series), the story is open-ended enough to leave the possibility that that might happen someday up in the air. After all, the protagonist knows little about the world beyond her hometown, so the world could be in terrible danger, yet we, the viewers, would be blissfully unaware.Think of it this way: most of the time in reincarnation isekai, a character dies in our world and is reborn in another either with the same age and form they had here or into a completely new body that they have to grow up with. This is the latter case, but with any other isekai like this, the story always begins many years after the fact, and information of what happened when they first arrived and acclimated is told briefly in flashbacks and hindsight (like, for example, what happens in Didn't I Say to Make My Abilities Average in the Next Life). This one doesn't do that. Ascendance of a Bookworm takes us through the long process of the reincarnated isekai hero learning how to live in a new environment, showing us the intricacies of mundane life while slowly building up the protagonist's relationships, repertoire and dropping hints at future OPness (rather than just give them a video game menu and knowledge on how to use it right from the beginning) throughout the course of her early life.To put it simply, then, this is not the story of an OP protagonist on a quest to save the world. It's the prequel story: the story of the early life of an OP protagonist who will maybe, at some point in the distant future, be forced to embark on a quest to save the world, but not today. And honestly, I think that's genius, because the author took the segment of the Isekai protagonist's life that always gets skipped over and made an entire series about it.

I loved the manga of this anime its wholesome and relaxing but at the same time sad as well could it be emotions??, anyways this is a fun anime unlike other isekai where the main character just does everyting  he/she wants and blablah u know the story.This anime take a different direction myne who has some what an illnes and is trying to cope with her short and frail body is somehting new and the athmosphere of her family is great and everything its just nice,relaxing its different but at the same time still at heart isekai.Just like that time I got reincarnated as a slime.If it has better animation in the future then I hope it does well its great show imo.

At first I was bored and uninterested but every episode is filled with building blocks to support the next. If you accept the fact that it has "Slice of life" genre you will definitely start to watch it with interest. I have always enjoyed romance and action and some with mix of both genre. However, Slice of life with touch of Isekai is new to me therefore I didn't accept it until the 3rd time I attempted to watch the episode 1 without skipping through boring scenes.     None of it is boring in fact, I was just nit picking the parts that would've piqued my interest. But when I saw it all without skipping, I was hooked in. Episode after episode is spent and I am satisfied. In fact, I wanted more! I truly hope that they create more seasons to come for this series.The characters are in fact quite likable, lovable, interesting and amazing. Each character has a purpose and connection (as they should be) and there are forms of development in which very critical to the story. The only downside is the fact that kindness and good things overshadow the dark side of the Isekai world she got brought in. Nobility are cruel, selfish and greedy individuals, especially towards those who are lower in rank than themselves. There are some depiction however not fully developed or we might see more of it in the next episodes to come. Human in general are cruel, selfish, greedy, etc... But if you have stature and power, you'd want to keep it for yourself or for your love ones.      Ofc who wouldn't want to keep beneficial things for ourselves? It is kind of instinctive. But Main is different. She understand that there has to be a balance between that. She want to keep things for herself and her family but has to conform with the current world she live in, therefore negotiation is an option and if all things fail "Chikara/Power" is a must because there can only be negotiation if both party are considered equal or the disadvantaged is willing to accepting the terms/condition. There are more obstacles to come and that's exactly why this show is interesting. I truly loved this series. I want more, seriously!

Seriously if they made an isekai anime about my book nerd ass, it would be this. Main is so intensely relatable in her absolute unfailing obsession to read books, I feel her pain in every single episode. It's refreshing and inspiring in its depiction of her determination and adaptability, and really gives a feel like if you really really love something like Main loves books, you'll somehow find a way to acquire it.

Waited for the season to finish before writing a review. With no (overdone) overpowered Isekai protag, no game-based system, and very little magic until the second half of the season, Ascendance of a Bookworm is simply about what the title says - a reincarnated bookworm living in a medieval world trying do what she wants most: read books. But circumstance and the world she's in hinder her dream, but she doesn't give up! The best part of the show in my opinion comes from how Myne (the MC) goes through trial and error to try and make her books. She has the knowledge, but that doesn't always translate to ability or resources needed to make paper. Along the way, she makes new things that better the lives of her new family and others around her - and it's not until later that others convince her to make a profit off of those things. She agrees, but only because it'll help her endgoal of making/reading books. It's adorable how single minded she is about it, completely derailing her thoughts sometimes at the mention of books and being able to read them. All the characters have their own personalities and are well rounded, none having the over-exaggerated characteristics/tropes of other anime - but they have their quirks that come through. The show shines best in its simplicity to just tell Myne's story, along with the people she interacts with. I actually feel the show loses a little something when magic is properly introduced and it somewhat devours the story, but it doesn't become the main focus which is good, and the show does a great job. I highly recommend this for anyone who wants a simple story away from the flashy fights and other anime-ness of other shows to go to a simpler, more earnest story.

TL,DR: A distilled gem of wholesome goodness, that will have you involuntarily grinning like an idiot whether you want to or not. Truly excellent writing, fantastic characters, and unparalleled world building make this a must watch series! When watching anime, I tend to gravitate towards action-heavy shows with a heavy dose of guns, swords, and violence, or series that feature dark stories with heavy atmospheres. intriguing premises, and morally grey heroes. I've really enjoyed stuff like Jormungand, Attack on Titan, Tanya the Evil, Black Butler, etc. Ya know, stuff that ain't exactly "family friendly." So when I saw Ascendance of a Bookworm pop up on my radar, I almost wrote it off as not my cup of tea. I mean, c'mon. A little girl trying to make books? Boooorrrrriiiiinnnggggg... right?WRONG! This show is one of the best anime I've seen in a long time, ranking among my all time favorite shows! I'll be watching it alone in my room, and realize that I am sitting there smiling from ear to ear like a madman! Its just so wholesome and sweet! No fan service, no violence, no fights. Just pure, unadulterated happiness. It is a masterpiece of world building, storytelling, and exceptionally good writing.Main and her friends and family are just amazing! Each character feels like a real person, with flaws, strengths, and emotions. The writing is such that the meandering pace of the series doesn't hamper it in the slightest. If anything, it enhances the story, giving viewers time to really immerse themselves in the world. You can really understand the situations and can feel the weight behind events that occur, even if there aren't earth shattering consequences lurking behind every decision. And the writers don't shy away from addressing interesting metaphysical topics. Ya know questions that come along with someone suddenly existing in a different time and place in a completely different body, as it relates to both them and those surrounding them.You can tell that the author really put time and thought into this work of art. It just feels like a gentle labor of love, like the author is truly crafting this beautiful story because they genuinely love it. And when someone puts forth this amount of effort, it would be a crying shame to not partake of it. I ABSOLUTELY recommend this anime!

I've been reading the official J-Novel Club translation of the English light novels (which is currently on volume 5), and I have to say this anime is very well done. The animation is simple, and at times stiff, but you can tell just by watching that this is a passion project worth supporting. As of episode 8, the anime is halfway through volume 2, and it hopefully will get to the end of volume 3 after all 14 episodes are out.And even if you don't read novels, this is a great, wholesome, and riveting story that anyone will enjoy. It's nothing like any isekai you've ever watched, and anyone who thinks this is "just another isekai" is really missing out on something quite special.Please try it!

I read the English Light Novel version of this (Localized from the original Japanese Web Novel) before realizing this even had an anime and I must say that this adaptation loses a lot of the magic.  The pacing is weird, a lot of the effort the author put into world building and character development is lost, and in just the first 5 episodes I've already seen two things that are big reveals in the LN just kind of...thrown in there.  It doesn't help either that the production values are a bit on the shoddy side.My Suggestion: Start with the Novel so you can experience the story as intended, then you can watch this if you enjoy works of art being destroyed.

As a person who gives a lot of anime the 3 episode trial and move on, I was absolutely caught off guard when this beautiful story stole my heart on the first episode. I love the story, the characters. They do an amazing job with the characters' backstories. I love that they didn't make the main character so overpowered, and has true issues to overcome. The entire crew is a genius. Thanks for this beautiful story.

this is a series that i dind't thougt much of when i saw the poster and read the premise so i didn't watch it for a while but one day i was bored and desided to watch the first episode and was hooked from the beging, this series has a certain alure to it. a way to make you wonder about this world, a nice feeling as you see the characters interacts. althoug the plot moves slowly it just keeps gatting better and better to the point where this is the anime i'm looking foward the most every weak.

Initial Thoughts: Ascendence of a Bookworm was a show that I initially didn't even consider to be a show I would watch.  Thankfully as I was going to the depression of how horrible this season was and how there weren't any shows out there which weren't either extremely generic or had a d-bag of an MC to deal with.On the day I looked up Ascendance I thought I was just going to be wasting my time with another bad anime like all the others, the first two episodes were pretty slow in my eyes but they did a good job building the show, looking back I believe the writer and production staff did right by this speed as the show seemed to build it's pace at an equivalent rate as it went on.   Maine:   At first I thought I was going to be annoyed because the main character Maine is a bookworm, but I was completely wrong, it was really cool how she was bringing all these inventions like paper made from plants, shampoo ect into the world.  I also really enjoyed the intellect of the show as the conversations were often very intricate showing the skills that Maine brought from our world over there.World:  I love Isekai worlds, its really the best part of these types of shows, but the "generic MC goes to Isekai" actually doesnt exist in this world, and Maine is anything but generic, instead of showing up a level 1000 in this Isekai world Maine ends up in a body that can hardly walk, she gets tired extremely easy so needs people to carry her around, so in this show it feels more like Maine is part of the world where other Isekai's the MC is suppose to be some hero and none of the characters have any depth at all.After thoughts:  Even if you dislike Isekai this show is one that you should watch, it doesn't follow most of the Isekai tropes and sticks with a more personal level in respects to Maine and interactions with the people around her, you get to see how this worlds economy and family setup works and it's really fun, this show is a solid 9/10 for me and i'm so glad the best show for this season is going to get a second season.

Most Isekai are usually combat related and all too often revolve around some power trip,  mind you those are not bad in their own right.  Rising of the shield hero was nice,  and I AM someone who liked SAO(I know a guilty pleasure by some opinions),  furthermore I am looking forward to "I'm a spider,  so what?".This anime,  is not like those however.  Furthermore the Isekai part of it is VERY IMPORTANT for the plot rather then just some "detail".  It has a lot of fluff and slice of life elements to the start of it,  so for some it might take awhile to get started(for some,  I liked it from the VERY beginning).  Its kind of "Doctor Stone" in its beginning except more slice of life like.  However that said,  this is a VERY different style of anime once it gets going.Mercantilism,  Politics,  the aforementioned creation of items(doctor stone as stated),  and family matters/drama all come into big play around the middle and only get more intense as it goes on.  Many in the comments section would mention tears and sadness at elements therein.This is without a doubt for me,  my anime of the year.  I rarely do reviews unless I am bored,  love something to death,  or see a sad lack of attention to a masterpiece.  This is the second and the third.  I love this show and its being moderately ignored.  Its one of the best animes I've seen in awhile.Perhaps you might love it too,  give it try.  Especially if your a fan of shows like Spice and Wolf,  Doctor Stone,  or even games like Recettear(CAPITALISM HO!)

To me, writing is the key element to any series. Relying on gratuitous action, fanservice, and slapstick comedy to carry a series makes or breaks a series for me.As an example, some of the old Doctor Who classic episodes were written so well that my immersion wasn't broken by the god awful low budget special effects from the 60s-80s.This anime has no:   -Thrilling action.   -Fan service.   -Overly dramatic romance.And it's better off without it.

Urano Motosu died how she lived, loving books. Upon waking up in another world as a young child, naturally her first response was to find a book as soon as possible. Sadly, in this new world she lives in, there is not a single book to be found. She now lives the daily life of a sickly girl named Myne, with a family she never knew prior, in what seems to be a time period similar to the middle ages. Eventually she learns that books do indeed exist, but only the nobility can acquire such a precious luxury. Despite her inconvenient circumstances and sickly body, Myne now is hellbent on using all her knowledge from her past life, as well as the resources at her to create books herself!Ascendance of a Bookworm is the ultimate dark horse anime to come out of 2019. I myself stopped watching the show only halfway into its first episode, only to come back a few weeks later when recommended to by a close friend. I sincerely urge you the reader to not make the same mistake I did, don't let this anime pass your attention!It's a rather simple slice of life anime at its core, needless to say with what information on it I've already synopsis-ed, it is very slow. However, I think that's the key to this anime's success! It's pacing and methodical story will immediately be a treat to fans of cult classics of the likes of legendary anime like Spice and Wolf. There is a lot of care and attention into every detail surrounding Myne's routines and struggles, even if it's at the expense of the stories pacing. While that may lose the attention of some viewers, it makes that final moment where Myne completes one of her goals oh so satisfying! Along with helping Myne with her objectives is a collection of incredible cast members. I absolutely adore Myne's family, if it wasn't for Myne's endearing goals, this anime could have been a heartwarming slice of life on it's own. Other than family members, she's also got her neighbor Lutz also who's her age. Lutz is an earnest lad that is reliable every step of the way. I myself felt very comfortable and safe whenever he was on screen, knowing deep down Lutz would be able to safeguard/assist Myne from any obstacle in her way. There's also a plethora of other side characters that are just the cherry on top of an already excellent cast! Eventually Myne's over fixation on books starts to decline, as she realizes just how valuable the people she has around her are. Not entirely though, because by the end of the day, Myne still dreams of the day she can read a book again.Ascendance of a Bookworm is one of the best anime of the year, it came completely out of nowhere this year! Especially during a season that had numerous isekai anime that were actually good! Not only did it surprise and rise in popularity through critical acclaim, it managed to overtake most if not all it's competition! Yet it doesn't stop there, for a second season is already in the making, set to release in April 2020!Might I just say, with the return of Re:ZERO for season 2, SNAFU's long awaited season 3, and my personal favorite anime Princess Principal's movie series premier, April was already shaping up to be a great anime season! Now with Ascendance of a Bookworm slatted to return in April too, what else could an anime fan such as myself ask for?

Honestly the plot is really good, it is quite long before it starts, but each episodes have its own unique charm. There's not much action (except in the last 2 episodes of the season 1) but this is what makes it charming. I don't really know how to describe the way I feel when I watch this show, it lighten my heart. In other words, I love this show.This review probably didn't help you to know if its a good show or not, but I really recommend it. Like, seriously, watch a few episodes and you'll probably get charmed by the characters and the plot.

I know a lot of people aren't really into the slice of life genre (myself included). However, this series is a true gem. I binged the entire thing after watching through the first episode and there is still so much more content left in the light novel. I really can't praise this series enough, the animators have done an amazing job (along with the artists), and the story still feels whole despite the limited time-span animators are given to convey an entire story. 5 * this is one you do not wanna skip over

What this anime brings is a wonderful story in a fantasy world, not from the view of the powerful but the every day person. I love how the protagonists humble beginnings are not glossed over but put on display to show the struggle that it takes to raise one self up and not made a joke, like in so many fantasy slice of life anime. While this anime may be slow it makes up for it by being well thought out and just a wonderful thought provoking story. This one is a Keeper!

Highly enjoyable, exciting and cute show! Love love love this! Hope they continue making these! This story line is satisfying in the sense that if you were in the same position you would absolutely exploit the knowledge you have! How many times do people say “I wish I knew that when I was younger” well she did and what she does with that knowledge is awesome! Really looking forward to this story developing

I haven't really watched a lot of anime recently. The last few seasons of the few I picked out, I don't think I watched any of them to completion. This one however, really gripped me. There are going to be a ton of people sticking there nose up at this one cause of its genre, but don't let them talk you out of trying it. I'm not going to argue that this is a masterpiece. I'm not going to say it's the best thing to watch this season for most people. What I will say is that for me, for the first time in quite a while, I was having a great time watching an anime.

This season of anime is probably my most contentious seasons. Simply because we have bookworm and average. Bookworm is a very very faithful adaption and average a very cartoonish adaption. I cannot hate average it is filled with nostalgia but makes me long for a more adept adaption thanks to bookworm. This adaption of  bookworm is almost spot on perfect. This is with out a doubt the star of this season of anime!

I am in love with this anime.  Unique. Interesting. They took a concept that most might find boring and brought it to life!  The music is beautiful and haunting.  I can't stop listening to it!  The coup de grace is at  the very end of every show there is a still frame art render that is just gorgeous every time.  I highly recommend this to anyone interested in high quality slice of life fantasy.  This is not a shonen fight manga so don't watch it with that expectation.

Ascendance of a Bookworm is so far amazing! Granted, I will admit that this anime is very niche in the sense it is for people who love books and do not need action/ adventure to drive the plot. Creates a whole detailed world in the matter of episodes, and implements history, economics, science, botany, and class system very well. The POV is from a college student who loves reading and is transported into a child's body. Her inner monologue and extreme amount of tenaciousness drives the story beautifully. Plus it has magic, life struggle, comedy, and a dash of romance (non sexual, they are children) to balance out the heartwarming episodes.

Great show. Simple, compelling and you cant help but love all the characters. Its a fun and different take on the issekai genre. Highly recommend. In fact, im not sure i remember any issekai anime with a female protagonist. One thing i love is how the main character really is leveraging her knowledge of a more advanced society here. Its a concept that doesnt get applied in many issekai anime, not to this degree anyway.

I'm enjoying this show.  I hope that it stays safe to watch with my kids as they enjoy it too.  While there is an audience for ecchi, gore, action and horror type series out there, a tamer, wholesome series has an audience as well.  The premise is interesting as well, with a slight DR. Stone vibe in that she's trying to build technology (although all book related) unknown to this world from scratch.

This Isekai follows a girl reborn into a new body from a different world but retains her knowledge.  A slice of life isekai that steadily progresses the story rather than jumping through parts like there's a marathon to be won if you get to the ending after 20 years in 12 episodes.  Each episode introduces new ideas and with them new troubles which the young girl must hurdle through if she is to acquire her dream of reading books in a time where paper is highly expensive.

If we're comparing this to other animes in general, this is one of the most original animes in 2019. The story starts off with a 21-year old college girl being reincarnated into a 5-year old girl named Main (Myne, Mine, that's how the anime spells it don't ask me). Now that we have identified it's an isekai, let's what our MC's Status is: a frail, weak girl who was born into a poor soldier's family with a sister. That generally does not seem like the most impressive conditions to an isekai regarding that most of these isekai genre anime's MCs are male characters who are incredibly powerful and has a harem of "cute" girls. She goes on trying to satisfy her insatiable desire for her books using several different methods that existed in Earth. What makes this anime really different though are two things: The fact that the MC, who was previously 21, turned into a 5-year-old, and the great writing on the characters! Ok where do we start... Ah! Yes! An isekai where a character turns into an incredibly young child! That's the most original thing I saw in years! No violence! No romance! Only a child with a fully developed brain who is working hard to get books but everyone is treating her like a child because she technically is a child! It is so satisfying to watch because it is unpredictable Spoiler Alert! Click to show or hide(But somewhat is because alot of us don't do business deals with a 5 year old). Then the characters... The characters are very unexpected written well. Even though only 2 characters are truly dynamic, every single character so far is alive. The father, a person who really wants his daughter's attention and love. The mother, a person who wants the best for her sister and the MC. The sister, a growing and caring child who recently started working as an apprentice in looming. And Etcetera. The characters aren't written like masterpieces and details because the point of the story is around Main getting her precious books, but it is written well enough to the point where you remember.In a nutshell:  The author wrote a hard situation to work out of. However, she did it either way! This story is incredibly underrated and you should watch it! It does start semi-slow and confusing, but once you reach episode 3, you will get hooked! Keep in mind, I only write reviews  for the shows I think deserve it.

I read ahead and I still want to watch the anime. It is a great story and a beautiful show. I didn’t even realize I’ve been watching for the whole show until it ended and I wanted more. Five stars would watch multiple times until satisfied. Even new episodes give me excitement that I haven’t felt in a while, and it is great they returned to the female protagonist for isekai anime. It has been awhile. I love this show.

I have read some poorer reviews and noticed it's all about the time you put in. In the first episode as soon as it starts, we see that our protagonist Main is a young adult woman that starts and tells her story. The genre itself is not very much about the suspense or complicated story line, after all this is a kid show with a truly wholesome feeling to it. It makes you feels warm and fuzzy inside because of how Main is a nice little girl. Quickly, as some people have denounced, it's clear this frail 5 yo kid is a proper "genius" but there's a secret that she's afraid to share with everybody for obvious reasons;She's in a patriarchal medieval fantasy world, and anybody with a once of sense knows that if she was to stand out too much, it could mean trouble.She's careful but quickly she stands out and this is where the story starts to get fun.She learns about this New World she has reincarnate in and starts her new life. The "kid show" portion is very much evident has this show tries to teach young girls to be independent, to become strong in difficult time, to love your friends and family, to follow your passions. It's pretty cute and will make your day little less dark!

I must say, it is good to see something different from genre that many thought was too crowded and too overdone. Given that most Anime started from books ((Manga and Lite novels) it makes sense that viewers would be attracted to the premise of an overwhelming desire to read. Add to that the well crafted characters and story arc that does rely on defeating some demon lord or evil this or that. Just a human striving to learn and improve life one painful step at a time. Well done to the writers.

I came into this thinking it was going to be some magical isekai anime that books are powerful and knowledge gives you power or something along those lines.  I am finding myself grinning ear to ear with what i got.  the protag, aptly named Main, Is just a super smart women from modern day japan that was reborn into this little girl.  Her knowledge from reading any and every book known to man is what makes her special.  I'm bad at writing reviews.  but what i can tell you is that this is just so fun to watch and i cant wait to see each episode.  If you cant decide if you want to watch it, stop reading this and go watch it NOW!

The first few episodes are so heartwarming and cute, also the entire concept of the anime is lovely! I cant tell whats going to happen next and I can't wait to find out! From the intro we know that this is a magical world, but there's so much happening in the series right now the creators almost make us forget about it until they bring up the strange ice tree in ep. 3. I'm very interested to see what kind of a role magic plays in this world.

It's an awesome feel good series. All of the characters thus far are likable if not lovable, the art is great, the voice acting is perfect, and the relationships are adorable. The main character, Main, is super knowledgeable, due to her tensei-isekai-ness, but she isn't OP. If anything, she's the opposite as she is born the frail daughter of a peasant family. Everything she does is because of her knowledge. I also like that, unlike a lot of isekai protagonists, she has real empathy. When she outdoes her big sister, she honestly feels bad, but she also doesn't have the answer to the problem and has to rely on her mom. All the while, her singular interest is to be able to make books because she was formerly a librarian.I feel like in a lot of ways, this is what the isekai genre was missing, at least in anime. Every isekai anime up til this point, it feels like, is fantasy-action. This is a pleasant departure from that. It is a character driven, relaxed pace, feel good story. It's special in how much it isn't special yet is so charming. I would go so far as to say that this is like Ikoku Meiro no Croisée, but instead of the MC being from a different country, she's from a different world. This is on pace to be one of my favorite animes of the year.

So Iseki is about fighting and so hey book did you know this was about books well it's about books and a small sickly girl but books man did I forget to mention books I think I forgot to mention its got books... Honestly its wholesome anime about a girl who wants her goddam books. She's a sickly weak little girl Spoiler Alert! Click to show or hideWHO CANT FLIP A DAM PANCAKE!!!!! And I'm in love with it this is going to be a very good anime and I want more.

If you like isekei's you will like this. It comes at it from a unique perspective that is refreshing. Now for my warped synopsis:Its about a librarian who dies and reincarnates in another world by possessing the body of a dying fever stricken 5 year old in a medieval slum. She charms her impoverished acquaintances with knowledge and crafting skills from the old world. This eventually catches the eye of a leader of the local religious order. This leader then secludes her in his room where he then ruphees her in order to perform magical rituals upon her without consent.

One is pretentious title, pretentious fetish of main character (books) and those irritating micro scenes that demonstrate internal monologue of MC, they try to be funny and cute and are neither of those.Apart from that, this is very nice show, that i could recommend (after 3 episodes) to anyone that is still tired after disappointment that was Isekai Sht Magician.Nice world building, interesting plot and its development, calm and warm setup.

A modern young Japanese woman dies in an earthquake and regains consciousness in the body of a child living in something like a Medieval European world.  She absorbs the memories of that child, named Myne, and assumes her life.  (We learn that Myne was a frail girl, so perhaps she passed on from illness?  Because as creepy as that sounds, it sure beats the alternative, which would see Urano basically steal Myne's body. . .)  Anyway, Urano was a bibliophile in her first life and brings her love of books with her into her second, only to discover that they remain rare and expensive in her new world (so, Medieval Europe before the printing press).  How will Myne manage in a world without indoor plumbing?  Without toilet paper?  Without--gasp!--books?!  Guess she'll just have to make her own!  (Books, that is.)  Or maybe buddy-up to some nobles and clergy. . .

...Motosu Urano, a bookworm who transported into another world and took over the body of a fragile blue haired girl named Myne. Her desire to be able to read books again pave the way for encounters that form new and exciting relationships. -Review-This adaption has its genuine aesthetics and the animation quality is what you would expect from a temp seasonal show. It lacks action but makes up for it with good attention to details, believable world building and a tiny, likable MC. This show fills a particular niche and is great at what it does.

So far the first episode is pretty boring, but I wonder if this is an anime that starts slow and builds up, who knows, so far  I really love the art style and animation, its not generic isekai trash animation that we see in other isekai, the animation is smooth and clean, this anime has a lot of promise for possible world building scenarios in future episodes, and its kinda odd, giving the protagonist is a bookworm, but has not even brought up the idea they were reincarnated, nor not realize what era they're in, which is weird considering the're a book worm, this seems like its gonna be a kid friendly anime, but that's fine, though the first episode was pretty boring, but it is the first episode so I'm giving it the benefit of the doubt until newer episodes come out, the music is also pretty  relaxing and nice.

I find the lack of yelling, screaming, announcing attacks, forced confrontations with antagonist to be refreshing.  The MC faces more pedestrian foes in day to day challenges which, through her own will and perseverance , she overcomes.  Her challenges are relatable to the average viewer.  I find myself rooting for the MC and her small triumphs as she progresses through this tale. I think many will enjoy this series.

to keep it short and simplenot much of a plot until you reach the end where it really starts taking off. Not your average isiki ( its only an isiki because of a simple plot spec rather than enveloping around it). heart warming and hits hard on the issues a lot about wanting to die or maintain the will to live (didn't expect that). Overall not the best of best but better a lot better than the average

I have thoroughly enjoyed the manga adaptation of this story & was super excited when i heard they would be releasing a anime version. fast forward to today when i tried to watch the first episode & i couldn't look past everyone's HORRIFYING DEAD CGI EYES. to quote Robert Shaw from Jaws: "lifeless eyes, black eyes, like a doll's eyes". i kept thinking to myself "i'll just get over it sooner or later" but after 20 minutes where every time a character's eyes were shown on screen it was all i could focus on i decided to stop.tl;dr if you can get over the way the eyes are animated, you'll probably like this because (if they stick to the plot) the story and characters are all interesting and realistically portrayed.

It starts out with an adult mind raping a child. Not really a great story if that's how you want to begin it. The manga was tolerable but with this part, I cannot suggest anyone taking in this story. The MC is constantly "sick" and rather than letting her family in on her story to help her, she goes to outside help and gets taken advantage of constantly. A very, very poorly designed and executed story.

...but I can't. This show poorly explores the very tired "reborn in a fantasy world" genre. The ending is basically spoiled in the first minute of the show so there is nothing really keeping you watching aside from how she gets there. One episode in they give you an extremely one dimensional, tropey character that utterly and completely relies on plot devices and everyone around her being completely oblivious to the fact that she is obviously an adult woman in a 5 year old's body, which brings us to why I feel it earned 1 star......The second episode is a whole lot more of the same, nothing to see here, except them sexualizing 5 year olds like it was some high school drama. Like, holy shit. This is creepy even by anime standards. They literally gave a 5 year old a deep, sultry voice and a broody attitude and then immediately began building a romance around him that the (old woman in a freaking child's body) is totally falling for. Got Dayum!So to sum it up, wanted to give it 2 stars, giving it 1 because of jaw-droppingly inappropriate innuendos.

Damn what a show...I thought I was finally done with the isekai genre, then in 2018 That Time I Got Reincarnated as a slime came out. and man did it blow me away. It gave me hope, and then just to add the cherry on top, this show came out. and damn did it shock me. When I first saw it I thought, meh. But I thought I would give it a try, and I'm glad I did!Not to spoil anything but when I was watching it, it became quite a tear jerker.Do not overlook this anime. You'd be missing out

In the beginning it started a bit slow but it picked up real fast. The character development has been incredible so far and the premise is interesting and unique. Spoiler Alert! Click to show or hideI love how he is taking on the role of the bad guy (outwardly) and hedging his bets on going it alone. This show looks extremely promising. Really gives you time to sink into the anime and get more involved with the plot as it goes along. Very well done, looking forward to the future of this anime!

The Rising of the Shield Hero being released at the same time as That Time I Was Reincarnated As a Slime is amazing in that we have the two of the best isekai animes in the last few years hitting us all at once. To those who enjoy that satisfying sense of progression seen in RPG games (New Skills, Leveling up, etc) in a serious, well written form I promise you will love The Rising of the Sword Hero. The MC is not some generic, cookie cut protag like most shows trying to capitalize on the rise in popularity of isekai shows. I can understand what he does, why he does it, and what he feels from the way his character was developed in the same way as many hit shonen shows such as HxH in that the character is introduced early and simply and it just fits together so well ill stop rambling just try it out man.

I don't have a lot of time, so I'm not going to go too in depth into this.When I first heard about this, I wasn't really looking forward to it.  I've seen a lot of isekai anime, and they just start to get old after a while.  However, once I looked into the anime a bit, I learned that two of my favorite voice actors would be working together: Asami Seto and Kaito Ishikawa.  Fans of "Bunny Girl Senpai" from last season will know them as Sakurajima Mai and Azusagawa Sakuta respectively.  That alone was enough for me to give this anime a fair shot.When I started watching the first episode, I wasn't expecting to enjoy it.  And for the first half hour or so (it's an hour long special), I wasn't very impressed.  It was predictable and uninteresting.  I was expecting that I would drop it, but the last 15 minutes or so of the episode completely changed my mind.The second episode is packed with character development, but it's not boring exposition and drivel like many other isekai.   We're introduced to the characters in a way that makes us invested in them.  It makes us curious about what will happen to them in the future.  It makes us keep watching.Trust me, this isn't just following the tried and true template of other isekai anime.  Although the first episode does little to justify that claim.  But if you can make it beyond that, I think this could be a very interesting and well made anime.  I'm looking forward to more.NOTE:  This was written after watching just 2 episodes.  My opinion is subject to change as the show progresses.

Personally a top 10 action slight romance. His faces when even the mention of the word royalty is my face 24/7 it’s great. It’s an overall great hype building anime the intense battle scenes get me tense as well as the hurry the heck up a kith scenes are also great lol. Love how so far they hint romance but they are engaging the plot tremendously and I have 0 problems with it. They do it in such a great job you don’t even notice until you’re done binge watching and asking yourself why did I finish this so fast lol. Overall great anime, great protagonist, great plot, great action, great supportive characters, great antagonist that make you cringe when they appear. 10/10

Well, the way this started out, I imagined it would be yet another "players stuck in video game" re-hash. After just two episodes, I knew it was something far better. A hero that everyone hates, frames, blames, and fears is a much better story than the rest of these types of anime. It gets surprisingly dark for a shounen. Though, maybe it's more of a seinen. I dunno, I'm not an anime expert. So far, there have only been a couple of episodes that we didn't need, or that didn't show us anything new. Overall, though, I'm really digging the story, the "game" mechanics, and how the story follows its logic consistently. Different mechanics for each hero, "real-world" repercussions for everything the heroes do, the fact that different kingdoms perceive the Shield Hero differently from the main one (I forget its name). The characters in it feel more or less like real people. They all have their own stories, perspectives, and motivations. The only major gripe I have (aside from absolutely despising the character of Melty, which is the point of her existence, I suppose) is that Naofumi is the only hero we know anything about. Even then, the only things we know about Naofumi are his thoughts and personality. Basically, the other three Cardinal Heroes are just foils and don't have any defining characteristics, motivations, etc. The only thing we know about them is that the Sword Hero is kind of a jerk, the Spear Hero is a naïve fool, and the Bow Hero is more skeptical and logical than the other two. That's it. That's everything we know about them. I wish they were more fleshed-out. Of course, there are only about 20 episodes out right now, which isn't enough to make every single character feel real and fleshed-out, but I'm hoping they get to it sooner rather than later. In all, it's definitely worth checking out. Not as boring or unoriginal as you would think, despite the pretty cliché premise. The action is good. The animation is above average. I dig the art style. The story is arguably the most interesting one I've seen in months, aside from Kimetsu no Yaiba (Demon Slayer). You most likely won't be disappointed.

I feel so emotionally manipulated. Shield started off as an anti-hero story with a edgy, disillusioned main character. That's great, that's something we don't see a lot in normal isekai power fantasies. But then the show then goes on to ruin every single one of the characters I'm somewhat emotionally invested in by destroying their characterization. The other heros treat Naofumi like crap and then Naofumi throws away all his edginess and hatred for them to "have a heart to heart.' wtf? He goes from actually disgusted with them to lowkey annoyed with them. The show plays up Naofumi's trauma with the false rape when they need emotional raphtalia scenes and completely discards that aspect of Naofumi when it inconveniences the plot.In addition: Come on! Raphtalia is not willing to kill the guy who tortured her best friend to death but goes berserk over some idiot calling naofumi a loser??!!Its pretty concerning how Naofumi's teammates are written. Other than the obligatory tragic backstory, the girl's lives seems to revolve around Naofumi and Naofumi alone, every other sentence is Naofumi sama this and Naofumi sama that (which gets annoying pretty quickly).I am so disappointed. I had high hopes that this is was going to be another good Isekai, but i was wrong. There used to be a time where i couldn't wait for the next Wednesday, but now i'm barely finishing an episode when it comes out.

I really like this anime and I hate how people are overblowing it with these reasons saying it's promoting slavery and making women look bad for false rape accusation.You guys need to realise that we all have opinions and you know what? maybe all of the things i just said are wrong. Whatever your thinking about whether disagreeing with me or agreeing you could also still be wrong. Stop arguing to other people about who's right or who's wrong because no one is ever right. When did your opinion become so highly important that others need to listen to you? This is MY opinion now if you disagree with me then that's fine. I will not try to convince you or discuss with you how I'm right. But please be reasonable with your opinion and respect others.

The art style and animation is very well done in this show. The use of brightness to set the mood and pacing for the show is very well executed. The twists and turns of the path to becoming the shield hero are unpredictable and intriguing. The length of the first episode was a huge bonus. I believe the show would not have been as well received if it was not developed so much from the start. Had it only been 20 minutes it would have felt rushed and underdeveloped. The main character has changed and the other heroes are starting to show their true colors. This show is sure to be full of surprises one after the other. I cannot wait to see the next episode and witness 'The Rising of The Shield Hero'!

This is the second review I've written in here. I do it only when absolutely necessary and I mean absolutely necessary because no matter what kind of anime you like there is no way in this world you will not like this. Music --> PerfectStory --> PerfectCharacters --> PerfectAnimation --> PerfectEverything else --> Perfect (I'd even say 104% perfect)Honestly, there's nothing I can say that hasn't been said in other reviews so just give this a try, it's absolutely amazing. Thanks to this I started reading the novels and they are amazing.

18 Episodes In, Spoiler Warning In-Effect**Rising of the Shield Hero has many chances to absolutely delight the viewership over the course of its run. I usually spend the first three episodes or so giving the anime a chance to hook the audience -- and it usually doesn't take much -- and establish a premise that I can sink my teeth into for the long haul. This anime did accomplish that, and it still manages to keep my attention, I'm just not able to give it five full stars for one very obvious reason:I find it hard to believe that so many people in the established Kingdom -- in various positions of material and social power -- would simply choose to debase Naofumi constantly despite everything he actively does to denounce, avoid, and even flat-out contradict claims of evildoing against him. In a world where cataclysm is impending, and one of your four saviors against it is being shut out of progress because of a criminal accusation (serious as it is, I suppose), it's like everyone is absolutely bent on making sure the world gets plunged into the dark abyss! And nobody is going to bat an eye about it -- everyone just nods their heads to everything the King says, the King's daughter says. They set up three of the four heroes to be pretentious know-it-all players and then immediately go full-ham and decide they should also be ignorant to the very mechanics of the game they're trying to win.I really wanted to give this anime five stars, but I can't. A very, VERY small handful of characters in this show act with any sort of psychological depth beyond "my friend said so, so it must be true". They're morons. And because they're morons, the main character is tirelessly dragged through the mud. It's frustrating. And it seems like that is the intent: to frustrate the viewer. Eighteen episodes in and I'd think this tired-out arc of "Naofumi is being forced to work with three good-for-nothings who are trying to screw him over but is secretly OP" would have been resolved by now. But it hasn't. I get that people are ignorant. I don't watch anime to reaffirm it. I'm just watching now to see whether or not it's ever going to end so I can actually enjoy watching him fight the waves and POSSIBLY interact with some ACTUALLY INTERESTING CHARACTERS beyond his own party. Minus Filo.Let's face it, she's a flat character. And I'm not being misogynistic.

I first came across The Rising of the Shield Hero when I stumbled across a commentary video regarding the controversy surrounding TRotSH. Since SJW criticism usually translates to high praise in my eyes, I had to check it out, and am I so glad that I did. In general, I enjoy the isekai genre but TRotSH is now my favorite of the genre.I enjoyed this anime series so much that I was inspired to purchase the manga series for my kindle app (which was a first for me). Now I await the release of the next amine and next manga for this series.

Exactly as the title says. I watched this anime because of the overwhelming amount of good reviews. And I will admit, after watching the first episode, I was excited to watch more. It just didn't hold up to my standards. I'll going to stick to criticism here since there's many other reviews praising this show. NOTE: I tried very hard to not include spoilers but I'm not perfect.Firstly, it's repetitive. The exact details may change but if the same situation happens over and over again you're not going to be surprised anymore. Adding on to this, the show, besides the first episode, is pretty predictable. There's so much foreshadowing that when you finally get to the dramatic reveal there's not really anything to reveal. Secondly, the characters. Some of the characters are fleshed out very well. Most of them, not so much. There are some important secondary characters that are so one-dimensional I known exactly what they're going to say before they say it. And again this adds to the repetitiveness. If they act a certain way ten times, you can be pretty sure that they'll act in the exact same way the 11th time. Finally, the pacing. It was weird. After the 12th episode, I thought the season was over. Then again at the 22nd episode. It had a very dramatic ending that tied back to the beginning and I felt fairly satisfied. And then they kept going. When I got to the final episode, I waited for the next episode not realizing the season was over. So, after all this criticism I will say that it was okay. It was fairly unique. It kept me interested enough to watch the entire season. But it just isn't as good as everyone says it is.

This series is almost perfect. It does suffer from a few cliches and generic situations but Naofumi has some fantastic character experiences, growth,and a great supporting cast in Raphtalia the 3 other Heroes with issues, and some of the royalty. Only removed a star because they're trying to push a harem he doesn't need, and the other 3 heroes are a bit too dumb at first, yet they do show some understanding as the story progresses, can't wait for the next seasons! The lower star reviews hate wayyy too much.

As fantasy fan there are just some anime that can just be really repetitive with the same plot  but different styles or characters that instantly gain a intense power boost in a middle of a fight that and defeats there enemies with one hit every single time that makes you go like okkaaaaaaaay???(Sometimes it awesome but not always)... BUT THIS does and WILL not disappoint you starting from the every first episode.
