No matter what your anime preference is this is sure to get you hooked. The characters are subbed perfectly and the development has been awesome so far it gets you excited. You have to credit the character designs too because it doesn't look like your typical cheesy types. Intro song awesome too.

This anime wasn't what I was expecting.  It was/is better than that.  I thought that this main character was the crème de la crème and was going to deal with his first rival throughout the series.  But, after the first two episodes, you realize that it isn't that at all.  The main character is inexperienced, but, he wants to live the dream and do his best at the sport.  His first rival on the court soon became his best ally and a way to fix his inexperience.   It is amazing how they work so well together, thus bringing up the saying "Opposites attract."  This anime is really good and I do recommend giving it a shot!

I was browsing through CR popular list after catching up on all my shows and reluctantly came across this awesome anime. The superb character development makes me appreciate and love something about all of the characters. I ended up watching all 9 episodes in one day and was completely hooked. If your into sports anime, then your at the right place. There is a perfect combination of comedy, drama, art, and depth in this series that will make you eager to see the next episode. Easily a 5 star anime!

I usually don't like sports animes, but this really surprised me! I love the unique and bold characters, the animation is wonderful, and the voice acting is good too. Though some aspects are a little generic, it's hard to make such a creative anime out of sporsts, and this is very well done. I recommend it to anyone who liked Kuroko no Basuke, or just anyone who likes some nice, simple, but still good anime. Even though i've only seen 7 episodes, it's going up there with my favorites. I even started reading the manga because i couldn't wait to know what happened next XD

Just saw the 7 episodes and must I say... wow. The animation is great, the characters are interesting and I'm looking forward to the next episode. Honestly thought that I wouldn't like watching a sport anime but I was pleasantly surprised- though how serious they are & how much thought they take into volleyball is a little alien to me personally, I will definitely watch this entire series. If you haven't seen a sport anime before, I suggest you start with this!

Even though there are only a few episodes as I'm typing this, I think it's fair to say that this is going to be an excellent series. After watching the first episode I immediately fell in love with the characters, the art style, and the sport they play, leaving me hungry enough for more that I read through the available scans of the manga in a couple of weeks. Now I can't wait to see their thrilling matches in motion. The series is well animated with nice music, and the voice actors do very well in portraying the characters' personalities. The writing is fun and hilarious at times but evokes strong emotion when it needs to.My only gripe is this; while the male cast is colorful and interesting, the female manager, Kiyoko, is rather lacking. It feels at times as though she only shows up long enough for someone to comment on her beauty, and she barely talks or shows any emotions until fairly far along in the series. It's not enough for me to drop more than one star, but it does bother me at times.All in all, it's got amazing potential and, to sports anime fans like me, I can't recommend it enough. Even if you aren't interested in volleyball, the charisma and depth of these boys are sure to draw you in.

I agree with the review about the knb vibe. After the third ep, I do feel like there could be some rather nice character development/friendships brewing. That's a BIG thing for me in any sports anime, the teamwork and determination really makes the sport so much more appealing. Once I fall in love with the characters, I will love the sport as well. Since I'm so impatient, I'm probably going to start reading the manga now. xD

I Hated volleyball and said what the hell and watched this show. It became my favorite show. I loved this show so much that I even tried out volleyball. I actually respect the sport a lot more. But that is beside the point, the show is brilliant. They have brilliant writing, great visuals and nothing that is too unrealistic. There is amazing character development and most of the characters a re really likable in their own unique way. F*cking amazing show.

I've never played volleyball outside of school PE requirements so when I started the series I had nothing to go off of. But quickly, I fell in love with the mindsets and drive all the characters have for the sport because it reminded me of when I used to play soccer. That rush of when you're trying to score and then the feeling of when you do. This show nailed it and had me cheering with excitement every game and practice. I wanted to see the boys succeed, I felt for the older guys who were running out of time and wanted to win finally.It's a good anime and I'm rewatching it again lol

The first time I watched this, it was because my sister forced me to do it. I figured an anime about volleyball would be stupid and boring. This show is neither of those things.Haikyuu is really good at pacing, storytelling, animation, excitement, all those things. But the characters, man. The CHARACTERS. The characters are the absolute highlight out of all these amazing details, and they're what really makes someone love this show. Almost no characters could be called one dimensional, and the show makes it difficult not to care for all of them even when you're supposed to be rooting for the main charactersI love this show. My anime-intolerant friends love this show. My mom loves this show. Everyone loves this show. Watch the show

Haikyu!! has hands-down my  favorite animation style out of all the animes I have watched in my life. For no reason at all I just randomly started watching this show with my intense bias against sports animes. I just decided, meh, volleyball? why not give it a shot. Boy, am I glad I did. You want to root for the main characters so bad throughout the entire anime which is makes the plot intense, involving, and rich. Aside from the fantastic development of the show, I have to come back to the animation. Haikyuu!! is truly the best art I've ever seen and it also has one of the best openings, Haikyuu!! OP 04, it sends literal chills down my spine.

haikyu is an anime that exceeded my expectations. everything was great. the animation was well done and all the characters had a set of strengths and weaknesses. i love how they made us cheer for every team. that the opponents weren't just antagonists, but people who'd also worked extremely hard. i enjoyed the different story arcs, and the intro was good as well.  this series is just overall amazing and it's a 5/5 for me!

This was my first sports shounen, so I do have a particular soft spot for it. But, that's not to say that it isn't good. It's definitely one of my top 10 animes, personally. I've watched it about 10 times (even got my mom to watch it multiple times with me) and it always fills me with pure joy and happiness when I watch it. I love the characters, the pacing is great, Production IG does another great job in animating this series, and it's pretty accurate in portraying the sport (played volleyball for a number of years). This is seriously one of the best out there and I cannot wait for season 4!

When I first  saw this I didn’t think it would be that good because it’s just about volleyball but it turned out to be one of my favorite series’s. The characters are so lovable in hiakyuu and seeing the characters grow is even more amazing.I really love this anime even though I don’t like sport in real life. I highly recommend you watch this series.Im also reading the manga right now and it’s also very good

This anime is amazing. I love how you fall in love with every character even if they are on the other team. It shows that everyone wants to win and has high hopes and dreams even if they know they are not the best team competing. The animation on how they receive, spike, set, etc. is very realistic. The music is so great. The games are intense, the feels are sooo strong and can hit you like a bus, and the humor is spot on. I have watched this anime 5 times (I know I have no life 0-0) and I'm up to date on the manga and rereading it atm ( about chaptrer 83). I highly recommend p.s. the character development is just straight satisfying SEASON 4 HYPE

This was a brilliant anime. I think that it has amazing animations, a nice soundtrack and the way, the show presents volleyball is really good.I personally did not know anything about volleyball, yet I fell in love with this series. The characters personality is deeply explained, with stories about their past. I like how there are no real "bad guys" just the opposite team.You will definitely like this anime.

Minor spoilers (in particular spots, caution!) detailing first few characters and general topic/thoughts over Haikyu!!'s "philosophy"/values in my eyesFor quite a long, I've been extremely competitive in almost everything I've done in my life. Even when I was young and didn't understand much, I put as much effort as I could. Eventually, I became more serious, more understanding, and continued to grow in thought. Because of these contributing factors and a recent involvement in Volleyball (around 3 years now, also I have family members who played a lot of Volleyball today and before), I feel a deep connection with the show and the characters created here. Shōyō ("Short" Orange-hair) from the beginning resembled myself for his youth, passion for Volleyball, and his ability to keep working hard even though he is against obstacles. Hinata never stops trying and is continually inspired to become the best. My favorite character, however, is Kageyama (Tall Black-hair); he may feel egotistical and rude to his fellow teammates, but he is just another perspective to the world of competition. Possibly a darker side of competitive people, Tobio is still trying to become the best and striving to better his teammates in the game. In combination, the cast in Haikyu!! are pieces of different competitors, placed in different stages and situations in their careers, they perfect each others' holes and want one another to become better for tomorrow. Haikyu!! may be about sports, but they also include the lightness of High School (school-life), friendship, and being on a team. For example, Tanaka(-senpai, the "baldy" with the buzz-cut) is hilarious and keeps the mood uplifting. Captain Daichi (Dark Brown-hair with a kind of square head) is a great example of a young leader who sees the best in people. He knows he may not be the best, but he is dependable when the other players feel discouraged and puts his faith in the others by believing their abilities will lead the school to victory. I give my respect to Sugawara (Dark Grey-hair with the mole near his left eye) because of choice of being a great teammate; he teaches his teammates and acts another guiding figure in the series. He is there to continue pushing the other players (mainly Kageyama) to maintain their training and not become stagnant in learning. It also helps on the creativity of the animators and other staff where they make the characters have funny expressions as well as scenarios. There is a correct balance between the action and comical relief that reels me in staying around to watch.Haikyu!! on the surface may not seem flashy, but it is definitely is exciting to watch. The reason it is, is because the characters are energetic and are always ready to practice more and more. Each person is exceptionally likable because of their diverse attributes that build their character. I adore the anime because it adds an element of thinking and strategy into it. All the characters have strong development throughout the episodes and become a better team. It's something I want to experience; that's why I'll keep my head up, not fall, and continue to be fired up, in order to just feel my importance to something's entirety. Thanks for reinforcing that ideal to me, once again. I'm thankful for this series and hope for its continued success and praise! Each player in Karasuno high school are important to their success; they all know that. You are not alone, everyone is right behind you. As long as the ball is in the air, the game isn't over. Continue to work hard ! ~~~That's why they are passionate for their position and aim for the right to soar. The development of the characters is something that hits close home and probably to many others out there. There is a lot of metaphors and things you can learn from, some are basic, some take more thought, some can only be found from particular perspectives. I feel as you grow and change into someone more refined, Haikyu!! will be there for you to re-watch and you'll discover something new that hadn't appeared before. If you or someone you know are a fan of volleyball, sports, or anything that is competitive, you/they should watch Haikyu!! because of the competitive spirit and fire that explodes in every episode! It is fun and relaxing as well as being seemingly stressful and intense! Nothing beats trying to be the best to me!

I have never  really  been interested in sports.  I had always thought most sports were boring- especially a sport like volleyball. So I was quite skeptical when my friend told me to watch an anime based on it. But I decided to give it a chance because I wasn't really watching any other anime at the time and felt like being open-minded.It didn't take long for me to get hooked and in full-binge-mode.  The more I watched, the more I became enthralled by the characters and their dynamics; their motivation and ambition were deep and contagious. I began rooting and cheering for them in their games because I truly wanted to see them succeed and win. They do a great job at explaining volleyball in depth and go through the importance of each and every role and position. It made me realize how deceptively simple volleyball was. I had always thought it was just a glorified game of hot potato over a net- I was definitely wrong about that.Anyways, upon completing this anime- it became my #1 favorite anime ever. It made me interested in sports for the first time in my life and gave me a story I wished would never end. I simply cannot recommend this enough.

This anime is honestly one of the best I've watched. I've played volleyball for 2 years, and the knowledge of volleyball put in Haikyu!! surpassed my own. It taught me a lot of things that will be helpful to be in the next few years. Haikyu!! has a lot of intense matches, and a lot of comic relief to counter. I found it extremely enjoyable to watch.Haikyu!! has lovable characters that are easy to connect with. By the time you're done watching the anime, you don't really dislike anyone. No character is the cliché overpowering impossible to beat protag/antag, but there are obviously some well-rounded players. Every character is good at what they do, and when you put them together, they're a great team. Everyone has their strengths and weaknesses.The person I really connect with in this anime is Nishinoya. I'm around the same height as him, and I can't jump very high like Hinata. So libero is where I'm the most comfortable. Nishinoya is also an enthusiastic and energetic person, so just watching him jumping around when Karasuno scores a point makes my day.I also like that none of the characters are really antagonists. They're just opponents reaching for the same goal. Every team Karasuno plays against is different, making each match exciting and new.The art is breathtaking, and nothing in this anime goes to waste. All the growth made in the characters and the plot are put to use. The music is also amazing.I really like that there isn't much romance in this. Yes, there are a few characters who obviously have crushes on others, but nothing really escalates. Which is great for me, because I'm not a huge fan of romance.

This Anime is fantastic for volleyball lovers and those who've never dipped their toe into the pool of "Sport's" Anime! The story is very focused and realistic. Character development progress's very well with ALL OF THE CHARACTERS. Having good development for one or two characters is always great but, when the story can encompass everyone and make them very individual its almost unheard of in an anime. Literally everyone has an important role on this team they're all on.My favorite things about this Anime:- Does not dip into romance of any kind but, does have your classic hottie that motivates certain people.- Classic "Punk's" or "Tough" guy's- Confident characters- Intro and Extroverts- Timid Characters- HILARIOUS CHARACTERS (along with scenes)- Knows when to be serious and throws in some serious "feels" when they play volleyball winning or losing.- Pace in this show is perfect, not too fast or too slow.Please, go watch this without hesitation and you will enjoy this

Gotta admit that i was a little skeptical at first about watching this one, but wow am i so glad i decided to watch this. Every episode keeps me glued to my computer screen and leaves me wanting more. The characters are just amazing and their growth throughout the series really shows. The way they interact with each other sometimes just cracks me up. I'm not even a volleyball person but this anime makes me want to actually play it to feel as cool as they do. A must watch for sports anime fans, and even if you're not into sports anime, still watch it you won't be disappointed!

short, "cute" but unless you want those and the Nagoya reference is not really worth the 3 min. It's rough to translate well  and without the viewer having at least some colloquial Japanese to understand what was said, even the subtext translations skipped over some.translation. My guess is because the "adult" context the joke.which isn't adult context in Japan.As for Prejudice: For someone to review it and give it 5 stars while writing "I can't tell you how frustrating it is to not understand what is going on"  & "i'll give it a 5 star since I don't want people to prejudice this anime for bad reviews" is prejudice.

There is no other way to properly describe the show other than short. Short main girl, short run time, short budget, and generally short on jokes. It's joked that it's from Nagoya, that's it, mind you there are other jokes there, but they are all in service to the fact that it is, in fact, in Nagoya.If you seriously having nothing better to do with your day and looking for a brainless show, there are worse ones to watch.

When you want to watch something but don't have time to watch something longer, this will do.  There's a joke or 2 per episode, you might learn 1-2 things about Nagoya, but it tends to leave you feeling unsatisfied.Long story short, new kid in town moves from "The Big City" to a smaller (but still decently sized) town where he tries to befriend a native with something resembling a Scrappy-Doo complex.  (Surly over the superiority of her hometown.)  Because of the native's town-pride / insecurity, she reacts badly to the newcomer.This is a little bit of a comedy, a little bit "here's how Nagoya and Tokyo differ" and not much else. This could be a good promo for a decent-sized comedy, but as is, it's spackle to fill in the gaps in your schedule when you don't have time for a full-length show.
I normally hate short episodes, because they're to freakin short! However this just has that spark in comedy to it that is just bloody amazing and worth catching up on...Done!

I usually love cat animes, or things like that. But unless you get the cultural differences between Nagoya and Tokyo, which seems to be the main focus, you probably won't understand much of what is going on. The cat part is only childish and secondary from what I've seen so far. A bit early to say its real rating, but for now, it's a 3. But, I was actually happy the anime was short at 3:30 to be honest, as I wouldn't be able to take the brain numbing censored sexual innuendos and main focus of Nagoya is lolz for 30 minutes. Will keep an eye on the next few episodes, but for now, it does not deserve a spot in my endless queue.

This Anime seems to have potential, that is until you see how short each episode is. When I saw the cover art for this anime I immediately assumed it was gonna be really good so I decided to watch the first episode. Don't get me wrong it wasn't bad but they made the episode way too short, I can't tell you how frustrating it is to not understand what is going on. All though the episodes are extremely short, it has a cute animation and I do believe it has potential so I guess I will stick around for more to decide wether  or not is good. For now i'll give it a 5 star since I don't want people to prejudice this anime for bad reviews.

When I saw RWBY on Rooster Teeth, I gave it a try because it looked interesting. As it turns out, I enjoyed watching it. The animation is cool and the plot seems like it could get interesting. I also really like the music, namely the intro. All in all, it's obviously not the best anime out there. The people in the background are just silhouettes and the show is on a pretty low budget. However, I think it's pretty interesting and for 5-8 minutes of my time per week, I'm not complaining. p.s The show improves with every episode.

RWBY is not about the definition of anime per se, but an encouragement to the artform we have been watching for years from an American perspective. The episodes are a mix of light hearted fun, likeable characters, and a little bit of genius for the fight sequences. The story follows four girls at a boarding school that specializes in the training of cutting edge warriors that protect society from an encrouching horde of monsters. Initially they have to overcome the differences on the inside before they can unify to overcome evils without. Rather than harbor preset expectations about voice acting, 3d cell rendering, or episode length when compared to the Japanese production houses that have been creating wonderful entertainment media for decades now, I think an open mind is needed. This isn't a first class trans pacific jetliner, it's a jet propelled ninja backpack, it isn't the latest Sony Vaio, it's the first Macintosh. It isn't a watershed moment for every anime critic, but I think the essentials are more than enough present to encourage what it already has going for it. For a show about killing monsters, please don't be a monster. For a show called Ruby please don't toss out the diamond in the rough.

Rwby's Pros out way it's cons and it's only getting better. Overview,Music:Top notch, Jeff Williams delivers and even if you despise everything else it's soundtrack is incredible.Action: Monty Oum's bread and butter and it shows. Excellent fight choreography and clearly Monty and the laws of physics had a falling out at some point because Rule of Cool is in full effect and it's all the better for it.Story: So far, nothing we haven't seen before, school for fighting monsters, creatures of darkness, If you are into any type of fiction then you've seen the premise. That said, it's way to early to be certain of where it may go and with multiple seasons confirmed there is ample time for them to subvert there premise or introduce more original plots. Also, it needs to be said that even if they don't do that, not having an original premise is NOT automatically a bad thing. If it's executed well that's all that matters.Animation: Needs work, outside of fight scenes it tends to be awkward and objects tend to clip. Lip sync needs work but has gotten better from the first episode. If it follows the pattern RVB did then we can probably expect to see them improve over time.(Compare RVB Season 8's CGI to Season 10's)Voice Acting: Better then the Black and Yellow trailers would have you believe, much better, but not perfect, most of the principal cast are new to voice acting so there delivery can be somewhat stiff and lack emotion, but again from the trailers to episode 1 to episode 8 you can hear the improvements.Overall: it still needs work, but know new show doesn't. Flaws in animation and some amateurish voice acting don't take away from the Incredible music, awesome action and so far, a likeable cast of characters. It will fix what is not great in time and like I said its already only getting better.

I'll preface this by stating that I was a fan of Roosterteeth before RWBY, so I am biased towards their work.In my opinion, RWBY is good. Produced by a small studio, it goes above and beyond what one might think it could be. The animation during everyday interactions can be a bit rough and seem a bit disjointed (Ruby can vaporize cookies on contact with her mouth). The voice acting can be a bit forced in places, especially in the trailers. And there are quite a few cliches.But RWBY has a lot of heart. It is very easy to love the characters and they each are memorable and special. The fight sequences are crazy (in a good way) and the animation there is much more fluid and fun. And the music is FANTASTIC!  The show really picks up momentum and gets better and better towards the end. The episodes are short, but it's nice for when you just have a bit of time and you want a fun little watch that will make you laugh.RWBY is good. It's not God's gift to mankind or the best thing since sliced bread, but it's fun and cheerful and enjoyable and good.

When I first tried to watch RWBY I was shocked at the 3d animation. But after about 10 minutes of watching it becomes normal, it is very immersive and provides for very brilliant action scenes. The character development is there for all main characters, (and well done), plot line is clear and understandable, and the characters are extremely likable and enjoyable to watch. I definitely recommend anyone to watch this show.

I have to say I've never been more impressed with this anime. Yeah its made in American and thats were alot of the markets moving. Can't really control that if you wanna keep the style alive. that part can be a little disconcerting but its something I've learned to look past.This anime goes above and beyond for series that goes for anywhere between five to ten minutes. and it accomplishes story wise in five to ten minutes what takes a half hour or godsakes three episodes at times to accomplish. its been great ride and good show to what others can do.

I've watched the first couple of episodes and this is a good anime, because it has all the hallmarks of historically good animes. Clever dialogue, quirky personalities, awesome fight fx (sometimes a bit overkill-ish), and an interesting story pace. Characters are super attractive, dynamic and interesting, likeable within a short span after introduction.Who cares about where it comes from. Good anime can come from anywhere there is a desire and capability to produce great anime, be it Japan, South Korea, China, Vietnam, USA, Russia, whatever. These artists too grew up on the same great art form from the motherland (Japan) that the rest of us did.Give em a chance to spread their wings for the sake of the future of this art form we all love and cherish.

RWBY has been one of the most ground breaking animes in years. and its grabbed audiences all over the world in less than two seasons. it entered the scene with some rudimentary animations and story but as season two continued to play out its animations have continued to improve and its story has opened and unraveled in some very fun ways.but despite its success and fan base its been under attack by the weeboo minority. individuals that believe anime should only be in Japanese and made in Japan. They believe that animes should only come from mangas and be made from manga drawn animations (no improvements or adaptations allowed) and story have to follow a rigid guideline. The problem is even Marvel and DC comics can't follow this to the letter so why do weeboos expect the same from all of Anime. this on top of the fact that half these guys are also closet lolli pedophiles.This is the same crowd that believe that the horrible reboot of Rozen Maiden was God and RWBY should never have been! they exist on a standard of double standards or no standards at all with no principles at all. The anime community will die it follows the direction of this Sci-Fi minority. The bigger problem as I keep pointing out in previous reviews is Weeboos. As also pointed out by one of the greatest anime legends to grace the art Hayao Miyazaki. He's continued to warn that the industry is being ruled by the Weeboo minority and not by fans or good animators. and good animators can come from anywhere Japan USA UK Canada, Europe China doesn't matter, they can come from anywhere and so can the fans.Despite this RWBY has shown the Weeboos are a minority. They'll keep hating and dropping BS reviews (on here especially). But RWBY has given anime a new lease on life, for this stands head and shoulders above the rest and is a classic in the making.

RWBY comes straight out of the mind of Monty Oum and has been dazzling audiences for a couple years now. Teaming up with the guys that brought you Red vs Blue to create a CGI anime. This anime may not always be visually dazzling but it has been making strides in improving anime and expanding story as all animes should anyway. but the best thing about RWBY is how much content there is in the anime vs other animes. This anime can fit a half hours worth of the story and content in ten to fifteen minutes. its been a revolution in the making.

The Bad:-Script. It is not horrible but paired with the poor voice acting at the beginning, it was a little cringing.-Animation. The hair, the mouths, etc. distract your attention from the show.-The episodes are too short to be absorbed in the show's world each week.The Good:-The MUSIC! Very fitting and great to listen too. - Action scenes. Though the animation doesn't fit for everything else, it does very well for the magic action scenes and different effects (like the flaking petals) make this extremely enjoyable to watch.-No ridiculous or obnoxious fan-service.The Getting Better:- The voice acting. It has improved since the trailers and first couple episodes but still much room for improvement remains. -The Plot. Yes, it appears very stereotypical, but I have faith that it will improve.-The characters. They are very one-dimensional now but they are beginning to have a little more depth. More soon to come I hope.

Rooster Teeth have done a lot of amazing things, but never have they generated any  original content of their own. As their first original creation, RWBY does not disappoint. Although many criticize the series 3D animation style, it is the very thing that gives this series a flair. The amazing graphics and effects that 2D animations are not able to obtain are all prevalent in the weapons and even the characters. As for the story, it seems simple on the surface but it is seemingly more complex as the series passes by. What you thought was just the White Fang seeking chaos and control now involves the story of Ruby and Yang's origins, as well as a lot of other internal conflicts. And better yet, romance has finally come into play. The characters are all unique, whether they're quiet and harsh, but also fun-loving like Blake, or Cute, querky, and caring like Ruby. What I'm amazed by is how the developers are even able to keep up with their color name system, which I am barely able to upkeep with my Fanon characters. Now, for the most attention grabbing aspect of RWBY, the action. There is a general rule that most actions should follow to become very successful, and that is a unique aspect to the world's fighting. That aspect is the transformable weapons, aura, and dust. The most eye-catching thing about the action is the extremely fluid animation that many 2D animations just can't do. Every single fight in the series so far has gotten me on the edge of my seat and overflowing with awe, with the only 2 reasons being: (again) the weapons and the fluid animation. Overall, I'd recommend this anime to anyone who is a newcomer to anime, or someone who's looking for something new.

I'm not going to pretend this is an outstanding series: it's not. In fact, it’s not very impressive at all for a vast majority of the time, and is upsettingly overrated. It does however have redeeming qualities sprinkled throughout that may or may not warrant a viewing, depending on what interests you I guess. I'll start with the positives.The art direction is generally pretty good. The design of the Grimm is fascinating, the sets and scenery can range from good to great (they get better every season), and the costume design is very good, for a few reasons. Many of the characters are designed after historical or mythological figures, and that design will also tie into their personal fighting style, personality, and story arc. What's also interesting is that the coloring schemes are used as a story element—exhibiting certain character traits and plot foreshadowing on a level that will surpass most shows of this trade.The last few points also tie into the lore and story, which are thoroughly designed by show creator Monty Oum. The lore is very detailed and thought out in a way that would require some outside reading for most. Since Oum's passing however, it seems that Rooster Teeth will be taking the show in a different direction than the creator's plans. Though such an executive decision is disrespectful, and frankly upsetting, this review will focus on what *is*, rather than what *would be*. He went out with a surprisingly weighty third season though, with a level of peril and scope that redeemed some of the series' more prevalent flaws up to that point. After that, there is a dramatic quality decline in season 4 that would suggest the writers were replaced by middle-schoolers.I’m going to keep Rooster Teeth’s politics in the review’s score to a minimum, but there’s no other way to describe it other than disgusting. They declined Oum’s wife after she revealed that she was aware of Monty’s plans for the series, and also proceeded to fire a majority of the animators, choreography team, and writers that had ties to Monty, only to write in their character inserts as central to the story. Not only did season 4’s story quality dramatically decline, but the conditions surrounding it are nothing but despicable. The quality effectively undermines the series’ peak at season 3. I digress. . . .Finally, the music is decent. Jeff Williams writes not only the intro songs, but does the majority of the soundtrack as well. The intro music is actually pretty good generally, with the first two themes being outstanding to me, and a periodic decline in volumes 3 and 4 respectively. The soundtrack itself is fairly good too, as it employs some clever thematic sensibilities to a small but still enjoyable degree. It doesn't shine high above most shows, and the material isn't overall very memorable, but it is a step up in quality from television's average endeavor nonetheless. Casey-Lee Williams, Jeff's daughter (if I'm not mistaken), also provides the vocals for the intros and soundtrack, with a truly beautiful voice and outstanding range. Now for the negatives:The animation, not including the generally well-done choreographic concepts, is fairly poor. I know animation is hard, but television has set higher standards. To be fair, the quality has increased along with the presumable budget increase, but there is still a sense that the characters are simply paper dolls devoid of weight. The quality of choreography in season 4 however declines dramatically, which subtracts one of the show's few redeeming qualities from the dynamic.Despite being arranged with the lore cleverly, the characters are diminished to simplistic, tired clichés. The characters I actually found interesting only sparked interest out of a predisposition liking for that particular kind of character, and at its worst the personalities and the banter between them are insufferably irritating or downright cringe-worthy. This is in no way helped by the voice acting, which generally reaches its peak at flat and minimally passable, but for the most part is just bad. The chemistry between the voice actors is almost absent in its entirety, and that can perhaps be attributed to the generally poor script, which feels choppy and hastily written. The story arc of season 4 however is a sure decline in quality. The plot goes almost-literally nowhere for nearly the entire season (with minimal character development), and there’s an oversaturation of uninteresting exposition alongside new, useless, irritating characters. Individual Volume Ratings: Volume 1: 6/10, Volume 2: 7/10, Volume 3: 8/10, Vol. 4: 4/10, My overall rating: 6/10 (≈ D-) (≈ 3/5 stars)I personally would like some of my time back, though again, there are redeeming aspects here and there that don't make it a complete waste of time. So watch it if it interests you. Don't if it doesn't. If you care about plot or characters though, it’s probably best to steer clear.If the decline in quality continues, I'll change my recommendation from a "watch if you think you'd like it" to a "steer clear". I can't see myself returning for a fifth volume, so I'll leave the review at it's most positive stage.

I had low expectations for this, as the animation was low quality, but I gradually began to love it! Everything about this exceeds my expectations. The pacing, grim setting/atmosphere, fight scenes, and plot all add up. The best part is the cut scenes. It really gives you a dark vibe and you understand the plot crystal clear. The characters aren't two dimensional and there solve plot points bit by bit

I had believed, at first, that this would be a "failed" anime. However, after watching the episodes and seeing great reviews, one can clearly see that this anime is nowhere near failure. I hope this anime will be one of the top animes out there since I think people don't appreciate the "3D" style art. To me, that art style just makes it much more unique. Also, in my opinion, anime shouldn't be judged by it's art style, but by it's story, and this anime got a heck of a story.

Definitely not to everyone's taste, this show is kind of all over the place when it comes to what it does well and what it needs to improve upon.What it gets right:Action sequences. This show has some of the coolest fight scenes I've ever seen. They're gorgeous, creative, well-choreographed, and absolutely jaw-droppingly awesome. The weapon and fighting style designs are amazing.Writing: while not always executed as well as I'd like when it comes to the voice acting, the writing behind the story and dialogue is solid. It's witty and funny when it needs to be, brings out the key elements of each character's personality, and for the most part it flows really well. The story's not that original, but that's not necessarily a bad thing since it pulls all of the story elements together better than many of the other series I've seen with similar plot elements. Also, the character pairings for teams is great- their dynamics, strengths, and weaknesses all serve to balance each other and make for really fun and interesting interactions.Character designs: Awesome. Each character that has an actual design is very creative and does a great job conveying the character's personality.Musical Score: Loved it. Bought it.What it needs to improve upon:Animation: Aside from the awesome action sequences, the rest of the animation needs some serious work (though I'd like to note that it does improve with each episode). The characters' movements are all pretty awkward and stiff for the most part. The syncing for the voices is hit-or-miss sometimes (more problems with earlier episodes than later ones), and there are quite a few times when objects and bodies overlap, ruining the sense that the characters and objects are solid. Also, I wasn't a fan of some of the "cartoon-y" elements chosen for some scenes, such as characters taking on Chibi appearances or playful fights turning into a 2-d cloud with arms and legs sticking out- it didn't seem to fit the style of the show and was kind of jarring to see. The animation shortcuts were also a bit annoying, such as the show's tendency to reduce background characters into stiff silhouettes. With a few exceptions, the backgrounds needed a lot more work as well.Voice Acting: hit-or-miss sometimes. To the actors' credit many aren't that experienced and are still learning and improving their skills- the acting does improve as the show goes on.As I stated before, this show isn't for everyone. I almost stopped watching it several times in the first few episodes because of the animation and voice acting, but the positive aspects of the show that I listed above made me decide to keep watching despite my hang-ups. I'm glad I kept watching and look forward to seeing the next season and seeing how the show continues to improve.

I'm glad that Crunchyroll picked up this series. It shows that this series is gaining more and more publicity among the anime community.I really like it how America is starting to develop their own kind of anime culture. I loved anime-influenced American series like Avatar: The Last Airbender, The Legend of Korra, and now RWBY.Also, this my first take on watching a CG anime. I've seen 3D anime, but mostly in video games, but this is the first time I've ever watched a full anime series in CG.Some things I liked about this:First and foremost, it is from Rooster Teeth (how can you not like Red vs Blue?), and it is Monty Oum's work. I also liked how each character has their own unique background and abilities. The plot is still in its early stages, so there are some hokey moments, but I'm giving this series a chance, and I hope to enjoy it all the way through to the end.

Eschewing most archetypes, and infused with a "doesn't take itself too serious" sense of humor, RWBY is a solid offering from Rooster Teeth and Monty Oum. RWBY posses top quality animation, with frenetic battle sequences and developing characters. While episodes are a tad short, each leaves you more interested in the story. I would definitely recommend RWBY to anyone looking for a change from the usual troupes. I am ever impressed with the strength of the female leads; the interesting plot developments; and the well-crafted nature of the universe.

This has been all I could ever ask for. I've heard some really nasty Weeboo rants and unnecessary wrath on the people that like this anime. one I'll say is the animation drawings are the most stellar but the CGI animations are second to none. and the best part if all is the fight scenes are a total death-defying thrill. There's somethings that if I had my way could be improved I really couldn't ask for anything in anime more fun.and actually as I'm watching season 2 they are improving the animations and the drawings a little more every time.

This review for RWBY is split into what I consider RWBY's important elements: plot, animation quality, soundtrack, and characters. It will be spoiler-free.Plot: RWBY's plot is interesting, but nothing ground-breaking. The first episode opens up with enough mystery and intrigue to keep you watching with a few memorable moments. The majority of the story takes place at Beacon, which is essentially an academy to train chosen adolescents to become warriors, known as Hunters and Huntresses. Why would this universe need Hunters/Huntresses? RWBY's monsters that inhabit the world are called "Grimm", whom, in my opinion, become more interesting in later seasons. This leads to some interesting plot points, but there also are a fair amount of "filler" episodes. Fights between characters are eye candy to watch, and most have plot relevance as well.Animation Quality: The animation quality improves greatly over the seasons. Season 1 has the roughest animations, specifically when depth-of-field is involved. For example, let's say Ruby is running away from someone from the foreground into the background. The running animation used in season 1 makes it appear as though the character is running on a green screen and can be cringe-worthy at times. By season 3, Rooster Teeth beefed up production enough to deal with unique animation challenges much better.Soundtrack: The soundtrack/music is one of RWBY's strongest qualities. Jeff Williams and Casey Lee Williams write/preform/sing the majority of the songs and they do an amazing job. It's hard to describe the soundtrack in words, so I suggest looking up season 1 and season 2 OSTs on YouTube. As of the time I'm writing this season 3 currently doesn't have a released OST. Needless to say, I'm excited for it.Characters: The characters are likely the largest reason so many people love RWBY. You have a young & somewhat naive Ruby, a tsundere Weiss, an extrovert Yang, and a shy & reserved Blake. Many consider these 4 young girls to be the series' main protagonists. Worry not about a small roster; plenty of other characters are introduced throughout the seasons to keep things interesting as well as... well, I won't hint or spoil anything for you . Saying anything more about each character would diminish RWBY's character development.Verdict: While not the most unique anime out there, the outstanding music and character development alone is worth watching for.

I have to say I was pleasantly surprised by this anime. 3D animes aren't usually my bread and butter nor is video game based animes which use the same animations. I was actually quite fun to sit down for 15 minutes have a drink and watch this short little piece. The animations are standard for you get form a game or an ani-short but it was the story that had me curious and that's I've been enjoying about this. Since there's no manga for this thing to go off of you really don't know where its going to go. Its almost like Binge TV you just don't know how its going to turn out till they get to the conclusion.I was very much saddened to hear about the recent death of RWBY's creator and I hope the series continues to live on.

TL;DR - This show is better written, far more entertaining than most of the anime that gets released each season in Japan.  There is a reason why RWBY has a large fan base in Japan and there is a reason why Warner Bros Home Entertainment Japan is officially picking this up for official Japanese localization.If you want to give this show a shot, you should NOT go into this expecting a typical anime.  For clarification, RWBY is not an anime.  Anime is... Japanese animation, created by the Japanese industry, for the Japanese audience, where the main spoken language is originally in Japanese and the first broadcast is in Japan.  Now before you go raising your pitchforks at this review, this statement is not to put down RWBY in ANY way, but you are actually doing a disservice to the awesomeness of this show by calling it an anime and expecting it as such.Much like Avatar: The Last Airbender or The Legend of Korra, the show borrows art influences from Japan; but RWBY stands on it's own as a creation from the wonderfully talented people working at Rooster Teeth and of course Monty Oum.Of course it has influences from anime (art/character design obviously), but first and foremost it is an American animated web series.  Upon watching RWBY, very quickly you will pick up on what I mean.  The humor is very American and extremely non-typical of Japanese anime humor.  It is refreshing to see gags and jokes that are not based on main male protagnists walking into the girl's changing room or finding them naked in the shower ending with a slap.  The humor, for the most part, is witty, intelligent and well executed (especially in Volume 2), but enough with the humor.From world building, to character development and growth, to plot development, to fight sequence animation; RWBY manages to do many of the important things right the first time.  Characters are interesting, characters have contrast with each other, interactions are well scripted and RWBY manages to make you care and like each character for their own faults and strengths.The sound editing and music of RWBY is fantastic.  Jeff Williams and his daughter Casey Williams have done a fantastic job with the soundtrack and if anything music is definitely one of the stronger parts of the show.  It fits, it works, and it enhances the show in every possible way.The action is very typical Monty Oum.  If you didn't like Dead Fantasy you won't like this, but I don't know many people that don't enjoy watching over the top, rhythmical, creative and just insanely cool fight sequences.Unfortunately, the show isn't perfect.  The animation is rough at times, clipping of polygons happen here and there and certain backgrounds can lack finer detail or textures.  Keep in mind however that the whole show is made in Poser and Rooster Teeth has been making great strides to improve this and you can see the improvement over Volume 1 to Volume 2.  In addition, the voice acting isn't Hollywood professional.  Certain lines may feel a little forced or even lacking true emotion, but it is good enough for the show.RWBY manages to do so much more with everything ELSE that the minor imperfect surface details are rendered insignificant.  I consume A LOT of anime each season and I've been watching anime since the late 80s.  RWBY is worlds better than a lot of the high production crap that gets put out each season by Japan, especially recently.I am hoping Monty and the Rooster Teeth team continue to pour their hearts and souls into this show and continue to deliver an epic entertaining experience.  Like a book, don't judge it by its cover and you will be pleasantly surprised."Haters gonna hate and ain'ters gonna ain't."

I'm going to come right out and say it: RWBY is not original. In fact, the core of the show seems to be to involve any anime trope they can. And if you are bothered by that then that's fine, it's your opinion and you are allowed to have it.However, that doesn't mean RWBY is bad. In fact, I believe the reason why RWBY is as popular as it is because of it's love and respect for what makes up anime. Unlike some shows that simply use a trope or a cliche because it will appeal to the most people, the creator and writers of RWBY use them simply because they like them and want to show why they do. For example, Ruby is not a cute, dorky girl for the sake of being a cute dorky girl but it's because she has so much less social experience than her peers and is shown to have a stronger affinity for things she knows about like weapons than stuff she doesn't like people. And the writers know this and point it out, like Yang intentionally leaving her so she's forced to meet new people. Likewise, the sharp contrast between Yang's lax and trigger happy side and her maternal, wiser side may seem like a huge contradiction until we learn about her past and see she intentionally holds herself back around Ruby. It's writing like this was why the tropes and cliches became as popular as they did and why RWBY does them well.But this wouldn't be a proper review without talking about the rest of the show. The writing skips in quality at times. Most of the time it's pretty average with the later season giving them a kick to really good. But there are times that the show can push the Rule Of Cool too far and rely on said rule too much. So you're enjoyment there is based on how much tolerance for that you have. If you don't have a lot or even an average amount, you're not going to like the show. However, I should say that I seen far far worse offenders of RWBY's offenses here, one of whom was cited as an inspiration for RWBY. The humor is rather good, especially if you're a fan of wackier humor. it definitely works well in the context of the series. So the writing as  a whole is surprising good.Now time for the animation. Although Volume 1's animation isn't very good, it's acceptable considering the crap I've seen like the numerous still frames and reused animation in a certain Gainax anime. And as the series grows older, the animation gets better as the animators get more and more experienced with the latest Volume's switch to Maya being a great improvement. And the fight scenes are consistently very good, being at the top of fight scenes in anime. (Barring legends like JoJo or DB). Although they do change drastically in Volume 4, they are still a treat to watch. So animation is good.The music is...phenomenal. As in, I play RWBY songs on loop when writing. They are blood pumping when they need to be like "I Burn", sad when they need to be like "Cold" or uplifting like "Gold." Jeff and Casey Williams knocked it out of teh park here. SO the music is spot on and the only thing that doesn't massively improve since it can't improve. The characters, although they fall into basic anime archtypes, have reasons for being the way they are or have variations that make them really interesting, like Jaune's deconstruction of the Idiot Hero. That said, there are a lot of characters in RWBY and most don't get a whole lot of development so that's a point against it. But all in all, the main characters get the development they need and are a joy to watch. SO yeah, the characters are good.The emotion behind the show is perhaps one of RWBY's biggest strengths. There is this sort of energy and feeling behind it, something that tells you that it's not just another generic show pumped out to make a quick buck but rather is a passion project by a man who loved anime and wanted to express that. And that energy and emotion resonates with the audience, enthralling them in the show. So yeah, RWBY's got a great amount of emotion.All in all, RWBY is a good show that has it's fair share of flaws. But, it most definitely makes up for them. If you're a fan of aniem that revel in tehir medium like Soul Eater or anything made by STudio Gainax or Trigger, especially Gurren Lagann or Kill La Kill, you will love this show. And if you aren't then at least give it a fair shot. While it has a very long way to go before becoming great, it's definitely very good.Have a nice day!

I must honestly say I was skeptical about watching this anime. I normally watch an anime due to graphics since my eyesight. Once I watched episode 1 I greatly fell in love with how the storyline and characters were; it was interesting and epically ecstatic about how the storyline is. It may be a practical anime to some, but its A MUST WATCH. Look on youtube about how this anime became what it is now. Knowing the background about it makes it that much more enjoyable to watch.

For the season 1-2-3. This show was really good. Animations and story was good, but it was focus on the unique combat action. But the creator died and season 4 is meh, season 5 is just horrible. The story went from nothing special and logic, to magical stuff with bad guys who do bad things for no reasons. + the fights that made the show cool are now horrible to say the least.Plus i really feel like there is product placement for their merc. For exemple : You will see Jaune hoodie, and they make that really akward joke arround it, only one time. Guess what, you can buy the hoodie in their own store for only 39.99$!

This was Rooster Teeth's first attempt into a animated series. From the mind of Monty Oum, this show with really take you on a ride of emotions from happy, to sad, to down right revenge driven. The first season yes is somewhat slow, but due to the long running nature of this show, it should be at least given a shot as it is mostly used as a way to deliver to the audience the world that was inside the mind of its creator. Each season increases in quality and polish by tenfold in the regard of voice acting, Vic Mignogna as well as Yuri Lowenthal join the cast later in its running, as well as in its animation. If you are a fan of a great series that grows and develops with its audience than please give this show a shot.

Monty Oum was the lead animator of this show as well as an animator of Roosterteeth's Red vs. Blue. As it has been stated in these comments, no it is not the best animated show on this website, but it was made by hand and computer in a studio office in Austin, Texas. This work contains the love and care that only a true animator can show for his work. Oum passed away on the 1st of January this year, and while this show "isn't the best" it is still one of the best anime I've seen, the best American anime I've seen, and the final work by the man that was and is Monty Oum. Even though he passed, he will be remembered for both the impact he had on people, and the works he has created, like this one, that will last forever in this modern tech age. For these reasons and more i can only give a 5 star rating.

RWBY was envisioned by the American Final Fantasy fanatic and fan-crossover videogame animator-turned-professional Monty Oum. This show shows that Monty is quite the anime enthusiast but at the same time its something much different.The action-loving and highly mobile characters move 60 fps from scene to scene non-stop here. Anime spends 20 minutes with a lot of looping and camera panning, featuring barely moving characters only to show us occasional fight scenes in between 20-minutes of girls just talking. Not to mention the story here is epic without suffering from season-long filler and side stories.The episodes are less than 12 minutes long and the payoffs start early and come often.

I was down on this series earlier, and I still stand by my opinion of the first 2 seasons (flawed, but enjoyable enough). The third season changed my opinion on it in a huge way, and I'm excited to see where they go next with it. The third season really lives up to the potential that this series has, and finally gives it a sense of purpose (both for the main characters, and the overarching plot). A vast improvement over the previous seasons, and it leaves me anxious for the next season to begin.

I am very much enjoying this series.I find it unique.I like that the characters are based off characters from stories and history like Jean of Arc is based off Joan of Arc,Ruby based off Little Red Riding Hood,Yang a badass version of Sleeping Beauty,Black Belladonna based off of Bell from Beauty and the Beast,Weiss based off Snow White,Honora based off of a Norse god and etc..I like villains,the monsters,even the style of the animation is nice and unique.The characters even though all diverse and different are so badass!This has literally been Rooster Teath's greatest creation yet.I am normally not a fan of American made cartoons but this one is very awesome,and has become one of my top 5! favorite animated series.And absolutely cannot wait to share this with friends and followers of my blog.I cant wait for Volume 3 do your best Rooster Teeth!

Rooster Teeth offers a refreshing twist on anime with RWBY. Having watched many of their video game commentaries, I was intrigued when they decided to produce an anime series. So far, it has surpassed my expectations. The English in this series took time to adjust to. Perhaps it was for the better since no subtitles meant that there was nothing obscuring the intense battle sequences. I found the graphics slightly lacking. However, the well choreographed fight sequences more than compensated for this slight flaw. I also immediately liked the characters. The cast covers a wide range of characters from dorky students to crazy professors. Some of John's dorky antics seems forced at times, but I didn't mind too much. Overall solid series and I expect it improve even more as more episodes are released.

I'm an animator, so this is coming almost strictly from that perspective.RWBY is unique in so many ways, the voice acting although not always perfect, is quirky and for the most part incredibly well done. Each character is unique both in their fighting styles and just the ways that they handle themselves, which is hard to do. even without the actual character models there it would still be possible to pick out the characters just by their movements and that is incredibly impressive.In the U.S. other than Korra, or Adventure Time we lack good, story driven animated shows, which is why so many people gravitate towards anime from japan. This show however shows so much potential as to what is possible. It's made in Austin Texas at Rooster Teeth and still feels like a large budget T.V. show.The first season may of been very rough, and it still has it's moments where they could've put more time into it, but the improvements so far from season 1 to 2 are huge. I can't wait to see where the story goes from here and I hope that this show influences more companies to make good shows like this.I'm just so tired of stupid animated shows that are aimed so largely towards children. Projects like this need our support!

For an anime with such a low budget, the pool of talent put into this series is impeccable. As a fan of both Anime and Rooster Teeth, I had many doubt for this anime when the trailers first appeared. Packed with action the trailers lacked depth and story, this query was blown out of the water. 'RWBY' is a great anime to watch if you are looking for a quick 5-10 minute fix. Although the story is lacking it makes up for this in character development and obviously its action scenes.I highly recommend this anime to lovers of the action genre.

RWBY is not for everyone, much like Gurren Lagann isn't for everyone or Fairy Tail isn't for everyone. However, to me RWBY is an astounding series imagined and created by a group who are much, much smaller than the bigger production houses. Some complain about the animation type, others the voice acting. Are they as polished as Black Butler? No, and to be honest it shouldn't be. RWBY shines as it is something original, and you can tell that the VAs, animators and writers really had fun making it. The characters are compelling, the battle sequences astounding, and the character development through the first Season was very well done. I can't wait for Season 2 to premiere this July, as I'm certain the RWBY team will continue to astound us as they refine their craft.

RWBY (By: Rooster teeth) is truly an example to the entire western industry on how to make an anime good without completely copying Asian country's. RWBY is truly a one of a kind anime that has a great storyline that you quickly get in to, the character designs are cute and amazing, the music is some of the best I've ever heard in an anime (I consider this to be an anime). The only thing that I have a problem with is the voice acting, sometimes it can be quite good and others it's completely crap and sounds out of place.If you can get past that one flaw than this truly is an anime to watch, it shouldn't take you to long to go through it but when you do...You'll be aching for more.

To be honest, based on some of the trailers I was expecting a little bit better. The style of animation doesn't bother me much but I think the project could be done a lot better. It appears that not much time is spent on character expression for most characters. The design on the weapons is incredible, but aside from that it seems very lackluster. The voice acting, as many others have stated, is atrocious for most characters. There is no emotion and therefore you feel no connection with any of the characters. Also, at least half the time it seems no effort was placed into making the mouth movements sync with the voice. I love the basis on the characters having roots in popular fairy tales, but I can't seem to care about them or their troubles. I blame two aspects for this. The first being as I already stated, the lack of emotion in the voice acting makes me not give a damn. Secondly, the length of the episodes doesn't leave you much time to develop any sort of connection. I also think the music, albeit incredible; plays a bit too loud. It seems to distract from what's actually going in in the show. Overall, I say it has a ton of potential and with the right funding it could become something incredible. I would be a supporter if RoosterTeeth started an IndieGoGo to make the episodes longer (15-20 minutes; 20 minutes would serve as a normal anime length), with more attention to design and sound mixing; as well as getting professional voice actors / getting current staff voice acting classes. A very high level reward could even be a guest character appearance in an episode for maybe, 5-10,000 dollars. Stretch goals could allow for additional seasons. Just throwing it out there.TL;DR: Incredible potential failing to meet epic levels likely due to lack of funding. Exceeds expectations for "American Anime" but still quite a bit off the mark. An IndieGoGo campaign could probably fix a great deal of the problems; if not all of them.

By no means is this series perfect, but I'd argue that it is worth watching. I've seen a fair amount of opinions on RWBY. Many say that it is amazing, and others argue otherwise. While everyone is entitled to their opinions, I may as well shed some light on how I see this. The first criticism I see is of the animation itself. Many fans agree that the first and possibly second seasons have some... dare I say rigid animation. The fight scenes are always a spectacle and seem like a dance between fighters. Beyond that, people are quick to criticize non-combat oriented animation. Despite my enjoyment of the series, even I find it a bit jarring. However, as each new volume is release you can visibly see the improvements the RoosterTeeth team has made. You have to keep in mind that they were pretty new to animation like this at the time of RWBY's release, mainly doing some animated moments for their series, Red vs Blue (set in the Halo games). The experience they have acquired over the years shows throughout the late volumes.Oh and if you don't like the 3D style of animation, stop clinging to 2D animation and get used to it.Another aspect that people criticize is the voices. Maybe it's because these people are biased towards Japanese voice acting and don't like English voices anymore. However, there is some justification for this. Many (if not all) of the voice actors for this show are workers in the RoosterTeeth/AchievementHunter offices and by no means professional. Many enjoy hearing their favorite online entertainers doing these voices, and other's notice the lacking quality. But as I mentioned earlier, they have grown as well... I believe...I have seen a couple of people discussing how they did not like the character design, calling them basic and such. To that I say: look closely to find many inspirations. Team RWBY (the character, not the show name) draws its inspirations from famous fairy tales: Red Riding Hood, Snow White, Beauty and the Beast, and Goldilocks respectively. Some connections are obvious, clearly seeing characters based on Joan of Arc and Sun Wukong (from Journey to the West). Others are a bit harder to see at first glances, like Achilles or Pinocchio. Some characters are not seen much or remain relatively stagnant in terms of growth. Others are given [somewhat] meaningful backstories and development through the plot, taking the hardships from their past and using them to move forward. A character's history, motivation, and intent are also shown in the music. Speaking of...I don't care what anyone says, the music is amazing. Jeff Williams and Casey Lee Williams have done a fantastic job with the music. It's nice how the music revolves around the characters and plot, even with a bit of foreshadowing if you look hard enough. Jeff touches many genres of music at certain times, and Casey is a superb vocalist. I seriously recommend you listen to some of the songs from this series from places like YouTube or your choice of digital music shops (like iTunes).Oh and the story... I don't feel qualified to analyze the quality of the plot. I'm no expert on how a story should be told, but I guess even the most famous heroes in popular stories start with a simpler life. But I enjoy it anyways!Sure the first one or two volumes may be offputting to some. You might disagree with me on many aspects of my opinion. But if you look past many of these things, you can see that it is not as simple as you'd think it to be. The series continues to grow, like the smallest spark invoking a roaring flame. You can't just start a fire and walk away. You need to stick by until the end, much like how you shouldn't dismiss it early to make a judgment.

This is undoubtedly one of my favorite shows I've watched in a while. The story is enthralling. The characters are well written. The action scenes are absolutely top notch, and have a lot of variety, to put it lightly. And the soundtrack for this series is nothing short of amazing. From high-paced songs that get you excited to see some action to slower more somber songs that may make you cry and a whole lot in between, all of the music is very well written.

I enjoy RWBY, I'll admit.  I had fun watching all of it so far, but it's not without it's flaws.First season they either ran out of budget or were to lazy to at least draw background characters, second season rectified this.  The animation during fight scenes is pretty good.  Other things, such as when they are running, it looks like they have something shoved up where the sun don't shine.  The voice acting has grown on me, but they also have gotten better as the series progressed.  The first season was pretty rough in this department.First two seasons I don't feel really do much other than build up (*spoiler* one of the bad guys gets arrested, but breaks out later anyways).  Yes, they have awesome fights, and new characters, and someone gets taken down.  But in my opinion, the real stuff takes off season three.Season three is good.  Fight scenes didn't look as good as in season 2 in my opinion, but they were awesome none the less.  The voice acting has gotten better, and the animation is starting to really pick up.  I feel like with this season, RWBY has finally made it's identity. All in all, there are still some rough patches in quite a bit of places, which is why one star was taken off, other than that, RWBY is a solid series, and this season is a solid season.

(Review as of the end of season 3)Do yourself a favor and watch more than one or two episodes before you dismiss this one.Animation: People often criticize RWBY for it's animation, and while it is rough in places and definitely atypical compared to popular Japanese anime and American animated shows, keep in mind that it's amazing for such a low budget, the rough parts get smoothed out some as the series progresses, and it has it where it counts in things like fight scenes.  The uniqueness of the animation adds flavor to the show and while it may be a bit jarring at first, it grows on you.Story: It starts out a little haphazardly in the first couple of episodes as RWBY tries to introduce you to its world and characters, but it quickly stabilizes.  The story increases in linearity and depth as the series progresses.  The premise of studying at a school to become a warrior may sound a bit familiar, but there are little and big touches all throughout that make it stand out from the crow.  The first season is mostly pretty lighthearted, but don't expect everything to remain happy-go-lucky forever.  Episodes are short originally, but get longer in season two and three.  Despite their short length, however, each episode manages to pack a lot in.Characters: RWBY is all about the characters.  The story is as much about the characters as anything else.  Expect to meet lots of fun, quirky characters, that will alternately make you laugh and give you the feels.Music:  I'm not normally a fan of the kind of style RWBY uses, so I mean it when I say it's pure awesomeness.  Oh, and if you want to get a feel for how things get darker over the course of the series (there are still fun parts; it's just that there are a lot darker moments in season 3 than season 1), look up the lyrics for the opening songs of the seasons.  Country of Origin: Yes, it's made by an American company, but don't let that dissuade you.  Who cares where it was made as long as it has everything you love in it?  What are you waiting for?  Watch it!Overall impression: one of my favorite series

When RWBY was just a few trailers, I was actually pretty excited for what Monty had in store for Rooster Teeth's fans to watch. And Monty delivered a fantastic anime-inspired show. Spectacular, over-the-top fights and displays of power along with an awesome soundtrack (courtesy of Jeff Williams). As the series went on, the animation even began to distinctly improve.The first season was amazing, though a little iffy on the animation, voices and dialogue. On the animation's problems were due to the guys and gals working on RWBY just getting a feel on the CGI engine (Poser) as well as working on entirely new characters. The voices and dialogue were a little something but notable because the voices for the RWBY girls, for example, are not really professional voice actors at first (Except for Blake's VA, Arryn Zech) and they needed some time to find their spot as those characters. The dialogue was mostly done by two guys (the dynamic duo, Miles and Kerry!) so prior to this, Monty himself gave the two some anime homework. Basically they have to be watching anime so they can get an idea of what kind of things to expect and what to write. All of those needed some work at first when things first started but slowly improve. Season 2 (Or Volume 2) eventually came around and anyone could tell they really improved. The animation wasnt so clunky or choppy. Voice acting has improved (Adding more characters as well), the visuals even improved. But what really stood out was the very first episode just made Vale look a lot more colorful and alive with actual people in the background instead of silhouettes, actual cars driving on the road, and street signs (The traffic lights especially) are now holorgrams reminding us about the Scifi/fantasy world the show takes place in. Even the shading has improved, from a "Cell shading" look to a more detailed, gradient kind of shading.Season 3 got slightly better with the visuals and even more so with new characters and adding even more to the story just deepening the plot even further. But it's become hard for me to watch with what Yang was tricked into doing.

When RWBY first came out it was pretty low budget and you could tell, but as it went along it gained more viewers and more funding, now it looks great.The characters are fun and have some depth to them, you find out more about them as you go so they don't seem static, the story keeps things moving along but also takes some breaks from action to make sure that the characters stay human.It's a show that I check back with every week to see more.

Okay.  I've watched this show all the way through twice.  The initial watching was "OH MY GOD CUTE GIRLS WIELDING BIG ****-OFF WEAPONS THIS IS AMAZING OH MY GOD THE FIGHT SCENES."The second watching was "Okay what can I find wrong with this show."The show itself is a great watch.  The characters are fun and vibrant, the world feels good and while season one was a bit sluggish in the end, season two picked it up and kicked it into high gear!Now, I've only got one REALLY particular gripe with this show, and it's the animation in some points.  (Watch the episode Dance Dance Infiltration, where Cinder is running on the rooftop and you'll see exactly what I mean.)  But that aside, that's the only REAL complaint I have.  Season one was in itself, the pilot all the way through.  It was a new idea, seeing what would stick as it tossed concepts and ideas at the wall and season two took what worked and ran with it in a really satisfying way.All in all:  Four out of five.  I'd give it a five out of five but seriously, go watch Dance Dance Infiltration.  Like now.  Go watch it now.  I'm complaining about it but I'm also advocating that it be watched so it's like a fifty-fifty deal.But seriously, set aside an afternoon, grab your favorite drink and snack and watch this show.  It's fun, it's explosive and leaves you with a satisfied sensation at the end.

If RWBY is anything, it is a good time and fun to watch. The action sequences are fun and interesting and the story does have progressions and arcs I'm curious to see told. The characters are fun and while the voice acting is not always great; I appreciate this for the fun ride it was and the the nice package it adds up to being at the end. Support RWBY because I have a feeling it is going to keep getting better and better over time.

RWBY being the product of Rooster Teeth has been kind of a love hate relationship for me. On one hand you have a team that brought you action comedy thriller like Red vs Blue. A comical slash dire masterpiece of fringe style comedy action story with a deep dark subplot. RWBY shares much of the deep dark world beneath the world type writing, and the world Team RWBY knows really is just a sugar coated topping.But I had to grit through some just off and rudimentary animations. I was happy and forgiving when I found out they were working on solving that. I do applaud what they poured into these short episodes. Its often more than what some animes put in twenty five minutes to an hour. More RWBY less filler...Some of the characters get annoying but it doesn't detract from the fact that they continue to develop and won't remain the same characters later on in times to come.I'm givin it back to RWBY cause they are cleaning up good and making strange story more strange.And Hters don't like it, change the Crunchy station. More Lolli less RWBY

I have faithfully followed this series since Rooster teeth announced that it was going to be a thing. I have always enjoyed the things they create, and this is no exception.After the first season I didn't feel I had enough to go on, so I decided to wait to review it. I'm glad I did. Putting the animation, and art aside I felt that after the first season we didn't have much story progression. However this season the Rooster teeth team has done an excellent job in fleshing out the characters back story, and giving the show a more serious tone. I'm eager to see how the show progresses.The animation as well has improved compared to the first season when we had black silhouettes for background characters. I'm glad they are putting in a bit more detail, and working on keeping the episode length above twelve minutes. To those people out there who won't watch it due to the animation, or because it is made in America I urge you to give it a chance. Sometimes it's nice to try something a little different.

its so unique. and lets be honest its probably the best looking cgi youve ever seen.the characters could use some more and the episodes need to be longer and please please rooster teeth make this series as long a red vrs blue. its more popular any ways. and apeals to a wider audience....not just xbox fan boys like yourselfs. im just hoping for more this is one of the few anime im watching this season. along with zangouku no terror and barakamon

At first, I didn't like the animation but it grew on me; the characters seemed to be sub par. However, I kept watching because of the fight scenes and funny one liners.
