It's also refreshing how short the episodes are. The first season opening song is too good as well. As this series progresses, you can tell that RT is growing as well our beloved MCs. It's 4am, sorry for the scattered review, give it a shot and I don't think you will be disappointed.

RWBY Volume 2 is an improvement over the first in every way. No more four minute episodes has allowed for much better pacing then last volumes at times brutal slog. Also the animation has received a marked improvement with much better backgrounds and smoother character animations. Top that off with a group of much actually menacing villains and much more screen time focused on the main team and volume 2 has everything the 1 volume lacked while still retaining what it did right (Excellant music and action.)

RWBY is one of those examples of how a show can do a lot of small things right in order to make it great. It doesn't have the largest budget, but the art style is unique, quirky, and memorable. Small details like how blood fluttering petals add a nice flare to already dramatic and intense action scenes. The quirky humour and witty banter between the characters in the side scenarios are what made this a favourite for me; the humour quickly grew on me and because of it RWBY is on the top of my all time favourite animes.

Hmm, a review of the web series RWBY. I know this show isn't an anime but it certainly feels like one and that's why I decided to write a review for it (plus the fact that there isn't much to write about this weekend). RWBY is a series by Rooster Teeth; a small production studio based in Texas who do a lot of different video shorts. RWBY is the first and might be the only series I'll watch from them not to say that their bad or anything but the other work they have created doesn't exactly fit my taste. Anyway, onto the review:StoryRWBY takes place in the world of Remnant where a legendary battle of light vs darkness rages on with humanity representing the light and soulless beast called the "Creatures of Grimm" representing the darkness. Humans power various weapons and magical powers with a mysterious element called "Dust", which gives them the upperhand and eventually leads them to victory. Those who specialize in using such powers are called "Huntsmen" and "Huntresses" and those who wish to take up such an occupation in the future attend special schools like Beacon Academy. Ruby, Weiss, Blake and Yang are four such girls who form a team in hopes of becoming Huntresses in the near future. Hmm, this setting is nothing new; a battle between good and evil, four girls with very different and conflicting personalities form a team, they all go to a special school (school uniforms included) where they hone their skills while becoming closer to one another. Nothing new but it's still pretty damn good the way it has been carried out. If anything Volume 1 is really all about laying down the foundation for the whole series and introducing the characters and the world they live in. The Creatures of Grimm do seem to take a back seat to everything that goes on in this series and that's the only part of the plot that seems to bother me a tiny bit.The premise and synopsis makes it seem like they're an incredibly important piece to the overall story but really the Creatures of Grimm are only given screen time when you venture into their territory like a hunter walking into the woods and encountering a grizzly bear. As long as you stay out of the woods, they're almost non-existent. Besides that one point, everything else in RWBY is incredibly good. What I find most interesting is the situation involving the Faunas or more importantly the White Fang which also forms the great relationship between Weiss and Blake. The Faunas are pretty much humans except they have some kind of animal like characteristic (typically ears) and that has brought about various acts of discrimination and racism. Not to mention the fact that Faunas are typically used as slave labor by the most prominent Dust producing company in the series; Schnee Dust Company. The Faunas attempt to fight for independence and equality and while some do so peacefully, more radical groups like the White Fang resort to terrorism. This only creates a greater divide between humans and Faunas but creates an interesting sub-plot that I really want to know more about. There are other subplots in this series that seem to be converging into one greater event such as Penny's odd origin (I think she's an android; calling it now), Roman's alliance with the White Fang which is strange since the White Fang practically despise humans, Roman's superior and her accomplices. Rooster Teeth really managed to lay down a great first volume while dragging in it's viewers and getting them to beg for a second.AnimationI think it goes without saying, CGI isn't something that can be given an accurate rating number. It's either good, bad or bearable and RWBY's animation is kind of in-between bearable and good. The action sequences are certainly amazing, more thought out and intricate than ANY anime I've ever watched. RWBY is the only series I've come across where I would actually want to go back multiple times and rewatch a scene again and again. Sometimes small explosions can get in the way of a fight scene but this usually happens during quick paced fights. The character designs are actually second the best part of RWBY's animation or more so of Monty Oum's creativity.Each of the characters in RWBY share some kind of resemblance or allusion to a famous fairy tail character or some historic figure. Alright screw the character designs, what I really wanted to talk about are the weapon designs. The majority of weapons in RWBY are hybrid combinations of projectile and melee weapons that are each beautifully constructed. I can't help but love each of the weapons incorporated into this series. My favorite being Blake's Gambol Shroud.Music & SoundThe voice actors for RWBY aren't half bad and it only takes the first time hearing them to get used to their voices. There are moments when the voice acting doesn't seem to sync up with the animation. The dialogue however isn't as aggravating or annoying as Japanese anime or their English dubs where we tend to have strange pauses, cutoffs or the usual "repeat something someone just told you because it's dramatic" thing. I guess in the industry of voice acting, most of RWBY's voice actors are actually amateurs but the scriptwriters made up for it.RWBY's soundtrack is definitely something you should hear. Even if you weren't a big fan of the series, you will most likely love the soundtrack which was mostly sung by Jeff Williams and his daughter Casey Lee Williams. Primarily hard rock with a little bit of electronic, RWBY's OST is out of this world. Admittedly, Casey does speak with a lisp so some words are slurred during a song but nonetheless, it's still an amazing soundtrack. Each of the main heroine's trailer songs were actually slight spoilers to their background and personalities which has only become noticeable after the ending of the first volume.CharactersRWBY's cast are a diverse set of characters and are very relatable (I know it's not a word, yet.), at least personality wise. I don't think anyone these days have actually gone to school to be trained in the art of killing monsters. As I stated before the dialogue and basic conversation between characters is smooth and sounds about as natural as would an average conversation with your friends. Just like I stated before, the issue between the Schnee Dust Company and the White Fang creates a significant change in the character development between Weiss Schnee and Blake Belladonna that I won't spoil for you. The other two members of Team RWBY include the blood sisters (yes, their blood related) Ruby and Yang who share good chemistry as to be expected. Despite their difference in personality, over the course of the 16 episode short series, the girls learn to set aside their differences for the sake of the team. It's a cliche that's been done a couple hundred times but RWBY transitions through it all making it unique as well. The other cast members include two other teams from Beacon Academy; Team JNPR and Team CRDL who each contain their own motif as well. As Team RWBY is to fairy tail characters, Team JNPR is to ancient warriors and Team CRDL is to birds.OverallRWBY is definitely a short series that will keep you interested. What RWBY has done is nothing new but it definitely stands out with great fight scenes, an interesting story and a great set of characters to enjoy. Remember that Vol.1 was simply laying the groundwork and building the Team mechanics for the characters. We have yet to really get into the deeper plot and this will most likely be the focal point in the next volume. Technically there hasn't been an official air date for Vol.2 but expect news on that sometime soon.

The four trailers kinda set my expectations pretty high for this and honestly, I was left wanting more. I was expecting something like a watchable video game with this, because the trailers were over the top and crazy with insane choreography, unrealistic but really cool looking weapons and amazing animation all with an awesome ost. But when it started running, the plot dragged on for way to long with stuff I didn't really care about, the first episode sets up what could be amazing if they stuck what they were good at. The plot isn't bad, it had a lot of potential but it focused on the wrong stuff. I didn't care about the school or the students or anything like that. I wanted to hear more about the criminal underground and the monsters that inhabit the world. We didn't see anything like that until around episode 13 or 14. That's when it gets real and really good. not saying the other episodes are bad, they had a few cool fights but there wasn't enough to keep it as memorable as the last few episodes. The soundtrack was great though, Jeff Williams really wrote some excellent pieces for the series. I not just saying there good, i'm saying they're amazing. The ost is also diverse too being able to go from orchestral pieces to club mixes, it's fantastic. The animation style was very refreshing too. It's done in a cel-shaded 3-d style similar to video games like Borderlands and Telltale's The Walking Dead, but it sames like the budget was saved for just the action scenes as the animation outside of them is average at best. Just look at the now infamous cookie eating scene. The voice acting was actually decent but the lip syncing is pretty shotty. I was actually afraid of what might happen with the voice acting because in the trailers, it was horrible. Overall, it has potential but let's hope that the producers really pull up there game for volume 2. I'm really looking forward to it.

To be honest, it is hard to know what to expect with this series seeing as how its the first of its kind.  An anime inspired western web series by a studio that rose to fame by basically playing video games.  But personally I found that this series kicked the arse out of 90% of the anime I've seen coming out of Japan.The story and characters are a refreshing change of pace from the norm, most breaking out of any  stereotype mold as the volume plays out.  The writers use there time very efficiently, displaying some plot and character developments very subtly, leading to some some big "ah-ha" moments down the road.  It was also nice to see so many female leads that can actually be taken seriously.  Only one or two could even be considered fanservicy at times, but it never comes close to taken over their characters.Oh, and the music is freaking amazing!  There are no words I can type that will do it justice.  The soundtrack wasn't #1 on iTunes for no reason.If there is one flaw it is the episode length.  Some of them are as short as 4 minutes, meaning that by the time you start to get immersed, the end credits roll.  But if you are marathoning it, its amazing.

Pros:Badass weaponry.Badass Characters. Also, characters are lovable.Badass soundtrack.Unique sense of delivering the show.Cons:Somewhat noticeable goofs.Voice acting may be bad but that grows onto you.Episodes are short.Amazing show. Gives a the term "Amerianime" a new meaning. There's badass characters, badass weaponry, and a unique style of animation. Although the voice tends to be "bad", that'll grow on you as that voice begins to mold into that character, making it dumb to change voice actors. The animation maybe bad but that's due to the a small crew working on this, so episodes tend to be short or noticeable goofs appear throughout the show but, then again, it's a small team producing these episode making them more badass for making a more badass show.

Have faith in Roosterteeth, have faith in Monty Oum, have faith in the RWBY team.They've got something going here, something that can last a long time. If RWBY can last as long as Red vs Blue has lasted so far, it'll be something worth sticking with.As for its start, while it has the occasional animation issue or clipping problem, its got great music, great fight scenes, and your typical Roosterteeth sense of humor, minus the curse words.I'm all for this show. Definitely suggest giving it a shot.

RWBY is a bit disappointing.  It has so much potential but it's flaws, few as they are, are just to prominent.Story: 4/5 - Okay I'll admit I'm being bias but I just can't help but love a story about a strong woman who's weapon of choice is a scythe.  That aside, the story feels cliched but cliche sells.Animation: 2/5 - I just can't get over how good the action scenes look compared to the rest of the show.  It just feels lazy.  Voice Acting: 1/5 - I've heard much better voice acting in art school class projects.Soundtrack: 4/5 - The soundtrack works so well with the series.

RWBY is a spectacular internet-made show created by Monty Oum. Produced by RoosterTeeth.com, this show carries many different actions, under the same subject. This show follows Ruby Rose a quirky, and a somewhat childish girl who is granted into Beacon Academy after she battles the evil Roman Torchwick. Roman escapes but Ruby is taken to meet Prf. Ozpin and is accepted into Beacon. Her fighting skills are greater in strength because she lacks a 'fear of death'. Ruby's weapon of choice is her High Caliber Snippier Scythe, know as the 'Crescent Rose'.Weiss Schnee is what most people would call bossy, bratty, and ambitious; yet, in episode 8 we see a kind and helpful side of her. She is smart and strong, using Dust in battle to take things to her advantage. Not much is know about her backstory and we hope to see later on how she got her arrogant personality. Weiss' weapon of choice is the 'Myrtenaster', a Multi Action Dust Rapier. She has a long scar along her left eye.Blake Belladonna is more distant and quite than the other characters but she has a fierce fighting style. Seen in the Black Trailer, she has deeper morals and cares for other human's lives, even if they have wrong doings; this makes me think if she had been granted mercy if she was face with death long ago. Blake shows many cat-like features, including her amber eyes and her bow. She also has great agility and flexibility. Blake's weapon of choice is her Variant Ballistic Chain Scythe, dubbed the 'Gambol Shroud'Yang Xiao Long is the last person on team RWBY. Yang has a very 'fiery' personality (X3) and is seen as the big sister of the group. It as been see before that you do not mess with Yang's hair in battle, she treasures that stuff! o///o' In battle or if she become enraged her lilac eyes turn to a deep red and her hair appears to give off fire. But in times of need, her great strength and skill are valued. Yang's weapon of choice is her Dual Ranged Shot Gauntlets, 'Ember Celica'This great anime brings four very unlikely characters together as they face the challenges and monsters to become Huntresses and help their world.I hope this gives you a little info about the show and it's main characters. This show does have it's flaw here and there with either animation of voice acting, but it still is a great story for when you have nothing to d Learn more by watching the show on CrunchyRoll or Roosterteeth.com-Tie~

I will say this now. Making a good action anime is hard, it's difficult to balance the various elements of plot and motives with the actual fighting itself, and how much of it there is. Animation: Shoddy character expressions (during fights, I look at faces. Also when people eat, drink, and speak), Nice fights (well thought out), Good Character Design Concept (nice weapons!), Why do all the enemies look horribly bad in detail compared to the MC's?? Spend some time on them!!Sound Mixing: Borderline terrible, I won't lie on that fact or try to call it better than it is. It's bad when you see a mouth moving but it doesn't quite try to sync with the words, or when something makes a sound, it doesn't quite "sound" like it is supposed to. The music is played louder to remain the focal point for the audio to overlook the mixing problems.Vocal Talent: Amateur Class 101. Add emotion to your voice, it's as simple as that. Everything else just follows through when emotion is added.Music: No complaints, I can see myself buying a copy of the soundtrack. It's pretty cool.Characters: I feel sort of "meh..." towards them, hard to describe. Just, it feels very plain when you see them interact on daily things but they're hype when fighting. It's kind of a weird mix, blame the story for that.Story: Light and Darkness is a thing I loathe hearing about, when someone talks about Light and Darkness as a plot theme, I think of how many childish stories follow this path. Originality Matters. Anything else? No, I don't quite see how starting an anime with no backstory and simply reused plot ideas are a good idea for a storyline.Overall: despite my criticism, I don't hate this anime. I can't. The fact is: How much "epic" can you fit into a couple of minutes without constantly trying to appeal to fans? It's difficult. However Amateur stuff has it's perks, and in time, seeds grow into something incredible. Hopefully this anime will become something I can talk about with friends, not because it's made by Rooster Teeth (American Anime w00t!! I <3 RvB!!), but because it became something worth bragging about having seen.

Monty Oum (Creator) is known for his action packed CG work and this is no exception. Note this series is a WEB series meaning episodes are supposed to be short. Each episode is split in half to keep content rolling. Even I know this, but I'm still bugged by it nonetheless it's a good series so far (Wished each episode was atleast 8-10min). RoosterTeeth has many other series to work with also so don't complain too much (Red v Blue!). Perks about the series:+ Bad Ass Characters+ Bad Ass Weaponry+ Bad Ass Fight Scene+ Each episode seems to improve from the past due to feedback.+ Voice Acting improved greatly from the trailersNegatives- Voice performance -  CG (Animation) mistakes - Irregular episode cut offs leading to Ruby Syndrome ( Cravings for more episodes and bolstering complaints about episode length nonetheless rewatches episodes millions of time due to withdrawal).This review will update when further content is added to the show ^_^

It's recently fallen short of the expectations I had for it.Volume 1 and 2 were very rough but overall I enjoyed them as they were an introduction to the world and I guess what passes for cues.If I had to rate it by seasons - Season 1 and 2 both... 2.5-3 stars for being entertaining with amazing fight scenes. They lose points on sub par animation in several scenes. (Character movements not looking at all natural.) - and for not having the best story writing.(Even character interactions and certain lines are just completely off and missing the effect they could have.)Season 3... 3.5 - 4 stars it was super solid and probably one of my favorite seasons. That's when  Spoiler Alert! Click to show or hideEverything gets dark. Honestly, a lot of people complained about the 180 from super happy positive almost "Magical Girls" young adults show, to a darker mood - but for the overall story line of the world it makes sense  Season 3 had a lot of amazing fight scenes and introduced a lot of teams  Spoiler Alert! Click to show or hide You'll never see again . Motion and animation had improved drastically for normal character interaction. Not as many cringey lines made it in here.Season 4... 4 stars. A complete overhaul to the animation for the show, more awesome fight scenes and getting a bit of story fleshed out now. It's starting to get to the main course of the world and whats happening. Character interactions are still shaky but much better from season 1-2. There was definitely some good character development during this season.Season 5 - 1 star.I honestly am not going to sit here and go through every issue I had with season 5 but it was a complete let down in my opinion. I feel like the team really stepped away from what they were best at - and it did NOT work out for them. Here's hoping next season will be better.I still love it, and I love the world and will continue to watch it - but just the trend they had set getting better was completely ruined with the last season.

Apologies for the length, but I wanted to be thorough in covering many aspects of the series.  I hope you bear with me.Synopsis:RWBY is a series about the world of Remnant, where people across several different nations live together in peace while keeping monsters known as Grimm at bay.  The story follows primarily an academic team of four girls training to become the protectors of innocent people, known as "huntresses", who train at a combat academy to fight these creatures of Grimm using weapons powered by their "aura", a magical force from within the user that protects and empowers them, and "dust", an external resource imbued in ammunition, clothes, and other applications for various effects.  These four huntresses, together, become Team RWBY, and they get into various sorts of trouble over the course of their time at school, Beacon Academy, while seeking solutions to troubling discoveries they make along the way.Details & Feel:The characters in the story are inspired from (and, in some cases, bear similarities with) characters in fairy tales, history, and folk stories from various cultures.  Perhaps most obviously, the fairy tales of Grimm are overtly represented amongst the members of Team RWBY.  The world itself has a deep and nuanced history and sociological reality that may be alluded to through the various interactions between characters and groups.  Many social patterns bear close similarity to American culture, which contrasts with the Eastern-stylistics of the character models and action sequences.If I were to make comparison of this series to others I have watched in the past, I would say that this show has several parallels to Soul Eater in the narratives, the general worlds, the action, and other tropes.  If you enjoyed that story, anime or manga, this one should feel similar in many ways.  The characters themselves are not so caricatured as those of Soul Eater, bearing more realistic motivations and personalities that help inform the tone of the series as being more mature and more down-to-earth in its themes.The story at its current state has reflected themes of loss, hope, love, friendship, calamity, abuse, coping, control, social justice, destiny, and fear/negativity.  Fear and other such negative emotions are a major driving force in the world of RWBY as madness is in Soul Eater, which creates a great deal of tension and impact within the story at critical points.  Especially considering parallels to the real world, whether at the personal scale or the global scale, there is a lot that viewers may find relatable in the narrative of RWBY.  It has been my observation as part of the fan community that RWBY has even managed to inspire viewers who were at an emotional low point in their lives.The dynamic of the show in terms of time is not typical, being that it is a web-series not designed for TV broadcast, but rather the average internet surfer.  The episodes vary in length during earlier volumes, but most do not reach anywhere close to the 30-minute-time-slot lengths that most anime on Crunchyroll has.  However, they are also not ever less than 4 minutes like how many TV spot anime episodes on Crunchyroll are partitioned.  They may tend to vary between 8 - 15 minutes each.  As a result, a volume will not be as long of a marathon as it may seem, but each episode will certainly not waste time.  Some plot progression may seem slow, or take more episodes than seems necessary, but that will be because some plot lines are carried through several episodes in tiny chunks that are equivalent to a whole 20-minute anime episode. The music composed for the show is most often vocalized and spans several genres, though the most prevalent ones are rock, jazz, and orchestral.  Vocals are generally performed by the voice of Casey Lee Williams, the daughter of the series' composer, Jeff Williams, though male vocal segments are present in several songs as well.  These songs serve as leitmotifs for the characters and their lyrics also allude to some aspect of the character associated with them, serving as another dimension to the lore of the series.  Knowing the lyrics of these songs can reinforce a viewer's understanding of the series as a result, or even alert them of what has yet to happen.Context:RWBY was not merely the brain child of the folks responsible for bringing one of the most successful machinima franchises in history, Red Vs. Blue, through the medium of Halo: Combat Evolved by Bungie, Rooster Teeth.  This is show is based upon the original work of Monty Oum, an animator who died in 2015 after the composition of Volume 3, but before its release.  Monty Oum was known for fan animations such as Haloid and Dead Fantasy prior to his work on the animated segments of Red Vs. Blue in later seasons.Monty's death was a blow that reached personal spheres within Rooster Teeth's working staff for the show.  For Volume 3 and onward, there is a profoundness of emotional content that will surpass even lenient impressions to be held of the first two volumes.  I would assert that much of this work is the result of a shared experience of the entire staff; it is a phenomenon that I struggle to find a comparable case in any industry for.  Monty's very soul continues to inform the narrative quality of this series.With this in mind, it is to be re-emphasized that, as a chilling coincidence, RWBY was set up to be a story with deep and profound themes of loss, coping, and hope.  Starting from Volume 3, the staff have been more prepared than ever to deliver a story that reflects genuine and organic feelings and circumstances aligned to these themes.  I consider this an assurance of quality in future work within the series, but take it as you will.Production Quality and Mitigating Factors:Something worthy of note is that a lot of internal talent for voice acting work, and the production team for the series gradually expanded, especially at the time during Volume 3's development.That said, the first two volumes have their issues as the earliest forms of the studio's work that may require endurance from a critical viewer.  Animation and detail will be profoundly lower due to the production staff breaking into new territory, and the dialogue will start out awkward early on due to the nature of central characters.  This all changes for the better later on as the production team learned from mistakes and improved upon shortcomings.  Some examples of this were the jarring juxtapositions of certain 2-dimensional effects with the 3D animation, "shadow people", bland environs, and rigid non-combat gestures.The first two volumes, however, are very important to the story as character-establishing/developing, world-building, and foreshadowing.  In fact, there are instances where that very same awkward dialogue uttered by characters has meaning that extends beyond anything you see until Volumes 3 and 4, making them valuable details despite their presentation.  The first two volumes are therefore worth your time to engage with first to experience the story the way it was intended.Volume 3 was the last one in which the particular modeling software used for the characters since the first episode, Poser, was employed.  At that point, the animation had already evolved in quality in many aspects.  Beginning in Volume 4, the production team began using Maya, which enables a degree of freedom in character animation that was as yet unseen in the series.  Without going into too much detail, the expressiveness of Faunus, a race of people with animal ears and tails, could be more nuanced and detailed than in the past.  Additionally, the facial expressions appeared a little less "broken" on the faces of the characters while not sacrificing anything with regards to more energetic scenes of battle.  This all builds into an ever more immersive storytelling experience, as a viewer will feel less like they are looking at Miku Miku Dance scenes (as one might mistake as the software used to make the first few volumes) as they are looking at an actual anime.Other Media:This series has an accompanying series called RWBY Chibi.  It is animated in a chibi style using Maya, and bears a simplistic aesthetic due to its nature as an in-between series for the Rooster Teeth production team, having been made after Volume 3 and before Volume 4.  Even so, the dynamic movement of the models in this series goes well beyond the previous Poser models, which is especially important for the impact of its slapstick routines.  If I were to describe the style in terms of proportions, it would be somewhat like if RWBY took place in The Legend of Zelda: Wind Waker and everyone was about Link's size; the show is not cel-shaded.  It is advised that you do not watch that series without finishing Volume 3, as it alludes to spoilers as far as the Volume 3 finale.Current State & Summary:The story itself has only recently completed its fourth volume, and it does not seem to have a quick path to an end in sight.  Many plot lines have split off and begun converging, yet there are layers of conflict that run deeper than what the protagonists are currently aware of.I have awarded this series 5/5 stars.  While there are certainly quality faults in the first two volumes, those faults only go so far in obscuring the quality story being told.  Improvements as the series went on also begin to overshadow earlier points such that your endurance through the awkward beginnings will be richly rewarded.  The particular score deduction that the faults would account for do not amount to enough to justify a 4-star rating as a result.  If I were to use the 5-point scale with decimals, it would be around 4.7 or 4.8 out of 5.If you are new to the series, I hope you consider watching it through at least Volume 3 before you finalize your own judgment.  Should you find that you enjoy it, a passionate community exists for the series as well.Recommendations from a fan to other fans:Every time I have been watching recent episodes, I would then pay a visit to the Youtube channels of MurderofBirds and Puns of Damage to witness their reactions.  They are among several major community figures for RWBY that accentuate the impact of each episode.  MurderofBirds tends to anticipate developments in the story based on current knowledge, while Puns of Damage would provide a heartfelt analysis of social and emotional content within each episode.  Both of these commentators have a deeply emotional and personal connection to the series that will even show in tears, so those who do not feel comfortable with watching real emotional outbursts on the internet may not prefer them, but I consider their commentary to have critically added to my own interpretation of the episodes as I was watching them.  I would recommend giving them a watch sometime.

THIS REVIEW IS UPDATED FOR; RWBY SEASON 4 EPISODE 12 Damn, Rooster Teeth... Just...  Damn... I never thought you'd do it, but...YOU FINALLY MADE RWBY INTO A FANTASTIC, MUST-WATCH SHOW!While the first three seasons were pretty fun to watch and had surprisingly good story, characters, animation and action, its Season 4 which really shows what RWBY should have been all along.The main problem with the first three seasons is that it was clear through the analysis of the writing that the creators didn't really know what direction to take RWBY in. Up until Season 3 Episode 6, the past episodes were practically fillers that had no general meaning or caused much advancement in the plot. This was incredibly disappointing when considering all the effort and the set-up they had for this world; with villains, dust, aura, and ESPECIALLY the Grimm. It was such as shame that they didn't use this potential!But Season 4 is where they TRULY kick it off!I'd even say that the first three seasons of RWBY to season 4 is like the first three Star Wars episodes to Episode IV; the first two were blegh, the third one was pretty good yet still had its problems, yet IV is practically a masterpiece!Finally this show takes advantage of the universe its made for itself by focusing more on the Grimm, creating an actual villain, and making the show a whole lot more darker and edgy! Now I can say with complete confidence that this is a must-watch web series for everyone!NO VERDICT SINCE THE SHOW ISN'T DONE YET

The beginning of RWBY is what will turn most people away from this series, as the series started as a web series by Roosterteeth. Season 1 is cut into six minute shorts with an obviously low budget, secondary character designs are  nonexistant. This does not mean, however, that the series stays that way. Quite the opposite, with each passing season the production value and storytelling ability evolve. Six minute shorts evolve into 15-20 minute episodes and the animation becomes more detailed and unique. Background art and character models have been boosted in quality so much Episode 1 of the series is nothing in comparison to the more recent episodes. As of this review Season 4 is taking the series to new heights artistically, and I only expect more from this franchise. As for the show itself...I honestly was shocked of how much I enjoyed the series. I came in with low expectation after seeing some comments on YouTube, watching only out of sheer boredom. I quickly became interested and the next thing I know I binged the current episodes in little more than 3 days. Likable characters and insane acrobatic fighting scenes blend well with a unique world loosely based on fairy tales from all over the world. Roosterteeth and the late Monty Oam have blended eastern and western culture in a way that only Avatar: The Last Airbender was able to do (with a much smaller budget). The lore and story so far have been almost entirely well connected and engaging while still allowing for some mystery and a desire to see more. Overall the story is without a doubt the best part of RWBY. That being said I have complaints. Thanks to the initially short story telling the show takes a while to get on it's feet, and even in the current seasons each episode can barely allow the plot to move forward, especially with the current arc being quite a bit larger. The first two seasons move slowly, behaving more like a schoolgirl anime than an action fantasy like it wants to be. This, however, is quickly resolved as season 3 smacks you with so many plot changes the series becomes almost unrecognizable. The show jumps from lighthearted humor to grim events so suddenly at times it can leave you in a moment of awe as you suddenly take in what happened. The show also suffers still from a lower than usual budget, and requires brief 3 minute fillers between some episodes, which adds to the story a bit but often remove you from the immersion. And while the story can be at times too much for the episode time to handle the overall plot in more than satisfactory to see. Overall I would give this show a 4/5. There is a lot of potential in RWBY, and it's almost perfect. It is, however, held back by a lower budget and the limits that come with it. But if the recent seasons are any indications they are getting far more money each year and with it more resources to expand. Keep with this series, you won't be disappointed.

I have loved this show ever since I first found it. It is fun and goofy, while managing to keep the serious aspects of the show serious. It is very good at hinting at the ominous future while keeping the characters developing in their own ways. The characters are very intriguing and yeah they might seem like your boring cliche characters, but I believe they are definitely developing them off that as it progresses especially with what just happened at the conclusion of the most recent volume. I would recommend this 100%. However you need to come into this with an open mind despite the animation and the "shallow characters". Keep in mind the characters do develop.

This is the kind of series that makes its lemons into really, really good lemonade.  The budget is pretty low at the beginning and so at first the animation isn't exactly Bones class material (that gets loads better every season), but boy do they use what they do have to its best capacity.  Despite its technical shortcomings, they do so many things right that even many beautifully polished anime don't manage to do.First the animation: It's mostly Poser Pro and it does look odd, kind of like slightly older video game scenes (that's what I kept thinking, anyway) but the beautiful designs, style and and world building among other things more than made up for that, especially as they kept improving as the series progressed.  The rapid-fire action and choreography for the fight scenes is pure genius (RIP Monty Oum, you were truly amazing) and the incredible music (it's all sooo good) just made it all the better.  Every weapon or "semblance" power is surprising and fun to watch (almost no weapon had just one function and the ridiculousness of some of them only made me love it more--the main character has a folding gun-scythe and super speed powers for crying out loud, and even coffee cups are to be feared).The most amazing part of this is the world building and characters though.  They all feel genuinely human, even a lot of the side characters.  That's true for a lot of good shows, but I think this one does it especially well.  There are believable motivations, complex emotions and most of all you can really feel for them, care about them, and laugh or cry with them.  A lot of girls in anime kind of annoy me but I love every one of these characters.  It's interesting too that most of them are loosely based on historical or fairy tale characters and that plays into their stories in an interesting way.  And the world of Remnant!  It takes place in a fascinating world where the moon is half crumbled, Dust crystals grant powers, mysterious monsters called Grimm prey on humans, animal-humans called Faunice fight for their rights or for domination, and hunters and huntresses are taught to protect mankind.  It's complex and mysterious, and really cool.Soo this is got long.  But RWBY is that good.  In short, just watch it, you'll see what I mean.  You'll laugh a lot and cry too and season 4 better come soon.

Okay, so, let me start this by saying that RWBY has made me into such a devoted fan it's ridiculous. I watched the first episode before I watched the trailers, first fight seen was great, mysterious, and I wanted to know more. Then the characters actually started talking to each other... insert cringe here. Yeah so the writing and and voice acting was AWFUL. God, such, cringe. But I thought the fight scenes were really interesting, and so I watched. I got to the end of the season, it was good, not great, but good enough for me to watch the next season. The next season was better, even if it had a bit less plot development. The animation got smoother, and writing got slightly better, and the show starting feeling a bit better in its own skin. Still some cringe, but less. Not much to say except that Monty Oum died. He was a genius, season 3 commenced. Wow. Like, wow. Fight scenes got more original, more glorious, and the plot! Wow, the writing felt not just good, but fantastic. I watched the show eagerly, I watched reactions, I watched reviews, that's how good season 3 is. I cannot wait for season 4, the show is so much more complex than I ever would have thought from just watching the first episode. Also, you should watch the trailers, they're amazing. Fantastic show, fantastic animation, I've cried watching more than once, just, great.PS Don't watch it on Crunchy Roll if you don't have premium. The episodes are too short for all those ads, watch it on youtube, you'll be doing yourself a favor.

While volume 1 may come off as a cliche and poorly written excuse of a "slice of life" or "Magical girl" type anime, RWBY is quite the opposite. The show's willingness to constantly improve upon itself keeps you intrigued alongside the vast and captivating story. By the time you finish volume 3, you'll be begging for answers. An anime that was created by a man with a dream, and four simple colors.Thank you Monty, you'll always be in our hearts.

For fans of basketball, Ahiru no Sora sticks true to the sports roots: game rules, breakdown of plays, and a typical high school life in Japan. An array of characters makes the story very compelling. You already get a hint of each uprising character without it dragging the story. The show has a wonderful soundtrack composed by Hiroaki Tsutsumi, one of the composers for Dr. Stone. To address the elephant in the room, Kuroko no Basket fulfilled it's own ability to bring anime into basketball. However, Ahiru no Sora brings out the beauty of basketball into anime.

I'm not really a fan of sports anime, but THIS GOT ME REVVED UP! The MC is great! I love his perseverance! The story looks really good and I love the animation! I can't wait for more episodes! Ok ok, I got too excited. Here's the plot: A kid that's short and gets bullied a lot enters his new high school for the first time, he heads to the basketball court straight away, but gets stopped by the basketball team members. He then challenges them to a game to get into the team. He then shows them his incredible basketball skills! Action, Fanservice, and Basketball.... What else do you need?!

I really love this anime. I wouldn't say I'm a huge fan of sports anime, but I do enjoy Basketball and this series so far has an interesting and fun story arc. It's light hearted, funny, it draws you in, and you can't help but love the characters. This delinquent basketball team, that is trying to make something of themselves, really does grow on you right from the first episode! It's in my queue and I'll be watching it every week. I'll look forward to it.

It was a little slow at first, but thank god I stuck with it! The next few episodes were amazing! I couldn't stop watching, everything was intense, fast, and incredible. Every shot, every pass, and every jump made it feel surreal and had a real impact! It is also quirky, hilarious, funny, and odd at times, but I am loving every single second of it! I am looking forward to hopefully see this series to go big. It really is an amazing show and I love the art style and characters. It has become one of my top best new sports anime this year!

I have been watching sports anime for as long as I can remember and a lot of the tropes I saw growing up are present in this show. There is a clear inspiration from Slam Dunk where delinquent but talented players come back to the sport, and in tandem with talented freshman, take a no-name team to great success. The premise is almost identical to Dear Boys where a talented, but short basketball player from a basketball family comes into a school whose team lacks 5 players and consists of a great players who lost their love for the game because of their unsuccessful history. But despite the glaring similarities, the show has a certain charm to it, thanks in large part to the cast that makes me wanna keep watching. Beautiful animation doesn't hurt. I'm always excited when a great sports anime pops up and this one definitely has the makings of one from what I've seen so far! I'm excited for more episodes

There's pretty much no flaw I can think of to this show. The creators depict basketball with the proper rules in perfect detail, as well as make an amazing plot for the show. It's inspiring to see the main character, being put down his whole life for being short while trying to play basketball, start to try his hardest to play official basketball, eventually turning a team of thugs who didn't care for the game into a team with amazing potential. It creates inspiration, it shows that even when people constantly put you down you can still get up and make something of yourself, and that's why I enjoy this show.

I'm so excited to see this finally become an anime. The manga began in 2003, so the character design definitely looks much different then what most are used to now. Although i personally love the art direction, i can understand why some may be turned off by this. This series is definitely less over-the-top then something like Kuroko, so if you're looking for something with flashy color lights with characters of all colors of the rainbow, maybe you should look there. Will definitely keep watching weekly

If you're like me and absolutely adore sports animes then Aihiru no Sora is an excellent pickup. The main character is quickly likable, and while some may draw some similarities to Haikyu with a short protagonist in a tall person's sport, their story lines are entirely unique to one another.In fact, they are rather opposite. Haikyu's team is a well rounded group of individuals that support and raise the baby bird that is Hinata. Whereas in Aihiru no Sora, the highly adept Kurumatani has to shape a rowdy group of high school punks into a respectable basketball team.However, they do share some similarities in passionate players, excellent music, and fluid animation with lots of technical terms from their respective sports. I would highly recommend both shows.

I'm not normally one to write reviews here, but after seeing the number of... frankly puzzling positive reviews this show has been getting, I felt compelled to play the part of the contrarian.The last few years have been a great time for fans of sports anime. A new wave of great shows - Hajime no Ippo: New Challenger, Kuroko no Basket, Baby Steps, Haikyuu, Ace of Diamond, and Hinomaru Sumo, among others - have really pushed the genre to new and exciting heights in terms of both storytelling and animation. It was my hope, when starting Ahiru no Sora, that this show would follow in the footsteps of those greats. Those hopes lasted... about 90 seconds into the first episode, but I stuck it out for the first three episodes hoping things would improve. Needless to say, they didn't.The StoryWhen you get right down to it, sports anime tend to be pretty formulaic, particularly when it comes to team-based sports like basketball (or baseball, or volleyball, or whatever). The protagonist, a highly-skilled but underappreciated high school athlete, joins an underdog team of misfits and losers, helps them bond and improve, and leads them into games against a bunch of strong, antagonistic teams, usually in a big tournament.Ahiru no Sora follows this formula to a tee, and brings virtually nothing new to the table. Sora, the protagonist, is a super-skilled, super-positive, super-bland main character who nobody takes seriously because he's a short guy playing basketball (gasp!). If this is giving you flashbacks of Kuroko in Kuroko no Basket, Hinata in Haikyuu, or Hinomaru in Hinomaru Sumo, that's because this trope has been done to death in sports anime. Sora is basically a distillation of the most generic traits of the aforementioned characters, but lacks any of their charm - he's not as quirky as Kuroko, not as relatable as Hinata, nor as ferociously fun and attention-grabbing as Hinomaru. Sora's only real character traits are that he's... relentlessly nice to everyone, and he's super into basketball. Aside from that, there's a running gag where he attempts to confidently stand up to a group of bullies before getting beaten up, but that's about it. After three episodes, he's still pretty much a blank slate.The story revolves around Sora discovering that his school's basketball club has been overrun by delinquents, who use the club room as a hangout and don't actually play the game (again, if you've seen Hinomaru Sumo, this is nothing new). Naturally, his love for basketball and "NEVER GIVE UP!" attitude eventually convinces the team to begin taking the game seriously. As of the end of episode 3, there are only really two other characters who have gotten any development in the show: Chiaki, the token comedic relief character who is characterized as a lazy pervert, and Momoharu, the leader of the delinquents who secretly likes basketball but gave up on it, and is inspired by Sora to start training again. It's not really any more interesting than watching Yuma, the similar delinquent in Hinomaru Sumo, learn to appreciate the sport and develop his skills, but Momoharu's growth over the first 3 episodes is by far the most interesting thing the show has to offer. Sadly, the excruciatingly slow pace of the first three episodes makes it hard to stay invested.While Momoharu's character arc does offer a glimmer of hope that this show could turn it around, far too much of Ahiru no Sora simply feels like pointless filler. Large chunks of the first three episodes are taken up by scenes of Sora's delinquent teammates getting into street fights with gangs from rival schools, alongside "comedy" bits in which Sora helps his teammates peep on the girls' locker room, steal underwear from apartment balconies, and attempts a layup naked in order to convince his teammates to practice, while the actual "sports" part of this sports anime takes a back seat. In all, I'd estimate about 25% of this show thus far has actually been focused on basketball, while the rest is either pointless filler or comedy that falls completely flat.Now, a slow start isn't always the end of the world in a sports anime. Some shows, like Ace of Diamond and Hajime no Ippo, have very slow starts, with more focus being placed on establishing characters than diving right into the sports stuff. If the characters and story being told were more interesting, or if the show were at least nice to look at, I'd still be willing to give it a shot. But sadly, neither of those things are true. Which brings us to...The AnimationSo to start with, I'll just come out and say it: dear God this show is ugly. Considering how many beautiful anime, sports and otherwise, are being made in 2019, it's crazy to me that a show with animation this bad is actually being watched by anyone.The best evidence of the low quality of the animation in Ahiru no Sora is, I think, the OP. An OP is typically where a show will put its best foot forward. Oftentimes some of the animators' most exciting, fluid animated sequences are featured, along with highly stylized visuals and creative transitions to build hype for the show itself. Ahiru no Sora's OP does none of these things. About 2/3 of the OP is taken up by simple long shots showing the main cast doing generic activities: running, hanging out in the club room, drinking water, etc., or just still single frames being panned over. What actual basketball action is shown in the OP is weirdly jerky and poorly animated, with occasional fast cuts to extreme close-ups of Sora's feet or hands to give viewers the impression that he's doing something flashy and athletic... without actually animating anything flashy or athletic. Even if we're not comparing to the best sakuga-laden sequences of the OPs in any of the other shows I've mentioned (and yes, there are 10-second clips in Kuroko or Haikyuu's OPs that make Ahiru no Sora's OP look like it was drawn with crayons), this OP just isn't good - it has very little character, very uninspired visuals, and nothing that gets me hyped up to see more.In transitioning into the show proper, these problems remain. The animation, particularly in the basketball sequences, just feels janky and "off". Forget about the creative, highly-stylized sequences of Kuroko or Hajime no Ippo that turn mundane actions into something out of a superhero movie - even compared to much more grounded, realistic shows like Haikyuu and even Baby Steps (which is far from perfect in terms of animation), the basketball sequences here are either poorly drawn while using the absolute minimum number of frames, or glossed over with lazy shortcuts. A good example of this laziness can be seen whenever Sora drives to the basket against his opponents (about once per episode): the effect is achieved with a single, abrupt cut. One moment he's dribbling in front of them, then the camera cuts to a close up of someone's eyes or feet, then suddenly there's another cut and Sora is behind them, with no actual animation frames showing his movement (and yes, I know Kuroko's Vanishing Drive did this as well, but (1) a character suddenly turning invisible worked far better in a show that already featured ridiculous, over-the-top super powers, and (2) his disappearing and reappearing were always dramatically represented with smooth, stylish visuals and sound effects, rather than abrupt, nonsensical cuts).The ugliness of the basketball sequences feels, in truth, like an extension of the show's overall aesthetic. The character designs themselves aren't terrible, but the show is plagued with off-model frames and wonky, inconsistent proportions (especially Sora's legs in some specific shots... seriously, pay attention to this and you'll start noticing it constantly), even in non-action sequences. Environments are generically drawn with as little detail as possible, which leads to the school and world in general feeling hollow and lifeless. Making matters even worse, the show's overall color palette feels strangely drab and washed-out, especially compared to the vibrant, eye-catching colors of most modern sports anime. I get the feeling that the animators were going for a "grounded, realistic" feel for the show, but didn't really have the talent and/or budget to pull it off and instead came up with something that just looks outdated and mediocre instead.The ConclusionFor fans of sports anime, I can't imagine watching this show and not feeling as if you'd rather be watching one of a dozen different shows that do what Ahiru no Sora is attempting to do, but far better. And for people who aren't into sports anime, I'd hate for a show this uninspired to be their introduction, as the genre has a ton to offer and deserves more fans than it has. The only people I could imagine truly enjoying this show are people who already love the source material (I haven't read it), or people who simply have a categorical love for all sports anime, regardless of quality.And if that's the case, I sincerely hope they enjoy this show - but for anyone else, I'd stay far away. If you want a basketball anime, watch Kuroko no Basket instead. Or, if Super Saiyans playing basketball isn't your thing (and if that's the case, what's wrong with you!?), watch Slam Dunk. Despite having been made 25 years ago the animation is basically on par with what Ahiru no Sora has to offer, with far better characters and story behind it.

I was super skeptical about this anime from the description.  That skepticism grew after the 1st episode, but decided to stick with it for a bit.  The 2nd episode was better.  I still found it slow, but I began to like the idea of a "bad gang boys turn good" story line.  I thought it could have a lot of potential. Unfortunately after the 3rd episode, I'm throwing in the towel.  Although I think the premise with the potential gang storyline mixed in is a great idea, the follow through fell flat.  It's too slow and tedious to keep my interest.  Too bad.  I really though after episode 2 that this was going to pick up.

Overall, for people who don't want to read: I recommend the first part of the series, up to the end of Soul Society, but not past that. The story started out nicely with few bad points, but later was prone to Kubo's horrible storytelling and inconsistencies.Don't get me wrong; I loved Bleach when I started watching it years ago. I even jumped into the manga just to get that extra little bit of story out.I'll start out with the good stuff.Bleach looks damn cool. Who doesn't like Death Gods with swords (not scythes) and black kimonos? Plus the idea of swords with abilities is pretty fun. The beginning (up to early 2006) was promising and I wholeheartedly recommend the beginning of this series. Just don't be disappointed by the recent developments.But, after the several asspulls and Kubo writing himself into corners in recent years, I can't recommend the post-Soul Society part of the series to anyone looking for good storytelling and consistency:1. Most of those seated officers in Soul Society who were introduced (or just shown in cover art) early in the series either appeared a few times or once. Good writers generally avoid huge casts, yet Kubo gave us a huge cast that was largely ignored except in omakes and the little comedy gold mines at the end of each episode.2. The Hueco Mundo arc looks oddly familiar... Ichigo goes to save the girl, travels to another world where anything can happen, fights all the ranked/uniformed baddies, makes a few friends among the locals (who were totally ignored since early 2009), and gains another power. I'll ignore the powerup since this is shonen, but the whole fiasco reminds me of an earlier arc: Soul Society. They're both rescue missions in another world with similar antagonists. Another world, same story.3. Powers are inconsistent. Yeah, this is a shonen, where power can fluctuate depending on emotion or some other crap, but since when did a Shinigami's ultimate skill, Bankai, get so freakishly depowered? Bankai is supposed to be rare, yet all the baddies we see can always shrug off a normal attack easily and almost always require bankai just to show how powerful they are. Just to note, Ichigo was able to defeat three lieutenants barehanded (vol. 18, ch. 152) yet has a hard time with the Bounts (anime only), Arrancars, etc. Unless Kubo forgot about the non-captain Shinigami power levels, Soul Society has little use for those fodder beyond the menial purifying of lesser hollows. Why not just send in captains to Hueco Mundo and the War? Oh wait... that's what they did.For manga readers:Spoiler Alert! Click to show or hide4. Aizen specifically gains a powerup each time he is almost defeated in all of 2010. This is all attributed to the blatant plot device known as the Hougyoku, which manifests the desires of those around it and advances the Hueco Mundo/War plots. It is the cause of Orihime and Chad's powers and Aizen's nearly omnipotent powers.5. Aizen knew about and manipulated Ichigo since he was born. Since when does a plot twist like this work well in storytelling? Never. And, why hasn't it been mentioned before? Kubo could've slipped in a simple "he's grown" line for Aizen, but there has been nothing hinting at this relation.6. How hard is it to introduce a group that isn't like the Visored (Yes, apparently the Vizard spelling is wrong) who are just there to help Ichigo regain/master another skill to fight some new enemy? Xcution will probably be ignored in the future, like the Visored.7. Give Ichigo a cool shockwave skill and everything's fine. Upgrade that shockwave with a black color, and it's still okay. But, nothing's ever been mentioned about a higher level version of the skill that has nothing to do with shockwaves. In fact, it's just raw strength at the cost of Ichigo's Shinigami powers. The Ultimate Getsuga Tenshou is completely unrelated to the original skill.When there is nothing relating shockwaves to raw strength, we can usually assume a powerup like this doesn't exist... EXCEPT in Bleach. Bleach is open to any and all powerups, without regard to foreshadowing or planning. The Final Getsuga Tenshou exists only in Kubo's Bleach, where he probably wrote himself into a corner and couldn't find another way out except with a never-before-hinted asspull of a powerup. Yes, Crunchyroll has this very same skill on the top of the page when I wrote this, but I'm just putting this out there under my spoiler tag.8. After building Aizen up for hundreds of chapters (or since the end of 2005) as a big baddie who gets all these powerups, Kubo rushes the ending and lets Ichigo and Urahara beat him in 5 chapters. Talk about anticlimactic... Sheesh... 9. The art quality in the anime sometimes dips (like most long-running shonen series). The swordfights sometimes devolve into crossed swords, sparks, and angry stares. Though it's probably necessary, the plot advances a chapter every episode, which is already a snail's pace. It's a bit of a waste of time when the same story takes 23 minutes to watch and five minutes (a minute for recent chapters) to read.10. Speaking of reading times, the recent chapters in the manga are filled with full page backgrounds and character faces. Neither are very detailed, especially the backgrounds. The dialogue is sparse, unnecessary, and unimportant. Does it really take a page to ask Ichigo what he wants to drink, another to announce another new character is back, or to open a door? And, why are there half pages filled with black or blocky backgrounds?Edit:11. Kubo rewrote the canon to the humans' powers THREE times. Read the manga or check out this spoiler tag.Spoiler Alert! Click to show or hideFirst, Chad and Inoue's powers came from Ichigo's excess reiatsu, then from the Hōgyoku, and now from hollow attacks before birth. Sheesh...Edit 2:Want to get a jumpstart on how to make fun of Bleach? Take a look at this: http://gliblord.livejournal.com/23557.htmlAnd let me add a quote directly from Kubo:"I think when I am drawing, I wasn't just clarifying the lines, but illustrating the 'air'. Therefore, no matter in drawing or writing, neither words nor lines, but singularly illustrating the 'air'. I always have this feeling of bringing the 'air' into the paper when drawing. How to phrase it, every panel should have a background. Backgrounds are drawn to remind the reader where is the characters situated. However, I feel that it was not that important. In this manner, at the very panel when a character is exceptionally distinctive, I don't feel like filling the background at all."

This anime has a great premise. It has cool characters. It has sweet action. The first 60 episodes are phenomenal, and have you on the edge of your seat. The first 60 episodes are well written, well paced, and are epic. Then... the show gets drawn out. The suspense is gone, the goal that drove the main characters is gone, and they are left preparing to fight an incredibly overpowered antagonist. It drags on and on for 200 episodes, which contains a few epic fights, but is mostly boring and repetitive. Then it picks up real well for two final, epic battles, with a climax that is impressive and great. Then it ends around episode 315ish and you are satisfied with the great ending. Then the show keeps on going. For no reason. And it sucks. So here is how you watch the show: watch the first 60 episodes, skip around through the next 200 episodes (many of these are filler), watch several of the many final boss fights, then stop when the climax ends (you will know when it ends). Then stop. Stop and don't be tempted to keep watching. Be satisfied.

Started watching this on late Adult Swim anime dub nights back in 2006, and was hooked and singing the first ED "Life is like a Boat" with Rukia as my favorite character. Fast forward six years, and here I am, with Rukia finally getting her first haircut (but nevertheless still my favorite character) and the "apparent" ending of Bleach's anime at episode 366. Whether you're a hater or a lover of the series, Bleach gives you a broad gray zone. You can be totally in love with the series for a few interesting arcs, then a nonchalant hater for the boring middle arcs, and suddenly a hardcore fan at the ending. It's all about timing and if you yourself have the time. Bleach is great. I'm recommending it. It's one of those classics that happen every now and then. It rode its wave of fame, and now it's slightly waning. One Piece is the same, even if you disagree, it's the truth. But anyway. Yes. Watch it. If you like the supernatural, interesting plots, and mindblowing cool fights, you'll like Bleach. If you like the cutesy romance and shoujo cliches... well, you should still probably try it.--- A bit of the other... stuff ---Music: Great OPs and EDs. Gendou has lots of them if you want to download them btw. (No aff) But action/fighting music is repetitive. (For example, arrancar arc) You might get tired of it soon. Graphics: Wonderful. Loved the hi-def SD at the end. The beginning quality is pretty good for SD here at CR, but the DVDs are the real thing either way. Plot: Yes, I admit. It's repetitive. Usually involves a girl being kidnapped and later saved by the "hero". But the getting to the girl is sometimes pretty interesting. Some arc endings may leave you unsatisfied. But episode 366 is satisfying. Basically you'll realize that whenever Ichigo gets the same power as you... you can be sure he'll rock it harder than you ever will.

This is both a manga and an anime review, about Tite Kubo's Bleach. Lets start with a synopsis for those who are looking to start watching or reading Bleach. Bleach follows a teenage high school student named Ichigo Kurosaki, who has the ability to see spirits. One day he meets a girl in black robes named Rukia who exorcises a spirit and claims to be a Shinigami (God Of Death) who's purpose is to exorcise spirits and destroy evil spirits called Hollows. Shortly after Ichigo's family is attacked by a Hollow and when Rukia becomes injured she transfers her Shinigami powers to Ichigo transforming him into a Shinigami. As Rukia has now lost her powers Ichigo must become the Shinigami for his town and protect it from attacks by the Hollows.I must say now I love Bleach. Its fantastic, full of action, great characters good story lines and very funny comedy. The manga art right at the beginning isn't totally amazing but as you get further in the art becomes fantastic, very original character design's and just overall amazing. Being a battle manga obviously there are some epic fights but its the fighting concept that makes it very original. Unlike Naruto, Dragonball Z and some other popular shonen manga's this is a sword based battle manga. Each Shinigami has a sword or Zanpakuto that is unique to each Shinigami. While nearly all Zanpakuto look alike (medium sized katana's) Ichigo's is almost like a huge broadsword. Rukia comments that a Zanpakuto's size represents their power so straight away we know Ichigo's character is going to be special. As we progress through the story we find that the Zanpakuto's have different stages which give the wielder different abilities, Much enjoyment from the manga is seeing the wide variety of Zanpakuto's and the different abilities that they contain.Bleach also has one of largest character rosters of regulars ive seen in a while, but the characters are so interesting it doesn't overwhelm the story or other characters. The main characters are Ichigo, Rukia, and Ichigo's school friends Orihime, Chad, Ishida (a Quincy) and a shop owner named Urahara who has considerable knowledge of the Shimigami world known as the Soul Society. As a main character Ichigo is great. He's the strong silent type, is fairly intelligent ranking in the top 50 (no. 23) out of the entire school for test scores. Its during this time we find more about Ichigo's personality. Because Ichigo has orange hair its popular belief amongst the teachers and students who don't know him that he bleaches or dyes his hair and due to that fact gets into many fights with older students and due to the fights (and hair) teachers believe him to be a delinquent, so he studies for tests to get good pass marks so teachers will leave him alone. Ichigo also doesn't like to share his feelings opting to close himself of from the people around due to witnessing his mothers death when he was young, adding a slight bit of tragedy to the character.Like everything Bleach isn't perfect. A problem often cited that doesn't really bother me much is the lack of romance. Its generally female fans who comment on this but some males have found the lack of Ichigo havintg an interest in a female character less convincing than some of the other shonen heroes such as Naruto. Also the story arcs are extremely long compared to some other mangas and can drag out for a good while. Bleach sometimes falls prey to some cliches as well but its so rare its hardly an issue.All in all Bleach is amazing and I would recommend it to any fan of anime or manga. Its exciting, original and has a few good unexpected twists down the line.

The series follows 15 year old high school student Kurosaki Ichigo, and the adventures he has dealing with his rather unusual ability, as a substitute Soul Reaper. This series is filled with drama, intense battles, and some comedy on the side. Overall, I strongly think you should check this Anime out.   Animation is great. When there is swordfights, they almost relate to real swordfighting, technique wise, they have the animations of the sword movements drawn out perfectly. In fights, the characters have special techniques that are fictional, but create a great suspense. Characters are great and thought out for the most part. Each main character has its own story and they all see action sometime in the series. Music is a great aspect in this series. It adds more emotion to everything and it makes certain scenes more important. The music can make the scenes sadder, more action packed, or they describe a certain characters mood. Music does a great part in Bleach Storyline is side tracked in some episodes by filler arcs, but for the most part, Bleach is fun and action packed, and you will want to see every episode.

I have read the entire manga series before watching the anime, and personally, I like the manga a little bit better. Both the manga and the anime are amazing, though. You will definitely become attached to the characters and the plot will drag you in. One you've started watching/reading Bleach, you can't stop. I've introduced some of my friends to Bleach and they've become just as addicted as me. It's an overall great anime

just watch it and get sucked in. from the moment i caught a glimpse of my friend watching this i had to ask what was this action packed masterpiece filled with a one of a kind story line was. after watching a few of the English episodes and catching up to my friend i needed more. i became so into it that just 30 minutes wasn't enough for me so i found this site and proceeded watching. And now the jokes on me because i still have to wait a week or so for the newest releases.

I absolutely loved Bleach. The humor, fighting, drama, and plot was amazing. People would argue against the numerous amount of fillers, but it you trully appreciated the character development and overall series, watching the fillers was never a problem!I highly recommend, but I always give a warning ... there's 366 episodes! Choose the time you start watching wisely, because it's had me pull all nighters.

Bleach characters are Awesome. Which kind of makes it sad because this anime had so much more potential if Tite Kubo had order some stuff in the manga in a different way that would have made some stuff more interesting.This anime has a lot of great action.The down side of this anime is that it has a lot of  filler episodes and it didn't mix in with the anime at the appropriate time.Sometimes it would come in the middle of nowhere and had nothing to do at all with want was going on at that time.So I would skip episode 33,50,64-109,128-137,147-149,168-189,204-205 213-214, 227-265,284,287, 297-298, 303-305, 311-342, and last but not least 355.Add all this together and you get 166 filler episodes which brings down the episode count to 200. If you skip the OP and ED songs 3 minutes and skip the 4  minute recaps on later episodes then you can watch 3 episodes per hour. Bleach anime should really be remade in the future.

Ichigo Kurosaki, is a protag with orange hair and Rukia Kuchik, is a soul reaper. I have to say Rukia Kuchik, is fiery. It's rare that there is a female character in an anime that is both "calm" "edgy" and "energetic" all at once. "Ichi" and "Ruki" interact with each other in a well seasoned kind of way. These two make the show steam like soul food. They fill the air with a nice aroma.Originally I thought Bleach was for kids, and in some ways it is, but it has a deep story that is contrasted beautifully by action and comedy. It's a rare mix.  Other anime studios try to pull this off but it rarely works. Overall this reminds me of Death Note meets Inu Yasha. As far as the animation, the anime is drawn more ferocious than what's happening now. Shonen Jump usually brings this to the table.You can probably watch this with your kids and enjoy it.Bleach is a must "wash". lol.

NOTE*-(This is a proper short review, not a usless 5 star! best anime ever useless review.)-Bleach, an anime centered around Ichigo, a "Highschool student-turn-Shinigami (reaper)" is a good anime. Having a great main story-line with loads of action packed fight scenes. HOWEVER, for a long running anime Bleach in all honesty is only 'Good' not Great. The early episodes of this anime proved to be one of the best and most interesting fighting anime's out there. The main story-line was great however the arcs (fillers) have most definately been stretched out much too long. The fillers in Bleach let the anime lose its momentum in terms of excitement. The fight scenes also sometimes feels too repetitive stretching out for 8 episodes sometimes which honestly makes the fighting seem a lot less intense as some fights can definately be made in half the episodes. The characters also are not very unique in a sense, several characters differ greatly from each other of course, however most of the villains and many of the shinigami are actually not entirely unique. Ichigo, being the protagonist sometimes also lacks what usually a main character in a fight anime needs; in all honesty besides the orange hair, he's not a very UNIQUE 'hero' as if you just change his hair color to black, he can definitely pass off as a sub character.Even with these faults, the overall story-line in this anime as well as the excellent music and animation which is pretty much as good as it gets for any anime proves to make this anime a lot more captivating. However i still believe that this anime seems 'Over rated' as a lot of the time the anime can most definitely improve, luckily seeing as the later episodes after the 'Aizen Storyline' seem to be more fast paced which is perfect for an anime like this. Overall, Bleach - 4/5 stars.The main story-line is great (manga) but how they put it together in the anime with the arcs let the anime down - 3.5/5 starsThe music is great, having epic instrumental music is great for a fight anime! - 4.5/5 starsThe characters, simply can be made more different, especially Ichigo - 3.5/5 starsFinally, the animation is one of the best that can be seen in any fighting anime series, no complaints. - 5/5 starsA great anime for those who love fighting anime (Naruto/One piece etc.) However, my opinion entirely, it's only an average anime out there.

Many of the arcs are really good.  Lots of fighting and interesting storylines, but every once in a while you get a real lame bit.  Not to say that should entirely take away from the show.  It is still a definite must see, but be warned there are parts that will make you say what the heck?!  The action is fantastic, especially when Ichigo (main character) gets angry.  Give it a try, you will be happy you did!

BLEACHBleach' is a story of Ichigo Kurosaki, a high-school student that can see ghosts and spirits- as the main character.Suddenly, a 'person' comes into his room, and -of course- Ichigo react reflecty; kicks that 'person' on the face!That 'person', that feels Ichigo've been rude, says; 'What's that for?' but actually this person is shocked, cuz this person is actually a shinigami (death god, soul reaper) which means this shinigami is a spirit, that can't be seen by most of the people.But, this shinigami isn't coming without reason. She, comes to the world of living, to kill hollows (bad spirits) and send them to Soul Society.Then, after that weird meeting, this shinigami sys her name; Rukia. and Rukia needs Ichigo's help.And that's how it work, until Rukia must give her shinigami powers to Ichigo; which is, actually, kinda a taboo.But Rukia must do it, cuz hollows are attacking Ichigo's house: and, Rukia is actually wants to give some of her powers, but Ichigo's body absorb ALL of her powers.Then, automatically, Ichigo becomes a soul reaper.He kills and kills, then send them to Soul Society, until a big problem comes..Rukia's mistake, to send her power to Ichigo, have been heard by Soul Society, so, her brother, Byakuya Kuchiki [6th company's captain], with her best friend [Byakuya's vice captain] come to the world of living, to pick her and deliver her to the punishment.Ichigo wants to keep Rukia in his side, but he's not strong enough to kill Byakuya, or even Renji.He's the only one who's bleeding, not Byakuya or Renji.But, Ichigo isn't a guy who cries in a problem.He always try, without fear.So he, who was been saved by Urahara, study how to fight and how to face enemies,and after that, with his classmates Chad, Ishida, Orihime, and Yoruichi [sensei], and of course with Urahara's help, he go to Soul Society to rescue Rukia.blah blah blah, after Ichigo fights tons of shinigami, with tons of helps from tons of people, Rukia is save now.But the series isn't end yet! There's still enemies, which is, actually, the former shinigami that died before; Aizen Sousuke, with his gang Gin Ichimaru and Kaname Tousen, plus those mighty Arrancars, Espadas, and Fraccions."Howl, Zabimaru!" -Abarai Renji"Reap, Kazeshini." -Shuuhei Hisagi"Raise your head, Wabisuke." -Kira Izuru"Sit upon the frozen heavens, Hyorinmaru!" -Hitsugaya Toushiro

This anime has some of the coolest music and unique art of all time. The first couple story arcs were truly laudable and what followed showed exactly how lame tite kubo really is. There are ACTUALLY multiple filler arcs that weren't in the manga. These arcs were inane, came out of nowhere, and took away from an overall strong storyline. The ending (of the anime, as the manga is ongoing, but not looking much better lol) was a travesty and did not give what this anime deserved.

Bleach is pretty good all in all yet it does come with its own amount of flaws. Filler is a big problem in bleach so big it will interrupt the main story arc while the arc is happening. Most people just skip these parts, but the fact that these parts exists and become an issue is disheartening.
