This is a great series, the writing is just as the first season was, simply picks up where S1 ended. People are complaining about the animation being different, but it's really not THAT different; if you stop caring, you won't even notice.The story comes across as somewhat more grown up this time, Garo's actions are far more real and emotionally impactful than any monster from season 1. I find all the characters likable, with great banter. Excellent.

Ok so the storytelling and animation was amazing and a contrapoint to season 1 that was only focused on humour and big fights. Season 2 had a great build up, but it ended too quickly. It didnt give the satisfaction needed after such a build. Kind of ruined the vibe and hype for the next episode. I got dissapointed when i came here today to watch ep 13. but there is none. Season 13 is hopefully going to not to long into the future and as good as season 2 and season 1. please dont let us hang on such a bad cliff again

Personally I went into this second season with essentially no knowledge, but with a healthy dose of excitement as I loved the first season. Upon watching it I knew something was up, it didn't feel right to me, but I hadn't watched the last season recently enough to pinpoint it. Now, having realised the change in studio (but more importantly the lack of certain animating staff) I definitely agree with everyone out there, it straight up doesn't look as good, in saying that it doesn't look 'bad' (apart from those god awful attempts at 3D). Despite my initial disappointment, a few episodes in and I can confidently say that this is still the show that I know and love, just slightly less epic. Definitely worth the watch.

S2 is starting slow but having read the manga I feel it will be worth the wait. S2 is exploring a lot of different side stories and is doing a good job building the world and characters around Saitama making him in a way "less" overpowered than in S1, even though he still basically is the strongest being in the universe. I do agree the first episodes feel a bit rushed though, and I hope it will become better as the season progresses.

Season 2 is overshadowed by Season 1's great animations. Non the less, this still feels like One Punch Man. Saitama is being less stupid about stuff, which is my main drawback when i started watching, because it defined him as a character. He has smartened up and feels like a little different Saitama, and its maybe for the better? The main reason i think they did this was because they have to cover so much of the story that dialogue has been shortened down, compared to the manga, and there is no time to fool around for ages and minutes on end. As a result, Saitama grasps the situation and intent of others much quicker than in the previous season. As another result, however, we get less internal dialogue as well.A thing this season is doing very well is character building of the other characters we are introduced to and stunning visuals and imagery. They are very effective at progressing the characters and story, we get quickly caught up on what all characters of interest are doing in the first episode and keeps introducing us to more characters resulting in the world fleshing out quite nicely and at a rather good pace.I wish, ofc, that the animations were on par with season 1, but other than that this is One Punch Man and i love it.

One punch man is finally back! Im not sure why people are complaining, they are basically nitpicking at this point as the season 1 is perfect. The opening sequence is good. It has the same feel as the first season. I do have to agree that Genos look quite different especially with that extra metal shine on him but beyond that I'm stoked.Update:I loved opm2 especially after episode 8. Stick with it guys.

I really was disappointed about the audio tracks and voices, the animation is important and the audio is really important, at least the voice is the most important so the voice actor can express the feelings of the character, and i think that this season we lost that, we lost the good audio tracks and with the new studio so be it, but the lost of quality and effort in the voices is killing me for real. We lost that stupid and funny and enthusiastic Saitama that were have the past season only for how is the voice acting, really if you read the manga is a lot better than this 2 chapters, the only part that i think they nailed it was the "aftercredits" scene of the second chapter when Garou appears attacking Tank Top Vegetarian, that was with a good voice and track if only the complete chapter was like that in audio even with a low quality animation than past season the chapters would be so much better than what it is now. Really hope that it improves

Fights are awful most of the time. Sound effects make it worse, with bad audio transitions.Story is rushed, and that might be an understatement. They are skipping A LOT of things.Animation is so bad sometimes that I have to mention it a 2nd time. (ghosting, weirdly drawn frames that are not in-betweens, crucial animation errors like with the octopus)The only thing that feels right are the music and voice acting, everything should be redone from 0.

We all know S1 was great.S2 has failed to live up to expectations. 7 Episodes in, the story is still poor. Barely anything has happened, and for a parody I feel like there is an acceptable amount of filler, jokes, pointless character and side story - but everything feels like filler, pointless characters and side stories in season 2.The overarching story of the return of the alien race & rise of monsters is super obvious, BUT we ALL know how it will end. One punch.

I am rating this show 3 stars to average out the ABSOLUTE 5 STAR RATING OF PERFECTION that was the first season... with the entirely mediocre second. Proudly displaying unenthusiastic voice lines with as few mouth flaps and as many close-up shots as JC Staff could cram in to do this cheaply... season 2 is a 2/5 even in a vacuum for how forgettable it makes the fantastic source material - but when you compare it to season 1, a celebration of the anime industry's best talent from many studios and works coming together to create 12 truly breathtaking episodes where every second is a masterpiece... and S2 just can't hold a feather to the series-of-light-punches wind of the original.They're killing my baby, and all I can do is hope that MadHouse gets to fix this before OPM gets Berserk'd

I have nothing but praise for Chihayafuru. Honestly.No really. At first I didn't even  consider watching this anime because the art is different from regular animes such as Shugo Chara. I gave it a try because there were no animes that appealed to me but i really wanted to watch a new series. The first episode you're thinking: "Ok..the art is fine...I can get used to this..." and then before you know it you're swept away by the story.  No. This is not a Pokemon card game-like show. No. It's not a fantasy card game anime like Yugioh (my brother watched that. whatever)It's a Japanese traditional card game. It's real world; no fairies; no magical powers (but talent that might as well be magic!) It's a series you NEVER would think you'd watch and before you know it you're watching it; dying to see what comes next, and thinking it's one of the greatest animes you've probably ever watched. The storyline is simple, the music is fine, the characters are lovable, and the animation is uniquely beautiful. No sexual explicitness like most animes here on Crunchyroll. (there goes a couple people) An anime that at first might strike you as boring but is most  definitely not. Watch it, and you might just love it. 'Nuff said. ~_^

I loved Chihaya Furu from beginning to end.  I can't believe how into the kurata matches I became.  I loved the animation.  It was "soft," but fit the dreamlike state and mindset of the lead character, Chihaya, and her ability to pull people in.  The writing is very good.  The characters were written with great care and chemistry which was expressed exceptionally well by the actors.  The only problem with Chihaya Furu is that it was too short.

Before Chihayafuru, Karuta was a game that was almost completely unknown outside of Japan. I typically stay away from shows like this, even if it's based on real games (ex. Hikaru no Go), but this show is different. I've watched the first 50 episodes that have been released to this point, and it looks like it may be another year or so before/if we get Chihayafuru 3 since the manga is not that far ahead of the anime as of July 2013. The recent developments in the anime and manga all point to a very strong possibility that this show is destined to have exactly 100 episodes, a very appropriate number for a show about Karuta. I have fears that this is the final episode, though, knowing Japan. Cancel the great episodic show in favor of 12-episode garbage you can animate, voice act, edit, etc etc and crap out in just 5 months.I can already see where some of the main plot is going, but I do find myself emotionally invested with the characters. It's a great anime (please don't go bonkers because I dared to only give it a 'great' 4-star rating. I don't hand them out like dog treats), enough that I'll be spoiling myself by reading manga as it's released from here on out. However, this is definitely one of those shows that needs to be animated.The odds of Karuta catching on in the United States are zero, but I'm sure there's a couple of people that have read the Ogura Hundred Poems.This is a very hard show to translate. Some of the poems seem lost in translation, but others are not.I didn't notice any deep animation flaws like other shows typically do, and the music is memorable. I needed a show to help me forget about that awful Amnesia show I saw that was only 12 episodes, and 50 episodes of a show that knows what it's doing was just the ticket.I've heard unfortunate rumors that there will be no 3rd season, and that the 2nd season was only made to promote the manga. Sales of Blu-Ray and DVDs are low in Japan. This may be the last we see of Chiahayafuru, so do what you can and fight to have all the manga volumes released in North America and all over the world.

My first impressions about this anime were very similar to everyone else's; I assumed it was going to be a boring story about a girl and a bunch of cards. The plot didn't seem to me like something that would be able to grasp my attention. But it amazed me after I watched the show, to what degree I was proven wrong.This show is just magnificent- no other words can honestly describe it. The story is rather predictable and the way the plot line unfolds is rather revealing. We know how its going to end, but the journey to the finish line is what we really want to know. The characters are truly the gem of this entire story. They feel so real and unique and develop in unpredictable ways. Suetsugu Yuki is a brilliant mangaka; she was really able to grasp the essence of Karuta and its 100 poems and string them into her characters thoughts, actions and perceptions. You meet the characters, and you truly to get to know them- their weaknesses and inner struggles, who they see as their foils and their own reasons for playing Karuta. The characters work hard; they are not perfect; they don't strive for perfection, rather they find faults in themselves and try to improve; they are also not unrealistically strong- rather they become strong.The story is such a refreshing breath of air! I have never come across a sports animation in any language, that could actually make me want to play the sport that it portrays!! Overall, the show really isn't just about the sport, it can teach you things too. We can relate to the characters in more than one way and what they learn can actually be life lessons for us to. The animation is so beautiful; I salute to the show's directors; they have not disappointed me. The music is also so inspiring.  Chihayafuru truly brings out the beauty of Karuta and the passion with which its characters play.

I have had a deep love of anime since I watched Princess Mononoke for the very first time when I was around 10 years old, followed immediately by Evangelion which I wasn't even able to conceptualize at that age but still had an awe for.Over the many following years, I have watched anime that have popped up or snatched my interest until recently when I've begun to take interest in not only anime again but Japanese culture in general as I move towards my foreign language major.Chihayafuru was not something I imaged myself ever wanting to watch - having been raised on the likes of Evangelion, Ghost in the Shell, Cowboy Bebop, Trigun and other classics.However, I became a Crunchyroll member after watching SAO and found a desire to support such a nice website and community. After becoming a member I decided I wanted to watch things that others had highly recommended in order to slowly widen my perspective of the genre.Chihayafuru is now among my favorite anime of all time. I never imagined myself getting engrossed into the dialogue and character development as much as I have. Each character is quietly developed or explored through their effort to improve themselves, like pages of a book being slowly turned through each episode.The writers of this anime are quite brilliant - the poems read in each episode often reflecting on each character's inner struggles or goals as a mirror of their self desire as they mature and grow up together playing Karuta.I find the art and animation crisp and uplifting to watch, especially in the more humorous parts when Chihaya is embarrassed or mortified by something. I would recommend this to anyone who isn't sure if they would like it - because before I watched it myself I was in the exact same place.

Who would've thought that watching an anime about a card game could be so greatChihayafuru is charming and pleasantly heartfelt. What I love about the series besides the fantastic characters is how the storyline unfolds perfectly. There's emphasis on how the characters develop into genuinely interesting and unique personalities. It keeps you in suspense as the characters' romantic overtones and relationships unfold, and entertains you with good humor, and a perfect slice of life without feeling rushed like other series out there. Shows like Chihayafuru is what makes anime worth watching.

I fell in love with this series in the first few episodes. This series is cheesy, girly, emotional, dramatic, all the good stuff that can make you cry. The music selection is not a huge one but they use them at the perfect times to pull on your hearts' strings.Later in the series, some of it can feel repetitive and the characters don't make much development (Especially episode 16 which you can literally skip) but if you can past that hump, it's still good. The animation is also very smooth and beautiful. They make some animation shortcuts but they are used well.

The first couple of episodes to Chihayafuru have been beautifully solid and I intend to see this series through.The artwork is lovely, particularly the character designs. The relationships between the main characters and their background stories are relatable and very human. You can really lose yourself in an episode thanks to the steady pace of the storyline. The introduction to the game of Karuta was handled brilliantly. What sounded like a simple card game in the description of the series turned out to be more challenging and intense than expected and I found myself wanting to know more: http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/KarutaI think this series would be most enjoyed by a 16+ predominantly female audience as it has elements of a mature nature and the stirrings of complicated romances and raw emotion.I look forward to the release of each new episode!

Chihayafuru is a beautifully drawn, somewhat slower paced, slice-of-life/sports fusion anime. Centering around the competitive card game Karuta, the show skillfully depicts the characters and their changing relationships to both Karuta and each other. The contrast between the main characters' younger and present day selves, and the maturity with which the show treats them provides a character depth that I haven't seen in most anime. However, the show is also chock full of humorous and goofy moments, which provides a nice balance. Additionally, the use of music and sound within the show, especially the reading of the Hundred Poets, adds an element that fans of the manga will appreciate!

TL;DR: Emotional, sportsy, fun. Kind of slow pace. Worth the watch/stick with it. I did not start Chihayafuru until the very end of the first season. Initially I thought it seemed kind of lame according to the summary. I don't watch "sports" animes and this seemed like that. When I started hearing from a lot of people that it was one of the best shows of that season I changed my mind and gave it a chance - I'm very glad I did. Story: 5/5   (Pace: 3/5) Definitely something I've never seen before. It is refreshing to watch something that is not like x number of animes. There's a good mixture of romance, comedy, sport, and SoL/School. The pace is probably the biggest 'issue' of the show. Personally, I don't mind it much. It's rather slow, sometimes a single match lasts multiple episodes. I think part of the reason for the pacing is to not catch up entirely on the manga. Characters: 5/5 I love all the characters. The development, like the pace, is slow. My fondness grew each episode. It may just be that I get emotionally attached easily, but I've come to care a lot for the characters and their well being. Art: 5/5The artwork is beautiful. The fast movements of Karuta appear smooth.

oh my word where do i even begin???? characters. every single one of them is relevant. doesn't matter how small a part they play, they all have dreams and feelings which the anime makes a point of showing.they are extremely relatable too, dealing with feelings of incompetence and other emotions that we all struggle with.The game itself. Its very intense and exciting and dramatic and its called karuta .yes, you've probably never heard of it *puts hipster glasses on* but thats okay, because they explain it really really well! by the second season you will probably be able to play it yourself (if you can read the cards) animation gorgeous. just gorgeous. its so pretty it makes me want to cry. and the way they use it makes it almost seem magical, just watch when they are playing and and and.... gosh can't even explain it its so awesome.story touching and heartfelt. you will cheer these characters on with all your heart. you cry when they cry, are happy when they are happy, and so on and so forth. there is romance in the story (taichi love forever!) it is important but not the main focus, instead it's weaved in throughout the story.conclusion watch it, thats all i can say, just watch it.add on cause i read some negative reviews, this is a sports anime that is first and foremost about karuta. that's how it is. so they will be playing karuta, talking about karuta, thinking about karuta for most of the anime. character development is not on the very top of the to do list (although there is plenty of it)

This anime may start out with an incredibly slow pace, but if one sticks with it, it is an amazing series to watch. The best thing about this anime is the fact that it develops over time, especially with each and every one of its large cast of characters. I highly recommend others to watch Chihayafuru for three reasons: the characters, the animation, and the experience of watching karuta itself. All of the characters are very original, unique, and well-written. Whether they are major or minor to the plot, I can assure that nearly EVERY character in this show gets some sort of development. Two standout characters are Taichi and Shinobu, both of whom are complex and interesting to me. I also love the main character, Chihaya, which is an unusual-yet-welcome experience for me.The animation of the show is simply stunning. Rather than cutting back as the show continues over time, the animation rises in quality as the show moves on! The show is filled with bright colors and tranquil scenery. Watching Chihayafuru has really made me want to visit Japan, just because of the beautiful way it paints a picture of its ancient country. This show has also introduced me to a new sport: karuta, an ancient Japanese card game. Karuta is the sole passion of Chihaya, and over the course of the seasons, the viewers are able to watch her develop her skills at it. It is a sport of memorization, strategy, and mental stamina. Each character has seemingly different styles of playing, which is always interesting to watch. The show does a great job of making each match intense and unique from one another. Overall, I give this anime 5/5 stars! I hope to watch a season three!

I have to admit that when I started to watch this show, I was not expecting it to be this good. Chihayafuru was, maybe (at least for me), the most constantly good show from Oct '11 to March '12 (tied with Mirai Nikki). Chihayafuru does an outstanding job of teaching the viewers the game of "karuta", and, more amazingly, it makes it really entertaining. The show gives an excellent written story of drama, comedy, and slice of life, (some art history too) all perfectly balanced. The cast of characters all have their own well-explained backgrounds and unique personalities, while also introducing new characters towards the end which you just know will have an important role in the hopeful second season. The soundtracks get better as the show goes along, as they help set the moods for all the different kinds of situations that the lead characters end up in. Finally, I have to say that this series provided a story that, even though it is still incomplete, has me completely hooked up and counting the days until the next season starts. Hopefully, that day will come soon, this show deserves and should get more attention. Great final episode. Everything does not have to be action in order to entertain. Masterful show for me.Masterpiece95/100.

When I first noticed this simulcast being added, my interest was in no way piqued. I didn't like the red lettering, or the simple font used for the title in the banner, and the characters didn't look too interesting. Plus, the card at the edge of the banner reminded me of hanafuda cards and I remember trying to play a game with them before and failing miserably at grasping the point of the game.I only checked out Chihayafuru when I was out of options and by chance, one of the screen caps used for an episode preview showed Chihaya looking cuter and more beautiful than usual (at the expense of sounding superficial, which I will admit I am). I am so not sorry that I did. This karuta game is nothing like what I imagined. In fact, I never even thought that a game like this could be played with cards, let alone competitively at a professional sport level. The concept of having to memorize 100 poems and then matching the second verse (printed on the cards) to the first (being read aloud) was so intriguing that I was compelled to watch more and see what strategies the characters will learn to improve, even though having to read the translations of the poems is somewhat distracting from the flow of the anime and the dialogue. I can definitely see this being a huge hit in Japan since the poems and the cards and the mention of the different types of cards can be easily understood by someone with a decent grasp on Japanese.Three or four episodes in, I definitely thought that Chihayafuru is reminisce of "Hikaru no Go", which isn't a bad thing at all, in my opinion. I remember loving Hikaru no Go (thought I never watched the anime or finished reading the manga) because I was exposed to a world that I never knew existed, while it actually held a lot of significance. Being educated about foreign culture is always interesting, especially when you get to see the very different type of skill sets and amount of talent required to become masterful at these mentally (and in karuta's case, physically also) challenging games. You get to see a type of amazing that has been hidden away, like discovering a treasure that was there all along.I love the art style, too. The way the eyes are given such beautiful and natural looking colours along with depth, the way petals are animated, the picturesque nature scenes, and the cloth patterns in Kana-chan's kimono shop! So breath taking! The animators really know how to place emphasis where it's due! Character design art wise is also very good. Always love the way Chihaya is drawn, child and teen versions.Music is pretty fabulous as well. Both the opening and ending themes suit the anime really well, especially the ending. Really compliments the classical poems. Background music sets the mood well, and I like how they always use the "swish" sound effect whenever players grab for cards. It really helps emphasize the speed needed for the game. Really makes it exciting.I like all the characters, but I don't know if it's because I'm jealous or something, I definitely like the two boy characters much more than Chihaya Ayase. She has all the perfect qualities to be the heroine, and she redeems herself every time by realizing her mistakes, but there is just something about her that gets on my nerves sometimes. Maybe it's her unrealistic commitment to the game, maybe it's her unfounded stubbornness, or maybe it's just because I don't understand why these two great guys are fixated on her, while she's so dense about romance, it's like even Superman wouldn't be able to see through her with his X-ray vision. Her best quality, in my opinion, however, is that she has a strong sense of righteousness and equality. In the end, when she forms the karuta club she doesn't care about appearance or popularity or perks. She rallies in a mixed bag of misfits and you can tell that later on, they will all be extremely grateful to her for it. I'm sure her unbiased nature is also what attracts Taichi and Arata to her.As riveting as the karuta games are, and also their journey to greatness, I have to say I think I might be watching this anime for the love triangle between Chihaya, Taichi and Arata. I'm almost certain that it is only Chihaya who doesn't realize this is going on, but I love the way it's going so far at episode 10. The romance side of the plot is progressing and I imagine Chihaya's realization of her romantic feelings will only make her a better player at karuta. I'm really glad I gave Chihayafuru a shot, because it is beautifully written and animated, and I would definitely recommend this to anyone looking for a good romance or sports/game anime. Both the karuta and the love triangle compliment each other and make it more interesting and compelling overall.Last comment: The reason why it is titled Chihayafuru is by far one of the best titles and explanations I have ever seen/heard. Smart, sweet, meaningful, and romantic is a wonderful combination as characteristics for any kind of title!

I admit, I was compelled to join those who had written a review after first episode or two.  However, I felt that it would not do the series justice by writing one so early and having to revise it a few times.  Now that at the time of this review, the eleventh episode was released for subscription members.  I feel that I can give a better opinion than if I wrote one on the first episode or two.  Initially what brought me to Chihayafuru wasn't an interest in the card game, or the poems themselves.  It was the animation quality that I had witnessed in the first episode.  It wasn't until after I had watched the first episode that I had that urge to watch more, and so I waited.  I waited until more released, that gave way when episode six was released.  Since then, I've joined many who wait week by week for the new episodes to come by.As a tournament/sport style series, I was surprised by the amount of heart that's put into the characters.  I was a bit cautious about giving the story a five, but now that so many episodes has passed by, I feel that this is what it deserves.  As Chihaya grabbed more members for a karuta club for her school.  While I found Chihaya's character to be a bit unrealistic even during the childhood scenes.  It wasn't in a bad way.  It works in the way that she interacts with everyone around her.  Chihaya is definitely the spice that makes everyone in the series work.  Without her, they all seem a little bland.The music is largely background and complimentary music, the opening and ending sequences are nice pieces.  While there's not much I can say about it, when it comes in, it definitely adds a good feeling to the scenes.The animation quality is clean and sharp.  The only times I noticed drops in quality isn't during the quick movements during the karuta games, or the background scenes of the city, countryside, or in a train.  It's during the scenes that have exaggerated faces which are intended to look the way they were.  That's the only downside.  The way the cards were soaked up by water after they fell in a puddle, the way tears started to well up.  The small moments are excellently animated and it's hard to spot any flaws.With almost half the series watched, and another half to look forward to.  I can only imagine how this will end.  If it continues this pace, this can easily become one of my favorites series, and so far has become my favorite series of 2011.  In this fan's eyes, it's not Christmas that I look forward to, or the New Years.  It's the upcoming episodes of Chihayafuru that I've constantly looked forward to week after week.  As I long for, or rather escape the idea of a conclusion.  I can imagine the thoughts I put forth for this review won't change much, and if any it could only praise the series more.  I only hope for a conclusion that can work well for a manga series that's ongoing.

I watched this anime to of curiosity,, because I like poems I got deeply attached  with the story as well, like Chihaya (the heroin) fell in love with Arata since they were young because of the game. Little did she know that his other childhood friend, tai chi is in love with her and is doing his best to match up with Arata's skills just so Chihaya would notice him. On top of that, this anime made playing Karuta  exciting, how the poems are related to their relations and so on.

This series really defines what a good anime should be like. It is based off a very old card game called Karuta where the object is to steal cards placed between two players. Sound boring? It is anything but that. It is so intense and the manner in which they progress the matched and the interactions is so well done I can't imagine anyone not enjoying it. Its very funny too! Lots of characters but its so easy to keep track of everyone cause they all exhibit such personality.Butterflies in my stomach the anxiety will overtake you. Biggest let down is when the credits role. Sun of a---!If you like game play animes like "Hikaru no Go" this one is for you!Just a warning though at 50 episodes the series doesn't technically end and can still continue so you may have to finish by reading the manga unless they come out with more later! Still very worth viewing though.

This show was good in a awkward kind of way. Chihaya is very airheaded, but she has the determination of a bull LOL. I LOVE TAICHI !!!!!!!!!!!!!! everybody is saying who they want to go together. like taichi or chihaya or arata and chihaya. For me it would definetly be taichi and chihaya. They've known each other for the longest and they have more chemistry, well to taichi they do. its kind of a one sided love. she just don't notice how he feels about her. Enough of me rambling on and on LOL. I would reccomend this show to everyone!!!!

This may be one of the best slice of life "let's make a high school club!" anime that I've ever seen.  It took me a long time to dredge up the motivation to start an anime that is about a niche Japanese card game that I've never played and will never play, but this one is really about the characters first and foremost.  The game in question has simple enough rules that I can easily follow what's going on, and coupled with unique likable characters, I really get the feeling while watching it of a coming of age sports movie.  The show has it's weak points:  Some boring episodes with an over-emphasis on the Karuta, and some of the relationships between the characters gets a little stale after a while.All in all though I really liked this one and I would happily recommend it to just about anyone who appreciates slice of life anime.  I'm looking forward to season 2 in January.

I generally avoid animes that are about board games, cards, or "sports" because they generally focus so much on the games/sports that the characterization and drama are totally left out, aside from "game drama". By this, I mean that all of the "draw" of these sorts of animes is "who's going to win!?". That... gets boring after an episode or two... but this anime, was out of this world!!!I'd never heard of Karuta before this, and when I looked it up, I realized it's very rare outside of Japan... but gosh this made me want to play it! The characters were captivating, and you could clearly feel every step of the way with them. When someone lost, or won, or had a turning point, you felt it too! It's very rare for me to get worked into an anime like this, let alone stay up all night to finish the series. In fact, I enjoyed it so much, I instantly went looking to see if there was a second season, which has apparently been announced! I cannot WAIT! This is definitely an anime I'd recommend, regardless of your tastes. It'll definitely be a new, refreshing experience. : )

What originally drew me to this anime was it's stunning art style, especially in it's coloring. I first came across it a Taichi x Chihaya amv. The amv didn't show any clips of the main premise of the show, the card game Karuta, so when I started it I was surprised. I thought this was going to be just another shoujo school love story, but it's more than that. The love tones of the story are very prevalent, but not suffocating. They're not the main interest. This show has wonderful moral applications about determination through failure and through victory. It has real life reactions to things, real pain, real loss, and real joy. It has good role models of both genders in different types of situations, you can find something to relate to in all of them. Chihayafuru teaches never to give up on your dreams, no matter how hard they seem or how long it takes, they are always reachable if you never let go of your passion.

To think that I almost didn't watch this. I was turned off when I read it was about a card game. But something compelled me to try it, and I'm so glad I did!Although the story is a bit predictable, it's realistic enough that you can connect to the characters, and extraordinary enough to keep things interesting.This series is so rich in culture. If you look up karuta on YouTube, you'll see so many Chihayafuru fans that went to look it up. Great exposure. And the characters' passion for the game and the poems made me look up the poems to read myself.It's a fun, smart, and endearing series. -YubochiThis pretty much was what I was about to say, haha. Chihayafuru is a very beautiful, original, piece of work and I will be buying this box set once it comes out to show my support for its creators.

To think that I almost didn't watch this. I was turned off when I read it was about a card game. But something compelled me to try it, and I'm so glad I did!Although the story is a bit predictable, it's realistic enough that you can connect to the characters, and extraordinary enough to keep things interesting.This series is so rich in culture. If you look up karuta on YouTube, you'll see so many Chihayafuru fans that went to look it up. Great exposure. And the characters' passion for the game and the poems made me look up the poems to read myself.It's a fun, smart, and endearing series.

Hyakunin-isshu which is called Karta is a quite new theme for anime, I think. So, Chihaya started hyakunin-isshu after she met Wataya? I wonder what happend to Wataya, he didn't return a greeting card of new year.  Hyakunin-isshu is called Karta in this anime. Players try to get cards which have half part of Tanka, most of them are from Kokin waka-shu, that was treated as a text book of Tanka (Old poem which has 5 7 5 7 7 sounds).  In this game, players don't have to understand what these tanka mean.As Ooe kanade said in Episode 6, Hyakunin Isshu were tankas Fujiwara Teika selected and they have translations in many ways. Yes, "Chihayafuru......." is a poem of burning love. I like this.

I was honestly so surprised how much I got into this anime. I'm really big on having major progression in the romantic aspects, but for some reason I was way more excited on the  growth of them playing karuta. I'm super happy I started this now and not back in 2013 like some of the people in the comments since it's apparently coming back next month. JUST IN TIME FOR MY BIRTHDAY. Reply to me if you have any recommendations for me to watch. Ill accept all even if I've seen them. Ty

I don't usually go for a sports anime and when I have, I rarely finish them. However, this anime was extraordinary in all aspects. It had an absolutely beautiful art style and the way they do everyone's eyes really draws you in. All the characters were very unique in their own ways. I really like how all the characters took the time to build everyone else up and give them the courage to do anything that they desired. The sport of this anime; Competitive Karuta, was and is a very intense and captivating game. It really inspired me to want to try a martial art or to even learn this game myself. The rules, the 100 poems, as well as the meanings behind the poems was extremely fascinating to me. This anime will have you more intrigued than any other sports anime out there. I truly hope that you will take the time to watch this, in my opinion it is well worth the watch.

Chihayafuru starts to tell a story of three friends raising to become amongst the best Karuta players but along the way more players are joining with the teens. The protagonist Chihaya Ayase is a girl who met talented Karuta player Arata Wataya and was inspired to start playing it as well with her friends. One of the best things I liked about it is the plot that makes characters grow so much. At the end of the second season, everyone has already grown into a whole new person in a good way. I like the role Chihaya has, which is to motivate everyone else and herself to become better at the game. I think we all could learn from her a few things. Finally, let's get to the Karuta. I am so impressed by how well the animation of the hands and cards flying is made. The whole sport is made into super intensive and every match is a struggle to win. I love how the players analyze the game and actually show the struggle they are having. Before this show, I didn't even know that so cool sport called Karuta existed. The show still teaches you everything so well that it's easy for you to get into the world of Karuta. I would absolutely encourage everyone to watch the series for several reasons, which the important ones are the fact that it teaches you amazing sports Karuta and it's really good motivational show that says's you should always chase your dreams cause if you want them hard enough they can come true. Only sad part is that the show ends pretty unfinished and sadly we probably never get a new season to finish the story what manga had.

This anime is one of the best animes I have ever watched.I have nothing, but praise. Chihayafuru is an anime everyone should watch. This is the only anime I have reviewed on CR, so that says something about the quality of this one. The animation is beautiful and the pacing is solid. It is emotional. Everything is perfect. This deserves to the called a masterpiecec. Too bad the manga probably will never be published in NA/in english.

This is, in my humble opinion, a true masterpiece. I am a lover of romantic anime; and, while romance wasn't necessarily a central theme it was definitely there. This was something entirely different, and fresh. I'm so pleased that so many other people share my sentiment. The protagonist was so vibrant, and vivacious it was hard not to have liked her character. I also found myself liking all of the characters in the anime, not just the lead. I hope that a third season is around the corner. This anime has earned my personal recommendation.

I want to by the manga if i can find it.   This show is a great show to watch 3-4 episodes at a time if you do more you'll get burnt out on it. It needs another season but one thing that bothers me the most is that a lot of shows like this like to do a recap of the last half of the previous episode that takes up most of the new one.  also full recaps of the season up into episode 13 or 14 i can't remember are annoying.  Other than that this show is great and worth the time to watch. Great character development and lovable back story for even the non main characters.

I wasn't sure what to expect out of this at first but after watching the first few episodes I was completely blown away. I never knew Karuta existed until I started watching this anime! Since Chihayafuru2 ended (missing one bonus episode btw!) I've started reading the manga. I'm pretty sure the anime was to promote the manga anyway, so I'm not entirely sure if there will be another season... regardless, it's a great show and I'm proud to say it's in my top 10 favourite animes! It's even got me interested in playing Karuta!Romance, comedy, drama and it occasionally pulls on your heart strings (in all different ways). Must watch! Spoiler Alert! Click to show or hideDef rooting for Chihaya to realize Taichi's feelings, but the manga kind of has shifted gears in regards to Arata's confession.

This anime is marvelous, you would not expect a card game to be so intense let alone make such a grand show! The protagonist is strong and well developed she does not start off as a weak character on the contrary she is a motivated girl with a love of karuta. the other characters do not fall on the wayside her childhood buddy's show massive growth throughout both seasons especially Taichi.Each episode left me wanting more the art work and score also assisted in that. I would recommend this anime any day, it reminds me if Hikaru no Go.

Chihayafuru is about Chihaya a girl with no talents and nothing to do. She feels sorry for Arata a classmate. They discover a beautifully addicting card game together. This is unexpectedly good! Why? I'm not really sure. The animation is amazing, the story is easy to follow and interesting. But why it stands out? If I had to "show my hand" it's the card game! The game is astonishingly cool, and when I watch this it makes me want to play it! To add to the shows emotional complexity this show is about bullying, a big problem in all countries, especially China and Japan. It's good to learn about this, and that it's a very dangerous thing, if you watch Chihya you should compliment it with the documentary "Please Vote for Me" about this same topic.

Chihayafuru follows the story of a girl named Chihaya Ayase who is obsessed with the Japanese traditional game, karuta. After meeting a boy named Wataya Arata in her childhood who introduces her to karuta, her dream from then on is nothing less than to become the best in the world.My opinion: Before I watched this anime, I suspected it would be a cliche, typical and bland shojo anime... But boy was I wrong! Chihayafuru is a thrilling anime that will make you want to keep watching until the very end. 9.1/10The art: The animation was amazing in Chihayafuru (Especially in the match scenes) The art style was average... However, the incredible texture they used really made up for it. 8.1/10The music: The music was average, there was some music that didn't quite fit, however... There was also some incredible music which extended the art of the anime with grace and tension. 7.1/10The characters: I loved the characters, they differed from the strong characters to the ones that needed a push. I love how each character had a different personality and style and that was wonderfully portrayed in their karuta playing styles. 8.1/10Overall: I really enjoyed this anime, it made me see karuta in a whole new light while putting me into the position of someone who is valiant and determined to work to their goals, it's a truly inspiring anime and made me want to someday play karuta for myself... I'm hoping there will be a season 3. 8.8/10Genres: Romance, Shojo, Comedy, Sport, Action, Slice of Life

This anime sat in my Q for the longest time. It didn't catch fire for me until the third episode of the first season and then I was hooked. The characters are all very appealing, especially Chihaya, whose passion and desire to play Karuta and be with her friends is truly inspiring. Still, there's something sad about her that I can't quite put my finger on yet. She needs an outlet for her love, which seems to be overflowing at times and I hope she finds what she's looking for. So let's hope the story continues to grow along with the characters. I'm pulling for Taichi and Chihaya getting together.

After watching this show, I can truly say the you get attached to these characters. It's well written and has emotion to it. The determination shown by the characters for this one sport makes it feel like the effort put into something really matters. The feeling of striving to succeed and the hurt in losing, this is something everyone can relate too... I had never hear of Karuta before however if the show were to have been base on any other sport I think it would be a little lost. Even though Karuta seems to be a game played with an opponent, you still get a sense of teamwork. They help each other grow stronger by using their strengths and knowledge which is why I find it so interesting. I liked that the characters stay consistent yet still manage to improve. I hope to see this show continued.

I just finished watching the animer series and I would have to say that it was truely a pleasure this series. I wish I have had such a passion for something in my early youth. I always love watching anime series like these that gives a person some insight that there is always something beautiful in the world to do besides trying to figure your everyday struggles. I would recommend it to anyone in viewing this series!!!!!

I watched this only because I read the manga series first. I was a bit scared because I don't really like game manga in the first place but, this actually was GOOD. I liked the manga series but it didn't have the animation that I yearned to see. Karuta is a card game which involves your hand moving to hit a card. Obviously, manga will not demonstrate this action. So I downloaded the first couple of episodes and started watching. I recommend this to anyone who wants a refreshing series with a bit of romance, lots of friendship, slice of life and if you wanna learn something new!Storyline:I'd say it's really good. There is too much karuta in my opinion. Just a bit too much. I would probably rate it higher if we had a bit more balance.Music:Great OST, great OP, pretty good ED. Pretty much.Characters:Amazing actually. They're all special and great in their own way.Animation:Awesome. It's just awesome. xD

Chihayafuru is a stellar and emotionally engaging anime based on the popular Japanese game Karuta. The characters are warm, unique and memorable which is only aided by the wonderful voice work and animation. The voice work of Chihaya and Taichi in particular shine for the cast and the beautiful animation, especially the cg scenes, add to the fluidity of the competitions in the show, while the comedic breaks and hinted romantic subplots are welcome and add to the depth and appeal of each character. The final personal delight of mine is the connection attempted to bridge poetry to a competitive sport which makes Chihayafuru feel first unique in a "sport anime genre" while remaining culturally specific to Japan. Wonderful. I only hope a second season will be followed!

Chihayafuru is a short series telling the story of Chihaya and her friends.On the surface one would assume it's a Sports themed anime, but it's not so much about the Karuta, it's more about the connections between the characters and their devotion to what they do.It's wonderfully realized artistically and has excellent pacing throughout.It's largely the cast of characters that bring this show to life, and the variety of emotions the show is able to stir within you.I really hope to see a second series one day in the future, there are lots of plots points that can continue (just like in real life) but I'd be happy with this bitter sweet ending too, the creators have left enough there for you to imagine your own ending!Chihayafuru comes highly recommended from meI believe the characters are the strongest single element that Chihayafuru offers, and so that is reflected in my 'overall' score alsoA+

Not sure why I started this. It looked like it would be boring. A whole anime about a card game that children play? That kind of thing really only lasts half a season but nope, after two seasons, why not wait six years to do the third season?Anyway, after a two day binge, I couldn't get enough. 2 whole seasons and 9 episodes in, we're not even half way through the manga. Also, Hanano-chan needs her own spin-off series.Man... where do we get Snowmaru merchandise? Where?

You might have been thinking of passing this up.  You looked at the description, you looked at the artwork and probably thought this had to be one of those silly shoujo romances that you're not into where the premise is a vague afterthought.Well, I'm here to tell you that it is not.This is an anime about COMPETITIVE GAMING, and it is glorious.The game is a very Japanese card game called "karuta," and before watching this anime you'd be forgiven for not knowing what that is.  I'm not going to spoil it for you, because learning about "karuta" is a large part of the fun of the anime.  What I will say is that I have been a competitive gamer for over a decade and that's where Chihayafuru strikes a chord with me.  That is where it absolutely shines.The way it represents all aspects of competition in a stationary game is so straightforward, it's refreshing.  It doesn't patronize the viewers by turning matches into representations of other fantasies (like, say, Food Wars with its extended metaphors for taste).  Instead, it shows each and every moment of a match in excruciating detail, and the intensity is breathtaking.  Throughout the story it gets into themes of preparedness, ability, mindgames, endurance, perception, technique, knowledge, ritual... and treats them all with such respect that you can't help but learn.Of course that's not all there is to it.  It has likable characters, humor, legit wisdom, beautiful visuals, and is accompanied by an epic soundtrack.  And yes, although it's not the main premise, it does have hints of romance in there.So give it a shot, especially if you've ever enjoyed a competition or two.  It's worth it.

I started watching anime several years ago and have many series that I have loved during that time.  I have no set art style, genre, or story line that I prefer.  However, Chihayafuru is the first anime that I have ever written a review about.  In short, it is because I feel driven to do so. I think Chihayafuru has the effect like anything that is extremely well done.  Like an amazing feat of architecture, athleticism, vehicular design, musicality, or anything else invoking skill.  When it is a masterpiece it doesn't matter whether individuals are highly interested in the subject or not - they will still take note and marvel.As proven by all the other ratings and reviews of this show - I think just about anyone could watch and enjoy this anime because it is just that good.To the writers, artists, and producers involved in this manga and anime - please keep striving ahead with excellence!

This had me on the edge of my seat and binge watching non stop! It definitely surprised me as I wouldn't of thought to watch this but I completely love this anime. I have seen there are live action movies of this so Im definitely going to watch those next! I have never heard of this card game and it has been turned into something beautiful and exciting. Love all the characters and I hope she realises who has been there the whole time for her!

I fell in love with karuta because of this show! The character development is really beautiful and the way they set up the story line to go back and show the past is very well written! I really relate to Chihaya and her dedication and passion to the art of the game. Her willingness to keep pushing herself and her desire to grow, change, and become stronger is very inspiring!! I hope they continue this show as I would love to see more matches as Chihaya and Taichi continue to excel! I'm excited for Chihaya to finally play a match against Arata!! Much love for the creators, writers and producers of this show! Please keep it going! ❣️

How to explain this series ?                 Ayase the herione or team ace cries half the series , can't figure out taichi is crazy about her and obsesses over a guy that ends up being a emotionally detached elitist jerk after his grandpa dies for 50 episodes . oh and they play an easy to understand but insanely difficult to master game, with seriously intense moments. I've watched alot of anime and this is  the first anime series I've hated the lead character and loved her almost episode by episode. The secondary characters keep the story going. The three main characters the first being Arata is hardly in the first 50 episodes, the other two ayase and taichi are in every episode but  make about 0% overall personal growth whilst improving their game until the last couple of episodes.          which is why to me anyway it felt like OE a female side character effortlessly steals the show.hard to tell if she was suppose to be the center of the story in initial drafts or is just someone reminisce of the author or the authors friend but she gets the most realistically weird lines, reactions and seems to be involved during every key point of the story and is the only one you see  steadily grow in and out of the game, she starts as a quite poet obsessed novice and by the end of the second season is the den mother of the team , she cares for the rookies and pushes the veterans to grow whilst given cultural significance to the playing pieces. :) I can't wait for season 3

The reason I writing this review is because chihafuru has got 3rd season coming out and even with 4th season of my hero coming this is my most anticipated anime of this year. Also this show is the show that really got me into anime because before this I had I had only watch Fullmetal alchemist and Blue exorcist. which are both brilliant anime but this really brought me into watch any anime I feel is interesting.

The competitive Japanese card game karuta, a physically and mentally demanding card game inspired by the classic Japanese anthology of Hundred Poets. Our story primarily focuses around the karuta club of Mizusawa High, and it's founding member Chihaya Ayase. With an overwhelming love for the game, Chihaya aims to become the Queen, the best female player in Japan, and since the game is for the most part only played in Japan, she would essentially be the best female player in the world. She is not alone in her attempt to achieve her dream, with teammates and rivals all around her, the journey to become the next Queen will be much more complicated than she could even imagine.Chihayafuru is better than it has any right to be, that's not to say we don't have niche competitive game anime, March Come in Like a Lion is the easiest comparison to make, and that anime is pretty legendary. While I do prefer that one rather than Chihayafuru, Chihayafuru is still surprisingly amazing. Every single character is well thought out and equally well written to help tell the story and help our main group learn to improve their karuta skill. The anime is also incredibly dedicated to showing as much karuta as possible, I don't think a single episode went by that didn't involve karuta in some way, which in a way is Chihayafuru's biggest strength. It's characters coupled with a great style and animation quality that manages to make simple motions exciting and outcomes sweat inducing. Altogether they craft a competitive sports anime that will have you cheering on each match till the end.

If you cared enough and is interested enough to be reading... GO WATCH THIS SHOW PLEASE.This is simply one of the best animes I have ever encountered, and definitely one that never fails to make me enjoy every moment the story even after numerous rewatches. The cast contains a wide range of unique and memorable characters who are all realistic but lovable in their own ways.While being part of the "shojo" genre, Chihayafuru nevertheless more closely resembles a shonen sports manga/anime; at the same time, with the delicate addition of separate emotional arcs for many characters, viewers also get to have a more complete perspective of these fascinating individuals beyond their passion and devotion in the sport--focusing more on their different ideologies. This is perhaps the reason why I deeply root for many of the characters in this show, as I consider the story to be ultimately character-driven. In the end, I would not mind even if they did not become the "best players in the nation," because the true greatness of the show lies in the overlapping arcs of each character as they influence and inspire each other to grow and change.P.S. I ship Arata x Chihaya... It's a shame that the manga's story(not in the anime) has headed towards a disappointing direction that spoils all the greatness the author has intricately developed in the previous storylines...

The show follows a young girl named Chihaya start a karuta club at her highschool with the help of her childhood friend Taichi. We get to explore how the popularity this game fluctuates from school to school and the different levels of dedication from its players. We see different techniques to play the game and the hierarchy in their societies (local community clubs).I really enjoy learning about the 100 poems and their meanings. I love learning about how the game is played and how tension is well portrayed between teams.Its an amazing show and hope more seasons will be created!

I wasn't sure how they were going to have a show that 2 seasons long with this premise, but now I want MORE!!!  This was an amazing show.  Yes, there was a lot about karuta, but they still fit everything else in there too.  Comedy, romance, drama, suspense.  The competition scenes really do drag you in and make you feel tense!  I was not expecting all that from this show, but this is in my top 10 now.

So you ask “What’s karuta?”Well, it’s a Japanese card game. And if it weren’t for this extremely well done series, you would never get excited about it. Yet here we are. 52 episodes later and I’m dying for more matches!One thing that this anime does better than most is making you fall in love with the characters. Before you know it, you care so much about every single one of the main characters. This series does a great job of using flashbacks to teach you about everyone’s back story. But they don’t overdo it like some others do. The flashbacks are well timed and they don’t drag on forever. You even learn just enough about the main characters rivals to get you personally involved with their matches.There’s almost no wasted episodes. A lot of series that are based on matches or battles or some kind of competition draw everything out. It seems like the writers realized that nobody really wants to watch a long drawn out training arc. In most cases the only reason we do is because we’re already invested in the series. But they don’t take advantage of that. They skip months of unnecessary training and get you right to the meat of the story. In only 52 episodes they cover 2 entire years of progress.When you start the first episode, you’d never think that you’d have all of your emotions tested. That is definitely the case though. You quickly become emotionally invested in all of the main characters. They time the music perfectly with all the important scenes. And next thing you know, you’re sitting there with tears of joy in your eyes as your favorite character has an incredible breakthrough. You also will find yourself on the edge of your seat stressed out about the outcome of the match you’re watching. And of course the overwhelming frustration when things take a turn and don’t go how you were wishing they would.They’ve got jokes too. This isn’t a serious series the entire time. The writers have very well placed jokes to break the tension. Sometimes that’s exactly what you need. Otherwise you might go crazy cheering and yelling at the TV for hours like a crazed sports fan.My only real complaint about this series is that they sometimes draw out an episode with the same flashback clips that you’ve seen a couple times before. It seems like they are just killing a few minutes so they can end on a cliff hanger. This doesn’t happen too often, so it’s not a huge issue. The flashback repeats are mostly when they are approaching an important match with a reoccurring character. You have to keep in mind that they had originally intended you to watch an episode a week, not a handful back to back on consecutive days. So it might not have even been noticeable when it was originally airing During a binge watching marathon you come to be familiar with them.Overall I would recommend Chihayafuru to everyone. I’ve probably watched it 5 times by now and am still waiting patiently for a third season to start. They leave it on a big time cliff hanger on the last episode of season 2, so there has to be a third in the works somewhere. Or at least that’s what I’ll keep telling myself as I check what series are scheduled to air every TV season.For more reviews please visit my page www.medium.com/@animedave

When I heard the director of Cardcaptor Sakura was working on another show that itself was enough to get me to watch, However it would be unfair to this show to simply call it "the other show he worked on with Madhouse" because Chihayafuru is so much more. Throughout its 2 season run the characters come alive in a way that instantly makes you love them and want to root for them. Chihaya is a character who at first seems like every other sports protagonist you've seen, perfect at everything and a sevant. However as the show progresses and we get more of her origins and backstory we see what makes her such an endearing character, she's full of tenacity and spirit and always is working on improving herself, and she's not alone in that trait. Characters such as her best friend Taichi could easily carry his own show and at points really feels like he's the character we are meant to wanna root for more so than even Chihaya herself, his development over the course of 2 seasons is amazing and has really endeared him to me as I'm sure he will others. Other supporting members of the cast all get great moments to show why they love Karuta and the show itself does a magnificent job of explains the rules of the game and helping convey why it is such an important part of these characters lives. Through the shows use of mood through its poems and making them truly come alive they instill a sense of awe in the viewer that sucks them up into the world of Karuta in the same its characters get into it. Madhouse really did a superb job on the animation and music of this series and I would dare say call it one of there best works, overall i'd say if you haven't tried this show yet I can't recommend it enough, you'll find not only a great cast of likable characters with great competitive matches but also a gateway into a world of beautiful Japanese poetry and how those poems can be related to even to this day.

This anime really intrigued me so very much! It was one of first watched, but I am constantly failing in finding something to top it. 1. I love the MC's personality. Chihaya is such a lively, passionate, kind and dedicated person. Her character really inspires me throughout the show, making me laugh and cry, because I can literally relate to her passion through the show, that's how strong her emotions are. She is still a child at heart and I love to follow how she grows from being so innocent and naive. Her animation is beautiful too, of course.2. My OTP (one true pairing) kept on changing! I could not decide who between Taichi and Arata I ship with Chihaya! That really prickled my curiosity, because usually I am dead set on an OTP when a love triangle comes into play. It played with my heart and messed with my emotions, but it was wonderful to, for once, really like both the love-interests. It causes inner-conflictions within myself and I found it really entertaining! (Although, I finally have my solid OTP.)3. Some anime tend to fail in this aspect, but Chihayafuru got it spot on. I really grew fond of each and every side-character. I wouldn't mind if the centre of the episode shifts to any character, because the show has succeeded in making me interested in them. This keeps the show really entertaining and I loved it!4. Karuta. The strangest card game that my wildest imagination never would be able to create, but I absolutely love it! I was so immersed in every game and I feel as if I personally become better with every game Chihaya and her friends play. I never thought I would wish that much to want to speak Japanese. To be able to play it myself and to, of course, wear a kimono while playing, at Kana-chan's request. The karuta really gets intense and keeps you on the edge of you seat.This show captured my heart, interest and time. The OP and end songs are beautiful and the emotional rollercoaster with Mizusawa is indescribable. I hope you love Chihayafuru as much as I did.

This is absolutely one anime you do not want to miss out on. If you are a fan of Dragon Ball Z, Bleach, One Piece, and Naruto, then this is a MUST WATCH.The First season has episodes 1-48. (2009-2010)The Second season has episodes 49-96. (2010-2011)The Third season has episodes 97-150. (2011-2012)The Fourth season has episodes 151-175.
