I'm a Nol and I love Fairy Tail ;P!

I must say I love Fairy Tail. It’s my favorite anime, and that’s saying a lot, considering I love anime and have watched quite a few. In this review I will talk about the pros and cons of Fairy Tail, in my opinion. Please don’t feel angry, for this is only my opinion. Everyone has different opinions, after all. Let’s start with the pros! First off, the plot is really great and I can tell Hiro Mashima put a lot of work into the design of the anime and manga. He’s also a great artist- he drew the manga all by himself!!! There is not just one plot that all the arcs revolve around. Every arc has its own story, which is great because it never gets boring. I especially love the Grand Magic Games and the Tartaros Arc. The Key of Starry Heavens, I must admit, could have been better. The Eclipse Arc was cool too. The Galuna Arc was also a good way to appeal to me and keep me on the edge of my seat, motivating me to finish the whole arc and move on to watch the entire rest of the anime. The second pro is that everyone has their own personality. It’s not just everybody is OP (lookin’ at you, Naruto!) or everyone is super weak or something. Some people are powerful, like Natsu, Gray, Erza, Laxus, Gildarts, Kagura, Zeref, Mavis, the Ten Wizard Saints, The Spriggan 12, and many other wizards. Some are on the weak side, like Levy, Milliana, Lucy, Toby, Chelia, and various other Mages. And as for personality, Natsu’s energetic and clueless at times, Gray’s cool and serious at times, Erza is stern and sometimes girly, Lucy is caring and sometimes vain, Wendy is compassionate and sometimes insecure, etc., you get the idea. Another pro is that, though the outcome is always the good guys win, the process of fights are all different. Sometimes it’s sadder, sometimes secrets are revealed, sometimes it’s an easy fight, and sometimes it’s a drawn-out, long and difficult fight. Yet another pro is that the music and layout of the anime is fantastic. The music is awesome, especially the Fairy Tail theme song, in my opinion. The characters are also very well-drawn. Obviously Hiro Mashima and whoever else helped him draw them as well as background objects really know how to correctly proportion everything! Props to Hiro Mashima and his cast and crew for all their hard work that really paid off!!!Time for the cons, now. There are only two, in my opinion, both related. The most egregious issue, I think, is the fan service. Fairy Tail really overused it. Now, I know you’re mainly thinking about fan service directed to all those perverted boys out there, but I also mean fan service for those fangirls. All the guys are crazy TONED. I’m a girl, but I’m a tomboy and have no interest whatsoever in 6- or 8- pack abs or tanned guys, so this really bothers me. Mashima really wants girls to get the idea that those Mages are really muscular, for some reason- all the guys walk around without shirts a lot. I watched the whole anime one time through without even noticing, as I didn’t care about that, but I read some reviews about Fairy Tail, some of them regarding fan service, and a few mentioning the muscle-bound guys. Then I rewatched Fairy Tail later on and couldn’t help but notice that it really was irritating. But the bigger issue (the second issue with Fairy Tail), I believe, even more than the abs of guys in Fairy Tail, is the fan service directed to boys. And that really is a huge issue. Obviously the pros overpower the cons, but I am very annoyed with the overuse of booby and panty shots. I’m glad that at least little girls like Wendy and Meredy before the 7-year gap don’t have boobs though. That makes it more realistic, but still, the girls’ boobs are so big, each one is the size of the girl’s face! And the filler episodes, where the guild goes to the beach to train or whatever, make the problem worse. The girls are all wearing skimpy, revealing bikinis, even Wendy, who has nothing to reveal. Apparently all girls just have to wear a bikini! I, for one, have never touched a bikini. I wear a swim shirt and swim trunks to swim. Anyways, that’s not the point. The point is the fan service. All the guys are perverts, too, especially all the old dudes like Makarov and Gildarts and Macao and Wakaba. So when they see a girl, like, loose her bikini top or something, they all turn bright red. In the OVA, even Elfman gets perverted at the sight of his SISTER- yes, his SISTER, as in Mirajane- without her bikini top at Ryuzetsu Land. Which brings me to the OVA- that’s the worst. If I were to give the OVA a rating, it’d be 2/5 stars. Three stars down just for the excessive amount of fan service, that’s how much I hate fan service. In the OVA, especially “Fun in Ryuzetsu Land!” or something like that, there is so much fan service. So much! First off, Erza loses not only her “legendary” bikini bottom, but also her bikini top! While on the Love Love Slider with a guy- Jellal, the dude she’s shipped with! I mean, come on! She gets naked while a red-as-a-lobster guy is next to her. How coincidental (I’m being sarcastic, in case you couldn’t tell. I’m sure you could). Second of all, Jenny pulls Mirajane’s bikini top off and Mirajane gets her back by pulling down Jenny’s bikini bottom. Is that not fan service? Also, there is, like, an episode with Lucy naked and bathing or showering every twenty episodes or something, which is annoying. In the “Natsu v.s. Mavis” OVA or something, they show all the girls fully naked and bathing all together. You get the point? I am fed up with the fan service. But wait!!! You should totally watch Fairy Tail!!! Just because I talked about its downsides for too long, doesn’t mean it’s bad! Fairy Tail is the best! That’s why I gave it five stars!!! I totally recommend this anime AND manga!!! Have fun watching and reading it! You’ll love it, if you want a long, super-awesome anime with too much fan service. Even if you don’t like long, super-awesome animes with too much fan service, watch it! Even though I hate fan service, I love the anime! It’s the BEST. Have fun!

Fairytail was one of the first animes I got into and had the chance to binge watch all of the seasons. At first I was obsessed only to realize after watching Naruto Shippuden, Cowboy Bebop, Fate/Zero that Fairytail was just mediocre. I was going to give this four stars ( just because there was a decent amount of good content) but after seeing the Dragon Cry Movie I confirmed my opinion at 3 stars. The focus has shifted even MORE on sexual parts of the characters and less on their focus or stories. I was really dissapointed with the movie and OVAs.

School teaches me math, english, chemistry and etc. It's a building designed to train the knowledge part of my brain.Why am I talking about school?Fairy Tail taught me things I would never learn in a school. It's enjoyable and my all time fave anime, Naruto or Natsu? Well, I have no clue because I love them both.Each character has their own unique personality which is great!This anime has triggered every emotion possible inside of me. To be honest I believe it's a roller coaster of emotions!In the end, I love this anime with all my heart. After I heard that it's ending my heart shattered into thousands of tiny little pieces.I will sure miss this anime, for those who haven't watched it yet, I HIGHLY RECCOMEND IT!

I started watching Fairy Tail season two and then got caught up with both the anime and manga (manga being after.. ) in only like 3 or 4 months. Now That the anime is over with I feel sad because It was my favorite anime to watch every weekend.. Tartaros arc is by far one of the best Arcs in Fairy Tail ever (imo..)   and the Grand magic games starts off a bit slow but at the start of season two is where things get pretty interesting. If you like anime like DBZ or Maybe anime that have a lot to do with magic and RPG like stuff.  then this might be something you can get into.. Fairy tail isn't made to be taken too seriously.

FT was the first anime I could really get into, it's a great gateway to a wonderful world full of original and lovable characters. The more you watch FT, the more you feel like you're part of their family.I think the character development and story lines are amazing and inspiring. Watching the characters learn and better themselves makes  you want to keep watching them.-Also, shipping in this anime is riiculous . It's pretty obvious who will end up together so it isn't as heartbreaking.

Those that are done raging between anime/manga adaptions feel free to read. Those who still don't understand why books and movies will ever be the same feel free to go away. With that being said, Fairy Tail is easily the best Shounen anime to date! Take this from a non-hardcore shounen fan. Granted, i do enjoy shounen as a casual viewer (despite me seeing over 3000 shounen eps) but I stand by my statement 100%

Ever since I have watched the first season on Netflix back 2 years ago, I was immediately hooked on how hilarious and amazing this anime is. It has made me laugh at so many times that most of them I cried. After all the intense drama that there is in the anime, it just comes back around like a hula hoop. Hilarious, awesome, sad, and heartwarming.Plus, it has some very cute characters that are amazingly delicate in their own way. Definitely recommend it, Truly a masterpiece!

Pleas fanboys & fangirls spare me...Humor in fantasy adventure anime usually makes my eyes roll but the wise cracks in the show actually makes me laugh. Every character is likable, even the bad guys. The romance is good but can be annoying when your OTP win't just shut up and kiss already...Talking to you Happy and Jellal! Just kidding, I don't actually ship them. The flashbacks are great and have a great score to go along with it. Pyromancy has always been a soft spot for me so Natsu is an ultimate plus. The anime itself is very repetitive but to not jump right into hypocrisy I'll just tell you to read the other low reviews.

While this show can make you sit on the edge of your seat and make you wonder what goes on next, it also provides you with light moments of comedy. And that's not just it,but when you watch this show you build  bond with the characters and understand how they feel throughout the show. And while your building your bond feel their emotions aswell and cry with them. Fairy Tail teaches me about life and that it's special and shouldn't be taken for granted.If you're searching for a show that will give you laughter,love, joy, sadness, and excitement, watch Fairy Tail and hop on the adventure with everyone!Side note:If you're a guy enjoy the fanservice that goes along with it ;).

This is one of my favorite series. It shows a great story line and has characters like no other. This is an anime that sets itself apart from the typical fantasy anime, it makes you actually like the characters. So if someone were to die, you would feel something, and not just be like: "Oh, cool...well then..." All in all, I would recommend this to anyone. It is funny and can get a bit "fanservice-y(?) at times.

At the start this show was  AMAZING but... after the first 2 arcs it just felt all filler, because I preferred the simple easy side missions they went on while they waited for the next bit, but after a little they forgot to do that and just went after big missions, the world use to feel dynamic, but then it just got boring basically, If you want a good story where you can learn to love the characters personally, you're not wanting to be here This anime is good, but repetitive, not good for ADHD/Dyslexic people, you'll get more attached to the backround then you do the main characters.FINAL VERDICT: 3/5 (Or) 4/10 Summary: Boring characters, non-dynamic, no feels.

Fairy tale started out strong and I am happy that they are making more seasons but the last 10 episodes the artworks and quality that was produced before the celestial arc has degraded so much it seems the editors and artist stopped caring and are just pushing it out for more sales now.aside from the beef I listed above I am still an avid fan of fairy tale I do hope they fix that one issue and do a lot more actual character growth beyond the friendship /guild bond link that is  running dry

I watched all of the first season and it was amazing. I loved every bit of it except for the long filler arc. But now, this new season is the definition of horrible. There used to be awesome fights and great character development and conflict but now each and every episode of the new season makes me wanna do the 2k15 kys challenge. Seriously this anime needs to get back on track with the manga and start producing an actual, serious, and amazing anime.

(This is my first review, so some things may be a bit flawed).  I was introduced to Fairy Tail by a fellow friend who liked anime.  Although I like it, the chances of me recommending it to someone are low.  Why?  The main reasons are because of the rampant fan service and the overused cliches.Honestly, I don't know how I put up with the fan service, but I somehow manage to do so.  First, let's start with the guys.  More than 90% are ripped or very close to it, even to the point in which a 13 year old is also ripped.  The only person I haven't seen like this in the series is a fat person.  However, the problem I have is with the girls.  When I watched the first episode, I noticed that Lucy was quite buxom, but I took that as an exception.  However, I noticed that 99% of the girls have DD breasts.  And don't call me a pervert, since I am a heterosexual female.  What is worse is that whenever they (as in the few girls you see in a serious fight) get attacked, their clothes get ripped.  I know, it' realistic and all, but it gets ripped in the wrong places, so that the only part of their boobs being covered is their nipples.  This goes to Lucy in particular, since she is unfortunately used for most of the fan service in the series.But the most important reason I don't recommend this is because of the cliched storylines.  The only person who never follows this is Lucy (again, I know).  As you know, the protagonist gets beaten down by a typically sadistic antagonist.  But when they remember the power of nakama, they get an irrational sense of power and somehow beat a person who was 10x as strong as them.  This usually goes for Gray, Erza and of course, Natsu.Anyway, long story short, I still like Fairy Tail because sometimes (as in 15% of the time) the arcs do give you the feels and also because of what some people may call slapstick jokes (I tend do have a liking for anime that is slightly lighthearted, but not much so).  But I wouldn't recommend this series to someone looking for a more mature and intricate plot.

I started out ignoring Fairy Tail just like i did Naruto way back in the day. Always saw it at anime con's and said i would eventually try and watch it... or there was too much hype and it probably wasn't that good. About a couple months ago i finally sat down and watched the first episode and i was instantly hooked. Fairy Tail just cracks me up. I literally will be laughing out loud at all the humor that they having good on in the show. Great Humor, Great Characters- appeals to your emotions. NOT for kids like someone previously mentioned! Especially how much sexual humor comments they make note to lol. Would you let your kid watch it? Don't think so. Of course every show is going to have characters that you're not very fond of, characters you love and such- it wouldn't be a good show if it didn't. Speaking from a fan who watched 7 seasons in about a month or so- (and is also a fan of the other big time shows One Piece, Naruto etc...) i'll say that Fairy Tail progresses in it's own fashion. You ALSO need to keep in mind that One Piece, DBZ, Naruto etc- have been going for MUCH longer than Fairy Tail almost all of them have ended. So while it may seem that the development in those shows progressed faster it really didn't. They all were around what? 500-600 episodes? Fairy Tail is on early 200's. It's STILL growing. The point in a story is that it is different. The author isn't worried about how fast DBZ, Naruto and One Piece character's have developed he's worried about developing his own characters at his own speed. So bottom line is- if you aren't down with his writing and have nothing but complaints there a millions of other series out there for you. He writes and draws for those who are interested and i'm definitely a fan through it all. I heard some not so great things are going to happen to the Fairy Tail Guild but i won't spoil it and i definitely won't stop reading/watching because i'm a true fan! Enough said!

Just to be clear, Fairy Tail is still in my queue and I intend to continue watching it someday but now I'm 16 episodes behind and I have yet to feel the urge to do so. Why is that? Is it because there are so many strong series this season? Maybe. Or maybe it's because I get it. I get the story. The writers have gotten every arc down to a single formula and it gets old. The story is so incredibly cookie cutter that while watching the first season, I skipped huge chunks of the story (~4 arcs)  and I came back and realized that I missed nothing of importance. I still got it. When I continued after skipping there was maybe 3 new faces whose names and allegiances I learned after a mere 1 episode. I missed nothing substantial which may give an idea that the story in and of itself is not substantial and fallen falls flat in many aspects.

Ok, at first i liked this anime A LOT, like to the point of no return or so i thought. after the 2nd season i started noticing a bunch of flaws.1. fan service, people this show is seriously aimed for kids, not perverts looking to have a good time, i can name two woman that have small chests. Even a twelve year old has a somewhat big chest.2. Repetitive, "I will never give up, I'll fight for my comrades until I win!' boy how many times have I heard a quote like that? EVERY SINGLE ARC like no joke. the plot over and over is, 1. Bad guys show up2. Bad guys start to beat the snot out of main characters 3. Main characters make a big speech about the power of comrades and friendship4. Main characters beat the snot out of the bad guysBoy is that an annoying plot after a while 3. Lucy, this girl is supposed to be one of the most powerful celestial mages in the world. Yet why is she always getting saved by someone? She can not fight at all, and it irritates me like crazy. She'll always get beat up and then be saved by Natsu or someone. Like why can't this girl even lunch someone? Its like she's there for fan service only. When she gets beat up she always has to have some article of clothing ripped apart so only one little string covers her chest. One time she just flew in the air nude. Ugh that annoyed me a lot. So in the end, i can't watch the second season with out rolling my eyes and making a remark about how annoying Lucy is and mimic them talking about their "nakama"

Fairy tail is a shonen genre show about friendship. It has everything: comedy, action, drama, suspense, romance etc... But it lacks depth and uniqueness. This show is full of reused and rehashed typical anime tropes. There are numerous characters that aren't fleshed out. The battles are redundant. The characters are drawn with "fan service" in mind. There are sympathetic villains. There are themes of revenge, troubled childhoods, teen angst etc... There is a formula to this show and it does not change. And once you watch one arc, you can pretty much guess how future story arcs are going to pan out. All of what I just stated isn't a complaint or a criticism. It is what it is. And personally, I don't mind the "typical" tropes that this show is full of. The reason why? Because the art style is good. Because the animation and battles are decent. Because "some" of the characters are really fleshed out and interesting. There are genuinely dark, deep, and realistically emotional moments in this show that are brilliantly written and shown. The only problem is that there are only a few, handful, of these moments that give you "the feels".So, like the title of this review, Fairy Tail is an entertaining show. It does what it sets out to do, and that is to entertain the viewer for the duration of the episode. The target audience age for this show, and shonens in general, are teen - late teen. But I'm in my early 20s and have really enjoyed this show. Also, both girls and guys can enjoy this show. The "fan service" goes both ways (although slanted to be more appealing to boys).So I "personally" rate this show 4 stars. But for the sake of a somewhat unbiased review, I will give it 3.

Fairy Tail and its anime adaption had tons of potential. I've watched almost 200 episodes of the anime, but I'm now ready to drop it. The author has consistently proven he'll ruin his coolest ideas and I'm tired of watching that happen. From the very beginning, the show has suffered from one and only one problem. You could argue there are more problems, but most of those stem from the one: There are simply too many characters. The chances have been plenty to reduce the cast from growing, but it's become apparent that Mashima Hiro can't bring himself to kill his darlings. The roster of names and faces has bloated beyond reason and it's impacting every aspect of the show.As much as I enjoy many of the characters, "kill your darlings" is not only a good rule for writers, it's a philosophy that's intertwined with greater ideals of art. The piece of work is more important than your personal feelings. You don't control the characters, you only interpret them. As an author, you need to respect their space and choices and you should let them live and die as who they are.Pacing is one of the most difficult aspects of writing. It takes tons of editing to fit every moving piece into its place. Fairy Tail characters are so numerous that the pacing is all over the place, the scenes will switch at inappropriate moments, scenes will end without any actual twist or personal resolution, dialogue is becoming repetitive, and I'm ready to give up. The story arcs feel stretched too thin and it's destroying the atmosphere in every scene. The characters you actually give a shit about can't even get enough screen time, because the supporting cast keeps butting in.You can love Fairy Tail. Personally, I'm done giving this show breaks.

Idolish 7 was originally a mobile game released by Bandai Namco in Japan, featuring a visual novel and rhythm game type game play. It is a Japanese only mobile game, however you can play it if you live in other countries to find out how visit the Idolish 7 fan wiki. But anyway onto the review, this show so far is great! The animation is smooth and the music and sounds are nice as-well. And all the characters are colorful and have distinct personalities. And I especially like that they did give Tsumugi the main female character a  personality because they usually don't and make them very bland. But Tsumugi has character which is nice. And I don't have any complaints. Like I said this is based off a game so I feel like you would be more excited about this anime if you played the game and have listened to the many songs by the idol groups(Idolish7, Trigger, and Re:Vale.). Anyway I recommend this anime if you like idol anime and like bishies.

This anime is based off the rhythm and visual novel mobile game released a few years ago in Japan. It has gained a huge following, and for the fans, this anime has been a long time coming! As a fan of the popular Uta no Prince-sama, and a veteran male idol anime watcher, I can honestly say that this one is a serious gem! While following the story of this 7 man idol unit (get it? Idolish7) we start at, just like the idol group, the beginning! It's all about trying to get their name out their, worry over other idol units, and how to work together as a unit themselves. And to of course, be top idols! This anime shows the real struggles of trying to make a name for yourself versus just them "magically" becoming the best. They aren't the best right now, they are unknown and are working hard to figure out the entertainment world. I know a lot of idol anime characters tend to lack personalities and/or not have any depth beyond their set image. But with this anime it's not like that at all! Every character (even the main female, I know a total shock) has a set image but they are not one-dimensional in their personalities or struggles! It's a refreshing good idol anime that has good animation (there is some CGI during some dancing parts but it isn't all that bad), plot, music/songs, and actual characters we can sympathizes with and not just annoyed at! I think for any idol lovers and even first time watchers, would be able to enjoy this!

I love the characters in this anime - they feel down to earth and not vague in personality - there's something more defined in their ambitions and they have, dare I say, some common sense? It's not just pretty boys living a lavish lifestyle as an idol, they're buckling down and trying to build themselves up from the bottom, but they have such good interactions it feels so refreshing and even relatable to a degree.And, you gotta enjoy that merged first two episodes, it really gives them the time to cement the character dynamics. And our female manager is focusing on her job instead of being in doki doki otome cliche situations, so that's always a plus! I'll be sticking with this in the long run for sure.

Honestly, this is the first time I've ever enjoyed an idol anime so much as to watch it past episode five  (coughutanoprincesamacough) and I fell in LOVE. The boys aren't bland and are all extremely charming in their own ways. They all have unique backstories that can really describe why a character acts a certain way! Along with that the main female protagonist doesn't drive me crazy and is actually a girl who can do her job and not be useless. Which makes me glad this isn't a reverse harem, like I love the reverse harem genre, but I hate the trope of the main female being useless. Other than that, the plot is very dramatic but is still filled with some really cute plot points that just keep you watching. Plus just watch the anime. It's bishie galore and it's beautiful!

As I read some of the other comments, I realized there were a few saying it was like every other idol otome anime/game. The main girl does not go chasing after the boys at all and they aren't trying to get with her. Of course there are some flirty remarks here and there, but the boys are much more interested in trying to succeed as a group rather than get her to notice them. The mobile game is amazing and I still play it today. Even in the game itself, you aren't trying to get the boys' attention, you're just going through the story as well as the rhythm portion. It's really fun to collect and merge the character cards too!I would recommend both to anyone!

IDOLiSH7 is a great anime for many reasons, but I would say its most appealing factor is the amount of effort that went into each character's stories, and how these stories all work well together. The amount of work that went into this anime is easy to see and it's very admirable, not to mention the songs are really catchy and fun. It's an anime where you can't wait to see what happens next, but at the same time it is relaxing to watch. I really hope this series continues for a while!

One look at this and one may think that this is your typical idol anime. A group of boys all fall in love with the same girl and their road is laid out to them in a rainbow where their first concert will have thousands of screaming fans just waiting for them. That they will defeat all the previous guys in a battle of popularity and get bigger than them. Blah blah blah. You know, that typical idol stuff.Spoiler Alert! Click to show or hideI was surprised. (Spoiler warning just in case. Especially for ONE part. It's small, but it's a bit of a spoiler)I rarely watch anything reverse harem. When I do, I either think its okay and probably never watch it again. IDOLiSH7 has me going back to rewatch episodes while waiting for the next episode. This idol anime actually has a plot. SHOCKER! Though I can say that some stuff may be slightly exaggerated, many of the small details are based on real life in a way. The way the fans are portrayed; the struggles to be in the idol industry; how personal problems are dealt with (not all but some).The best part? The guys didn't fall in love with their female manager (which I'm to assume is "you" on the video game). They love their manager as what she is: their manager. There might be a time where one hits on her, but it's not cheesy and it's brushed off. I'm not saying that I usually hate the female protagonist. I don't. But this is refreshing. It's nice to watch an idol or any reverse harem anime where the guys don't "fall in love" at first sight.If many don't like the typical plot of an idol anime but want to give one a try, I suggest IDOLiSH7. And I will say, as a fan of a kpop group, this hits me right in the fandom feels. You can't help but love them all.

I got into this late and at the suggestion of a friend. I thought it was supposed to be an Utapri ripoff and wasn't that interested for a while. But I was mistaken. The fact that there's seven idols and they're rainbow colored is about where the similarities end. This isn't really an otome show, and that makes it a breath of fresh air. It's rich in terms of drama and incredibly funny moments and the characters each have so much going for them that it's hard to choose a favorite. If Nana and Utapri had a lovechild, it might be this show. I haven't gotten this into an anime in many years. It's splendidly made and has catchy songs as a great bonus.

I've followed IDOLiSH7 since before the anime aired and watching it has only made me appreciate it even more. TROYCA has done an excellent job capturing the heart of i7 and bringing the story to life in a whole new way. If you're even a little curious, me and this 5 star rating highly recommend you give it a try!I dearly love this series and I am heavily anticipating season 2! Please. I love Re:vale so much and I want to see them so bad.

So I watched this because I've played the game since it released because I'm a total sucker for rhythm games, especially those that have Ono Kensho, Egutan and Kenn in them, haha. Honestly - this is probably one of the best idol anime. Period. And I hate idol anime. There's a real plot that follows the game very well, and the characters are actually all developed. The animation is a bit more... bishouneny than something like Shounen Hollywood, but it has that same feel where the characters are real people with real problems. Do I think this falls short in the fact that everything is a little bit grand? Yes - but it's not like an otome (this doesn't really feel otome beyond the manager is a girl and there are only other male characters, they don't all compete for her affection, there are only subtle nods to its genre) where there is inexplicable magic and rainbows. It is more of a over-emphasized version of what the entertainment industry in Japan is really like, while still having some truth and classic anime drama in it. It's really well done, and the animation is consistent for the most part. Plus the songs are really fun and good, if you're into that.

I originally started watching this anime because I felt like indulging in something mindless and kind of ridiculous. The first episode is silly, but as the show goes on you slowly start to get engrossed in the characters and their shenanigans. What I once watched ironically I now genuinely enjoy. I've watched every episode at least twice. Is it a silly idol show? Yes. Is it a great silly idol show? Absolutely. (Also the songs are really catchy and I listen to them... a lot...)

IDOLiSH7 is a mobile otome/rhythm game that many have loved for years now and we have all been asking and asking for there to be an anime and there finally was. As expected the dancing is CGI which to me is the only downside of the whole thing. However the great voice acting (same actors as the ones in the game) and beautiful art style make it all the worth watching. I can't wait to watch more and fall more in love with some of my favorite characters.Riku Nanase is my favorite out of them all by the way.

When I watched the first episode, my thoughts were: "Oh, this is going to be like Uta no Prince Sama. Reverse harem set-up, and cute boys with a solid reason to not actually go after the MC, because, y'know, idol contracts."I have never been so happy to be wrong!In hindsight, the comparison is a complete disservice to the show.  The characters are all dynamic and feel seriously real; The idol stuff they do feels very down to earth and I love it; There's no reverse harem!!! Just people being people, getting along, forming relationships, like, wow. Clear and pure friendships? In front of my salad? Amazing. Like dang, can't believe they made a female protagonist not get crushes every .5 seconds while not realizing it at the same time. Or have the shockingly talented and good-looking idols fall in love with our average but oh-so-talented MC after she breathes.Another thing that I adore about the show, is their CG.  It's shockingly good, like I was not expecting to be able to watch 90% of the CG parts without having my soul slowly wither away.Also! The voices! Everyone who sang sounded pretty good, like, not actual idol good obviously, but it was really impressive. The songs were also overall enjoyable!If I had to pick out something I didn't like, it would be how Iori takes control of a lot of things that, as manager, Tsumugi ought to be doing herself. If not entirely, than mostly.  However I can also see that as being just how they are, for both characters: Iori is used to having everything he does be perfect, so it would make sense that he can be rather imposing with his ideas and suggestions.  Tsumugi is shy, and whatever confidence she had in her management abilities takes a huge hit within the first few episodes as well.I might not be an avid consumer of idol anime, but this one is undoubtedly great and I hope that more people give it a chance.

This is the anime of the year for me, this is really amazing in my opinion. It is just so down to earth and genuine feeling, combine that with an excellent story and rare spot on directory/script making - this is seriously something special and I feel bad for anybody who'd miss it because it doesn't seem like what they were looking for. If you lke drama shows you should give the first episode a try.It was made with pure passion and love, there isn't anything about it that feels stilted and like it was inserted just to please the viewers. That's kinda rare, and if you can recall really great shows, that's usually the case with them.The story is pleasanly creative and keeps surprising you, I love that so much. The characters always feel down to earth and realistic, which gives the kyonai effect. Since it's all down to earth and not exaggeraeted, you connect to it, and when things happen you feel them with no need for dramatic music or over the top crying or whatever - the characters can say what a real person would and it impacts you emotionally just as much.The animation is fantastic, it looks great, imo the lives are the best anime idol lives in anime history. In a second watch you can notice details that aren't good in them, where as in Love Live it's all clean and beautiful, but in the first watch that's not what you see, and the motion capture they used for the dancing and the effects they used for the visuals work brilliantly to bring a gush of excitement just like the crowd gets. Seriously, if you analyse the lives' shots you can notice there was a lot of attention to using them well to convey the excitement, with characters moving loosely around the frame to show the wild dancing, or showing fans overjoyed in the right moments for an impact. It's seriously a work of art.The background music is new too, they used more like DJ/american or something sounding stuff for the more lighthearted tracks and it's really cool, it sounds great and it's a mix up from what I'm used to hear.The comedy is hilarious, oh my god. The spot on directory I mentioned earlier helps that a lot. The timing of the lines and sounds can be really perfect and it's really funny. The jokes are great one by one, even my mom laughed out loud as I described some of them to her.I wish I could say it is really a 10/10 but I know there are tiny imperfections that would bother some that I easily didn't mind. Sometimes they try to set up information about future stuff and it goes over your head and you just wonder what the point of that talk is. That happened heavily in episode 2 which made me think "oh, so it is a regular idol show after all?" but no no no no. Luckily it happened pretty rarely after episode 2 so that's fun. It's also imperfect how EVERYBODY has some drama stuff attached to them, like that's very fun to watch but admittedly it's not that realistic. I think it was handled so well though that I really doubt anybody would mind that, none of the drama is drama just for the sake of being serious - it all has great messages and was done organically, it all feels like genuinely good drama that genuinely fits the characters and enhances the story. I feel like I can't complain, but idk, maybe somebody else would.Anway, as I said, I think this is amazing, I think it's pretty groundbreaking. I hope it will gain the popularity it deserves, and I hope other studios will mark this as inspirational. It was clearly made with a lot of love and passion, very organically and with 0 fanservice in mind. It just makes it incredibly good, you wanna keep going on and on and you feel for them so much. I'm gonna get the blu-ray because I want more seasons, please try the first episode! If you feel hooked at the beginning but it fades off in peisode 2, don't drop it! I felt like that too, from episode 3 and on it's a steady ride.

One of the greatest shows to kick back and watch when you're avoiding your larger responsibilities in life.  Definitely worth watching if you want a melodramatic but funny experience with seven singing boys (who arguably represent the seven deadly sins, in my opinion) and the trio of much more attractive boys who sometimes oppose them.  Even the boring members turn out to have something interesting to bring to the table.  It's good.

This show was great and I was glad I watched it. This series showed the struggles and the emotions of stars trying to reach to the top. It made you understand each character and learn about them, even the minor ones like the fangirls! I loved how the rivals were also supporting, unlike most shows which only focuses on the rival's bad sides. It made you fall in love with both idol groups, and in the end, wanting both of them to become the best they can be. At the end of the series, I felt like I've known each character, but still hungry for more. One of the best idol shows I've ever watched!

This Idol anime is well designed, animated, and thought out. The progression doesn't feel off. The characters feel unique but familiar and are interesting. The dynamics between the cast remains fresh and interesting because of their different ideologies and back grounds. While I still prefer Uta-Pri, this is right up there in the top of my anime lists. The story is so good, the characters interesting, the music is fun and makes me feel like I'm at a concert.

I'm not usually one for idol franchises in general, but IDOLiSH7 has completely won me over. Even though everyone's pretty formulaic at the start - each boy has a color, number, musical symbol, and key characteristic, if you will - you start getting hints and pieces of what lies beneath their bright, hopeful shiny exterior. After watching the first episode, I did go download and play the game, so I'm eagerly awaiting Season 2 as we get even more in depth into each of the boys backgrounds and stories!

Holy crap, this is an amazing show. It is absolute perfection in pacing, animation, voice acting and music quality, and I fell in love with every single character, from the main manager character to every single one of the idol group, the rival characters, and even the side fan characters.The fact that this is one of those animes based on a dating sim/rhythm/mobile games comes as a shock. These types of animes are often plagued with terrible characters and plot, where the main avatar character is so bland so as to be completely spineless and detestable, and the idols are left with so little characterization they might as well be overdressed scenery, all the while insisting that we're supposed to like and be invested in these characters.This anime falls prey to none of that, and has genuinely moving moments. Without giving away any spoilers, I found myself laughing and cheering along with their successes, as well as feeling completely devastated by their setbacks. It's so rare to find an anime capable of getting me this invested these days, much less one based on a mobile game.You do not have to play the game to love this anime or understand what's going on. It is wonderful and stands on its own. If you're looking your next anime about camaraderie and overcoming struggles together, you need to watch this right now!

First time when I watch this anime, I was thinking that whoever made this... the guys seem to be very pathetic and weak. My interest to watch it decreases. But, I think after watching the first episodes. I could not stop watching it! They are funny in their own way even though they are very immature and not professional like the other bands. They have never hated them or make the other bands as their rivals. Instead, they always learn from them and take their career to success.

there are a lot of idol animes out there that promise good music and well the japanese idol experience. as someone who went to some of the concerts the cgi on most at the concerts are horrible and that one thing i can appreciate that they did not to that. also the story is really great. there are a real progression of the characters and story. i really love how the season end and they are not stars. the one thing i worry is the second season many times they just start the gimmicky songs and season. i appreciate there no reverse harem aspect and just idols. i hope next season does not disappoint.

Really enjoyed the first 1-2 Episode being combined and not extremely rushed. While they still used CGI for the concert performance scenes it didn't feel nearly as static as a lot of the other current singing series with their CGI. Was a lot smoother and felt like it had more "moves" although they weren't entirely in sync since it was only their first performance. More reasonable as in new band - not many fans yet and working hard to get your name out there ect. Looking for more character development but definitely will be keeping this one in my Queue.

I mean, what to say? If that's what you're into, go for it. If not, don't bother like always. If you're expecting anything different or original, don't. Last original idol anime that interested me was Shonen Hollywood. IDOLiSH7 has the same idol formula, with hot trope guys, one being your typical blonde-hair, blue-eyed, pale skin white gaijin, and then there's your main female lead who's supposed to be you reflected in the character, but half the time the girl is just too shy. There is CGI for dancing animation, music, glitter, fangirl squeals, guys getting with the girl, etc etc. So basically, it's not for me, but it might be for you. If so, don't be ashamed and have fun with it.

Seriously, are you debating watching this show? Stop and just watch it. Actually here's a few questions to help you decide.Did you like one punch man?Yes - You'll love thisNo - Keep readingHave you ever dreamed about having psychic powers?Yes - You'll love thisNo - Keep readingHave you always wanted to see a no holds barred fight between Alakazam and Mewtwo?Yes - You'll love thisNo - Keep readingDo you enjoy stupid looking main characters that are humorously OP?Yes - You'll enjoy thisNo - Stop reading and reconsider your life choices.

All I have heard about this anime is hype, hype, hype.  "A new story by the same creator as One Punch Man" "It's going to be so OP!"  "It's going to be the best show this season, probably this year" etc.So how good is Mob Psycho 100?  Short Answer: It's pretty amazing, but I'm pissed I have to wait for season 2.Long Answer:Let's start with the story:The main plot starts with Reigen Arataka who claims to be an psychic who can exorcise ghosts/spirits.  After we quickly learn he has no gifts whatsoever, he calls in his student Mob, real name Kageyama Shigeo, to finish a job for him.  Mob is a true  and powerful psychic who easily destroys the ghost Reigen was hired to exorcise.  Reigen collects most of the money from the job, giving Mob a small amount in change.  Mob doesn't seem bothered by this since Reigen explains that ghost was a low level spirit he could have easily handled and he's just letting Mob get experiance. However, shortly after this we see a caption titled "Progress Toward Mob's Explosion: 22%"Mob has amazing psychic powers, but like Saitaman from One Punch Man (sorry I feel like it's impossible not to compare), few people actually recognize it.  Mob's parents would like him to stop bending spoons and Mob's fellow classmates ignore him because he sleeps in class, has no athletic ability, and is socially inept.  The plotline of this show goes in so many directions, espically in the early episodes. The craziness was entertaining to me becuase I never really knew what to expect.  For me, all the plot twists and character twists made Mob Psycho 100 worth watching on its own, but I also have to give a shout-out to the art becuase it's amazing.The Animation/Art:One of the things that hit me immediately with this anime is the art style.  You can really see One in it.  One is the creator of both One Punch Man and Mob Pyscho 100, however One Punch Man was redrawn by Yusuke Murata.  The anime of One Punch Man was based off Yusuke Marata's art.  On the other hand Mob Pyscho 100 has always kept One as its author and artist.  So, you can see One's art style much more in Mob Pyscho 100.  Let's be honest; One is not the best manga artist.  That said, art is in the eye of the beholder.  One's art style is unique and interesting.  Add in studio Bones and a good animation budget, and you get a pretty good looking anime that has a unique flare to it.Music:I'm no expert in the musical realm but, I think the music is pretty awesome.  I watch the opening every time because it's catchy and I always find something new to look at in the hypnotic visuals.  Mob's psychic fight scenes have this cool borderline Indian music that sounds mysterious but also gets you amped up.  Character Development:*Just be be clear I'm refering to character develop as 'changes in a character over the course of the narrative' i.e. character dymanics, not expanding the veiwers knowledge of a character.This is one of the few shows I can think of where secondary characters go through dramatic changes in character (even more so than the main characters.  Bad people turn good and good guys turn bad.  And the reasons why they change make sense. It's another one of the aspects of Mob Psycho 100 that keeps you one your toes.Comedy to Seriousiness Balance:Mob Psycho 100 is a comedy, but it gets a little more serious than One Punch Man.  It likes to end on comedic notes, but dives into deeper psychologic issues than a pure comedy show.  I found myself laughing its one-line and slap-stick style jokes, but it shines at satircal comedy.  If you thought One Punch man had good comedy you'll like Mob Psycho 100.If that all was too much to read throughReasons to Watch Mob Psycho 100:-Crazy plot-Funny-Interesting characters-Cool art-Great Opening-Intense fight scenesDon't Watch Mob Psycho 100 If:-You hate uncompleted shows (but there is a guaranteed 2nd season)-You hate rollercoaster shows that are too crazy and move too fast-You're a hipster that will automatically hate anything that is popularOne last piece of advice: Keep watching until the very end of the second episode.  The first episode is very directionless and nothing unexpected happens until the end of episode 2.  Episode 3 finally dives into some cool fight scenes and they get even more intense after that.

So surprisingly, it has been awhile since the end run of One Punch Man, a series that literally had every one laughing their heads off as they were cultivated by an egg headed god running around destroying enemies (with one punch of course) and creating misunderstandings everywhere. While everyone waits on a season 2 (which let's be fair here, we won't see it for a long time)[EDIT: Okay I did say that when I first wrote this review, but OPM did just get greenlit for a season 2 so. Maybe it will come sooner than expected. Anyway, moving forward.]there are always going to be new shows to talk about. Madhouse has moved on to create shows like Prince of Stride, Alderamin In The Sky and in the future I think they have a show called All Out scheduled for release.  Erased and Ajin came around in the Winter season, and both of those shows left a pretty good impact on the community as well. Twin Star Exorcists came out and showed everyone that Pierrot cares about all of it's works except for Naruto (although I guess the filler is pretty popular in Japan, so I guess they do care). Bones had just finished up their adaptation of Boku Hero No Academia which if you haven't seen that, please go do so it's pretty awesome. However Bones wasn't satisfied enough for the year after giving us a great show like that. No they had to take it "ONE" step further (see what I did there?) and keep the momentum rolling with the airing of Mob Psycho 100, created by the very same being who created One Punch Man. And after seeing the first episode to say I was ultra super happy would be kind of an understatement. So being already caught up to the web comic, Mob Psycho 100 definitely shows plenty of promise to build the hype train. Sure it won't do as much as One Punch Man did, but given the studio behind it, and the fact that Yoshimichi Kameda is involved (did key animation for some no name works like Evangelion 3.0, Soul Eater, FMA Brotherhood and oh yeah One Punch Man), it definitely spells great things to come out of the show. So what is Mob Psycho 100 about? Well to be pretty simple, It's about a middle school boy named Shigeo Kageyama, who just wants to live a normal life. The kicker is however, he is a super powerful esper, a being with psychic abilities. Although he would like to keep this power a secret, some people are aware of his abilities. His family knows about them, and another person named Reigen Arataka knows about them. Reigen is what you could call..... a fraud. And I'm pretty sure a lot of people who aren't familiar with the web comic aren't too fond of him from the first episode alone, but thankfully the series does build on his character, and to be honest for me, he's probably my favorite character in the entirety of the series (just like a TINY bit higher than Mob, for reasons I cannot say because then I would have to spoil it...... and no one likes spoilers (for the most part)). Anyway, Reigen runs an exorcism clinic of sorts, and although he claims he can exorcise any spirit that comes his way, he kiiinda has to call out to Mob for some help.... and by some I mean all the time, at least when the table salt solution fails (which it does). Mob does get paid, roughly a little bit more than your standard waiter / waitress an hour. So basically you could almost consider it slave labor, but apparently to Mob, he doesn't mind it so much. Another thing you may have noticed is that percentage that ticks off until Mob's explosion. Mob is basically bottling up his feelings as he goes about his daily life, but as you can see from the first episode, any time his stress builds up, the percentage meter towards his explosion does the same. As you would expect, once that meter hits 100, he loses control and well..... and explosion happens. Mob does his best to keep these powers suppressed, but there are always going to be people that will push his buttons unknowingly aware of what might happen to them. All in all I have high hopes for this series, the animation is great considering the source material (and honestly after reading it for awhile now the web comic material is actually pretty nice as well, despite what people might say about it), the music has a really cool vibe to the show, and the opening and endings get you so hype for the episode and for the next. Do I think Mob Psycho 100 is going to live up to the hype of One Punch Man? Probably not, because One Punch is a different beast. However that being said, I think the show will be great enough to stand and earn high praises on it's own when it's all said and done, rather than staying the shadow of the gargantuan that is OPM that came before it. Also for additional stuff, I had just read a conversation between the director Yuzuru Tachikawa and ONE discussing the series being adapted, I think it's pretty cool, and kind of gives you a gist of what may occur in the show in the future.

Just so we're clear, Mob is by no means a repeat of One Punch Man, though I don't think I would complain even if it was.One Punch Man and Mob Psycho are both stories about insanely powerful characters, and while OP man ends there, Mob Psycho delves much deeper.On the outside, Mob is a comedy about a lackluster middle-school student. As we grow to know Mob, we discover a child who is horrified of his own power... When he allows himself to experience the most human part of his being - his emotions - that power is swells beyond the point he can control, so he suppresses his emotions - in essence, his humanity - at all costs. Despite this complex, he is still a teenage boy who desires acceptance and confidence. Before Mob realizes it, he finds himself surrounded by a cast of endearing characters who place their confidence in him, spurring him on to discover his own potential and, in so doing, his own humanity.PLEASE, do yourself the favor of watching this show. You'll be glad you did.

Mob Psycho 100 is a showcase of the best things anime has to offer and is the epitome of great storytelling, animation, pacing, character development, comedy, and of course, ACTION. The MC is lovable. The characters are hilarious, creative, and well thought out, development-wise. The action scenes will pump adrenaline through your veins so fast, there should be a warning for addicts. This anime will make you laugh. It will make you cry. It will make you say OMG WTF ROFLCOPTER many times. Regardless of the preference one may have when it comes to genres, this show is to be watched by anyone and everyone who has ever even heard of what anime is. To do otherwise would be doing a great disservice to both the show and yourself. 10/10 stars

The animation is phenomenal, the art is great, the story is intact. And while I can see the comparisons to One Punch Man coming, these are very different series, that look the same at a glance. in general, Mob Psycho is much more serious, especially since One Punch Man started as a joke manga as a test of some page layout software, whereas this is what the author originally had (and arguably still has) as his main series.In short, give it a shot, because this is going to be one of those series that keeps getting better

From the first 2 episodes you could have easily dropped it and assumed that the series would just turn for the worse. But after the initial build up from the very basics of character development and such the anime had turned up to 10. In the most recent episodes you can see the plot becoming more defined and the overall writing shining through. If you want to give it a real try, dont just watch the first 2 episodes, at least watch the first 4 or 5 then make a decision. I initially was skeptical because of the first episode because of cringey Reigen and bland character, but it turned up to 10 and all the characters have grown on me a little more. There are a lot of emotions that can be derived from the show, and I believe that people are mistaking the art style for a simple attempt at a comedy, but I believe its a whole lot more than that. At first glance you'd tihnk it would try to go for comedy through and through but in reality I think it just makes it distinguished and gives the characters originality and present a more metaphorical approach to display each character's struggles. IMO this is more on the serious end, but with  anot very serious feel, definitely makes you think and makes you feel. Give it a try :D:D:D one of my tops for the season.

If you've seen  One Punch Man, then you know what to expect. Mob knows that he's the most powerful. Yet it's not his defining trait. He's hardly even a protagonist- he's just a small, weak kid, with no friends, few skills, and no physique. But he has a kind heart, a curious mind, and not an ounce of guile in him.Couple this with psychic powers like that of a god, and you have a character that you can root for.Overall, the meat-and-potatoes of this series isn't the flashy use of awesome cosmic power; it's the small kindnesses, the personal revelations, the growth and changing of the characters in front of you. In this, it surpasses One Punch Man's anime by far.It might start a little slow, but this anime is almost sure to make you laugh, cheer, and think. And isn't that worth investing a little time in?
