This is the perfect show for anyone who loves a Mc with power beyond anyone else. This show has a similar plot as many other shows but this shows executes every single scene perfectly. The Mc "Ains Ooal Gown" is a overlord with supreme power on a quest to conquer the world. This show is very comical, unique, and most of all ENTERTAINING! I would Recommend this show to anyone who wants to watch a very entertaining and funny show

At first this anime seems to be the typical MMO Driven Anime, however, as seasons progress you begin the realize the ingenious mind of Kugane Maruyama.   The attention to detail of different character personalities does not disappoint. You'll find even the character development of characters doomed to die will catch you off guard when they actually die.   Kugane Maruyama will lead you on an adventure towards climatic scenarios that you want to see so desperately bad, and then he will give you the climatic resolve you so so desired in an orgasmic outcome of pleasure and the need for more.   The surprising Originality of the anime, despite being a MMO-Style Anime is very pleasing. I get so involved into the world that I almost forget entirely that the MC is a MMO player.   Adding to the Originality you'll also watch as the path of the MC Slowly takes him down a Dark Path leaving his humanity behind him. Highly Recommend this Action Packed Anime

So, there's a trend lately of anime with ridiculously OP characters that don't take themselves too seriously, and this is most certainly an example of that.  So, if that doesn't appeal to you, this show won't either.  At first, this looks like this will be an SAO-style anime, but once the protagonist encounters enemies in this world, it's obvious he outclasses them on every level.  Momonga is a max level rpg character and guild leader who gets transported to a real fantasy world, along with his guild hall and all his npc minions (who also greatly outclass all enemies encountered thus far).  On top of all that, he's also very intelligent and doesn't take risks (although he easily could afford to).  So, in terms of power level, it's like "What if Light Yagami (from Death Note) was One Punch Man, and what if he also had an army of One Punch Men with which to punch men once?"If you're looking for a fun power trip, a silly comedy, or an epic (albeit relatively low-stakes for the protagonist) fantasy adventure, this checks all those boxes nicely.One final note, the Opening and Closing theme songs from artists "OxT" and "Myth & Roid" have been consistently top notch for all three seasons thus far.

Of all shows in this genre, Overlord is without doubt the best crafted alongside Log Horizon. The characters are well developed, and have more depth than the majority of the anime in this genre which sometimes feel more surface level. There's a healthy amount of fan service if you're interested in that, but if that's something that can put you off of a show - it's not a focus in more than the first 2 episodes of season one. The first two episodes are likely designed this way as a hook for the incel crowd and dialed down in comparison to some anime that is floating around on Crunchyroll. Definitely worth giving it a shot, stop if you don't like it after episode 4 or 5. 10/10 A+ top kek

I slept on this anime for so long, then I decided to add it to my queue but kept skipping it didn't seem interesting (even though it had good reviews). Finally decided to watch Episode 1 and WOW amazing. For a few minutes I though it was going to be another anime where he is trapped in a game, someone who is weak, scare, doesn't want to hurt no one (especially humans), but NOPE I was completely wrong. Anyways don't skip this anime is entertaining, funny, exciting, and the art is superb. Finish it in 2 days.

We're all familiar with the genre of being pulled into a video game world. However, this is a fresh take on it. In this series, the protagonist finds his game world turning real. However unlike other series where a good guy gets trapped in a new world, this guy was the leader of a guild of bad guys - the monster types, who thwarted adventurers. So for this series, the goal isn't really about escape. It's about dominating the new world. He's not an evil person, but at the same time he doesn't care about breaking a few eggs to get what he wants. He has no problem crushing anyone that gets in the way of his plans. And it's fantastic. I am a latecomer to this series, but I burned through all of season 1 and got caught up on season 2 in record time, because the entertainment factor is really high.

I absolutely loved season 1 of Overlord, as it puts the tired genre of "stuck in an MMO" on it's head. Originally, I found Overlord on Funimation a couple years back. Although my friend recommended against me watching it, I was way too intrigued by the thumbnail given to the series. I am honestly ecstatic that I went through with it in the end, as it is by and far my favorite anime of all time now. This is the first anime that actually got me to go through and read its original source material in the LNs. Every character is masterfully crafted in my opinion, and the few times that explanations are not specifically used (such as the case with Albedo's race), they are covered just as beautifully created and explained in said Light Novels. Although the anime did an amazing job with the adaption, I would highly recommend the LN because it gives more of a complete picture of how they were all crafted.So for TL;DR purposes: If you have not watched this anime yet, you are denying yourself from seeing some truly amazing work. For newbies to the series: give the series a shot. For newbies and veterans alike: read the LNs as well if you want the complete experiences.I for one cannot wait for season 2 to drop within the next couple weeks!

Overlord is what you would expect from an MMORPG based story. Main character somehow ends up in the game after something goes wrong and thus uses his/her gaming knowledge to overcome obstacles and threats through the story. Overlord is just like that, however it is the way this is presented that makes the story interesting from start to finish.The main character, Momonga (Ainz Ooal Gown) finds himself stuck in an MMORPG called Yggdrasil after the servers are shut down for good while he is still logged in. However the world he is now stuck inside becomes more realistic than just a game. Taking on the physical persona of his in-game avatar, Momonga's story throughout the series revolves around exploring the world of Yggdrasil alongside his companions who were simple NPC's in the game but have now acquired personalities of their own. The story-telling is quite balanced. You never feel like you're out of the loop throughout the story, nor are you left with a sense of boredom due to things moving slow. The main selling point of this anime are the characters, more specifically the dynamic between Momonga and one of his minions, Albedo who was originally just an NPC character that inhabited the guild hall of the game prior to the server shut down. Now I know what you're thinking. How is this any different than Log Horizon or Sword Art Online? Well while it does have similarities to other anime/manga that delve into the world of protagonist in a virtual setting, it differs in the fact that instead of other players, the world of Yggdrasil is inhabited by former NPC's now with their own personalities. It is definitely worth a watch if you enjoy the type of 'stuck in a video-game world' setting. The story, the characters, the music and the atmosphere are exceptional and are sure to draw you in.  If you find yourself in need of something to watch, I highly suggest Overlord especially now that it has been confirmed that Overlord will be getting a second season in the future!

How do you review a nearly perfect show, what could I possibly say that would be worth reading? This show is incredible. It perfectly balances telling a story about the main character and his minions in a way where they aren't simply minor characters that you will forget off screen. It shows the motivations of all the ancillary characters and what drives them very well without making them seem like throw away characters used simply to advance a plot. This show is one of those shows that gets a repeated viewing from me when I watch a new show that turns out to be a dud which happens far more frequently since there is just so much damn anime these days. Watch this show, then watch it again to see all the little things you may have missed.

Are you sick an tired of trapped in an MMORPG anime? Me too. Quire sadly it has taken over almost the entirety of fantasy anime, meaning that getting some normal fantasy anime is very rare. All the game talk and level systems get in the way of the story. Overlord does a great job of breaking that scheme. Sure, the series starts with the main character being trapped in a game, but it evolves in such a way that it steps away from that flat, overused and abused narrative to lean more and more on the fantasy elements. The show also gives a great perspective by playing from the main antagonist's perspective, rather than the heroes. Very enjoyable and highly recommended. I do hope however that we get some true fantasy anime back into the mind of producers.

This anime started off slow for me. The hook missed its mark during the first episode and I contemplated on whether I should continue with Overlord.I'm glad I decided to watch the second episode as from there on, the hook was cast deep and I became quite interested in knowing what Lord Ains will be doing next to further his ambitions in the new world.Fantastic series, I powered through the three seasons in three days. I'm reading that a fourth season is due to come out somewhat soon so i'm excited.All hail Sorcerer King Ains Ooal Gown!

Today, the isekai is considered stale, and people have not been enjoying it as much ever since Sword Art Online came out. I, personally, am a fan of isekais, but I can see why people think that they are getting old.At the beginning, you might think to yourself that Overlord is just a generic isekai with an insanely overpowered main character. He gets stuck in a game as the character he was playing, is a mage, and is incredibly overpowered.As the show goes on, however, there is a lot of character development and the plot gets really intense. The first season focuses mostly on Ains, but the second and third focus more on the side characters.This anime is by far one of my favorites and will most likely stay that way for a long time to come.

Now I just spat some straight facts up there, along with a few head turns, but don't worry I have the words and descriptions for you.So here's a good synopsis from the isekai connoisseur as myself:An average man with ties to his past guild is transported to a new world, along with his guild base. This new world is home to several characters with their own interests and goals, however one day this newly transported boi comes and creates some problems and solves said problems with his own spin on it.This anime focuses not only on a level 100 World-class "god" but the inhabitants of this new world. And that right there is the selling point. Its not the villainous deeds the protagonist commits. Its the characters and how they all blend nicely together to make a believable fantasy world, especially since the camera leads you off the main character and sometimes he won't be present for whole episodes. The idea of a man with nigh unlimited power coming to ruin it all is a fun prospect, however the story should mostly be about the development of the world and how it is built upon by those around it. This is my favorite anime by far and I would love if other people saw it my way.Here let me tell you a story. I was like most folk out there, young, naive, a real stickler for a certain taste of anime. However one day a friend brought this up to me. Now I ignored it as one should to a regular RPG anime, but after some consideration and thought, I checked it out. By golly this anime rocked me like no other. It hits up on all the best parts a story should. It tells a great protagonist with realistic flaws and ambitions. It builds the world where everything is concise and nothing is rule-breaking, especially since this is meant to be a game. Characters flow through the world as each one is unique and any could be a favorite. If you considered this anime even a little. I whole heartily implore you, please check it out. The first episode won't be enough to real you in, but its a start, and before you know it you may be up at 3 A.M. wondering how you got here with a smile on your face.

This series had the potential to be an absolute masterpiece. The world building that Maruyama wrote into his tail is expansive. The plot is fresh, and has you pondering the validity of might makes right. But, the studio that makes it always starts with some decent animation, but very quickly everything deteriorates into pan still shots. The CGI is atrocious, especially in season 3. It is depressing that the studio making this show pours so little love into it, but I still enjoyed it.

When this show first came out I didn't know what to think of it and didn't give it a try. Then the second season showed up, and I didn't even notice. But because of the trailers and reviews of the show before, during, and after the third season, I then decided to give it a try. After three days, I finished the all the seasons, and after watching from start to finish all I can think is... WHY HAVEN'T I SEEN THIS SOONER!!! Man I was an idiot for ignoring this show because it was amazing. The fights were great, and the story kept me on the edge of my seat. And I mean that literally, I almost fell. It was so funny at some scenes, and the story kept you wanting to see more of the world and characters. If I could think of one word to describe this show, it would be magnificent!

In my opinion, the best fantasy anime out there! Of course it has its downsides with little action from time to time and madness mixed into the whole thing. But that is what makes it so good! This isn't a normal fantasy anime where the person is super powerful, well he is but he has also lost his connection to his humanity, meaning that he has gone straight down the villain hole. You're basically watching a show from the evil demon lord's perspective! Of course, he still has some connections where he does some things out of habit but then he has no idea why. You're basically following the making of an absolute evil!

Overlord has quickly become one of my favorite series to watch, with an interesting and diverse cast of characters that are all extremely intriguing in their own right, coupled with a story that can pull you in with its many twists and turns, especially the stuff that you don't really get an explanation for. Overlord lets you see a small part in a much grander scale, and doesn't try to explain everything to the audience through dunce characters, which is one of my favorite things about the show. it can be slow in places, especially around the lizardman arc, and it sometimes suffers in terms of animation, but it is very much worth watching, and i will always recomend it.

I love this anime, I really do, but its CGI battles really left me feeling a little bit down. It kinda feels like they cut some corners there. The animation is super smooth, the story is very interesting but when the CGI effects come in it kinda feels forced. This latest season really drove it home though. The CGI goblins, battles, and creatures were very difficult to watch, which is a let down because the story is getting good. But I would still recommend that you watch it for yourself and not just take my word for it. I mean what do I know I'm just a guy on the Internet.

I'll start by saying this:Season 3 did a great job with the characters and the over arcing story, because of these qualities I will definitely return for the next season.However if this were any other show I would have given up do to the over use of CGI and underwhelming ridiculous CGI fights. Spoiler Alert! Click to show or hideBattles like the Goblins vs the Humans looked so ridiculous that it completely took away any emotional weight that episode had. You can also see this in the final battle of the show, the baby goats were meant to be terrifying, but to see the terribly animated CGI monsters stomp through a crowd of faceless CGI lookalikes is completely ridiculous and betrays the horror that the scene was trying to impart. If next season is like this then I'm afraid I'm going to have to drop this show and read the light novels/manga.

Overlord is what I would call a special type of guilty pleasure, it may seem just like another power fantasy, but it is more than that.What Overlord does right that many others like it don't, in my opinion would be it's setup and that our protagonist for all intents and purposes is the villain. The power fantasy that is Overlord is one that strikes fear into adventures, heroes, entire races, you name it. The satisfaction of seeing the good guys work up plans and actions to then be torn down by our "hero" just seems to work surprisingly well. Of course though the villain needs to be good, and Ains Ooal Gown manages to be that perfect embodiment of a power fantasy, he is respectable and always willing to give his opponent the chance. Only to then strike them down disgustingly fast when his generosity is overlooked. His servants also manage to bring their own intimidation when out on the field, spreading the will of their supreme one. Top it all off with some witty humor among Ains and his subordinates during down time and you got a large cast of good villains brimming with personality and power. Overlord is by far one of the best power fantasy anime on the market, and is well worth the watch for those looking for a good isekai. (Yes, it is in fact a isekai, a great one too!)

Great overall. The story progresses very slowly but makes up for it with a lot of world building and character building that keeps you curious about what comes next. Animation rating I would give 7.5-8.5 out of 10. There are moments where I would have liked to see more effort placed into the art work rather than the use of CG but overall does not take away from the show. Season 3 however used more CG than the previous seasons and I'm hoping this does not become a trend with the series. Nice mix of MMO and Dungeon and Dragon terminology. Excellent fantasy setting. Seasons may need re-watching to pick up on subtle hints left in dialogue that later are brought up. My overall rating is 8.5/10 or 4/5 stars. The missing star is due to the over use of CG and unnecessary dialogue at times.

This anime will not be for you if you are a pleb. Sounds harsh but its true. If you like naruto or sao or have only seen like 2 anime you wont enjoy this. Its not a hero story, its not a fan service plot line of hero surmounts everything. Its as the title says a series about an all powerful overlord who basically always gets his way. The anime certainly doesn't do as much justice as the book, so if you like to enjoy in mild comedy and sinister over tones. I recommend the book first and foremost. The anime is still wonderful imo, its not a super wealthy series so you can see some animation flaws. But here's the thing, its unique to the sense that we finally get to root for an evil guy. If you're tired of constant good guys being good just because, and you want to see the consequences of peoples actions. Then THIS is the series for you. Because its good to be evil.

One of the best isekai animations I've watched and the main cast of the show are all amazing characters. The fact that ainz doesnt bulls**t wins out of the love of his friends or last moment clutches from his a**. If this show ever gets canceled before the writer finishes the light novels especially with all the arcs and material he could create I would be very upset because this is in my top 5 favourite animes

I'm not a hardcore anime guy, but I do watch quite a lot. Somewhere in-between casual and hardcore. Anyway! Overlord is amazing. i'd heard about it for awhile, but never bothered looking into it. The basic premise by the description isn't the most original, guy gets stuck in a game, lots of anime like that. But this one is totally different! Not only is the main character essentially a villain of sorts, they aren't afraid to spend lots of time on NPC's or side characters. The world building is top notch, and a good blend of action, humor and personal stories make this anime hard to stop watching.

The first episode of Overlord game me a sort of Sword Art Online vibe. It's about a player  who's trapped within an Virtual Reality Massive Multiplayer Online Role Playing Game (VRMMORPG). However, that's about the only thing that these two share in common. Everything else COMPLETELY different.The main character, formerly Momonga, now Ainz Ooal Gown, is formerly a normal guy working as a sales person. He's not talented or special in any way. He's an average person with a job. He just loves the game he's playing in. When the game was announced to be shut down, he stayed until shutdown. Then he awoke in a new world, now only in control of his avatar turned real body and now talking to the NPC's that he and his guild members created.What's compelling about the main character is that he's ultimately just a guy trying to hold the reins in a situation that he has no idea about. Despite playing up to the role of the Lord of Death and Overlord of the Great Tomb of Nazarick, he's still learning and trying to be better.The cast of characters is plentiful and interesting as well. From the lovely Albedo to the kinky Shalltear to the quirky twins Aura and Mare, all the NPC's brought to life are a treat to watch.There's no real sense of danger, but all the same, it's fun to watch Ainz crush stupid people and anyone who thinks they have a snowball in hell's chance of beating him or his powerful and numerous servants. Also just as enjoyable is the sense of discovery. New territories and kingdoms are fun to see because Ainz and his minions actively shape the world around them, making them active protagonists.Also, this is a different spin of the guy trapped in the game because the guy isn't the good guy. He's a magical skeleton, so he plays the role of an evil monster, even if that isn't necessarily who he is as a person.If you still need convincing, there are plenty of battles, lots of excellent dialogue, and well-crafted animations.Give the "trapped in a game" anime another chance.

Unlike most of the "All-powerful normal off-worlder who jumps into the video game realm anime", Overlord includes a lot of perspectives as the main character tackles challenges in the new realm (which is referred to as Yggdrasil)Ains Ooal Gown, or the Main character, is a normally office worker who decides to visit a video game he and his friends have played on since the beginning. He wants to reminisce about in his memories when his friends were still online who no longer play the game due to IRL problems. Suddenly, he is transported into Yggdrasil where he gains the help of the NPC's his friends made and then the story goes on from there.What makes this unique is the fact that Kugane Maruyama, the creator of Overlord, puts in perspectives of simple adventurers, towns, hell, even politics in the mix to create a sense of an actual world. People who  matter to Ains Ooal Gown himself. This creates relationships with the NPCs or his "comrades" and makes sense in future plot ideas forward.The cast is actually not that forgettable. It's pretty easy remembering who is the supporting cast and who is the main cast. I highly recommend this show. It's incredibly refreshing in comparison the to the shows who follow the tropes with just pure, PURE fanservice.

On a serious note. I am seriously happy to see such a contrast from your typical pussy male leads in majority of the other Animes. We all know Ains is OP but its still so interesting to see him work towards his goals in confidence. The pacing is on point. Story is very creative. I can't stress enough how incredibly refreshing it is to see a Male lead who isn't constantly second guessing himself and is confident and believes in himself. This is a seriously satisfying show to watch.

This is by far my favorite -oh boy I'm now possibly trapped in a video game- anime. I only started watching this because Log Horizon was taking forever.Art:★★★★★ - Never been upset with how something was drawn, the CGI is done pretty well too. Doesn't go too over the top on death scenes.Story:★★★★☆ - Characters have great development. The direction is a little loose and slow to deliver but the wait is generally worth it.

This show is AMAZING its amazing, it is a show with great character righting and is unlick most other animes,  of a simalar theme Ex; Sword art online, how not to summon a demon lord, or any other shows that involve being stuck in anotherworld though how not to summon a demon lord is like this but several layers down in greatness, Momonga ( Ainz Ooal Gown ) Is a simple Man who is a social nightmare, has close to no skills for being a leader, and is overal like a loser, but suddenly he is thrust into a situation he cant controll, he is unfamilar with being a leader, a role model, A  Overlord. The characters are amazing too, such interesting personalitys, such a wide veriaty too, and it isnt just one storyline , we have had 3 so far, and i hope to have many many more.

This anime is perfect. The characters are all unique and special in some way. I'll also like to add that the creator did a fantastic job in their story building. This anime has the perfect mix of action, comedy, and a bit of romance. Also, I love seeing the characters progress and get stronger, like ( *SPOILER*) Spoiler Alert! Click to show or hideBrain Unglaus for example. His fight with Shalltear Bloodfallen has tore his will and confidence apart but recovered and managed to... give her a free nail cut? But that's still progress unlike the time where he didn't even touch her. (excluding the part where she catches the blade). I'll give this series a 5/5 for story building and unique characters. I'm looking forward to the next episode.

It's a great adaptation of the old being sucked into a game world motif. They do a great job portraying what an individual would actually do in that situation, and have fun with it because he is an undead and his guild consists of only nonhuman people. So you get to see the MC try and learn about the world as he travels and quests as "Momon," and you also see him be a badass as Ains Oowl Gown. I would recommen this show to anyone that like anime honestly, probably would give it an 8 or 9/10

Overlord puts a refreshing twist on the Isekai subgenre, a subgenre constantly plagued with subpar content and lackluster protagonists, with the protagonist this time being not an O.P. hero but rather an O.P. villain. He is the overlord of evil minions capable of annihilating entire kingdoms that worship him as a literal god. One would think this would be the usual Isekai experience; however, as Youtuber Mother's Basement said in his review, "What's So Great About Overlord," the main character actually feels like a socially awkward yet genuine guy. This creates a fantastic dynamic with him trying to act cool in front of these actually evil villains and keep up with their schemes that they think he has planned a trillion steps ahead of them. This coupled with a vast array of characters the show is one of the most refreshing and entertaining out there -- even if the embarrassing nature of the openings make me want to slam my head into my desk at Mach five.

Overlord has become the #1 for me. It's the only series I have waited on almost religiously every week to be released since I discovered it, since when DragonBall Z was airing throughout the initial 3 arcs. I refuse to read the manga until the animation has "completed;" so I can re-experience it in it's written form. There have been so many entries into this genre of anime, but I feel like this one is the first one, for me, which truly is doing it right. I won't compare it to others by name but I'm sure we can all think of a few "almosts" to the stuck-in-a-game setting.It's got the right touch of residual game-world mechanics in a realistic (relative to anime) environment, incredible character and world building, immense depth to characters (both expendable, and not); No way to tell which characters are gonna bite the dust, so you develop attachments to all of the characters built, and pray they survive / mourn if they do not. The show has a dual nature where you will root and fear BOTH sides of the coin, good and evil. Watching the MC struggle to weigh his decisions in-character as evil or check them against his more "human (player-like / fourth wall)" decisions adds a greater level of depth to the story. The twist that NPCs are slowly evolving and could potentially change drastically from their game counterparts is a nasty, but exciting fringe benefit.My greatest worry was squashed quickly; "if he's basically max level living in starter town, won't this get boring?" NOPE! Turns out the threats of real-life to everyone but him are far more terrifying when put into context of the MC's ambitions. The added layer of actually caring about dozens of other characters the MC's decisions affect make you think what YOU would do in that situation, and worry if the choices he's making will impact things/people you care about. It's a dynamic I don't think I've ever experienced to this degree in anything aside from actual RPG games where I have direct control over character interaction.I will refrain from any more in fear of spoiling stuff. If you're on the fence, just watch the first few episodes. You'll be hooked. I mean hell, I finally made a username just to post this. Enjoy.

The characters are cool, the overlord is intriguing and flawed (but don't tell any of the minions that), the pacing is completely perfect, and although the main character seems OP, there is clearly a threat in the world.This anime captures wonderfully the danger of the unknown and the benefit of a methodical and planned approach to things. A refreshing change from the headstrong protagonist that charges in despite knowing nothing and prevailing because of plot convenience. While I understand that a careful planner may not seem to be an obvious choice of character to make an interesting story, this is a stellar example of how to do that and make it shine.Lastly, it always has a great OP and ED.

TL;DR: 9.4/10. Definitely worth watching.Overlord is a high fantasy anime where the MC ends up in his favorite game's world. As is often the case with this genre, the MC is stupidly overpowered from the get-go, which often leads to a severe case of "I know the MC is going to win anyway, so there is no suspense" syndrome. Luckily, this is not the case in Overlord, Overlord excels where most animes fail: World building and character building. This ultimately leads to relatable weaker characters that have struggles, ambitions, dreams, and woes.10/10 Story(It's a bit slow at times, due to the aforementioned world/character building, though since this is what gives the show an edge over every other "Trapped in a game world" Anime I've seen, it doesn't subtract anything from the score. And isn't as fleshed out as it ought to be due to its relatively short seasons)10/10 Humor(I seldom laugh at Animes. This one tickles my funny bone, though)10/10 Characters(Due to the large percentage of time dedicated to character building, it lands on 10/10. The characters induce a sense of sonderness. Which is what every character should do.)7/10 Animation(It's good, just not spectacular. Doesn't take away anything from the show, but probably won't age that well, IMO)10/10 Lore(Lore is important in any Anime set in a game world. Overlord excels at this part. Everything is extremely well done and fleshed out)All this lands Overlord at a well deserved 9.4/10 overall. Am I biased? Yes. Is Overlord worth watching? Absolutely.

I like Overlord. My one problem is the fact that the rate of plot progression is too slow. Not in a boring filler way. The episodes are still genuinely engaging, but not enough happens in a season. Overlord is structured in a way one would expect a longer series to be structured but doesn't have the season length to justify this. If there were large seasons like 24 episode long or it had BEEFY long-ass episodes this wouldn't be a problem but with only 13 20 or so minute episodes in a season, the end of a season (season 2 in particular) feels way too early.

TL;DR:  Thicc Skeleton Daddy doesn't even need his golden pimp cane to crush lesser Isekai into submission. The undisputed Overlord of the Isekai genre, Overlord is the epitome of what this genre should and can be.  Through great storytelling, world building, and a beautiful supporting cast with plot for days; Overlord now sits at the top demanding other shows to get on its level.The protagonist Momonga (aka. Ainz Ooal Gown, aka. Big Skeleton Daddy [B.S.D.]), starts off as the stereotypical gamer who has a hard time socializing with others; so he role plays as his character instead-The basic character formula that almost every Isekai shares. But after three seasons, even though he can still be unsure at times, B.S.D. has come a long way.  He's steadily evolves as a character, grown as a leader, demonstrates a knack for strategy and ability to learn from both successes & failures.  While other Isekai craft a story for their socially awkward op protagonist to follow, Overlord instead has the protagonist create the story themselves. What a novel concept! B.S.D. ends his first day in this new world with the goal of conquering it-not having to defeat the evil demon king in a far away land or save the world from a great evil; B.S.D. is that big bad and trounces every other would be conqueror that would dare impede his progress toward that goal.  The same man who role played as the absolute ruler of his MMORPG has continued that same role in this new world. This anime speaks to the fact that given the power, resources, and opportunity to take over the world & shape it the way you'd want to, you would do it.  If you were all powerful and could wield magic & armies at your command, you wouldn't follow someone else as they guide you on a journey-you'd carve your own path.  You would do whatever you wanted to do.  And it just so happens that what B.S.D. wants is world domination. You owe it to yourself to watch this anime.

So many animes and shows tend to follow tropes of following the good guy, and fighting against the bad guy. Overlord stands above so many other shows by creating a world that is not only more complex than a lot of other shows, but the main characters of the show are not necessarily protagonists, and are most certainly not heros. In fact, some could be seen as outright villains. The main character himself is not your average anime hero, but an undead skeleton. And he does not need to learn his abilities or power, he already has them day one. This allows the show to concentrate more on the world, and the character development itself, rather than overcoming physical fight obstacles. His flaws come from who he used to be in the old world, making him much more complex. He also deals with the fact that despite him being surrounded by adoring subjects and minions, he is in fact quite lonely as he had been practically abandoned by his friends.Not just that, but because of the way the main character is, and his supporting characters, there is a real sense of risk to the minor characters. People who have personalities and character built up, and are even seen as important to the story, may very well end up dead, sometimes even in pointless ways. Innocent people DO DIE because of the main character, and remorse for these actions is not shown by him.If there are some flaws to the show, it would be that sometimes stories can be rushed a little quickly, and aren't given quite enough time to be fleshed out. Another flaw is that sometimes it seems like the story goes in unnecessary directions, for seemingly nothing but filler. A good example of this would be the first half of season 2, which seems to focus on characters that almost seem unimportant, while the main characters take a back seat. However, I personally do not think this is the case as it builds the world, and sets up the stage for future parts.All in all though, I can easily say this is one of my favorite animes, if not my favorite simply because of it's magnificent storytelling, fun characters, expansive world, with a good bit of humor, wit, and power mixed in.

One of my favorite things to see in anime is when a show takes a stereotypical situation and simply flips it, fajumbles it, makes it all wibbly-wobbly.Overlord does this beautifully, from the rivalry between Albedo and Shalltear, to the great fight scenes, this Anime had me completely immersed for the entirety of the ride. (SPOILERS)My favorite part of the second season was all of the utter confusion. I loved how everyone was fighting everyone thinking they were someone else. The biggest disappointment was that there wasn't a scene where everyone just stopped fighting and said: "wait a minute are you fighting for the Eight Fingers?" "No we just beat the crap out of them" "then why are we fighting?" "You attacked first" "oops"(done)Can't wait for season 3 and hope they delve deeper into the stories of the guardians and give some more of that sweet sweet character growth like we got with sebas.

First review, this show brought me to it. There's an indescribable feeling of contentment I derive from overpowered main characters. I enjoyed one-punch man and mob psycho 100, so naturally I enjoyed this, too. There's plenty of comic relief, accompanied by a considerable amount of ass-kicking done by the protagonists. Characters are building well in my opinion. Soundtrack is bad-ass and definitely impressionable. 10/10 would recommend.

The show tends to get a little slow towards the middle and pics it back up in the end of every season so far and that's not a bad thing. The creators have brought more dimension to the supporting cast of characters. The first Season being Mostly about the MC Lord Ains, Season 2 takes it by probing more into the Secondary characters The Floor Guardians And 3 seems to be going into the Maid Staff and others around the background all while the MC takes a steady rise to power in this new world.A must watch for those who enjoy High Fantasy or Story Driven RPG's

There is not much i can add as far as reviews go . After watching season 1 and 2 I can say i Really enjoyed this show , and i hope it comes back for another season or 2 .I started watching the show on a whim , i was bored and not much looked interesting .I prefer darker , more mature anime.I was pleasantly surprised and as i stated above i quite enjoyed the show .I recommended it to my son and he liked it also .

There is a great deal of depth to this anime, far beyond the surface level cries of 'sexual exploitation' that some are spouting. The society depicted in this anime mirrors our own in a few unique ways. For one, I do not look at the process of piloting the FRANXX as 'male dominance'. The themes evident here are immediately sexual. As such, the male-female duo is not unlike the act of procreation in our world. Much like our world, the female is responsible for generating 'life'. The male plugs into the female and both work together to create a child. In DARLING in the FRANXX, this same duo is creating the energy, or life, to pilot the mech. Indeed, while many may blindly see this as 'male exploitation of women', can you also not say that the male is dependent on the female partner? The plot even says that they must be in perfect resonance in order to function. They both NEED to rely on one another in order to succeed. There are no duplicitous motives, only harmonious ones. Philosophies aside, the animation is top-notch, and Zero Two takes the spotlight as an engaging character that adds much to the movement of the plot. She is sporadic, barbaric, romantic, and unusual, and has both a primal and refined take on 'love'. Her affection for her 'darling' is slightly overbearing, if not excessive at times (blood and saliva seem to be regularly shared to symbolize their connection), but it is also refined as she employs the heartfelt and classic pet name 'darling' to describe her feelings. The way she gazes upon him fondly, caresses his head, and confronts those who might challenge their relationship, is indicative of a more civilized mind. All in all, I look forward to seeing how the merger of these two lost and lonely souls brings them a renewed life together.

This show has a very slow build up exploring relations ships and what it means to be human in a world where humans have stripped themselves of humanity. Kids raised more like machines than people struggle to understand how to relate to each other.World building Is slow and gradual but almost every episode, You get a new puzzle piece of the bigger picture, Prepare to take a while to start putting things together, But it's done very well.The action takes a back seat to characters, This show inst' really about the mecha at all, and the action is more of a backdrop for where the characters are in their relationships, but the writing Is very creative and tells it's story very differently than anything I'm used to. And I always am excited about what surprises the next will bring. Episode Charter development has been pretty great.I didn't like the protagonist at first, he seemed far too stale and passive, but as episodes when in my opinion of him has really changed as I've come to realize that given the environment he was raised in he's actually a very strong and independent individual, steps ahead of everyone around him.Episode 13 was a real treat the brought on some feels and Had some Elfen Lied vibes. (not in the gore and nudity department) but in some very similar mood and concepts.I've noticed many people complaining about the slow pace or the last few episodes being "filler". when to be these episodes were filed with charter development and interesting unique writing. I guess if you're expecting a fast-paced action mecha show then this show just isn't for you. Personally, with each passing episode, my enjoyment of this show is becoming on par with some of my personal favorites such as FMAB Fate/zero and Gurren Laggan.

What a strong debut! The show is like Kill La Kill, Gundam 00, and Gurren Lagann all had a baby together, which for me is awesome because it combines concepts from series that I love. Studio Trigger is back in top form with this new mecha anime. It feels like the true successor to both Kill La Kill and Gurren Lagann. I thoroughly enjoyed the first episode. The animation is top notch and the fight scenes are dynamic and flashy. The characters are interesting. My personal favorite is the mischievous mad scientist/top notch soldier 002. The concept of male and female pilot pairs is interesting and original. I plan to tune in to watch it each week and you should definitely give it a watch!

So far only two episodes are out and this is what i understand of the show.The show is a giant metaphor about relationships, sex, and intimacy. The robot is something symbolic of the relationship between the people controlling it, two people who can manage a good relationship are able to control it well and trust in each other. This can be further observed with the societal and parental pressure to have an operating relationship (robot) that these characters were expected of having. The main character, though, has obvious troubles of intimacy and understanding of what a relationship, reflecting his inability to pilot with just anyone. This is where Zero 2 has problems. She can't maintain an effective relationship with most people since its forced and they don't fully accept her. She will try to "pilot" it solo, this creates a toxic relationship that hurts both herself and her partner, often killing her partner.All of this is wrapped up in a ridiculous and gorgeous package that trigger animation is known to offer. Extremely entertaining, tons of sexual innuendos, and a very interesting way to deliver a metaphoric commentary on today's relationships. Can't wait to see where the show goes next!Edit: Now that i'm 8 episodes in i'm going to have to knock off a star for a couple reasons. 1. Hiro is a super boring character. Extremely bland, predictable, lacks personality. He doesn't have any interesting thoughts especially after the 5th episode. 2. The animation/art is usually pretty good and excellent in key moments. However, the bad moments are REALLY bad. Extremely obvious when the work is outsourced. It grossly contrasts the moments/episodes that are handled extremely well (such as the first episode). It's at its worst when the character models look awful and the environment is plain and boring.2.5. To pair with the animation, some episodes and scenes within the episode don't seem well directed at all. The first two episodes and a couple others have some excellent direction and scene construction that communicate the show to the viewer extremely well. A lot of this is somewhat lacking in several of what i dub to be the low budget episodes.Overall i feel like the show has taken a step backwards from its original episodes. Hopefully it will turn around and progress the plot while better developing Hiro since he remains to be the weakest part of the show.

I will admit by the second episode all of the sexual innuendos had me feeling rather uncomfortable in terms of the focus for this series. At this point in the series Im starting to get the feel of whats going on and rather than cringe I feel myself accepting all the sexual references as part of the art style/aesthetic. I was worried that the show would rely on its sexual nature too much and start to slide into ecchi territory (no pun intended). THIS IS NOT THE CASE. I feel the sexual nature of the show is less of an innuendo and more of a metaphor and references the intimacies of interconnected relations between two individuals. Im excited for further development, I honestly haven't had this much fun with an anime for a while!

As of the first hour of so of content I can say with a good amount of confidence that this is well worth watching. It does very well at introducing its characters and world without giving you too little or too much.Basically, do yourself a favor and just watch it, your brain will thank you later.----Possible Spoilers Past This Point---Is it original? As it is with any series, debatable. The art style and functioning (Libido power stuff) of the mechs is similar to Star Driver, the driving force of plot around the MC is similar to Argevollen where he's the only one who'll be accepted. These kids were raised in a lab for one purpose similar to those in Hamatora, like Bungo Stray Dogs most all of their names have some meaning/reference to reality. The way some characters see the Mc is like how Chidori sees Katsuhira in Kiznaiver and the sheer brute force of the mechs and blood from both the creatures and humans reminds me of Iron Blooded Orphans. I'm sure you could also throw Eureka Seven, Kill La Kill, My Hero Academia and a few others in there lol

THIS ANIME IS SOOOOOO GOOD. Episodes like 14 and 20 made me cry alot. it gets pretty emotional and got me on a personal level idk why. i RECREMEND that you watch this its realllllyyyy good. it starts off kind-of weird and boring, but if you have patience it all will start to make since, it gets better as you watch it trust me. it ends really well, i hope they will make a 2nd season. the cliffhanger though ;^;  IF YOU DONT WATCH THIS ANIME I WILL FIND YOU AND KILL YOU Thank you for reading my reveiw.  and PLEASE DO ME A FAVOR AND WATCJH THIS ANIMEEEEE????❤❤❤????

Enjoyed this show from start till towards end. refreshing and enjoyable, brought something new to the robot / mecha genre.only gripe is that god awful ending that almost put me off recommending the show.SPOILERS:reincarnation is always a cop out of an ending and bringing a new enemy in very last minute without any explanation is poor writing. standard for trigger though.still a definite watch though8/10

I don't usually write reviews, but when I do then it's because I truly cherish an anime. DARLING in the FRANXX can be categorized into several genres but it doesn't necessarily pop out in any of them. And that's what I like about it. It tackles so many things at once, truly making a unique anime viewing experience. Now I, along with many others, believe that this anime had so much potential but was wasted towards the end. They could have easily made the plot stretch into another season, but instead it ended in a somewhat underwhelming way. Some people dislike it for this, and I used to as well. However, I realized that the impact this anime left upon me once I finished it meant something. It meant that I loved it, although I seemingly didn't want to. This is when I came to the conclusion that I have to accept it for what it was, not what it could have been. Sure, I was aware of the flaws in this anime, but it takes an actual fan to truly admire both the flaws and strengths of a show. In the end, this is what it boiled down to for me. I can't speak for everyone and I may not know much about what makes an anime truly good, but what I do know is that I love this anime. Inside and out.

The plot for most of the show was top tier. I mean TOP TIER. The mysterious nature of everyone outside of squad 13 and their inability to understand what to do with their feelings and growing interest in their own world and lives made for an interesting show. With that said, I absolutely loved this show, recommended it to every anime friend I have, and have Zero Two as one of the backgrounds on my MacBook. If the plot didn't dive off a cliff towards the end, it would have been an easy 5 stars. I'll probably rewatch the first half of the show at some point next year. Until then, I'll be waiting for new Sword Art, Re:ZERO, and Danmachi.

Ok ok all innuendoes, and sex jokes aside. There really isn't a whole lot to go off of with only two episodes so far. But,  you cant help but be completely drawn into this. The animation is beautifully done, and its refreshing to have thematic developments entirely around playful sexual chemistry. Honestly, I started the show the second episode was released and have watched both over multiple times. There is an enchanting mystery around this. Really looking forward to see where it takes us over the next 22 episodes. *Tips hat to Trigger*

I'll do my best to keep this one short and to the point.I have no illusions to what this anime is and tried to be. It's a romance anime disguising itself as a mecha anime with a lot of political and social commentary.I didnt think the poly/soc commentary in the show was particularly deep. I mean, it's not like it isnt something that hasnt been said and done before... but it is refreshing to have it said time and again, because it does need to be every so often.Now i had absolutely no problem with the ideas the more episodes i watched, but the presentation and execution was downright sloppy in most cases. This anime had the potential to be outstanding, and the ideas were fantastic. Unfortunately, it did not live up to itself and instead played it extremely safe by giving us a formula that was already done before...I've watched all 25 episodes, and i have to say the ride was... interesting, to put it extremely generously. The show started off very strong in the first episode. The world was unique and set up in a brilliant way, and the characters were all introduced very well too. People could argue that it was very much like TTGL (Tengen Toppa Gurren Lagann) from the very start in that humans are being suppressed by a superior race and are forced to essentially live in a post apocalyptic world, but i honestly never got that impression from the beginning.i wouldnt say this show was bad by any stretch.Now... that's not to say that it was any good, either.Because episodes 2-9 were an absolute slog. Remember how exciting and fresh episode 1 was? Well take all of that away. Throw in a lot of mellow drama, the strelizia doing something cool maybe once every couple episodes for 10 second and completely lackluster/meaningless character interactions and you have that 8 episode stretch down to a tee.Epsidoes 2-9 were mediocre as all hell.Now episodes 10-15, on the other hand? They were really enjoyable. And you know what? it was very much the same sort of stuff that we saw in the previous episodes with a lot of character focus and minimal action set pieces. What was the difference, you ask? The things that happened actually had significance.We got much more insight about the sort of world our characters live in.The characters were developed in meaningful ways.We had actual plot progression.Things were happening in a way that mattered to the narrative, and the characters themselves. And it was great! Unfortunately, things don't stay that way for long. episodes 16-19 were pretty non descript in the same way that 2-9 were. not much else to say there.and oh my god episode 20 has to be...  Spoiler Alert! Click to show or hideone of the worst plot twists i've ever seen in my entire lifethe show literally turns into gurren lagann in that "the klaxosaurs(beastmen) werent our true enemies, and it turns out our true enemies are spacemen who want to annihilate all of earths inhabitants(the spiral races)". Episode 21-24 is a continuation of that "arc", and the only parts i found enjoyable were when the kids were having a normal life by farming and doing other miscellaneous things. oh. and that 5 minutes where everyone was in space to get the super strelizia(super TTGL) to the warp gate. that was also pretty cool.  Now let's talk characters....None of them particularly stand out with the exception of 002, Hiro, and Dr. Franxx. Becuase the show actually puts a lot of focus on themSpoiler Alert! Click to show or hidewith Dr. Franxx development coming near the end of the series right before he dies, giving us virtually no time to really care about him. he has no defining character qualities, we just get a lot of insight into his past.. which, again, who cares?Hiro is easy to tackle: He's generic shounen/anime protag #900. Nice guy to a fault, loves to help his friends even at the cost of his own well being, gets the hot girl without being particularly special or doing anything impressive. This cliche is getting pretty tired, but it's still an easy one to role with so i dont really knock the show for it.002 is also a pretty simple character to break down, in that shes a callous woman who doesn't care for anyone but herself until her ice cold heart is warmed up by our Hiro (haha, get it?) and she becomes true to her (and every other girl in anime that's just like her) natrue and becoems very gentle, considerate, and kind hearted.Ichigo: Well, her defining characteristic is that she loves Hiro. I mean... yeah. That's basically it. She's also the leader of their squad (but not really).Zorome, or as i like to call him Discount Na(Bo)ruto, is a head strong dummy who bullied Hiro at first, but quickly became his pal again after their extremely shallow conflict got resolved. Miku is just a girl version of Zorome, but i'll admit i did enjoy the dynamic between hr and Zorome (being that they were paired)Ikuno is the quiet nerdy girl with no characteristics other than being in love with Ichigo. Yeah, go wild with that one i guess.Mitsuru is a completely boring block of wood with a chip on his shoulder about Hiro, which like Zorome, gets over it pretty fast once the benign conflict gets resolved. Futoshi just love to eat and loves Kokoro. That's basically it.Kokoro is the sweety of the show. The cupcake if you willSpoiler Alert! Click to show or hideThat is, until she cucks fatty hardcore by straight up lying to his face and saying she'll be his partner forever, and then turning her back on him within a ten minute time span. For Mitsuru no less, whose about as boring as Ikuno is.Goro is the overly-reasonable best friend to Hiro, who is in love with Ichigo By the way, are you noticing a pattern with these characters, in that their defining characteristics is that they like eachother?My problem is that none of these characters have any depth as people. Some of their pasts and back stories get fleshed out well enough, but these characters themselves feel like aliens pretending to be people. None of them stand out. At all. The interactions is where i derived most of my enjoyment from this series as a whole, but even then only about half of them were actually worth a damn. The show was geared more towards growing the cast as a collective, rather than individually.But this idea doesn't work when there is so much more focus put on Hiro and 002 than all of the other characters. So they all end up falling flat.And i mean that's pretty much all i have to say. I hate the fact that i don't particularly care for this show. Because, again, it had great potential.I haven't been this disappointed with a series since Sword art: online, however i wouldnt put this show on the same tier of awful that SAO is. Should you watch this show?Honestly, despite everything i said, i would say yes. The show is as mid tier as it gets and it doesn't really go out of the box, but it still has a lot of enjoyable moments even though its not being as good as it could have been. But at the end of the day, id' honestly say to just go and watch Tengen Toppa Gurren Lagann instead or at the very least before watching this for some points of reference and the fact that it's much better. My reviews arent exactly popular, and i realize that, but that aint gonna stop me from writing them.So until next time!

Darling in the FranXX is an instant classic. I'm not even talking about how 002 stormed in and dominated the yearly waifu rankings, or how Ichigo somehow managed to fight for the "best girl" slot against her. The ensemble cast isn't wasted and each and every character has a role to play. 13 episodes into the series and we have seen all 10 kids go through growth and development beyond what some anime do for one character alone. It's the combination of all of these things that blow me away, but it's not the most surprising thing to me.Darling in the FranXX is not there to hold your hand. The information that NEEDS to be passed along, is done pretty well. It's not all spoon-fed, but it's not hard to access either. But the information that you WANT, the stuff that makes the show so good is often snuck in. They don't make everything obvious. Instead, we're given little glances into their lives. The way they live, the way the world used to be, and how the world works now. The show expects you to have a kind of curiosity about the questions it offers. It also gives answers if you're willing to look for them.I'm not going to spoil anything about the show, but if you've been looking for an excuse to watch it, this is it.

Trigger has done it again. Seriously awesome. Their usual flair and lack of sanctity make this ride one I plan on enjoying the whole way down. Just get off whatever high horse you're on (metaphorical or otherwise) and allow yourself to like this. It's okay, no one will judge you.That said, expect mecha action, interpersonal relationship conflict, and socio-religious critique we've all come to expect from Trigger/Gainax. Enjoy!

From the post-apocalyptic society battling random creatures in heavy machinery all the way to outer space battles that no one would expect from the beginning of the anime, it is very reminiscent of Gurren Lagann. It is good, do not get me wrong, it's just there were not many aspects to this show that have not already been done before. As always, the way things are differ from show to show, but they all have most of the same over and undertones. I enjoyed the very humanistic aspect of the parasites, on how they are very much so developing into teenagers and adults throughout the span of the series. Children will always be a product of their environments, but they'll still have their innate curiosity that will truly allow them to grow into their individual personalities. However, parts of the show gets to the point that everyone is into anyone and it's like watching a high school drama of confined spaces and small dating pools, BLEH. Spoiler Alert! Click to show or hideThe best episodes of the series are 13 and 19, and they also give much of the backstory you lust for in the beginning of the series.

3.5 starsSimply drawn but well animated art. Over the top combat. These are things the studio is known for.The first episode is somewhat cliched. However as the series progresses, the plot shifts gears multiple times. First the main characters are introduced and the stage is set. You'll get an idea of what humanity has become. But then you'll soon learn that the main cast is different, as they begin to discover what being human means to them. There's a lot of innuendo and nearly sexual content, but it's not done in the typical way. It's done through the eyes of naive children who are coming of age and don't know what that means. The story spends a lot of time on the unrequited love of youth, exploring the characters attempts to make sense of their place in the world, and their connections with each other. The plot will change directions a few times. Because the plot changes so much as the series continues, it does feel like you're watching something completely different at times. But it was entertaining in it's own way.

In a post-apocalyptic world where teenagers don't know anything about sex, despite unknowingly having studied it all their lives, a boy who knows all there is to know about the theory, has performance problems, but that all changes when he meets a girl with AIDS & he turns into a god of sex. Now he has to choose between doing it with her, despite knowing it is killing him slowly or not do it all. He chooses to keep doing it with her.

This show has so much potential. It's not just the fabulous Studio Trigger and solid A-1 pictures, It has a lot of big names behind the scenes also working on it. Theres also a manga running simultaneously with the anime. The Author of the manga is Kentaro Yubuki the artist from To-Love Ru so you know the art is on point. The animation looks stunning the musical score so far is solid and some characters are really standing out. Especially Zero Two. There are some serious undertones and metaphors to the dual gender piloting system that you will see almost immediately but I think it makes it more interesting. Episode 4 has phenomenal I would highly recommend you get to that episode before figuring out if you want to continue it.

If possible, I will definitely give more than a five star. Best anime, and I truly enjoy every episode of the anime. This is also my first review in Crunchyroll, and for any anime series. After the anime ended, I no longer see any reason subscribing to the premium membership as the others are just not as good or worthwhile. Will stay tuned for any subsequent series for this anime.Fantastic storyline and amazing efforts in character development. Well done producer.

Darling in the FranXX has an unfortunate name. It sounds like some kind of french drama that I would never be interested in watching. Combine that with a photo that screams Full Metal Panic knock-off, and one could hardly be blamed for swiping left. That said, I WAS DEAD WRONG. Equal parts Eureka Seven, Evangelion, and Tenchi Muyo, with splashes of S-cry-ed, SAO, and Guilty Crown, (and the occasional Studio Ghibli slash Makoto Shinkai vibe), Darling really delivers. It even follows a love story reminiscent of (and every bit as good as) The Fountain... This anime is a rare gem, a true masterpiece. I found it pleasantly surprising that there was very little military or politics in this show. This isn't Gundam nor G.A.T.E. -- It's Gurren Lagan, but a million times better. The characters range from tired cliché to truly unique and are developed well throughout the show. The plot has slow, enjoyable moments and fast, insane action. There are small inter-personal conflicts, literally world-ending conflicts, and healthy doses of both sci-fi and fantasy. This is the type of world that offers secrets and wonders for all types of fans. I spent a good portion of my time wondering about the origin of the Franxx machines, Dr. Franxx himself, and APE. I even came up with a whole theory about Mankind having evolved to the point of becoming Klaxosaurs and APE were literally the evolved descendants of apes and monkeys, using bio-engineered human test tube babies to pilot giant robots in a war to kill off the rest of Humanity à la-Ender's Game, but again I was wrong. PLOT TWIST!   Spoiler Alert! Click to show or hideThe council of elders was actually being run by an alien collective consciousness, klaxo sapiens were the original sentient life on Earth, and the children must combine humanity and klaxo-kind to defeat their common enemy! Whew.  In the end, I found myself wishing Hiro and Zero Two would continue their story in a second season, no matter how lame the story loophole. Time travel, alternate universes, whatever it takes! I might even make a little fan fiction for the the first time ever... Okay probably not, but I definitely give this the highest possible rating and recommend everyone watch it. For anyone still reading, yes there are sexual innuendos, get over it. There are also some annoying transliteration issues, like extremely liberal subtitles, and "darling" being pronounced "tah-lee". I love the Japanese language (#Subz4Lyfe) but the word darling is said about 9001 times in this show, so it gets really annoying. But don't let that stop you! Get going and watch this anime!

I dont know how to write reviews so sorry if this is painful to readFirst off, I didnt know I could cry so much with a mech type based anime oh man - call me silly but geez. Ok so, we got professor hojo over hear doing insane clone research managing to make a team of kiddos to fight for said "resource" with the start of the series  kind of explaining how things work as far as male and female roles work to pilot the Franxx - its like looking into a set group of teens in high school not knowing why the feel funny downstairs annnnnd maybe possibly figuring it out on their own - on their own, thats a key point, youll come to see why. Spoiler Alert! Click to show or hideIm really over the whole male dominance argument because I guess nobody saying that bothered to watch the final episodes where the male volunteers his life force to join his now female host in fighting the bad guys to death The love story aspect and science spun together perfectly, it wasnt a mushy gross blabla I love you you love me the whole time and the reason for what the heck is going on does get explained, just hang in there.

I just finished darling in the franxx and i have to say i'm not into mech- like animes or sci-fi related sort of things but i PROMISE you if you stick around and watch the first 3-4 maybe 5 for some people episodes then you will not regret a single minute spent on this beautiful masterpiece. i'm not one that cries and rarely even shows emotion at all, but this show made me tear up. Have to say it's one of it not my favourite anime that i've watched to date. Heres to hoping for more.

The title says it all. This is BY FAR my favourite anime ever created (and I’m a massive weeb, so i’ve seen A LOT of different anime). I mean, I’m one of those people that you look at and think “damn, I don’t wanna mess with that guy”, and here I was crying my eye balls out. It amazing, sure some people would disagree because of the ending and all that, but I think it was really good. The characters are incredibly detailed and filled with emotions. Because of this I can safely say that Zero-Two is now my ultimate waifu. I really can’t emxpress how much I love this anime and would recommend to anyone, I mean I’ve already spent about $500+ on merch and I’ve never bought merch from an anime before. The animation itself is also breathtaking and the voice acting whether your a dub or a sub, is superb. Literally the only bad thing I can say is, I wish there was more episodes, PLEASE GIVE US A SEASON 2 FOR THIS SHOW. Anyway, 100% recommend this show.

I initially wrote this to meet the character count but I ended up writing more so yeah:I expected this to be some normie run of the mill sci fi anime before I actually watched it. However, I was greeted by a much more captivating show than I expected. The story never leaves you without more questions about the future of the 10 adolescents under seemingly helpless circumstances. The underlying tone that reeks inevitable doom provokes curiosity and anxiousness as you see relationships develop between the protagonists. And then there's the opening sequence. That damn song. It's honestly one of the reasons I kept watching the show, as it too conveys the anxiousness and pain within the characters as a result of their environment. Also, I'm not a very emotional guy when I watch shows, but this one kept me holding back tears the entire time. It's because of how well the writing conveys the character's anxiousness, helping the audience feel the characters' struggles. Yeah I've said anxiousness several times now but that's really the best word to describe this show. It's a good trait to have, however. I also forgot to mention that the first time I watched it, I watched the entire damn thing in one day. I hope that says something even coming from a random dude in the internet.

This anime was amazing, I wish it would never end, one of the best animes I have watched. It really touches you, beside all the jokes and the sexual things that you can find,(I think it is part of the anime) it is really beautiful. Love it!I remember and feel everything when i watched the anime, if i see something related to it, i think it is something that will stay inside you by how the anime touched you, now the only thing to do is to pray for a second season, that the probability is low, its sad to say but it is. Only thing i can do now is to re-watch this anime a lot of times again and cry. This anime really touches you in the feelings, i wish they had made it with more careful in the last episodes, and at least did like 28 episodes i dont know, a little more longer, making everything more clear. If is not going to have a second season, the should do at least an OVA with a different ending idk, i wish i would have seen hiro and zero two together with the squad building their lives. Since hiro became a human/monster, they became a more beautiful couple after that. and i dont get why so much people hated the anime, i know about the last episodes and the ending, but just appreciate how beautiful the anime was you know. And beside this masterpiece it has some awesome musics too.Zero Two best girl.I heard people saying that they made something different in the manga, so if it don't have an ova or a second season the only choice is to read the manga end.

I'm not really a fan of mecha's, and honestly I wasn't too sure about this series when I started watching it, but after the first few episodes, I was hooked. From the character development, comedy, and to the more emotional parts, this is truly an amazing anime.  Spoiler Alert! Click to show or hideI would love to see a second season following the two kids at the end of ep 24.Edit: The ending was complete utter trash compared to the rest of the show, come on Trigger, Aliens? Why... This show could have been so much more if they got the ending right.

ya boy cracked this can of feels open over the spring, its pretty chill with a good story till they do some crack in the second half. thank god i watched this high so it made perfect sense when it happened but anyone watching sober is gonna be thrown for a loop when they go full cray cray. besides we all know the reason the second half sucked is that the animators were scared to see what the hentai community would do with a beloved show with 18+ characters i mean jesus. this show was probably written by an AI that midway through production found a few unspecified sites and immediately committed suicide. they had no idea what to put so they took a line from the jojo's animators, like literally a line of coke and finished the series. giving this a 4 because i wrote this review high and it seems like a good even number

These are probably the best words that describe this anime. To be fair I have been hesitant to watch it for a while because of all the stigma around it. I found the first episodes difficult due to all the innuendos at every turn. However, I fell in love with it after that. The cast of characters is diverse and entertaining, the worldbuilding is fantastic, the action sequences are great, and the themes are intriguing. Honestly, I was hooked, Id watched 20 episodes in 3 days. However, in the last 5 episodes, it just got bizarre and things started making less and less sense. It felt rushed and like the director was just throwing a lot of whatever in a blender. The emotion of the final episodes was clouded by some of this nonsense. I would definitely recommend watching this, as I really did enjoy it and don't regret it for a second, however, its bumbles prevent me from giving it the highest of ratings.

So I watched the series in full and I enjoyed the ride that this anime took me on. To be honest, this was the first show/anime that made me cry especially at the end. The criticism behind the show is valid for sure and introduction of a new enemy with like 4 episodes left made the ending feel a little rushed and the changing of pace may seem a little weird. This change does remind me of what Gurren Lagann did but not as well executed. Overall though, this is an anime that has everything and I thoroughly enjoyed the story to its fullest. Plus, Zero Two is flippin adorable

DARLING in the FRANXX is an anime that I will come back to time and time again. The show started off relatively light-hearted, but the emotional and moral twists and turns gave this anime a very rare level of depth. Zero Two is an incredible female protagonist, with the perfect amounts of passion and devotion. A lot of female protagonists are overly affectionate, or artificially mysterious or distant, but Zero Two is an incredible example of passionate writing. The blend of her wild, animalistic side with her loving, romantic side hit me in ways I haven't experienced before.Simply put, I will always fondly remember DARLING in the FRANXX, and the connection that Zero Two and Hiro shared.

Darling In The Franxx was recommended to me by one of my friends months back, and I decided to check it out. Boy, was I happy I chose to. Darlifra's storyline and character development seemed to go along with each other and kept me hooked the entire time. The basic concept of a dystopian future is one I'm sure we have all seen before, but not to this aspect. As the title says, this anime was the first to truly pull my emotions from me, and leave me with a series that I can (in some aspects) relate my own life to, and enjoy to it's fullest extent. I've rewatched it 3 times, and I still find it almost as good as my initial experience. I recommend this to each and every one of you that may be surfing through the reviews to see if this is worth a watch. The impact it left on me is greater than any anime I've watched in my years of viewings, and It is for sure my favorite.

This was amazing!!! That ending made me cry so much!!! Please if season 2 will arrive, please make it awesome, and not bad. This anime made its way to my Top1 list. However, Virm would still be alive and was preparing for a new attack. This time (The new) Hiro and 02 would be more powerful and more prepared to stop him. This time maybe without the death of these two amazing characters (Hiro and 02)!!! Just imagine. Obviously, Spoiler Alert! The anime started out okay. I wasn't expecting ALOT, but I can't say I didn't expect more. I love myself a good dystopian mecha anime but this wasn't it. Not everything about this show was bad. The beginning had a good amount of world building, character development, and some serious plot points. The conflict started around episode 17-18. The anime took a turn into becoming a huge twisted story about how the world came to be.Spoiler Alert! Click to show or hide Zero two became a huge klaxosaur, kokoro got pregnant(?), Hiro became a klaxosaur himself, Zero two and Hiro traveled out of space???? You get the gist right. I really wanted to like this anime. I enjoyed the character development. But it was so rushed, I could barely follow... I want to give this anime a 2.5/5. Zero Two is still bae though...

I really loved this anime, as it combined action and warfare (a subject I like to watch a lot), and romance (something that basically every anime has) very well. The character development was decent, and the plot was fairly realistic until the second half, where (SPOILERS) it became a humanity and klaxo sapiens versus VIRM alien war. Everything else seemed like it would have been possible to happen in real life. Overall, this anime is pretty good, and I would recommend it if you like a nice mix of romance and warfare.

Started off strong, beautiful art, the chicks were only moderately sexualized (which is the best ive come to hope for tbh), and there were interesting character dynamics between most of the cast. It was really looking like it was going to be a great five star anime, but then it happens. Spoiler Alert! Click to show or hideAlright, so they have a cool dynamic between the humans and the underground race that lasted up til episode twenty.... What should come next? A fight between them? Diplomacy? Anything? Nah, fuck that. They had below the ground, and on the ground. We need above the ground! Aliens! Yeah aliens, a giant armada, then they turn into a giant robot with tits and save the day. Pardon? What happens to the underground people? Who cares! Honestly the worst waste of potential i can think of.

I enjoyed every part of it, It made me happy and It made me sad(in a good way of course), but this is an amazing anime or what you want to call it. I think it changed my life forever and I will remember this show. It made me think that life isn't as bad as I thought. A big thank you to everyone who helped to create this masterpiece. - ArtyXP (Artūrs Kristaps Gubiņš) (edit) - I might start watching more anime and doing other stuff, just because it was that inspirational. Before I watched this anime I had only watched like 10 episodes of other anime's and anime scenes. Before this I had never wanted to watch anime, but thanks for changing that. I would rate everything 10/10. Before I watched the episodes after episode 11, I saw a few comments on Instagram that after episode 16 everything isn't good. I believe that there was not a single problem to this anime.(Also sorry if my grammar is bad or anything.)

This series really was a roller-coaster experience.
