I jumped into this anime knowing nothing about it while also expecting nothing. I didn't know what I'd be getting myself into. Here are my thoughts of the show, and what it's about, based on the first episode.Mira is a outgoing young girl that hits it off with a young boy named Ao during a summer camp as they stargaze. Inspired by their shared goal of naming an asteroid, they dive into the life of amateur astronomy. Mira and Ao never meet again, until one day Mira stumbles apon an after school club.This show features a Slice of Life pace revolving two main characters, Mira and Ao. This story is about their love of astronomy and possibly eachother. Focusing on getting their club more funding, they decide to embark upon a mission to pique the interests of their fellow classmates while spreading information about the club's activities. Will they gather more member? We'll find out.If you want to watch a casual anime with some comedic relief give this one a try.

Yes, its looks to be a Cute Girls Doing Cute Things, and in my book that's a fine thing. Nothing out of the ordinary in the character designs, its well done along with art and animation. It's not at Kyoani levels, be amazing if it were, but its more than adequate. The characters are indeed cute, and theres the requisite teacher/adviser. This will fill in my CGDCT needs nicely. They threw in the little possibility of yuri twist there, but I don't think it will be more than a tiny undertone.

INTRO: What you need to know firstThey say first impressions are important but in the case of Gintama they usually don't do him justice, so before you decide by the premise here's  a bit of advice, go by the 3 episode rule and you'll see what  I mean, Gintama is by no means your average ShounenJump story. Yeah i know 150+ episodes seems like a pretty big commitment, but no need to fret Gintama is an episodic series. Don't like the sound of episodic shounen you say? Well its episodic because it has to be. Gintama's strength is not in the usual beat strongest boss, then beat the strongest strongest boss etc =.=   Its in its hilarious yet at times surprisingly deep episodes. There are story arcs, mind you,  but they usually dont last longer than 3 or 4 episodes at a time the rest of the episodes are short stories contained usually in one episode. It is a perfect balance of the bread and butter of Shounen's a story Camaraderie with some badass action sandwiched in between random and hilarious episodic goodness.So lets get startedFirst offPremise: Get to know our heroesGintama, a carefree, lazy, snot picking hero is an ex samurai working as a "Yorosuya" (jack of all trades) with his buddies Shinpachi a wanna-be samurai and overall Otaku  and Kagura a young girl that is actually an alien from a planet of warriors with super-human strength (think Saiyan) during Japan's Edo period. However its been decades since earth has been invaded by aliens and during the transition the world is now 1/4 old world 2/4 Modern 1/4 Futuristic. While not slaves the people of Earth are treated like second class citizens at times bullied and taken advantage of by aliens who are also backed by the government and the police force Shinsengumi  led by Isao Kondo who often clash with the Earth resistance group the Joi Faction led by Gintama's ex comrade Kotaro Katzura. That aside Gin's greatest concern is usually finding ways to pay the rent.Music: ForgettableThe OP and ED so far have been pretty good, not that memorable but pretty good. The OST itself is forgettable, few, and unnoticeable. While some say thats what an anime background music should be I tend to disagree. There is a balance of the music not being distracting but at the same time enhancing the experience. Good background music that comes to mind are The Over World theme of Zelda, Naruto's fighting and depressed themes, and FMA music. (The worst that comes to mind is Bleach's old "kickin ass theme", you know the one, with the female chorus saying "oh ohhhohh")Characters:There are a lot to meet In the world of Gintama not only are the characters so detailed and vastly varied (from a sadomasochist female ninja that uses nato beans as a jutsu  to a robot maid that thinks its a famicon with Dragon Quest inserted) They are each more complex that you'd think doable especially considering the amount of characters the series keep introducing. Suffice to say each one of them has made me laugh, I can't think of one character that hasn't. To me the characters are the cherry on topAnimationNot mind blowing in its action sequences (compared to the bleach/naruto main story line animation splurges) but nonetheless very satisfying. Where it shines at its best however is in its over-the-top expressions and prefect timing. Taken for granted compared to stylized action sequences but a pillar that supports what makes Gintama so much fun.

If you're looking for an action packed, power-up riddled, fight driven alternate history sci-fi samurai anime with improbable female anatomy, oversized swords (probably to compensate for the boobage) and crude humor... this isn't it.But! If you're looking for a silly, 4th wall breaking, over the top,  alternate history parody sci-fi samurai anime with surprisingly accurate anatomy (across the board), short and to the point story arcs, a smattering of bad-ass fights, surprisingly touching moments, and more crude humor than you can shake a (curiously phallic) stick at you have arrived at the right place.The plot is fairly straightforward: Instead of Americans forcing open an isolationist Japan, aliens known as Amanto invade the Earth - this sets things in motion for a truly bizarre alternate history where Tokyo is still known as Edo, aliens walk the streets and most modern - as well as futuristic technology - is widely available by the time the story takes place (which is presumably sometime in the late 1800's). But, as the saying goes, the more things change, the more they stay the same. Samurai lost both their status and their swords; forced to abandon their bushido simply to make a living as a working stiff. Not to mention the government is corrupt and the economy sucks.Enter Yorozuya Gin-chan, aka Sakata Gintoki; a ronin and freelancer who's smart enough to let go of his dignity and take whatever job comes his way. He refuses, however, to set down his wooden sword (except for when he's taking a dump, or eating, or reading Weekly Shounen Jump, or sleeping or something).  He, along with Shimura Shinpachi (his apprentice/employee... sort of),  Kagura (employee/roomate/little sister... sort of), and Sadaharu (Kagura's giant dog) have many a wacky adventure as they try to make ends meet, and occasionally save the world.Acting as foils and occasional cohorts for the Yorozuya trio (or fab four, if Sadaharu is with them) are the Shinsengumi. It's tough to be a cop in Edo; the Amanto have diplomatic immunity so they can do whatever the hell they damn well please; washed up samurai line the streets (some are more harmless than others) and it doesn't help that the chief of the Shinsengumi - Kondo Isao - is stalking (with the best intentions and the worst luck) the violent elder sister of Shimura Shinpachi; the Demon Vice Commander Hijikata Toshiro  is obsessed with mayonase and Captain Okita Sogo is just flat sadistic (luckily he's usually more interested in assassinating Hijikata, than unleashing his madness upon the citizens of Edo), and their top spy, Yamazaki Sagaru just wants to play badminton. It's amazing the city's still standing - especially when they lock horns with the Yorozuya - or join forces for the greater good (depends on everyone's mood). Meanwhile, there's various forces trying to bring down the government and generally interrupt Happy Fun Time. Some, like Katsura Kotaro through more comedic means, and others, like Takasugi Shinsuke through brute force. Then of course, there's rogue aliens, stupid princes, rampaging gorillas, incompetent ninja's, MADAO, little old ladies, Naruto jokes, and a plethora of other odd characters to spice things up.It sounds like a train wreck of a series. But it isn't. Gintama combines comedy, sci-fi, action and drama as many other series wish they could. It proves itself a better fit as a "slice of life" anime than a straight shounen, but this comes as a welcome relief to anyone tired of the 300+ chapter story arcs with little to no plot advancement (and endless filler in the anime adaptation). Episodic in nature; story arcs (both comedic and serious) are well executed; the usual time wasting devices (a fight episode that's mostly talk; excessive flash backs or recaps and so on and so forth) anime studio's use to pad out episodes are done away with in favor of solid writing and short (and oh so silly) omake.  Animation quality is top notch most of the time - the worst episodes animation-wise are on par with an average episode of several other shounen series. The best are edging not-so-stealthily towards movie quality. The music is excellent as well; Audio Highs consistently delivers with whatever the situation calls for - from big band to acoustic guitar ballads to hard rock and everything in between. Opening and ending sequences - in addition to being lushly animated - are always a joy. Especially when DOES is involved. On top of all that, the voice acting is supurb.All and all, Gintama is a genera bending, 4th wall breaking, lough 'till you cry - and sometimes just cry (manly tears!) - good time.

Awesomeness is what defines Gintama. A must watch for anyone that is an anime fan. First 3 episodes are a little on the not so funny side but after that it's all out laughing like crazy. Watch the OVA as well as it's an excellent sample of the kinds of things you can expect from this ingeniously written anime. it's not as random as some might have you believe and there is somewhat of a story line behind all the mayhem.The episodes don't follow your standard story arch format, it goes for more of a day to day life of Gin-san and the rest of the cast. Some episodes will have you rolling on the floor laughing and yet others will have you tearing up, while others will have you begging for more action and for Gin-san to show off his true skills. It's a great anime and I highly recommend this to anyone, especially if you've watched many animes although it is not a requirement as Rumbel Subs does an excellent job of telling you exactly what they parodying and/or referencing. Anyone who watches this and manages to keep a straight face has no soul. The characters are memorable, and this is the first time that I've seen an series pull off being able to not rely solely on a plot and do it so well! This is a classic for the ages! The mysterious past of Gintoki, Zura and Takasugi compels you to keep watching this anime. The recurring charcaters are awesome too. Hijikata, Okita, Kondo, Elizabeth-san, Otae, Yamazaki, Otose, Catherine do a wonderful job for most part. The lack of main plot is backed up by these solid characters.Soundtrack of this series is something that comes once in a decade. The music used in the series intensifies the depth of the scene, whether it be a comical situation or a matter of life and death. Animation is also of a great quality. Costumes are awesome and the edo is designed in a weirdly attractive style. In my opinion, Bl**ch and Na**to are far too overrated. This is what an anime should be like. Once you start watching it, the lack of main plot will not - yes I said, IT WILL NOT - bother you at all.

Hideaki Sorachi is either a genius or smoking marijuana when he created Gintama. Whatever inspired him has given birth to a never-tiring concept in the shonen genre. An anime that has no limits—It can parody anything. Gundam, transformers, samurai, aliens, ghost, celebrities, idols, and monsters. Dragon Ball, One Piece, Bleach, and Naruto are among the anime that was parodied in Gintama. It can make you laugh so hard, you'll hurt your stomach. It can make you cry. It can keep you in the edge of your seat. Other mangakas are probably jealous of Sorachi because his Gintama can't get old nor possibly ran out of material because it's so flexible. You can have a parody version of Batman crashing into their home one day and it would make sense in the world of Gintama. I mean, they already had Will Smith before in one of their episodes. Gintama is character driven. You'll watch it for its memorable characters more than its story (If there's even any). Shockingly, nearly all of Gintama's character are not just memorable but can be a star of their own show. In fact, this is the biggest strength of Gintama—the characters!

In short, Gintama has ruined all other anime for me for the rest of my life. This is storytelling at its finest. I could gush over the depth (the utterly unfathomable, beautiful depth) of the characters who are so human you forget they aren't real--samurai, aliens, robots, and villains alike. I could praise the brilliance (and hilariously clever dirtiness) of the humor juxtaposed with the sudden beauty of the most touching/tragic stories that you will ever have the fortune of seeing and making you sob until you feel like even your soul is crying. Or I could rant about how much I've been trolled/learned about trolling and thoroughly enjoyed being trolled. But basically, I could just say that I worship at the altar of Sorachi sensei, and I have never been more inspired or jealous of an author who portrays himself as a nose-picking gorilla. Gintama is one of the best things I've ever watched in my life, and if it's not for you, I don't know what to say. Except maybe that it'd give me an urge to rip off your mole.

Oh, boy. Where do I even begin to review the colossal anime (in length and in depth) that is Gintama?Someone once compared Gintama to a hot pot of anime, and it is probably the best descriptor for it if Gintama can ever be summarized in a mere few words. It literally has everything under the sun (and beyond it, with aliens and all) and seriously everything you could ever want in an anime bundled up in one unassuming package. It's clearly not flashy; there isn't anything particularly gorgeous about the art style, there is no elaborate plot, no in-your-face drama. But what Gintama does have is heart.It's not even cheesy. Gintama brings out the most genuine emotions, and before you even realize it, the whole character cast has completely grown on you. Where Gintama shines the most is undeniably in its cast, from the main-character-who-really-doesn't-act-like-one-but-is-nevertheless-the-coolest Sakata Gintoki, to the alien-girl-from-China-who-is-absolutely-awesome-in-berserk-mode Kagura, to the glasses stand Shimura Shinpachi, to his insane sister who abuses eggs, Otae, to her unshakeable stalker (and somehow Chief of the Shinsengumi) Kondo Isao and his second in command, Demon Vice-Chief Hijikata Toushirou with the mayonnaise addiction and tsundere-ness, and super Sadist (with a capital S) Okita Sougo whose number one priority is killing Hijikata-san and usurping his position. A glasses-wearing ninja assassin, a ninja with hemorrhoids, a girl who really wants balls, and a really pitiable sunglasses-stand round out the main recurring cast. Then, there is the (now moderate) terrorist Zura who is somehow still the oddest out of a cast already so odd and whose antics cannot even be summed up here because he is really just too odd. Seriously. Watch out for this guy and the OST that plays every time he appears.Somehow I was carried off track trying to describe characters... but the characters are really pure gold. Well, silver. You don't even realize it until you reach one of the serious arcs, and then... that's it, you're absolutely hooked, because each and every one of the characters are so incredibly real. All those early episodes that never seemed to do much? While it's true that Gintama does have a slow start, never skip any of the early episodes (besides 1-2 if you really have to). It is during those episodic, seemingly-unimportant gag moments that you get a feel of the cast in daily situations, much like getting to know a person in real life. And then when it actually matters, those people who have slowly wormed their way into your heart become really effective characters. The way characterization and character development is done so subtlely is unparalleled in animanga already, and then...You have the hilarity. We're talking about laughter that hurts, laughter that drops you to the floor and squeezes tears out of your eyes and suffocates you and makes you cackle. Cackle. Admittedly, a lot of Gintama is hit-and-miss depending on if you know what they're referencing or punning or parodying about, especially in the beginning. But as the series goes on, Gintama begins to rely on character jokes too, based on the characters we've all grown to love over the course of the series, and all of it is done so impeccably well and so cleverly. Yes, there are definitely times when Gintama misses. But, when Gintama actually does hit (and that hitting becomes more and more frequent), it is absolutely out of this world funny. I am almost convinced there will never be anything funnier, because anything funnier would be lethal. And that's not even all of it. Sorachi-sensei is a genius already, but then the seiyuu cast freaking make it even better. This is why you should choose the anime over the manga, folks. But I'm sure you already know that since you're on Crunchyroll. I've actually always been more of a manga person, but I listened to someone who advised the anime and it seriously makes a huge difference. Not that the manga is bad in any way, and arguably there are some parts with better pacing in the manga, but the freaking voice actor cast. I've never paid much attention to seiyuu before when I watched anime, but every voice actor absolutely shines here. Tomokazu Sugita.. Akira Ishida... Kazuya Nakai.. Kenichi Suzumura... I am thorougly convinced you can never find a better Gintoki, Zura, Hijikata, or Sougo in anyone else. And, of couse, our poor Shinpachi, Sakaguchi Daisuke, who I am surprised still hasn't lost his voice yet with all the yelling he has to do.Also, the awesome OPs and EDs and OSTs. They set the mood very, very well.I mentioned the serious arcs earlier, and I really wanted to bring it up again. Let it not be forgotten that Gintama is a shonen. It tends to focus on the comedy a lot more, but it is still a shonen through and through, and when it actually shows its shonen side... it is intense and you can really see where their budget went. Fighting is always straight to the point, and there can actually be a lot of gore. And then... DUN DUN DUN... you realize that Gintama is actually capable of plot. Yes, there is actually a plot. Don't listen to people who say Gintama is only a gag series--those people have clearly not watched the whole thing. Gintama's plot takes like sixty episodes to actually show up and another two hundred to actually develop, but it is there underlying all of the comedy. 265 episodes later... you realize a huge plot was actually brewing behind the scenes after all. Of course, it's still going to be mostly comedy and episodic fun, but Gintama has its serious side, too, and it does not feel out of place at all. The anime has gone on hiatus, unfortunately... but I really believe it will be back some day. And when it does, I will come right back and watch it with all of the characters I've grown familiar with... and I know it'll still be a resounding five stars. The manga reached its tenth anniversary just recently; here's to another decade of Testicles!

I honestly started watching Gintama because I heard that it has good comedy and I wasn't expecting anything extraordinary from it, but after a while I fell in love with this series. No anime could make me feel all these emotions but Gintama. At first glance, Gintama doesn't look special. but let me tell you something; Gintama is a treasure, a piece of art, no I am not even exaggerating at all. Everything was beyond my expectations. I have a huge standard, so that means a lot. I can't explain Gintama, and no one will ever can. There's some moments in Gintama I would be about to cry and then, I would laugh at what was happening. Gintama is seriously turning me into a bipolar. You can't predict what will happen in this anime, seriously. I recommend Gintama to someone who has at least some kind of experience with anime because Gintama has a lot of reference to other anime, and it makes it funnier if you understand what's going on. I have to add that the humor in Gintama is really original, I mean, everything in Gintama is. Gintama has serious arcs and less serious ones, but you can't hate those random funny episodes because they are actually important as well; they are part of the plot (yes, Gintama has a plot)All this to say that: GINTAMA WILL FOREVER BE MY FAVOURITE ANIME, that's huge because like I said, I have a high standard. I want more people to know about Gintama and laugh with me because laughter is the best medicine! Also, you absolutely have to watch the last movie of Gintama after you finished Gintama': Enchousen (season 2) because it's AWESOME! Best movie I've seen so far!

This is the show that beats them all.Animation 10/10: Gintama had excellent quality to begin with, after like episode 170 they go widescreen and became amazing.Story 10/10: Most original story in anime ever created. The comedy, action and drama are meshed together in perfect harmony. You'll be crying from the drama one moment, and the next cracking up at sex jokes.Characters 10/10: Good whole characters, best main character in any anime, no lie. Virtually no fillers after the first 2 episodes.Overall: My favorite show.

At first I was like, it is too long, should I invest my time in this? Soon I had my answer. YES, Gintama is a masterpiece. I think it is the funniest anime I have ever seen. The anime itself is a joke, making parodies about the most popular animes, manga and other popular references.Yes, it is extremely funny, yet, when it has to be serious, it is one the coolest, most dramatic, sentimental and darkest series!. The characters are just awesome. There are at least 20 main characters! Each one of them is memorable, no one is secondary, they all work in harmony to create and excellent work. It is not like other anime that they introduce a character and that's it. Everyone is important. Now, Gintoki is definitely one of the Weekly Shonen Jump stars and here you will know why! He is hilarious, cool, strong, good hearted,a glutton, loves to drink.He is such a complex character, so cool and he does not even try. Which remembers me, After watching this anime you will not know why this is such a good anime, but still love it! Nobody know what Gintama is about, but still they love it! Even though it is kind of a gag anime, it has some stories that are very interesting, being the most important for me the Shogun Assassination Arc.Also the openings and ending are memorable. Everything is amazing! It doesn't matter if there are 300 episodes, at the end you will feel like you need more, believe! This anime is surely a 100% recommended!

As with most people who first gave Gintama a shot, I watched the first three episodes, didn't think much of it, and ended up dropping the series for a few months....big mistakeI eventually revisited the series and since then, Gintama has become my one of my absolute favorite series ever (and I've seen countless different anime). After a few dozen episodes, the comedy starts to pick up and once you hit those serious story arcs, Gintama just becomes amazing - with some of the best story telling and fighting scenes out there!If you're still debating on whether you should watch Gintama still - Just Do It!

You may have read a thousand and one other good reviews, but I think that all new viewers still have a bit of doubt in their mind. Sure, Gintama doesn't appeal to everyone, but for some damn reason, it brings together so many different types of people. I was very cynical of this show at first, in fact, it took me a month or two to convince myself to watch episode three. It was a gradual love, but once I realized how good this anime was, I never went back.So you can keep reading other reviews and try to nitpick and doubt every biased thing coming out of fans' mouths, but ultimately, you will have to give this anime a try and whether you like it or not is up to you. I'm just saying this anime is the best for me.

Simply this anime surrounds 3 main characters with many many other sub characters. The main character Gintoki is the hero of this anime, being a uniquely lazy hero who has this humorous charm about him which makes us all laugh and love him. This anime most DEFINATELY has the best arcs I have ever seen in any long running anime. Most arcs (eg. 9/10 arcs) or sub stories are all extremely well played out and written leaving me laughing or even tearing and crying in some episodes. This anime makes you love every character, as it is a long running anime, it creates depth with each character, making you love each and every single one of them.the only let down is that this is still a japanese cultured anime, having a lot of its humor and jokes made for only japanese people to understand which leaves foreigners wishing they were japanese. TTA MUST WATCH ANIME, SIMPLY EXCELLENT!!I recommend to everyone, this anime tops the list for sure.If you thought this was a helpful review, please check out my profile and other reviews :] thanks

This is not a real review but a warning: The first few episodes are terrible and make you wonder how anyone could ever enjoy this show Gintama. I've seen animes come and go, since I saw my first anime in the early 1990's.. (not counting atroboy) >.>After awhile I got bored of the usual animes, (anime with too much stereotypical characters, and lame story-telling). But after finding Gintama, this changed themes in anime on a whiole different level. O.OI was first weary to watch Gintama... but since watching the first episode, I'm hooked. At first it gives off this crazy view of another universal look, taking place in a time of a past era... leaves you thinking (what if?)...aliens came to earth, we end up getting technology at a earlier time..and even though trying to live a simple life..there is chaos.Sounds like a pretty good story, even it's humor is way off the charts. But leaves a form of satifaction after reading the manga, and even watching the end of the episode of this series.This isn't a normal type of story-telling, but I don't seem to get bored watching Gintama. The music suites the scenes perfectly.. Loved hearing Tommy's op song theme for the starting of the series.. This anime gets even better.. the characters blends into this type of universe.. (not like some other animes that has so many characters, can't follow the story-line)... However with Gintama, your able to follow each character. ~Cause the characters in Gintama doesn't seem out of place~ ^o^As for the animation.. I admire the work put into this series, and plus it isn't bad on the eyes, cause it does have great detail.Humor?... For the humor part of it, I'm not a fan of bathroom  humor.. like some bathroom scenes in some animes.. but for some reason Gintama can make the joke work in this type of reality.I rated Gintama a high rate, cause it's not everyday to watch an anime, that you feel you want to see more of.. This series has a certain charm, and it's humor of has (many) types of non-reality that doesn't seem to slack. But when theres a serious moment in the series, it doesn't crush Gintama's worldly atmosphere.. actually it enhances it.Gintama is a rare series, that we won't see much of in years to come. To me it's a rare find, even when re-watching the episodes, it still makes me laugh..Glad to watch this anime, it's worth looking into.

There are really no words to describe the greatness of this show. There are several of them that I can throw at you such as: pure comedy, real action, best feels, badass copyrights issue and insane hype  This is worth re-watching over and over and over again, please do recommend this to your friends and family. Their time won't be wasted in vain, I guarantee you that this is one of the most beautiful part of anime and manga industry. <3

I never write reviews for shows. But after binge watching 353 episodes in a span of 3 weeks, I have to say Gintama takes the gold and the silver, balls and all.Gintama has both wonderful gag arcs and dramatic arcs, with compelling characters to boot. The comedy in Gintama is HILARIOUS, with all kinds of clever, random, witty, and, of course, dirty jokes. The fourth wall is practically thin air in this anime, and the troll faces in Gintama are truly divine. Tomokazu Sugita is a god of voice acting, and the other seiyuus excel at line delivery as well.A lot of people may get intimidated by such a long anime, but there is no fluff in this show, not even in the gag episodes. The drama and comedy are well spaced so that you have plenty of laughs and plenty of action at all times. The action scenes are fantastic, full of spirit and intensity without dragging it out unneccessarily. The morals in Gintama are also well delivered. Gintama veers away from suicide missions, maintaining both courage and responsibilty. It also rejects the 'lone hero' trope, instead believing in sharing the burden with comrades. I was pleasantly surprised by its touch on gender roles since Shonen Jump characters tend to neglect women. But Gintama displays women who fight equally to men, get injured equally to men, and carry conviction equally to men. Though not perfect, Gintama is on the right track to strong women in mind, character, and body. One female character proudly announces she is neither man nor woman and is simply herself, the individual. Gintama committs wonderfully to friendship, faith, integrity, and resilience.If you managed to read this entire review, congratulations, you win Gintoki's balls, which he loses quite often actually. Gintama is truly a crown jewel of anime and no words are fit to describe the imperfect masterpiece Hideaki Sorachi has created. If you decide to watch this rollercoaster of an anime, hold on tight.P.S. If you finish the show, come talk to me about the character shippings.

Having a bad day? Gintama. Having a good day that you can't cry? Gintama. Moral lessons? Gintama. Unique characters? Gintama. A Great Sense of Humor? Gintama. A Spice of Reality life Situations? Gintama. You cannot go wrong with watching Gintama, the voice actors and actress really matched with the characters. For newbies, who are curious if they should watch Gintama or not? You should and why not?. A little note in here, the first 20 episodes, you might find it boring and unusual but I guaranteed you as the episode goes higher the more it becomes Good and brilliant. I am the type of person who easily gets's bored but then someone told to keep watching so I just kept on watching hoping that it would get better and Oh my God, it did, you'll miss it for not being able to watch! Each character has its own sense of uniqueness, diversity and it's own characters. This anime will give you a lot of " Anime joke references" haha. My favorite person in this anime is Katsura, Okita Sugo, Shinpachi, and Gintoki, although I love all the characters in this anime. The anime wouldn't be this good if one of the characters in Gintama is gone, but those 4 people are just my favorite. Give it a try!I hope you find this review helpful. Have a great day!

Literally I have watched over 100 different anime series and out of all of them this is my most favorite. BUT IF YOU KEEP WATCHING DEAR LORD THERE WILL BE NO REGRETS.You will find yourself laughing, crying, choking on whatever snacks your eating, and absolutely falling in love with every character. The comedy, storyline, action, adventure, plot twists, character development, and unique genius is what makes this anime so great.I highly recommend this anime. There will be no regrets. GINTAMA FOR LIFE <3

It isn't even fair to compare Gintama with any other anime, because - let's face it - Gintama stands on its own. This show has brought me what i truly want, it is a phenomenon and above all does not Drag you around the bend like most anime do nowadays, only this show can waste time by making an episode about wasting time, or makes you sit through 30min of who eats the next bite of meat in the Soba, and makes it worth your time, each episode is an adventure, each story arc magnificent, this show is one that MUST go on

I adore Gintama. Why? It's funny. It makes me giggle. It's weird. It's weird in a good way. Sure there is a lot of toilet humor, jokes based on the male anatomy, terrible puns and bad impersonations and downright nonsensical jokes but that just gives it it's charm. You know, the same charm the a crude, tasteless teenage boy might have. Ok, maybe charm isn't a good word, but it has something and that something is a good something. Think SNL skit, except animated and in Japan. With aliens.

My sister kept telling me to watch this anime. I watched the first 2 episode and got so bored i stopped watching it. A month later after having no other anime to watch i just kept watching it. After the first 15 episodes i realized that i was hooked. I couldn't stop watching it, it's as if my eyes wouldn't let me stop. I couldn't even sleep lol, my hands just wouldn't let me turn off my laptop, it automatically made to go to the next episode. If you really want to know why Gintama is the full package, start reading from here.  Gintama is freaking hilarious. Some episodes you literally choke from laughing. The other night i was rewatching episode 152 and cried because it was so funny. Gintama is very meaningful. Some episodes make you choke from crying. Even though most of gintamas episodes are meaningful, there are those episodes that make you cry from having such a heart ache. Trust me on this, i know from experience, i woke up with swollen eyes because of this anime. Gintama has amazing action. I sometimes wonder how the anime people do it. Their art is pretty tight, i would never be able draw the epic battles this anime has. Gintama leaves you with suspense. This anime leaves you with an impression after each episode. WARNING You wont really understand if you start from a random episode, start from episode one and push through the first 6 or 10 episodes and you will be hooked!!! but don't just take my word for it... watch it, NOWWWWyou wont regret it!!!

This show man....I had a terrible time getting past episode 1 of this show when first finding it. Take my advice...just watch the show, dont go by the first episode which if it had been episode 30 would have been great. The first episode is a cold shock to the system. You really need to dip your toes into the insanity that is Gintama before becoming fully immersed in this Rollercoaster of a world. I dont like reviews that tell me what the show is actually about. So, light spoilers here. I will just tell you what the show has done to me:1: It made someone look at me extremely funny when I burst out laughing for apparently no reason when watching with earpods. 2: Its had me tearing up. And I am a dude. Im an adult dude. 3: Did I mention milk out your nose funny? 4: Its caught me by the short and scruffies and made me watch until the damn sun came up because I lost track of time. 5: Its gone from being a light funny show to being one of the most badass Hard Boiled shows you will see......then flips the script and does a whole show based on toilet humor, but done in such a way that its not "hur hur he farted". More Seinfeldian "Can you spare a square" stuff. Again keeping me up until the sun came up through multiple arcs....Then does straight toilet humor. The whole show is insane, its obnoxious, its adolescent, its gross, the storyline is completely inconceivable. It breaks most taboos, and it shouldnt work. Trust me you will love it.

This being my first review please excuse its roughness.Story: 10/10 Never have I seen another anime in which every episode was fantastic. The arcs were all great and the filler was always good and some of it was better than the arcs. Truly a masterpiece.Art: 9/10 This show has some fantastic art however the it's not perfect, just very close.Sound: 8.5/10 Has some very good music but some of the op's and ed's could be better as well as music being reused a noticeable amount.Overall: 9.5/10 Fantastic in so many way with an amazing cast of 3 dimensional characters to a story so absurd in so many ways they is still able to retain the tension and emotional impact in all the scenes it's needed in. It may not be a 10/10 but i comes very  VERY  close. TL:DR: Watch the show, you won't regret it.

Gintama is not only comedic with memorable characters, its always dramatic and its not afraid to tear at your heart with not only the story and twists, but even the soundtrack will make you cry. Its by far my favorite anime, makes me laugh, cry, scream... just everything. I will never stop recommending this anime. Nothing has ever compared to how much I love this anime. The absolute love you will feel towards these characters.. its unbelievable. Almost 500 episodes isn't enough, but at the same time if it ends it will feel complete. The moment this anime end tho I will be cry and rewatch it. Nothing like it.

I first were a bit sceptical about Gintama, but after watching all episodes(to the date i wrote this) I gotta say, its one of the best series i have ever seen. Many other reviewers have written very detailed explanations about the start of the show and i wont copy them(read them yourself ) All i can say is that Gintama has a lot of silly humor, but occasional serious arcs as well and the balance is pretty good imo. Ofcourse there are some jokes that can go over your head if you dont research things, or read the episodes comments(that i had to do several times xD ) Watch atleast 5 episodes to really get into this Even JoJos Bizarre adventure needed more episodes to get interesting(for me atleast, had to watch half of the first season of jojo to get into it, it is also really good) 5/5 would watch the whole thing again because the fisheyed Gintama and silly Kagura!

As someone who is very new to anime I have been very choosy on which shows to watch. I had heard rumblings of this show long before having a Crunchyroll account. After watching the first couple episodes of the show I slowly grew to like the quirky characters and fun scenarios. That was just the first 15 episodes. I bought a Crunchyroll account because of this show, and not a single regret is in my mind. This show can leave you crippled from laughter, saddened by a dark twist, on the edge of your seat by emotion filled battles, and leave you craving more as the building story becomes more epic and more gripping. The characters are beyond lovable, the shticks are well crafted, and each episode has love and passion poured into it to the point even filler feels like it is on purpose. I cannot sing this show's praises any more and am happy to know it was brought back from the verge of cancellation on a few occasions. It deserves every bit of a attention its been given and more.

Gintama. It's a series that everyone calls "the best comedy ever." I had to check out the series everyone boasted highly about. The first couple of episodes caught my attention but reading it had no plot discouraged me from continuing. It wasn't until I reached episode 25 that I knew it really was something else. This show has unique characters that always keeps the comedy fresh and hilarious. For example, today I found myself trying to resist laughing out loud in a computer lab. This show just always finds ways to make you laugh with its references/characters/situations and being on episode 173 I can tell you it's "the best comedy ever." The plot of Gintama is basically following the lives of Sakata Gintoki, Kagura and Shinpachi while meeting new characters and allowing them to develop through their adventures. Although comedy is its strong suit, it does have action that is just as entertaining. I highly recommend this show! Edit: I finished it and can truly say it's my #1 show. The action that takes place later in the story reminds me to stop calling it "just a comedy" because it's so much more. Once you reach episode 300, there is a clear plot as the manga is on its final arc. If there's a time to start Gintama, it would be now before the final season begins!

Honestly a review can't do this long standing adaption justice, so let me say this, you see that review to the right? Look closely at how many people reviewed 1 or 2 stars, on a crappy but popular anime you can see how a lot of people rate it harshly in order to try and compensate for the artificially high score, but with gintama that doesn't happen. Or how about this: https://myanimelist.net/topanime.php If this doesn't show you why you should consider watching gintama, nothing will. If you have a good sense of humor or enjoy comedy even a little bit, this anime will blow you away. The first few episodes aren't that great, but give it time and I garuntee you'll wonder where gintama was all your life.

Gintama is one of if not the funniest comedy series ever made. Even though it is in Japanese I don't think even an average joe who has never see anime before would be able to resist cracking a smirk. With it's many quirks, over the top reactions and truly well thought out jokes silly or long running, a joke never falls flat or becomes bland in anyway and that is something that is truly remarkable. If you love Comedy you've reached Valhalla.

Fantastic comedy? CHECK. Tear-jerking drama? CHECK. Unbelievably epic, well choreographed fight scenes? CHECK. Well developed characters? CHECK CHECK CHECK. Gintama is an oddity in the sense that it is able to mash together so many differing types of storytelling and absolutely nail it all. If you haven't even seen this series, start now!That all being said, it is a very long series and can take a little bit of work to get into at the beginning. But stick with it, it is so worth it. Much of Gintama relies on its fantastic characters and the interaction between them all. When watching at the beginning for the first 20 episodes or so, you're still being introduced to/warming up to all of the characters. But the longer you stick with it the better and better it gets.Gintama has become my favorite anime series by far. Zura janai, Katsura da!

Gintama's greatest accomplishment is that despite being a shonen comedy/action series with an overwrought premise and hundreds of episodes, it stands apart of the best work of its kind in a long time.Its sense of humor is brilliantly juvenile and smartly self-referential. The main character is a (sometimes shockingly effective) good-for-nothing manchild, but you'll love him more for it. There are numerous interludes where characters break the fourth wall and apologize for their sins against the viewer, for instance, and then later apologize again for having wasted your time with a meta joke. The show knows all the stupid tricks that other shonen shows use to pad their time, and slyly pokes fun without ever coming off as mean.Gintama would be great parody if that's all there was to it, but in fact it stands apart as a serious story as well. It's hard to tell at first, but buried beneath the poop jokes and absurdities is a touching series of interwoven narratives about Japan keeping its soul in the face of overwhelming change.You'll laugh. You'll cry. You'll wish you had a time machine.  Even if shonen bores you, stop what you're doing and watch Gintama.But if you want, you can go get a drink during the first episode and try to catch up later.  It's what Gintoki would do.

This show is hilarious that is the common belief about Gintama,but it also contains action scenes and heart-warming or heart-breaking moments,it is a mix of everything and I mean everything:sci-fi,samurai,contemporaneity,parody,original story.Gintama is an anime of contrast that will surprise you with not only every episode,but every scene.It is unpredictable and discontinuous,but it is part of its magic.Sometimes it may be hard for someone non-japanesse to get all the jokes,but it is not that bad,if you are a fan of anime this is a show that you have to watch no matter if it is just 5 episode or all,when you feel bored on Saturday evening open an episode,I am pretty sure you will not regret it.

I was skeptical at first, but I am so glad I got hooked on this anime! I love how even though there are so many episodes, there is still something that can make me laugh. I have favorite characters, but I think all characters make up GIntama and that without one, GIntama would not be complete. I recommend 100%!!! The only thing I would have to tell new watchers is that there may be some episodes where you may not find funny and you may see that they are trying hard, but I still am in love this is anime, so I still say go and watch!!!

Amazing art,characters that you come to love even if you hate at first,Amazing heartfelt arcs and stories, but above all, HILARIOUSLY FUNNY!! I lost track of all the parody references and I have never been happier,never get tired of it.I,like many was confused by it at first, the plot is somewhat confusing, if there can be considered a plot lol. But all in all, knowing about writing and animation myself,I have to give my props to the mangaka and the staff in the series, it takes a lot to draw your emotions and keep yours interest so fluently. i'm honestly amazed.So watch it,no matter what you do!!Ill give you 300 yen xP!

At first I didn't like this show, I didn't watch this for like 2 months. Then I gave this another chance and little by little I started to appreciate this anime. It isn't your typical shounen anime like naruto or bleach, but it's one of the best in my opinion. Yeah, this show is episodic but it has some arcs which were usually 2-5 episodes. Battles didn't last 30 episodes like it would in bleach.  Strongest point in my opinion on this show is its humor and characters. The show itself is very unique, I haven't seen anime like this. Variation is also one of the main grips of this show. There's parodies, some bad-ass battle scenes, horror stories, romance and much, much more. I think gintama itself is genre. Animation is pretty good, particularly starting from episode 201. It irritated me a bit that they used 4:3 ratio until episode 199. I got used to it after a while. There isn't an actual story, but Gintoki's past itself and events from joi war era are often mentioned so I think that's the main story. But I like the way Gintama does its story.

A lot of people would confuse me in the past when I would ask if I should watch this anime or not. I felt like I could never get a grasp on if i would like GinTama or not. The way people talked about it made it seem like it was one big comedy with some all right drama every now and then. So let me describe this anime for you perfectly so you won't be confused:1) first, GinTama feels more like an 'experience' than just watching some anime. I've never felt that before from any other anime.2) yes, the series is chock full of humor and hilarious situations/characters etc. Seriously, no series (and i've seen a good bit just name one) does humor better and makes you authentically laugh more than GinTama.3) the isn't some 'random' series with random things happening all the time like people describe it to be. When people say 'random' i picture boring episodes that i just have to grind through to get to the good bits. GinTama is simply an 'every day' series of the Odd Jobs group and their friends in Edo. It is very entertaining and never feels forced or random. Everything flows brilliantly.4) GinTama balances humor and drama better than any entertainment show i have ever seen. It's what truly makes GinTama an experience. Think the epicness of One Piece story wise and add in the best humor done on any entertainment platform and you have GinTama.Basically, experience GinTama you will love it.

Gintama is my favorite anime, to put it bluntly. It has absolutely everything. Comedy: Poop jokes, puns, slapstick, nudity, parodies, and recurring gags. Violence: Fighting for friends/allies, fighting epic battles against armies, bleeding from various wounds, sadistic enemies who love to cause pain, more slapstick, typical shounen-style fights that last for 5 episodes. Romance: Comedic unrequited love, requited love that was not meant to be, lovers torn apart by various circumstances coming together to die in each others' arms, homosexual love, heterosexual love, idol worship, pet love. Drama: Arcs that will break your heart one second and have you laughing with tears streaming down your face the next, built-up drama that ends in unsatisfying gags, drama that is hinted at in the beginning and not mentioned again for 100 episodes, moments that make you truly begin to relate to and bond with a character previously only used for gross comedy. The usual problem with Gintama, though, is that it may take a few tries to truly see the worth. Nearly every fan has that story of people who tried and disliked it and refused to try again. I was convinced I hated the show until I was forced to watch the popularity arc, the third attempt. That got me mildly interested and by the next week, I was binge-watching every episode with my brand-new Crunchyroll account, purchased just for Gintama. Give it a try. Then another try. And a third one for good measure. And you'll be hooked.

Gintama is one of the few anime that can actually make me laugh out loud in real life.+Gintama has very funny characters and they never cease to amaze me. They characters are very lovable and cute. +Humorous, you better not eat while watching Gintama because you might spit out your food because of how funny it is. +Good story; something new always happen+It will make you feel better after you had a rough day.5/5 "ITS A MASTA PIECE"-Dunkey

Gintama is and will always be my go-to anime. I join new fandoms, love other things, but in the end I will always return to Gintama as the one series I love above anything else. Every single character speak to me, I love them all and everything they do. The jokes are hilarious, I might be immature for laughing at toilet humour and dick jokes but dammit if it isn't the best kind of comedy I can think of. And when you don't laugh your ass off at the stupidity and silly antics of the characters you will bawl your eyes out from the serious arcs and the heartwarming side-stories. The new season and the improved budget makes me so happy because it looks like Gintama is finally getting the quality anime that it deserves. There's a special charm to the earlier seasons, but there's nothing like looking at the characters you love in beautiful high definition animation! One thing I do wish for is some more recognition of the series in the West. It's booming in Japan, but very underground anywhere else. So if you love this series or want to recommend an anime to someone, please tell them to check out Gintama. They won't regret it. Please watch Gintama!!

I'm not gonna lie when i first started watching Gintama I didn't think much of it. The first 2 episodes were really boring (no need to watch them btw) and I thought it would be a cheesy comedy series. And boy was I wrong. It has so much depth and the show will never go dry in my opinion. Give it at least 1 season (49 episodes). I know its a lot but when a show has 10,000 5 star ratings it has to be pretty damn good lol.

The most-fun television show I've ever had the pleasure of watching.Not just in Anime.Television.You'll fall in love with almost every character, and their recurring gags.If you like your anime incredibly serious with an enthralling story, and the most heroic of protagonists....then maybe this isn't for you - the author is a gorilla, after all.However, if you enjoy solid character development and laughing until you hurt.Then please stop reading this and watch Kin-..... Gintama start to finish.Don't forget the pickled sea-weed.

Best show eva made. Let me just say that this is the first anime that I've watched 200+ episodes with. It knows how make you feel mixed emotions in almost every episode. The characters....I love every character in this show and that's a surprise to me cause I usually don't like at least one person who is too annoying or mean in a show. The thing about this show is that they all can be mean or annoying in the show..........but good annoying!!XD The genre.....this show has basically all the genre, it has comedy, action, horror, drama, a little bit of romance, etc. I don't think I'll ever get tired of this show because it's so different. You'll never know what would happen next.

If you barely going to start watching, don't judge the anime based on the first or second episode. I feel that with this anime you need to watch at least three or four episodes before deciding if you like or not. While the first season may be all comedy, it really starts to heat up after the second season and so on but most of it will just be one shot comedy. There is hardly any plot involved so if you are watching for the plot, you will hardly see any but that doesn't mean the anime isn't good. The serious story arcs make for very good memorable moments  This anime is best suited for people that enjoy tons of comedy with some intense fights in the middle. This is one of my all time favorite animes and I hope whoever is reading this enjoys it too.

This review is half story and half review.  I truly love this anime from the bottom of my heart so I wanted to share my experience first then give it a review after.Once upon a time, a young anime nerd was tired from work and came home only to see that none of his anime had new episodes because it was Golden Week.  Sad, bored and without plans for the night, he decided to see if there were any other series' worth picking up.  Suddenly there it was.  1 episode of Gintama on the whole site.  Episode 75.I thought to myself, "Weird.  I'm a pretty avid anime fan but I've never heard of this."It was destiny.  It happened to be a recap episode.  Something I would hate if I was already following the show but for someone new, it caught my attention."This seems pretty funny.  I'll give it a look."I was not ready.By that time, the anime was about 110 episodes deep.  I started from episode 1 and worked my way to the end in a just under a week.  I laughed, I cried, I got hype and I became hooked.  Gintama became my absolute favorite anime of all time in a few days.  Nothing was even close.Back then only Rumbel Subs did Gintama.  No one wanted a piece of that.  It was too dialogue heavy with lots of slang and figures of speech.  When Crunchyroll announced Gintama as one of their marquee titles when they launched their pay service, I immediately signed up.  That was in 08.  It's 2015 today and despite Gintama not airing the entire time, I kept my membership active.  I've enjoyed other anime here since, but I kept paying because of Gintama.As for my review of Gintama, what's there to say?  It's brilliant.  I've never seen a piece of work like this that can tap into every single feeling.  I've cheered.  Loudly.  I've cried literal tears of both sadness and happiness.  I've gotten angry at characters' inaction because they felt weak.  I've felt empowered when they overcame obstacles.  Most importantly and most frequently, I've laughed my ass off.  So hard.  I've laughed so hard that people looked at me like I was a lunatic.That's what Gintama is.  It's the extreme of every emotion.  It's absurdity that's grounded.  Random, yet calculated.  It's morality without presumption.  It's action without fear.  It isn't just an anime or manga.  It's the soul of the writer given life by amazing characters, story arcs, and profound messages mixed into it's hilarious wit.  It constantly changes the game.  It breaks barriers.  It goes places that other anime won't dare go to.  It makes fun of the stuff no one talks about.  It gives new outlook on things you already know and it touches your soul.This has been my favorite work for over 8 years.  Nothing compares.  What's weird is that, it's about 90% filler.  It's gut busting comedy.  A mix of wit, slapstick, shock and awesome placement of references from other anime, popular or not.  Suddenly out of nowhere, that 10% happens.  Action that rivals the best battle anime out there.  Stories that leave you speechless and deep in thought.  Tragedy that makes you appreciate your life more.  Triumph that makes you want to go out and achieve.I'll admit, the first handful of episodes start off slow.  I feel like the author was just getting a feel for his work and then he suddenly poured everything into it.  Please give it a chance despite it's slow start.Perhaps this is a lot more for me than it is for anyone else, but that's how much I love this show.  If you get half of what I get out of it, you'll love it.  If not, hey, at least you'll laugh your ass off.

The first 50 episodes or os is bad but at least reach episode 100 before rating because it's started out really horrible in my opinion, I'm not sure if it's because I wasn't used to it's kind of comedy yet or just because it did start out boring but after awhile, I found it as my favorite anime. .Why I liked it. 1.) It has very strong female characters that most animes don't have. (Not saying that no other anime has strong female characters)2.) All of the characters all connects like strings.3.) Each character is unique and funny in their own ways.4.) This anime seems plotless but the plot is silver despite starting out cliche, for example, Takasugi and Gintoki used to be comrades but are now enemies, that's plenty enough cliche but Sorachi makes it so that it seems unique as if it was a fresh idea and not something similar to anything else.5.) Character development. Every character has their time to shine. Even the characters that hardly shows up in the anime.This anime is often just comedy but when the arc comes, it's an epicness and feels overload.

Gintama has everything. It could be classified as so many genres. It has action, comedy, romance, great characters and story-line, etc. And yet it still manages to be better than any other anime with all those things. It quickly became my favourite anime, and I have seen everything from Hunter X Hunter to Kara No Kyoukai to Berserk to Magi to Durarara!! But Gintama never gets old and never fails to surprise me. Gintama is number ONE!!!

TLDR; Spoiler Alert! Click to show or hideGintama is certainly a piece that I would recommend. Do not waver at the large amount of episodes. The first few may be slightly off-putting to some, however KEEP WATCHING. It will be worth it, I promise. Great balance of comedy and action, comfortable shifts to heart-wrenching scenes, beautiful characters, unarguably a wonderful show that you will certainly enjoy. Ah yes Gintama, notorious for all of its gut-busting humor, badass fight scenes, and tear-jerking moments.There are times where at one point i'd be laughing my ass off, only to be on the verge of tears moments later, I kid you not. There are many reasons why this show is amazing, so let's take a look at them.1. The setting.  Gintama takes place during the Edo time Period in Japan. However, aliens have inhabited Japan and the ways of the samurai have died out. Let's also not forget to mention that at this point there is advanced technology.2. The characters. Gintama has a wide array of characters, and each and every one of them is significant to the show. A silver-haired samurai with naturally curly hair, a cute but excessively strong alien girl, a stalker gorilla cop, a (sado)masochistic assassin, a wanted terrorist (who happens to be unbelievably stupid), etc. Each character has their own ties connecting them to each other, and they all have well-thought out (often sad) backstories. The characters are not boring pieces of cardboard with flat and cliche personalities. This includes the antagonists. They all have some type of reason for what they're doing and it isn't just "muahaha I'm doing this because I'm evil". I personally love almost every character in this anime.3.  It's ability to easily shift from vulgar and comedic, to deep and emotional.(And Vice-Versa) Gintama is easily one of the funniest animes I've seen. But despite the first few episodes showcasing pure comedy,  It is so much more than that.  Gintama does not only have comedy, but also includes very deep and emotional episodes. Episodes that will literally make me cry my eyes out, the type of episode you would not expect after several d*ck jokes. Don't worry, Gintama has amazing action arcs too. After watching Gintama, I have found that they have done a more exceptional job delivering Action than many Shounen-Action animes. 4. Hilarious Parodies.Yes, you knew it was coming. This is one of the aspects of Gintama everyone knows about. Nothing is safe from being parodied by Gintama. There are far too many references to name, however expect Gintama to Joke about your favorite animes. I would also like to add that the Gintama staff just loves trolling its fans.Those are the main things I had thought I should mention, but I'd also like to talk about the Art, Animation, and Sound.Art- I enjoy the art. The highlight of it would be the hilarious(and occasionally badass) expressions the characters make, I'd say the art is fairly good. To me it sets the mood pretty well.Animation- The animation is okay, not much to say about it.Sound- Wonderful OSTs. Memorable and appropriately placed. Some of the Openings were not memorable, however there are several that easily stick in my mind. Endings were okay as well. Didn't remember most of them.----------In conclusion, Gintama is certainly a piece that I would recommend. Do not waver at the large amount of episodes. The first few may be slightly off-putting to some, however KEEP WATCHING. It will be worth it, I promise. Great balance of comedy and action, comfortable shifts to heart-wrenching scenes, beautiful characters, unarguably a wonderful show that you will certainly enjoy.

Gintama is, in a word, brilliant. Honestly, it took me a long time to start watching this show because it didn't sound interesting and didn't look like anything special. However, after I started there was no stopping. Some other reviews have said as much, but the first few episodes are somewhat slow. After I went back and watched them again, I realized each episode is basically a character introduction and the source of many ongoing jokes.This show is predominantly a comedy. It has every kind of humor imaginable, from parodies to scatalogical jokes. Beneath all the humor though is the true brilliance of Gintama. The serious arcs are epic - recall this is shonen - and the character development is outstanding. Some story arcs will end with a good laugh, others with tears, but it always feels right. This is what separates Gintama from other shonen: Sorachi is a master of creating a story that plays on every emotion. It isn't all laughs, and it isn't all excitement and fighting. Whatever the feeling is, it is done so well it can't be adequately described in words. You just have to experience it yourself. No other anime I have watched has made me feel such a wide range of emotions. No other anime has such perfectly human characters who you can believe are real people. This is one anime you will wish would never end.Underlying all of that is a slowly building plot. Yes, Gintama has plot, though sometimes it's easy to forget as it moves from one goofy arc to the next (with a few epic battles scattered throughout). It's like a darkness churning under the everyday humor, mishaps, and adventures. Truly, there are so many layers to Gintama that no review can do it justice. This anime is a rare gem with brilliantly original characters, finely told stories, and a whole lot of heart.

I believe decades from now Gintama will be remembered as a legendary timeless classic. No other anime like it, Gintama is one of the few anime that can make you go from laughing from it's hilarious momemnts to shedding tears in the same episode. This anime has everything that makes any piece of entertainment engaging. In this amazing journey you will laugh, cry, be inspired, watch amazing action set pieces and marvel in this delicious world of Gintama. Just a warning Gintama starts a little slow, introducing characters and setting up the world but it's a small price to pay for such amazing experience it will provide. Must watch for all anime fans!!

As a fan of the big 3 and several anime there not a single one of them that can ever compare to Gintama.I was skeptical reading at the description and scores that is getting But after catching up I realized that i was rightThe scores did not give it justiceIt deserved WAYYY MORREEEI dont think that there will be any review that will explain the greatness that is Gintamaso i can only say WATCH IT and you will understand .

In honor of the new season coming out, I've decided to write a review. I have very high opinions of this show, and as you can tell from the title and the rating, this is without a doubt one of the most hilarious shows I've ever seen.The show centers around three main characters, and their business Odd Jobs Gin where they'll take on any job for the right price. These jobs can include anything from helping a sushi restaurant to investigating a crime scene, giving the show nearly limitless options.As I mentioned, there are three main characters. These are:~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~Gintoki Sakata- He's the leader of Odd Jobs Gin and is a former war hero. 20 years before the events of the show, aliens called Amanto invaded earth and humans didn't want them there. Many people took up arms, including Gintoki. This is important, as it's where he gets his master sword skills from and many of his past allies from the war now belong to an Anti-Foreigner Faction, numerous terrorist groups that still fight against the Amanto government.Shinpachi Shimura- He's the "straight man" in the show. He starts working for Gintoki after getting fired from his old job, and he's a hardcore otaku nerd (kind of like many of the shows viewers including myself). He and his sister share the goal of rebuilding their father's dojo.Kagura Yato-  A girl who is part of one of the strongest warrior races in the universe. She loves pickled seaweed and her over sized dog Sadaharu (the 27th). She uses an umbrella that also acts as a machine gun for a weapon... it's pretty cool. Though her father has appeared in the show, Gintoki acts as a father figure for her. Like Shinpachi she works for Odd Jobs Gin, but unlike him she also lives there.~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~The show contains many other well-written characters and stories, and you never know where each episode will take you. Though it's a comedy first and foremost, it has many touching scenes and arcs- as well as some awesome battles (I'm looking at you Benizakura and Yoshiwara is Burning arcs). Something however that can for some reason be a turn off to people is that it has many fourth wall breaks and references. These are personally one of the main reasons I love the show, but be warned if you don't like those.Overall, I'd recommend this anime to anyone, and you, the reader of this review, are no exception. Though the first few episodes were actually kind of slow in my opinion, by the time I hit episode 10 I couldn't stop laughing.WARNING: THIS SHOW CONTAINS VERY CATCHY OPENINGS. BE PREPARED TO START HUMMING THEM UNCONSCIOUSLY IN PUBLIC.

Gintama means the world to me and all these experiences and feels, and the way it's moved me and made my world a little brighter cannot be put into words.People think Gintama has no substance. Ha! Let me just say if you dropped Gintama before the 50s. You don't know Gintama. If you dropped it before the 100 mark you really don't know Gintama. You think you know it and then it in the 100-200+ but by 260 it's a whole new level and with layers of depth.It doesn't take 50 eps to get good like people say. It's the way it is, does nothing wrong, It's just a matter of hit or miss. And without the earlier build up and settings the 'great arc' that come later are just okay shounen. Gintama's so hard to describe but it has all of my being and all of my heart.Thank you Sunrise, Thank you to the Voice cast and to all the staff, but most especially, Thank you Sorachi Hideaki. Your work means the world to me.

If you like tons (and I really mean it by "tons") of comedy with a perfect mix of action, Gintama is definitely the anime for you. Though many of the episodes are stories on their own, Gintama does follow a plot line throughout the series. If you have a short attention span and prefer simpler plots (versus anime like Bleach or Naruto), it consists of a series of many short arcs or episodes on their own, with the arcs lasting about 2-5 episodes per. Comedy wise, based on personal viewership, it is the MOST troll anime I've ever watched. Like, on a completely different scale. The producers love to screw with you so much (in a good way) but this seemingly strange quality is definitely why I've stuck with Gintama for so long. You probably don't get it right now but they are some episodes that'll just make your mind explode. In addition, Gintama will have you rolling on the ground laughing your guts out one second, but the next second you'll be bawling. Though it may seem like this anime is the kind with a rushed plot, it does an amazing job at transitioning viewers through many different emotions and stories. Hideaki (author) and the producers do a fine job of timing the revealing of the characters' traits/histories throughout the series. Lastly, as a musician, I do wish to pay my respects to the musical portion, if you're interested in that part of anime. The openings and endings are generally quite catchy and the animations fit nicely with the music and plot. Often times, especially with this anime, it is to your benefit to watch through the credits as what follows may or may not contribute to the plot. Though Gintama has a fairly low viewership in other countries, it is widely popular in Japan. You've probably heard this over and over again from other anime crazed fans, but honestly Gintama is an extremely underrated anime. The plot, characters, and comedy are weaved together in such a perfect blend, with tons of comedy balanced with the brief but substantial moments where characters are revealed, gradually drawing the you in as you learn the deeper connections behind each profound personality. Gintama is truly a hidden and polished gem in the anime world. If you've read through this whole review, thank you for your generous time. Hope this helps in your endeavor for anime of your interest. Sincerely, One with a tremendous passion for anime and the like

Gintama, an anime that lacks attention outside japan and an anime extremely worth watching.Gintama is definitely an anime of its kind, excluding itself into its very own genre which holds very little anime. Gintama lays out an forever expanding universe (very much like one piece, but gintama doesn't explore it) filled with excellent written characters. The show is Shounen, while its jokes are very mature, and the show completely strays from the long and boring anime fights which plagues shows like Naruto and One Piece.The lack of fight makes the little fights that exists in Gintama extremely worth watching and re-watching. This is not the only excellent feature of Gintama, it's reference to anime series, manga series and game is excellent! Those who are experienced with old school anime(Gundam 0079, Doraemon) to new anime (Bleach, Sket Dance) will enjoy the anime more through references and jokes! Gintama is also filled with characters that are well written and worthy of their own show.Gintama arcs are very short, yet they leave a very nice after taste that last longer than some of the extreme long arcs from other WSJ shows.Nearly every episode outside of major arcs is episodic and filled with excellent jokes. The animation of Gintama in the beginning is decent, and as it began its second series and third series, the animation was bumped up further making it one of the more excelltly animated shows out there! (Sasuga Sunrise!)But is Gintama without it's flaws? Of course, no anime is without flaws. Gintama suffers from its slow build up of the series, a major amount of atleast 50-70 episode of the original 200 episode is no where near as good as the rest. Also Gintama is only excellent to those who are experienced with anime, therefore understanding the references which makes the show so good. Therefore it is not a new anime fan friendly show.In conclusion, there is not much to say besides that once you have seen most of the Gundam anime, most of the WSJ anime and mangas and old animes. You are set for the ride that will be in your mind forever!

When I first watched this show I really didn't know what to think going into it.  The picture on Crunchyroll looked good so I gave it a shot.  By the end of the first episode, I was laughing my ass off and I realized I was hooked.  Throughout the entire run of the show, I was always made to laugh, even when the subject of the episode was decidedly sad.  The show is goofy and serious all at the same time and I highly recommend it for anyone who is in the mood for something fun.

One of the deepest,Brilliantly thought out,Emotional jerking,Most epic fight scene,Funniest humored, Anime.The characters all have great personalities.And the humor is really a marvel.Then the serious arcs are very captivating and Immersive.Rating:Characters: 9/10Story/Plot: 8.5/10Setting: 9.5/10Animation: 8/10 - (10/10 on serious arcs)Sound: 9/10 - (9.5/10 on serious arcs) (OST, Openings and Endings get a 9/10)Overall: 4.9/5 Stars.PS- By all means, i have not overrated nor underrated this series.

Okay so I'm sure that other people have thought this too but Gintoki is extremely messed up, he has some major issues mentally because of his involvement in the Amanto War.  The first and most obvious symptom is his tendency to attempt to solve everything alone as well as the fact that until Kagura and "Glasses" showed up he didn't associate with anyone long-term for fear of losing them.  However this personality trait is most obvious during the varied "serious" arcs throughout the show.  The second, but slightly less obvious symptom is his attempt to make EVERYTHING silly, he's always making joke's or getting into ridiculous situations but the one thing that never changes during these comedic moments is the "Dead Fish Eye's" he has.  He's just doing all of that fun stuff to try and forget the enormous amount of emotional pain he is in.  This is further cemented by the fact that his eye's only show any life when he is fighting/getting the crap beat out of him/beating the crap out of bad guys, by doing that he is able to drown in the fighting and momentarily forget in a way that even silliness can't do for him.  Of course this pain and general instability is not only confined to Gintoki, all four of the main fighter's of the Amanto War are extremely unstable.  We have Gintoki that is doing his best to forget, Zura, I mean Katsura that is trying to preserve, Takasugi that is trying to erase or destroy and Sakamoto that is running away.

Gintama is one of the big four in anime! (Naruto, One Piece, Bleach and Gintama!) and it should deserve to be number one!  Gintama offers comedy, action, drama and lots and lots of mayonnaise! The start may be a bit confusing but after 5 episodes it will leave you completely hooked and wanting for more! I started watching a month ago and I'm almost done the entire series! Watch it, you won't regret it!

Seriously.  No words I can say will be sufficient enough to explain this masterpiece if you haven't seen it already.  But I'll give it a try anyway.The plot revolves around The Odd Jobs crew, Gintoki, a samurai who is the definition of an honorable man; while at the same time being the definition of what kids shouldn't aspire to be, in a comedic way.  Kagura, the cute but surprisingly rude, strong, but surprisingly clueless, and kind, but surprisingly immature heroine.  Shinpachi, the straight man who's job (narrative) is to retort to the randomness of this world around him, which is a suprisingly important role in this insane story.  Plus a whole cast of other whacky characters that you will get to know and love.  There are many reviews already who explain the plot much better, so I'll get to what I think of the Anime myself.Immature, random, and stupidly hilarious, mixed in with the most touching moments in Anime history, topped off with amazingly animated actions scenes on rare occasions.  The humor is crude, the references, shameless.  They've parodied every stereotypical genre, and do a damn good job at it.The story itself is very self-aware, constantly breaking the fourth wall and explaining the plot through a narrative.It may be a bit slow in the beginning, I have to admit, which is why it's recommended to start with a few episodes before making your decisions.  Either the Anime grows on you immensely and you assimilate into it's world and it's humor, or the show itself evolves constantly to grow funnier every episode.  Either, way, it's worth sticking around 200+ episodes.And the great thing is that it's not a linear plot, so there's no 10 episode cliffhanger where you NEED to know what happens next.  You can watch it casually over time, and slowly enjoy it like a succulent candy that must be savored.  Of course, just because it's an episodic Anime, it doesn't mean it will stop you from wanting to watch the rest.  In fact, it may even make you want to watch all of the episodes in one go, just because of how brilliant the momentum is in this show.  TLDR; It's hilarious, it's touching, it's characters are lovable, and the rare actions scenes are delicious.  If you put everything together on a crazy pot full of insane situations and ridiculous plots covered with copious amounts of references... You get the strange stew for the soul called Gintama.  And it's wonderful.

Gintama is an odd anime, unlike most shows that stick with a small amount of characters, Gintama grows and adapts. Yes there are four main characters, Gintoki, Shinpachi, Kagura, and Sadaharu, but all of the other characters aren't just one time appearances. They become part of the series as if they too mattered and they do matter. There will be episodes that focus on these "side" characters and because Gintama focuses on more than just the main characters you get a richer more full world. You don't get repetitive comedy, you get fresh new jokes with fresh new characters. Each character has a important background, each character is interesting, whether it is the homeless man in underwear or the Ramen shop owner. The series has a sense of community. I've yet to see a character that doesn't reappear. Gintama is also very parody rich, it parodies other anime, games, shows, American tv and movies. Whether it's Dragonbleapiece, or Pretty Cure, you are sure to have a laugh.Gintama also has serious moments and surprisingly an actual plot of sorts.
