Whenever you reach these 2-6 episode serious moments you will enjoy them, then it goes back into its fun loving normal self. Gintoki and his crew always help out someone in need and seeing the various people they help and the stories of this world in which Gintama resides is very interesting, inspiring, and fun. Some of my favorite quotes come from Gintama. Whether serious "Fight on and those cold fingers will be warmed by the heart of another," or the speech about Strawberry milk.The main reason I love this series is because it is really fun to watch, whether it is Okita and Hiijikata bickering, or Gintoki and the crew being ridiculous. All of the characters are fun, there was an episode about the homeless man named Madao and even though none of the main characters showed up it was hilarious. Gintama does start off slowly though, which is why I know very few people offline who watch it, so I recommend starting at episode 3 where they actually introduce the characters in the timeline. 1 and 2 are kind of out of place and frustrate people who aren't patient. I know Gintama isn't everyone's cup of tea, but if you like anime it is worth a shot!

This anime left me speechless.. It covers everything! Comedy, romance, horror, action, adventure, robots.. whatever comes in your mind.I really can't express how much I love this anime. Compared to other long-series such as naruto, bleach or one-piece, this is the best!From all of my heart, I wish this anime never ends, and I wish if I could ask for more!I never thought of sharing my opinion about any anime; even though I saw many great animes that deserved to be commented on. However, this is my first review of Gintama just because I would like to show how amazing this anime is!If you did not watch Gintama, then I don't know why you're watching other animes.

The premise isn't anything we haven't seen before, and I'm not a fan of featuring overly young characters facing mortal peril, but despite these very snap judgments, this anime managed to hold my interest throughout the first episode. The world jumping is handled in a very stylish way and the deliberate style shifting right before a character uses a special attack just drips with artistic flare that isn't seen in a lot of series. Sure, I feel like the anime is prompting me to prepare to hit a button, but it's a nice touch that shows that the studio wanted to put forth just a little more effort than normal to stand out.Downside: So far, the Japanese Female Oppression Beam is alive and well in this series. We're properly introduced first to our main female protagonist, but as this is a shonen series, naturally she has to be eclipsed by the male lead, because having a female lead that's stronger than the male in combat would make his dick fall off or something. On the upside, however, despite her seemingly cold personality, it's clear she cares deeply about people and she's allowed to be just as weird and quirky as the male lead, showing that she's not some stuck up, sneering superior tsundere. She's got her own vices and things that reveal that she's just as much a typical selfish kid as the male protagonist. At first, the character interactions are eye rollingly expected, but quickly the characters show that they've got more to them than a one-note personality and more than one emotional state, at least by shonen standards. When comparing to the likes of the big names in shonen anime, it looks also like this series will be able to keep a proper pace up, and not go meandering around useless story arcs. The art direction alone is enough to keep me coming back regardless of how much the plot wanders. The appearance of the demon world and attention to lighting is very inspired and crisp, on the level I would expect from a medium budget feature movie. It's clear that they're trying to stand out from the crowd, and I appreciate that. Keep an eye on this series. While super young characters aren't my thing, it still managed to keep me entertained, and I'm interested in seeing how the story ultimately plays out, as long as it doesn't succumb to typical shonen drag, which I doubt it will because of the production values involved. This is definitely not a cheap series to produce, so they're not going to waste money on unnecessary filler arcs.

It's not the generic shounen manga setting that bothers me. It's not the rehashed trope of teenagers blowing stuff up while in so called mortal peril, even though their plot armor is thicker than the soviet IS-4 tank's steel plating, either.What ultimately sets me off is how mediocre the execution is, as an anime. Not having read any of the manga, I'm not one to judge how the work is as a whole, but the show is somewhat painful to watch.I want to love the show, I really do. I'm a huge sucker for action/revenge/supernatural stuff with a sprinkle of dark pasts, but there are moments where I'm seriously left wondering how much effort actually went into this adaptation, in moments such as the obligatory "walking in on a showering girl" scene, the unnecessary and extremely annoying little... creature.... thing..., the frustratingly stale delivery of character emotion, and frankly quite confusing interactions. Okay I'll admit the last two are very subjective but my point still stands and these four aren't the only issues.I also cannot exactly say I agree with the graphic design choices, and the battle scenes are somewhat reminiscent of battle cartoons aimed at toddlers, but hey. I though that about world trigger at first but I grew to love that show.Ultimately it's not very clear cut whether you should watch this or not. I recommend against it if you've already seen a lot of shows like this (or not even, it's a marginal difference), since the small details like out of place fan-service and rehashed scenarios are much more annoying the longer your history with anime is. However, if you are either new to this kind of show with 14 year old kids duking it out with monsters using really funny looking weapons, it might not actually be a terrible experience. I for one remember enjoying a lot of crappy shows for no other reason than because I liked some small aspect of it.

Here is where the rubber meets the road. This is so formulaic its kind of nauseating to people like me who have been watching anime since the early 90's. I am not speaking for all veterans of anime of course, but its been a common complaint among my circle. Typical characters and arcs as well as "shipping wars" among fans made me look away. Even still, I hung out until the end of the last big arc before the time skip. It was watchable while I waited for my other shows to update. Heck, I even liked it and the action was pretty cool.Then it just fell flat and characters were regressing not progressing. I just lost interest. Final verdict? GREAT SHOW for anime beginners. Seriously hits all the sweet spots for first timers. Might not do it for those of us that have seen it all before. Your mileage may vary though. Ken out.

Currently viewed 10 episodes at the time of writing this review...When I first started to watch this show I remember thinking just how cliched it was... yet I still watched it regularly, before I knew it it was a show I looked forward to it every week. Cliched shows are only cliched because they have a popular style which appeals to viewers again and again right? I mean, thats the reason why the typical shonen cliches exist in the first place, because they remain popular, and sell volumes / DVD's... a proven fact.The characters are not very unique, but are still quite relatable, the MC Rokuro has a typical tragic back story which gives you a better understanding of the reasons he has for his lifestyle choices and decision making. Benio I have to say.. I'm not the biggest fan of (Mayura is best girl <3), but she serves her purpose, and you do warm up to her in the end. The Familiar.... shall I go there?? ... its probably my most hated familiar EVER (Kuro-chan for life), I literally cannot stand the stupid thing, it has absolutely no relevance to the story and has the most annoying personality and voice, I dont understand why Studio Pierrot thought it'd be a good idea to include it. The pacing of this show is very good (sort of), it starts slow, then speeds up a bit then WHAM gets very dark very suddenly, it totally sucks you in... and then it fizzles out...It was at this point where things got pretty dark that I absolutely couldn't wait a week to find out what happens next that I picked up the Manga.... this is how I ruined this show for myself. I literally used to hate people who would come across as manga hipsters on the comments and reviews... but oh God I've turned into one of those. Seriously this anime adaptation cant shake a stick at the far superior manga. All of the tense built up elements of the manga seem to have been brushed aside or not covered in enough depth in the anime. Very important elements and battles have been completely cut out, and the character development doesn't even compare. I actually really love Benio in the manga, she actually comes across as human, not just some robotic, ohagi-obsessed exorcist chick who has no social skills. Plus her and Rokuro's relationship is so much more complex (I ship them). In fact the anime pretty much follows a completely different (and inferior) storyline at some points, it just seems like they've made a third of the episodes as fillers. Don't even get me started on episode 10!!! like seriously, episode 9 something pretty major happens, and the next episode doesn't even mention anything about it, let alone progress further with the plot, its just filler. The only thing that redeemed it was bread crust mans facial expressions.Basically... this is why I've ruined this show for myself, which makes me quite sad as I was enjoying it up until that point.therefore I advise anyone wanting to watch this show to not read the manga until you have completed the anime, and if you are planning to watch this and you are already familiar with the manga please don't start watching expecting too much of it as you will be disappointed.

To begin, even though I rated this 5 stars, I am actually rating it a 4.5, but that's not possible with the click the star rating system so I rounded up.Now, it has been awhile since any show has had me as stoked as Twin Star Exorcists. Not since The Irregular at Magic High School and Sword Art Online have I been invested in characters the way I am now. I am getting up early every Wednesday just to watch this show. With that said, I'd like to discuss the aspects of it.Story: The fundamental part of every story in every culture is the plot. The plot here is pretty simple. The world is plagued by Kegare who feed upon humans secretly from an alternate and parallel reality called Megano. Exorsists exist to purify Kegare corruption sites and wipe Kegare out where they appear to feed on humans. A prophecy exists that speaks of the Miko, an all powerful Exorcist who will destroy all Kegare and Megano entirely, thus freeing humanity from the threat.This story is not about the Miko at all. Rather, an oracle has declared two teenage Exorcists to be the Twin Star Exorcists, two powerful exorcists who's union will bring forth the Miko. This is the story of Enmadou Rokuro and Adashino Benio, the twin star exorcists who quite frankly, do not get along and are forced into an arranged relationship of sorts by leading exorcists and the trials they must overcome together. Because this is not really about a "chosen one," and is instead about making sure the chosen one can make it to the world, I have to give it extra points. 5/5. Characters: No good story can advance without good characters and a strong supporting cast. This anime...has 3/4 of that. Rokuro and Benio, at least at first, appear to be overpowered walking tropes. But this show really digs into their characters and they grow from two dimensional characters into well-rounded, strong characters with personalities, abilities, complexities and weaknesses that truly make up memorable and lovable characters. It also shows that they are not, in fact overpowered by a ridiculous amount. Rather, they have a lot more power than other exorcists their age, but they still have a lot to learn and there are exorcists, and even enemies, a lot more powerful than they are. A lot of the supporting cast fit in perfectly well, from Ryogo, Rokuro's adopted-but-not-really brother figure to Mayura, Rokuro's childhood friend who has a crush on him but is best friends with Benio and is not afraid to tell Rokuro how useless he is. The leader of the exorcists is an eccentric but excitable man who is determined to get the Miko into the world and happily puts the two through one embarrassing moment after another, to my great amusement.However, other members of the supporting cast fail miserably. Benio's grandmother and Mayura's grandfather are entirely forgettable in the show, and Benio's familiar Kiniko, seems to have only one purpose in the series. Annoy the viewers. This familar is largely the only reason I cannot rate the characters a full 5/5. He's too annoying and overused. His sole purpose in the show is to make fun Rokuro and yell loudly when he senses nearby Kegare. His whole purpose in the show is really to draw attention to a fight about to happen in an annoying way. Benio, for all our sakes, dump him, soon. 3.5/5. Kiniko, you dropped the character score down by 1.5 points by yourself! Be ashamed.Action: I really enjoy watching the action scenes. It's well choreographed, well-animated, and it does not shy away from the nitty-gritty. Gorey and dark but also fluffy and lighthearted enough to keep it from getting depressing.However, a few of the fights are pretty....bland. Seeing Benio's old master summon some guns and wiping out Kegare by the score should have been a lot more exciting than it was. The Kegare just stood there laughing and let themselves get shot. I think it was supposed to show how powerful she was, but it really just looked like target practice and no real threat was there. So for action I give it 4/5. Music: 5/5, nuff said. Fits really well and helps set up the mood. Overall I give this anime a 4.5 out of 5.

I was really feeling this show at the beginning, then midway (ep. 8-11ish)  I was not too sure to be honest, but I stuck with it, cause, well, why not? Still had potential. Plus someone had mentioned it was going to get 50 or so episodes, so I figured it was slow because the show is being set up. Well  the latest episode was AMAZING. So fingers crossed.  Here's the thing, the episodes for the show are actually very well paced! They don't leave you in suspense all the time and a lot of information gets across. I love that the show tends to resolve it's current issue in a single episode, then moves on. It doesn't pull the whole, "Hey, here's an issue, let's finish the episode RIGHT before this gets resolve, and ADD ANOTHER issue on top of it...and leave the viewers hanging for another week" Another Plus: The story is picking up! I can see a lot of potential for the characters. I'm not just talking about Benio and Roku. I'm talking about the side character! Yes the side characters, who I actually don't think are just simple side characters. I think these other characters are going to get some good development, like Mayura and her dad. Update: I think it goes into fillers and it loses steam.....if it's not filler, then the episodes were not as good as they could've been. So in summaryPros:-Great Pacing-Huge Potential for the Story and it IS picking up-Compelling main & side characters that are developing nicely. Some might even surprise us!-Amazing Art Style-Good Comedy-Great ActionCons:-I'm not a fan of Benio. She started out awesome, but seems to be losing momentum!  But I'm hoping this is all due to her coming development. -Benio's pet (For Reals....) :/  It doesn't get any better....UPDATE: Yes, Benio losing momentum was DEF due to upcoming character development, but I think then it goes to filler, so the show loses momentum again.

Over the course of the first 5 episodes I thought was extremely stereotypical with the main character being a hot headed, immature, OP, loud, Naruto/Natsu cutout. Turns out he eventually grows out of his 14 year old shell and takes on the responsibility of becoming a young adult trying to save the world from Kegare (demons). The female protagonist also impressively evolved throughout the show. Her personality slowly matures to a point that her "cutout" personality becomes something of a base of the soup rather than the main course. Whats unique about this show is that as they evolve together, they truly begin to understand each other in ways many other anime friendships can never achieve. This show is definitely something where you may have to wait to see a good solid plot progression. Especially since in the beginning it feels a little cliche in many aspects such as constant flashbacks, character cutouts, plot stagnancy, and rather poor soundtrack. However, as you stick with it, you will begin to feel a sense of overcoming all of these cliche barriers as well as inseparable bonds between characters being formed. To be honest, this show barely deserves a 5 star rating. But because it portrayed character development so well on top of creating a good reason to like the characters, I want to further promote this show to others by giving it a solid 5 stars.

this adaptation of the manga follows next to none of the source material. they left out huge antagonists and decided to add pointless familiars. the manga doesnt have half of this romcom bs going on it either. im not sure what they were thinking when they wrote this anime but the manga author should be pissed.i guess its a decent show if you havent read the manga. but i would highly recommend the manga if you enjoy this joke of an anime

I'm going to establish first that i'm not really too big of a fan of these types of "exorcist" series because I feel a lot of the writing is lazy. An example is that there are no rules established to what spell power is so it's a very abstract concept within the world. Spell power is introduced into this world as something you could build up by gaining stamina to use more than one talisman and this idea becomes dismissed as the series goes on. Most talismans become irrelevant due to the cursed power forged through contract with the kegares. After a while this show becomes fairly predictable. Throughout my watch I'd say it was fairly underwhelming. Some of my reasons will contain spoilers, you've been warned.Pros++Yuto Ijika. He is a character you love to hate or hate to love depending on the impression this series left you with. The only thing that annoys me is there isn't much insight into why he does the things he does. They painted him more chaotic evil where i think he actually falls more on being chaotic neutral.+The animated zoom-ins when they use signature abilities and the way they sequence introductions seems pretty cool.+Wagakki Band getting more exposure.+For the most part, pretty stylized and nicely done animation.+Although i'm not a fan of exorcist series, seems like a good series for someone younger and new to start on.+Ohagi man.Neutral+-+-Music Choice. For the most parts you become accustomed to hearing some of the music and realize it sets the pace but some of it didn't do it's job as well. Also suzu's metal music was pure cringe.+-For what it was this series feels super drawn out. The pacing isn't great and it always seems like they try to dip their toes on side characters but play them down to the point where it makes you wonder why you should care. They played Kuranashi to be this big bad mofo and he gets squished extremely fast.+-The 12 guardians. Love half their designs, hate half their designs. Not a fan of the "edgy DA OC" Shimon. Most of them are completely untouched/unknown until you get to the Kuranashi arc.Only like 3 of them show their special form.Cons--Kinako. One of the most annoying side characters, they even dedicated a whole episode to this rodent.-A lot of seemingly important plots don't pan out such as Kamui disappears for like 30 episodes, i would think he would be the stepping stone to fighting Kuranashi. Speaking of which..-The Kuranashi Arc: it was pretty disappointing. it seemed like he would be the anti-exorcist based on when abe made the tree and when he spawned. For someone that had lived a century he's tricked quite easily by a 16 year old boy.-Mayura doesn't inherit the tiger talisman from Seigen. I think she would be more relevant to the series if she not only inherited it but was also acknowledged by the head exorcist to be worthy.-Signature moves. When you see the 12 guardians use their signature moves it leaves an impression of their strength. You nearly see Rokuro use astral disaster every episode and it's considered his signature move but it only ever seems to do work on low tier kegare. During the start of the series Rokuro is like the one punch man of the series. To me the funny/ironic thing was if i remember correctly Arima announces that Rokuro and Benio are the strongest exorcists and will birth the Miko. You'd think over time they'd tap more into their hidden potential but they really hard plateau and for the most part seem largely irrelevant.-This series was heavily recommended by CR and was a bit disappointing. Usually CR recommends series with pretty high potential.

I made it episode 33 of this one so I like to think I gave it a fair chance but to be honest, I'm just not interested in seeing how it finishes.As a lot of reviews a quick to mention: this anime begins with plenty of cliches and trope right front and centre. I cannot deny that but it did one thing to start that caught my interest which is to create a love triangle that is forced on two of the characters as opposed to only one. "Okay," I thought, "So we're verring away from the harem thing probably. Let's see what you do with this."Sadly, it does very little. The process for my has been as stylish as you can wish for but it's all flash and no susbtance.##### Minor vague spoiler warning #####At the point where I gave up: we had recently lost a character that pretty much did nothing but wimp about and do the whole "has super duper mystery powers but no control over them nonsese" that we get and ended up using said powers to sacrifices themself for the greater good. Nothing we haven't seen before. However, the entire primary cast is suddenly super sad about losing this character who has spent most of the time on screen together doing nothing but stumbling into combat scenes and doing "a mystery thing".We then find out that this character has some shared history with our main male protagonist and all about his past which lines up with the now lost character. None of this mentioned before, none of this shown. We're just meant to believe that these people formed strong bonds and had all these feelings for one another.It was at this point that I decided that I didn't care how this plot resolves. With characters whose motivation seems to turn on the point of "because now the plot says we're going this way" and most of the development being an excuse to get the next fight to reveal the next power level move being unlocked I am just not invested in what happens.It's far from the worst thing ever created but with other stuff sat on my queue I feel that my time will be better spent elsewhere. Watch it for the fight scenes if you have time to burn, maybe.

If you watch this anime to the current episode, and you don't fall in love with it I think you might have something wrong with you. lol But really though, I have seen a lot of anime lately with yokai and omnioji and the like, but this one stands out. Maybe because, personally at least, I really enjoy the good feels between the MCs and the comic book-esque fighting scenes. The story and art are very well done, none of the silly screen effects like you see in some anime...All in all, I really think this is a great anime, but may be sort of an acquired taste for some. I LOVE IT, but that's just me~ x)

There is nothing particularly essential about this show that makes it a must watch. However, it's not entirely unlikable either. The combat is mostly a series of calling out the name of a move (which is then bracketed across the screen in case you missed it) followed by a flying punch, flying kick, or energy blast. The plot and battle progression is very formulaic. So if you are looking for something to watch, you might enjoy it. But it's also pretty forgettable.

I've only made it about 5 episodes in and I'd like to finish the series, but I just can't watch it anymore.pros: good animation, battles are interesting and exciting, I like where the story is headed.cons: The main characters are just too obnoxious. I imagine they might get better as the series goes on, but I just can't watch anymore. I found Asta's voice from Black Clover more enjoyable than the two main characters and that stupid mascot.

This series takes a lot of inspiration from other larger and more successful anime. Shows like Bleach, Dragon Ball, Naruto etc... It tries, sometimes quite successfully to have it's own style... But nothing it does it really remarkable. The story is cliche but passable, the action... passable but nothing fantastic. The humor can be pretty good at times though.Sadly what stands out is the last segment of the show, where the writing is clearly takes a significant turn for the worse. I haven't read the manga personally, but I understand that this show veers far from it's source material, and that almost never ends well. It's not a terrible anime, I'd give it a solid C+. You can do a lot worse, but you can do a lot better too.Pros:Good musicAttack names(to explain is a spoiler, but you'll understand if you watch)Real character progression - the two lead characters definitely mature a good bit.Cons:Terrible endingInconsistent writingThat stupid mascot character has possibly the most annoying voice in any anime in the last decade.

The beginning maybe a little slow and weird, especially considering how the main protagonist looks but once you continue thru the story the plot gets better and you find this to be a great anime. I am not one to write reviews, but I find it worthy of my time. I like how unlike any anime before it, it gives you the exorcist supernatural feel with hints of the protagonists having feelings for each other. I certainly recommend it!

This show speaks for itself giving you no room to catch a breath, from the moment you enter you are gripped into a thriller past and thrown into a deep story line in which 2 characters meet as a part of fate and are thrown into a depth-defying future that can only be described as humorous, and dangerous. By watching each other and yet avoiding each other, this shows the truth behind friendship, love, and willpower to protect those you love. Once you enter their lives, you can't find much of a reason to leave it giving just one more show to add to that list of Anime that you just can't stop watching. I would recommend this Anime to anyone from the Beginner to the Hardcore veteran because it's just enough to keep you there while keeping you enthralled on what can only be considered a quality Anime in the making.

It looks pretty, but that is about it.  MC kun is supposed to be haunted by a tragic past: he'll NEVER fight again! Instead of exploring themes of PTSD and overcoming adversity, he just gets over it.  This immediately sinks any promise of character development he could possibly have had.  Despite screaming about how he'll never be an exorcist again (while living and eating for free in an exorcist dorm), he still keeps his weapon with him and leaps into action to save the day like he was just being a spoilt little shit this whole time.  Worse, the female lead is supposed to be super skilled and can fight circles around MC kun.  He makes one clumsy counter-attack and everyone drops their jaw and pretends like he is unbeatable.  He hasn't even practiced in two years and didn't have that much experience before then either.  I understand red oni/blue oni pairings, I really do.  But this isn't passion Vs technique... its iron-clad plot armor Vs mastery... where we are INFORMED that MC-kun is the best after clearly seeing him outclassed.What proceeds from here are far more shounen cliches, an annoying side-kick, and not much else.  I hear the manga was awesome, and this may have gotten good after the first 5-6 episodes... but I saw no reason to stick around.

PLZ READ ALL!!!!!Really good show but some problems I  feel are that they started off the show over powered and then in no time they are really weak. I  wished they showed more training and bonding together faster. The story moves really slow yada yada. As well as that sae girl she just pissed me off..........But anyway move the story along fast and try to portray the 2 more as a couple, instead of teens going on a first date but for the whole story which is how I feel it is. Rokuro is two uhh how do I say this without cursing..... A GIRL DOG DAMMIT....... you get the point. Benio insults him one time and he gets all sad and mad. Do not get me wrong these are just the bad parts in my opinion, its still a really good anime and I want more and for it to never end lol like most animes I enjoy I just want you guys to keep pumping out more and more. I wish I had taken my time watching it instead of binging it cuz now I'm out ;(If you took the time to read all this your amazing!!!!!!!!

Fucking Kinako wasn't in the manga, and after episode 16 or 17, the story takes a completely different turn. It's probably because they decided to make this a 50 episodes anime, but I feel betrayed watching this way more happy story than the original. The manga had a more interesting dark tone that I come to like and that is non-existent after they made their original story. I really really wish they made this less episodes but more honest and faithful adaptation from the original manga. Two stars cause Twin Star....just kidding. It's because the production quality of the anime isn't bad at all.

I started watching Twin Star Exorxists on the first day it was aired. There will be some spoilers in this review. The concept of this animé an action shonen with Rokuro Enmado who although a very strong exorcism but refuses to be one and Benio Adashin from Kyoto who is considered to be one of two of the strongest exercisers for her age. They do most of their battles initially in a parallel would caled Mangano fighting beings called Kegare. Rokuro lives in Seika Dormitory near Tokyo and is walking around. Benio is riding a train to her new place of residence when her familiar, Kinako warns her that there is an Kegare  about to attack the train. She begins to fight the Kegare by using a prepared talisman that temporarily opens a gate into Mangano. She arms herself with more talismans to fight the Kegare. While trying.to fight the Kegare Benio is forced out of Mangano and starts to fall by a bridge. Rokuro is walking by the bridge and tries to catch Benio from falling. They both fall into the water of the river below. They both get out of the river and Benio uses a talisman to open another door back into Mangano bringing in Rokuro with her. Benio boasts to Rokuro that she will defeat all Kegare but she begins to run out of her spiritual energy. Rokuro seeing that Benio is a little over her head with this Kegare makes the comment if you can't make a boast without backing it up what good is it. Rokuro then starts to fight the Kegare and with the first punch purifiers the Kegare. They exit Mangano where he tries to assist Benio to where she will be moving to. While along the the way Benio who is broke and starving asks Rokuro  if she could get something to eat at a convenience store. He hands his wallet to her and she spends all of his money on all of the rice and sweet red bean cover paste called hogai which is her favorite food. Benio hands back the empty wallet Rokuro and doesn't share any of the hogai. Rokuro leaves Benio in discuss due to her rotation attitude and that of her familiar Kinako. He goes home to Seika Dormitory to his shock he finds Benio there along with Ryogo Nagitsuji, Shinnosuke Kunizaki, Atsushi Sukumozuka and the head of Seika Dormitory. They find out that they are to be forced into a prearranged marriage to give birth to the Miko the rebirth Abe no Seimei. The relationship between both Rouko and Benio is that of two tsundre characters.

I really like the story of this anime, it shows how characters have to work together in the end, and shows exactly how weak characters can be, and the amount of effort they must put in to become stronger. I am really tired of OP characters just beating all enemies in sight quickly, and without much effort. This anime is more realistic with it, and has our two main characters trying seriously hard to become strong, and save their friends, and each other. The enemies are cool looking, and the powers are neat. Animation is great too.

I'd say I've watched a fair amount of anime so let's assume i know what i'm talking about. Basically the story start very cliche and there are a few moments when you think "man the character is really stupid to do that", or that "wow shouldn't they have learned something by now?". Well from where i see it, its just a really really slow plot, the characters develop slower than everyone would like so if this end up being 24 there will not be any significant change unless they just scrap everything in one episode. I just see lots of potential and so far its kept my interest. Certainly not best of the season, but i would recommend watching it.

I wanted to love this, I wanted to really really enjoy this anime. The story seems amazing but... The delivery? I can't handle the constant flashbacks upon flashbacks - to the point they'll flashback scenes from like 5 minutes prior like you'll have already forgotten. And the same emotional flashbacks over and over that don't really add much since it's what you've already seen. A few are well placed, but most? Meh.And the screaming of names the moment someone gets hurt. Like "ILL SAVE YOU BY SCREAMING THAT IM COMING!" it just hurts worse than any other anime of the same nature. And the RPG-esque game style of freezefame attack names, coupled with a face shot?Edit: After watching Episodes 19 and 20 I also want to add that  Spoiler Alert! Click to show or hideit feels like they are shoving as many power ups, character emotional scenes, character development, and SCREAMING NAMES as they can in two episodes to rush the story along. It feels like they plan to finish the series (season?) in the next few episodes or want to get a bunch more flashbacks in!Delivery was terrible, period. The story itself? Amazing - cliche sure, but really fun! I plan to read the manga, I hear it does it more justice.

This show really excels in the 2nd season. The first couple of episodes kinda dragged on, but what kept me coming back was the beautiful animations. Once the characters developed more the story really begins to take off. If I had to complain about anything so far it'd be that the main enemies are pretty linear even for a shounen. All in all great show, has kept me consistently coming back to it for 20 weeks.**Posted at Ep. 20

Just as my review title states, I don't care what anyone else says about this show, I love it! Every week it leaves me pissed that I have to wait another week to see more. I haven't read the manga, and if it's like most Anime, Ill probably wait till after the anime ends, because it probably leaves a lot out, and a lot to be desired from the manga. But since I haven't read the manga, this show is killer!

I am enjoying this thoroughly, however, I cannot see it lasting very long. It's doomed the moment they revealed that they have to have a baby. First of all they are too young to have one so theres a couple of years in the storyline but secondly I dont know how he can get anymore powerful. His arm doesnt really morph and she definitely doesnt have anything different other than the incantations she puts on each limb of her body. The other characters are kinda rubbish. They just hang in the background trying to be useful but we all know in the end that the two main characters come in to save them everytime. As for blondie I dont know how her story will pan out...fancying the main guy who doesnt fancy her back and he has to live eat and breathe with the main girl.

The premises is seen so so many times. You have two characters who hate each other but you can see from the start that they are gonna end up together. This time the girl is the serious type and the boy comic relief. They try to be funny with these cheap jokes about adults trying to get them together and girl finding porn in boys room. Cheap... Love story is a bit forces and painful to watch. In one minute they hate each other and in another they do nice things for each other and help each other. The refrain "I MUST GET STRONGER!" is so so cliche! You have seen so many bad guys this far and they obviously can't defeat them yet. You have way too many things on top of another. Too many stories are being told on top of each other and non of them are moving forward...

I initially got started on this series through the anime which it took me a bit to sit down and try to watch, but ended up being pleasantly surprised considering the lack go good anime lately. The animation and character designs are great, and voice acting is good too, no complaints there. Around episode 6 I was caught up, and wanted to know more of the plot and didn't want to wait so I went to read the manga. I spent a whole day getting caught up on the manga and it's been a bast getting to see how this story develops into a darker mature story. Now having read the manga and thoroughly enjoying the plot and characters that are later introduced, I was even more excited to see it in the anime. However, the anime makes a few slips, and takes some liberties in rearrange key story elements in the way characters first meet and so forth. These change ups in the anime series really messes up the pacing and overall story they are working towards;  it was just disappointing since the manga's  version of the story was executed so damn well. If your curious, I highly recommend reading the manga online to see what I mean. I hope that so far this change up only goes as far as Rukuro's Master, Kamui's first and second meeting with them, and how that affects the meeting with Benio's brother. I hope they stop trying to rearrange the great story the manga is far ahead on, and don't try to play it to kid friendly.....I'm getting tired of anime pulling hits at the best moments when they shouldn't.  As it stands with the current mixes and changes I'd say this is actually a 3.5 out of 5 stars, but I can't do that with the rating system. So for now I'll give it the benefit of the doubt and hope it recovers and starts to be more like the great plot the manga has, and give it 4 out of 5 stars.

This anime led me to one of the greatest manga I have ever read. The anime has been pretty good so far, but they changed a lot of things for no reason. I don't know why studio Pierrot feels the need to change so much from the source material. They ruined Tokyo ghoul, and I hope to god they don't ruin this anime too. One of the changes they made was adding an anime original character. And this character will probably piss you off with how annoying it is. Although, this anime is slated to have more than 40+ episodes, so I will reserve my full judgement until then and hope they follow the manga more closely in future episodes. I fully recommend the manga though.

The plot of this anime is pretty cool. It's similar in a way to Soul Eater. It's plot is something everyone has probably seen before, but that's not really a bad thing. People enjoy watching these kinds of story. I'm one of them. However, the reason I'm only giving this a 3 star rating is that this anime's story telling needs a lot of work. The story is extremely rushed and it doesn't take the time to really develop the character relationships in a way that really hooks you in and  help you relate to the characters at all. I felt like I was reading a 12 page children's story book when I was expecting more of a novel. Although I don't have much confidence in this, I hope that they're just trying to rush through setting the scene so that they can get into the meat of the story.If you've watched everything else then maybe give this a try. But if you haven't yet, there are a ton of better anime out there for you to watch.

I read the first volume of the manga and to me the many changes they made from the original are glaring. that isn't to say this is bad. one thing I noticed they replaced the scene where Gramps and Ryogo are exorcising a young girl of a Kegare as a way to introduce the the function of Onmyoji and there reason for existance, instead they had a fight scene that explains nothing except swords and explosions. the second thing is the new characters, the cast is light on important female characters so adding one new one isn't too much trouble, but I really don't see the need for a mascot character. this is just my thoughts on the first episode so I'm refraining from giving it a harsher review. my only true concern is I can see it going the way of the soul eater anime, which is generally regared as lesser stroy wise when compared to the manga. but we'll see I have not done any divinations to know the future of this anime

The Story of "Twin Star Exorcists" isn't the most original thing ever but nowadays, nothing is truly original anymore. "Twin Star Exorcists" provides good action scenes with nice comedy and likeable characters. That's good enough for it to be worth watching in my opinion.The animation is pretty decent too for Studio Pierrot standard.Music is great too especially the OP by the great Wagakki Band.Please give this a watch all shounen fans out there~

I'll admit, this anime is fairly standard in what I've seen, but that's not a bad thing. I'll start with some negatives; the plot can be predictable at times, there is a section in the middle that feels repetitive but is ultimately important, the fights can be underwhelming especially regarding their finishes, the main characters at first have generic motivations and personalities. However, this show did something that other anime's have failed at- make me care. The relationship between Benio and Rokuro develops wonderfully and meant that even though it had a predicable conflict at the end and a somewhat predictable outcome for them at the end- I wanted it. The range of characters was excellent and the art style was good. I watched the dubbed version (not by choice at first but I liked it) and the voice acting was great. There's an interesting message about how the mix of bad and good in humans makes us human if you wanted to write an essay on it. I really liked both Benio and Rokuro who were both strong and flawed in their own ways. There were times where I felt that some ideas were rushed over but I was left wanting more. There are currently 50 episodes and I want more. Overall, it is an enjoyable show that is worth your time.

I'll be honest the story was really good in the beginning, but I stopped watching it because it went off from what the main original manga was trying to produce. Everything was in line together but close to the middle of the season everything just started to change and nothing was coming out as plan like in the manga. I stopped on episode 47, because I got tired of how the story was already messed up.I just didn't like how it went off topic and change the chronological order of how everything was supposed to be introduced. Though I am going to try and finish the show. I feel that this would be better for like beginner's because some people don't really know about manga's and some do. But like most anime's don't always go with the manga and some anime's actually sound better than the manga, but for me I'm actually happy that I'm reading this manga instead of watching the anime first.Luckily, the anime had first came out after I had just started to read the manga from Anime club, when I use to be in high school the club members would read manga's before the anime's would area out.

To be honest the characters ruined the show for me especially Rokuro and his 'in his feelings' decisions in which he tries to fight Kegare every. Every TIME. Dont get me started on Benio.. her attitude at times can be unbearable. And Kinako, whats the point of his existence in the Anime anyway?!. Overall the show was meh but The intro's and animations were quite good. But I heard the manga is quite good and is more descriptive so ill check that out. Adios

I started it thinking it wouldn't be too special just from the look of it. I could not have been more mistaken I ended up finishing the anime in two days it is 100% worth a watch! I have watched over 225 other anime and rarely come across ones that I will sit and binge anymore but this brought me back to when I was first starting with anime and just wanted to know what every anime would end with. This is one of the best anime I have watched in a long time

Please bring this back I fell in love with this and want to sea more so I will stay tune if there is a twin star exorcists 2 so please make more...………………………………………………………………………………………………………………………………………………………………………………………………………………………………………………………………………………..                                                                                                           Ps: if you need more people to act I got u lol

to make it clear I liked the show, I thought it was great but I can see why people would want to give it the lowest possible score in the  history of mankind and its understandable why. to sum this up in a nut shell this story blanketed in clichés and a near translucent plot aside from the two well placed twist at the end. this show is for people who like the shonen battle show where love prevails all and has a happy ending and people who don't like that will without hesitation move one to their preferred category. and thats fine it wasn't for you in the first place but they go one to leave a ill written review, its like having the worlds best musicison judge the work of the worlds best artist it jest doesn't resonate well. watch this show if you like Naruto but don't expect it to be anywhere as good I jest got that kind of vide watching. its got some good art work and I'm not certain if it was the third or fourth opening song but it was one of the best that I've heard in a while and the characters and plot are predictable but likable and its a happy ending, its not a angle beats or Naruto nor fate/stay but its still entertaining for the target audience but it sadly gets trashed buy people who haven't even gotten past episode 5 out of 50. I hope this clarified some things if any and gave merit to my star rating.

The impurities of Magano do not rest, creatures that can be described as hellish and demonic who invade our world on a whim, threatening our way of life as long as humanities exorcists could remember. Rokuro Enmadou, a used to be exorcist in training, has given it all up over a traumatic past and now lives in Tokyo. Benio Adashino, a growing prodigy within the realm of exorcism has been summoned to the area. The meeting of the two signals the reincarnation of the one true exorcist that will cleanse all the impurities of the world, bringing peace and order at last. Rokuro and Benio will be the ones to bring that peace, as the twin star exorcists, who in time will give birth to this one true exorcist as prophesied, the Miko.As said in the title, Twin Star Exorcists was one of the first anime, (3rd anime I watched to be exact) it got me hooked into the unpredictable unique world of anime itself. Before I go into detail about the show, I'm going to say that I won't. Despite a great first half of the anime, the second half of the show just was slowly going down and down, a new story that wasn't taken from the manga, with weak writing and losing focus of what made it good in the first place. So while this is an anime review, I'm going to instead recommend the manga. Of which I decided to pick up not long ago, and re-sparked the once devoted love I had for this series. If you absolutely want to see the anime though, just don't expect things to stay good after the halfway point, play it safe and lower some expectations, since the story after that point is not a true adaptation of the manga, and just feels thrown together for the sake of continuing the anime.

At first, I loved it. Sure, it was cliché but they manage to make it work. I'd been hearing a lot about it, so I watched the anime first and immediately binged the first 5 or so episodes. Even without reading the source material, it was painfully obvious which parts were filler. This anime really is a classic example of a bad adaptation. Whether it was the lack of people in the background or the unnecessary scenes put in to make the main characters look cooler, it made my love for the show waver quite a bit. At some points, it was as if the main characters were in a ghost town- no police, no bystanders, not even any parents concerned for their children. The way the fillers were done seemed to be in order to pad out the story and make is as long as possible, and they wanted to do so in the quickest way possible (not even one bystander off in the distance?)After hearing that the manga was better, I decided to give it a try. Thank goodness I did, since it has everything I loved about the first few episodes and more. I was surprised that the mascot character wasn't there at first, but I thought back to the anime and realized that he never really added too much to the story and was probably an easy add-on. I realized after reading it that the anime could only ever be action-adventure or some sort of rom-com school adventure. What made it work in the manga was the combination of both, but I found that the anime was either one or the other.Since this review is about the anime, I will say that the animation is nice as well as the character designs and voice-acting. If I had remained ignorant and not read the manga my opinion of this may have been higher. The fight scenes are well done which is what made me so confused when some scenes seemed to have not a lot of effort put in (and I don't mean sloppy artwork, I mean things like timing of the fillers and consideration as to whether it seems like it would happen in this universe.)If you really want to give it a try, I'd at most only recommend the first few episodes since the story then goes off-track, and while I've learned that that can be a good thing, this unfortunately was not the case.

The beginning is promising, but majority of the rest of the show feels repetitive and cliche, besides parts leading up to the ending. 50 episode is too much for a story that could have been told in half the time. This a somewhat unique take, but still a very cliche shounen rom-com. I feel like some episodes could have been cut out or several could have been condensed into 1-2 episodes instead of taking of multiple. The plot was somewhat original, but towards the end I began to see similarities to other anime. The power scaling in the show, seems to cater to the plot whenever it pleases, which can throw the viewer off. Not to mention the fight scenes can be somewhat annoying and repetitive with the calling out of each move along with text, followed by a battle cry(happens way too often.)The characters are likable, but can be very annoying at times with their interactions. Some of the plot twist can be easily predicted with a little thought and can be found in other well known anime. If you like rom-coms with some action, then this anime might be for you, but 50 episodes might be a bit much if you prefer story over romance & comedy. I found this painful to watch half way through, but continued anyway, because I hate not finishing a show.I wanted to enjoy this show, but by the end I couldn't be any more happier that it was finally over. After watching so much anime, this one just felt way too predictable towards the end, even at times during the middle of the show. The romance was very cliche and annoying at times. The action, besides the complaint about announcing every move every single time was ok. The visuals at times were amazing and sometimes they were the opposite. The entire anime was cliche, but if it was executed better I might have been able to enjoy it more. I got some laughs here and there, but overall this anime was a bust for me. I feel like this show would have been much better with 25-30 episodes as majority of it felt pointless and painful to sit through. If you are new to anime, you might enjoy this, but if you are a experienced anime viewer and have watched more than just shonen anime, I will definitely not recommend this to you.

Twin Star Exorcists has a lot of potential with a hero with a bitter past and a netherworld full of evil spirits. However, it's emphasis on a forced romance feels... forced. With a typical tsundere gag, a lot of episodes are wasted trying to make sparks fly. The comedic relief is also lacking and the jokes aren't unique enough to be refreshing. It does have some badass moments and some badass characters, but the plot as a whole lacks cohesivity and isn't compelling enough to wait for the story to progress.The manga does a much better job than the anime in progressing the story so if you're really interested in the story I would go ahead and read the manga instead. The anime isn't a bad show to play in the background though.

This anime is really good in my opinion, and i really like how they finally showed us some real connection between Rokuro and Benio. I like the pace at which the story moves and i like how all the characters are some what developed and have a reason too be in the story. The reason why i didnt give it 5 stars is because i do think there are some things they can improve upon but never the less still a good anime

This one I’ll keep brief. What I liked about this show is it’s co ed, not to a Bleach degree but more so than Naruto. I liked the bonding between Benio and Rokuro, how they had to work hard to understand each other and ultimately work together. I even liked the idea of their arranged marriage. I liked the character designs (more on that in a minute) and most of the character interactions. I liked the action scenes to a point (more on that later). This show worked…For about 20 episodes. Then they introduce the 12 most powerful exorcists alive today, without giving any reason or explanation of how this kegare problem persists if they’re that damn powerful. And if Rokuro and Benio are more powerful than them, why are they needed? Their character designs are suppose to reflect their uniqueness, but part of the appeal of this show in the beginning was the simplicity of the standard exorcist uniform, and the fact they had the same set of skills. Then they travel to Kyoto to battle basara, but they struggle against some, easily defeat others, and simply can’t/don’t defeat others. Then the final arc comes where once again we have a villain so over powered the writers had to have him choose to not simply kill the heroes because then it’s game over. Also the plot twist at the end is so clichéd and predictable I can’t honestly recommend this show. One thing I do want to mention is this apparently isn’t based on a game, video or otherwise. The star logo upon death of kegare and the screen caps of the techniques used got old fast and annoying; I’d rather they yell them out (which they did too). A bonus point for "Re:Call" by i☆Ris.

The color palette is nice.... After 7 episodes, its really slow, and the characters are dull. We're told (several times) how worthless the Rokuro (the male lead is), but that never really comes across. Considering the amount of time they waste in exposition and flashbacks, they definitely could have put in some more 'slice of life' elements to help the viewer actually understand Rokuro's basic worthlessness and tragic past (which we are teased with incessantly but still know nothing about, which I'm expecting to be disappointingly simple at this point). Maybe its a 'slow burn' type of thing, but if you only have enough emotion to put into one episode, it probably shouldn't be spread out over six. The fantasy elements are neat and could be interesting (and maybe are later) but at least at the beginning we're treated to the same moves and spells over and over, and expected to be amazed each time. The danger to the characters hasn't so far ever been actually convincing in the least, and the same plot element keeps getting fed to us over and over again ("seems like the kegare attacks are getting worse!") without any actual progression with them.  They could honestly get away with that if there were actually a little more depth to the characters.(aside: The 'evil laughter' of the kegare (interdimensional Demon things, which I don't think is explained ever as it is in the manga...though I did doze off a couple times so maybe I missed it) is reminiscent of Puella Magi Madoka Magica, which also is a constant reminder of how this show isn't as good as that one (not that it should be, but doesn't help the cause).)If it were between watching more Black Clover or this, I would definitely choose this, and as much as some people have hyped it, maybe it does get better over time. It is visually okay to look at, but, just like the characters, it always feels like they're dragging their feet on its potential, and maybe don't even care if they're going to get there. Two stars for potential and for not being Nobunagun.

I've watched whole in mare 2 days. And I loved it. Series starting late, about 8/9th episode but at first you laugh and enjoy the fight then you love it and watch fight then you realise that you fall in love with main characters when you were laughing at them.And finally you are sad. Topic covering main characters were almost like forgotten and you just want more about them and less about fights.... but it ended.... and now you've got void in your heart.... and just want season 2.... sadness.... ;<

At first, I mostly got attached to this because of the neat, other-worldly stuff that was going on. The interested exorcisms and powers. The backstory of Roku that I absolutely needed to know.But then the plot decided to smack me in the face, and just keep getting deeper and pulling me in further.Needless to say, it got REAL interesting and REAL good, kind of all at once, and then it never stopped getting good. Haha! The character development is insane, and the details and backstory just keep getting better. Towards the end when things start coming together it did keep me on edge. Watching this simulcasted was almost self-torture, honestly.Not to mention some of the openings. The openings. ARE SO GOOD.If you like action/fantasy/lil romancin on the side. Definitely pointing at this one here, it's pretty dang good actually.

There are a lot of reviews for this show so I'll just say a few things here.  I'm 32 episodes in at this point in the series and I have seen our main characters grow up from kids to young teens. Not many animes do this (actually, hardly any anime does this) so it was refreshing for me to watch them grow up into mature young adults.  I do find the shikigame annoying but that's a staple of most anime I watch; in other words, I'm not going to decrease a show's rating just because it has an annoying character in it.  If you want proof...well, just think about the anime shows you have watched in your life...trust me, you'd need several hands to count the annoying characters you've had to endure.  Anyway, the relationship between Rokuro and Benio is adorable and not over the top with the romance.  I particularly enjoy Arima's tenacious trolling about the awkward affair.  It is hilarious.  Rokuro, as a kid, is pretty annoying but I still believed Rokuro would act that way...I mean, he is a kid with a grandiose dream after all.  The show also doesn't hold back on the damage the two MC's face throughout the series.  Let's just say people are gonna lose stuff...important stuff...Lastly, the action sequences are good.  The fights with the basara have a weight to them.  I am confused about one basara that likes to play heavy metal music.  It's weird, but fortunately, I like heavy metal music.If you are new to the series, give it a couple of episodes.  I believe it's worth it.

I will start off by saying due to some early on power level imbalance which has become way to common, plus some what I thought at the time to be Bleach like similarities it was hard to see it for its own thing. However as I watched more and more into the series I did realize this show was quite good in its own right. This show overall is a fun anime with a  good  fighting game like aesthetic to the fight scenes they do these ultimate moves and the attack name plasters across the screen followed by a picture of the face of the person doing it screaming their head off, but somehow this never got old for me. this show has good pacing for the most part, but it does make some really bad choices at some points when this are grim exciting then something happens that kill all tension flat out; luckily this only happens one or two times. now that I put in my biggest gripes and likes I will put a pros and cons list for sake of simplicity Pros: in no particular order1. Great main characters with good believable development between them2. Fight scenes are enjoyable.3. Most of the the villains are complex enough to be sympathetic, but not so much that they become confusing.  4. The plot is good and doesn't try to be FF7 in levels of complexity, so I can watch once and get the plot after thinking about it for a while.5. I didn't once consider quitting part way through. A lot of great anime can have this issue where you say to yourself well I can give it two more episodes then I'm done. I never had that moment with this.  Cons: from biggest deal to smallest 1. The bulk of the supporting cast is under developed for the amount of screen time they get.2. the final boss.3. The one or two pacing killer scenes.4. The power level jumps, but these are nowhere near the level of say Bleach. Then once it happens it stays pretty consistent there after, so not to big of a gripe here.  That's my lot  hope it made sense.

its litterally the standard shonen formula anime, it feels so corporate and predictable, all, litterally all of the characters are just archeatypes like the cold loving one, the standard brown-haired portagonist and tsundere girl. most of the characters are so edgy their where times i thought this was ripped off of deviant art. The animal is terribly annoying and it just served as another standard part of the shonen formula as the animal companion. the only, only thing i can say is different and unique about this show is it is a romance, both protagonists have a very strong bond and thats the only thing worth watching for, if you can stand the filler. which is 90% of the show anyway because they wanted to maximize profits by making this anime longer. they only ever kiss and confess at the very end, litterally the last couple minutes. thats all the true romance you get, the rest is half romance stalling just because its corporate and simply sticks to a formula, you can tell how thin theyve worn the story by the end, and i could litterally not stand to watch 18 minutes of filler and the characters doing nothing except talking, with the other 2 minutes consisting of half romance and the worst least hyped poorly made fight scenes, you can tell they where made by workers being enslaved by a corporation and forced to make mildly interesting fighting animation as fast as possible. it all feels very predictable and unbearable at times, standard cookie cutter anime.

This anime is a typical shounen onmyouji stoyline, good vs evil, love and hate, all the things that typically represent this genre. That said I thoroughly enjoyed the story. While in the beginning, I was not a huge fan of either Benio or Rokuro, the characters grow on you as watch them grow, live, and mature. I enjoy new innovative anime, manga, and light novels as much as the next guy, but shows like this remind me why people love these cliched and stereotypical plots. I definitely recommend this series!

wanted to give it 4 stars , but kinda can't . not to say it was bad , but like some other reviews , nothing new here , nothing ground breaking. Just a standard anime tale given enough episodes to develop the characters solidly. Kinda reminds me of Eureka Seven , but I enjoyed E7 a lot more , maybe because like another reviewer stated , I've seen this story before and would be great for new anime watchers but YMMV for those who have been around for awhile.

On its own, it's a decent quality anime, not the best and not the worst. When you bring the manga into perspective the anime has much to live up to. Frankly, as most people are excited to find a new anime for their beloved manga this anime was a disappointment. There were very few situations that lined up with the manga and I would not recommend it if you have already read the manga. The manga has great quality artwork that makes someone want to reread it twice and plot in depth that the anime did  not live up to instead deciding that halfway through the anime they were going to complete change the plot while attempting to include major scenarios in different situations. Also, the art was weak and required more effort to be on par with the manga. There were some episodes I did enjoy such as the anime has one or two episodes that focus on the Shimon X Mayura ship, but the manga quickly followed up with subtle but sweet situations.The anime has much to yearn for if it is ever going to strive to catch up to the manga's quality.

Pretty simple here. The shows concept, art and everything is great except implementation. The show can build some real hype but it never really seemed to deliver on it for me. It was slow, but doesn't really have a lot of character development to compensate. The fights are cool but you never really get a good struggle, just flip flops from "we can't even hurt him," to "we just one shot him." You never really get the sense that they grew. I just couldn't get into it and I really wanted to.

The story was alright for a shounen for most of the series.  Thinly veiled excuses to fight monsters and some poorly written angsty teen drama about a couple being forced to work and live together even though they hated each other.  It even did a decent job showing why they eventually fall in love.  What it failed was it's landing.  The ending is atrocious with deus ex machina and old irrelevant characters coming out of the woodwork in droves.  The McGuffins were way to convenient and nothing explained why anyone should care about what was happening at all.  As vested as I became with the characters, it was easily shattered when the story itself stopped caring.  A huge waste of time.

So let's get something clear first off. Like many anime adaptions, they diverge quite a bit, this is a really good anime, but very lacking compared to the manga.With that out of the way, we can continue with the review. So, when we talk about shounen anime, this one falls into many typical stereotypes. Overall, I give the plot a 10/10, presentation 8/10, character depth 9/10, progression of story 5/10. This is one really good anime when it comes to plot/story, and character depth. Mostly it's presented in a light-hearted and funny way, but has some very dark times in the character developments. Most of the characters are lovable and mostly work together to improve among themselves, some in harsh ways, others openly competitive. If you watch the anime, just know that it can be frustrating at times to follow the developments, they will throw juicy morsels at you one episode, and then not follow it up til several episodes later. The romance aspect between the characters can be described as typical for a shounen story, but it doesn't end like most. Wouldn't want to spoil anything for you guys/gals. Action sequences are decent, but they never stop showing a bold type Japanese name of the spell's freeze frame, even for common spells that are used often which is why I say decent, or the action would be amazing. I hope this review helps and if you do watch it, I bet it'll be a new favorite for you guys too. I've been watching anime since the mid 1990's and this is in easily my top 10 now.

I'm reading the manga and when I found out about the anime I thought I'd give it a shot. At first Rokuro reminded me of Naruto with him being so loud and obnoxious but he grows up and is slightly calmer. Benio was the strong exterior/fragile mind complex going which was a good refresher since she came like that straight from the beginning. It was slow at times then at the end it felt rushed for the characters to get stronger which technically they didn't. All in all that anime is a good binge worthy show to keep you occupied. I hope in the future they will do this anime following the manga like how there was FMA and then later FMA:Brotherhood because the characters grow so much more and work so much harder. It would be nice to see that on screen.

*Possible Spoilers Ahead*Twin Star Exorcists is the epitome of your generic action/adventure shounen, stuffed full with every cliché in the book. Brooding protagonist with a  dark past? Check. Said protagonist wants to be the strongest [insert title]? Check. Constant flashbacks, ridiculously named magic/attacks/special moves, and yelling someone's name 50 times in an episode? Check, check, aaaand check. Seriously, it's all there. I partially expected this going in, and yet I will admit that I had an inkling of interest in the show. Throughout the first arc (episodes 1-20) the show held mild enjoyment for me; nothing exceptional, and it definitely had problems, but it had just enough intrigue and potential to make me click to the next episode. And then I keep watching, and oh boy was I in for a disappointment. TSE, in its race to rise above mediocrity, firmly face-plants into just-plain-bad for the remainder of it's 50-episode run, kicking up more glaring flaws than the MC can yell "YUTOOOOO." Plot/character threads left hanging, one-dimensional characters, inconsistent pacing, and deus ex machina galore (seriously, this show would have been so much shorter if the main cast wasn't constantly saved by inexplicable occurrences.) My biggest complaint though, is the sheer amount of forced emotion it tries to push onto the viewer; e.g. "Look, these characters are all crying, that means you need to be sad too!" It spends so much time reminding you to be sad, or angry, or happy for the young couple, that it itself completely forgets to give you a  reason to feel these emotions. "No, I'm not sad that this character 'died,' you never gave me a reason to care." "No, I don't care about the MC's romance, you never put effort in to make it believable." It was frankly embarrassing how often the plot would be sidelined so we can hear about what they're 'feeling' for several minutes. /rantOn the more technical side, the animation varies from average to sub-par, with re-used sequences during fights a very common occurrence. Music was okay; not bad, but largely forgettable. Not really much else to say, nothing exceptional to see here. tl;drFor a show running a full 50 episodes, it's quite simply just not worth the time investment. A wholly generic shounen that starts off 'okay,' but quickly devolves into a tedious slog that buries any small sparks of originality or entertainment that might still be there. Honestly, if the show had ended after the first arc, or was condensed into a 24-ish episode run, I might feel differently, but as it stands this is not a show I would recommend to any self-respecting anime fan.

I'm someone who reads the novel so I came into this show with bias. They skipped a lot of content, content that they could have easily made 3 episodes of and most of those content should have been damn good. Instead they rushed it so they can show off their precious toys. When I read the novel, it wasn't the mechs that enticed me, it was Ernesti's relationship with the people around him. Here it's obvious that they're putting mechs as the centerpiece. Because of how rushed it feels, it's hard to care about characters other than Ernesti. That said if you love mechs and magic, you might like this work, i'd still give it a go despite my first impressions.

This is quite original as it is unoriginal. What I mean is, this anime has taken basic scenario events for your stereotypical anime, and given it a kick boost.It's nothing very new, your basic main character fiasco with robots beating the living heck outta each other, but at the same time it's playing with a different idea.The first episode show the main character being good at something, dying and being reborn into another world with magic and robots while keeping his memories through his sheer desire and love for robots. Him and his friend's (sheer speculation at this point as only at the first episode) save the world and/or change it hugely.Though it is still very interesting as for some of it's own original pieces and how the story seems to be playing through. I very much so recommend this, and I cannot wait for the next episode

The first episode looked great to me, and it continues to keep my attention through the season.  There are points where it seems to be a little rushed, or could use more background details, but that is easy to look past.  This is an interesting combination of 2 ideas, where you take a person to be reborn into another world with magically driven mechas.  Naturally it helps a great deal that he is a genius and retains both his memories and obsession with mechas, but getting stuck in a child's body come with it's own limitations.  Add support of friends, and being born into the right family, and you have the beginnings of a great possibilities.A genius programmer mecha otaku has his life cut short by a car accident, and is filled with great regret over the models he will never get to build.  Finding himself reborn into another world of magic, mecha, and giant monsters he is instantly fascinated when his father saves him from an attack in his knight frame.  Combining genius and obsession with the goal of becoming a knight himself, we see the first episode fill in the growth required to start his path to greatness along with a new threat to the kingdom itself.  The growth and progress he shows are astounding, but not without setbacks.  His eternal optimism is contagious as he chases not only his dreams of an ideal mech of his own creation, but also preservation of the safety of his friends and kingdom.

I am a big fan of the manga and light novel so it is no surprise that I have found a new love in the anime adaption. While the plot may feel 'rushed' considering they compressed  a number of chapters from the manga/novel into one episode, that is by no means a downside. While the build up does not hold the same impact if you have read the manga or novel, the visuals and music definitely make up for it in spades.Speaking of making up for things, the first episode is definitely how you are SUPPOSED to introduce a new anime adaption, especially for those who are not familiar with the original material. Knight's & Magic is your typical 'present day individual transported to a world of high-fantasy' setting, however it implements giant robots/mecha which offers an interesting twist on the genre. If you are a fan of fantasy/magic and giant robots, Knight's & Magic is right up your alley. The only reason this anime falls short of five stars is because of how fast they introduced most of the plot and characters in a single episode. This is just personal preference due to the fact I have read the manga and novel, but does not take away in any fashion from the overall show. I look forward to seeing how they introduce the rest of the story and I can safely say that it is off to a good start. As this is the first episode, this review will be updated as more episodes are released.

Holy  BALLS, I love the magical mecha in this series. Let me get that out of the way first. If you want some mecha eyecandy, then look no further, for this series crammed with ornate designs and tiny bits genuinely interesting speculative magic-science regarding how they work.The elevator pitch for Knight's & Magic is fantastic: "Gifted programmer, and cog in a large corporate machine is transported to a world of magical mecha, huge monsters, and geopolitical intrigue where his knowledge could change the balance of power."Unfortunately the execution turns out to be "Fearless super genius, and cheerful sociopath Mary Sue character effortlessly wins at everything." There is actually a good story and interesting world hiding behind that hideously cloying facade, but you'll only ever catch glimpses of concepts that could have made an excellent and original series.Still... I made it through the first 10 episodes and keep coming back for more, so I guess it can't be that terrible? The story beats are generally good... it's just that the telling of them is abysmal.

So I started watching Anime in 1998. I remember when a good season meant :  One Piece, Naruto, Bleach, Code Geass, Death Note, Nana, Welcome to the NHK, Honey and CLover, Higarushi and Haruhi, Black Lagoon insert 100s better shows here.  I am a deeply cynical/pessimist about the state of Anime today. In My disappointment this  this the current state  and this is probably the most interesting anime i have seen on crunchy roll this season.This  series starts like Tanya Evil, the main character is Onada from Yowa Peda except he is 30 and a genius programmer. He gets hit by a car while buying is mecha toys and dies. He regrets all the gundam models he wont get obuild today, and in the future.  He is reincarnated with his memories to the Kingdom of Vision Escaflowne where he realizes he can live his dream of building magical girl robots.Okay t his isn't exactly accurate.  The story is a born again in a new-world  (opposed to be thrown into a new world)   with some twist. The guy reincarnated wits a a genius programmer and hard core gundam otaku. He dies in a car accident and wounds up reincarnated as a boy in a Kingdom where they use mechs equipped/powered with RPG magic to fight demons. Luckily his family is heavily invested in training mech pilots   which gives him a chance to achieve his life long dream of building his own unique Grandam.

This anime is as an excuse to show off great looking and very intricate mechas. The story just seems to be an after thought. Nothing bad ever seems to happen to the main characters. Anytime they're faced with a challenge, they always effortlessly overcome it. It's worth watching if you love mecha's and don't care about a dry story. I certainly enjoyed it for that aspect, but the lack of a good story is why I subtracted two stars.

CRUISE CONTROL IS ONDO YOU LIKE GUNDAMS?DO YOU LIKE MAGIC?DO YOU LIKE MONSTERS GETTING PWNED?HAVE YOU EVER WANTED TO WATCH GUNDAMS BEAT THE CRAP OUT OF MONSTERS?LET ME TELL YOU THIS IS THE ANIME FOR YOU!The series so far is everything I could've hoped for in an anime.
