They utilize time skips in a proper and well thought out manner. The pacing is somewhat fast but its really good so far. The artstyle, and music is awesome! The monsters are unique and interesting so far, and the main character has a unique spin. I love Gundam, and I love Magic, this show brought them both together and has literally made my 2017.ConsSide characters lack depth, feels bad man some are pretty interesting but you wont get much out of them.  (7 episodes in maybe it will change)There's a hell of alot more to the story you're missing. There's a lot of side story and other things going on that would be really cool to see in the show. It has an episode limit (im hoping for 50 but probably 25, if its 12 I am cry)

After watching many different types of anime, this is like a breath of fresh air.The anime is face paced and fun, as of  writing this review we are currently 7 episodes in and they have been a great 7 episodes so far!I love Eru's love for mechs and how he is able to control magic as he would programming.The character development is a little slow but great none the less.The animation is great and the overall story is pretty awesome!I look forward to watching this show every week!

I only got through five episodes because I just couldn't shake the feeling that nothing really matters in this world. It isn't super emotionally deep, which leads me to believe that I am supposed to enjoy this for the fun value. And a world where magic, mechas, and monsters exist definitely seems like a lot of fun. I didn't really have any fun though. I feel like the world is just shallow, and only the main character gives anything meaning. I'm all for a good power fantasy, but it is just like his achievements don't mean anything at all. The writers are definitely trying to convince me they are important through characters reacting with surprise, or talking about how unprecedented an accomplishment like this is, but we really aren't made to care about the results. Like, we don't really know any of the characters, the kingdom, even the main character has little personality beyond, "I like robots". Maybe if the robots and action scenes were great it would be fun on that level, but all the fights are pretty forgettable due to looking like every other mecha fight with no redeeming story components.If you really like Mecha and Fantasy, you might like this anime in spite of its flaws. The magic/tech systems are genuinely interesting but don't go in expecting much.

K&M's biggest sin is it makes me miss the series that use each part of it better.Reincarnation into a magical world: K&M could have done without it entirely, just letting Ernesti be a robot-loving genius. Done better in Tanya the Evil.Mecha in magical setting: K&M has them on such a high powerscale that nations don't field anyone not in a mecha. That's before Ernesti sets off DBZ-level power level increases. Done better in Escaflowne (series). Main character as center of female attention: Several eps in and only 2 waifus, neither really in it to win it. Done better in *list too extensive.*

Bolded text is tl;drThis anime is about magic and mechas, but it is also about engineering. The show stars Ernesti, a student at an academy that trains Silhouette Knights(mecha pilots). Ernesti himself is a coder reincarnated into this world. What I love most about the series is not the mecha fights (which are fun), or the magic (which I desperately wish I could know more about), but the sheer earnestness and joy of Ernesti and his team designing, iterating, and testing their new toys. Ernesti is more an engineer than a fighter (though he kicks butt), and as of Ep. 4 that has been the focus of the series. That said character development is not good so far, I couldn't tell you much about any of the characters besides Ernesti, and he lacks depth too. Also Exposition Lady, in which a Morgan Freeman style voiceover tells what just happened or explains some aspect of the world, is mildly infuriating if you already dislike exposition dumps. Luckily outside of the 1st episode she pops in quickly and mostly serves in a slightly less annoying capacity as a narrator. All that said, I love it. Ernesti's love of robots is infectious, it has enough action and plot to hold your attention, the magic is cool, the mechas and fight scenes are well done, and it's genuinely fun to watch. If you dislike Ernesti by the end of Ep. 2 you can can probably pass over this one, as he's definitely the main draw of the series.So why did I write this long review? Because it's my hobby. 8/10 would rebalance power/mana ratios again.

I'm going to echo what a lot of other folks have been saying here: this anime is lacking in character development but overall isn't bad. The MC is adorable in his reincarnation. Visuals are pretty, and the building your own mecha concept is decent. The problem is that I'm not really invested. I'm not sure I care what happens to any of the characters.There's also not much world-building here. I have no idea what the monsters are and why they attack humans. I don't have much of an idea about the society, except that it's some sort of kingdom ruled by a king. I don't know much about the magic that powers the robots except that there is magic.Basically, it's fluffy cute so far, without any real depth. All that said, pickings are a little slim this season, so I'll probably keep watching.

I love anime like this, it has a sort of clichéd but amusing concept. I found myself laughing in the first episode already, if you don't mind somewhat clichéd stories then this is for you trust me when I say it kinda grabs you. I cant wait for the next episodes. I like the fact he keeps his memories and can understand tech from the world he was in still! this show has a great potential!Edit1: episode 2 is drawing me in, its been awhile since ive seen this kind of story. its taking something so generic and making it into something so profoundly enjoyable and interesting, I haven't seen something this enjoyable in years. please let this be a 25 episode season and have 5 seasons, for the love of god this is good! I love the fact that he isn't to op either, he is susceptible to mana drain like everyone else in the story, just taking his old selves programming skills and using them on mechs gives him a massive advantage,. I like where this is going

Honestly, when I first saw this anime, I thought, "Wow! A reincarnation fantasy anime! Just want I needed." Although, when I started watching it, I noticed most of the entire anime was just... a person making a robot with stuff half the audience have no idea what are. I think it really depends on if this is the kind of anime for you. But if you expecting a fun really overpowered character like in "Wise Man's Grandchild," this isn't the kind of anime for you.   Also, they almost NEVER talk about the main character's reincarnation. If you are going to not talk about the mc dying and being reincarnated at all pretty much, what is the point of them getting reincarnated in the first place...? To make robots in this world more understandable? I really don't think you need that to make the robots understandable, it is a fantasy world, the audience would somewhat expect it.

This anime is something of a guilty pleasure for me. I hate it when there is tension, or conflict, or anything that makes me feel uncomfortable in a show or movie. I know. I have the tastes of a child. That's what I mean when I say it's too easy to watch. The protagonist is a genius engineer, tactician, and fighter. He faces hardly any setbacks, which means there's no character development. He's almost like Rick in Rick & Morty, except this is a mecha anime, not a nihilistic, sci-fi cartoon. The most character development we see is in Kid, Dietrich, and the princess.The plot itself is not terrible but I think it is fundamentally flawed in that there is no definitive end. What is our protagonist's goal? To make robots? He's already done that, so where does it end? The only hint at an overarching story we've had is when the elf queen referred to Ernie as the chosen one or something along those lines.What the show does have going for it is good animation, fight sequences, and pacing. The 3-D animation doesn't stick out like a sore thumb (cough cough Netiflix cough), and the action sequences are complex and exciting. The pacing is almost too fast, but that is much preferred to being drawn out. The show liberally uses time lapses which is completely fine by me. The result is two completed arcs in 13 episodes.

First, let's immediately point the elephant in the room. This anime is bound to be incomplete and to feel as lacking due to 2 important points :1) It's based on a Light Novel that isn't completed yet.2) It's skipping half of the content from the Light Novel, meaning some character are barely developed in the anime while they are really well described and constructed in the Light Novel.From this point, I would say the Manga is a LOT more better at explaining and showing the story from the Light Novel's content.Due to this, the story, design and characters will feel cheap and simple. It makes the series suffers from some really bad case of time skipping. (Think of it as if each episode of 20 minutes covers 2-3 months of in-story content.) At best, you could consider this anime as a summary of the Light Novel.Still, the visual quality and sounds are really good and, if considering it alone, it's still fun to watch. If I could, I would give it a 3.5/5, but I wouldn't give it 4/5, hence the 3 stars. If you start watching this, don't think you'll have a quality story like Escaflowne or Code Geass. The visual is on par, but not the adapted script.

It's cheesy the Main Character is a Marty Stu who looks like Mary. It's glorious while attempting to follow the Mech, D&D, MC reborn in a new reality after dying in Modern Day Tokyo, and harem troupes. The art direction, and timing make the show 100% fresh while making sure to hit every predictable troupe ever. It deserves it's 5 star ratings, not only for being fun, and entertaining, but this one will be a fan favorite for years.p.s. if you want 100% original content. This one technically fails, while being brilliant in it's originality.p.s.2. Oh and if you enjoy this, read the Light Novel it's based on. It's even better.

I have been a fan of the Mecha genre of anime for some time. I have to say this anime presents it in an interesting light by using the transported to another world trope after death and the mechanical side is interesting and I have enjoyed the action sequences and the idea that magic is based on a programming language.However having read the light novel and the manga I feel like they have skipped several major plot points and in some areas, it feels rushed.Overall I think it is generally a good anime.

Too often I feel people give things bad reviews because something isn't original. People say this has been done before or the concept is the same. I personally don't think there is anything wrong with that. I mean at this point in time everything was inspired by something else right. Overall I would give it a solid 4 simply because its still in its infancy. Before the end though I imagine it be be an 5 or beyond That being said I think this mecha anime is awesome. Essentially transferring one person's mind to a different world, but having lost none of his genius. So far its only a few episodes in, but I think this show has so much potential. The very idea behind that concept of creating new new units, you can go anywhere from there. Combine other ideas from other mech shows. I think this show is only limited by the creators imagination. Just like in the show, if you can dream it you can make it. Only episode 6 was just released, but this could be a top notch show.

The premise combines several otherwise cliche elements into something unique; a genius programmer is reincarnated into a world where magic is "programmed" and can power giant mechs.  All have been done before, but this show intelligently combines them into something that's instantly engaging.  Personally, I love the fact that it spends so much time on building the mechs, offering a glimpse of some deep world-building.The animation and art are mostly fantastic.  The fight scenes are very well done.  The mechs and the monsters are highly detailed.  The main characters look pretty good, but you can tell a side character just by the lower quality.  In a show where the Mechs are clearly the focus, the good definitely far outweighs the bad.Three episodes in, the plot is still coming into focus.  It starts innocent, man vs monster, but there are hints of something darker on the horizon.  Creating stronger weapons will help the humans (and dwarfs) stand against the monsters, but what happens when they're turned against their creators?  Other reviews point out that the anime skips through a more detailed set-up available through the manga, but focusing purely on the show, it does a very acceptable job of introducing the world and putting the plot into motion.  It is also worth pointing out that there are a few bits of narrated exposition that are a bit jarring next to how engaging the rest of the show is.  Once again, the good far outweighs the bad and I'm very eager to see how it develops!On the weaker side of things, the characters are so far a little simplistic.  The only character that really stands out is the main character, in good and bad ways.  Ernesti is a little too capable, "good", and has no backstory worth mentioning.  However, accepting the original premise, his enthusiasm carries the scenes of dialogue.  As the darker elements of the plot come into focus, we'll hopefully be introduced to some villains and to more grey areas of the current characters.Strengths:-Fantastic premise and world, taking a handful of otherwise cliche elements and creating something interesting-Great looking mechs, monster(s), and action scenes-Three episodes in, interesting hints of a deeper plot and intrigue-A mecha fan's dream medieval fantasy world-Very little fan-service (knock on wood)Cons:-Character animation simplistic compared to the mechs and monsters-Characters are weak, so far

Its funny, I didnt read any other reviews, and I was also going to say character development felt rushed. However:This protagonist is a damn fine character. He is just FUN. His genuine enthusiasm comes across very well and you can feel how he connects to the people around him. I like shows like this quite a bit. Things like Aldaramin in the sky, or sports shows for the same reason, especially ones like days and yowamushi pedal, where the protagonist has a strong positive effect on those around him. That said, you can feel the jags in the  plot. Especially how they just say "oh by the way these 2 guys are his best friends" If you are like me you will say "Wait wut?" and wonder how exactly that happened. But, I can forgive that because you get that same chance at those same kinds of feelings from how he builds his team. However if it leads to this show not having enough material to go past 1 or 2 seasons thats going to be a shame."Central Genius" Shows arent new, but they seem to be doing quite a nice job with this one at episode 3 and hopefully it will continue to build to a strong season end.

The first episode did a very good job of hooking my attention.  It's fast paced but does an excellent job of introducing our basic characters while at the same time giving us the history of our protagonist(s).  It's a little generic in the sense that our main character is reincarnated into an alternate universe but it has a unique take on it.  I'm very excited to see where this goes.  Especially after we've caught up to the character's "real" time and the main plot unfolds.

This review so far is just for the first episode. I'm not like a huge mecha fan (not saying I don't like it, I'm just not hardcore about it or anything) but this show has really caught my interest, especially with the fantasy elements that are mixed in with it. The first episode throws a lot at you very quickly, with information and backstory that might normally take an anime 1-2 episodes to explain before getting to the core storyline. Despite that I didn't find myself lost or left behind, only wanting more by the end. If it keeps up, this show could be one of my favorites this season!EDIT (SPOILERS)So now, after 6 episodes, my opinion has changed somewhat. While I like how fastpaced the first episode was, it didn't really keep it up for the rest of the episodes so far. One thing I especially don't care for is the fact that they have not mentioned Ernie's past life or reincarnation once since the beginning. It seems like it was just used as an excuse to explain his unusually high intelligence and love for giant piloted robots, which doesn't even really need a reason beyond: this character was born especially smart and interested in mecha. Like, why even go to the trouble of showing the backstory of some nerd who died and was reincarnated in a world with giant robots if it's the last time it's going to come up? Maybe it'll impact the story later on, who knows, but for now it was completely pointless.This is by no means a BAD show imo, it's entertaining and cool I guess if you also are super into mecha, which is why I still rate it 3 stars. But the characters are all pretty flat with no development so far, except maybe one or two side characters. I'll most likely watch it through to the end, but I'm sad to say that after the 1st episode it hasn't really made an impact on me.

i love this kids fascination with robots and at first i thought it was maybe a little silly or lame but it quickly grew on me. i honestly think this is one of the best anime stories i've seen yet, and it seems to hold a special place all of it's own. the cat and mouse games and the strategy the main character has to keep coming up with is fun as well..... i hope this gets another season & continues to remain at this quality level.

Some of the anime details are not the same as the manga. It's also more rushed and details are left out. There are some important details like how hard the main character has trained to become as powerful as he is. The manga also does not begin with the mc's life in danger. Instead the mc is depressed about the fact in this new world he couldn't make models anymore. There are many other things that are not the same at all. They could have put more effort to make it more like the manga. The anime is overall rushed and inaccurate.

This is a hard one to rate as there's a lot of great things but also some holes so I'll start with saying my 4 stars come from a mecha fan.This in an isekai technomagic mecha fantasy which is exactly as much as it sounds like but it mostly pulls it off; my only real issue is it doesn't do much of anything with the isekai and it'd likely be better without it. It's really just there as as fanservice that only goes as far as half remembered dreams of mecha model-kit boxes with no real nods to great mechas or series of the past and it's better to pretend they aren't cannon and treat the main character as a prodigy since he has knowledge from the other world but not his memories and its sets up his awe of mecha in a way that doesn't require his fanboy qualities to carry over into the next life.That said both the technomagic system and world are interesting and with a season 2 happening we'll see more of the world, the mechas look great and the fights are fun to watch though the side character's battles feel more weighty than the main character's after his debut. Reminiscent of Grancrest War in a way with a smaller cast who get more screentime. Worth watching and a must watch if you like mecha.

Me finishing this drama is a big step because I am absolutely not a fan of mecha but I loved the characters especially the eccentric cutie I also loved how there wasn't the unreasonable jealous rival within the school (I'm sorry but they get annoying). The thing I didn't like is that the story is very rushed. They are many many times in this drama where they could have slowed down the storyboard to paint a more complete picture. Instead, it looks like they were trying to show as much as possible while fitting it in these few episodes. I think they need to remake this but pace it.

If you are looking for a overpowered main character and have nothing against mechs i recommend this show to you. I myself dont like mech anime that much but i was enjoying this one the whole time. However it sometimes come off as rushed and suffers from little to no character development. most of the people you see remain static and just hangs around. The show pokes at some of the relationships and hints at love but nothing interesting happens on that front.

As good as this anime is, it can't be anything but  okay at best. The story is like every other anime where the main character gets transported to another world and begins to make it his/her bitch. The action is amazing if I do say so myself, that coming from a guy who really doesn't enjoy gundam anime. The ending isn't satisfying at all, it leaves a lot of questions to be answered for the soul purpose of getting viewers to read the manga. It seems like it was cash grab that was cared about to an extent, but overall didn't matter to the author as long as it got people to pick up his manga. It's a good anime to watch if you wanna kill time, but I wouldn't get too into it since you'll ultimately feel let down by the end.

This is an unbiased review based purely on my large amount of experience from watching many Animes (over 700), without knowing the source of this or where it came from.It is therefore purely based on watching this Anime by itself and in its entirety alone.I don't have the habit to watch Mecha Animes but as a friend recommended this Anime to me I gave it a run and was I really surprised at the quality it was made with.It has many likeable characters which have their own issues and over time overcome em too, they grow as people and learn, and adapt to the environment and situation they find themselves in.Personally, I love the characters in it! I especially love the main character, his closest female friend and the Princess of a country which will be shown later for those that didn't watch this yet.The story was surprisingly realistic for a fantasy genre and had a really smart pacing of the story in which it has shown the most relevant parts to the story in the right times and the right way.In compare with other Animes this Anime, in my personal opinion, has done the story and characters in the right way. Nothing was too much, there were insinuations which you need to figure out yourself too, which contributed for it being more realistic, nothing was given fully on the plate which I find would be a mistake, to reveal too much at a time I mean or not let the viewers figure things out on their own.I literally did forget that this anime was an Isekai (Another World) genre, it has never brought that to your attention, especially not by force as if it lacked any confidence. On the contrary, this Anime went full on with confidence and was truly like an adventure, an adventure of innovation and passion!Watching this Anime really filled me with inspiration, with passion and emotional strength I didn't know I could feel. It made me feel excited for life and the possibility it offers, it has the ability to show doors that you didn't see there before. This Anime has the ability to touch your heart in a way only this Anime can do.This Anime has a very positive and lightweight feel and it fills your heart with light, which may or may not touch it and show you a new perspective in life. Of course, if you open yourself to it and let it touch you, embrace it with what it has to offer to you.I saw allot of potential and I've opened myself to it, it has touched me in a special way and filled me with light and I hope it will do the same to you too!I personally love it and it is one of my most favorite now, I am really happy I got to watch such a well-done story in this form!For this reason, I truly recommend this Anime for everyone and for all-ages, it is truly remarkable and special in its own way!

come to be entertained by very cool giant robots battling each other and giant monsters. this isn't meant to change your life or blow your mind. that doesn't mean its stupid though or that you have to lower your expectations. i got exactly what i was expecting and was very satisfied. honestly better than a lot of Gundam anime. as original as aldnoah zero. story is fine. just dont think about it too hard. go with it.

The Good:The show is gorgeous, visuals are always nice and the animation never seems to falter. Mech eye-candy if you will. But this is where the good just about ends.The Bad:The story is as bare bones as it can get. The main reason the conflict of this show seems to exist is so that people can show off how strong the main character's mechs are. There's little to no character development at all since the main character just seems to get everything they want. There's no struggle.After six episodes there are two female characters that absolutely love the main character for no reason at all. Making it feel like they are just there to swoon over the main character and nothing else. All the other characters are in constant awe of the main character as well. I don't feel any sense of tension or development while watching. Everything is far to obviously going to work out, which makes the story feel lazy. I wish I could have finished this show to give it a more full review but I was struggling far too much to continue watching. If you love big mechs with over the top fights and don't care too much about anything else give this show a go, otherwise you're going to be bored.

Knights and magic isn't really special, but to me it's a lot of what I've wanted from an anime since i was young. Cool robots, good animation and action with said robots, a colorful tone that (usually) doesn't take itself too seriously, yet takes itself seriously enough to not be a kid show, fun characters, and a fantasy setting with mecha. Only problems i had with the show were that the pacing feels too fast at times and the main character was a little too over powered at times (also i was confused about if he had the mind of a 30 year old dude, or only remembered that he liked mecha model kits) also i think the show is to short. I really don't get why some people hate this show or think it's bad, I do think it's not for everyone though, if you are looking for a super serious war story like mobile suit gundam, or an over the top mecha with a hot-blooded protagonist like getter robo, you won't find those, what you find here is a mecha  that's kinda unique in it's own way, machines and magic coming together is something i love a lot and i do understand it isn't for everyone, but i certainly love it and can't wait for season

The tag line for this anime had me hook line and sinker. And then the fact that the show actually explored and used it had me finishing and wanting more.Only problem is that the story telling mechanics are embarrassing. Interesting interpersonal developments and political intrigue are glossed over in exposition dumps, IN THE MIDDLE OF THE EPISODE, and you never get the sense that the main characters are actually in any danger of failure. That being said, the rare instance where we know everything will be okay, but not HOW are really well done and it is exciting to see Ernesti cracking codes and problems that no one else even thought to solve, with little more than his wits and broken mechs. Sadly those examples stop after he instantly gets infinite resources and unconditional governmental support.TL; DR: Five star concept, two star execution. Could have used a bit more George R.R. Martin influence.

I loved the first half of it. But was rushed like those who read the manga, or was it a novel, say but I dont think its too bad. I found it funny and lighthearted... Second part ... I just hated that princess. You will know which one when she comes out even when she was" redeemed " just no. I never wanted to slap someone soo much before. I also didnt get how the character switch from caring about school to forget it lets fight this war. Did I miss that he and his friends graduated way early or something? Some things were just rushed.

First, I will say that it was rushed. And that's why i give it a 4 star. I would have loved to watch more episodes of the in-between stuff that the novels offer but I guess they might have not had the budget to do so. I slowly been easing my way back into mecha anime. I find its really easy to understand, not feel lost in, and greatly enjoy. (I usually felt alot of pressure to try to understand mecha anime series that had too much going on) I really love fantasy as well so its a two and one for me. I recommend you give it a try. <3

I understand some reviewers had dislike the story-line but they design a very good setting.I never read the manga but I do agree it mostly to promote model kits and toys.I did enjoy watching the anime for what its worth it was a very good Mecha action anime with magic. Story A young Japanese man who is a programmer and model kit enthusiast dies in a car accident.He is reincarnated as a child in an alternate world where magic and giant robots exist the name of the child is Ernesti Echevarria who has a dreams to ride giant robots called Silhouette Knights and Build them.First had to study magic which he advanced very well when he enter the Knight school and later became a prodigy. In a Knights training mission he manage to defeat a giant demon monster that attacked which he hijack a Silhouette Knight fromone of the pilots who ran in fear of the giant monster and defeated the monster and became a hero. I notice this anime has a lot of hidden references and easter eggs from other Mecha anime shows I watch in the past trying to tell a story you be surprise are in the anime.  AnimationThis is been made by 8-Bit Studios they have been know to help make anime's like  Infinite Stratos, and  Aquarion Evol with their style mixture of 3D and 2D Animation similar to Gonzo style Animation. I have to admit they did a decent job of making 3D and 2D balance in this anime to make it look smooth and simple. Sound Effects and Music They manage to get Masato Koda who is the music composer for this show for those that don't know he was video game music composer formerly employed by Capcom a long time ago best known for his work on the Devil May Cry and Monster Hunter series who did a good job of creating decent sound track for the anime. The sound effects sync very well with the Magic and Mecha.   The opening songs fhána the song  / Hello!My World!!  and the ending Ayaka Ohashi  the song - You & I  did alright job for the show. OverallThis Anime is very action packed if your into Mecha this is the anime for you, its not the best for character development if you want a good story but it has a interesting setting I did like.

As someone who has been keeping up with the slow manga adaptation of the novel I was pretty hyped this was getting an anime. I really enjoyed the story and how even though it's got mechs and magic it is more interested in giving it's characters time to shine and grow instead of being all about high paced action especially at the start.Then I watched the first episode which butchered something like the first 10-12 chapters of the manga into what looks like an all out action-mech like mess of garbage that just looks not terrible and sounds good. I now understand what it's like to get cat fished.

I agree with a lot of the reviewers, the anime was a little of a rush.But I would most definitely say that it's an anime worth watching if you're just looking for a good time. Negative stress free.I loved the main characters personality, his drive, as well as his ability to win people over. None the less the hidden humor in everything was great as well. Giving some form of relief in all of the action that this anime packs. The thought process the characters go through is also pretty unique. It queues you into his thoughts as well as gives you a different perspective of him.All in all this is a well rounded anime in which I would recommend. Especially to those who are just getting into anime.

This started out so well. It seemed a new take on an old premise, and I thought there would be more involved with the protagonist being both aware of and taking advantage of his new  life. It started well! But the character development stalled in the face of fights with new characters, new mechs that just seemed introduced out of thin air, with thin veneers of backstory, and too often removed all too quickly from the storyline. Perhaps a longer or 2nd season could have helped in the characterization and world-building, but by 2/3 of the way, I was just watching with little interest, hoping the story would improve, that the characters would get more fleshed out, that the world-building would amount to something. Nope. Spend your time elsewhere...

This anime does deserve all 5 stars. I wish they'd make another 2 or 3 seasons of it. Or for those who hate seasons they can just call it "another story". The audience of the Crunchy Roll is tilted towards anime overwhelmed with fight and action, but I think this anime has an awesome balance of story and action. Some may say the main hero had not enough challenges, but that's also what I like in it. Less struggles more smiles and yet Knights, Magic, Robots.

The other worldy aspect is tacked on and absolutely pointless. They could have just skipped the entire intro aspects and simply had the MC be a super genius since that is basically all he is. Despite the cliche moments all through out, the high impact energy actually makes for a really endearing production. Furthermore it has an opening that changes multiple times over the course of the show which for such a small thing, helped hype me up as it really showed the progress of the show.

Its always great to see a mecha show where the pilots like what they do and were fighting for a great cause. Ernesti Echevalier is how all mecha pilots should be, full of enthusiasm and the ability to not get depressed by the situation. All the characters in this were great including the bad guys. Great mecha design and animation. Its shortness allows the story to move along at a great pace. Plenty of action!! This get a full recommendation from me!!

First, let me get my rating criteria out of the way. For me, one star means the show is so atrocious I lose brain cells trying to wrap my mind around it, and it should be disposed of in the dust bin of history never to be seen again. Two stars means the show is so bad that it needs a complete rewrite, but the premise is at least deserving of that rewrite. Three stars means the show is mediocre and you can take or leave it, but it's not so bad it needs to be rewritten. Four stars means the show is actually very good, but is lacking one or more special "X" factors that would push it over the top. Finally, a five star show is one of those rare gems that's so amazing it literally helps define a generation of viewership whether individual viewers personally like it or not.Knight's & Magic is a tenuous 4. On the plus side the characters are amusing, the graphics are solid, the BGM and sound effects are respectable, the premise is neatly packaged, and the main draw of the story (all the mecha) is outlandish enough to be cool without becoming patently ridiculous. On the downside the characters are a little tropey, mixing cel-shading with 3d graphics doesn't always work (albeit, in this case, it worked most of the time), the SFX were recognizably canned imports (yes, all SFX are mostly canned imports, but does every reptilian kaiju have to have a remix of Godzilla's contrabass-with-a-resin-glove roar?), the plot feels rushed (although, reading the LN's, I must admit that every major plot point was hit with a bullseye and every time skip comes straight out of the author's hands), and the mecha designs look too futuristic for a medieval D&D world (though that's mostly thanks to the 3d rendering).In the end the pros outweighed the cons, resulting in a respectable 13 episode anime series that tells a complete story worth a watch (and even a re-watch or two), but the cons are still heavy enough to keep Knight's & Magic from five stars of glory.

There is plenty of material here. In fact, there is far too much. This show feels as if it was planned for being 48 episodes and someone came in and ordered them to shove it into 13. This show takes the prize for having the absolute worst pacing I have ever seen. Some episodes have 4 or 5 distinct segments that each should have warranted their own episode. There are even points in the (well animated and interesting) action scenes that feel like you are watching it in fast forward! The degree to which this show is rushed and badly paced means none of the characters have anything resembling competent character development, the world building is the absolute bare minimum and there are incredibly abrupt time skips despite the character aging not at all throughout the show. Finally FAR FAR too much of the show is simply explained by a narrator.All that said, with some many complaints, why even 2 stars? Because despite all the above problems we still have a decent-ish fantasy - mecha anime hybrid that was quite fun to watch. There is enough material there that you can tell what they were going for and what they wanted to do - and those goals are good enough to make this show still watchable. Pros:Fun actionCool ideasMecha and Fantasy togetherCos:Literally the worst pacing I have ever seenSuper rushed - should have slowed down and been much longer.ZERO character development. Everyone in this show is little more than a cliche or a stereotype.

Its a really generic power fantasy with blank character work and animation to match. on the upside the color palate hits some high notes and the designs of the mechs are only held back by the cg animation that is supposed to bring them to life.There is no reason to watch this, unless you have finished your backlog and really want a mech series with no regard of important elements that make a good narrative.

This anime is basic.If you want Mech in a fantasy world where the story has no fangs this is the anime for you. Minimal character development saved by fantastic art and fun technology progression. If this is your first run into the mech genre and you would like more. I suggest Esclaflowne which is fantastic or the first season of Iron blooded orphans (If you are happy with how season one ends stop there).

Listen. I enjoyed the show as a whole. Let's just get that out of the way. It was really fun and had some good parts to it, however I did have quite a few problems with it. My biggest problem is that the pacing is really weird. Everything just feels very rushed, and to me it seemed like I didn't really know what the plot of the show was going to be until like halfway through. There are some good fight scenes in here, but a lot of them feel VERY anticlimactic, especially with some of the bigger villains. The magic system is never really talked about other than the fireball spell and the air spell, which is kind of a problem because it's half of the title. There's also little problems I have like them introducing too many characters that never get developed, no one ever ages beyond the initial time skip, by the end I honestly couldn't remember who some of the bad guys were, and halfway through they start adding sound effects to the OP and it's really annoying and jarring which sucks because I loved the song. I know I just listed a lot of negatives but honestly overall it was an enjoyable show if you don't want something too deep or thought-provoking. The soundtrack was pretty great, and the mech animations were pretty cool honestly. It was a fun watch but I wouldn't recommend it unless you ABSOLUTELY love the genre or just want a time sink. (Also he appears in the kid's body when he's already a few years old... so what happened to Ernesti's original consciousness????)

Love the concept dislike everything else . . . Characters are dull and boring (including the MC), story development is sporadic, MC's powers don't even make sense(he was a programmer that built toy Gundam as a hobby, so therefore he can build thing that shouldn't be possible for humans to comprehend because it would take to long? learns in 3 months? then there is the stupid jolting lines some characters say that just make you go what? "is this a prelude to war" finally the narration please stop

Its very upbeat show. About a genius kid (5yrs old?) who is fascinated in the mechs that in habit his world. His name is Ernesti and his dream is to create his very own. Learning all he can about the magic at this school which powers most technology in his world.       He already has caught the eye of the king cause of his I.Q. and innovation in inventing things. If he could make a revolutionary mech which hasnt advanced in tech in 300 years. The king will aid Ernest in his goal if he is able to wow him with mech he has never seen before. Thus thats where its starts off.      The battle scenes is highlight of the anime. Making very cool planned out battles and they last very long. Great special effects. The show as well is animated very good and immerses you further in the story.      The kind Ernesti is very adorable as well. Very enthusiastic about goals. Most people mistake him for girl at 1st cause of his appearance. You cant help but root for him all the time cause even when I was little I had a big fascination with mechs as well so I can relate. (watched the 1st terminator when i was litttle.)          His VA really matches his said appearance. VAs in general never feel out of place in this anime.      My only gripe of this show is the mechs are all 3d. If you ever watch a show called gundam seed which has hand drawn mechs. In Gundam Seed the mechs are animated quite wonderfully. You would gladly agree if seen it.

A really cool idea with a interesting protagonist! But the ease with which he accomplishes his goals makes the entire story feel like there's no real conflict. At several points, it feels as if there's about to be conflict, but nothing serious ever comes of it, even when a main antagonist is introduced. Great idea, cool visuals, but every character is one dimensional and uninteresting except for the protagonist.

Characters each have their own little quirks but no real character development aside from dietrich (even then, his character development was miniscule). The show does bring some interesting ideas with the robots in a fantasy world. The MC is the typical dense protagonist that isn't interested in love and is only interested in his obsession (Robots in this case). I feel like the MC is a psychopath, he completely forgets his past life and doesn't hesitate in heading into danger. I also feel like the writer did NOT mean for the main character to be like this... It just suffers from poor writing.The side characters aren't any better, as they only serve to support the MC. I feel like some of the characters that have died and the older generation of the cast are the more interesting characters. A lot of stuff bothered me, in particular the forced drama in episode 9 that tries to make you care for characters you barely know. Overall, it's a fun show to watch, especially if you enjoy mechas. The mecha here have some cool designs (though there are better) and the concept is pretty creative. Don't watch it if you're looking for a shounen with deep characters and a layered story like FMA:B or HxH. This is just general wish fulfillment. Average show to watch while playing a game or working on something. I wish I can give it a 2.5 but since i can't, i just rounded it up.

I wanted to like this show, I really did. Crunchyroll got basically no good anime this season, so I was really hoping this would get better with time, instead of worse. The setting and the plot itself are not the problem, and the art style is clean and looks nice. The setting is pretty typical for a "journey in another world" setting. Some random programmer who happens to be a giant robot nerd dies and is reborn in another world. Honestly, if they cut the first few minutes of the show and didn't even give us that information it would have made absolutely no difference to the story going forward. But the nice art style is failed by poor animation quality. Lots of static scenes of characters sitting around tables explaining things. Almost every single episode has at least one if not more scenes where the whole cast sits around a table and talk for a few minutes at a time. My explanation for my rating is somewhat long and spoiler heavy, so I'll just give a brief summary up front before going in deep.This is what it really breaks down to:-The writer does not maintain consistency of his world elements. A lot of the things that are explained turn out to have almost no consistency in the world just a couple episodes later. -Characters are incredibly flat. They can almost all be summarized with a few words, and have little personality beyond what can be understood in the first 2 minutes of their introduction. We can only assume that this is to cut down on character development scenes and focus on the awesome action sequences of giant robots fighting things, except...-The fight scenes are not very well animated. They are not fluid, and are barely interesting most of the time. Aesthetically the art style is nice to look at, and I'm sure the manga they ripped frame by frame to make this show looks great. But when the main appeal of your anime is great big fight scenes and scarce else, you better make absolutely certain that your fight scenes look and feel amazing. I'll give some more specifics under the spoilers.Spoiler Alert! Click to show or hideSo basically we are introduced to a world where these great big robots are powered by a special engine called an ether reactor. Ernie, being the giant robot nerd that he is, wants to build his own robot. Which apparently he can't do because humans can't use the magic that is used to create them. Because only the Alfs can make these reactors, and they live in a tiny isolated village and are regarded as a national asset akin to nuclear weapons, aether reactors are really scarce and giant robot design has stagnated for 500 years. This is explained over the course of several episodes. The episode after they finish establishing how difficult it is to innovate these robots, the evil empire is introduced. They have successfully stolen an unfinished and buggy prototype robot from our MC Ernie. But when they are introduced they have not only successfully reverse engineered this revolutionary new design, they have managed to either build new or retrofit thousands of these new mechs practically overnight. So basically, everything the first 8 episodes or so established is totally blasted into pieces by the 9th episode. There is so many things wrong with this that it is a challenge to list them all. -First, the alfs are apparently a very rare race and are the only ones who can make aether reactors, which require very rare materials. Even if they wanted to make more reactors, they wouldn't necessarily be able to because of lack of material. So where does the Zaloudork (ok that's not its real name but I started calling it that in my head and I can't remember what it was called in the first place) Empire get all of its aether reactors? An empire that had apparently previously fallen from glory somehow managed to hold on to, craft, or otherwise acquire thousands of reactors that are so top secret and so precious that even the kings of some countries would have difficulty acquiring just one of them, can make these things like toyota corollas? What is this?-Second, we know for a fact that the model of mech stolen by the Zaloudork Empire was a prototype with a lot of problems, and was also the most revolutionary design ever seen since giant robots were first created. Setting aside how the Zaloudorks managed to get a hold of thousands and thousands of aether reactors, how in the world did they manage to reverse engineer, perfect, and retrofit or build all those new robots in almost no time at all? Unless I blinked and missed it, there was 2 time jumps in the storyline. The first was from when the reincarnated Ernie meets a robot for the first time to when he enters the academy, then again between him planning a prototype for the king and it being stolen. There is almost no time gap between it being stolen and the massive global offensive performed by the new-type mechs of the Zaloudork Empire. And since this whole attack was apparently a sneak attack that overran most of the neighboring countries in short order, there is no way they could have done something drastic like hiring massive numbers of workers to retool all those mechs in the span of a few months. Unless the spy agencies of the other kingdoms are utterly incompetent there is no way such a massive mobilization would have been pulled off.   Ok, forget the Zaloudork Empire's means of production. Let's talk about something specific to episode 9 and not even concerning the over-world inconsistencies I noted before. Let's talk about when Ernie overruns the Zaloudork outpost all by himself. So first of all, that fight scene was really lame in a lot of ways starting with weak animation, but it sets a precedent. Ernie's mech is unbelievably overpowered. It chops up the other new-type mechs guarding the outpost like fish on a chopping block. He is leading his supporting cast to infiltrate the Zaloudork occupied kingdom and save a princess. Reports of his party traveling towards the capitol are spread ahead and so the bad guys send an idiot of a miniboss to go try them out. This miniboss has a short fight with the supporting cast and then flies away in an airship to escape. The big question is, since Ernie and everyone are traveling together, and Ernie's giant overpowered mech is being pulled along with everyone... did he step out to take a piss and take his OP FLYING robot with him conveniently allowing the annoying miniboss to fly off? Where was Ernie during this whole last fight scene? Setting aside the fact that the miniboss himself was really lame and probably should have just met a horrible end on the spot, why didn't Ernie show up AT ALL for this fight when he is literally right there traveling with the convoy. If Ernie had shown up he could have chopped up all the enemy mechs and the miniboss in short order. Such blatant plot armor for an expendable character is just too much for me to take. Refer to Willing Suspension of Disbelief on tv tropes if you don't get where I'm coming from.   Overall it gets 1 star for being a vaguely different twist on giant robots and 1 star for having nice art. Everything else about this show is disappointing.

Knight's & Magic - the grammar in the title is killing me to type. Henceforth, I shall be referring to this show as K&M. Whoever named it clearly didn't speak great English.You'd think the creators chose the genres at random. Fantasy, magic and mechs together aren't the first thing that would come to mind when you think typical. But that's precisely what it is; the blandest, most generic fantasy concept, mixed with the blandest, most generic mechs. Add a supposedly school-like back drop and some fraternal twin sidekicks, and there you have it. Honestly, the scenario sounds more interesting than it should, but what K&M lacks is execution.The core of the issue is the writers trying to cram too much story into 13 episodes. The pacing is awful. It lacks the essential, "show instead of tell," element we see in anything remotely good. As a matter of fact, they should have scrapped the narration entirely. It feels like I'm reading a fantasy picture book that's trying to be as dry as non-fiction. K&M relies too much on the main protagonist and the pretty colours. Everyone else might as well be as personable as stage props.For me, the only saving grace it has is Erne himself. He's so bubbly, and enthusiastic, and sparkly you can't not dislike him. My favourite scene was that one in the first episode, where the teacher turns around to find student half the size - and age - as the rest, staring back with eyes so bright and eager to learn. But too much time is spent on him, and we learn next to nothing about anyone else.Unfortunately, the potential is wasted. It's a shame, but it's an illness we see all too often. Is my life richer after viewing? No. Would I go out of my way to see it if it weren't conveniently airing at this moment? No. Is K&M recommended to the reader? Not particularly, but if you have nothing better to do, it's not so bad you'll regret searing it into your retinas.

Its an original idea and I like the concept a lot, its just so rushed that I'm not even sure how much time has passed in the span of 10 episodes. Maybe 3 years? There's no tension, One project is started and completed in the span of an episode when it takes months to complete it in their time.  Honestly could have been a very good show, and I was pretty stoked after the first episode, now its just taxing.

I have seen the first nine episodes, hoping that the show would correct the major issues and become what I hoped it would be, but have given up hope.  The major issues I have with the show is 1.Pacing – limited world building, underlying story seems to be “let’s get to the next mecha battle as fast as we can!) Story lines that start up and then are dropped without explanation.2.Lead protagonist issues – inappropriate laughter (I guess trying to show his love of mecha), verbalizing obvious statements,  no connection with back story of Japanese mecha fan other than desire to ride mecha, basically declaring war with no hesitation.  etc...3.Story/narration - narrator foreshadowing something 15 seconds before it occurs, no respect for audience ability to see what is happening, instead it feels the need to state the obvious via character lines.  Size mismatch between original operators and lead, but cabin readjust for his size even though a big deal is made about him not being tall enough to operate.  And last but not least, Airships that are a total surprise, but look like the end results of years of advancements… you would expect craft able to carry just one mecha, not the equivalent of aircraft carriers!4.Animation.. does the moe pretty well, battle shows cuts through where the riders are in a mecha in an obviously fatal strike then later you see people crawling out of the suit unharmed ala A Team.

Like the title with the grammatically incorrect placement of an apostrophe; Knight's & Magic isn't generally concerned with the little things. . . until it's ready to zoom in to the smallest detail. Most of the narrative is told through a narrator informing us that a lot of time has passed since the last scene, and lots of boring, but important stuff has happened. Between narrative exposition, we get scenes focused in on specific critical moments. Most anime and television does this to a certain degree (we typically don't have to sit through our MC taking a dump or brushing his teeth, for example) but Knight's & Magic takes this to Nth degree and somehow makes it work. And of course, Knight's and Magic is trying to be All the Anime. It's a magical, medieval fantasy with knights; kings; grumpy, arrogant, elder advisors; princes; princesses; elves; and demonic monsters. It's a Giant robot adventure that deep dives into the details and engineering of Mechs. It's an everyman awakens in a fantasy world. It's a story about a boy genius who gleefully pursues his hobbies and radically alters the world as a result. It's a military drama with strategy and spy-craft. It's a story about a small group of friends led by an amazingly talented leader rising up and taking on a destiny greater than they could have ever imagined. It's 8 episodes in and the world is fast becoming more fully developed than many stories with hundreds of episodes. It manages to pull all of this off without being terrible, but actually being pretty entertaining. Yes, it certainly feels rushed and I'm sure that a lot of us would love to see this world unfold over a few hundred episodes. . . but this is clearly a 13 to 28 episode series - as is 98% of Anime - and while we might be getting the cliff's notes version of the story, at least we're getting the whole story instead of just the prelude.

So I would recommend not watching the last two episodes, not because we tragically lose characters or anything.  Just because they're freaking stupid.Story/Setting - 4/5 - A perfectly fine story in a pretty cool setting.  The world consists of a series of sky-islands each with its own unique geography and culture.  Cool.  The story is basically a sandbox adventure where we travel around in a neat flying blimp-boat.  You had me at flying blimp-boat.Writing - 2/5 - The writing is not great.  The writing is abysmally bad if you consider the last two episodes.  In general the dialog is weird and not very authentic feeling.  The show lacks anything resembling grit, and all the characters pretty much get along except for our token bad guys.Characters -1/5 - The characters in this show are all painfully boring, underdeveloped, and lacking in personality.  They all just get along all the time.  Like... Why is Katalina, who worked for the evil empire, such a nice, just, valiant person from the get go?  I can't imagine her ever being in the Empire.  Can't we get a few flaws for our characters?  Shortcomings?  Something to complicate them even just a little? If we played a game where I described a character and had you try to guess who I was talking about, I doubt we'd get a single match, because the characters have no personalities or defining characteristics.  Except maybe our grumpy pilot.   And don't get me started on the completely unnecessary host of side characters dropped on us like so many sad little bombs at the end.Artwork - 5/5 - This show is gorgeous.  Probably worth watching just for that.Voice acting - Largely left me wanting to strangle myself.  The show sounds like a bunch of teenage girls walking around a candy store going "Ooooooo!   Ahhhhhhh!"Over All - 3/5 - Beautiful art and a cool setting make the show worth watching if you like adventure/fantasy.  An unadvanced, largely directionless plot and boring characters keep this from being rated higher.

I've been keeping up with this anime despite the pretty flat looking art style. I'll start off by saying what I like about GranBlue Fantasy.1st: it reminds me of Final Fantasy, which I like.2nd: the animation is nice.And now onto what annoys me about this anime:1st: Flat looking art style. The cover looks way better than the anime.2nd: The violence in this anime is like rated pg13. Where's the blood spill from slashing those annoying Empire soldiers??3rd: If there is ACTUAL killing, then that annoying Mustache Empire dude would already been out of the picture, but noOOo lets keep him alive to make the story more "interesting."Granblue, at first, looks promising but falls short on a few things. It could have been a really sick anime, but the flat art style and lack luster violence kills it for me.

There's a lot of promise here but the show doesn't deliver.  It's a fantasy in the tradition of  Record of the Lodess War in the sense that the main character starts out on an adventure while accumulating allies along the way.  It starts off with promise.  There is conflict, dragons and magic.  That's the first episode.  I made it to the end of episode seven before I decided, enough is enough.If you enjoy stories with cute mascots and a great deal of emotional back slapping, then you may like this.  The characters are juvenile. The adventures are not that adventurous.  This can only have been meant for preteens as it is not complex.  However, there is a good plot there.  It just went to waste.  It may be at a certain point (beyond episode 7 of 13) that it came together, however, episode 7 introduced a character so disturbing to my ear that I could not continue under ANY circumstance to subject my ears anymore.

Honestly, I've tried to watch animes that were based on games before but most of the time the plot was way too confusing and you had to know the game in order to understand. This anime seems like a first where I can GET the plot! If that's the case then I'll be really pumped! Also the fact that the voice actor for the little dragon is Rie Kugimiya, the same voice actor for fairy tail's happy (the cat), also piqued my interest. (He's practically Happy reincarnated lol) I love the art for this show right away~ made me think of the anime grimgar fantasy and ash with its stunning artwork. It's worth watching for me just for those two reasons alone.

...and the video game I guess.Granblue Fantasy is based of the mobile rpg of the same name, and incidentally the manga adaptation.  It follows the classic fantasy-rpg setup of boy meets mystical girl and defends her from the kingdom that's hunting them.  The plot is rather generic, but you're not here for the plot.Let me just say, we haven't seen art and animation like this in years (maybe even in a decade).  Every character is hand drawn, backgrounds are painted, and everything just flows so beautifully Grandblue is a treat to watch.  Oh yeah, Lyria is cute and Katalina is gorgeous, so the waifu is strong with this one as well.Unfortunately there are negatives, and they're glaring as well.  First off, the plot is nothing you haven't seen before.  Second, there's CG.  In a visual spectacle such as this, where so much time, effort, and care was taken in drawing every frame, would they include CG monsters?  It breaks from the classic feel of the theme, and is overall a bad decision at concept.  The CG itself is passable, but not at the level of something like God Eater.But despite my misgivings, this is still an unexpected treat.  While not a contender for anime of the year (or season as Konosuba! S2 has everything else beat by a long shot), it's still a great watch.

This is a very well done high fantasy adventure with knights and dragons, and wizards; it is set in a realm of magic and steampunk.   Apparently, humanity and the other races (we see elves [Harvin] in the intro to the next episode) live on "islands" floating in the air.  The animation is excellent, and the characters are likable, though undeveloped thus far. The music is excellent, also. It is the story of a village boy, Gran, who trains as a knight, and his companion, a talking baby dragon (or flying lizard) named Vyrnso. He seeks to visit his father at Estalucia, the Island of the Astrals.  A Battle-Airship is passing overhead and the captain-of-the-guard, Katalina, decides to rescue her charge, Lyria, from imprisonment by the Erste Empire and in escaping, fall into the forest near Gran's village.  And, thereby the adventure starts.   The story is often compared to the  Final Fantasy video game, and it is excellent, and I can't wait for the next part.

Right of the bat, it needs to be mentioned that GRANBLUE FANTASY: The animation is an anime adaption of a video game series. The main character is based off of the male counterpart from the aforementioned game; though it looks like the female counterpart will be making it in to some bonus episodes.As for the anime itself, it is a bit slow moving; but this seems somewhat intended with the chosen art-style and tone of music likely aiming for something more carefree. In many ways, this anime feels like it touches more on 'artistic' value then it does 'story'; which can be taken as either a plus or minus depending on who is watching.Is it worth watching? Possibly. I don't feel as if I am really missing anything watching this anime, as opposed to just checking out the game. I definitely have enjoyed it enough that I was interested in checking up a bit on this game to see what it might be all about. Speaking of - it is worth noting that GranBlue draws heavy influence from Final Fantasy; which was more then hinted at with Bahumut, and confirmed with Tiamat. I'm not sure if GranBlue will be available on English; though it looks as if some workarounds are available for those who want to check out the game.

There is so much wasted potential here. This is a fun fantasy series, with gorgeous animation and piles of cool ideas. And it's all wrapped up in a creative and interesting setting. But shoving the show into 1 season of 12-13 episodes is a massive waste. Episode 12 seems to scream that there wont be a second season and this was all just an expensive commercial for the game. That's really a shame.Pros:Good animationGood musicLots of good ideasCons:Wasted potential, so much wasted potential...

Another video game adaptation into anime for this cycle. It seems we are getting a bunch for the coming year. So I gave this 4/5 because I feel that it has a lot of potential. Albeit if you are reading this I only watched 2 episodes and I played none of the Granblue games. So just know that this 4/5 is a coming from a complete blank slate. Pros: -If you love Fantasy anime then I believe you will love this. World building is done fairly well. The addition of a "sky world" has been visited by other mediums. If you liked the One Piece arc in the sky then Granblue is right up your alley. -The animation style is by far the best thing about this anime. It has a style reminiscent of the Final Fantasy Tactics but with a bit more anime-flair. The fight scenes are clean and fluid, not outstanding but it does the job to show character strengths. -The music is partly composed by Nobuo Uematsu, so I am guessing they got a lot from the Granblue games which is a big plus because the world and the music work in tandem together. OP is another plus, Bump of Chicken songs are top tier J-Pop in my opinion. Cons: -The plot is nothing short of common at this point. Mysterious people who have tremendous power but disappeared. Princess-like heroine needs help from a Empire looking to abuse said power. Wide-eyed honest boy looking for adventure in search of Dad accompanied by cheeky animal side kick. Granblue is unfortunately shacked by it's video game counterpart playing to the mobile video game community.  However, I believe there is still room for improvement in this area. -Character development should be the focus come the next few episodes. But if they fail with shallow character relationships then this will be another big Con for Granblue.OVERALL: I think there is a lot of potential to build an entertaining anime here. A grand adventure amongst the skies. The animation and the music is already there. The hollow plot is a consequent of the video game plot so I think it fair to let that go. With only two episodes I'm excited to see more!

Final Fantasy is about as formulaic as they come, but who hasn't wanted a series done in the same animation style as the cutscenes? I mean, if you're happy with Advent Children, I guess you'd be content without it, but c'mon. Same with the World of Warcraft movie! It wasn't "terrible", but watching WoW game cutscenes, who hasn't thought just once: "I wish they would make this into a movie."The art style of Final Fantasy XII concept art with the storyline of just about any JRPG/kitchen-boy-to-chosen-one-fantasy and, voila! You have Granblue Fantasy: The Animation.It's fun, the character design is adorable and badass at the same time, the story is light and entertaining, the animation is solid enough, what's not to love?It's a great watch with some great potential, so let's get these view numbers up without judging too harshly, you're not watching this to learn anything.

The show is so peculiar that I find it hard to find the right words to describe it. The plot of season one wasn't anything too special: our skyfarers arrive in a new location by chance or quest, there's a problem affecting the population concerning a primordial beast and sometimes the empire, a battle ensues to help the primordial beast be free from the empire's influence, our skyfarers leave, then repeat. Most of the show has a predictable outcome, but one that's hoped for. The art is downright solid and can be the only reason you watch the show. The characters don't have complicated pasts.Or at least shown in season 1.Now that season 2 is here, I'm excited to see the plot progress. The definite end of the entire franchise seems to be if or when Gran meets his father on the Island of the Astrals, but I doubt the anime will go that far in hopes of getting viewers to play the game. For whatever they decide to show, though, I'm ready.Finally, something that simply speaks volumes: Katalina in full plate armor. An anime for fanservice would find a way to show skin or cleavage, but they keep her fully covered as armor should be. Meaning the show is aiming for respectable characters, not dumb ones that fit a wet-dream role.I can't vouch for everything, but for the show to be based on a game and be this solid is impressive to me. I don't play the game, but I love the series.

First off......I will explain that when it comes to rating an anime, two of the biggest things for me are if the anime can hold my interest and if I found it enjoyable to watch. Since these are both true, this rating may seem higher than one would expect with the amount of things I nitpick. Elaborating further, if Crunchyroll allowed half ratings, I would give this anime a 3.5/5. However, since they do not, I feel this anime is more deserving of a 4/5 instead of a 3/5.Pros:- Character Development: For most of the main characters, the viewer is given enough backstory and allowed enough depth into the characters that one cares enough for them and is pulled into their story and the grand adventure.- Enjoyable Story: For the most part, the story itself is enjoyable to watch if one gives it a chance.Cons:- Slow............: If you are looking for a fast paced, action filled, fantasy world, do not watch this. This anime takes its time, sometimes too much time, getting through each plot point. If slow story with occasional action is not your style, i would not recommend this.- (Some) Action Scenes Look too Easy: Some of the fights went by in the blink of an eye, the protagonists defeating the enemy like they were nothing, then the next fight could last for a while. This made some of the action parts throughout the anime extremely unenjoyable.- Ending: If this anime does not get a second season, many viewers will forever feel unfulfilled by how the season ended.Nitpicks:1. At first, the animation style of the characters was very off putting compared to the background they were against. While I got over this a few episodes in, there were still times when this was evident.Spoiler Alert! Click to show or hide2. Near the beginning, before heading out on their journey, they made a point to mention that now that Gran was linked to Lyria, long distance separation could weaken, or even kill, Gran. However, throughout the entire series, this plot point was never used in any way.3. The PG-13 thing of never killing off any of the main bad guys but totally not caring about the lives of the soldiers protecting those evil characters (Episode 13 made fun of this fact).4. There are so many unfinished plot points. How did Apollo become the Black Knight? Can we get more of an explanation as to who Rosetta is? What about the two treasure hunters from episode 8, who are they? Who are the Lumiel Order of the Holy Knights and all of the backstories for the 9 NEW CHARACTERS INTRODUCED IN EPISODE 12, THE ACTUAL FINAL EPISODE? 5. Why end the show half way through the journey????? One of my biggest dislikes with anime is when the company decides to just end the adventure right in the middle before the main narrative has been completed. At the very least, you can end with a cliffhanger of sorts to lead into a second season; episode 12 just left me with an unfulfilled feeling.6. Why is "Episode 13" (Extra 1) even a thing? A single episode continuation of the 'story' set in an AU where Gran is actually Djeeta, a girl, but the journey is the same all the way up to them on the airship after the Leviathan fight, except for the fact that almost all of the 9 new characters introduced in episode 12 have also joined the crew??? And the episode focuses on them at a vacation resort, chilling on the beach and figuring out why there is no ice left??? We all know why this episode was made *coughcough* Fan service *coughcough*. I will say though, the off screen fight in the cave, with its death and gore sounds, did make me laugh, but that was the only good part of the episode.In Summary: Because of how the show progressed, ended, and all of the content added to the show in the true final episode, this anime is in desperate need of a second season. In my opinion, a 24 episode season would have worked a lot better with the show and their style of story telling, allowing for an actual ending instead of what the viewer gets: forced waiting for a second season. As it stands, however, this anime was a nice thing to watch in the evening that I watched it and I am looking forward to seeing this continued, hopefully.

I'll admit I was nervous after seeing what happened with monster hunter and puzzles and dragons to name a couple, but wow, this so far has been incredible. The artwork is phenomenal along with the voice work. The plot isn't anything unique to start with but having played the game I know where it's going and it will come into its own. Which isn't to say that it isn't refreshing, this anime would have been one among many had it come out a decade or so ago, but lately there's been a shortage of really high quality sword and sorcery RPG-like anime (at least that I've seen personally).

Though only two episodes are out at the moment, they were surprisingly captivating. The scenes and way the "magic" or "skills" , if you prefer either term, are very well incorporated into the show. The art style is a bit more drawing like which I absolutely love considering it is something different and very well done. If you enjoy this I highly recommend the series "Grimgar of Fantasy and ash" which portrays a similar style of anime.

This is a very well done high fantasy adventure with knights and dragons, and wizards; it is set in a realm of magic and steampunk. Apparently, humanity and the other races (we see elves in the intro to the next episode) live on "islands" floating in the air. The animation is excellent, and the characters are likable, though undeveloped thus far. The music is excellent, People who complain about anime being from a game due are not truly anime fans not giving it a try and giving it a bad rating because of this are truly trash and should not have a voice in rating a anime and saying "anime from a game move on" before even trying.

I knew by the title alone that this is an RPG game adaptation but the game is not a console game but for iphone,android and google chrome.They will most likely make a  console games after the series is done. But when I watched the anime adaptation I knew the art looked very familiar and its the same art director in some of the Final Fantasy games , Very good animation, the world looked amazing,the background has so much details  the character design are very well defined.Makes me want to cosplay this one too.The story is not very complicated and the characters are ok and hope there is more development .  I thought this one is a very good video game adaptation after 2 episodes.

Season 1 (4.5/5) I really enjoyed. Fresh environment and colorful animation, the game-turned-anime had a good start. The characters were exciting and the stories were compelling enough to be a decent anime on it's own. Season 2 (4/5) Lost some of it's vibe. I don't know if they weren't actually planning on having a season 2, when the first season became a concept. But, something wasn't as interesting as the beginning. I still enjoyed watching our lovely band of friends, but it felt different. Looking forward to what Season 3 has to hold.

I kinda like this show. It's story arc is ok. The characters are ok. But that's about it, it's just ok and nothing really special. It's definitely not the best anime out there, but it's decent. At times all the cutsie female voices are a bit much for me, high pitched and whiney at times, and that's anime for you, but I felt it's a bit excessive. The art work is pretty standard, if not a little plain and old school looking.

I'm coming at this review from the perspective of a guy who actually plays the mobile game so bear with me. I won't analyze the story elements so much as try to explain why they're like that and where Cygames went wrong. I won't discuss anything else but all I'll say about music is I love the intro and most of the music is ripped from the game itself. The animation is what I expect from A1... choppy at times and beautiful at others. In the game I am at chapter 96 and rank 153 (if that last bit matters).  Wind is a stupid element. This anime covers the weakest point of Granblue Fantasy and goes up to Chapter 12 in the mobile game and the beginning of the Erste Empire arc. For perspective atm there are 124 chapters and we'll be entering the third arc. Later on in the mobile game (around chapter 30ish) the writing staff was reinforced with better writers and the story reflects it. However, this isn't a mobile game and Cygames had hindsight to draw from. An anime has about 3 episodes to catch your attention before people choose to get invested and sadly I have to say I only stayed on board because I wanted to see how this show played out. In a mobile game those that play usually understand that they are in it for the long haul and will put up with pacing issues or slow character development because that's how the medium works. Not in an anime and Cygames didn't understand this. One complaint is lack of character development outside of Rackam. In fact all these characters develop at some point and have deeper back stories when explored:Katalina was a rising star in the Empire.Eugen is a man with a regrettable past.Io is probably the one I'll excuse because her character development comes from interactions with another cast member we barely saw. Gran is as you see him but even he has choices to make later on. His connection to Vyrn runs deep and Vyrn is connected to Lyria. But you wouldn't know unless you played the mobile game.Rackam has a very deep connection to the Grancypher that shows up in chapter 30ish.Cygames could've approached these characters differently, choosing to show more of them then they did. Instead thet followed the slow format of the mobile game and did it sort of faithfully. That isn't a good thing considering it is the worst part of the story and it didn't translate well into anime format. They could've added more hooks for the audience to bite into. It's inexcusable when you can look back on your own game and fill in the story's weak points and make it anime friendly. Moving on to two more gripes... Episodes 12 and 13.Episode 12 had a bit of fan service introducing many of the gacha crew from Narmaya (butterfly girl) to Yodarha (old midget guy). This worries me because they all have great back stories but how can you cover so many characters over the course of a season?
