Unless Cygames invests in making OVAs for them then they can't do it without compromising the show. What is going on here?Episode 13 could've been better. It could've been an hour long OVA showing one of the many great side stories that double as beach episodes but went for the generic beach route instead. Sadly this is the episode they use Djeeta in. To give you some perspective Djeeta is the female MC in GBF the game. The player can switch freely from Djeeta to Gran as they wish. So essentially everything that happened to Gran happens to Djeeta. But anime doesn't work this way. They could have done introduced Djeeta better. Yet another example of how the mobile game can't just be translated over to the anime directly. AT LEAST PUT HER IN THE COVER ART! So while the anime only viewers are justified in thinking Gran was tossed aside they are technically wrong. This however, doesn't excuse the way Djeeta's introduction was handled. TL,DR: The anime suffers from being an almost direct copy of the mobile game's weakest point in the story. The two mediums aren't the same and it shows. Cygames needs to think about how to present this story in a more anime friendly fashion if it wants to bring more people into the Granblue universe. Handle Djeeta better. She needs more love... she's already nixed from GBFV so far as we know. Please make side story and character OVAs if you're introducing us to gacha characters. Naru deserves it. Hopefully they get the hint and season 2 will be stronger. Especially since, assuming one episode=One chapter, we'll be seeing 3 more interesting characters in Rosetta, Vira and Ferry... yes the same Ferry as the fighting game.

There is so many  things this anime gets right and yet so many things it gets wrong. The writing needs work and that’s just putting it mildly. Random side characters that were dropped in out of nowhere.Can someone please tell me why did they change the lead character?Now there is no hope for this anime after getting rid of the one role that could have been developed fantastically if they weren’t so stupid. That was a really dumb call because you just Alienated an entire source by making this anime a fantasy chick flick. By ripping the romance novelty right from under our feet, they have doomed this anime to fail hard. I can’t in good conscience recommend this anime after these poor discussion. Everything falls apart in episode 13, this anime could have been so good but alas it was all for not.  Idiots

I've rewatched Granblue Fantasy and tried my damndest to like it, I really did. There's something in it that's drew me in. I like the art design. I liked the promise of adventure and seeing new sights. I liked the few moments of action in between the long - and I mean long - transition of exposition between scenes. And that's where GBF:TA falls flat. In spite of its surface beauty and promise of adventure, it just kind of drags along from point A to point B with no true feeling of tension or gravitas. The characters feel dry and underdeveloped, lacking anything that would make you relate to any of them... although strangely enough, the one character that really truly feels developed is actually an alternate gender-bent version of the main character in the last episode - and that is JARRING. It has potential, but just lacks substance and character. It's like biting into a really nice looking piece of chocolate and expecting a delicious filling of some kind, only to find out the chocolate is hollow. It was somewhat tasty at first bite, but leaves you yearning for more. As it stands, GBF:TA is a lesson of how to avoid writing a disengaging script for an anime. And it's such a shame too, because I really did like everything else the series potentially had to offer. Just give me more to bite on next time.

I don't write anime reviews very often, but here I am writing on a series that isn't very good.  The first two episodes were decent, but I ended up not watching it for a while.  Picked it up again and stopped around episode 7 or 8 for the rest of the summer until this week.This could have been decent, but turned out very poor, especially the end.  With the last break and coming back, jumping back into it seemed as if the story had skipped ahead.  So I didn't pay much attention and used it more for background noise.  Then suddenly there was an army of a couple weak guys, and a ton of super OP girls.  They beat another "boss", had more people join the army of travelers, and changed the main character into a girl and did a final episode at a beach instead of adding to the story.  Probably knowing they weren't getting another season, as their writing was poor for the entire series.I finished it mostly to take it off of my already large queue list of series I actually like  and ended(hoping for more seasons on most!) and those I like and still running.  You aren't missing anything if you skip this series.

Note: This review is based off the first season of GRANBLUE FANTASY: The Animation. I never played the game. I just want to make that clear.To be honest, I just watched this show on a whim. There were only two episodes out in January, and it looked pretty, so I watched it on a slow afternoon. Thirteen episodes later, it is time to write a review, and boy do I have a lot to say. This show is incredibly divisive to me, with a large amount of pros and cons.First, lets begin with the pros. The visuals are absolutely beautiful. Whenever they introduced a new island or area, my jaw always hit the floor. Every shot is gorgeous and breath-taking. The original sound track for GRANBLUE FANTASY was amazing. The music added to each situation perfectly. In addition to that, the OP and ED were two of my favorites from the season. The animation is smooth and flows well. This goes along with the visuals, but it is still a nice touch. Finally, the characters were well written. I found myself enjoying how they acted and their interactions between each other. Especially how Rackam and Io act towards each other. The voice actors added to this with perfect representations of their characters and well-written dialogue. Now, lets get to the cons. The story is unoriginal and not that well written. This is the biggest thing holding GRANBLUE FANTASY down. It is ok, but it never tries to be anything unique. The story also starts showing signs of wear at the end, with a rushed ending and many plot holes. This could be different for other people, but to me, the story was not that great or not presented well (I never played the game so I can't really say). The character facial animations can be flat out boring and emotionless at time. This is more of a minor problem, but it still bugs me greatly. Finally, there is the beach episode. This is a con in itself. That was probably one of the worst episodes I have watched in quite a while. Why does it exist? Why?To be honest, I would like to see a second season of the show. It was not that bad and I did end up continuing the show all the way through the season, when I dropped many others. I do hope that they fix the problems of the story. That is the biggest issue and if fixed, this show could rise from ok to amazing. If you want to watch it, go ahead, but know that there are some serious flaws to consider before starting the show. Overall Rating: 7/10

I was so excited when the first two episodes released. I watched them right away and was sad for the long wait for the rest. However, I was not disappointed. Episodes 1-12 were amazing. I feel 13 wasn't necessary. Yes I understand Djeeta is a a switchable character, I have played the game. Even as a person who plays female characters, I opted for Gran. I just much prefer his character. I hope for more episodes, but the story continues as Gran and not Djeeta - and definitely not flip flopping back and forth.

The final episode is complete fan service which is weird on a 13 episode series...  After that it was engaging and I wouldn't mind seeing a second season to resolve some of the more significant plot threads.  Enjoyable and consistent fantasy that never strays from the safe path but hits all the right notes anyway.  Probably deserves 3.5 stars but I can't give that and I enjoyed it more than I should have.

Has great visual appeal good settings and likable characters also has pretty much nothing new writing was inconsistent many unanswered questions. The fights were predictable as were the many powers displayed but I liked it anyway it was presented fairly well the different style of airships were interesting as were the many types of sentient creatures presented. Has very little fan service the English dub is pretty good and then episode 13 comes along and as someone who hasn't played the game or read the manga I'm totally confused as Gran is replaced by a female character I really thought that this was a dream and the character having it would wake up and everything would be as it was in the first 12 episodes this was a bad decision by the producers of this anime which already had some problems to start with as I mentioned above and I didn't mention all of them. I'm giving a high 3 rating here and a 6 on a 10 scale very mildly recommended.

Judging by the intro, outro, and the first three episodes. This seems very much like One Piece set in an aerial fantasy setting. Different animation style(but fitting for the setting). This anime was a bit slow getting started and wasn't sure if it was going to be a simple monster collection show(never played the game) or if it was going to have more depth similar to an RPG(many have excellent stories with worlds capable of being adapted into anime). So far it hasn't disappointed and has the potential to be an excellent anime. As I watch more, I will update this review, but it is definitely on my watch list now.

This is probably one of the best looking of the season- new anime based off a popular Cygames franchise. RPG based anime are usually not my cup of tea, but like Tales of Zestiria- Granblue is just beautiful and has a familiar Fantasy-Adventure story that's easy to get behind. All the characters- and I mean all of them- look really sharp. There are some downsides- it has an annoying flying dragon mascot with a more annoying voice that I want to drop-kick to the moon- but otherwise there's not much to complain about. I'll enjoy watching this one each week if just for the visuals.

It is painfully obvious that it is based off a game all the way down to the fight scene music. The story is linear like that of a classic style RPG. But that doesn't make it bad. As long as you go into it know that is the case you'll find it to be enjoyable. It's not psychologically stimulating, but it's fun and that's just perfect for game-based anime. If I were judging it as an original series then I would certainly not rate it at 4 stars. But for what it is, it's pretty good. If you go into this expecting an original series and judge it based on that expectation then you're stupid and wrong.

Backgrounds are beautifully rendered, but characters and figures look out of place against them due to their fuzzy, ill-defined linework. In some scenes, characters look as if they were cut out and pasted onto these photo-realistic backgrounds. It's somewhat jarring and distracting to the overall serious tone of the story so far, and sometimes breaks the immersion. 3D/CG visuals are great however, and actual animations are satisfactory. By the way, Nobuo Uematsu composes music for the series, so we can look forward to that.

I compare Granblue Fantasy to a bag of aired out bag of potato chips that were already bland to begin with. They're a dime a dozen product that you can get anywhere, you already know what you're going to get when you bought them, and above all, they're not something you associate with quality. Sure, the chips are passable enough to eat them if there is nothing else to eat, but why should you have to be reduced to that option?This is a forgettable dime a dozen fantasy genre anime that does absolutely nothing to bring anything new to the table other than its unique art style.ts only saving grace is that it isn't "bad", but by the same token, it can't be called "good". (In particular, I've noticed this show borrows rather hard from a certain other popular franchise, but I'll leave contemplation on that to you if you decide to watch this)The art style of the show is actually kind of refreshing, but unfortunately they leave a significant portion of what they draw unrefined, leaving a majority of what is on screen to be left looking like something out of a sketchbook for the show, the only real exception to this is when the scene is mean to be moving and draw your attention. Otherwise, the animation itself flows just fine.The writing for this show is so incredibly uninspired, so predictable, so lazy, and so utterly bland that it can't be ignored. Everything that advances the plot is so utterly lazily staged that it can't be called natural, it is incredibly superficial and comes off as so painfully predictable that there is no tension, no wonder, no nothing. Everything that happens is either unnecessary or incredibly forced, leaving you with a sense that everything was just made up on the spot to keep the show going with no real sense of consistency in plot or development. This show also has a seriously bad issue of glossing over important details or just forgetting about something they mentioned entirely.The cast of characters in this show is going to be a hit and miss, as some characters are cut and paste cliches and others have some level of originality to them, but not by much. Overall, none of the characters have any depth to them whatsoever except for Lyria, the blue haired girl, but even then her personality is filled by the "cliche and contrived tragic backstory that does nothing but serve as a half-assed MacGuffin." That should tell you how badly one-dimensional all the characters are if the "depth" they have is relegated to something that was made on the spot to advance the plot via a flashback. All in all, none of the characters presented have any real depth, no meaningful aspirations, nothing. This goes both for the major characters and minor characters, both protagonists and antagonists. Conclusion:All in all, this anime is uninspired, unoriginal, flavorless, and incredibly predictable. If you have nothing better to watch, then sure, I'd say this is certainly better than a lot of the other dime a dozen animes out there and will serve as a decent time waster. However, if you're looking for a decent anime to enjoy, I'd say look elsewhere unless you're starving for more fantasy genre anime. But whatever you do, avoid the 13th episode. It's not a continuation of the show, and it is most certainly not worth your time. I was tempted to give this show a 2/5, but I decided it was passable enough to be considered "average", despite all it does wrong. And finally, I personally recommend the English Dub if you do decide to watch.

7 episodes in and so far this is "Meh."The animation is great, aside from slightly jarring moments with CG (and all the janky movements that come with it), the music is wonderful, and I've run out of positives.It's a real shame the series doesn't capitalize on that. The characters are pretty dull and unrelatable, and the story is, so far, pretty absent. I really want to like it (yay fantasy and all that), but I just don't. There's good potential for the islands to be varied and for interesting characters to be introduced, but it says something about a series when I root for the villains.There are better and more enjoyable series available.

The MC is the blandest garbage of a character I've seen.  He has nothing to defend himself with apart from a dinky sword that glowed orange for 2 seconds and glowed blue for 3 seconds, that's it.  By carried I mean the blue girl Lyria is always saving him and he even dies in the first episode, until he gets revived by her.  The only time when he's able to do anything significant in terms of power is when Lyria gives him power, otherwise, he would just be a kid with a sword.  In episode 12 we saw so many other characters that could have been more interesting if they were the MC because they have awesome abilities, like the guy with the crazy speed and thunder fists.  Overall, the MC sucks, isn't strong at all, and is totally bland and basic.

The show reminds me of many great animes, with a story reminiscent of  One piece and  Secret of Cerulean Sand and animation like  God eater . yet the reason i give it 4 out of 5 stars is because the beginning reminds me of the beginning of  Cerberus (for those who haven't seen it, it has an amazing first episode but the rest of the series turns worse and worse with no real character development) so i'm kind of afraid that the show at some point wil rely on the good animation to gain more followers. But all in all, as of now it is a show worth watching.It's about a young boy named Gran and his lizard/dragon friend who go to help a mysterious girl named Lyria after her airship's exploded. With the help of her guardian Katalina they fight of soldiers from the empire and try to escape.

2 episodes in, and before I did any research I already knew that this anime was based on an RPG, because it has RPG storytelling. While I do enjoy a good RPG, it does have an odd flow to it when it's being played out in anime form. It also hits a lot of the cliches you'd expect from a fantasy RPG. It's not that it's bad-I am sure I'll keep watching, but there's just nothing here that was new/original/compelling so far. So if you like fantasy or RPG's, by all means watch it. But have realistic expectations.

To start on a positive note, Animation is of top quality. Fluid, well drawn, colorful, crisp, no jarringly obvious CG detected. Character design is faithful to the source material. Argument to be made that they could have preserved the original art style (which notably used some very somber, dark tones), but let's be real - carrying over handdrawn style is very rare with anime adaptations. It's a good job.Onto the not so good, I read the manga up to about volume 4 (fell behind just because I got distracted by other stuff) and based on that was really looking forward to this series.However, I have to say the 1st episode is really sending up some red flags. Basic problem is that they pretty much info-dumped a lot of the underlying backstory in the first episode, which was slowly drip fed to you in the manga. The end result is none of the expected pacing, dramatic delivery, or somber tone from the manga at all.For those interested, the anime basically starts 2 months ahead of where the manga does, and pretty depicts every obscure past event, secret, and tragic happening which was revealed piece by piece thru flashbacks & dialogue over the course of the main characters journey in the books. Tragic secret of the beasts? Spoiled. Why Hank is hunting down his former comrades? Spoiled. Heck, they even show a great majority of the beasts and their powers... which very much spoils the 'monster of the week' factor the manga had going for it.I don't think it is un-salvageable, and plan to see it thru for a couple more episodes, but quite simply it is not a great start at all. Show runners have already put themselves in the position of recovering lost faith, and my anticipation has changed to worry & disappointment.

Before starting I saw a review that recommended I start from the 2nd episode and I decided to do just that. The first episode has a serious pacing problem as it's very rushed and I'd describe it as an "info-bomb" that didn't prepare itself very well. Watching the 2nd episode 1st remedies this by keeping the mystery intact by introducing us to one of the relatives of a main character. It's honestly almost as if it should've been this way from inception especially due to the dialogue in the first episode relating to said character in the second episode. I'm only two episodes in but I'm interested in seeing where  this goes after being extremely skeptic initially. If you start from the first episode you might not get the most out of this show

Significant violence and bloodshed throughout. Drawing and animation are good.The plot in the first episode feels very front-loaded. They packed a whole lot of story into the first episode. While it was by no means bad, it felt oddly structured. The events took place at a breakneck pace. Some of what happens feels like it should be very impactful, but since this is the very first episode, you don't have any strong ties to any characters yet. It made what could have been meaningful under other circumstances feel relatively shallow.The second episode however, was much better than the first. If anything the second episode should have been the first episode. It picks up from there, and while it doesn't move particularly fast, it's still entertaining throughout the season.Did I mention the bloodshed? Yeah, there's a lot of that.

Didn't read the source material so I don't come into this one with rose-tinted glasses like a lot of the other reviewers. If you want a throw-away anime about furry war heroes who are betrayed by society, this is your jam. It's kind of like if you removed all of the things that made Golden Kamuy great (art, story, food), but made up for it by replacing the soldiers with furries. And you got the concepts and artwork for the furries from a 6th grade class. I'm going to throw the word "furry" around a lot - not because I have strong feelings one way or the other about furries, but because that's what this show is about: people transforming into poorly anthropomorphosed animals.Art: 2/5. I saw reviews praising the art in this show and I have to wonder if the reviewers are time travelers from the 90s. The fights are not good. The peaceful scenes are not good. It's cheap and bad. Story concept: 2/5. I mean, I guess I could get on board with a bizarro American Civil War world where people wear purple and green cowboy hats, but it's just a throw-away setup for the furry anti-heroes, so it doesn't really matter. And the furry anti-heroes are really not that interesting or sympathetic. Writing: 2/5: Inconsistent at best, with lots of awkward transitions between fan service and emotional appeals. Sweeping plot elements from one episode disappear in the next. Side-roads that don't go anywhere other than to establish that a character is "really driven." A mustache-twirling bad guy who just wants to watch the world burn. Actually, I can relate to him, because this world sucks. The reviewers who have read the source material are pretty much uniform in saying that this show blazes through elements of the manga that were interesting and aims straight for the spectacle of fights, which might have worked if the art didn't suck.

The introduction is about two nations that went through civil war due to economical disputes. These sacred beasts are experimental, biological weapon of destruction which gave them the upper hand in the war, however it has a downside of the unknown. The "technology" has side effects which affects the soul of it's user. They messed up the initial story telling and character introduction. They could've made 3-5 episodes with the episode 1's story alone. It could've given us the opportunity to relate, like and hate to certain characters of the show before actually finishing the war. They simply thrown a ton of information and rushed it. I believe that in the manga the introduction is done better. I highly recommend that you read before you watch.  I don't even feel anything about the people, soldiers, sacred beasts that died in the anime. They just died. There is no special connection or sympathy. They could've done a better job tbh.In my opinion, the animation and art is quite superb however I'd give it a fair share of 7.5/10 overall for now, since it's just episode 1.

This is what happens when an author tries to justify perverse societal norms and a lot of the fans can see through the giant gaping holes in their rationalizations.In more detail, the "moral" metaphors in this anime are:-Killing your own soldiers when they return from war is a good thing, because they're too harsh and inconvenient during peace time.  In fact, they should just off themselves since they're too troublesome to even bother with.-The word "soul" doesn't really mean anything.-If you harm/damage/change someone, it's okay to kill them off if they're inconvenient to you, and if they fight back when you try to do that, THEY'RE the bad guys.On top of the disgusting "morals", the plot is weak and entirely predictable, and there's precisely one, single moment of character growth in the whole series so far, in the second episode.  No character growth at all after that.The fight scenes are also nothing to write home about.  Or even pay attention to.  Boring with predictable outcomes and no real consequences.

This show was a little interesting at first.  Soldiers turning into pokemon that were OP as hell seemed like a good idea.  Unfortunately whoever wrote the script for this had no idea what they were doing.  So many things get glossed over and it's just not as interesting as it should be.  You'd think monsters battling each other would be really intense, right?  But instead they are just kind of slow and boring and it feels like "ehhhh who's next?".Don't even get me started on Schal...At it's core though, this show will still likely satisfy some viewers.  It's not very good but if you like floppy action fights involving pokemon and werewolves and teenage girls then maybe you will still like it.

ASB is a story about soldiers who were given god-like powers and how they struggled after being returned to society. I was really looking forward to seeing how it would be adapted from it's manga. Honestly it's not worth watching. First episode front loads all the exposition giving Hank a tragic backstory. It was honestly the weakest part of the manga and something that should have been told much later when the main villain is introduced. Episoode 2 is where the story really starts. Schaal is introduced. Her tragedy is fleshed out really well. I'm fully invested in watching how her story unfolds up until the point where she meets Hank.This is where everything just falls apart. ASB shines best through the mini stories of each Incarnate told through a simple formula. Hank reminisces over what kind of person they were before or during the war. Schaal observes how their return damages the lives of those near them. Fight scene ends with introspection on deeper meanings of what it means to have humanity just before the Incarnate is killed. What keeps the manga from being an unbearably depressing drag is the lighthearted interactions between the Hank, Schaal and their supporting cast. This version abandoned all the character development and what's left is a dry bones telling of a man hunting down some monsters. Changes are expected in adaptations. Epitaphs of the Incarnates are cut shorter which is reasonable. But as of the end of the third episode none of our cast is interesting enough to warrant continuing this series. Just read the manga if you want to enjoy the story.

I don't watch horror or tragedies for a reason and this is pretty much a horror tragedy.  Thoroughly depressing and filled with people whose lives are destroyed over and over and end up dead.  This is not a story of redemption, but a story of one tragedy after another, which I'm guessing ends with the protagonist dying, or worse, committing suicide because he knows that he can't stay or he'll become a monster also.  Yeah, I'll pass on watching more.

I noticed that a lot of people on here are agreeing on the fact that they don't like the order of story being presented here compared to the manga. I would agree on that statement. It's hard to give a rating to something that you know is adapted from a good story. However, I'm here to judge the anime. overall the animation is smooth for the most part. Nothing to complain about Studio Mappa who usually dose a good job in the first couple of episodes. The voice acting is great and even though I don't like the fact they present characters too early they did a good job in expressing their personalities. Spoilers for the first 2 episodes:The reason why I don't like the way they put things in order because it takes away the mystery of the journey of Hank. In the first chapter (the later half of episode 2) we see Schaal try and get revenge on Hank for murdering her father. We all know that Hank is a great guy and how right he is in killing his teammates. So it takes away a lot from Schaal's journey and quest to see if Hank is right in his killings. You see, the later half of episode 2 is the first chapter of the story. We don't know if Hank is good or bad. We don't even get his whole backstory till a little later in the manga. It takes away a lot from the message of the story of saving people's humanity and seeing if our main character is really right. End Spoilers:Over all I still think it's a good watch and even with these problems they are minor and don't override the story for me.

Episode 1 is an exposition dump and montage of characters we'll only really meet once slowly losing their humanity.  The rest of the series is one off stories about a single character getting killed and what they were like before going to war.  The main character, Schaal, should be learning that these creatures have completely lost their humanity and killing them is necessary but instead maintains her desire to save them despite everything she's encountered.  Episode 8 even throws away the idea that they're losing their humanity by having one successfully regain her senses just to make the military officers hunting them the real monsters.

First off READ THE MANGATo the Abandoned Sacred Beasts commits something I like to call "The Author Surrogate Sin" where the character that we, the audience, are supposed to self-insert into as they learn about the world. The main girl is that character, in this adaptation, we already know the "things" she's just finding out so her profound observations come off more like she's patronizing us.There are other issues, like being unable to maintain a consistent tone (Boob joke into the Horrors of War back to the boob jokes in the span of 3 minutes) and having the cool moments get overshadowed by PLOT that is thrown at you with the subtly of a brick. It's action scenes are fun, and when they're actually keeping a tone it works. It's not good, it's okay, it's animation is okay, its story is okay, its characters are ok, it's just okay. Watch it if you're really hungering for something like this, but then you should just READ THE MANGA.

After watching the first episode, I'm very much looking forward to more. The action is well-paced so far. A unit of soldiers called "Incarnates" can transform into a variety of mighty beast-human hybrids. There's a civil war going on, with technology pretty much the same as the American Civil War. Naturally, the Incarnates have a huge advantage, but they can still be killed with sufficient firepower. The war isn't the focus of the show, though, despite early appearances. The focus is on the Incarnates themselves as things go very badly for them. The main character, Hank, is a likeable action hero, but he's ultimately facing the same tragic fate as the other Incarnates. We see the origin of the main villain, and our hero is motivated greatly to go after him Spoiler Alert! Click to show or hideas his love interest Elaine is stuffed in the fridge.

First off I'd like to say that this show isn't really bad. It just isn't overwhelmingly good either.Our story follows our enigmatic loner hero dressed in an ominous white military uniform who was turned into a literal monster by the recent war. He is on a grand quest to put all of his former friends to rest because they were also turned into monsters. The worst of his old pals is his old friend turned scary crazy man, who also murdered his one true love. While on his adventure he meets up with a plucky sidekick girl who joins him on his quest to save the souls of his friends.If that plot seems eerily familiar, it might be because Gun X Sword is about an enigmatic loner hero in a black tuxedo who teams up with a plucky girl sidekick on his quest to track down the man who killed his bride, and every other anime from the late 90's and early 00's was also about war being bad and how terrible PTSD is.This show should have tickled all of my old anime nostalgia. The character designs, the writing, the art-style, everything. It's like this show was made when I was a kid, and then sealed away in a time-capsule to be released when I was old and jaded enough to appreciate the overt "war makes us monsters" metaphor. The problem is that there is a reason that I don't watch those old shows today, and this one kind of has all of those problems.

Make it through the first 4 episodes I would say and the show does develop different dynamics other than the Hank must kill 1 beast a show thing.  The animation is actually awesome, and there is not a character that I can say I dislike which is actually surprising.  I rarely write reviews, and this may even be my first.  I just think this show deserve a lil bit of love and nowhere near as much hate as people are giving it in the reviews.  I also watched the 2nd episode first like one of the reviews suggested, and it worked for me.

I absolutely adore this anime's art style and the character designs between the cast are pretty distinct! It definitely grabbed me in upon episode 1 and the reveal of the Incarnates' power but man- later down the line it quickly becomes mentally tiring to watch by the amount of despair and angst it has. It's a promising how in the first few episodes with the introduction of Schaal and her ideals of 'saving' the Incarnates from their seemingly inevitable fate but that quickly becomes next to an impossible feat with time and time again of either her, a military personnel, or Hank slaying them down. Even with EP 10: Spoiler Alert! Click to show or hideSchaal eventually understands and fully accepts Hank's ideals with putting down the incarnates and her own unique hope of saving them is lost. It's more or less for worse when everyone else in the cast is pretty much hellbent on slaying Incarnates and believe it's the only way. It would have been super interesting to have Hank's (or any others') ideals challenged upon coming across an Incarnate that actually came from the bleak. Maybe there is a way to 'save the Soul' after all. When the world isn't hopeful at times along with its sadness, what's the point of being engaged with it?It's just a dull trudge near the end of the same pattern and outcomes. You already have an inkling of what'll happen by the end of each Incarnate encounter and it really feels like a chore to complete the anime if you're stubborn enough not to drop it. Sacred Beasts has SO much potential but it chose the streamline path instead. It's like a straight-shot without keeping you on your toes and you're exhausted by the end of it. As for the characters, I feel like Cain and Elaine among many others DEFINITELY should have been fleshed out. It feels like a 'save the princess' situation where the main antagonist is the bad guy because he's bad vibe. This definitely needed more episodes, or at least a better way of handling the scenes. EP 10:  Spoiler Alert! Click to show or hideAND the first time we ever saw the making of an Incarnate 10 episodes in was completely without impact on me. Man, I really wish it was shown sooner... Just little things like that cement the hell they went through, the dark undergrowth of the series besides the present. It'd be nice. Part of me has the feeling it might be extended to Season 2 but if there ever is one, I wouldn't be interested. I love the show's concept but certainly not how the latter half was executed.

Despite this show being underrated this show amazes me, and still going. The combat is decent, intensity level is shown a lot, and Cain is literally the Dio (Jojo's Bizarre Adventure) of this show. Definitely, a must watch.You can have your own opinion on this show, whether you're watching or not, because you are missing out on one hell of a ride.Also, Liza is definitely my favorite character of this show.

It is a good monster vs monster slayer in a dark setting. It is however enormously depressing with its metaphor of CTE(athletes)  and PTSD(soldiers) rolled up into one big steaming roll of depression and candy wrapped with monster costumes. After coming to grips with that, you have to accept that the MC has to either eventually off himself in this story or they will find some cliché magic cure and he will live happily ever after with his jail bait sidekick. Both endings sound crappy i'm just hoping he ends it in a blaze of glory.

I want to like this and I'll give it another 2 episodes but I'm not impressed. I'm not highly critical of it yet either but for now it's just a bounty hunter anime with lots of action and ZERO substance. The first episode was so rushed, I quite frankly don't care about anyone in the anime. Ok, so he killed some ex-comrades...Who gives a hoot? Certainly not me.There is zero emotional impact on me. Why should I care that he's killing his friends, if he doesn't, oh wait, maybe this story should have been told at a different pace. Maybe each of his friends was important to him because there was a backstory for all of them.Well, there's no backstory, so I guess his friends are not that important and killing them, is as routine as washing your hands.

This hurt a little bit. After watching the first episode I could only think of over dramatized T.V. Novellas. You are bombarded with lore and such that really feels empty. Characters are slightly built with many of them being introduced and dying off within the same episode. It all lacks a lot of impact and it is presented as though it's supposed to mean anything. TL;DR there's so much cheese in the first episode you could host a fondue party.

Did you see the drum roll? that scene in the beginning made my panties wet. If the art remains consistent, this story of Micheal Jackson vs Wolvarine seems promising. Captain Ahab must uphold the oath, and maybe find his white whale, who took a fatal breast wound; or just collect an assortment of grills to fill the void left in his pancreas when baby beluga took one for the team.

I was looking for something to keep me busy while waiting for new episodes of Demon Slayer. I decided to try ASB and found the first episode very enjoyable. The coolness of the special unit walking up to the fortress and wrecking it caught my attention, followed by the enjoyment of trying to identify the various mythological creatures. The double cross and reveal of the villain was predictable, just based on the character design, but oh well. After the first episode, things started to get a little boring for me. The introduction of Schaal added some emotional elements, but her character is boring and complacent. Would have much rather seen her continue to hunt down Hank rather than become his little puppy dog. The thing I still enjoy is watching the creators' vision on myths and how they bring them to life. Other than that, it is a pretty typical action anime with good guys/bad guys and the relationships they build up till everyone is friends.

It may be because I only started reading the manga after watching the show, but the timings are different and, where manga-Hank had 5 years to get over what happened at the end of the war (no spoilers here), anime-Hank had only a few months. He's broody and alienated from everyone else and it makes more sense than quipping jokes while hunting down friends (ok, small spoiler but this is practically why you're watching it so, like, relax). There are enough shows out there that have that kind of hero/story - I like how this one always hits me in the feels.Also, Schaal has more back-bone in the anime than in the manga, and I hardly enjoy her meh-ness in either, so that also counts in the anime's favour. Lastly, I would be remiss if I didn't mention the incredible artwork used for the end credits. I never skip.

It is very okay, it sets the standard of an ok anime. I find the purple haired girl very shallow in terms of character, and I would think the same of Hank if it wasn't for the first episode. It's only in the first episode where I saw some of his leadership, emotions, and background. Now he's just someone that doesn't really captivate me. The only reason why I'm still watching is because the idea of him killing his former comrades even though he doesn't want to and because he's fulfilling an oath they made together, it makes me want to see their oath through and sympathize with Hank along the way.

The animation quality is really good for now and it works as a pretty decent story on its own, so if you have no interest in reading the manga then this is a perfectly watchable show but not the best one to come out this season.  (I'm really digging Fire Force.)  But do yourself a favor and check out the first manga volume on Comixology or some other digital platform.  You won't regret it.  As others have said, the pacing is much better and the story unfolds much more naturally.  Also ...--- MILD SPOILER ALERT ---Whereas the anime paints the Incarnates going as simply going wild due to some sort of defect with the process that turned them into monsters in the first place, the manga makes it clear that it was mostly due to PTSD and other psychological changes caused by the horrors of war and the change in sentiment towards Incarnates from civilians after the war ended similar to how Vietnam War veterans were treated in the US after that war ended.  It's a much more complex and compelling narrative than what the anime portrays.

After watching the first episode I have some initial thoughts. I do think that the animation quality is fairly high and the combat scenes were overall satisfying. The first episode did cover a LOT of story points in a short amount of time, which may have been a slight bit rushed, but still overall alright. I did not have a big issue with the show trying to convey the overall message of the story quickly in the first episode, though I would have liked it to perhaps be a 40 min pilot instead which would have made it all feel more properly paced.while the story is only just beginning I have some hope that it could turn out well if done correctly moving forward. That coupled with the satisfying action so far made me give the first episode a cautious 4/5.Hopefully, the show can continue to prosper.

I was really hoping this first episode was going to draw me into this anime. I had a lot of expectations. Expecting Decent Animation/combat:First fight scene wasn't logical in any sense. Upon the first transformation, the HUGE dragon, I expecting cannon fire bombarding this guy, but NOPE. Said dragon flies and wreaks havoc unharmed despite being so large. In the next fight, they all seemed to die relatively pretty easy given they were regarded as "gods" by the anime. Then there was the revolver. Like whut? Everyone else has muskets, but the Captain belonging in the "monster" group has a revolver...?Plot:Don't know what the plot exactly is because I got so bored I stopped 3/4 of the way. However, a lot can be assumed from just the title. On another note, one of the things I enjoy the most is how the characters progress through the plot; whether they achieve or fail as time progresses. Thought it was kind of lame how the characters interacted with each other. My last straw was the Captain's last battle speech. I found it weird how someone deciding to confess could raise morale in the group when the group is certain of their inevitable death in the near future.Complaints:It was weird seeing a Captain, an authoritative figure, acting so chummy and gooey about love on the battlefield. To me, it was just all sorts of wrong.

For the first episode of a new show, it kind of threw you right in... They threw a lot of plot at you really fast... It's like the guy who tells you stories about people you don't know and acts like you were best friends with them as well... And the whole time you are thinking who are these people and who is this random guy who walked up to me telling me this story... The issue is once you have been watching anime as long as I have you tend to have seen it all... SO what really makes a show stand out, in the end, is the character development and the interactions between the different characters...The first episode was interesting in that  Spoiler Alert! Click to show or hideit has a plot twist which made me wonder what will happen in the next episode... Because it made me want to see episode 2 i gave it 4 stars for now... So as far as watch-ability goes I will watch the next episode because I am interested to see what is going to happen next... So in that regard, the show was a sucess... Will it have staying power? I cant answer that yet... Will the characters develop over time I cant tell that yet... But what I can tell you is after watching the first episode (if you can make it to the end) you will want to watch the 2nd episode when it comes out...

The anime so far only has 1 episode and it was pretty good in my opinion. I haven’t read the manga but I saw some reviews complaining how they rushed through “secrets” but honestly from what I hear I’m kind of glad they did cause I would rather not have something that seems like “Irregular at magic high school” where it takes 10 episodes for us to get even close to a comprehensive knowledge into what’s going on.

EDIT after Ep. 8: Well this is one more show which simply gets worse as it goes. The only thing the show has going for it is busty blondes and their male equivalents. There is a huge lack of writing integrity here. It's like the writers expect you to know things they haven't mentioned about the world. For example, the first 4 episodes are about how the people are handling the end of the war well, everyone is happy to just keep rebuilding, or at least happy not to be shelled daily.Then episode 5 happens, now the following avoids major spoilers but still, I want my review to stay, so... Spoiler Alert! Click to show or hide Madhouse, a guy we saw once, alone, now has a platoon of beasts. So this platoon makes sure to destroy a town, drive Hank the hero mad, start a war, declared a new nation smack in the middle of the recently united one, raise an army, garner citizen support, and convince some "nobles". Remember,  North and South were democratic republics, now we have nobles... What? Whe...? H...? The people were fed up because, the town got destroyed, so they joined with the Incarnate because a visible Incarnate destroyed the town. I'm not joking this is ep 5. In almost as many words!Oh, there's more. So what does Madhouse offer? Remember, the NOBLES and their sympathizers joined him, so he'll be offering riches, or easy life, maybe glory? Nope! EQUALITY! Literally quotes Marx's manifesto! No, I am not kidding, the kingdom, formed by nobles and soldiers, promises equality to win over their sympathetic citizens.You may say, "that's realistic, people lie, its propaganda." Yes, but this lie is hilariously transparent. Madhouse is the Supreme Leader, self appointed, there are no elections, unlike in the Union they are revolting against. The Union had a president, house and cabinet (not congress). This is just an unbelievable thing to happen, even in world with beastmen. Why would citizens leave a democracy to follow the nobles to institute socialism? What... How? Why? Why are politics in my Weekly Beasty show?! Who did this hamfisted butchering?! Moving on...Also the people in the 4 episodes north and south were war fatigued. They were, like I said, satiated simply living. There was no visible class strife other than for the beasts. The beasts, Incarnate sorry, were the only ones stirring trouble, living poorly or as hermits. So this class strife is out of nowhere. You thought I was done? No. There's more. Now, since this New Piora Nation is accepting Incarnates, in order to stop Incarnates from joining, The Piora Union is planing on killing all Incarnate. Unlike what Hank has been doing... Killing all Incarnates. Yes the twist is, their new plan is to continue the old plan. Without Hank, so that's different, see? No. Oh, and now, instead of using Incarnate to hunt Incarnate, they are simply killing them, regardless of sanity. Like Hank, but without him, so we're supposed to sympathize? Feel bad? Be surprised? Who is spilling their Emo into a Weekly Beast hunter show?! Who was that obtuse? You do feel some for the Incarnate, but then you remember they cheated in order to win a war, and you feel better (read bellow for clarity). Just horrible writing for the sake of no payoff. There is no legitimate reason for you to feel for the Incarnate. Oh and they keep translating it Incarnates, no. They think Incarnates is ploral for Incarnate. No. Incarnates is the action of incarnating, "the Devil incarnates while devouring the soul..." Incarnate is plural, like a sovereign isn't he or she but They. You do not refer to Queen Elizabeth as, "she," but as "They." Bad writing and poor translations, are a bad mix. Should expect more from Comcast/NBC Universal  So, I took off one star. The animation is average, the music and acting can be asked for more, except for the end theme, and the writing is a horrible mess. If you watch this in a brain-in-hand stupor, you won't notice, but if you try to follow a coherent plot, forget it. Bellow are first impressions after ep 2.Aside from the main character looking like classic Wolverine, this anime has very little going for it. The animation was smooth for the most part, it's not very high detail though, ufotable's Demon [Slayer] has this beat. The music is acceptable, even good in parts, but the writing and direction absolutely kill the show. After all, if you don't have a story you simply have some animated monsters fighting.While I appreciate the buxom blonde in a short skirt fan service, I much prefer a good story. At least get me to suspend my disbelief for a moment. The show's description reads "forbidden technology" is used by the North to defeat the South. In the show that's repeated, but then the doctor who used this "forbidden technology" said it's the fruit of her "top secret research". I hope I don't have to explain why that's a contradiction, but I will anyway. To forbid something, it must be known, can't be a secret. Calling it "forbidden technology" implies that the South refuses to abuse their people, even if it means defeat. Two, it makes the North cheaters. I'm sorry but I really couldn't care less about what happens to cheaters. Any and all ills you get, you brought on yourself by cheating. These weren't unwilling participants. These were fully conscious, free, men and women who chose to kill people more honorable than them. That's your protagonist, how can you cheer for him in the slightest?So, the author couldn't make up his mind. Is this a "forbidden technology", or "top secret research"? Since forbidden technology is used more often than secret research, I am going to say this is forbidden technology, which the South could have used, but chose not to. As such, the show is worthless to me, because I don't care about its protagonist or his "friends", the doctor, or any of the "beasts". They cheated and murdered, they deserve every ill which comes their way.And before you start drawing comparisons between the show and the American Civil War, the show never states there are, or ever were, slaves, or the emancipation there of. This was simply a war between two separate countries who use to be one. It was a war for power, "unification", one side wanted to rule the other. Nothing noble in that cause. This is closer to north vs south Vietnam, than the civil war in America.Edit: However if the contradiction is some sort of translation error, the show's writing is still not good. The information is blasted at you at highway speeds, there is no character building for the beasts, and the main character is kind of lame. Hank, or Harry, whatever his name is, loved his childhood friend but never told her? Remember this is a 20 something soldier dealing with death daily. This isn't some teenager with nothing more than tonight's homework on his mind. So, the manga could be great! Hey, I love the monster of the week style in a weekly shorts collection. But come on, as an anime, this is lame! You can pack whole paragraphs in a scene, unlike manga, this has the space to tell a story in a much more meat and potatoes way! This isn't quarter dollar instant ramen, I expect you to have marinated the meat and smoked the cheese! Instead, this anime opens up with a machinegun volley of contradicting information. Forbidden brand new top secret research. Next week: Jewish Capitalist Nazis invade Canada for the wool!<- this was after episode 2. Episode 5 we got Socialist Nobles fighting for Freedom! I can't believe I was so close with what was supposed to be a joke.

Democrats are not my favorite people, and whats more a nation of them... Aww jeez! That by itself made me slow to pick this up and spring a chance, but as a lover of everything that is anime I looked passed it and gave it a shot. Hey listen it was nor good or bad just that the deliverance was kinda forcefully rushed and not well thought out. It's like going to the beach fun while your there, but you end up getting stung by a jellyfish and having unwanted sand up  your crack!!

I don't even know where to begin with this anime. It's incredibly off beat and certainly doing its own thing, and to be frank, there's really nothing like it on Crunchy Roll. The visual style, production values and overall timing of the show are nothing short of spectacular. I really don't need to make this review very long because if you're tired of seeing high school stories and want something more mature but not heavy handed, this anime is for you, and it's bound to be a classic amongst the likes of Cowboy Bebop. No joke, this could be the next big mature anime series, so get in on the ground floor for this. If the first 5 minutes turn you off, DON'T STOP WATCHING. You'll be thrown for a loop in a hurry. Join a misfit band of superpowered detectives solving cases against other supers who dress like it's the 19th century using abilities that are unique and interesting. Sure, the mature lead has an ability most of us are familiar with, but don't think for a second that this series is even remotely like Charlotte. This is its own thing, set in a Victorian-but-modern city dripping with awesome style, goregous animation and quick wit. The only thing that I'm afraid of in this series is that it'll be short lived LIKE Charlotte because of how expensive it must be to produce... but if the end credit sequence is anything to go by, I think we could be in for a good 24 episodes in this season at least. That's it. Just watch it, and be hopeful they don't go back on their promise for a second--or maybe third--season.

HERE'S A VIDEO VERSION IN CASE YOU DON'T WANT TO READ THIS WHOLE REVIEW! https://youtu.be/3ZsmcmewhGYWhen it came to the Fall 2016 anime season, this was really the only show I kept up with. I don’t know if you can’t tell, but I don’t usually talk about trending topics and that’s usually because I’m not on top of the 10’s of shows coming out each season. I was kind of looking forward to this season because I wanted some closure from the cliffhanger that was the first season, but what I got was… unexpected to say the least. Just to recap my season 1 review, which you can watch right here if you click on the card icon on the top right corner of the video, I basically said that there were quite a bit of problems when it came to the pacing, storytelling, tone, and the fact that the show felt way too black and white. Some of the plot lines ended poorly and the detective episodes were quite poor.Well, some of these problems continue through to season 2, but season 2 also improves on a lot of these issues quite a bit. It also adds a couple more problems that I may have not picked up on, but it was an overall improvement. There’s a lot to get into so let’s get into it.*transition slide into story*I really have to split all of the parts of this review into 2 parts: The first 4 episodes of season 2 and the rest of the season. That’s because the first 4 episodes of season 2 are completely disjointed from the main conflict of season 2 because it’s a backstory to how the Agency was created and Dazai’s time in the Port Mafia. Let’s give this a bit of analysis before we jump into the main story.*transition slide into First 4 Episodes*The story follows a character named Oda who’s a low level member of the Port Mafia. Though, there are a couple things that are special about Oda. He’s the friend of one of the top members of the Port Mafia, Dazai Osamu and another random guy, Ango. He’s also gifted with an ability that lets him see a few seconds into the future, which is why he’s one of the best members of the agency even though he isn’t on the top.The set up for these 4 episodes is basically a detective story, but actually done right for the first time in this show’s history. That’s because the show has more time to set up the events of the mystery, have time to get sidetracked and explore some subplots, and give a good amount of characterization that makes me really like the main character. Even the side characters got some exploration and motivation as to why they do what they do. Some of these ideas connect to the main story, but the majority of the events don’t. These 4 episodes had more of an emotional impact because they added so much to the characters without overstepping the bounds of the story.The pacing in these 4 episodes is divine. They kept each event on screen long enough for the audience to understand what’s going on, but nothing overstayed its welcome. It managed to do in 4 episodes what the whole first season couldn’t do in its run time. The tone of these 4 episodes was always more serious and more focused on the plot. The show never broke into a different art style for the comedic scenes and even the scenes where Dazai was making suicide jokes were pretty toned down. It really felt like the show I wanted this whole show to be. The ending also left me quite satisfied as it closed up all of the subplots and created a direct link between Dazai in the Port Mafia and Dazai in the agency. Though there are a couple issues with these 4 episodes.I may not have noticed this in the first season, but this show really over explains every detail at points. Characters go on endless internal monologues that seem quite unnecessary because they show the same information on screen. It feels like a failsafe in case people didn’t catch onto the details on their own. This problem also exists in the rest of the series as well.Another issue is that the main motivation for what occurred in the final episode of this arc was quite weak. It was based around characters the audience barely ever saw and it was only implied that there was a close relationship between these characters. You’ll know what I mean if you watch the 3rd episode of season 2. It’s similar to Kyoka’s near death scene in season 1, but done slightly better. There’s just more room for improvement with the execution of this plot point.So, the characters and story are better overall compared to season 1, but what about the music? Well, the music is superb. Every track fits the tone quite well and there are many memorable songs that add to the mood. The opening scene of the show displays this perfectly and really lets the audience know what they’re getting into. The creativity with lighting and the use of credits in the OP of the show adds a couple bonus points in my books too since it shows that they weren’t being lazy with the execution of this backstory. It’s a shame that the OP’s got less creative as they continued since there are 3 OP animations that all go to the same song. The overall animation is nice and the director’s choices add an oomph that I didn’t expect. This can specifically be seen in the flashback scenes and in the final fight scene for the anime. The aesthetic for summoning abilities in this show changed from Japanese characters to English letters. It adds some more variety to the visuals as the words are moving to create a sense of explosiveness when summoning abilities. The themes explored in these 4 episodes laid some of the groundwork for later in the series. One of these themes had to do with grey morality and how it’s really tough to see who’s in the right most of the time. All of this combined compels me to give these 4 episodes a 7.5/10. Too bad the rest of the series brings this score down a little. We should get back to the rest of the series for the rest of this review.*Rest of the review card*Many of the points I’d make for the rest of this show has already been stated in my season 1 review. The tone switches too much in this show, though it was better in this season by a bit. The comedy gets in the way, but less often. The show is paced at a super speed so it feels like you’re getting 2 episodes in one. There’s a huge problem with over explaining details the show shows on screen and the detective episode is quite weak. Unlike season 1, less characters are explored and less characters are given characterization. This makes it hard to care about the conflict when the villains seem 1 dimensional and stale. Actually, the conflict in this season is a plus compared to last season. The show turned from a 1-dimensional conflict that was barely explored to a 3-way war that has stakes and loss. There are alliances, traps, and more. This also adds to the grey morality I mentioned earlier, but as I said, it isn’t as good as it could be because of the weak characterization of the American and European writers. There are also random shonen power-ups that ruin the tension because every time there’s a conflict, there’s a random power-up that makes everything an equal playing field. It makes the show feel like a wannabe dragonball Z, especially when the power-ups look like a budgeted version of a character going super saiyan. The character dynamics are quite improved and there’s a decent bit of character development. Two specific instances of note are between Dazai and his old partner in the Port Mafia as well as Aktagawa and Atsushi. The first dynamic has so much chemistry within itself since these characters knew each other for so long and it shows in how they fight.The second instance shows a lot of room for growth since these characters never fought together before a certain point in the show. It’s just too bad that the show left off on a cliffhanger for an even bigger plot line that seems to have been foreshadowed for quite a while. The worst part is that there’s not a confirmed season 3 so it really hinders this show. The flashbacks of Atsushi and the repetitive dialogue of how Kyouka killed 35 people also make the show drop in value as it’s unnecessary because the audience already knows about these events. I mean, we don’t need to see Atsushi’s backstory more than twice as a maximum because it never adds anything new to his character. I already talked about the music and animation in the “first 4 episodes” part and all of that stays true here except for the fact that the visuals for the OP in these episodes lacks creativity. The title card is placed poorly and what started as a gritty world turned into a generic shonen. It really doesn’t hold up to its seinen tag that is has for some reason.Overall, this show has tons of problems and some problems that bother me now more than they did when I reviewed season 1. The cliffhanger is bothersome and the weak characters make the conflict less compelling. The character dynamics are better and have more room to be explored while the themes are explored poorly. The pacing is a bit too fast, but it makes the show feel like it’s always progressing. The arc of this season ends decently, but ends with one of the biggest deus exmachina’s I’ve seen in a while and the explanations of simple ideas make this show harder to watch. Even with all of that, I give this show an 8/10… in terms of my enjoyment. It was one of the few shows I kept up with this season and it kept me hooked. On a critical level, the whole series is now a 5.5/10 because, as I said, some of the things I noticed as a problem in season 1 became bigger issues, like telling instead of showing. There are a few stand-out moments in this show that get overshadowed by the mediocrity.Season 2 alone is a midrange 6 out of 10 since it has the 4 episodes that are just great.

I have never read the manga this is based on, but so far after two episodes, this anime really holds up strong. EDIT: I just want to address some points that I've seen come up now."There's too much comedy": We got a taste of this in episode 3, but the series gets really dark and brutal. Having recently gone ahead and read the manga in my spare time I can say that for a fact. If you're put off by the comedy in the first 2 episodes don't be."The ability names are stupid": For this one you need to understand that the characters are based on literary greats (I mean, Bungou does pretty much mean  "literary"). The ability of a user is a reference to the user's works in some way. "No Longer Human", for example, is the name of one of the real life Dazai's most beloved works. As nonsensical as the names are however, they're not as disconnected from what they do as some people seem to think: The name of Dazai's ability would be transliterated as "extinguish that which makes you human". The move "extinguishes" a user's ability. It's vague but it does tie. Doppo Poet, too, involves writing things down and "bringing them to life", which can be seen as a play on the more metaphorical way in which poetry does as such in real life. The list goes on too. All the powers names make sense in a vague way, while paying homage to the respective character's real life inspiration. I, personally, find it very clever.Anyway, now I've gotten that out of the way, the main point of this edit: Having seen the manga this is based on up to the 30 chapter mark, I can see that I'm in love with this series even more. Anyway, back to the actual review below which I wrote as a newbie to the series (I would have put this at the end of the review, but I wanted to address these points most of all) -_______________________________________________The animation is beautiful, and the characters movements all vibrantly pop to life. The premise is extremely interesting, and the characters are all quirky with their own lovable flavors. It's incredibly off the wall, as others have pointed out, but that adds to it's charm. I also went into this no realizing that the characters were based on literary greats, but now I do know as such, this anime has gotten me interested in researching the characters backgrounds, and their works, so that's a big added bonus.The writing is superb, balancing black comedy with a depth of character, and a serious underlying attitude - It's the sort of show that manages to balance it's humor at just the right place, allowing for some genuine depth and emotion to resonate from within the characters. When a show is able to make even suicide funny you know that it's going to be a good one. And this does it's black comedy superbly, never feeling in bad taste, yet never ceasing to push the boundaries either. And they somehow manage to make it feel respectful, despite itself.So far my biggest complaint is that the pacing has been a slight bit wonky at points, but that's a really big nitpick. So far this looks like a really great hidden gem. If this quality of animation & writing keeps up throughout the rest of the series, this is going to be one heck of a ride.

This has become one of my favorite anime ever. This anime has it's own style. It is easily the best anime of 2016 for me (along with Re: Zero). It has a motif of literature (like he names people after authors). There is a diverse group of characters. You will even like some villains. This anime doesn't leave you going "ugh that's all I get?" or the feeling of being left hanging. The endings are often suspenseful, but it leaves you craving for more, in the best way possible. Action, comedy, suspense, you name it BSD has it. The battle between the heroes and villains is a game of chess meets UFC with superpowers. The animation is beautiful. I personally find it best on CR on PS4 for some reason. Watch it. Love it. Demand Season 3, 4, 5, 6, 7, 8, 9, 10..

Seriously is a life changing type of anime. The characters they use, are depictions of real life authors/artists. It makes you go research the authors, then re-watch it to find little easter eggs... it's a totally re-newed experience.The storyline is a little comedic in season 1, but as soon as you hit season 2... it gets so awesome. I loved the beginning of season 2.Please watch and support this anime! I want more seasons.

This show has kept me hooked from the start of season 1 all the way through to where it's at. The character development and backstories are incredibly thought through and explained amazingly. You'll love one character and immediately fall in love with the next.The show has done an amazing job keeping the mystery aspect I love to see in shows with not just the story but with some of the characters. Even after learning a backstory of a character you still feel that mystery aspect towards them and I absolutely love that about the show.Each episode keeps you hooked, ready to click the next wondering what happens and in my opinion, that's one of the best things an anime can bring. No episode felt unimportant and I always kept going until I didn't have any more to watch.I can't wait to see where this show goes int he future!

Seriously, no other show has captured my attention like this one. There's something for everyone here; it's funny, it's dark, it's mysterious, it's dramatic, it's over-the-top, it's something much deeper than what it seems. The premise of the show is one of the most creative I've ever seen. Most of the characters contain a supernatural special ability, unique to each one of them, and those abilities are some of the most interesting and creative powers I've seen from a supernatural show in a long time. Even further, each character is named after a famous historical author, with all the Japanese characters holding the names of Japanese authors, American characters holding the names of American authors, et cetera; and the powers that each character has are based on one of the works of their namesake, as well as many other things about their stories and personalities. It's honestly one of the most enthralling parts of this show to me. Beyond the superficial parts such as that, the meat of the show itself doesn't fail to keep you on the edge of your seat the whole time. With complex, well-written characters, many of whom tread the line between "good guy" and "bad guy" so perfectly, an amazing plot that never fails to surprise you and reward you for watching further, and beautiful animation and soundtrack, there's very little I can say about this show that isn't the highest praise I've ever had for an anime.Seriously, watch this. You won't regret it. No matter what genre of anime you're into, no matter what you've watched in the past, you will love Bungou Stray Dogs.

[Review based up to episode 12, end of season 1]Comedy, action, supernatural, secretive organization, poverty, suicide...... this seems like a lot to take in, but Bungo Stray Dogs does it all, and it has a good plot and great characters.  It starts off more as a comedy but gets deeper as time goes on.  The animation is amazing, especially the backgrounds and the action sequences aren't bad too.All of the character's names are based on real Japanese authors.  It's interesting to see the parallels between these authors and the characters that bear their names.Here's a little bit of info about each author/character pair I found interesting.Atsushi Nakajima: main character in anime  (this spoiler is revealed at the end of episode 1)Spoiler Alert! Click to show or hidecan transform into a tiger Real Life Author: (1909-1942) Famous for his short story "Sanetsuki" (Tiger Poet) which is about a man who tries to become a great poet but ultimately goes mad and transforms into a tiger.  Despite this he eventually realizes his humanity and grows becuase of this experience.Osamu Dazai: supporting character in the anime, his ability allows him to cancel out other abilities.  He often tries to commit suicide (usually in a comedic way).  Real Life Author: (1909-1948)  Many of his works center around mental illness and human nature.  He also tried numerous times to commit suicide, finally succeeding in doing so by drowning in a river.Doppo Kunikida: supporting character in anime, his ability is call Doppo Poetry which allows him to create objects through writing on his notebook.Real Life Author: (1871-1908) Famous novelist and poet who brought in romanticism into Japan, and is famous for his lyrical poetry.  This series reminds me of Blood Blockade Battlefront and Fairy Tail in terms of supernatural powers and the idea of nakama/friendship.  The character designs are also a little reminescent of Soul Eater (the downward dropping eyes and facial structure) also the comedy is similar in taste.If you're looking for an action comedy that touches on tough topics, but stays pretty light and funny check out this show.  So far it looks like a show I'm going to stick with the rest of the season.

I think just pointing out something like its quite different art style is as good a place as any to start; something about the faces and specifically the eyes communicates so much more emotion than most other anime's I've seen. I love the connections to real-world authors both Japanese and abroad; the famous authors I could recognize from the character names were fun easter eggs while the Japanese authors I didn't know allowed me to learn and understand a small sliver of what Japanese literature was built upon the backs of. Character progression and a unique storyline also made this a fantastic work of art; it's honestly quite difficult to find any negatives when trying to write this review. I also personally love the blurred lines between the organizations and whether each leader or member is doing what's right in their own eyes. The struggling and the suffering certain characters are put through and try to grow past help strengthen, in my opinion, the overall story as well. The little comedic moments help break-up some the darker storylines and sometimes episodes could get a little abstract and weird, but that's something I would've missed so I'm not going to complain. All in all, it was/is a fantastic anime that I'd recommend wholeheartedly; hopefully there's another season in the future?

I wasn't sure what to expect when I started watching this series.  It pulls you in with quirky, charismatic characters and a plot with many twists (which could be said for many series, I know).  There is always something interesting happening and I have never found it boring. As they develop each of the characters, it makes for great storytelling with bits of humor thrown in to balance the drama. Many times situations look one way, but then things come to light which completely turn things on their head so it isn't predictable.  I do recommend watching the movie Dead Apple a couple of times, to catch things you may have missed in the first watching...as well as making the storyline a bit more clear.  At least that was my experience. I also read the Manga version.  Overall, I definitely recommend the series.

The art, the music, the atmosphere, the jokes and every little detail what this series has is a masterpiece for my soul.I remember when I started to watch it most of the abilities were a little bit odd for me, but after a few episodes everything just made sense by itself. How the story and the relationships work is mind-blowing!!! The fighting and the life lessons what it has still makes a huge impact on me. Yes, yes maybe I'm a little bit overreacting, but honestly, since I finished the season three it's hard to get as much involved into an anime as I was into this. My soul trembling and suffering because it wants more.Spoiler Alert! Click to show or hideAnd last but not least...Dazai and Chuuya relationship is a gold ticket for me! I just love them!!

OOOOMMMMMGGGG Latest episode AHHHHHHHHBut in all seriousness...If you like mystery, action, cool character please check out Bungo Stray dogs. As a fan from 2017 ( pretty late, yeah I know) it didn`t bore me out. Usually, after watching an average quality or not very populated anime you wouldn`t stick with it. Yet with season 3 coming out in April 2019, it was worth the wait. With memorable moments from the manga shown in season 3, who wouldn`t watch it. I highly recommend giving this anime a try, if you like a not big fandom, detectives/mafia anime with a dose of magical abilities and a whole load of charcter`s personal problems.

Let me just say that with how well this show is, it is surprisingly underrated. I remember dropping this anime on the on the first few eps when the first season was out but I'm glad I did because I just binged it all to the very recent episode of season 3 in a week. Season 1 does start off pretty slow but give it a chance. The more you watch the more action packed it gets plus the character development makes each of them important. The momentum keeps up in season 3, can't wait to see whats next.

I would take a bullet for Nakahara Chuuya, no questions asked.No, okay, all jokes aside, this is my favorite anime of all time, and this is coming from someone who has watched anime consistently for over a decade. I cannot even begin to describe how wonderful and multi-faceted all of the characters in Bungo Stray Dogs are. There are twists you don't see coming and, even being caught up on the manga, I still have no idea what's about to happen. The show is equal parts hilarious comedy, sinister adventure, and incredible fight scenes. I really struggled to like some characters at first (not naming names (Atsushi)) but have since pulled a 180 due to the amazing storytelling. I'm serious; this is a must-watch. I will be cosplaying from this show until the end of time. Words cannot explain how good it is.

When I first started watching, I was hoping this anime would fall under some of my most beloved classics. It seemed to have a similar feel at first to some of my more casual favorites but it didn't sadly. I will be honest, I don't think it had anything to do with the story or most of the characters, but more just personal interest. Some of the actions by two specific "sibling" characters hit my moral compass in all the wrong areas, I couldn't tolerate them at all because it was just so over the top at times.Spoiler Alert! Click to show or hide I do not recommend for anyone triggered by Incest or Public Sexual actions/displays/suggestions. And I mean this genuinely for people with actual triggers, not people simply offended by this.  I feel the story itself lacked something, I'm not sure what.
