Perhaps it was the pacing but it just didn't grab me. It seemed all to casual. I'm also a bit bothered with how much many of the characters looked like remakes of characters from Black Butler.

I wanna start this off, I love how they named the characters after Japanese authors, and their abilities after the books they've written. It's really a good idea and I would 10/10 buy the books that they wrote.I remember starting this show back in... 2018. I only watched the first episode and didn't even finish the first season. It wasn't until this year, after I met my girlfriend, we binged watched all seasons, including the movie. It's a really amazing anime, and all the characters are amazing too - even the bad guys. (Except Fyodor, forget him.)My favorite character from this is Chuuya Nakahara. I relate to him in a way; especially being short. XD Spoiler Alert! Click to show or hideSpoiler warning: Chuuya's still trapped in the book at the end of season 3 but yes, I know he makes it out and returns in the manga, and makes an epic entrance with a helicopter. Can't wait to see that animated. Overall, I highly recommend this anime; even for beginners.

Like many anime I make the mistake of reading the synopsis before watching them and I need to stop doing that. This was a fun and interesting anime from the start until the finish. If there is more I'll be sure to watch it then. Blah Blah Blah you get it. People have written enough about it I'm sure you'll get the picture. If you want something that takes up time but doesn't feel like poop when you're done I think this should do it, if not more!

I love this anime for many reasons. One being the action, one being the characters, one being the story, and one being the way they characters are developed as are their relationships with one another. This anime does character development really well, they also do progression with relationships in a way this is heartfelt and makes you invested in the relationship. Even if you don't necessarily like the character (as I didn't like some to begin with) you still get invested and drawn in watching their stories unfold and learn to understand them. The action is also done really well too, like the main character doesn't level up right away. He has to learn and battle and lose and get better, he just doesn't suddenly become good and amazing at fighting all of the sudden. Anyway, I think y'all should watch it.

If I could sum up this show, it would be shallow but fun.  As long as you can ignore the Marty Stus and the stupider then they think characters and ideas in the show, then its easy to find this enjoyable.  The action is fast paced, the comedy is enjoyable, characters are mostly well-written with one glaring exception, and the visuals are pleasant.  That said, for a more detailed breakdown of its problems, see below.For a work based on great literature, there is precious little development given to the ideas espoused by its inspirations.  Merely speaking a few words of supposed wisdom are not enough to actually demonstrate why its considered wisdom.  The show never bothers to explore anything it says, as if somehow just mentioning an idea is enough.  This is not to say the works it references are poor or stupid, but the viewer can't tell because the show itself doesn't do anything smart with them.  The literature referenced is considered great because it EARNS those lofty ideas through demonstration again and again of its themes.  The show certainly doesn't earn anything with its focus is on main characters, who while occasionally clever, more often then not just get what they want because they happen to be the main characters.The worst example of this by far is Dazai, who is supposed to be a legendary figure in the city they inhabit with a high level of intelligence.  Yet he does incredibly stupid things that only due to plot armor, 'cool' factor, or comedy allow him to survive.  If you walk to an enemy base, alone, and are surrounded by people with guns, and you have no supernatural ability to deal with bullets, you are going to die, period.  Even with another team member's ability to cure fatal injuries, they still have to be physically present and it takes time, and Dazai would be in tiny little bits, or shot repeatedly in the brain.  At some point it becomes too much to take because no one important in this show is in any serious risk at all, unless the author obviously wants a 'tragic' death.Another example is that any intelligent enemy would target the vulnerable members first with bullets, then kill everyone else.  Yet everybody in this show is too busy stopping to talk while giving precious time for the enemy to arrive before they actually try to kill anyone, and this happens OVER AND OVER AND OVER again.  All while this is happening you have characters making poses and exchanging one liners while we're supposed to believe this show is actually intelligent from its pedigree.  If there is a chance a fight might be nearly impossible to win without actual casualties among the protagonists, expect the show to cut away and NOT show how in the world the enemy was defeated without some of those bullets cutting down vulnerable members.At its core Bungo Stray Dogs is above average action show with some good ideas for abilities and characters.  It also has the greatest anime Great Gatsby villain I have ever seen.  I'd just like the show more if it stopped pretending to be anywhere smart enough to be referencing great works of literature and instead accepted its place as dumb fun for everyone.

I am surprised this was tagged for seinen. Do you need a super obvious main character that lacks originality? Low self worth, check, no family, check, guilt inducing life circumstance, seems to lack spine but is self-sacrificing, check. All the low tide markers for young boys to think it's coollllllll. I've seen it referred to as "comedy but then it get's "Real Dark"" you mean ham-handed mob references of "bad dudes"*tm? Nothing about "super bad bad guy that is bad and kills people!" is real darkness. Bad guys speeches are stupid, and the power activation is really slow. You could walk up to them and smack them across the face before they get done verbally announcing their powers. Plot is so cut a paste cookie cutter trope that it makes me want to gag. The bad guy isn't convincing or motivating. The dialog is super clumsy, badly repeating. Hope you like being beat over the head with the same "bad past flash back" 10 million times in the first 5 episodes alone. There is no tension or intrigue, and it's like watching people over act very poorly. Only good thing it has is the comedic animation, the faces and timing is well done. This is not for someone with a older taste for refined plot. Super disappointed, so many people raved about this and it is just so stupid and cheesy.

The characters are very interesting and well crafted. However the biggest issue is the story and direction is a bit of a jumble and some scenes could have used more work  Spoiler Alert! Click to show or hidethere was one scene where a character that was shown several times gets shot and I'm guessing dies, but since none of the other characters really reacted to him getting shot and he's never shown or spoken about again I'm left guessing  . They also have a problem starting up an interesting problem or character conflict then just suddenly switch gears to a different problem without resolving original conflicts in fact they flat out never address what happens to some enemy charactersSpoiler Alert! Click to show or hide they capture and run off to do other stuff.I'm honestly only sticking thru because some of the characters really pull their weight interest wise, although the writer does play favoritism for specific characters (especially Spoiler Alert! Click to show or hideDazai and Ranpo both who I find to be too childish of characters ) Honestly never read the manga but I'm considering dropping the anime to try it and see if it is maybe less erratic.

Don't know why i didn't give this show a chance.Back when i didn't have premium this is the show that was advertised the most to me, so back in 2016. I finally started watching it because it's made by the glorious studio Bones and holy hell was it worth it. Comedy, characters, animation, songs all stick to you because they're all unique and different in their own way (Dazai for example xd)The music kind of sticked to me the most, especially the OP of S2 and some of the fight scenes.

A set of high-fashion character designs move dryly through an underworld tinged with the occasional supernatural power in this piece that just didn't work for me. I couldn't care less about anyone here, didn't find the fight scenes suspenseful, and after a full season couldn't detect the hint of a theme or point to the whole thing other than, we've got drawings and a budget, might as well pump this out. Attractive and competent I guess, but not bothering to get into the second season.

(Solo vi hasta la 1er Temporada)Bungou Stray Dogs es una serie de acción con ligeros tintes detectivesco y sobre natural.Trama La historia gira en torno a Atsushi un chico que fue expulsado de su orfanato porque su presencia traía desgracia al lugar. Despues de un rato se topa con unos detectives y descubre que el como los detectives tienen habilidades sobrenaturales. Estos lo invitan a unirse y pelear contra las fuerzas de la mafia. Aunque la trama no esta mal realmente, tampoco es del todo original y tiene tendencias enormes al fanservice. El principal ofensor es la inconsistencia del ritmo en la serie, es una serie que busca que la tomen en serie en muchas ocasiones pero traicionandose a si misma rompe ese ritmo y pone un humor completamente ridiculo (y no en un sentido muy disfrutabable). Arte/Animación El diseño de los personajes es un general bastante variado y bien realizado, eso algo a remarcarse, aun mas con la animación no quedándose a tras. Las peleas aunque generalmente sin mucha fuerza siempre están muy bien animadas,Musica La musica de la serie no me hace recordar ni un momento en especifico, así que puedo decir que no es muy impresionante. El opening estate bien animal pero no crew sea visualmente interesante al memos para mi. El ending simplemente no tango mucho que decir de el ya que no sucede mucho. Resumen Bungou Stray Dogs es una serie que probablemente no era para mi para empezar. Aun así no puedo evitar darme cuenta de lo mal que es el tono de la serie, como si fuera una crisis de identidad no me logra atrapar e ninguna forma. En lo particular no la recomendaría a menos que te gusten las series con mucho "shipping potential". Le doy un 4.0/10

Note: This review is based off of the first two seasons of Bungo Stray Dogs.Similarly to Noragami and Chaika-The Coffin Princess, I watched this show because of Studio BONES. Studio BONES is one of my favorite anime studios, so I trust them enough to at least try to watch some of their works. Bungo Stray Dogs is yet another excellent work by BONES.First, what this show does right. The characters are definitely the strong suit of this show. People like Kyouka and Dazai are really interesting and fun to watch. They are developed really well and their interactions are interesting and fun. The animation is incredibly well done.  Motions feel fluid and realistic. Fight scenes are blood-pumping and action packed. The potential is available. The power system is incredibly unique and original. The OP is also well done. It's entertaining to watch and listen to. The story is strong and well developed. I only have one problem with the show. That problem is the pacing. The pacing can be all over the place. Sometimes the story moves slowly then picks up speed quickly only to come to a sudden break. This improves in the second season, but still needs some tweaking. Overall, this is an excellent watch definitely worth the time to watch it. The only problem is the pacing, but if you can overlook that, the show is great. I am excited to see what will happen to this show in the future. I recommend this show to anyone who is interested in watching it.Overall Rating: 9/10

I loved this show when I started it.  The art is really interesting, the interaction of the characters powers is really cool, the "teams" so to speak are interesting.  But as the show goes on, it becomes more and more contrived.  Every plot point or twist is painfully predictable or forced in order to progress 'poetic' relationships or interactions between the characters.  This is NOT helped by the fact that death is irrelevant to the main cast, because [LIGHT SPOILER] they have a person in their group that can basically bring anyone back from death.  And even that power is overwrought: it works or doesn't only depending on how 'exciting' it will make the scene or that part of the story.Season 2 is abysmal.  It's like watching proto-dialogue for 24 episodes; it feels like the writers outlined how they wanted the dialogue to go and then never actually WROTE the dialogue, so the characters just BARF out their motivations and what they're thinking.  This in opposition to actual dialogue where you can glean their thoughts indirectly from the dialogue.It's just lazy.  And when the finale fight is a classic "anime laser beams" fight I just said "I'm out."  Good god.

5 star rating cant compensate this value of this masterpiece if you dont watch it well its your loss lolI don't even know where to begin with this anime. It's incredibly off beat and certainly doing its own thing, and to be frank, there's really nothing like it on Crunchy Roll. The visual style, production values and overall timing of the show are nothing short of spectacular. I really don't need to make this review very long because if you're tired of seeing high school stories and want something more mature but not heavy handed, this anime is for you, and it's bound to be a classic amongst the likes of Cowboy Bebop. No joke, this could be the next big mature anime series, so get in on the ground floor for this. If the first 5 minutes turn you off, DON'T STOP WATCHING. You'll be thrown for a loop in a hurry. Join a misfit band of superpowered detectives solving cases against other supers who dress like it's the 19th century using abilities that are unique and interesting. Sure, the mature lead has an ability most of us are familiar with, but don't think for a second that this series is even remotely like Charlotte. This is its own thing, set in a Victorian-but-modern city dripping with awesome style, goregous animation and quick wit. The only thing that I'm afraid of in this series is that it'll be short lived LIKE Charlotte because of how expensive it must be to produce... but if the end credit sequence is anything to go by, I think we could be in for a good 24 episodes in this season at least. That's it. Just watch it, and be hopeful they don't go back on their promise for a second--or maybe third--season.

Honestly one of my top favorite anime's.  It's been out for quite some time but has only recently risen up to the surface and from what I know, the writer of the manga is still extending.  This is a series you will want to be lengthy because you just cant get enough of these characters and there are so many with their own background stories that make them so easy to connect with, including the villains.Bungo Stray Dogs is not our average Crime Anime. The real mystery is what surrounds the groups of highly gifted individuals and it's still difficult to figure out where the plot is actually leading too but that's what makes you want more!Oh! I usually dont like the main character as my fav... but.. <3 You are just going to have to watch this so I don't spoil anything. Enjoy!

I'm hooked. This show is fundamentally different from other shows yet so entertaining. It has basically everything I look for in anime - light humor, dark humor, beautiful action scenes, and motifs unique to the anime. Every character is its own individual, and you start to feel a blur between good and evil more and more as you watch. I fell in love with this show that constantly battles the meaning of life in both a comedic and heavy way. I thin this show tries to explain to the audience that we don't go through life in a straight line, the course that we want to. We go through hardships we would never expect, as we always expect and wish for what we can't obtain. The stories told by all individuals were so captivating, deep, and beautiful. Love this show with all my heart now, hope you guys can appreciate this series too!

Atsushi Nakajima, an orphan kicked to the curb encounters an eccentric suicidal man by the name of Osamu Dazai. As a thank you for saving Dazai from one of his many suicide attempts, he offers to help Atsushi with his troubles. Dazai happens to be a member of the supernatural detective agency, and decides to assist Atsushi in a problem involving a mysterious "tiger" terrorizing him. With the help of Dazai and his detective partner Doppo Kunikida, they solve the mystery, but it leaves Atsushi in a rock and a hard place. Atsushi is then coerced into joining their firm of supernatural investigators. Without an alternative for his future, Atsushi now begins his work to solve unusual cases and fend off against malicious organizations in the city of Yokohama.If I were to shorten my description of the anime, I would call it an incredibly grounded Blood Blockade Battlefront. To those that don't know what that means, here's your version. Bungou Stray Dogs is a supernatural, super power action comedy, with a good vs. bad story. The anime's biggest strength hands down is the various abilities and fight scenes, other than that it does boast a sizable cast of good characters. All having their own reasons for doing what they do, regardless of what side they're on though, all of them love their city, doing whatever they can to protect and nurture it. a fun watch I can easily recommend. Bonus points to Crunchyroll for also managing to snag the Bungou Stray Dogs movie Dead Apple for us.Season 3 edit:OK, season three of Bungou Stray Dogs was fantastic! It gives a lot more growth and small development between our characters, and the second half's major events were freaking awesome! The season three payoff alone is absolutely worth watching the entire series! Any opinion I might of had previously about wanting a little bit more from this anime has been completely defenestrated, and I can now wholly recommend this to any action anime fan!

The first season of Bungo Stray Dogs is charming and silly.  Then slowly towards the end of season one and the beginning of season two a lot of deep and somber undertones came out.  That where always there to begin with. No longer was Bungo Stray Dogs this charming silly comedic relief anime that I had thought it to be.  It was this dramatic symphony that really that really made hit me hard and made me cry. It really made me think that your friends should never be taken for granted and that there really isn't a fine line between good and evil, but that good was simply a little bit better because among helping yourself you are helping other people in the process.  If you have not watched Bungo Stray Dogs I strongly recommend doing so.  ( Plus the art style is beautiful and the character designs are really unique)

This show did not disappoint. The concept of using popular author names from both Japan and the west(but mostly America) was unique, interesting, and it felt so gratifying when you knew or recognized one of the authors. It was humorous when it needed to be, but it didn't let that take away from the anime being action packed with some dark undertones. My only complaint with this show was that it was not longer!. I was captivated by the action, the plot, and the very concepts. Even the side characters were reasonably fleshed out. This leads me to my other point. Characters. The main cast was really well done, from character design to backstory. The main character felt like someone we could sympathize with, while also being someone we could back in a fight. The supporting characters where quirky and wonderful, causing laughs and providing comic relief, but not being intrusive in the storyline. The anime also knew when it was time to properly flesh out characters, taking away the reins from the main character and the storyline. This was probably the shows equivalent to filler, yet it wasn't boring or plentiful, and added to the plot directly or indirectly.Overall, Bungo Stray Dogs was an anime that I do not regret watching, and would recommend to anyone who is a fan of their action anime

I was recommended this one by a friend, and trustworthy one at that, so I knew this would good and I wasn't disappointed in the slightest. This show's not only action-packed , but is also pretty humorous and creative, which I wasn't expecting. The concept of basing characters off of not only famous Japanese authors, but American ones as well and all their powers are based on their most famous works is awesome to me. Hell, the creativity and passion on this one practically flows out the screen and onto my bedroom floor. It actually somewhat reminded me of Noragami as well, especially in the action department. My one complaint would that I feel like the concept itself can more interesting than the actual plot in some places, which is why it's only a four for me.Overall, I highly recommend this one especially if you like action, comedy, or you're a major bookworm

I have to say, it took me some time to finish Bungo Stray Dogs but it definitely was worth the time. An interesting series nonetheless. What turned me off this time around was the "weightless" battles. Yes.. even to my surprise this series fell on the same old trap. I really had high expectations as the series appeared mature from the beginning. It was really funny to see how many characters didn't die in the series. For me part of a great battle are the stakes. Unfortunately in Bungo Stray Dogs the battles were magnificent, with evolving powers, powerful enemies and cunning schemes only to be brought down by the shallow aftermaths. Battles aside, this show had very nice artwork and interesting music and BGMs. The characters were satisfyingly developed but for the mature audience, a lot of questions arose as the series progressed. This was mainly due to the way the show projected new strong characters all the time while undermining the main characters. The scenario wasn't too much of a mystery in contradiction with mainstream tantei stories but then again it was humorous and light as well. I can't really offer a definite answer for its value but let's just say it is up to personal preference. Speaking of values, in the ending of the series values and beliefs were the main "engine" behind those final battles. The ending was good enough with clear indicators pointing to a second installment in the series.I have to say, the series was a black sheep for me. Not in a bad way though. It had a unique style that as many other reviewers said many enjoyed and liked dearly. As for me, i think Bungo Stray Dogs was really entertaining in it's own way. Unmistakably a great series to watch.

I didn't really care for some characters but overall anime was very unique and unpredictable. I loved the ending (episode 24) and the amazing individuals who grew into something even better, good and evil unite. I think I am just a sucker for awesome villains and great plot twists, this anime gave me everything I ever wanted; action, creative character design, plot twists, and the epic end battle and a happy ending.

Judging from the first episode, this series was NOT what I was expecting. However, I decided to give it a chance and man I am glad I did. The story is quirky, fun, dramatic, comedic, and so much more. The character development is captivating and a joy to watch. This series will make you laugh, cry, and, beg for more. The creative writers and directors for this show should be considered "Genius", as they have incorporated the personality traits of the real authors and poets that the characters are named after. The imaginative play on words and comedic references to the "literary masters" is both imaginative and educating of the Japanese culture. Need I say more? Definitely check this anime out if you get the chance. You won't regret it!

Great Show; but I wish it were longer. Had some great characters, but they didn't push some of them to their fullest abilities (namely Dazai, the Detective boss, and other enemy characters). Moreover the Dazai backstory was a little to abrupt, but added some very good flavor and feels to the show. Overall, great fight scenes, solid story and character development, plus the leads weren't super overpowered--except for Dazai.If you have a weekend where you want to binge a interesting anime, this is the ticket. It'll leave you wanting MORE...

Do you like classic lit? Do you like clever character design? Do you want to watch a show about super-powered detectives fighting super-powered mobsters, all of whom are based on authors and novels of literary merit?WELL THEN DO WE HAVE THE SHOW FOR YOU!Bungo Stray Dogs is a multi-layered, tear-jerking, visually stunning story following a lovable underdog character and his wayward mentor as they harness amazingly creative superpowers (like creating your own dimension and turning into a human fursona) to fight engaging and unsettling villains. Characters as good as this gang don't come around every season so definitely give this show a chance if you want a relatable and lovable cast that not many shows can give you/

I will say that this anime is fantastic. The best four episodes in anime are the second seasons first four episodes. I haven't seen something that good in quite a while. Not much else to say other than my direction at the audience. To those reviewing this anime and don't like Dazai's suicide thing, because you don't get it, perhaps look up his name...and the fact that most of the characters are based on authors or their works, maybe then you could POSSIBLY understand what it means when Dazai wants to commit suicide...oh heck...ill ruin it for you...DAZAI a real WRITER...killed himself after much thinking of what would be the best choice to do so...he walked into a canal and drown along with his 'lover.' which if you watched the show more than 5 episodes gives many allusions to the canal and his suicide which seems to bother people. THERE MYSTIQUE AND RESEARCH COMPLETE now enjoy the show after looking things up...or doing your own research btw the second season might give this mystique away after you realize all the bad guys are molded after foreign authors including the main bad guy............F Scott Fitzgerald.

...naaaanchatte! I have many words! But I'll keep it short.This show, I wasn't so sure about it just from the cover and the summary. It seemed like a historical thing, which I don't like, and idk I was just hesitant going in.However, this show has completely blown away my expectations coming in, and the expectations that continued to build from there. First of all, the art just knocks you out from the get go. It's beautiful, it's powerful, and it makes everything feel sharp and in-focus (if that makes sense). And most importantly, it doesn't hurt to binge watch it! Some shows make it hard to continue watching over a long period of time, this isn't one of them. Then, the characters, so wonderfully fleshed out and human. And the fact that they're named after famous and influential and renowned writers? Cherry on top. I still can't figure out where Lovecraft was from, and I feel like it's cheating to look it up! I am also quite partial to F.S. Fitzgerald, Spoiler Alert! Click to show or hideand I hated that I didn't like him and didn't know his motivations until the end. However, when he did reveal them, I hated that I couldn't really hate him anymore. I also hated that I didn't understand how acquiring the weretiger and that book would somehow bring his daughter back, but I'm hopeful that we'll get an explanation in season 3.  Continuing on... Season 2 really is just a pack of feels hand-delivered to your tear glands, IMO. At least, the first third(?) is. Ahhh, storyline was brilliant. I'm very good at deducing plot points, character actions, and generally being able to determine after a few minutes where a scene or storyline will go, but there were some moments where I was truly completely taken aback by the turn of events, which is much appreciated.The action was amazing, with the art the effect is just wonderful and exciting. It was also well-paced and not there just for the sake of it. Every little bit felt important (and not just the action). Spoiler Alert! Click to show or hideEven when I was wondering why they lingered on the Kyouka storyline when I thought they had exhausted it, they managed to surprise me with where they took it. So I took a breather while writing this, and came to the decision that the plot, characters, art, story, literally everything, were so perfect and complex that you should just watch it yourself.

Well this is one odd duck. Keep in mind I've been actively avoiding long running, convoluted, crowded cast shonen anime. And yet I still fall face first into them. Oh well, at least this one is good. But weird.First: this cast is huge. Only 2 seasons exist so far and there's a large group of "heroes" and larger group of antagonists, a third group of IDK-what-they-are's and many side tangential characters. Bring you notebook to keep track. Thankfully the designs are really distinct from one and other. Also they somehow managed to give enough time to most of the characters that you at least get a sense of depth if not a full arc.Speaking of characters, their powers are really cool and completely bananas. I won't spoil any specifics (seeing it yourself is too much fun). But it makes for a lot of great action. The animation is more than up to the task. Now the conceit of these characters is where things get weird. They are all named after authors. Most of the Japanese characters also "look" and "act" like those authors. I use quotes because the looks are updated to the modern day. For example, the farmer guys look like they came from today's countrysides. As for acting, folks with more literally experience will tell you they often act like what the authors wrote more than what the authors did in life themselves. You can see ANN's reviews for more details on that front. What's really fun as an American is that the foreigners are like ~characters~ from their namesakes' works. So "Herman M" look like Captain Ahab.~~Trigger Warning: Suicide~~Spoiler Alert! Click to show or hidePart of being based on past authors is that some of the authors had issues that show up in their characters. In particular is a main character, Dazai, who fantasizes about suicide. This is difficult because the real Dazai Osamu attempted suicide several times before succeeding at age 38. The character Dazai "attempts" suicide a few times in earlier episodes. Thankfully this trails off eventually. And we start to see story reasons for this behavior that makes things more sad but less gimmicky.~~End Trigger Warning~~All in all as long running, convoluted, crowded cast shonen anime go, this one is better than most. It's not that long (yet) and while complicated, you can follow what's going on. There are a lot of characters, but they are worth watching. And while the action follows the shonen trope of being crazy space bananas pants over the top, its wonderfully drawn. And there is (usually) a reason behind it. It's a pretty good way to spend 24 episodes. While much of the story closes are the end, there is so much room for more afterward.

i was hooked at the first episode. everything about this anime. the humor, the tragedy, the character development, the art, the story. it's just wonderful. i only wish there were more episodes so i could binge even more. honestly dazai is an amazing and creative character. turning something like suicide into such a lighthearted and comical thing was unexpected and certainly unique. this anime felt new. original.

At the time of writing this review, I've watched the entirety of both seasons 7 times. If I were you, I would start watching it before you even finish reading this review. You can even start right now. You won't regret it.This show has everything you could want: talented voice acting, a pleasing and somewhat unique art style, an entire cast of interesting characters, a plot that goes from zero to 100 and doesn't stop drawing you in, a pace that isn't too slow or too fast, and a unique theme.  Every character is named after a real-life author and abilities/superpowers are named after their most famous work.  However, just because you know the name of the ability, doesn't mean you know what it does (which I appreciate).  The characters are not just the namesakes, but also embody other characteristics of the authors (the manner varies: it could be their personality, interests, fashion sense, writing style, etc). It's very clear that each character was designed carefully, with a lot of thought.  The show is incredibly creative and somewhat more mature than many currently popular shows.  It is a genre mix of supernatural, comedy, dark, and action.If you like this anime, I highly recommend reading the manga as well (from the beginning, because if you skip to where the anime ends, you miss character backstories and all the moments the anime did not include), as well as the official parody manga, BSD wan.

I was skeptical at first getting into it and wasn't sure if I really wanted to get into it because it seemed weird? For lack of a better term. But I'm so glad that I gave it a chance and I'm so glad that I can recommend this anime to others. It's a show that's done very nicely and it's funny in a dark way. The first couple episodes of season 2 were my favorite. It is one of those animes where I believe that the secondary characters are much more likable than the main character. It is one that you have to keep watching for it to make more sense. I want more seasons of this one for sure!

Bungou Stray Dogs has everything you could ever ask for; Great animation, a wide variety of distinguished characters, and ever changing story line, plot twists galore, and enough action and mystery to keep you hooked. (The only thing missing is a musical number and a hot springs episode but we'll have to make due.) If you're looking for a new anime, look no further. Personally, my favorite thing about this anime is the fact that its characters are each named/based off the works of an author.

It took me awhile to finish watching the second season to give it a proper review. I liked the first season better. I watched the second season a little confused at the beginning, thinking that I missed key elements to the show. I had not.The story and it being a supernatural sort of show is definitely something I like. It had a fair amount of action and a fairly good plot to go with it. I would recommend watching this if you are just interested in a show that fits the criteria that I had mentioned above.

This anime is pretty good, but before I watched it, I read all the reviews and boy did they really hype up this show. Finishing season 1 all I want to say is don't read the reviews other than this, the anime itself is great all around, but people hyped it up wayyyy too much. I don't want people to fall into the same trap of reading 'OMG THIS ANIME IS THE BEST EVER' or 'WATCH THIS OR YOU'LL REGRET IT' or even 'IF YOU DO ANYHTING, MAKE SURE YOU WATCH THIS AMAZING ANIME' with everything being '10/10' and 'ITS MY FAV ANIME EVER'I fell into this trap and post season 1, I was kind of let down seeing as i've watched a whole bunch of Anime's and coming out of them pleased, satisfied and feeling accomplished, only to read reviews saying that it wasn't that good. Then I go to read reviews for this and think, 'damn, this must be amazing' only to see that its just like the others that I've watch and enjoyed.Sorry to be a buzzkill if you've read up to the end, but I think by now you get the point. Don't fall into the hype, IMO its always best to go into an anime with a nuetral mindset excluding the hype of others.

i have heard quite a bit about this anime and well, i wasn't disappointed. this anime delivered on the hype, even though i follows the time and true method, i still like how this story progressed and how even the supporting characters continued to play major roles throughout the series. such a well written and funny at times at just the right tempo and times, while also keeping a natural flow between the episodes. binge watch worthy for sure, i couldn't really stop after one episode either, just felt that good and had to watch more.

The art was great, the character arcs were great, the messages were great, the literary theme was great, and this show actually made me cry, which is difficult for an anime to do. (So many anime have tried to make me cry over the years that I've kinda become immune.)My one complaint is that at times the writing for individual episodes could be a little bit lazy. The episode with Rompo vs. Poe felt a little on the ridiculous side to me (and at first it had me super excited too... ;~; )But, other than that, I would definitely rate it among my top favorite anime. I will be buying the manga if I ever get the chance, and waiting in anticipation for a potential season 3. o(>v<)o

It took a couple of episodes for this one to really sink in but everything worked in it.   Once the premise was set they used the world they built to tell a solid story that felt similar to other anime I have seen before but just had better writing, better production, better characters, and overall better execution than the rest.  The first season is strong but the second season is where the show really takes off.

I originally heard of Bungo Stray Dogs last year, right before the anime came out. Although the title intrigued me, I was even more interested when I learned that the characters were based off of authors! I read through the manga all too quickly, and after watching the anime I only have more praise.The manga itself is incredible, and the anime does it justice! I was slightly worried about the adaption, but everything was kept extremely accurate, and the extra episodes are done in good taste and fit in well with the original plot. Not only is the story great, but the voice acting is perfect. The music is some of the best I've heard from a lot of shows recently; it really fits with and contributes to the overall feel of the show. It has been so much fun watching the characters come to life.Bungo Stray Dogs has the perfect balance of intensity, humor, and action. It satisfies all my anime cravings with lovable heroes(and villains), great atmosphere, creative abilities, and fantastic fight scenes. It deserves all the popularity it's getting and I'm so proud of how far it's come!And yes, I'm going to be  that person and say it: I liked Bungo Stray Dogs before it was cool.You won't regret watching this show!

Ok, kids. I have been watching anime for a while, since the original Astro Boy in the 60's (shows my age, lol). I've done all of One Piece, Bleach, Naruto, Cowboy Bebop, Space Dandy, Gate, Sword Art Online...you name it (except for the sports ones, just don't get it). This is, by far, one of the best out there. Fantastic characters, story line....the animation is just freaking....freaking....damn....beautiful. It really is.If you don't watch this, than you are truly missing out. Don't. Miss. Out.

I really appreciate this anime because of its unique characters.  Each character manages to feel real; characters develop at a steady pace, without becoming stronger overnight or being weak/wimpy forever either.  The animation is beautiful, and I find the literary references amusing.  Additionally, the plot is complex enough to be extremely engaging, yet not so overly complicated as to lose the viewer in excessive twists and turns.

From the beginning to the end, this anime kept you invested all the way through. With the beautiful animation, and great story- it would be hard not to continue watching. The chemistry between the characters, enemies and allies, were exceptional. I loved how it wasn't completely black and white, everyone had a reason of doing what they were doing, they were all their own people- not just bad guys and good guys. Not only did it make me cry because of tragedy, but it also made me cry because of happiness. The only complaint I have is that the ending suggested a third season and there's no third season.

If you’re a seasoned anime fan, you’ll have encountered innumerable entries to the ‘high school rom-com’ genre. Many are cheap and sloppy, full of two dimensional characters and hollow drama. There’s little satisfaction to be had watching socially awkward teens dance around their emo feelings for 12-24 episodes without providing any meaningful closure. But don’t despair, because Toradora! is here to restore our faith in anime, humanity, and true love stories.First let’s talk comedy. Toradora! has it in spades. Over-the-top slapstick, snarky repartee, ridiculous reactions and visual gags are all out in force and hit you when you least expect. While the second half of the show changes focus to drama and romance over the heavy comedy of the first half, there are still great laughs to be had in nearly every episode. To this day, “Smells…like…MILK!” never fails to wreck my friends with laughter. Bravo.Still, the true worth of a rom-com is in its romance. Jokes are simpler to write than the journey between two characters falling in love in a way that resonates true with viewers. In my opinion, most high school romance anime never involves actual love at all. Typically it’s just children wallowing in various stages of infatuation and obsession, yet too afraid to act on those feelings. However, Toradora! sets the bar higher yet again with characters who confess their feelings and noticeably mature over the course of the show. The emotions they convey carry vastly more weight as viewers can relate to these well-rounded and evolving characters.Yet I reserve my highest praise for Toradora!’s presentation of true love.  As I said before, ‘love’ in this genre is better labeled as infatuation. Even within Toradora! most of the romantic relationships follow that formula. However, the primary romance (beware vague spoilers ahead) is actually based on genuine love. These characters accept each other as they are instead of placing one another on pedestals. They value the other’s well-being over their own as if it’s the most natural thing in the world. With that honest love established as the basis of their relationship, the emotional payoff of their romance satisfies to the core of one’s soul.Of course, no show is perfect, and Toradora! has faults that need be addressed for this to be a balanced review and not the drool spattered ravings of a fan-boy. Especially glaring problems are a couple of events which transpired in the last two episodes. Unavoidable spoilers ahead.Spoiler Alert! Click to show or hideFirst, Taiga and Ryuji’s decision to elope makes no rational sense, even for teenagers. There was no threat that warranted running away from. They seemed afraid their parents would separate them and force life choices they didn’t want. However, there was no proof this was the case. They never talked to their parents even once to express their love for each other or big life choices. If they had, and the parents had been against it, then running away makes perfect sense. However, without any real threat, the choice becomes a contrived decision by the writers to add more drama for the sake of shock value.Secondly, Taiga’s choice to leave without a word to Ryuji at the end of the last episode is 100% the writers screwing with the audience. The character of Taiga we’ve come to know would never make the choice in a vacuum. Again it’s just more forced drama to shock viewers that makes no sense at all.Sorry about that for those who haven’t seen the anime yet. The short version is the writers make several decisions purely to shock viewers, but these choices make no sense and don’t have any real impact on the story.  Just cheap drama for the sake of drama. Both problems could have been avoided if these plot points weren't rushed into the final two episodes but instead had time to develop properly.My other serious issue regards the three main characters who don’t end up in the final romance. They are all written to be sympathetic and relatable, and you can’t help but root for them. However, they are given absolutely no attention in the closing episodes of the show. Happy ending or bittersweet, there is nothing done to hint at their lives after high school. After spending 25 episodes with these characters, I felt a hollow ache in my gut all day after finishing the last episode. I needed a final chapter to their stories, but the writers simply ignore them. It was a huge missed opportunity and keeps the show from having a completely satisfying ending.When all is said and done, though, Toradora! is an outstanding anime, delivering almost everything you want from this genre. Each episode relentlessly attacks with the laughs and the feels and, most amazingly, tells a real love story. Toradora! ranks up there with the very best rom-com anime, and absolutely deserves your time.

Characters: 5/5Story: 5/5Animation: 5/5Ending: 4/5Flow: 5/5Overall: 5/5How can one start about Toradora? Looking from the perspective of an outsider, there is nothing truly different about this show than the hundreds of other romance anime's that have been seen already. However, my opinion quickly changed upon watching the first couple of episodes, and turned into a deep obsession by the end of the show. There are just so many things that Toradora has correct, it is easy to understand any flaws that the show may have, which trust me, are few and far between. With a flair of character that the show gives off, there are just too many perfectly blended elements that work in conjunction with each other in order to make it the perfect romance anime.The plot of the story is as follows (don't worry, no spoilers). Ryuji is a young man that finds himself entering high-school in his second year. He happens to be in a class with his best friend, Yusaku, and his crush, Minori. However, he happens to run into the most ferocious female in his school, the Palm-Top-Tiger herself, Tiaga Aisaka. They don't hit it off instantly, but when it's found out that the Tiger has a crush on Ryuji's best friend, the shenanigans ensue as they try to help each other out in going after their crush. It is true that the best wing-men are those of opposite genders. Things change slightly when they coincidentally live side by side, and at the same height (they travel often to the others house through the window), and when Ryuji learns that Tiaga can't do anything on her own, he started playing the father figure in her life, by cooking her meals and making sure she wakes up in the morning.Mmhmm, innocent father figure, right?The one bad thing I have to say about this show is that it's predictable. There aren't too many twists and turns in the grand scheme of things, but the tiny little leans that the show gives you throughout the story are enough to keep anyone entertained. By episode five, the viewers will, sadly, know exactly who will end up with who. Or so they think. The story elements are dished out in a way that is more than enough to fill anyone, but it's like a buffet when it comes to this. Each episode is filled with plot important content, so it always leaves you with hopes and dreams of what can possibly be in the next episode. I was never bored while watching the show, and I could barely wait to hit the next episode button.Even so, there is one thing that contributes to the biggest success behind Toradora. If you haven’t guessed it yet, it’s the character development. There are five different main characters of the show, being Ryuji, Tiaga, Yusaku, Minori, and Ami. Each ones personalities are so unique, that not a single one of them can get enough screentime for me. Ryuji is the chilled, “normal” one that seems to be the voice of reason, moved along with the obsession to clean everything, yet shy enough to be just adorable when trying to talk to Minori. Tiaga is a very aggressive female character that can be oh so cute when she isn’t headbutting Ryuji in the nose. Yusaku is a popular nerd that takes school very seriously, but when paired with Minori, can be very eccentric. Ami is something of a (insert vulgar language that Crunchyroll disapproves of here), but in a loving way that you’ll understand if you simply watch the show. Now for my personal favorite, Minori, who is an insane teenage girl that quite literally makes me laugh every single scene that shes in. Seriously, just look at her. She can go from being an adorable love interest to a crazy psychopath in just a single moment. Each character get’s their own little backstory, and airtime, which means by the end of the show, everyone wants genuine happiness for all the characters. Throughout the show, I found myself wanting different characters to get together. One of the female characters would do something awesome, and I’d want them to get together, only to go and ruin it whilst another stole the spotlight, so I would cross my fingers for the new contender for a few episodes. These flip-flops of emotion just emphasizes the small turns that the characters go through during their development, and as you watch the show, your feelings for them change depending on their actions. Remind you of anything? (Real high-school love triangles).Sadly, the ending leaves a little bit to be desired, but to the shows credit, or should I say credits, it wraps it up well enough. The slowest part of the show can be considered the last three episodes, but even so, I still watched them with the same amount of love that I held for the previous twenty so episodes. One of the things that really upsets me with the last few episodes is the seemingly 180 rotation in character that Taiga undergoes. I truly liked her hard exterior that she threw up in front of Ryuji, but during the end, it became very rare. It wasn’t a Taiga that I liked as much as the original, so I didn’t feel as strongly towards her advancing slowly upon her goals. But still in the end, I felt somewhat glad that everyone was, more or less, happy to an extent. Despite the weakness of the last three episodes, it was still an engaging conclusion to a spectacular story about their crazy messed up love triangle.Despite the few amount of shortcomings that the show does have, Toradora is an amazing show to watch through, and easily makes it into my top 10 anime’s of all time. The predictability of the show can be countered by the small twists that occur every couple of episodes, and the characters alone are enough reason to keep coming back, even if the show didn't constantly push itself gracefully through the story line. I definitely recommend Toradora to everyone, of both genders, and all ages, for one of the most adorable, comedic, and comfortable romance anime’s on the market.

I absolutely loved this show. I normally enjoy romance shows, but the depth and the dynamics of the characters really set this show apart from any I have watched before. There was a maturity to this show, and at certain places, things got really really "real". I was left somewhat unhappy by the ending, but mostly just because the show was over. YOU NEED TO WATCH AFTER THE CREDITS, OTHERWISE YOU WILL BE INCREDIBLY DEPRESSED. This show really becomes something else in the last couple episodes. Episodes 20-25 are like an incredibly different show, and it will hurt your heart a lot. I promise you will not be disappointed by Toradora.

Teenagers are odd creatures.They can experience unforgettable joy and heartbreak within minutes of one another, and they are just about as predictable as a lightning strike in clear skies. However, in most media, they are rarely portrayed realistically, and this includes stories centering around them. Male protagonists have an annoying tendency to be 2-Dimensional Every-men that try too hard to seem "relatable" but just make it clear that the author has completely forgotten what it is like to be a high school student.This is not the case with Toradora.Each and every character in Toradora was made the way they are for a reason. Each and every one of them has a personality, hopes, and dreams guiding them. Though they are only works of fiction, the realism of the emotions they feel makes you hold them dear to your heart, making you care deeply for them as the series progresses. The series guides us through the joys, pains, and confusion of young love in such a realistic fashion that one could almost believe that it was a true story.Toradora is a truly beautiful story, and I highly recommend it to anyone and everyone with a device on which to watch it.

If you're seeking to step back from the action a bit and take a break, Toradora is highly recommended!   A perfect series for a seasonal endeavor. Although a very mushy and sappy romance genre, the series brings warmth to your heart and brings the viewer closer to the characters emotions and overall dynamic. You can relate to the characters in some ways and that is certainly what you want from an Anime.  Toradora is a series that you can't just watch once. You will feel the overall emotion throughout the whole year after finishing it, making you want to watch it multiple times. A great schedule for watching it is - [Nov. 30 - Dec. 24] - If you start it the last day of November you can finish it and watch the finale on December 24, the day before Christmas!Enjoy!

I know that in some ways anime's can be very predicting and even annoying at times at how predictable they are... But seriously, this anime's character development is quite unique! It constantly reels you in! The best part about this is that in some ways Toradora! teaches you about what love is in some ways... We are taught from a young age about what love is supposed to be and in some ways that's how Ryuuji and both Taiga start off with what they were taught love is- it necessarily isn't wrong- but it basically focuses on that you should love in your own way. They go from what a crush is vs. admiration of someone to actually finding out love is just being there for one another.Every character in this show has their own ways of learning love too.Minorin - to love herself before she can love othersYusake (I think I spelt his name right) - that we can love someone, but have to do things for ourselves first sometimesThe President - that even if we love someone, we need to focus on their goals and dreams in life tooAnd Ami - that loving someone isn't putting them up on a pedastool, but valuing them like an actual human being.Toradora! is love :)I will recommend it continuously to many people and already have!

My first real experience with a Rom-Com was with 'Toradora!'. I cannot fully express how happy I am that it was 'Toradora!' and not some other Rom-Com. To me, 'Toradora!' displays all of the fundamental mechanics of a romantic/comedy, while also making the characters very interesting and lovable. I find in some Rom-Coms that it is very difficult to find the right mixture of lead and supporting characters, however in 'Toradora!' I could not ask for a better combination. Everyone (especially Inko-chan) fits perfectly into this incredible anime. Watch it now! Then watch 'Golden Time', they were both created by the same person and 'Golden Time' is very feelsy! Enjoy!

Toradora is one those anime's you just don't watch. You absorb this anime. Why?Between the characters, the plot,  the seiyuu, and the ending it all leaves you satisfied that you watched it. I have read the light novels and this anime closely follows it to a t leaving few minor details that don't really matter(except at the end Taiga mentions that she lived near by Ryuji). This is my first review for anime that made me(a cop) cry.I highly recommend this anime and give it 100/5 stars.

Toradora is a story of a boy named Ryuji and a pint-sized firecracker named Taiga. It follows them as they meet all the various challenges that life throws at them. In truth, it sounds quite bland, but a simple sentence describing this show can in no way do it any justice. Behind this normal-sounding plot hides some of the most charming and deep characters that I have ever seen in my (embarrassingly long) time watching anime. All the characters seem to be quite formulaic, but every last one of them conceals wonderful surprises that are waiting to be discovered. The interplay between the colorful cast of characters makes you really love every last one of them. This is a show that delivers on the promise of laughter, tears, and a whole mess of fun. If you haven't seen this show yet, do yourself a favor: quit reading and get watching (and for GOD'S SAKE watch the last episode to the very last second after the credits!!).

ToRaDoRa!I was working in a campus computer lab last year, was three weeks ahead in all of my college courses, and had nothing to do. So I watched ToRaDoRa! Why not? I'd never heard of it before and wanted to watch something other than Code Geass for the ninth time, although Code Geass is anime gold, but... You know what I mean. I didn't think much of the show and decided it would just be filler until my next test...Twenty-five episodes later I had stayed up three nights in a row without sleeping, laughed my head off countless times, and cried twice. Through the writing, voice acting, and story I felt immersed in the lives of these characters. By the end of the show you have actually grown to like these characters so much that you miss watching the show.You will root for your favorite character and cry with them by the end of the show. I cannot recommend a more beautiful anime to watch. The animation and art are gorgeous, the characters are well developed and written, and the dialogue (and monologue) is realistic and funny. The characters are written and developed in a way that makes you feel like they are based off of real kids. Most anime based around the high school days rarely portrays the characters like most high school kids really are. There's always some whimsical, supernatural oddity going on and high school is just the cover story for it.ToRaDoRa! simply tells a story as if it were taken out of a real teenager's diary and made into a screenplay. Whilst watching I could relate to the things the characters were going through and experiencing, unlike many of the anime I have watched where I cannot relate to the characters in the slightest. ToRaDoRa! is a story of real life and it is portrayed realistically and beautifully without fluffing up reality or making it out to be what it is not.The show leaves you with just enough information that you don't feel like every episode is a cliff hanger, yet you still feel the urge to keep watching until you finish it! And once you have finished it you will either 1. Cry tears of joy or sadness depending on who your favorite character is.2. Watch it again.3. 1 and 2.What more can I say? This anime is beautiful. The story is what makes it so good. It could have been a book for all I care and I still would have loved it. Watch it, adore it, love it!-Mikael

I really enjoyed this one, If you happen to be a member atm this is a must watch. I am normally not a huge fan of romantic comedy’s but, a friend I really trust recommended this one to me, so I thought I would give it a try and I’m happy I did. This show has everything, comedy, romance, character development, and it actually ends on a satisfying note (at least for me, may not be an ideal ending for everyone). Overall, it’s a good watch and Taiga is just too funny. If you end up really enjoying this one I would highly recommend watching "My Little Monster" (see my profile for a review), and if you’re looking to take advantage of your membership then I would recommend watching "Kimi ni Todoke - From Me To You" (review also on my profile). Most of it is also limited to members. Hope you enjoy Toradora as much as I did!!

I normally try to avoid spoilers of any kind when writing reviews, but I can't with this one.  Until then, I'll make a brief spoiler-free intro, and after I'll make a brief spoiler-free outro.**My opinions expressed here are solely calculated and intuitive observations.  Being that my reasoning behind my review is somewhat controversial, I realize some self-serving internet extremists will find this "not helpful".  To all those who read this, please take only into account what I have written, not what people say about it.  That is all I ask.  I'm not saying you should agree with me, I'm asking for you to respect my beliefs and opinions.  Thank you.  I wish I didn't have to write this, but the internet being what it is, I must.**To begin, this was probably one of the best animes ever created in terms of story and development.  All characters, even supporting ones, get an incredible dosage of character development and you learn to love all of them.  There is no sudden and unexpected change of attitude or random plot holes.  To tack on with that, the sheer and incredible infusion of advanced story-telling elements is incredible.  The thought-provokingly awesome symbolism and irony leaves nothing to be hated.This could have been a legendary anime.  It could have been perhaps one of the greatest animes of any genre ever created.And then the writers tripped up on the ending.  And yes, I watched past the credits.  Yes I understand the implications.Before I begin the true review, I will leave a couple words for those who wish not to take spoilers.In the end Ryuji has three choices, essentially, of relationship paths to take.1) Really good ending.2) Tear-jerkingly amazing ending.3) Absolutely, needingly, undeniably best ending.*~*~*~*~*~*~*~*~*~*~*~*~*~*Spoiler Alert! Click to show or hideThis anime was really good....And that's all it is.In order, the above choices were between Taiga, Minori, and Ami.  So yes, I am saying that the creators took the worse of the three routes.Taiga's was the "safe" path.  It was predictably obvious and drastically unrealistic.Let me explain.Taiga and Ryuji functioned best as a family-sort.  Ryuji being the father-figure Taiga never had, and Ryuji finally getting the chance to take care of someone like he always wanted.  Their relationship helped push both of them out of the false, isolated paths they were both in at the social level.  They boosted each other into the spotlight and helped each other become okay with who each other was.  But that's as far as it should have gone.  I can honestly say I am not 100% convinced by their "mutual love".  Shoot, I act as Ryuji does towards multiple people, some of the opposite gender, but never would anyone be fooled that we share any sort of feelings beyond friendship.  Love just doesn't happen the way this anime depicted it to.  Love doesn't just "happen", contrary to popular belief.  There is always a reason for it.What makes the fact that their relationship was turned the wrong way is the way the ending of the show went.  The final 6 episodes were drastically different than the anime's feel, which is totally okay normally; but this time around, the show lost sight of its original path and fell to nothing but angst and drama.  This was especially prevalent with the final two episodes.  There is absolutely and unarguably nothing but built-up hope and passion that the classmates will be together forever.  Obviously not entirely possible, but in order to not totally lose sight of the anime's true nature, the creators were forced to take a path that isolated everyone from each other, essentially.  I'm not saying that the feelings weren't right, and given different circumstances it would have been the best possible ending.But cue stage entrance left, Minori Kushieda and Ami Kawashima.Let me start with the first.If Ryuji paired up with Minori, this anime would have been absolutely stunning.  Easy 5 stars, easily on my top 5 list.Minori is fairly clearly only airheaded for the sake of avoiding pain.  She is a character who has so helplessly fallen in love with Ryuji but keeps pretending she isn't for the sake of Taiga.  She makes arguably the biggest sacrifice for her friend.  She gives up her own happiness and her only love for someone else.  She doesn't just smile through her tears, she laughs while her heart is speared by a toxic-soaked diamond blade.  Admirable, sure.  But not okay in terms of story development.  It doesn't feel right as a watcher to see her pain.Not to mention that Ryuji did truly love her, and she truly loved him.  It was a mutual feeling and the writers should not have let this one slip through the cracks as if it was okay.  I am NOT saying that people can't get hurt.  But unnecessary pain is not okay.  Because by any means the reason they didn't end up together is because Minori bottled up her heart.But any other note, why is her relationship not the best ending?Because Ami Kawashima.She is by no doubt the most incredible character in the story.  She isn't flawless, and she knows it.  But she found her true self.  She is the wisest and most realistic person in the entire show.And the most self-sacrificing and loving character we will probably ever have the honor of seeing.Ami loves Ryuji for the most legitimate reasons of all of them.  She learned who he was as a man.  She accepted him as a person, as he did her.  And slowly, surely, they consistently saved each other and covered each other's 6.  As Ami said, they were on equal playing field.But unlike what she said, she wasn't always one step ahead of him.  After the scene in the gym shed where she was making ornaments, she fell hopelessly a step behind.  She wouldn't just come out with her feelings and kept talking in code.  She was always reaching out when he ran off to be a hero or of the sorts.  "But wait..."And she did nothing.  Completely OOC.Now Ryuji was listening,  And Ryuji probably would eventually have deciphered what she said.  But Ami made one mistake.She ran away when Ryuji needed her most.  I'm talking about when he was shot down by Minori (for Taiga's sake).Ami, like Minori, gave up her honest and real love for Ryuji.  But this time, she did it for someone she only recently met.  She was sacrificing herself for the others, trying to maintain a balance that could never be kept.I cried once this anime.  And it was after the shoe scene with Ami.  After that, I lost all traces of any sort of hope for an "Ami route".  She had given up.  By snatching her shoe from Ryuji and storming off (which by the way the shoe represented her refusal to just come out with her feelings and give herself up to Ryuji), she had finally and officially quit all pursuit of Ryuji.  And I bawled my eyes out.I could only think of one thing:"Ami won't get Ryuji."My heart closed up after this scene and has remained bottled up for the last 3 days.  I still get on the verge of tears thinking about the loss Ami suffered.I don't feel that way for any other characters.  If Ryuji went with anyone else, I would only ever feel upset for Ami.If the creators took this ending, it would be the first anime I have ever seen that I would give 6 stars....Ryuji's head was awash and a mess after his rejection.  Honestly, he probably liked all three girls equally, but didn't go so far as to love any of them yet.  But given his character development, the first one to be honest with him won.And Taiga won.  By pure dumb luck of mumbling to the wrong person in a half-conscious state of blurred unawareness.After episode 8 it became a struggle for me to watch because I saw the direction the anime was taking, and I didn't like it.  After episode 18, I had to sit on my hands to prevent myself from skipping episodes.I love everything about this anime, but the fact Ryuji ended up with Taiga is not okay. *~*~*~*~*~*~*~*~*~*~*~*~*~*This is an anime that could have been legendary.  But it took the safe route and only ended up good.If you are a more intellectual viewer, and you care mostly about the relationships in animes, I'd actually recommend you not watch this unless you have no other animes to watch.  It becomes a struggle to watch through the scenes knowing the ending route its taking, and at the end you heart yearns for more, but not in a good way.  You want to change the ending, and you will spend a decently large portion of time, wasting time thinking about what it should have been.I'm not accusing anyone who loved this anime as being stupid or discrediting their taste.  If you loved it, good.  I am happy you found enjoyment out of this, because that is what this type of anime is for.However I will say this: Toradora! Portable is a fantastic game that allows you to redo where the anime screwed up and take the ending you wish.  So if you make it through the anime and, like me, wish to fix the problem of the ending, then play it.  At the very least it will help you get the thing the clinging to your heart off.I'm not saying the ending was wrong, because it wasn't.  I'm not saying the anime isn't fantastic, because it is.  I'm not saying that the given character who Ryuji ends up with is bad, because she isn't.But this could have been my first ever 6-star anime.I guess I keep on searching.

Toradora is a series that defines its genre, and in my opinion is a wonderful example of anime as a story telling medium and the art form as a whole. On the surface, it seems like a fairly simple love story, but dig in a little and you'll see that it's so much more than that. Toradora shows what it means to fall in love, and it shows us that sometimes nothing is everything. Once it's all over, it leaves you wanting more but at the same time knowing that any additions couldn't do justice to what you already have. The strength of a romance lies in its characters, and Toradora delivers. The characters are all extremely well written, as are their dynamics with each other. The words they chose to say and actions they take all make sense for who they are, and you're never left wondering why the characters do and say the things that they do. You're happy to see them happy, and you're sad when they're sad. The characters are all easy to empathize with, and we've all been in their positions at some point. Repeat viewings especially illustrate that point, as it can be easy to miss some of the more profound moments the first time through. In short, even if you don't prefer romances or slice of life series, Toradora is worth your time. I honestly believe that Toradora is a series that every anime fan should watch at least once, and that it has the strength to convert non-fans. As I said before, Toradora is a true example of excellent storytelling and of anime as a whole. I really can't recommend this series enough. ________________________________________________So, everything above this line still holds true, and applies to the dub version as well. While the dub isn't perfect, it certainly lives up to what fans should expect for such a wonderful series. I'll be the first to admit, when I heard the dub voices in the trailer for the first time, I wasn't sold. That said, the voice actors brought their A games for this one, and they do a fantastic job of giving each of the characters the personality and spirit fans of the Japanese version know and love. As someone who loves this series, I can happily say that the dubbed version lives up to the original, and I whole heartedly hope that this release will introduce more people to this incredible series and create a whole new group of fans. If you were a fan of the original, I encourage you to watch the dub as well, it certainly does not disappoint.In short, whether it's the original Japanese or the English dub, 「とらドラ」というアニメが本当に大好きだよ！

An anime that always blows away a person the most is one that he/she had little expectations for, and Toradora is the best example I can think of.  After I saw this anime I felt like I had to text everyone I know and demand that they watch it now, until I realized, not many of my friends like anime... The main quality of Toradora that amazed me so much is the character development, there is not one useless character in this show. It's a story that's been done so many times, but Toradora gets it right. It's no surprise that the director of Toradora also directed Honey & Clover 2, another very highly regarded slice-of-life anime. There are some viewers that would say this anime is flawed, but in my opinion that's the beauty of it. Yes, there are some flaws, but it's impossible to have a perfect anime. The fact that there are flaws and it still manages to be one of my all-time favorite anime is the true greatness of it. There might be an anime out there that is "better made" than this one but there is no anime with a bigger heart, which is truly a measure of excellence. I often compare this anime to another one of my favorites, Cross Game. I would say Cross Game is nearly as good or tied with Toradora because both have amazing character development. Cross Game is slower and longer, but if you loved Toradora, definitely give it a shot. Both of these anime will be regarded as classics for years to come.

There is something strangely unique about Toradora.Down from the way it begins, to the way it ends. There is just something strange about it and I could never quite put my finger on it. As I rewatched this anime, I have realized that it was indeed something beautifully orchestrated. At first you think you know how it is going to end, and y'know what, you may just be right. But understanding the ending does not make the content inbetween anyless important. And that is where Toradora shines.Scene from Scene, this anime captivates your mind. It keeps you intrigued, have you laughing while moments later you will feel sadness and anger. This anime is very good at drawing out the emotions in characters, the development between each one is perfect. As those character you first think are shallow, eventually flesh out to have far deeper meanings behind their actions.Especially Minorin.So, that is why I rate this five stars.If you seen animes like 'Pet girl of Sakura-Hall'. And enjoyed it, this will be a pleasant experience for you as well.

Story PreviewSpoiler Alert! Click to show or hideOn the outside, Ryuiji looks like a tough mutt. He has the image of a delinquent. However, people misunderstand him. On the inside, he is really a nice boy, overflowing with kindness, and has the cleaning and cooking abilities of a housewife. Starting his second semester of high school, he runs into the palm-top-tiger, named Taiga (Tiger sounds just like Taiga haha). Taiga is a bossy, cute, "midget", but with a deadly personality. The duo use each other get closer to their crushes, but end up questioning themselves...is it really them that they love?Personal RatingsAnimation - AStory - A+Ending - A-Back Stories - B+Heart crusher - A++I'm an anime veteran. Like seriously, I've watched a heck load of anime. Out of all the years I've watched these shows, there's never been one as moving, and heart-gripping as Toradora. I'm a guy, so usually i'm not the least interested in these types of anime, however, i'm not the least regretful. This is the only anime with an ending that i'm completely satisfied with...but also unsatisfied with. There's a void in my heart that only a show like this can fill. I'm satisfied with the ending, but unsatisfied because that it ended (weird cycle, I know). I sometimes find myself awake at night, wishing there was more. That's how powerful this anime was to me. I gave it a shot, so should you.

I can count on one hand the number of school romance/slice of life animes I've watched to completion. Most of the genre I stop watching after only a few episodes, and I generally avoid the whole genre altogether. I don't know what possessed me to give this one a shot, but I don't regret it... ok, maybe a little bit, my butt hurts from being glued to the screen marathoning the whole thing. Bottom Line Up Front: if you like romantic comedy, school drama, slice of life shows, watch it. If you're not sure, give it a shot. If you don't like the genre, still give it a shot. I'm not a big fan of the genre, but I thoroughly enjoyed watching the show, enough to even write a review about it.Here's the long version of the review:Toradora is a romantic comedy in a Japanese high school setting. There are two main protagonists with three other major supporting characters. The story centers around these five characters and their interactions, feelings towards each other, relationships and hardships. Ultimately it is a love story, but more than that it's a dramatic coming of age story. There are many references throughout the show on maturity and the passing from childhood to adulthood, and it's interesting to see the symbolism employed to bring out that theme and how each character, with their unique personality, approaches it. It's subtle at first, but each character develops so well, not too quickly, not too much, but just enough to let you know how much they've grown. Some may consider the character development "incomplete," and it some sense that is the case. There are many loose ends and unanswered questions at the end, but the show ends beautifully, just where it should. There's a line in the show that goes "We are far too young to talk about life philosophy, we still have at least 10, 20, 60 years ahead of us," which seems to suggest the "loose ends" were intentional. The climax and ending is pretty typical and predictable, but a last minute twist on the story would not be suitable, and it would only cheapen the show as a gimmick. There is plenty of "fan service," but not so excessive that it takes away from the story or characters.Characters:Ryuji Takasu - one of the main protagonists. Typical nice guy, with qualities suited for a housewife - good cook, enjoys cleaning and other sorts of housework. His character twist is that he has hard eyes that make him look like a delinquent and therefore everyone at school treats him like one. Unfortunately, his character development was a bit disappointing. There were some small movements in the end, but overall didn't develop as much as the other characters.Taiga Aisaku - other main protagonist. Short definition: napoleon complex tsundere character. The initial impression of her is that she is a spoiled princess type. Feisty, short tempered, strong and quick to get into physical confrontations. She doesn't have a very nice personality and can barely take care of herself (lives like a slob). Pretty good character development, a bit predictable, but it was done really well. She ended up a depth and dimension rarely seen with characters of her type in most other shows.Yusaku - Ryuji's best and only friend at the start of the series. He is vice-president of the school council, class representative, captain of the baseball team (or men's softball, that part wasn't made very clear) and also has pretty good grades. Seems to start off as the nice, smart, popular and driven support character, and it seemed he would be forever be in the back seat, relegated to nothing more than a supporting role, but he ended up having much more depth and character than initially thought.
