Tends to provide some of the "lighter" comic relief. His character development is almost non-existent at first, then all of sudden makes a huge leap. Still, like most male characters in this genre, the development is a bit weak.Minori Kushieda - starts as the typical happy go lucky space cadet with ADHD. Almost playing the same sort of role as Yusaku and similarly, also almost relegated to the back seat as just another support character. However, her character development is one of the best in the show. She turns out to be so much more complex. The way her mask cracks and then breaks near the end of the series was simply fantastic.Kawashima Ami - childhood friend of Yusaku and also a model for magazines. She's pretty, has a smoking hot body, popular and also very manipulative. Starts out as the pretty girl that naturally clashes with the female lead. Initially felt she was just another "filler" character meant for fan service and to act as a distraction for the male lead, but turns out to be the most complex character in the show. Many people may disagree with that assessment, since her development is the most subtle. Her "crisis" episode happens very early on, and then she's never the focus of the story again, but slowly as the story progresses the deeper layers of her character are revealed,usually indirectly.

Toradora! is a series that can be successfully enjoyed regardless of your tastes in genre. The development of the main characters allows the viewers to deeply care about the outcome of their stories. Furthermore, as the series progresses into its second part, the show goes into high gear feeding from a strong story and cast of characters that are backed by an impeccable voice acting. Toradora! is a masterful execution of an high school drama and slice of life (and maybe the best one out there) that teaches how character development is supposed to be done. Hoping for a movie. Extremely recommended. Masterpiece. 95/100.

I’m not going to hide the fact that I’m a big fan of romance shows. In fact, Toradora is the first official anime that got me into watching anime and at the time, I believed that this show was a special romantic comedy that I would always cherish and remember. A few years later, I have watched a lot more anime and I can still say that Toradora is one of my personal favorites. Why? It’s because Toradora does things the right way. Keep in mind that after about 2 years of watching anime, I say it’s about time that I write a review and what better way to start my 1st review than with the anime that started it all for me: Toradora.Story:The premise of Toradora is quite simple, but unique. The main protagonists, Ryuuji and Taiga, both have crushes on each other’s respective friend, Yuusaku and Minori. The story basically follows Ryuuji and Taiga as they agree to help each other win the heart of their respective crushes: Ryuuji with Minori and Taiga with Yuusaku. To be honest, I thought the story was fairly predictable, but it’s still unique because of how they executed it. Both Ryuuji and Taiga start off by heavily disliking each other and are only willing to work with one another to gain the ones that they’re in love with. Definitely not your standard rom-com. The anime does a great job in making it’s concept unique because it falls away from your standard romance clichés and the way how they portrayed Ryuuji and Taiga growing closer with one another was something I never fully expected at first. In fact, the way they decided to develop Ryuuji and Taiga’s relationship was unpredictable in of itself and I really appreciated that. The characters definitely deserve most of the credit for the actual unpredictability of the story and for its overall uniqueness from other rom-com.Characters:This is one area that I believe Toradora truly shines in. One of the things that ticked me off in any romance anime is how some characters would sometimes “force” drama for the sake of drama. Some of the decisions made by these characters to create drama can be unnecessary and annoying at times. But Toradora’s cast avoids these clichés and the interactions that they have with each other feel genuine and real. There are 5 main characters that appear: Ryuuji, Taiga, Minori, Yuusaku, and Ami. All of them go through some impressive development and their bond with each other is only strengthened by the well-executed interactions. Yes, there is still drama in Toradora, but the drama is convincing because the characters actually have a reason and a motive for the actions that they choose throughout the anime. I will have to say that if you’re the type of person who hates tsunderes, then Toradora is an anime that you should probably stay away from because they didn’t call Taiga the Queen of Tsunderes for nothing. Taiga starts off pretty much the very embodiment of what a tsundere is, but here’s another major plus point for Toradora: Taiga can also be considered somewhat of a deconstruction of a stereotypical tsundere and the fact that she develops heavily throughout the series, turns her into a great character by the end if you are willing to give her a chance. Art/Animation:Toradora was produced in 2008 by studio J.C. Staff and while I can say that the animation is pretty decent for the most part, the art isn’t the best part about this show. I’m going to be completely honest here; Toradora does not have the greatest art ever. In fact, I’ve seen better art in other anime of the same genre. Unlike most rom-coms that I have watched, Toradora’s art is mainly average and at first, I was even unsure about watching this show because the character designs weren’t exactly my type. But don’t let this shortcoming prevent you from watching this fantastic rom-com. It’s important not to judge a show by its cover.Sound:Toradora’s music was composed by Yukari Hashimoto, who composed music for other shows like Golden Time. Besides a few piano tracks that I enjoy listening to, the soundtrack for the most part is nothing absolutely amazing to write home about. Honestly though, I don’t need Toradora’s soundtrack to be godlike or anything cause I watched this show for the story and characters and I got what I wanted. If I wanted to watch an anime with amazing soundtracks, I would watch anime having composers like Yuki Kajiura, Yoko Kanno, Joe Hisaishi, Kenji Kawai or something. One track that stands out to me in Toradora is “Lost My Pieces”. It’s a very nice piece that does a great job in portraying the emotions that’s going on in that specific scene and definitely a track that I could listen to on its own. Lastly, I wasn’t the biggest fan of the opening and ending themes, so yeah.Enjoyment:I truly enjoyed watching Toradora and the characters play a huge role in my enjoyment. I think I was able to enjoy Toradora to its fullest because no one completely steals the show here. Instead the 5 main characters I mentioned earlier develop great chemistry with one another that watching them interact with one another is already enough to get me excited. The fact that I’m constantly trying to figure out how each relationship is going to be developed, definitely helped in my enjoyment.Overall:Toradora is a unique and a fantastic rom-com. Honestly, I consider this show to be one of the greatest rom-coms that I’ve ever watched and 2 years later, I’m still saying that. Sure, Toradora is not perfect and in fact has its share of problems though I refuse to mention these issues due to spoilers. Would I recommend watching Toradora? Definitely yes. If you’re a person that wants a unique rom-com with fantastic characters and assuming you can be patient with tsunderes, then Toradora is right up your alley. Thank you for reading my 1st review and remember that this is just my opinion and my opinion alone. If you think my review is helpful in convincing you to watch Toradora then that makes me really happy and if it doesn’t, I’m already happy knowing that you at least decided to read my review in the first place.

Toradora is the single best romantic comedy I have ever seen.  The writing is top quality and will keep you interested from the very beginning and just pull you in more and more towards the end.  This is a show that absolutely destroys the writing and character development of most other rom coms.  It is a show that I can easily recommend to fans of romantic comedy or even those who are often put off by the genre.

This needs to be said, WATCH AFTER THE CREDITS. I have seen so many people who don't do it, but seriously, you have to watch after the credits!To be completely honest, I'm not a big fan of the romance genre in general. So when a friend of mine mentioned this show, I immediately shrugged it off because of the lack of fantasy that I always watch. I can't believe I actually put this show off because of that. Toradora! is nothing like any other romance show, it goes into the deeper meaning of love and even though you realize what will eventually happen pretty early on the story, the way the show is presented is absolutely perfect. The only truly stereotypical character is Ryuuji being the "nice-guy" and no Taiga is not really a tsundere. Watch Riyogaa's review for a much better review than this.

Alright so, five categories, five possible stars. Go!Plot: 4.2/5Overall very excellent plot, however, there were some hiccups in there for me for the way the plot develops for me. Like,  Spoiler Alert! Click to show or hideAmi's tone changes throughout the anime even though she wants the be "cute" and "nice" to everyone, but kind of just found a medium between her two sides. Though I may be missing something here.Artwork: 4.6/5Artwork is very picky for me, sometimes I judge an anime based on it's artwork alone. (I know this is bad, though can't stand some of the styles...) But this anime has a great artwork style! Taiga is really cute :)VO: 4.8/5Overall good VO's, nothing to really complain about here.Characters: 5/5Great choice of characters! Large and wide variety of different characters with their own personalities, and takes a twist on the usual mom, for Ryuji anyway.Ending: 4.8/5Some may wonder why I judge ending here, but it's because I really, really dislike cliffhangers, but this doesn't do any of that horse hockey. Nice and tidy conclusion, which is nice for a change.  Spoiler Alert! Click to show or hideI'm looking at you, no game no life.Overall: Great anime, a must watch. 4.5/5.

So every once in a while I like to take a break from my normal shounen/action anime binges and browse for a ticket for the feels train. Now I, myself - and I think I speak for a lot of guys out there who don't want to admit it - have a soft spot for sappy romance and love stories, as long as it isn't too cheesy and they don't botch it. I was definitely not disappointed when I randomly selected the masterpiece that is Toradora. This show did an incredible job in showing amazing friendships, how diverse and complex someone's thoughts can be, bringing out the importance of family, and of course a love story that we can all only dream of (unless you're really lucky). The drama and plot of it was all done in a very smooth fashion and never had any cheesy or  over - dramatic moments. It had you feeling so happy for some of the characters while making you very sad for some of the others that you were possibly routing for the whole time. It had you trying to guess what would happen in the end rather than making it too obvious. And of course it had you riding a very bumpy feels train the whole time. I don't know about you, but I love the feels.The characters as well were so much fun to watch and made for a really exciting show. Everyone had their own unique personality, and Ryuji and Taiga simply made one of my favorite duos in all of anime. Each and every one of them were hilarious and they had me going from laughing one moment to crying the next (yes, man-tears were shed) or just watching with the biggest smile.They also even had some pretty BA fight scenes that you wouldn't really have expected, which was totally awesome.All in all, coming from a guy who really enjoys an occasional well done Slice of Life/Romantic Comedy to go along with my action anime, Toradora was fun, very emotional as well as thought-provoking, and was one that I thought definitely deserved one more 5-star review (by yours truly).Hope you watch, and if you do you will surely enjoy!

I think if i was in my death bed and someone asked me what was my favorite anime of all time i would have say To... ra...do...ra.......bleh then i would die... At the end of this series i found my self relating to myself to a lot of the situations presented in the show. I only watched the dub so far but i recommend watching it on your language (if your language is Japanese or english) so you can feel the emotion in some of the best voice actors i have ever heard

I rarely write reviews for any of these I watch. However, I had to do it for this particular series. I've watched many stories, but by far this is probably the most incredible story for its genre I've ever seen. I am a particularly emotionless sort of man and rarely get worked up for real life issues to fictional stories. Yet this one actually brought out an emotional response for me and I loved it. I highly recommend watching this! I just wish they had continued with the series.

Honestly IMO Toradora is either something you will like or not. It's far from a plain romance and yet romance loves could very well get caught up watching it over and over again. The show itself is a mesh mash of everything. You have action, drama, romance comedy and just a little bit of everything. Granted it starts out a little all over the place but cleans up nicely as it goes along.As far as characters go the main two Ryuji Takasu and Taiga Aisaku are far from outstanding in their own right. Now before you bash me lol I will explain. They are in all rights nothing special which is outstanding. Despite their outward appearances and reputations they are normal. They are not made out to be handsome and beautiful. They are not a cut above the rest. A normal person can find it easy to relate to these two. That right there makes this a special series in its own right. As the description states Ryuji is just dealt a bad hand when looks are involved thanks to his father and it completely masks how the boy really is. Mean while Taiga is making up for her stature.Then you have Minori Kushieda and Ami. These two are polar opposites. Minori is a sports fanatic and all around overly energetic. Ami is a semi calm and collected model with a slight personality disorder from time to time. Both grow on you as the story progresses.Moving along to good ol' Yusaku. I would define him as a book worm and over achiever but if anything he is a dedicated friend to Ryuji. That right there makes him a interesting side character. Anyone that has stuck beside Ryuji has got some serious dedication to friends. I could go on about all the characters but that would ruin what you will learn if you have not watch the series and just be repetitive to those that have watched. So I will end with characters like this. They are a good bunch that really pulls things together. You may not like them sometimes but you sure as heck won't hate them.Now the story itself is your basic love/life story. You can find things to relate to and other things are just maybe out of this world for some viewers. Lets face it not everyone has the same life experiences but things tie everyone together. I can't say my school life was like this but there are things in the show that match up with my life and others will probably feel the same way. Really there is no need to go into detail. If you watch a good bit of shows or think about life in general then you can have a rough idea of how things go.The animation was well done yet not over done. I don't think it should be done any better then how it is now. It was really smooth and the facial expressions went from anywhere between mundane to extremely intense. You are not really left guessing how someone is feeling unless it was meant that way.The voices fit the characters. The pitch and elevation of the voices went perfectly with the characters draw expressions and body language. I don't really have a lot of this.The music for the openings and closings were outstanding. I actually enjoyed sitting threw the openings and closing every time. After watching the series a few times I started skipping ahead but over all I always make sure to catch it all once in a while just because.Overall I really enjoyed Toradora and would highly suggest it to anyone. Take the time to just sit down watch it and soak it all in. Laugh, cry and scream at all that is offered to you in this wonderful series. Oh and for the love of all that is holy lol makes sure you watch every last second of it all. I say that for a reason. So do it!!! Lol.Thanks for your time. Enjoy the show.RaiderP.s. This is my first review written period lol. If you want to critic it feel free to send me a message with your thoughts good or bad. Being human means we make mistakes and learn from them. Later.

I'll start off by saying that I am not a fan of love triangles because they are usually shallow. But, this anime did it right. I cared for all of the character deeply and was cheering various characters on throughout the series. This a great lighthearted romantic drama. Comedy is heavier towards the beginning of the series while taking a more dramatic turn in the latter half. Also, this anime contains the most beautiful kissing scene of all time. I won't spoil the characters involved but it was magnificent. This anime is a must watch for romance fans.

Ever wonder what Toradora means? well, Tora means Tiger which is our Female Protagonist: TaigaDora: means Doragan and specifically means dragon meaning our Male Protagonist:RyujiWhile I see there encounter and daily challenges I will came to love them in every way, I can't say Toradora is for everyone, cause some of these stuff are incredibly deep- but if life have taught you anything don't jump off this rollercoaster until it reaches to the top! (that is if your deciding to watch..)

Toradora is a slice of life, romantic comedy that consistently tugs at your heart. On more than one occasion I found my eyes watering from the joy this show brings. Spoiler Alert! Click to show or hideIn a nutshell, it starts out with Ryūji having a crush on Minori, who is friends with Taiga, who has a crush on Yūsaku, who is friends with Ryūji... heh, say all that three times fast. So Ryūji and Taiga work together to get closer to their crushes. But as time goes on, they begin to notice each other. This is a story of their relationship.

When CR first added Toradora, i marathoned it and it was sheer amazingness, it instantly became tied for my #1 favorite anime of all time, for some reason I never rated or reviewed it but now I am.I sooo wish there was another season or some sort of continuation (It has a few ova's and they're pretty good.) i would go into detail about why I love Taiga and Ryugi and everyone else, but if I did this review would be a bit like a novel, its that good.

You know something's special when you come across it and after you finish, you simply NEED to watch it again. Having been one of the first anime shows I've ever seen, Toradora!, the first time I saw it, did not command a very good first impression on me, and this was all because I simply didn't get enough exposure as it was to anime television. Nevertheless, by the end, I was telling myself, that this was one of those shows that I really did not regret watching. I had to watch it again.Sometimes, I think the first look only gives you the first impression. Because the second time around, things tend to get a little better. Was that the case here? This is what I thought.Plot: Whenever you compare an anime such as Toradora!, it's only fair to compare such a show to other shows within the same setting and genre of romantic comedy. When doing that, you can bring up shows like Special A!, Kaichou wa Maid-sama, and other high school romantic comedies, since they basically stick to the same plot, albeit minor details that can always be differentiated. I wouldn't count on that for Toradora!, which is a very good thing.Takasu Ryuuji, the protagonist with an evil look in his eye, has had feelings for another girl, Kushieda Minori, for quite some time. Things are going well, because this is a normal high school setting, of course until Ryuuji stumbles upon a love letter for Ryuuji's best friend, Kitamura Yusaku, written by the most feared girl in the whole school, Aisaka Taiga. After a misunderstanding and some kind of mutual agreement between the two, they form a friendship in which they help each other get to the ones carrying each of their affections.Up to this point in time, the only thing I've seen were high school anime shows. Kaichou wa Maid-Sama and Special A, so to speak, shared a storyline, and it really got to me when I made that transition into watching one to the other, so the only thing I could think was, "these were absolutely similar, how will Toradora! surprise me here?" Sure enough, unlike the main characters having things like initial attraction or just that defining factor that tells the viewers, "these are the main characters and you know how this plays out, deal with it," Toradora! pins the two protagonists on opposite ends, without any attraction whatsoever, practically disgusted towards one another, and then throws them back into the mix of high school anime. How did it play out? Good job, writers. While it can't be helped, that we know how a series of events will turn out (though I can tell they tried their best not to make it predictable), what has been restored is the fact that this situation allows for a deeper storyline, which means better character development and less fillers. It's easy to fill in a generic structure and just fill in characters for certain roles, but to the writers, I really salute you for this one.Characters: Characters can always be replaced. You can easily replace the role of a character in a great number of genres, and that's the issue with many high school anime shows. They lack value because the flattest characters can be used and it can still be passed as a decent show so long as you change one or two elements, but not for Toradora!, that's for sure. I like the fact that Ryuuji's case is one based on looks; nobody wants to get near him just because of that supposed "wild look in his eyes", Taiga with her tsundere-type personality that eventually blossoms into something a little different, and Minori with her unique personality and key moments that are quite essential to the storyline.The downside to this, I fear to say, is the fact that these are the three characters that seem to have received most of the writer's attention; while the others are worth noting, these three characters really give Toradora! its ability to shine. From my observation, they've undergone the greatest amount of character development. I think it's a bit of a shame, as I was hoping for the characters to receive an equal amount of development; this eliminates the idea of favoritism and makes it seem less like the writers are pointing you in one direction by siding with one specific character.Content: Nothing new here, to be honest, aside from your typical high school romantic comedy routine with its own kick. Minori's quirkiness really plays a key role in providing the comedy relief; standing up during class to give her take on airheads, her radar, love of spicy foods, list goes on. In addition, the other characters do have their own strange moments as well, and unlike a show that is confused by its own genre, Toradora! throws in just the right amount of comedy to complement its heart-dropping moments. Fun and playful when it's necessary, and serious when it counts. Is it a perfect blend? It's one of the best I've seen so far.Miscellaneous: For starters, I have the openings and endings of Toradora! all stored on my computer, and they happen to be among the most played songs in my playlist. What can I say, whenever an addicting pop track comes around? Just itching to download and press repeat. Animation wasn't top-notch, but it was definitely one of the higher-quality shows I've seen.Well, that's really all I have to say about that.Overall: Let's say that you've seen the shows I've mentioned above. Let's say that you've also seen a good number of other high school romantic comedies and are quite avid with them, but haven't seen Toradora! yet. Knowing that, let me throw one thing out there for you: you can't call yourself avid in this genre if you don't know what the benchmark looks like. In my opinion, in this genre, in this niche, whatever you would like to call it or categorize it under, this is the anime to beat, this is the story that others should strive to write, and this is just another show that will withstand the test of time, because I'm sure it will continue to pop up as a suggestion. Sure, there are other high school romantic comedies that can beat Toradora!, such shows including Clannad (which, arguably, does not even belong in this genre), but to be honest, you'd be hard-pressed to find a show in this genre that can deprive Toradora! of this title that I've given it.So, asking me whether or not it's worth the watch, see for yourself why this show receives positive reviews. It won't help if you continue to put off watching.

Short Synopsis:This show revolves around the high-school years, struggles, and love life of Aisaka Taiga and Ryuji Takasu.  There really isn't much else to it.Characters:There are five major characters in this show.  They are as follows:Taiga: A chibi tsundere, that sums her up very well.Ryuji: He is constantly mistaken for a delinquent because of his appearance, but really he's just a clean freak.Kitamaru: Ryuji's best friend, on the student council, and also a bit insane.Minori: Taiga's best friend who is always happy and is on the softball team.Kawashima: Kitamaru's childhood friend, and a model.The characters all have their own personal feeling for one another, loving each other and not wanting to admit it, secretly hating each other at times, loving each other and not knowing it.  The overall chemistry between the characters was very good, and I enjoyed it.  There is a decent character development over the course of the show, all the characters changed for the better, in my opinion, by the end from how they were when they were first introduced.Story/Plot:We all know how these shows go, obvious couple ends up together by the end and this is no exception.  The story wasn't actually bad though, it had it's sad moments, funny moments, and very memorable moments.  The story revolves around the school life of Taiga and Ryuji, their love lives and finally them ending up together.  It's decently done and I wasn't really let down.  Toradora did a better job than most for it's genre in terms of it's story-line albeit predictable.Music:The BGM didn't really stick with me at all, I doubt I'd ever recognize it.  The OP/ED weren't bad but not really memorable to me.  Overall the music wasn't bad, but it doesn't really stand out either, it's just average.Artwork/Art-style:The artwork wasn't bad at all, I wasn't really disappointed by it and I doubt others would be.  It wasn't the greatest, again it was just average.Enjoyment:This is what's most important, is it enjoyable?  Yes, Toradora is something I really did enjoy.  I kept wanting to watch some more after each sitting.  There's definitely better out there, but this is something worth taking the time to watch.  It had it's good share of comedy and sadness to make it into a very enjoyable and memorable show that I would recommend to others.Pros/Cons:+ Better story than most in it's genre+ Nice set of characters and their development+Some very memorable moments- Predictable ending- A few annoying side charactersFinal Score: 4.4/5 starsReviewed by RAZ. Revised and edited by HG

In a sea of moe and/or classroom drama type animes, this one definitely fits into the mold. But at the same time, you can't help but love it. Each character is stereotypical in his own way, and also forgettable if you watch the individual characters (the princess, the tsundere, the outgoing, etc). But taken together, with little idiosyncrasies in their stereotype, it makes for an excellent watch. The way the characters develop is fun as well-- it is both expected and unexpected, a mark of good storytelling. I chuckle often watching this. It also gets intense at all the right moments. I'm only at episode 11, but it seems like the characters get less and less stereotypical as time goes on.Further edit: I am now on Episode 20, and I retract what I said about the characters being stereotypical. They only seem that way at first. The character growth for the whole cast is phenomenal.Final edit (and change of 4 stars to 5): An emotional rollercoaster. I cried at the end (and I'm a guy) T_T I will never forget Taiga or Ryuji.

I've watched a lot of anime on crunchyroll and this is my first time writing a review on one because I feel this anime deserves justice. It is everything I've wanted in an anime and not one character in the show whether they are the main character or side characters did I not like, everyone was lovable and unique.  I am a guy, and I can tell you this show evoked so many emotions and the latter half the show is when the show is really at its best. Every episode was enjoyable and not for one second was I bored. For those of you who are unsatisfied with the ending in the last episode wait till after the credits there's more to it. Overall this anime is in my top 5. I hope you'll enjoy it as much as I have.

This was an absolutely excellent anime.  I laughed so hard through the earlier episodes.  My heart was tugged in the later episodes; some tears watered my face.  The character development was amazing and enchanting.  I usually don't watch things a second time because I tend to remember almost everything, but I may have to make an exception.  The ethical principles taught through the story-line (sacrificial love, honesty, true friendship, etc.) were beautiful as they were developed.  The characters really grow on you.  Good luck stopping once you start watching this!  This one is really easy to give 5 stars.  Enjoy!
