A beloved romantic comedy anime about two students that are labeled as delinquents by their fellow classmates and teachers, after a couple interactions together they find out they both have crushes on the other’s best friend. The odd duo work together to assist in their goals to gain the attention of their respective crushes. Toradora is as aforementioned a beloved anime by the community, I myself believe there are better romantic comedies out there, but this one still is very very good, make no mistake.

Review in brief:  Toradora! is full of the usual highschool rom-com tropes and clichés, yet it not only succeeds but excels at nearly everything it works towards.  It doesn’t contain those tropes just because they’re standard; it knows how & why they were meant to be used in the first place and uses them to their fullest.  By tying them together with a strong central theme, Toradora! becomes an excellent journey crafted out of familiar story elements.Review in full:  The premise of Toradora! is simple; it’s a high school rom-com in which the main characters are trying to hook each other up with their best friends, as they each happen to have crushes on the other's friend.  It’s a premise that surprises nobody, and it doesn’t take much thought to correctly guess how things will end up.  If you don’t know who the main characters end up with by the end of episode 2 then you simply had to have missed something.  At this point Toradora! may sound like a waste of time, but that would be deciding that a cake tastes bad based only on its shape.  The “main romance” elements are basically given to the audience from the get-go because they are only a setup for the real goal of Toradora!, and that is to cultivate a character drama around the concept of self-honesty within the artificial world we know as “high-school”.It starts with the characters, both main & side. On the surface they are quite tropey and in many ways just what you’d expect out of this genre of anime. In this way they also tend to have exaggerated physical and emotional features, emphasizing their feelings and antics towards the other characters. However, in time it is shown that these “typical” behaviors are, much like the rest of high school society, a façade, within which vulnerable teenage self-identities hide in fear and feared personas are cast into by those less caring. These characters aren’t the standard templates they initially appear to be; they are actually defined by their thought processes and emotional reaction points. This refreshing form of characterization is the path that allows what at first is just a typical rom-com cast to grow into the central theme of self-honesty. It’s why the exaggerative covers are there in the first place; the slew of templated, cutout characters in anime’s ubiquitous high-school setting can easily give us viewers the depressing expectation that they’re almost all cover and no book.Toradora! also makes great use of its generic setting and story arcs therein.  It proudly features the anime-school staples: festivals, P.E. swimming, the beachside summer house, and a field trip so blatantly opposite to the norm that it’s a joke.  Unlike lesser school anime that merely use these to run their characters through the typical thematic jokes and leave it at that (“It’s high-school, surely you didn’t expect something different!”) Toradora! makes a point of using each situation to allow its characters to bond through necessitated teamwork, enter environments where they’re more willing to peel back their fronts a little, and create moments that snowball over the course of the show to become dramatic scenarios of their own later on.Because of this, no matter how predictable or generic the main story elements get, Toradora! is always able to deliver a dramatic experience, witty comedy, or even both at the same time via multi-layered character-driven interactions.  My only real complaint is that Kitamura's arc could have been handled better in regards to Kitamura's character and development feeling a little lacking up to that point, but it's nothing too serious and builds the setup for the rest of the show.Toradora! is also doubly entertaining, allowing it to appeal to a wide range of expectations.  Firstly, its pace is maintained via arcs of 2-3 episodes, long enough to make each arc matter without dragging any scenarios or plot elements out longer than necessary.  Secondly, it possesses a decidedly silly flavor of humor.  Most of Toradora!’s comedy doesn't derive from situations or misunderstandings between characters (as one would expect from the genre) but most often just the characters goofing around and having a good time, especially where the outwardly enthusiastic characters are involved.  Not that those other forms of comedy can’t be effective (otherwise one would think that they’d be far less common) but Toradora!’s comedy is innately refreshing.  By allowing the characters to simply act as they are within these silly moments instead of following a rigid joke scenario it fosters an air of genuineness that gives the whole show a special charm and occasionally even sees characters develop through comedy.Even the production values of Toradora! end up amounting to more than they initially appear.  With its clear and effective use of both color palettes and emotive animation to reflect each scene’s mood, the visual artistry does everything it needs to do  to make the end result shine.  Of particular note are the dramatic sequences with highly controlled frame-rates, emulating a live-action movie to great effect.  The sound (especially the voice acting) is just about a perfect match, with distinct and lively voice acting for nearly every character and catchy music that captures the mood from a high schooler’s mind noticeably well.Now it must be said that many people who dislike the show cite a disdain for Taiga's violent and reactive character.  If you don't like her it will likely detract from your enjoyment.  For me, having known people who were surprisingly similar was enough to accept her when she wasn’t likable and led to her growing on me over time, which seems to have been the author’s intention.  I can say with confidence that Taiga's character is exaggerated to the same degree as the other main characters and didn't come off as comically strange or unnatural to me like other violent tsun-type characters tend to.Verdict:  On the surface, Toradora! is a generic high-school rom-com with a standard premise and a cliché & predictable outcome.  Dig deeper and it discards those notions when it turns out to be an intricately developed character drama, complete with moments both tender and lighthearted.  It shows us that something doesn't have to be one-of-a-kind to be truly beautiful, special, or even unique.  At the end of the day the journey can mean as much as or even more than the destination it leads to.  That is Toradora! ~ a whimsical adventure in a familiar neighborhood.Side note:  This review, in part, was made to present the topics discussed in the MAL blog article “Toradora: Maturity and cliché” by Awesomecake with spoiler-free wording.  If you’ve already seen Toradora! and want to know more about its underlying themes I highly recommend giving her article a read.Link: https://myanimelist.net/blog.php?eid=769730

Let me start out with the thing that will get me in the most trouble first, and trust me when I say, "I can't believe I'm saying this" but... I like the Dub for this show better...Still With me? Okay, lets move on to the actual review,I don't really like dishing out 5 stars, I feel like it's an improper statement for any show to say it is absolutely perfect. And Toradora, isn't perfect, just like any show; but unlike most shows, Toradora doesn't try to be perfect either. It goes out and flaunts its flaws just like the rest of the show in a way that makes it feel like reality. There's just enough cheese and embarrassment in this show to make you remember back to your crazy romances or crushes you had on girls/boys in high school or middle school. Each character throughout the series is given some pretty hard realistic scenarios in ways they deal with love, or how they approach complex social situations. and Each character feels alive in the ways they deal with those situations and each other. It leaves you unable to stop yourself from rooting for a pairing you having been pushing for all season. This show even manages to pull of the very minor Harem elements in the right ways, where each person feels like they have a shot, and though based off the opening and the shows cover image, the answer for who gets the title of "Toradora best girl" is pretty obvious for the get go, there are lots of moments where the show makes you doubt that will be the case, holding intrigue the whole way till the final episodes.The only things I'd comment on are very minor, and hardly worth mentioning, sometimes (though rarely) the comedy does feel a little slow, or certain situations forced, but this is rare and far in between, not really negatively impacting the show much at all.

Toradora is the first Anime of the Romance genre I've watched, I was blown away. The characters are well developped and pleasant to the eye. The story gets to you, you feel a certain attachment to many of the characters, and everything that happen. There's no moment where everything feel unnatural, everything that happens feels so real.It is for me the best Romance Anime, and certainly one the the best overall.

Toradora! Is a story about young love, the kind felt by those in highschool. While this might seem stereotypical, the story does more with the concept than I believe I have ever seen.In Toradora, the true focus is on the characterization. Our two main protagonists go from friends, eventually attempting to help one-another in their pursuits in love, and eventually end up more like family. All the while, the supporting cast makes itself heard. You see, unlike in most romantic shows of this nature, both main characters start the story in love with other characters (rather than with one-another). The way that they attempt to fulfill their love, and the struggles felt by those who know that their love should not be fulfilled, are all too bitter and sweet.You will laugh. You will cry. More importantly however, you will empathize with the characters on this show. You will see a story of bonds which are so strong that those affected are willing to give up on their own happiness and their own selfish loves, simply so that their loved ones might be happy with what is best for them. Don't go into this show looking to "ship" characters. That's not where this story excels, even though it is a romance at its heart. What is more important, in my view, is how our beloved characters grow and develop, coming to realize what is truly important to them and how to deal with their teenage emotions. In the end, this is a story about love, family, and about growing up. I would highly recommend it to anyone who enjoys romance, or to anyone who simply wants a fun story with interesting characters to light up their day.

Toradora! is a far cry from the normal types of show I watch. This was actually my first romantic-comedy. I prefer fantasy or science fiction anime. Regardless, I was in a period where I didn't want to watch another of those categories. I decided to branch out and try another type of anime. That led me to this show. I heard good things about it so I gave it a shot. To put it simply, this show is a masterpiece. Toradora! is absolutely brilliant and amazing. The show creates a bond between the watcher and the reader. You find yourself rooting for about everyone that pops up on the screen. The characters are the strong point of the show and are incredibly well done. They are relatable and fun. No character is flat or stereotypical. As the show goes on, the characters noticeably mature and develop. I found myself enjoying everyones screen time.The interactions between the characters is amazing as well. The constant insults between Ryuji and Taiga or the way Ryuji and Taiga almost drool over their crushes are a blast to watch.  The plot was magnificent as well. Toradora! constantly sends you through all sorts of emotions. Some moments have you laughing and smiling while others have you crying. My only problem with the show was the ending. While I was satisfied with it, there are a couple of unanswered questions that will pop in you mind. This is a minor problem but worth mentioning all the same. It is by no means a bad ending, it just could have been better.  Spoiler Alert! Click to show or hide Still that kissing scene at the end was absolutely beautiful. I almost started crying. Overall, Toradora! is a well written show with amazing characters that make you actually care for them. It is a must see and has become one of my favorite anime of all time (Top 10). This was one of the most enjoyable anime I have ever watched. I recommend this show to anyone who has even the slightest interest in watching it.Overall Rating: 10/10

Beautiful romance slice of life with comedic moments. My favorite of the genre to this day, just re-watched the whole thing in 2 days. The story starts with a guy living with his mom while he goes to high school, and his dads no longer in the picture so he kinda of takes care of his mom and cooks for her and what not, while she goes to work. Can't really say anything bad about the anime, just watch the first few episodes and before you know it ull be half way through the anime 10/10.

Spoilers!!I love this anime, don't get me wrong. This is one of those animes that you watch when you wanna say "awwwww" and "we all can see she loves him" while eating popcorn. Just waiting for them to get together. I normally don't like animes that does'´t have any fantasy elements in it, but I do have some exceptions like this and some other dramas. So why four stars instead of five? I think some of the scenes would have been even more touching and strong if she would have not hit the boy. There could have been more times when Taiga  would have just took Ryuujis hand or stricken his hair instead of hitting air out of his lungs. Or held back. Besides after so many beatings he should already expect the punch... I kinda hopes for more growth in her way on dealing things. How at one point she would realize that she doesn't wanna hurt him. This is why I like the kissing scene. It is full on emotions. Fear of loosing watch other and hurting other people. Lust and love that they have for each other is innocent, but I don't know what they did after the cameras were of... It is quite common for these type of animes to show only one kiss but I am gonna say what everybody else is thinking... GIVE US MORE!!! Maby that is the romantic in me screaming, but still. The time when Ryuuji wanted to get away from home cause his mother collapsed of exhaustion and Taiga runs after him only caring about his needs showed how much Taiga loves him. She did not let go of his hand. At that time she supported him like he had supported her despite the violence and name calling. Am I happy that I have seen this anime? Yes.

This is a series I have watched countless times, and on each rewatching I marvel at how well these characters are portrayed through the entire series. As a romance story, we all should know that the two titular characters Taiga (the TORA) and Ryuji (the DORA) end up falling in love. What fails in many romance anime series is when the love feels either rushed or left for the final 2 minutes of the series.Where this romance works is in the believable progression of the two. Going from partners to friends... eventually to lovers. It never felt forced nor did it feel like they were writing in "conflicts" to further push the dramatic envelope. I guess that's one of the pros when it comes to adapting Light Novels to anime rather than manga. In manga, they need to keep readers coming back each week... something that relies heavily on forcing at times useless conflict. That was never the case here.It felt organic, like it gave us the viewers ample time to come to terms with the overarching love story as well as gave the characters time to fall in love.In regards to the dub, I just finished watching the entire series dubbed... for the first time... and when it comes to my anime I am usually more inclined to go the subbed route over dub. The dubbed adaptation was surprisingly faithful to the original with a stellar cast that brought these characters to life just as wonderfully as the original Japanese. Cassandra Lee Morris was incredibly charming as Taiga and Erik Kimerer brought Ryuji to life better than I could have ever expected. The rest of the cast performed wonderfully with Johnny Young Bosche as Kitamura and Erika Harlacher as Ami; the one who really stole the dub for me was Christine Marie Cabanos as Kushieda! The character was super hyperactive with a personality that reflected in every word she said. While the amazing Yui Horie played Kushieda picture perfect in the original Japanese, Cabanos gave the character just as much character while maintaining everything that made Kushieda such a memorable part of the cast.Overall, this a picture perfect dub and as a whole... whether you want to watch it dubbed or subbed... this is an Anime that noone should ever miss.

So personally, I used to dislike the Rom-Com genre. But Toradora helped change my mind. It gave me laughs and made me cry. The intro to this series was great and helped me get an understanding of each of the characters quite quickly. Even though I could guess the outcome of the show, I really appreciated the way details changed how I connected with it. Overall this anime helped change my view on Rom-Coms for the better, and I would suggest it to anyone who likes Romances, Comedies, or Slice of Life genres.

I had been hearing about Toradora for years.  Really, who hadn’t?  However it had never quite made its way to my “To Watch” list.  Something to get around too one day…maybe, but nothing that had really been overly special that demanded that I see it soon.  So there it sat in the back of my mind from when I had first heard about it in 2009.  Fast forward to about a year ago and two reviewers, whose links I will post at the end of the review, posted their opinions.  They were Former D2 Brigade members, for any of the old fan base out there who remembers one of the more fun collectives of reviewers, Professor Otaku and Arkada.  I am subscribed to both on YouTube and donate to both or their Patreons throughout 2015.  I have, overall, trusted their opinions and will say rarely have they swayed me wrong.  Both have very different personalities, but have seemed to agree, for the most part, on whether or not a series was good, even if they didn’t personally like it themselves.  It came as an interesting shock then when I saw their respective reviews for Toradora and saw that their opinions be not be any more different.  Arkada praised Toradora, and said it had a nearly perfect ending, wonderful characters, and a great story.  Prof, however, saw things as very differently talking about the lack of originality, how many of the characters fell into tropes (or were completely unlikable), and stated that while better than many shows in the Slice of Life genre was still not good simply because just stuck to the overall formula not going at all of center.  Suddenly this series rose to the top of my list with the thought of which one of them I was going to find myself agreeing with.  In the end it was both.Toradora is a good show, however, like Prof, I do not understand the rankings of eights, nines, and tens that it receives.  If I were to rate it on a ten point scale would be a solid six point five or seven depending on the mood I’m in when I see it.  That is far from saying its bad however I do not see what the great hype is about.  Again I find myself agreeing with Prof that Tiga is a little, and I quote, “stink bug”, but at the same time I will agree with Arkada in saying that here character is a well done version of a Tsundere.  In fact a nearly perfectly done version of one.  Like Arkada I find myself thinking that the characters are very well done and will say that they are one of the better portrayals of the seventeen year olds.  From the pranks they play on each other at the beach house, to the way they argue, bicker, and try to change themselves, the shallowness of those final teenage years are captured perfectly.  It was so bizarre that after I watch the series through the first time I found myself noting how well the two of them captured my opinion of the show.  I agree with Prof that I it does not take too many chances and it suffers from that.  I agree with Arkada that the story that is told is well done and that the end game story is a nearly perfect ending.  In the end I find myself being the middle man of hatred and love for a show and saying this:  Toradora is overhyped.  The characters are archetypes and do not break the mold but do manage to do very subtle variations.  I love how Ryuji looks like a thug, but he really is just a nice guy neat freak.  I love how Tiga is supposed to be adorable, but is such a raging b.  Still they are archetypes that while there are those little differences they do not go that far off model.  They are cookie cutter characters thrown into off cookie cutter bodies.  Minori is probably the most interesting one of the batch and that maybe because of the fact that she is so off kilter like so many teenagers are.  The plot, once again does do nothing too unique.  The story arcs are fun and flow from one to the next with ease, and do so well, but it is a still cookie cutter.  Here we see all of the tropes of the Slice of Life Romantic Comedy.  Once again though I do find one thing that was very brave and that was while the plot and the outcome are quite easy to predict how they get there and the reactions of the characters is somewhat different.  These are not as Prof points out, what people think people act like from second hand, but instead what a group of teenage kids really are like.  So while the outcome and the stories might be predictable the journey there is not.  Instead of taking the interstate we get the back roads and see character times that we know entering all too well known events in a fun way of real people.  Is everything realistic?  HAHAHAHAHAHAHA!  Not on your life, but are they real enough to be relatable?  I’d say so.  Overall the story, the characters and the animation is really good, but not everything that it is hyped up to be.  Those reading this may notice I gave it four stars out of five.  I have a hard time with the five star scale so allow me to add it would be three out of four for my mindset.  I like the series and I wish to own it now, but it is not the Masterpiece that so many claim it to be.  Prof Otaku's Reviewhttps://www.youtube.com/watch?v=lkt8QAhqles Arkada's Reviewhttps://www.youtube.com/watch?v=1_dXLRsPomU

This anime will keep you laughing and having a good time through the first 20 or so episodes. The last ones will hit you right in the feels but they are good emotions, I swear. The first episode was interesting but nothing that would instantly pull you in. Ryuji seemed like a very classic, over-used and mundane character at first. You know, the boy with those "killer-eyes" that wasn't really popular in school. The writers steer him out of that light rather quickly and give him the recognition he truly deserved and you root for him all the way though ! I'm glad to have stuck through with the anime after hearing of it though. The progression in the anime is amazing and at just the right pace. I loved all the major characters; Ryuji, Taiga, Minori, Ami and Yusaku. The supporting characters, Ya-chan, Haruta, Noto and Inko-chan even were a real pleasure to have as well. I've never said that about an anime before and in fact, most shows leave me hating the majority of characters. If you're looking for a fun anime packed with laughter and feels, Toradora! will definitely not disappoint.

I think this is the best romance anime ever. It just shows us that love can come in any shape or form no matter how it starts off. I think this anime can give many people hope. It shows us that there is someone out there for everyone as long as they are treated the way they like to be treated. Just be patient and you can end up as happy as Ryujji Takasu and Taiga Aisaka! I really wish for a second season. I do not have the words to recommend this as much as possible so please watch it.

Toradora! seems to capture the essence of how a teenager dreams about romance, without seeming too philosophical or wise beyond his/her years. Occasionally, Toradora! has some sober moments that hint at a deeper message into self-love and accepting yourself for your flaws while acknowledging that you should work on yourself; be happy. That being said, this is a more mature version of slap-stick comedy and it doesn't seem to take itself too seriously. The audience sees some #animelogic like how Yasuko doesn't seem to age over the twenty year flashbacks that the producers show. Toradora! has a good balance between the sober moments and more humorous and light side to being a teenager. I enjoyed the dynamic character development. TL;DR: Must watch anime because it's just really good. ∩(︶▽︶)∩

This anime is awesome (in my opinion) it takes place at a school where Tiger and Dragon meet each other AKA , Taiga Aisaka and Ryūji Takasu meet . The story goes through their school life Taiga has a crush on a guy at the school so she gets Ryūji to help her get him , but eventually she realizes that she loves Ryūji and that Ryūji loves her and then it ends . its awesome and great for a family to watch (if you can get past the language and perverted things ) other than that its a series that will leave you with your heart in shambles and you wondering if there is more to the story than is shown .

Romance is an extremely common genre in pretty much every medium; well, except for maybe MMA. With a market so flooded with cheaply made cash grabs that are made about as well as a Chinese motorcycle, it's nice to see something genuinely enjoyable for a change. My only real complaint is that the ending gets a little weird around the last five minutes of the episode, but thankfully everything works out and the show has a nice succinct finale.

Toradora! is why you watch slice-of-life shows. It's relatable, its surprisingly funny, the art is beautiful, and it revolves around a wonderful blossoming relationship. 100% recommend to anyone looking for a light-hearted show with some bittersweet undertones. Characters - They are all very watchable, but not believable at times. Many of the characters seem very one-sided, but throughout the show they become more visibly complex and human. Plot - This is a pretty typical layout for the slice-of-life genre. You get a festival, a vacation scene, pool scene, as well as others. As predictable as it may seem, the comedy and subtle romantic progression keeps this show rolling steadily and makes it very watchable. Fighting - It's a slice-of-life so don't expect much but the fighting is actually pretty good. Each movement has meaning, impact, and flows well. Emotional Investment - This is about 80% why you watch the show. In the beginning, you know it's going to happen, but it's a beautiful process. Each of the characters has someone in mind and our protagonist not surprisingly (that's one thing I don't like) gets everyone to fall in love with him, but he makes his choice later on. Sooner or later you start to identify with the characters and their reasons for the choices they make, and it becomes nostalgic to watch because of the high school setting. This is the whole reason the slice of life genre exists, is to do what this show does. Comedy - ABSOLUTELY HILARIOUS. It's pretty rare but when it happens it's killer. Seriously laugh-out-loud-like-nobody-else-can-hear-you funny. The timing is spot on and many if not all of these have huge replay value. Clichedness - Like I said before the plot is cliched as anything but it doesn't take away from the substance of the show which is the character development and romance progression. The one-sidedness of the characters does certainly seem cliched but they open up to the camera later which makes them more relatable. Dub - 10/10 the first and only dub i've actually genuinely enjoyed. the voices perfectly fit the characters and it helped to get me invested in the show more.

I went into this show with low expectations, just thinking it'd be another High School drama where the main character is crushing on a girl who's wayyyyy out of his league. I came out with mouth agape. This show totally blew my expectations out of the water and set the bar. The final episodes, after ### and ### kissed was just outright adorable, "1 more.", "Okay, 1 more.", "1 more." I started tearing up on the final episode, the twist got me hard. I'm so glad I watched till after the credits, I left happy. I definitely recommend this show to people who enjoy Romantic-Comedies.This show definitely needed an OVA, just imagine it, it shows the two lovers all grown up, with kids, sweet, adorable kids. It would leave the show with a sound ending, and not leave most people, like me, in the end with tear filled eyes.

My First Review:Well, here it goes..! In this anime you can really see how real friends should be like, same time you're having an amazing experience and idea how really is the world out there and how people act in many central situations via difficulties of life. This anime carries a deep meaning to it, you shout never criticize someone from how he look or how powerful he's cause we're all humans and out hearts are frangible. You shout never play with someones emotions NEVER cause someday your turn will come to face this challenges...Am not a professional at writing reviews but that's what came out from my chest and what I really feel and understood from this anime

Wow. Where to begin. Toradora is the best romantic anime I've ever seen. Not to mention one of my favorite anime of all time. The comedy never ends, and there are some moments that could make even the most cold-hearted person crack a giant smile. The relationship between Taiga and Ryuuji is adorable, and leads to some very funny and silly shenanigans. The development is great, and the ending kinda tricks you into watching after the credits *wink wink* *nudge nudge*. Just do yourself a favor, and watch this show, I'm certain you won't regret it.

Well i knew the name and i knew the music but i had no idea what i was walking into when i started watching this ....YESTERDAY! and now its gone (╥_╥)﻿I was ready to throw Toradora to the wind and go back to watching some (mindless) male protagonist destroy hopelessly outmatched opposition (+/- a sword) but within the first 15 minutes i knew id be watching all of this though it pains me to admit it.It has some great comedy and the emotional roller coaster can reduce some to tears.....obviously that didn't happen to me (╥_╥)﻿ #PoolAccident I'll admit that its predictable in places but in many ways i felt that made me want to get to the end and see it all play outIts well worth a watch and has snuck onto my list of favorites "lost my pieces" from the OST brings it ALL backas the title suggest MORADORA NAOW PLEEZ

I just had a few episodes left of Toradora to finish as I was recovering from a cold going around, and I have to say I am definitely surprised and strangely emotional after finishing it tonight. I want to state at the top of this review that this is not my genre of preference, and that I have mostly stayed clear of anime since 2007 until a recent and most welcome return. If you need a quick answer, yes, Toradora! is absolutely worth your time and investment. Below I provide some reasons why.One of the biggest reasons I have resisted anime that can be described as "slice-of-life" or "high school romance" (I just made up that phrase but you know what I mean) is the inevitable paperthin plot and dependent conflicts. I can't say I am an older viewer, exactly, but high school was never so dramatic or one-dimensional as the setting of Toradora!. I must admit that watching the series straight through, binging on the episodes by myself probably caused me more grief than necessary, because I tired of some of the conventions of the plot and the characters. It can wear on anybody, especially because these stories have been told before. What makes Toradora! special is "how" it tells its story.From a character perspective, although not entirely original, the cast is easy to fall in love with and think about when you are not watching Toradora!. It might be a deal-breaker for some of you to read reviews that say that the characters are fairly generic, and I wouldn't blame you. What separates Toradora! from its competitors are the voice acting and certain power episodes where the animation jumps into overdrive. The voice actress of Taiga does a great job in general, but at times delivers a performance that is...very, very effective? (lol, I mean moving...tear-jerking, seriously). In general, the actors/actresses have great chemistry in this series, that elevates these characters into a definitely exceptional romance anime. As a YouTube reviewer (Glass Reflection) carefully noted, the ending of Toradora! is much better than most that tell this kind of story, but personally I found myself looking at the endings of different narratives of the Toradora! universe, and found satisfaction and peace (such as the ending of the PSP game and visual novel). Much like how anime is produced and consumed today, the full story of Toradora! is not contained in just these 25 episodes but also the visual novels and the manga. Thumbs up, Toradora! will definitely linger in my memory!

I am very critical of the shows that I watch and the books that I read.  I rarely write reviews.  Nonetheless, I felt that this was worth taking a few moments to share my two cents. First, I'm a guy.  Over twenty years military and a college degree.I loved the character development in this story.  The male and female leads where both very strong and neither one overshadowed the other.  I could have watched a few seasons of this and not found myself bored.  I had mixed feelings about the conclusion.  My first reaction was that I didn't like the way that it ended.  However, the more I thought about it from the perspective of the characters.  I feel that what they did was very much consistent with their respective characters.  It was by no means a bad ending at all.I will say this that despite anyones opinion of the shows conclusion this is one story that is worthy of your time even if you find yourself with mixed feelings regardings its ending.  I feel that it was time well spent.

Squishy! Black Clover is a comedic spinoff of Black Clover with a Cute Chibi-Style, similar to Petit Clover. Episodes are 9 minutes long. Story summary: The unknown Culprit starts turning Black Bull members into Mechas, who is the culprit?All 8 episodes were pretty hilarious, breaking 4th wall at times and switching art style. Opening is sick btw.Quote of Yuno letting the feelings out:a "cool" character isn't allowed to talk too much! They can only mutter now and then, and they have to say something cool when they do! I rarely get to put my intelligence to use or show off how smart I really am. Also, why the hell is my catchphrase "You can't be serious"?! Can't I say something longer? Then I'd have more lines and be able to talk more often! I mean, at least this has visuals, but if this was a drama CD, I have so few lines that you wouldn't even be able to tell if I was still here or not!Funny clip:  https://twitter.com/Geometrican/status/1212627484451180544?s=20Note for other reviewers: Giving bad rating for animation quality is unrelated, it is done perfectly in a way it was meant to be done, because of reviews like these I would rather have option not exist.

Funny take on the petit clover format fun to watch a bit eccentric nothing too serious, the style is of course downgraded compared to the principal anime, but it's normal for the format and type of anime, I enjoyed it. It's not for everyone taste but it has his own merit and those who compare because of "animation quality" definitely don't know this is a style of animation for those types of spin off comedic show.

-First of all, did they not get that the original Black Clover filler was  HORRIBLE in the first place? Everyone hated it. But guess what? THEY MADE AN ENTIRE SERIES ON IT! -The opening is basically just reused animations from the official anime. Unless you didn't realize that the characters are chibis, only 3 seconds of the OP has them as they are in the anime (3 seconds of chibi Asta and Yuno). The rest of it is just them actually looking decent-ish. As good as you may think the OP sounds like, if you don't watch it until the end or you've never watched Black Clover at all, it's the most deceiving thing that ever exists. That's all to my TedTalk

Who takes an anime notorious for obnoxious characters and little to no pliot and says, you know what this needs? To be MORE annoying . It feels like filler intended to waste users subscription charges. Astas was already about as loveable as nails down a chalkboard ass is, WITH HIS CONSTANT SHOUTING, then you decided we needed to be subjected to it more for even less purpose. 1 star cause it won't let me rate half

It's hard to really give it five stars. It does what it says it would, but the animation style really makes it difficult to watch. Most powerpoint animations have more dynamic movement than this seems to. The faces are static, and flash between two stages continuously, there's a lot of sliding animations, and in general, this looks like it could have been produced in a few days by a single bored intern. The writing is okay, but boils down each character into their tropes even more than the original series.That opening, however, really prevents me from being able to give it one star. It seriously trumps every OP that the original series had, which is an absolute shame, seeing as this side series really doesn't deserve such a high quality OP.

It as all of the clichés of your high school anime. You have a monotone main character, a tsundere girl, the popular girl, and the non-existence of parents. Also, it as a similar yet fantastic atmosphere to season 1 of My Teen Romantic Comedy SNAFU, another great show. There is a twist to the show though. The main character might talk awkwardly, but he is observant, thoughtful, highly apathetic/pessimistic, yet at the same time wants to make friends. The tsundere girl has an insecurity issue, which she makes up for by isolating herself from everyone else. Unlike a typical tsundere character who is usually just violent or a narcissist. The popular girl is a kind person who gets along with most of the class rather than being unkind to those below her. The lack of parents cliché is explained for once, as they are isolated in a government-run program that makes them live away from family. The unique twists of your slice of life make it enjoyable to watch.TL;DR - Unique twist on high school slice of life shows and fascinating atmosphere.

This show revolves around a advanced high school and the students are to stay within the school area. In the beginning each student is alloted 100,000 points which equates to 100,000 yen to spend on for the month inside the school. The MC is very analytical and observant; but also monotonous. Judging from the first episode he is going to be the epicenter of how to solve class 1-D's financial problem with the help of Hirikita-san *spoiler*(They were alloted 0points as a class due to showing no merit which case the teacher told them the first day of class resulting to their class being as she said, "Garbage.".).

Keep in mind: at the time of this, Episode 11 and beyond haven't come out. I'll go into spoilers later as well. Broad Description:If you liked Fruit of Grisaia, I feel like you might like this too. The main characters so far have been fantastic! The dialogue is fantastic; art and animation are very solid.  Fan service isn't distasteful for the most part. There might be some that might make the sensitive ones to it uncomfortable, but it didn't bother me and actually contributed to some characters' development later, besides the usual "character development". I'll go into spoiler territory for that later.Specifics Description:The world-building is well done; plot progression stays consistent; Spoiler Alert! Click to show or hideThe only main real problem is that this show introduces far too many characters that don't get fully fleshed out or exist solely as a trope with no deviations. I understand that this is actually beneficial to how the main characters are portrayed and how they stand out from the rest of the cast, but the bar that they set up for the cast is too low in my opinion. The main character seems a bit too overpowered, but it's not bothersome. I've seen far more overpowered MC. The reason why I feel like he's overpowered is that I never felt like he was close to being expelled. There has been the threat of expulsion on him, but I never felt like there wasn't a problem where he couldn't solve it. For the fan service part I mentioned earlier, There have been 4 parts that I can remember as being fan service. Two of them differ from the usual fan service. You'll know which ones they are, because few shows actually pull off similar parts like this show did, Fruit of Grisaia being one.

The anime Classroom Of The Elite has a great story line going for it.As it is very similar to the anime Baka to Test to Shoukanjuu. The anime taking place in a school trying to rise up in the ranks of the classes through "tests" and "points" The plot goes through many phases and as well as lots of plot twists throughout the anime.I can say surely that this anime is a incredibly anime and I add my recommendation for anyone who reads this review to watch.

Fake enthusiasm!Classroom of The Elite is the most surprising of the season, not because of the twists (which there are), but because of how much I liked it. At first glance I thought it was going to be an almost interesting show that I was going to enjoy for the fact of filling time for not thinking of the emptiness that is life. But turns ou-Nvm idc just try out the first 3 episodes if you're hooked you're hooked. I like it a wee bit too much, you should also. :D(Also favorite new series not counting second seasons and the such, shout out to the homie BNHA.)

This show has a lot of known elements to us. It's a classical high school slice of life, with the harem for the mc, the fan service, the school life, the tsundere girl, the big boobs.Should we call it overpowered mc? We could I guess. Even if the mystery around him remains.You can compare it to other shows that contain all this and say if it meets up or not or that it's stereotype and boring cause we've all seen it before.But I dont think comparisions count for anything when you're spellbound to just plow through the episodes (all but maybe ep 7 wich seemed to be mostly a fan-service filler) to find out how it's gonna end and what's actually going on.The plot and story is made to keep you guessing and being intrested and they've done it well.When I've watched all episodes and just want more, I'm not going to compare the show to all the others or start nitpicking at it. I'm going to admit it was a good one.

Just to put it short, i haven't seen an MC like this guy before and also how he's a little more evil than the others.                                                                                                                                               i'm not gonna write a review long. i just wanted to put my stars up really. ignore this review. even though Classroom of the Elite is super good. take a glimpse of the first few episodes.

The premise behind this anime was fantastic, and I loved how the opening crawl of each episode (quoting people such as Nietzsche) helped to give a basis behind the theme of each episode.That being said, the show began to go on a downward spiral around episode 7, when it seemed to care more about fan-service then the plot itself. And I get it; showing off the occasional boob or butt shot is just something one has to accept when it comes to anime. But to dedicate an entire episode to it? In an anime series that is attempting to come across as serious? It just ruined the entire pacing of the show, and the second half of the season never really recovered.Is it worth a watch? Maybe. I havent read any of the light novel that this is based on, so I can't comment on whether a second season would be worth watching or not (nor do I know if there even is a second season coming). It has some interesting themes, and if you can get past the fan-service, then this might be worth your time

when i started Classroom of the Elite, i thought the premise was interesting. a few episodes in, and it was fun to discuss theories on the forums since we didnt know everything about the school and the system yet. but for me, as the season went on, i just found myself asking "why do i even care?" and answering "i guess i really dont". the story sets up classes basically trying to outsmart each other to gain points. but i was not entertained or impressed by how things turned out. the storytelling was too contrived.

This is not a typical school anime (of course non of them are..), it's a bit like Guilty Crown mixed with that "bad grade bad habitat" series that you have to fight for As to live a first class life, you get it, "first class" AHAhaha.. aww mmkay move on.  After you withnessed the worst explanation ever, lets jump into the rating pool!The characters were written good and their sides, characteristics and secrets were introduced to us in a right way at the right time and there is enough misteries left for a second season. The art is nothing special, a normal not eyecandy but still good.  The story is kind of irrelevant, you want to uncover it but nothing special that would blow your mind.  Story: 4/5  Art/animation: 4/5  Voice acting: 5/5And I gave it a 5/5, because it is a good show after all.

I wasn't expecting much, but this show ended up being excellent. There's a few things holding it back from 5 stars for me, mostly the fact certain aspects felt inconsistent to me, like its supposed to be a high school anime but there are 10th graders with character designs that make them look easily over 30. A lot of the characters have behavior that doesn't make sense for high school as well.However the setup is really intriguing and I want to see a second season.

Amazing anime one of the best ever aired in my opinion.  It is defiantly a action, romance, anime filled with lots of attention grabbers.  Season 2 has to be made. With all the excitement and adrenaline that this anime causes is awesome.  This anime knows how to get you on the edge of your seat.  I would really recommend it to anyone who enjoys anime in general.  It is amazing and as to bee seen by everyone. It is to bad that some feelings weren't really said but hopefully season will be aired and solves this mysterious cliff hanger about Ayanokoji. (main character)

The show begins right off the bat with high-tension and interesting characters. The beginning arcs are stellar with awesome development and scene building. You can feel the stakes rising with every episode but then you get an infamous anime pool episode where the stakes drop off entirely. Don't get me wrong, it's completely fine to have a laid back breather in a show, the problem lies in what happens after. Basically, the show never really picks back up for me. It wasn't a "Masamune Kun's Revenge" tier bad ending... but I'm still a bit disappointed at where it ended up. Fun watch, don't get too invested. 6.5/10

Classroom of the elite season one feels like a huge cliffhanger for season two.A distant main character, seemingly bored, but very full of himself isn't a new concept for a main character, see:death note, code geass, and one of my personal favorites (tho I only read the manga) : kamisama no iutoori /kamisama no iutoori ni Everyone who enjoyed the before mentioned titles should give "Classroom of the elite" a shot.

These characters are flawed, but that's the point.  They are also reflections of Japanese society - and that's also the point."Deru kugi wa utareru" - the nail that sticks out gets hammered.  Everyone in this series is flawed in some way and this takes its time to explain those flaws, but does it in a way that is believable despite the idea of such an apparently rich and powerful school.  The ideas portrayed (payment for value, focus on talent, learning how others work, etc.) are all requirements for functioning in Japanese adult life.  Is one better than the other?If you're paying attention, this is a primer on how children should grow into responsible adults - while showing off all the potential pitfalls (in the form of other characters) that can come your way...Good on multiple levels, with characters you can relate to and care for.

This anime offers a slice of existentialism rather than life. From Jean-Paul Sartre to La Rochefoucauld, I love how philosophy is used in this modern-age show that depicts reality; inequality, the plight of people to transcend how others describe and rank you, to the impermanence of life and titles in general. The duality of character, the faces you wear and how you are perceived by others as a determining of your character are all relevant and present here. It offers a unique plot line, and an intriguing twist that distinguishes itself from your run-of-the mill anime. I like it a lot.

Hoping for a season 2! This anime breaks from the typical lame MC who's there to please everyone, he is extremely intelligent and does what needs to be done to protect himself. The whole aspect of the show revolves around being cunning and outsmarting your opponents. The Mystery of the MC is what makes this show so great, and makes you want to know more about him, and his past. I'm really hoping for a season 2, the ending definitely gave me chills, and has me seriously curious how the MC develops, or changes as he interacts with more of his classmates.

Dis is da best and the end is a twist and i hope there is more than just 12 episodes 

I started watching this series with just a little bit of interest in the was it was described. I didn't think I would watch this series to completion. Boy am I glad I gave Classroom of the Elite a chance. I know I will finish this season and hope for another. There is just the right amount of intrigue to make you want the next episode to come around quickly.The character development is deep and the interactions are realistic. At least as realistic as anime can be. The story development makes you wonder how things will go next week and the next. I highly recommend this anime.

> solid premise> main character is actually a wooden block> main girl is also a wooden block> dialogue is clunky at best and cringy at worst> opening theme song and OP are just not appealing to me> art is nice, but there's nothing spectacular> character designs are also nice, if not somewhat generic> pacing is quite poortldr; This show tries to be more intellectual than it actually is; which is a boring and somewhat generic high school show. It makes you think it has something to say about humanity when it actually doesn't

This anime is extremely interesting watch for me purely based on the fact that this would be a great experiment to see happen in real life with how money and having access to everything a person could possibly want would affect how they treat their real life responsibilities. Plus the characters look like they have quite a few layers to them which will be fun to watch assuming they expand into their personalities.

I saw the announcement, read what is about, saw the promos(including the one on anime expo) and finally saw the first episode and safe to say, this is what a really good light novel adaptation is all about. the animation graphics is smooth and beautiful, the soundtrack and background music fits well, the voice casts are good, and last but not least, storyline is great. i cant wait for next week or the next episode. and it makes me want to buy the light novel. my rate is a whopping 5 out of 5.

Kiyotaka Ayanokoji Talks slowly with disinterest, but according to his continuous self-dialog, he cares but cannot express it.  He, unfortunately, is sitting next to the most paranoid and schizoid girl, Horikito, in his class. The different personalities of their classmates are distinct, if not a parody, of Japanese dysfunction. They have the rich narcissistic boy; the pandering girl that wants to be liked by everyone; a number of superficial, self-involved teenagers; the angry guy that sleeps in class; most of whom abuse the system in various ways.  They are guests of an elite, government supported, academy that pays them a stipend according to their worth as people.  Which over the first month =0. "You are garbage", said the teacher.  And, thus the tale begins. The plot is good, as is the somewhat trite character development. The animation, apparently done by a Viet Namese company, is also quite good.  Despite its naivete', the anime enjoyable to watch,  I find myself rooting for the protagonist.  I episode #3, the characters have become much more than their stereotypes, ending my only objection to the series.  It's now showing good character development in ways that you wouldn't expect. It's turned into an excellent series!

So many shows are about overpowered protagonists always winning through the sheer power of plot contrivances. Classroom of the Elite, on the other hand, starts with a bunch of good-for-nothing kids who screw themselves over early on and suddenly find themselves staring down expulsion and having their lives ruined forever. What's clever is how they work together (or not) to pick up the pieces and actually start to do well, perhaps even overtake the top class! A nice change of pace, intellectually, and even motivational, to prove that just because you messed up once, you aren't doomed to eternal failure.

Every time I feel like I have a grasp on what the show is about, the new character insights throw me off and I'm here like "oh shi*t." But for a 12 episode piece, it does its job by keeping you hooked the whole time. At first, I was a bit annoyed that so many episodes were dedicated to  underwear, but it was genius at the end. I would've liked if they developed the ending scene and set it up to be longer- it would have more of a shock effect then. But otherwise, I have been persuaded to start the manga.

From what you've seen you might've thought its one of those cheap animes that just follow the stream of new shows that gets puched back, but in reality yeah it is.The best thing about this anime is the drama. i personally think that it is very well made, also the way where they seperated the "ELITE" students into many clases and not just your typical class with all these charecters that you get to see everyday. Full of mysteries would give it a 8/10. untill i keep up with the manga i might change or update my review.

Classroom of the Elite is one of those anime's you watch and just get mesmerized after watching the first 2 episodes. The anime was beautifully constructed from just 3 out of the growling list of light novels being produced. What is also a big thing to see comparing to other anime's is the amount of VA's they put into this. In guessing, I believe there is over 20 voice actors in this anime just in the Japanese alone. With the dubbed, there is around over 40! With it also being held with No Game No Life, I believe this was one of the greatest anime's in the 2017 year. This anime was one of the best with bringing in a Typical Slice of Life School anime's. But let's be real, nothing of this school is anything from Ordinary. Hoping for Season 2!

I guess I can understand why most people like this, but it's frankly boring to me. I disliked most if not all of the main cast and shows like this live and die on the viewer liking the characters. To be fair I never got to far into the show, but I didn't like what I saw from spoilers either. Spoiler Alert! Click to show or hide also the ending is a WTF a bit. So Mc has no attachment to anyone and is going to betray them and use them?

I truly enjoyed watching this anime and believe that it needs a SEASON 2 soon because of the many mysteries still left and the story arc seeming to have just truly begun. The plot of this anime is very intriguing and it keeps the viewer in constant interest and intrigue as to what will happen next. This is still much of the story left and I think that this anime can really go far and make it places. It has a little bit of everything without overdoing it. I really hope that another season is made and more if possible, I believe at least 3 seasons can be made one for each year of their journey. The anime has so much potential right now I would hate for it to go unproduced or for it to not be attained to it's full potential.  SEASON 2 is a necessity for this anime.

Love the characters, especially the unreliable narrative we get from our main character. Wish it ended more conclusively, since theres a lot of loose ends to tie up, but I guess season 2 will do that. I know about the light novels but some parts don't line up entirely with the anime's storyline so I don't want to go to that for all my questions. So I guess it's the waiting game until season 2...[spoilers ahead-]I really like the slow shift of your stereotypical "she's got more than she'll letting on, thinks ten steps ahead" character, to her becoming arguably one of the more normal characters, a lonely girl who just wants her brother to accept her and some friends. Meanwhile, your typical "ditzy, friends with everyone" girl has far more behind her back that we don't know about yet. I really hope we get more of her story next season, and of course more of our MC. I especially love the slow shift of our perspective through his narration, starting with him just being an awkward kid who could barely introduce himself to becoming so much more.

He is a quiet and unassuming guy who isnt good at making friends and would rather keep his distances. He is also a students of D class. which is a lower class.. there is a bunch more detail but i dont know how to put it in words.I dont know what to say but this is an ]AMAZING SHOW YOU HAVE TO WATCH....... ok. if you are reading this... im just telling you i am really bad at putting things in words.. so the show is way better then it sounds

The only thing I can say is that this show is ABSOLUTELY AMAZING! I love the art, the attitude, and the suspense of waiting for the next episode to just hurry up and start already. The are characters I hate, and there are characters I love - Ayanokouji Kiyotaka -, but the important thing is to just enjoy what the producers have to offer. I REALLY HOPE there is a season 2 coming out. This show touched my emotions in every way. THANK YOU!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!

This Anime was actually one of the last on my list.  But out of boredom I checked it out a bit early.  I wasn't disappointed and wished I had seen it sooner.  Such a variety of characters.  Nothing of what I expected (BETTER).  The series has a slow flow but it leaves you wanting more... I mean literally, the last episode ends so epic you know they HAVE to either make a second season or a 2 hour movie.  They can't do that to us!!!!

I didn't get into "Classroom of the Elite" until the second time I tried watching it, but I'm glad I went back and continued to watch.  This is definitely a show that deserves a second season. All the characters are interesting, making me invested and wanting to see them developed more.  The mystery element of the story adds to the depths of the characters as well.  "Classroom of the Elite" deserves more recognition than it does and I have nothing but praise for it.

I actually watched the Anime first and really liked it. I read the Manga and was very disappointed. They changed so many scenes. Ichinose from class B played such an important role in helping D Class with the security camera scene early in the show. Sudo and his troop of friends got so much action time, I did not even see the Pool scene as well as the volleyball scene in the manga. Lastly Horikita got so much more time then a lot of the other girls Airi Sakura, Ichinose, Kei karuzawa, Kushida. The Creator of the Light Novel as well as manga writer are very disappointed/angry in how the anime went. A lot of Japanese fans are angry. Will unlikely be a 2nd season for this show, they may as well redo it since it does not have Japanese support.

Hm... Without giving too much away, one thing that I really liked about the story is character interaction. I think this show has a lot of interesting characters. Not to say the characters I'm referring to are all likeable (I mean, they are to me), but I think there are many characters in this story that have some depth to them and are well thought-out. One of the recurring themes in the show is that most people have something they are trying hide, and this truth is exposed multiple times throughout the season. It makes me more interested because I want to see even more characters who weren't shown much in the this first season come to light. And of course, I want to see what happens to the main characters.

This anime is a gem as far as I am concerned the main male and female are a great duo the characters are likable less so than some other anime I have seen but enough to keep me engaged my biggest problem with this series is that I want more to me this feels like a show that had a great first season good characters a good hook and twist on high school life  with a main character that we could follow and watch grow but were missing the seconds season the first season did a great job letting us know what the school was like what was expected of the students and what our main goal was to reach class A that is great now let see a season two more focused on the class D student lets see our main male open up let see them learn that he is there key but he is of no use to them if he only sees them as tools lets watch as they play mid games with each other and the other classes to reach the top and lets see any emotional pay off to a damaged character that could be changed in to some one we all love and root for not because he is winning all the time and we know he is the smartest person in the room but because we followed him through his hardships and came out the other end knowing that he has changed and though he may be defected he is not a tool molded by others

It's a very good anime if you like intrigues and mind-games. Who tricks who? One of the best anime I've seen for quite some time.Reason for this, is the characters and plot. The plot is quite simple in surviving the "Elite School", however, the way it is done is very well made. The characters are strong and well written, especially the main character, even though that much isn't revealed about him. I do hope we get a 2nd season. Also, I wish more anime had this type of plots and protagonists.

Classroom of the Elite is a psychological drama, set in a state-of-the-art prestigious high school where nearly 100% of the students after graduation go on to university or find employment. Our story focuses on the students of classroom D, one thing to note is that at this school, students are given a virtual currency that they can do anything with and are given a certain amount each month based on the class's overall performance at all times. The classes are rated from A to D based on this system. Ergo class D is in trouble.This show is basically a huge piece on equality in society and stuff like that. It's good, but not my cup of tea though, if you liked SNAFU, and want something somewhat like that with raised "stakes," you'll most likely get something Classroom of the Elite.

This is probably one of the best 12 episode anime's I've seen in a long time. For anyone who's a fan of anime's such as Code Geass, Death Note, FMAB or any other anime's with a genius level protagonist who's always 2 steps ahead I highly recommend watching this anime. This anime has a consistent plot, interesting characters and a very unique concept all being explained by the MC. You might feel as though the anime is kind of slow in the beginning but like with all great anime's it picks up the pace 3-4 episodes in. Would have gave it a 5 if it only weren't so short. You should also pick up the light novels once you've finished watching the anime if you want to know what happens after the anime.

Honestly can't wait for more seasons of this show. I remember finding it on here one day and thought that maybe it wouldn't be that good so I'll just watch a couple episodes. I was wrong on so many levels. The show grasped my attention and had me begging for more each week. I really do hope another season comes out soon. If one does, I look forward to see what happens next and to learning more about the different charachters.

This show was amazing. It was not your normal high school anime that we are all so used to. Instead, the two main characters make the show a surprise to watch. Not only do they have their own secrets of the past, but they also make the show hard to predict. Almost every episode this season was finding out some secret that the other members of each class have hidden away.It was an exciting anime to watch and I hope that they make another season.

This show has many characters that we get to see many sides of. Even though this anime is based off a light novel and some people probably think that the protagonist is just a "Light Novel Protagonist", that's not true at all. We get to see many sides of the main character, Kiyotaka Ayanokoji. This anime contains a variety of characters, a reclusive quiet girl, a guy who loves basketball, a girl that can get along with anyone, a smart 'leader of the class' kind of guy, a shy girl who loves her privacy and many more. To sum it up, everyone should watch Classroom of the Elites, it's that great of a show.

I love the main character because he is different from the usual teenager in high school animes. I'm so interested in his background and origin from the snippets we get in the anime. I tried to find the manga, but the characters are really different from the show. I like the anime better because he is so cool, nonchalant, clever, tough, and interesting. All the other characters are so unique which adds so much more to the show. I honestly desperately wish there was a season 2!

The Premis of the show is very Interesting and I imagine another season is on the way BUT let me state why this didnt get a 4 or 5 star rating from me im typically very critical about Drama anime and shows because I feel as though its easy to make drama but not easy to envision how personalities ( characters ) go about overcoming the drama and other obsicles this show did a great job at having the ALREADY GENIUS characters overcome setbacks BUT the didnt develope from it the closest thing to character development in this show was from a side character changeing his ways and becoming a better student later down the road from the support of the lead cast but the majority lead cast never changes on top of that we have all these characters that are presented as very important yet are never touched on im just hoping the series can flesh out these characters in the next season

Club watched the first episode of the series. Club ratings are 1-5 stars.Member 1 - Rated 5 out of 5 stars.Member 2 - Rated 3 out of 5 stars.Member 3 - Rated 5 out of 5 stars.Member 4 - Rated 1 out of 5 stars.Member 5 - Rated 5 out of 5 stars.Member 6 - Rated 3 out of 5 stars.Overall rating: 3.7 out of 5 stars. Club chose to move on to the next series on list rather than watch the second episode.

I seen this was on Spotlight or the email, and thought why not based on the premise. A group of geniuses fighting to reach the top by doing what whatever trick, manipulating nature by undermining the rules with exploiting loop holes. Almost everyone is doing it in this show. That one of the reasons I loved watching this show. The other reasons is the  fast pace drama that goes on in the show, the fitting music choice to amp each scene, the  colorful cast of  Class D highlights this very well, and the setting its self made for a engaging watch. It had so many  great twists, and turns along with hints throwed at you to keep you coming back!

I have to say this was compelling, this show has really makes you think something will happen and then it does a 180. Its very cleaver and i feel like a lot of anime fans who really enjoy things like death note will love this. The context of the show is there is a school filled with the elite children who are ranged in 4 classes from A-D. They are given money at the start of their time there and many spent poorly, as children would. They soon find out that that money is all they will get for free and that they will have to compete with the other classes to get more money. Its actually very on the nose how they show class divisions in a classroom environment. We seem to go down a path with the MC were we think about Class and the order of class and whether it is or could ever be fair. Some might say its pretty Communist level thinking, id say it starts of more socialist. But, by the end we see the game for what it really is you should differently watch!

TLDR: This is one of the best anime's from 2017, so go and watch it. You won't regret it. After averaging up the categories I'm giving it a 9.4/10 or 4.7/5 StarsStory: The first Episode gives you a complete false sense of security and then rips it away right at the end.Without spoilers lets just say the school is not as it seems. The characters tackle interesting situations in a plethora of unique ways. I don't want to even go into detail since going into this show blind was such a treat. My only gripe is that some of the problems that the main character deals with feel like they're far below his god tier intelligence. His interesting past is being foreshadowed and I can't wait to see it in S2. 8/10Art: The animation in this Anime is really clean and detailed. The lighting is very refined and crisp. The use of high-lights and mid-tones is superb. The faces characters make are believable.The detail in the backgrounds is great too. It really pisses me off this anime didn't get nominated for best animation of the year. 10/10Sound: The voice acting is great, the music fits the situations and sounds good. The sound effects are slightly above average. 9/10Characters: The characters in this show are interesting. The main character is so great when something happens I can't help but wonder what he'll do next. My only gripe with him is that he's so much smarter than everyone else but lowers his grades and always holds back in general, as well as when he solves a problem he never want's the credit, so he lies and gives it to someone else. The side characters are also really good too, no bullshit tropes every one is their own person. Would go into more detail but don't want to spoil. 10/10Enjoyment: I binged the whole show in a day...What more must be said...? 10/10Verdict: 9.4/10 or 4.7/5 Stars

To the average viewer the show appears to be cliche. There's the average genius protagonist to your right and the tsundere with insecurities to your left,,, but unlike many other shows-- there's a reason for everything. There's a reason why the main protagonist is monotone, there's a reason why the tsundere has insecurities, there's a reason why it occurs at a school secluded by the rest of the world, there's a reason why there was half an episode about missing panties. It wasn't just for comedic relief or a filler-- there was a reason. idk abt you guys but it's one of the most logical shows i've come across.  I can 100% guarantee you, whoever you may be reading this, that as long as you're logical and watch this anime with an open mindset you will not regret watching this

I really loved this anime, it does have a lot of build up, but its worth watching, you can find out who the main character really is in episode 2 if you pay attention. But it doesn't take full root until the end of twelve. I hope they do another few seasons soon it has great potential. Its more of a thriller mystery. You don't know the characters very well, and its about finding them out. But it is a very fudged up world, very like the real one. Life is like a carton of eggs, the trick is to not have them all broken before you can go get new ones. And some of us are born with a carton that's already got broken eggs in it. And that's all we can ever buy. Anyways its a must watch.

Imagine a world you can do whatever you want and live in a lap of luxury. This is what the illusion is about, all the students get to live in an area where you got what you wanted and there was no stipulations, unless you forgot to read the fine print.The students were only focused on the main prize till a wrench got put in some of their plans. It goes through a little bit of each person's life at random times, some were worth it. I definitely want to see more of the main character in action or things that would trigger a full blown attack since he seems to day dream about the past.Other characters seemsd to want to help but had to hide themselves from harm and danger by the other 3 classesAll the characters in the school have a wide range of personalities. Of course, it would not be complete without the clicks within the classrooms, who's being singled out, etc. While this show did steer out of path at times, it stay pretty consistent throughout.

Mostly Spoiler Free, Spoilers MarkedAn interesting anime all in all, this is how I will break down my review:Art: This show had no intense battle scenes, or overly complicated characters and mechas, so right from the get go, it would be pretty hard to screw this category up. The characters look more or less like you would expect high-schoolers to look like, so no crazy hair, or insane eyes or what not. For the most part, at least. As most of the characters look so ordinary, the ones that don't stick out like a sore thumb. Unlike most high school shows where this leads to a short game of spot the main character, here the odd-ones-out are antagonists and side characters. A giant, bald, buff, black high schooler in japan? Possible, but not in line with the rest of the characters.4/5Voice acting: Again, nothing special or out of the ordinary here. No attack names to shout out, or overly dramatic scream and cry moments. The voices are suited to the characters, and the MC does sound apathetic enough, which suits him. One quip I have is the customary engrish. You'd think that with the amount of native english speaking weebs out there by this point, there would be a handful of fluent VAs specializing in english speaking characters, but maybe the industry hasn't caught up yet. This aggravates me enough to knock down an entire point.4/5Premise: A nifty take on high school, the premise itself is interesting, IMHO. There are a few unexplained plot holes that irk me, but nothing major enough to destroy the suspension of disbelief. For me a problem with a lot of the "closed off school" premises, is that they quickly veer into illegal and dangerous territory, yet still take place in the middle of Tokyo. here at least nothing extreme happens. Even the worst students have their basic needs taken care of for free. The only thing that bothers me is that they all have cellphones, yet contact with the outer world is forbidden. How is this enforced? I thought it might be an inner network, where they can only contact each other, but Spoiler Alert! Click to show or hideone of the characters apparently posts selfies to instagram? If anyone actually does have an explanation (either plausible headcanon or Visual novel info), then please tell me.4/5Plot: Although the plot is interesting, it moves very veeeeeeeeryyyyy slowly. The plot is driven by character motivations rather than exterior occurrences, so that does make sense. In addition, even though the overarching plot moves very slowly, the episodes go by rather quickly, and I don't remember being bored with any episode thinking it was obsolete or three times to long. This includes the filler pool episode, which was even enjoyable. The character motivations aren't too odd or unbelievable, especially when you take into account that from the get go most of the characters are inherently flawed to a point at which they had to go to this specific school in the first place.4/5Unique elements: Every episode is titled after a philosophical quote, that supposedly has something to do with the contents of the episode. Most of the time this is a stretch. A lot of people found this to be pretentious and therefor annoying, but I disagree. While it is pretentious, I would hardly say it was annoying. In fact, I want to argue that this is in fact beneficial to the viewers. Even if the quote has little to do with the actual episode, they are all interesting quotes, and some of them even caused me to research the person who said them and read further. That's more than you can say for most episode titles (that can sometimes even spoil entire episodes *ahem* One Piece *ahem*).4/5

Parasyte was one of the first horror manga I read.  I didn't think I'd like it at first since horror wasn't really my 'thing,' but it grew on me and became one of my top-rated series.  So I was ready to be disappointed by a mediocre anime adaptation.  But guess what - so far it's been fantastic!  While the character designs have been changed a bit, and the technology updated (the manga's 25 years old now, so there have to be some changes to make it modern), the story, horrors, thrills, comedy, and pacing are spot on.  Migi is their same rational, calculating (yet slightly endearing) self.  The animation looks great, and if this keeps up, I can expect interesting existential discussions and awesome action later on.Word of caution: If you don't like gore, and humans morphing into toothy monsters, stay away!  This is grisly!

This series is nearly flawless. By far one of the best of the late 2014 simulcats, and masterfully blends intense action and suspense with a deep character base. The MC feels very relatable in his circumstances, and the series will consistently keep you pleading for more. Great music, better animation and art style, and devoid of many of the typical character tropes that plague many of today's anime series. Click play. You won't regret it.

Back in 1997 the manga for this anime was released to North American readers in a magazine, similar to shonen jump, called Mixxzine by a company that would be later called Tokyo Pop. Other manga titles in that were far more popular/well known published in the same magazine were Sailor Moon and Magic Knights Rayearth. For 16 years I've been waiting to see parasyte released as an anime series and the wait has been totally worth it. There is some changes in order to modernize this series that was released back in 1988 but they don't seem to affect the telling of the story. This is a must watch!
