But it was a good show to turn your brain off to and just kind of let it play while you think about other things. Watch the show if your bored with nothing better to do or need a filler show just to clear your mind from your last show. In the end watch if your a casual anime fan, but those of us who enjoy a deep story with interesting characters with plotlines and sub plotlines this show is trash.

I cannot believe that someone put so much effort and made 12 isekai episodes only to excuse the fanservice cleavage exposition. If you like that, this is almost Fairy Tail experience, similarly, plot is not even important anymore. I watched whole 12 episodes, because i wanted to give chance again for sweet, cheerful fantasy anime genre like this. And hopefully i wanted to be proven wrong it is generic, for example i hoped in the later stage it will turn out this is gintama-style parody of isekai genre. But it was not. It is serious in it repetition of tropes and cliches.But the worst thing for this show actually is not the fanservice, not bland characters and neither the plot that is so consistent that you can watch simply last episode and it will suffice or watch whole season in reverse order for the same effect. The actual problem is that no plot milestone, no decision, no action in this whole series feels any weight, no character feels relatable, no villain feels as the one anyone should watch out for. Everything is sadly washed-out to the very end, supposed plot-twists are not even slightest turnout.

For a character who's supposed to be OP he gets slapped around alot. Alot of the dialog is pretty bad and boring, and his powers arent all that special. He also carries around a sword the entire show and uses it like once. They drag out most of the episodes to the point where most could actually be covered in 5 minutes. All in all, pretty bad show and would not recommend you watch it unless you like bad anime.

Take a shot every time they say "cheat"You'll be hammered in no time and then the show might be entertaining. I'm still watching it in hopes that the story goes somewhere and occasionally a joke worth a laugh will happen. other than that they lean into every word of the title.Is it an isekai? yesdo they "cheat" by just giving the main characters OP powers from the start with little focus on them gaining control over these amazing powers for the sake of moving along a rushed story? yesdo they use magic? yes

The biggest failing of this series is how it continually sets up dramatic reveals that don't deliver.  They either reveal something that I was expecting for quite a while, or they reveal something so inconsequential that I feel confused why they conceal it in the first place.The 'cheat' concept is repeated a lot, but it's really just your standard overpowered isekai hero.  It delivers on having cute fantasy girls, and it's never really bad; just somewhat uninteresting.

Someone, in the comments of one of the episodes, compared this to a kid's daydream, and I couldn't agree more. Just remember how one of your daydreams played out sitting in class. How shallow the plot is to make the MC look better, and how even the most legendary characters harolds and the strongest, end up depending on the MC. It's just a bunch of terrible writing, it's probably the same as asking a 13 year old to make believe a story, and just writing it all down.The animation is pretty terrible as well. I was honestly convinced it was done by JC until I just looked it up.

Honestly, not sure if this anime is getting bot review.I am a fun of the Isekai genre but I understand that Isekai's are bad for the most part I am just partial to them (they're fun). This show is so far below the average I have seen the comments on the show "I love the animation of this show" but it looks like it was made by sliding a PNG over a background. The story is pretty dry too, there is nothing really special about the main character, no planning, no idea what he's going to do, very flat character.I see how this show has a decent rating but honestly, this show is probably the worst isekai I've seen.

Going into Isekai cheat magician, i didnt expect much, just fun isekai story with plenty of op-ness. Maybe even isekai and magic version of one punch man if things were great... After all, the title does suggest something along those lines.Instead this has turned out to be show where quality drops considerably with each episode (maybe only exception is up until ep 3- everything after that is downhill). And now, after episode 10, i find myself at point where i will drop it. At time of writing, episode 11 is out and i just dont feel like watching it. Honestly it reminds me of masters of ragnarok, but that show, as bad as it was, at least had few elements that were ok... this... not reallyIts artwork is probably the best thing it has going for it as character designs and artwork is actually quite decent, but is dragged down by animation. Sound and voice acting is ok mostly as voice actors (who with all honesty dont seem to be best, at least not yet- but i do wish them more power moving onward) give their best to breathe life into proceedingly worse story and lines, but even they cant do miracles. There are several scenes that are supposed to be emotional, but fall flat on their faces.Characters start off interesting enough- you can see there is potential for them, however they move in direction that makes them increasingly one dimensional and just.. boring. The main character is pretty much only one who they try to give some depth to, but even that fails horribly as he is constantly brooding more than batman, makes stupid decisions even for a little kid, let alone teenager. Interestingly enough it seems like main pairs magic teacher has most depth despite her short screentime..And story.. oh geesh the story. It is all over the place. You could probably make up better story as you go along that would be more cohesive.For clarification- i dont mind bad stories as long as anime manages to keep me entertained, but there has to be something other than just pretty artwork to sustain it. This one.. has nothing. It takes something horrendously special for me to give something a low rating, but as much as i hate to say it, this is in.

Where do I start.  Bad character development.  Subpar animation.  Low budget sound.  Horrible writing.  Some episodes were more cringe-worthy than others, but there weren't enough decent episodes to redeem this series.  The anime is based on a light novel series that was not popular enough to get localized outside of Japan, which speaks volumes.  A light novel series that is far superior to this would be 異世界魔法は遅れてる! (The Magic in this Other World is Too Far Behind!)  Similar concept (the "cheat" aspect), but with an intelligent MC and cast of characters that are far livelier, entertaining and endearing.

As many other reviews have mentioned, this anime brings nothing new to the table. It doesn't even take itself with a grain of salt like certain alternatives (that contain a slime *cough*). The primary protagonist is overpowered in power level alone, yet is frustratingly incompetent at avoiding injury (even by episode 10) or remembering his core character motivations (especially by episode 10). The secondary clear-set-love-interest is overly competent but doesn't have particularly clear character motivations besides sticking with the primary protagonist/self-insert. The world building is present, but not particularly interesting or bringing anything new to the table (basically all concepts have been explored prior). The relative quality of the animation, and the lack of outright filler-material is the only saving grace.

All but two episodes in this anime feel very slow. This is because there is no good comedy, amazing animation or strong character development that happens in any single episode. As for amazing large scale fight scenes (Which are one of the only reasons to watch a show with a hideously OP protagonist) simply do not exist in this show. The show is even not good at developing romance (which might make it somewhat more interesting). This show is simply a strictly worse version of the wise man's grandchild a show that I thought was pretty boring, but was at least passed faster and had more interesting things going on during down time. 2/5.

Like most other people on here, I thought it started off alright, because it was carbon copying every isekai ever. It showed some promise, but had a few missteps that could be forgiven. After episode 2, however it seems to go out of it's way to try to be boring and confusing at the same time. Scenes jump around, characters change motivations at the drop of a hat. Not worth watching. It's the Star Wars Sequal Trilogy of Anime. Xeroxed start with a terrible center, and I'm not even watching the end.

Bruh. This anime is so clichéd its not even funny. I wasn't gonna write a review or give it a rating but it was just so bad I feel like I have no choice.Art Quality: 7/10. Including both the drawing and music, these are probably the 'best' aspects of the anime. Not much to tear into here. Plot: 3/10. It started out decent but got worse as we progressed. Lack of action is a real killer, why even make a magic anime when the protagonist barely uses it? Half the time he seems confused at the fact that he actually has magic. You find out later on that the Mc is summoned whilst meeting certain criteria like "learning magic" but where? He only uses body enhancement and  summons the spirit whom controls the weakest of all elements, wind. But his female companion gets to wield multiple elemental magics.. Bruh what. If that wasn't bad enough, you really start tearing your hair out when you find out the Mc is a typical sissy who uses no forethought whatsoever. The whole plot is finally revealed and centered around the mc's trying to stop a sibling quarrel. To sum it all up, two people get their lives ripped away from them to stop two brothers from fighting over a country because their political views are different. Sounds fair right?Character development: 4/10 again, Mc is supposed to have the ability to learn magic, only does 2 things. And acts like a 10 yr old when he is in high school. Love how easily they get over situations. Ana dies, next episode she's forgotten, k cool.Mc's leave a decent life for this magic war filled one, no problem, must've not had many friends. In the end, just another washed up clichéd isekai anime

This is post ep. 7. (and before you say "why watch so much of it if it's bad" I have the urge to finish the shows I start especially when I feel there is potential, which I feel there is some here. I haven't read the manga but if it's handled differently then the studio screwed it horribly)What I mean by the title of my review is that the show has these scenes that try and be high-stakes and emotional, but it just fails completely because there is no good character buildup and world building done as a prerequisite. They just throw as many cliches as they can without any real purpose, and most of them contradict themselves. Like the elf swordsman being one of the strongest adventurers, but barely being able to hold her own most of the time and not really displaying any wowing techniques. Like she can cleave monsters in half and shoot fire, whoop-dee-doo. I feel like that alone doesn't make you one of the best adventurers in your city.The series is just failing to create any feeling other than the fact that everyone is useless when the going gets tough except Taichi. Which should not be the case considering the people around him are supposed to be some of the strongest in the area. The characters make me feel like I'm stuck in the Sahara desert with how dry they are. Everyone is pretty much useless regardless of how strong they are, except Taichi. And it's all for the sake of showing how strong Taichi is, I guess?Take Overlord for example, extremely overpowered main character, but everyone else in the series isn't as useless as throwing a potato at the enemy. Overlord also actually does some world building, hell even Wise Man's Grandchild did at least a decent job worldbuilding and with character development so that the series wasn't as bad as this one.This series is like when you answer all "unsatisfactory" for the surveys that ask how you felt about their product. I will say the voice acting is pretty nice, but the way everything is used in this show just feels wrong and it results in a terrible implementation of the story.And if you somehow read all the way to the end, all I'm saying is, it's not really worth watching this one. Go watch Death March to a Parallel world Rhapsody if you want to watch a show where it feels like only the main character can do something and it still be nice to watch.

It isn't bad, because the bar for bad animes is truly low (cough* wolfs reign). This anime is almost a work of art in that it is the most dry, straightforward, mechanically produced encapsulation of the issekai genre. There is absolutely nothing new or special that separates this anime from its peers. It is somewhat entertaining to watch as each episode competes with the previous to be an even greater generic advancement on the overall plot line.

I feel as it is unfair for cruncyroll to demand original work out of its paying members when they don't out of these shows we pay (or watch commercials they're paid for) to watch. I have never in my life seen such a blatant rip off of various ideas from other franchises done so poorly and effortlessly. its the equivalent of taking spam mail, blending it together with bleach and hot sauce, then injecting said concoction into your eyes only to commit harakiri whilst touching yourself with your own entrails to the meowmix song every single episode.

Like many other shows this one has a lot of great potential but it seems to have a common problem with every episode:  During each episode questions are raised about what's going on and each additional episode isn't answering those questions but are still adding more.  In fact, there are a lot of things about the characters that are hinted at and then the subject never seems to come up again.There is a lot suggesting that there is a lot going on behind the scenes that the viewer doesn't know about but it makes me want to bang my head against that wall because it never gives me any adequate information about what I really want to know.If you just want a show to watch with a lot of action and mysteries, which never seem to get solved, then this would be a good show to watch but if want a show that cares about keeping a good flow and keeps you informed about what everyone is thinking and/or doing, you won't like this one.

I've watched a lot of other world anime. And when I say a lot, I mean I go out of my way to find new ones. No exaggeration, this one is at the bottom of my list. (I've currently watched up to episode 6.) The start of the story seemed ok, there were smaller pieces here and there that seemed potentially interesting...? The foreshadowing in this show kind of sucks/doesn't add suspense to the episodes at all. It's like, the show is trying too hard to look like it's balanced between cool/serious/casual just to end up being the worst kind of cliche for an other world anime. It's not even cliche in a funny way, it's just.... straight up cliche. Nothing particularly good stands out about this show, it's way too generic.

This is probably the worst Isekai out there. I wanted to see where this was going but this show does not leave me wanting more.  Spoiler Alert! Click to show or hideLike in ep 6. She used her magic to dig a whole, fill it with water, then drop hot liquid metal to create steam to take out most of the enemy... Id honestly think that the liquid metal would have sufficed. Oh and what did that steam do, not much cause the next scene still showed a shit ton on the enemy.  I could go on but its pretty much a waste of time, just like the show.

The anime starts off great, and follows the manga up to a certain point. Its well animated and I enjoyed watching what I read in the manga come to life. However, towards the end it just skips an entire section of the manga (probably cuz it was "to violient" and "depressing") and it just gets horrible. The story doesn't hold up to what the manga is going for (which is a hundred times better). The writing and story plot is just boring and predictable to no end after this and just a train wreck of "lets kill everyone cuz it's shocking!!" I wanted more from this anime and I just feel like it's another Hellsing, or Full Metal Alchemist wait for its Ultimate version or Brotherhood......We can only hope we get it, so Akame ga Kill can be enjoyed the way it was meant to be.The manga story finally wrapped up and it was sooooo amazing in comparison to the way they ended this anime. If you loved this anime you really must read the manga, it's  ending is well done!

Towards the end, it just feels rushed an sloppy. Akame ga Kill is a good example of how not to do an adaption. I have no problem if the anime deviates from the manga, as long as its done in a way that feels natural to the series. Akame does not though. I can't give specific examples, as that would give away the story, but I do feel as if the last few episodes just felt rushed as all hell. All Akame has going for it is that it no character has plot armor, but the manga is able to handle this much better than the anime. I very rarely diss adaptions as I understand that things will change, but Akame just disappointed me very much.

I've never seen anything quite like this anime. One minute it'll make you laugh so hard that you're suffocating to death on the ground, and the next it's going to make you shed tears all over your floor.The story follows a completely average MC (by that, I mean he isn't OP, but he isn't weak either). This gives plenty of room for him to grow in strength and character, and so far, his growth has been quite interesting. I mean seriously, farm boy to assassin? The strongest aspect of this show, IMHO, is the characters. All of them are extremely interesting, and you want to know more about them and who they are. Not one of the characters in this show feels unimportant (even the blank and nameless people in the backround). They all feel alive with unique personalities, making the Akame ga Kill! world seem to be in tune with ours. You can connect with these people and understand them (for the most part).As of right now, I have no real complaints with this anime. I can't find anything worth noting. However, the blood and gore might be too much for certain people. If you are squeamish, don't watch this, because this show has some of the bloodiest action I've seen (but it is nowhere near the level of say, Elfen Lied or Gantz).

The first couple of episodes are filled with cliches and extremely cheesy scenes. The story felt like it was rushed and was written by a middle schooler. The audience is pretty much told almost all of the main characters' past through a very somewhat predictable, corny way. The main plot of revenge is very run of the mill. The only thing that kept me watching and entertained was its animation and its fighting scenes. Some may disagree with me, but personally, the fighting scenes remind me of Samurai Champloo's with added blood, violence, and girls. My feelings toward the storyline, however, completely changed after episode 6. It really felt like the writer(s) finally realizes what he is capable of and started applying himself. Not only do the animations and the storyline came together, the soundtrack of this anime is very fitting. When I first watched it, it just felt like they were trying too hard unique but as you go on, you'll eventually get your ears used to it and probably wouldn't be able to think of soundtrack that would fit the anime better. I would give this show a 5/5 but there are still some in it that make me cringe really hard, so a 4.5/5 (crunchyroll won't let me give half of a star) seems really fair. If you've seen enough anime, you'll probably be able to take the cringeworthy moments head-on and if you just started watching, and think it's boring, just wait it out and you'll soon change your mind. Maybe. That's what happened to me anyway.

I believe this anime would have good potential, if the story wasn't so hasted, No character development and shallow motivations for a plot that could have been better exploited. Everyone gets killed before we have the time to grow on the characters, so by the time they die, it really means nothing. Also, the title refers to one of the main characters, but only on the title. Akame has near zero importance to the plot, and her screen time is far less than Tatsumi.By the way, there are funny moments, most of them based on girls' sexuality exploitation. Still funny, but it comes a time when I grew tired of it.Something else that I grew tired of is the time spent by Mine to explain 1000 times, and in different occasions, the not-so-great mechanism of how her weapon works. It is both not that difficult or impressive, so please stop losing precious time in life-or-death situations to explain to your enemy how your power works: IT'S A GUN, for god's sake!What a shame.

I have been a big fan of the manga for quite some time, I remember when it was just a dream for Akame ga Kiru to become an anime and guess what our dreams have come true. First of all the plot, is really good and follows the manga well. The plot is intense and sad but still has comedy relief that fits (I have loads to say bout the plot but I'm just gonna cut it short to that). Now the characters so far really live up to my high standard imagination of them, they portray them quite well and so far I can really feel them even if it's so early in the series. Lastly the graphics/animation it's self, is quite smoothe and fits the anime and is good and showing wat needs to be seen. Anyways I really love it and can't wait till they get to the really intense parts of Akame ga kiru XD

Written after watching 3 eps.The first three episodes have had a nice balance between the necessary plot, character development, action, and comedy to set up the rest of the show and action to keep it interesting.Plot: 4/5The plot is decent. It's easy to understand so it can move along at a decent pace and still allow for time to be spent on character development, fight scenes, and some comedy.Summary:MC leaves for the imperial capitol with 2 pals to earn money for his starving village. Along the way the get separated, and upon arriving the MC is taken in by a noble family. During the night a group of assassins kill the family and in the midst of the choas, the MC discovers that the nobles had tortured and killed his friends in a gruesome and painful manner. MC then taken in by the assassins and begins training to become a full member of the guild or whatever. It's kind of like a justice league of assassins whose main goal is to rid the empire of corruption by killing naughty rich people.One problem so far is that the whole reason he comes to the capitol in the first place was to save his village. But beyond being a device to bring him to the capitol, the situation is ignored. I'm hoping to see this part of the story line resolved or addressed by the end of the series cause he kinda left his whole family there and it would be really shitty to let them starve. My other issue has to due with his training. It looks like he's going to spent an episode "training" under each member. While it's a very good device for introducing the different characters more intimately to the viewer, it's hard to tell how much training he's actually doing. Although he does seem to pick up a few applicable skills along the way, it's mainly from observation than any real training. Still better than line barrel where the don't bother training the mc at all and then send him on multiple missions to save the world. no wonder he gets his ass handed to him in every ep, like wtf. This MC comes pre trained and is already pretty skilled so that's a bonus.Characters: 4.5/5 I really like the characters for this show. They all seem to have distinct personalities and some depth. Except for the girl in black with the red eyes and the sword. She's got the whole quiet, cute, girl-with-traumatic-past-who-kills-things vibe. but its only episode 3 so there's time for her to improve so we'll see. Other than her, all the characters have unique and interesting designs that keep me waiting to see them all together.The MC's motivation for becoming part of the assassin group makes you sympathize with him very much. His motivation has been kept relevant, however, unlike other shows they do not overplay this to the point where he becomes a whiny bitch. It's very refreshing. Another thing I like about the MC: he can handle himself and demonstrates inner strength while still maintaining a personality. Most strong MC's have some complex that makes them serious and solemn cause they have to become stronger to save the world and NO FUN ALLOWED. Or they're some cocky bastard who has anger problems but turns into a bitch when sh!t goes down. Not this dude! This MC leans more towards the cocky bastard side but is very well rounded making seem more human.My one concern with him is that he's too overpowered. Spoiler Alert! Click to show or hideIt's a little ridiculous that some village hooligan goes out and defeats some crazy strong general, and then next a martial arts master with more years of experience than the kids been alive for. They specifically built up that guys skills to and he gets killed so easily? Like damn, what village did you come from? Detroit with swords?The other characters in the group are all unique and have some sort of backstory that's given to them. Sometimes the development is done very tactfully, but as with the 3rd episode, it is done by means of flashback with character narration which is lame and unoriginal but it was kept short so i don't mind.Art/Animation: 5/5Me gusta. it's fluid. it's pretty. I prefer more flashy art, like what you'd see in "No Game No Life". So far my lust for dramatic scenes with intricate detail and lighting has been satisfied. I really like how the scenes in the city retain a feeling of life and movement, instead of being empty or filled with still silhouettes. There are also scenes that really showcase the artists' talents. For example, at the end of the 3rd ep the have to rendezvous at a certain location after a mission. It just so happens that its under blossoming cherry tree and it makes for some pretty animations with the petals and bright contrasting colors.The fight scenes are great. Hoping to see more elaborate ones, but I'm sure we'll get to see some of those later.Voice Acting: 5/5They speak, I listen. no complaints here.Overall: 5/5I really enjoy the balance this show has between plot, characters, action, and comedy. I have some minor issues with the plot, but hopefully they can be addressed in the coming episodes. Even with that, I still found each episode enjoyable. I'm looking forward to next weeks episode with lots of anticipation. If you're looking for something fun to watch that combines a dark plot and lighthearted gags, then tune in, you won't be disappointed. Even if that's not what you're looking for, tune in, you won't be disappointed.

Just like my title, now I understand what all the  intense hype  was about!Akame takes you down the road of basic education for survival during the first episode, and tells you not to trust every pretty face you see out there. The main character is likable and the action scenes are really well done. I enjoy the premise of the anime thus far and, despite some watcher's dissatisfaction at the fact that this is similar to most shounen out there, this one is really likable, at least to me. From the first frame, it's hardcore action, and it even ends in action! But Akame is more than just punches, it has rather nice comedy added to it. I admit that sometimes the comedy is misused and confuses my feelings towards a certain action (one moment I could be covering my mouth in terror and the next I'm just cracking up). The other characters, including the assassins, have their personalities brought out with that really good voice acting this anime has. Kudos to the voice actors! The soundtrack is also awesome.  I recommend you watch this one! Now I understand what all the hype was about, lol.

I binged through this anime in 2 days. The only disappointing part about this anime is that it had to end. The adaptation, the visuals, the music, the story!! It all fit together so well. If you haven’t seen this anime yet, please for the love of (whomever you believe in) watch this already!!! I’m off to read the manga as well as the spinoff and the prequel to get my fix. If you’re like me, you’ll fall in love with almost every character including the “villains (or heroes depending how you see it). Be prepared to experience happiness, excitement, sadness, joy, anger and anxiety in this rollercoaster of a show. Soooo good!! Enjoy!

People are saying that the show starts off good and then gets bad, but I disagree. The first episode was not very good at all. Outside from that one music number, but I can listen to Le Chant De Roma online whenever, so that isn't a good reason for me to watch the show.It starts off with a cold opening that explains how corrupt the Capital city is with a montage of torture and execution. But then after the opening the anime plays itself as if it were a light hearted shounen adventure series. But we already had it explained to us that the Capital is corrupt and that this world is a dark place. So anyone with a functioning attention span already knew it was going to have a dark "twist" at the end of the episode. Had they skipped the cold opening, the episode would have been better in my opinion. It feels like a waste of time to build up towards something when there is no payoff, as it was obvious what the episode was going to build up to something dark and edgy.The series also has an issue with trying too hard to be dark and edgy, but also inserts a lot of out of place "gags" in that I didn't find funny, but also took me out of the moment because it contrasted so much with the dark tone of the rest of the scene. The dark tones are also handled poorly, as the villains are ridiculous caricatures of bad people, being mustache twirling jerks with no humanity who may as well eat babies for breakfast and kick puppies for all the subtly they possess. Its not a believable setting and feels like what a 13 year old kid would think "dark" is, rather than something that is actually mature.The dialogue was also full of unnatural and awkwardly inserted exposition. Why did the rich guy tell our Protagonist about the 3 races if he probably already knew this? Why did the guard decide to tell the protagonist about the child prince and corrupt prime minister if speaking such words were considered treason and thus dangerous? Was it worth risking his head for some stranger he hardly knows?  Spoiler Alert! Click to show or hideThe end of the episode also conveniently has a certain character show up just to provide exposition to give the protagonist their reasons to join the Assassins, then is not in the show again. It feels very contrived to have such a convenient coincidence drive the show. If the stars didn't align so conveniently for our protagonist and that didn't happen, the rest of the show wouldn't exist.A good writing will write a story in such a way that the outcome of events are not entirely up to having luck or coincidences drive the plot forward.

I really liked this series, especially at first!  From what I am reading from other peoples' reviews, there is a chunk of the manga that is missing from the anime.  Even if you haven't seen this already, you probably know that   Spoiler Alert! Click to show or hidemost everyone, except akame & najenda (NR), and Wave & Angel dude (jagers) die  I felt like, although the anime was pretty solid as a whole, (especially the animation and drops into the characters) the plot suffered from decline in the relevance in the deaths.  I don't know about you, but I felt like the deaths in the second half of the show started to lose importance,  Spoiler Alert! Click to show or hidewith exception to tatsumi's and especially lione's death this made the anime feel like it was just killing off the characters to give a "shock" factor.  The more characters died, the less i carried about them when they died. I feel like the first two deaths in night raid had a real reason and served a purpose to the plot:  Spoiler Alert! Click to show or hidecheele's solidified the hatred between the police/government for the viewer and Bulat's granted tatsumi his armor and gave him a fighting spirit But the deaths of characters later in the series seemed redundant and rushed,  Spoiler Alert! Click to show or hideespecially lione's, that seemed uncalled for and cruel, like she didn't need to have died, she could have gotten help.  Mine's also, hers felt a little bit more justified but still drove the plot in a way that made the deaths seem unimportant Throughout the anime, i felt like the amount of character development gradually decreased to a point where there was maybe a little flash back and then they were killed off.  I also have to say that the importance of the deaths somewhat parallels Tatsumi's emotions (super to near zip at the end, just another sacrifice).  Overall I ended up liking the anime, despite the flaws in charter deaths, but i would not recommend this anime to many people.-Delaney

I don't usually write reviews no matter how much I like the anime (vise versa) but now since I just finished watching the last episode of this very emotional anime series I'll give you my thoughts on it. I read only a little manga and I haven't read this one so I can't give you my opinion on how it was adapted but only the perspective of an anime viewer and I got to say... This anime in particular took a lot of people on a feels trip... I'm not the biggest tragedy fan when it comes to entertainment but this one was really good. Since ancient Greek times when they invented theatrics tragedy has always been the biggest hit and this anime although had a lot of happy moments, it also hit the mark on tragic moments.I definitely suggest that anyone give this a try that can handle violence in anime to find  out what I'm talking about.

I'll start off by saying that I was among the apparent few that didn't read the manga before starting the show.With that stated, this show was delightfully animated with vibrant colors and fluid movements, the action sequences seemed to melt off the screen like butter....bloody....bloody.....butter. The show doesn't stop there, the animation is accompanied by fantastic voice acting and spot on musical scores. All these positive notes should go hand in hand with an outstanding script shouldn't it? Well to answer my own question "Yes, for the most part". The story is truly captivating through the first 12 episodes or so, twist and turns are aplenty. In fact I applaud this show for going in directions that other shows haven't. However as the final act begins and the show nears its climax the dreaded flaws appear, at least for me. You can feel how rushed the show is to have everything rapped up in a nice digestible ending. The ending just didn't have as much of a powerful impact on me as I initially expected, it kind of felt like "All this bloodshed, all this carnaaaaaaaand its over" Beyond the shows conclusion, it is definitely worth a peep. Hope I was somewhat helpful

The first 18 episodes of Akame ga Kill! were amazing.  They were doing a wonderful job of following the manga.  The music, voice acting, and animation were all fantastic.  Once the story changed around episode 19, the overall quality seemed to drop as well.  Music cuts were being reused, animation seemed to become shoddier, and the story was ridiculously rushed.Aside from the anime and manga not being canon, it was watchable.  The split really hurt the anime though, resulting in deaths that were highly anti-climactic and foreseeable.  The main reason that Akame ga Kill is so tragic is that you didn't expect the deaths of the characters.  You had no idea who was going to die next.  Once the pace sped up and the manga/anime became non-canon, it lost that.If you like watching action anime, you will probably enjoy Akame ga Kill!, but if you read the manga, it will be nothing but a big pile of disappointment after episode 18.  Viewer beware.

Do you remember when everybody was ranting on about how plot armor doesn't exist in Attack On Titan because some people were dying (It's not a spoiler, you should have watched it by now)? If you were having some emotional distress during those dim times, your gonna have a bad time with Akame Ga Kill.The show overall is very enjoyable. They can successfully shift from a lighthearted and funny environment with two heroins shoving their bikini clad bodies into our MC's face, straight into an edgy and gritty scene without skipping a beat. It almost seems like there are two different shows happening at once, with the feel being that much different.While i did enjoy them greatly, the characters were the worst part of this show. The bad people were sometimes almost too evil and sadistic to seem realistic (and don't give me the "It's an anime its not realistic to begin with" argument). Some of them are believable and do a good job at making you hate them just enough to not like them, but not enough to seem just dumb. Originally i thought the show was going to go down the road of showing the good side of the bad guys to make this almost like a moral dilemma, but it didn't really do that until halfway through the series, with the Jaegers (And even then its only a few people). Night raid is somewhat what you would expect. All the assassins are deadly killers with a fun and happy side. Some of them have tragic back stories that add to the story, and some are just simple people fighting for the cause they believe in. While i said the characters were the worst, they were still very good.I personally found the premise of the show to be very interesting. There are weapons called "Teigu" (translated to imperial arms) that each have a unique ability and form, ranging from a full suit of armor to a makeup box. A lot of attention and detail goes into these weapons, and the characters who use them are the ones to watch out for.Now to the reason you all have heard of this show, the death count. SPOILERS(kinda?) I did the math and less than 10% of the notable characters, ones that lasted more than a few episodes and were important to the plot in some way, are left. If you watched both openings and took a shot every time somebody who died shows up, you'd be dead. But unlike Attack on Titan, when a character dies in Akame Ga Kill, YOU WILL FEEL IT. When a comment on a video has 1600 up-votes on the top comment, you know two things. Somebodies very likely Dying, and they're going out with a damn bang. Overall: 9.5 out of 10 with some some cringe worthy moments towards the end. Definitely worth a watch, and DEFINITELY worth a read if you like manga.

This anime is, in simple terms, fantastic. I have been watching since week 1, and have enjoyed this show unconditionally. The characters are all quirky and have lots of depth. However, if you get really attached to fictional characters, this may not be the show for you. Not saying who, but there are a LOT of character deaths in this anime. Just a warning for you. I have a friend who literally stopped watching because of the death of his favorite character. The story has tons of detail put into it, and now that the last episode has aired, you can just binge the whole thing!!!! I highly recommend this anime to anyone looking for an amazing action series with lots of blood and violence, but with the occasional sprinkle of comedy. Akame ga Kill gets my 5 stars.

Just finished up this show like a couple minutes ago so all i have to say is It's good but not great. Many people will say it was rushed, (which it was, specifically the last couple of episodes) and that it deviates from the manga (Which it did). However, just give it a shot because it is an enjoyable experience nonetheless. I enjoyed it personally but because it was rushed i couldn't give it five stars. But it did enough to keep me coming back every week to see what happens. So just give it a try and if you don't like it then you can drop it, hate on it, it doesn't really matter, the story is over now. It's not like you can do anything about it but post your opinions on it. It has a special place in my heart now.

I added this to my queue but didn't watch it till the second season due to other shows that were playing at the time.  It's a good thing I did, when I enjoy anime it's great to not have to wait till the next week to watch a new episode and that's what happened with Akame ga Kill; I had a small marathon.I only read manga for anime that I really enjoy, I plan on starting the manga after next weeks episode to see what the differences are in the story.If you enough humor, great action, music and story you'll definitely enjoy thisINCURSIO!

The moment I watched the first episode, I knew everything is going down. That being said, this anime is simply great. Now let's summarize this quite bit. In all, the anime delivers what other anime can't do. Simply, it delivers reality and undo carebear moment, it's truly releaving to watch an anime that isn't frightened to kill a few -- or shall we say half? -- of its characters. Moreover, the plot itself is a bit linear but the real question in regards to this: Which group will meet the retribution demise in the end? That question alone hovers over every episode and it's honestly amazing how they set it up. They don't favor one side and another -- and as an added note, one death saddened me to a point where I almost teared up. Finally the setting itself, the fantasy of a tyrannical lands full of Game of Throne's like drama is beautiful. The ending theme and its artwork reminds me of games I used to play, japanese rpg to be more precise. Now shall we get on to the main beef ratings?Animation: 8 Although some animations are still rigid like those scenes in which they just hover over a picture, the fighting scenes give enough beef and it's also supported by a perfect unison of the manga-like scenes and animation. OST: 9It has that familiar feeling whenever they showcases its few but unique OSTs especially during battle and on-town. Characters: 9I like it how they go over each character leaving no character in shadows, recently they showcased Lubba's story and it cleared it up. Oh and note the multiple deaths but at the very least they do show their scenes beforehands. However, some characters are simply bland and a copy of tsundere and whatnots, regardless they don't hesitate to do whatever their ideology wishes them to. Excitement: 10Every episode always has an action scenes and every time, it gives me -- and hopefully the viewers -- that moment in my PC chair: heart beating fast, unable to predict the next outcome, fear of death for a character; relieve or sadness over one. Simply great! Enjoyment: 10It's been awhile since an action anime has kept me in my seat rather than a boring expression.   Stellar **  Edits will follow as the show continues on, so don't get angered too much if you don't find this review to your liking.

Is killing innocent people using trumped up charges the right thing to do for the greater good of a nation? Is doing your job even when you know what you do is morally reprehensible okay so long as you can feed your family? Can the murder of perceived evil people be justified? They say when 2 Imperial arms users meet in battle one of them will die.Each character is ruled by their own resolve, quirks and ethics. All of them are likable up to a point this extends to the "bad guys", the Empire Jaegers [Except for the crazy girl with the dog nobody likes her] Romance, comedy and drama are woven together seamlessly in this extreme fantasy setting. Dark themes, adult situations and graphic violence in these the show excels. No one is safe. Give the first couple of episodes a watch if you like action or suspense like Hunter X Hunter or Attack on Titan. You will not be disappointed.

Akame ga Kill isn't just a simple anime to me anymore it's a weekly love affair. There is nothing out right now for a mature audience that will do what this anime does. It is that simple I have cried and I have laughed. I spent a whole saying I wasn't going to watch it after seeing my favorite character die, to only give up and watch it again next week. This anime just does everything so well, from the narrative balance to the art style....For it is the perfect anime for me.

Wow, I haven't been this into an anime in a while. I finally decided to give this show a shot a few nights ago and ended up watching up to episode 14 in one sitting. I believe the last time that happened it was with Kill la Kill... I'm completely engrossed. Let's get one thing straight beforehand- I was really thrown off during the first episode; the way that the writers transition from grim, dark, and serious to comedic and lighthearted was and is much too abrupt. I feel as though it kills the "immersion" and makes me regret caring about the serious moment that just happened. However, as the series progresses I either found myself less bothered by that, or those moments just weren't as jarring as the first time.Aside from those poor transitions this anime tends to hit it out of the park... So far I'm really enjoying the character development (especially Akame) and the overall pace of the series. I unfortunately haven't read the manga so I'm not sure how faithful the show is, but the story has me very interested.  Spoiler Alert! Click to show or hideOne thing I'm looking forward to is finding out if the Minister uses an Imperial Arms and what that might be, and the whole thing with Tatsumi and Esdeath is hilarious (and kinda reminds me of Bolin from Season 2 of Legend of Korra) The fight scenes are thoughtful and hard-hitting (though they could be a bit more gory) and so far the powers/techniques are nothing ground-breaking but insanely enjoyable. Animations are beautiful, character models unique, voice acting fits each character like a glove, and the protagonist is really likeable. Akame ga Kill! caught my attention with the action and kept my attention with the story and characters. I look forward to seeing out the rest of the series.

I began to watch this anime with no great hopes, but now I find it really awesome. The main story is not really different from any other you have watched so far, but it is the conflict of the moral and ethics that makes it so cool. Is killing a justified mean to achieve justice? Is there any legitimacy in revenge? Those are some of the questions in my head I can't give an answer right now. The characters are really cool and funny, Akame is gorgeous, you have some fanservice shots, and alot of cruel and sadistic violence, What else can you ask for? This really is 100% recommended!

This shounen action-comedy's humor is puerile. The plot is telegraphed. The characters are flat (and driven by out-of-nowhere expositional declarations as much as previously apparent traits). Occurances happen because the plot requires them to, at least as often as they are character-driven. The hero's trajectory is a threadbare cliche. But I'm still watching. This is partly because its predictability is comfortable. It doesn't feel insincere, overly condescending, or wrote.Dealing with the familar can be nice, but I mostly watch the show for its uncomfortable moments:  brief but regular juxtapositions of troubling, gruesome, and often flippant sadism against relatively childish and optimistic slapstick comedy or warriors-of-honor-fighting-generic-evil battles.The idea of contrasting and intermixing the sort of blood and guts (and cynicism) of Berserk, Blade of the Immortal, or Fist of the North Star with and against the heady (or cloying) youthfulness of something like Naruto or DBZ is fascinating. Some will find these spots jarring, but they are what keep me coming back.Recommended to guys who think they have outgrown shounen anime, and to those who think they should.

Akame ga Kill! does what every action anime should; blood, death (even of important characters), and actual combat scenes often with complicated swordplay.These may seem like obvious things, but they're often neglected in animes like Inuyasha, which has none of the aspects listed. Even Bleach barely ever kills anyone off. Like in the real world, there's death and violence everywhere even if you can't see it on the surface. You win some you lose some, which is shown in Akame ga Kill!.Akame ga Kill! also has a nice amount of comedy and will probably have some romance as well, which balances the anime so it isn't completely action and eventually boring fight scenes.So far this anime is amazing and original, I can't wait to see the rest of the season.

After watching the first episode of this anime, I tried finding the manga. And even though I recently started it, I couldn't stop reading. I finished chapter 51 a few days back, and IT WAS AMAZING. Although some scenes were quite disturbing, there's comedy, romance, and action found in it. (And there is one thing I learned after reading it: don't get attached to anyone. If you do, your enjoyment of it will definitely go down. SO  BEWARE.) I have high expectations for the anime!!

By far the most enjoyable of Summer 2014.I haven't read the manga but watching it has made me want to read it now. The plot/pacing is very solid, the animation is superb and the level of violence is both disturbing and astounding.The character work, in particular, is what stands out the most for me. In just four episodes I already care about the characters in Night Raid more so than most anime's this season. Can't recommend this enough.

Do you like gore, sadness, despair, and your favorite character(s) to die? Watch Akame Ga Kill.The manga is some of the best out there, and the anime is following it religiously.Without spoiling anything, I will say there are moments in this show where you will most likely skip a heartbeat. The manga was that good. I own all the volumes.The anime has impressed me with great pacing and balancing talk and action with roughly 10-12 minutes of the episode talk and the rest seat jumping action.It's not like other titles (*COUGH* NARUTO *COUGH*), that have too much talk.Rather Akame ga Kill! is just so amazing. You need to watch this show and rate it after the first four episodes at least.Highly recommended.

This anime has a lot of potential with what I have seen so far. I have only read the first few chapters of the manga and the anime follows it really closely. The combat is nice and the characters keeps getting better with every episode. The art style for the anime is extremely beautiful just like Sword Art Online and other animes. They all have a common goal to save the country from evil. (the story gets dark sometimes to really show how corrupt the country is) You should give the anime or manga a chance and will not be disappointed.

For me, this anime at first seemed fairly standard, but then it changed. Without spoiling anything, this anime made we genuinely worry about the safety of the characters. I was anxious whenever a fight broke out, which added to the stakes and tension. Spoilers, some characters die, but I never felt as though they were cheap. Some died simply in the fight, but it was used to reinforced the reality of conflict and the tragedy felt by both the heroes and myself. One death in particular left a plot line unfinished, but it was done in a way that made me feel sad and mourn the loss, rather than angry for the unfinished plot line. It mimics life in that death does not wait for happy endings, it takes us when it chooses. One that depressing reminder, it is a great series and one that I will highly recommend, but a warning to those who enter in expecting an easy watch. Prepare to be pushed to edge of anxiety. The type of anime that we sometimes need, Akame ga Kill! is one of the best anime I've seen and as an audience member, I've never been played so brilliantly by a writer before.

Akame is a shonen assassin show about a boy who gets swept up by a group of rebelling assassins trying to overthrow their despotic monarchy.  It's an interesting and compelling concept, but the execution is WAY off.  The characters are very shallow, and very unrealistic, which beaks all immersion, and the show kills them off at regular intervals without much payoff.  The cast would have been great in a more light hearted story, but with this subject matter it clashes horribly.  .BY FAR the most interesting and compelling relationship in the show is Esdeath and Tatsumi.  They have opposed world views and are generally almost perfect opposites, and are both the most developed characters in the show.  If the show were about their relationship and trying to influence each other and ultimately understanding each other and their feelings with the backdrop of the assassinations and rebellion etc this could have been amazing.  As it stands, the titular Akame isn't even the most interesting character in her own show, and the end is just one more let down.  I hear the manga is better so I may check it out, but the anime was a disappointment.

I know this anime is catching a lot of flak for not being true to the Manga, but I'm alright with it. I still developed a bond with all of the characters and it definitely leaves me wanting another version that is truer to the manga. I finished this feeling all sorts of emotions. But if we just continue to bash the anime then we will never get a reboot or anything because the only thing the producers care about for projects like this to take off, is if it can make them some money. If they think there is a market for it, they will do it. But we are not giving them hope by bashing this anime.

The story premise is fantastic and the main plot is fine in the beginning. However the story fails to convey any depth to the characters. You can always tell when a character is about to die because the writing is set up so that you're force fed a bunch of "character development" before killing them in a shocking fashion in the hopes that this will make the viewer care for the characters and get emotionally invested.

Right out of the batters cage, yes, Akame ya Kill! feels a bit rushed towards the second half. But with the new trend being a 2 installment, 24 episode run with more modern anime, I feel the rushing was justified and could have been terrible, which it was not. Besides some generic tropes, I see deeper, more nuanced messages in this show that people completely missed. People love to hate Akame ha Kill!. The dichotomy of pure evil versus pure good is traditional. Yet this anime not only explores the concept of pure evil for evil’s sake on the surface, but gives what we see as evil a more human face and an outlook from a particular upbringing that informs the character’s actions. And then we see those long held beliefs change over time. We also get to see pure good for the sake of good, how that came to be and where it would go. Some were corrupted and others stood strong. If I could go back in time I’d tell the writers to give this anime 50-100 episodes, something like FMA Brotherhood - just long enough to not feel rushed, but definitely long enough to explore each character and make the missions longer so we can see a more nuanced set of changes in the characters, their inner turmoil and set up the plot twists with a bit more anticipation. Overall I highly recommend the show and suggest going in not thinking “ok this is going to be a super serious show with something huge to say like the big 3 did.”

Some critics will tell you that the ending was sloppy and rushed where as I feel this story was perfectly told. You are placed in the daily life of people who has too commit everything they are for a cause. Since they work in the shadows there is no prize, no compensation and no happy ending. Being in the line of fire isn't a happy story and neither is losing your friends but sometimes you have too make sacrifices that is bigger than you can handle, sometimes you need too risk it all too make a change in the world. But who will know if your story is never told. Not all victories are happy and nothing gained comes without a price. It may be a sad story, but this story portrays the feeling of loss for victory perfectly.

So basically I don't want to spoil anything, but this anime left a minor hole in my heart with how it ends. It is very sad and very brutal. Even though I would have preferred a different ending, I will still say the author accomplished what he set out to do: make people feel sad. It explores the indiscriminate nature of violence and loss associated with war and combat. It also explores the concept that people may not always be remembered for their great sacrifices made to contribute to what they believe is the greater good. Both of these concepts leave a feeling of despair and hopelessness whether or not the protagonists accomplish their goal because the cost is so great. If they lose it is a total defeat and if they win its a pyrrhic victory. What makes it so sad and disturbing is that all of this violence and loss is portrayed by cute, fun and colorful anime characters. It starkly contrasts what the average anime would put forth in terms of plot, therefore, many things come across as shocking. Especially with the contrast derived from the colorful anime characters and the horrifying and dark concepts explored throughout the series. I so badly wish things would end differently, but if they did, the concepts and points established by the author would be made less meaningful. Yet I still find myself wanting an OVA or second season with some way to make things turn out different a few of the protagonists due to the despair and sorrow inflicted on me by this anime. Stand alone, this is pretty good. However, the manga is much better and has a better ending.

this anime started off fantastically and followed the manga very well but as time went on they cut out many things especially towards the middle and the end of the anime. the oneSpoiler Alert! Click to show or hide i'm going to use is mine's and tatsumi's relationship in the anime is very sudden and has nothing really leading up to it also they cut out what in my opinion was a very good part of the plot the manga had with the imperial arms taking over their users body and manifesting themselves (tatsumi becomes a dragon at the end of the manga) but i still enjoyed this anime due to its well animated fight scenes and sticking semi close to the plot but i cant give it full marks for what is in my opinion a loss the series could have used in my opinion more down time between fights for character growth which in my opinion would have made Spoiler Alert! Click to show or hideSpoiler Alert! Click to show or hidethe deaths of those who did die a lot more impactful rather then getting the feeling of well another bites the dust. i would still would recommend it to my friends who haven't read the manga though.

This show, while it was brilliant in pretty much every way, destroyed me. Never before has any form of media, whether it be books, movies, shows or songs, depressed me as much as this show. And I like to think of myself as a manly man. A big big boi. In fact I never cry, not even at the crushing disparity that is my life, although I did cry at the end of the Lord of the Rings.(Spoiler) But at every death scene, I myself died a little more inside. For every Night Raid member snatched away from us. Not for the Jaegers though. While this show does, admittedly, do a good job of trying to make you care for them, I like Night Raid too much to root for their rivals. Every death scene is set up beautifully beforehand, usually with some sort of touching moment shared between whoever will die next with either Tatsumi or another Night Raid member. And every relationship felt real and genuine. However, I say that this show is both a 0 and a 5, because it is at the same time one of the best and one of the worst shows I've ever seen. It's a brilliant, well crafted work of art that I thoroughly enjoyed watching. The music was great, the characters were all unique, they all changed in some way, and the villains were well crafted. However, the deaths were just too heart breaking and soul crushing. It seems people are never happy with these kinds of anime, because they're dissatisfied if no one dies and the character is invincible (like Death March Isekai), they're unhappy if characters die but don't stay dead (like Dragon Ball Z) and they're unhappy if everyone dies, like this show. The deaths are also a gentle reminder that everyone we know and love will die, sometimes in brutal, bloody, gruesome, horrendous ways, that should not be viewed by our unprepared, deliciously naive eyes. The mental trauma bestowed upon the viewer is also both good and bad. Chelsea's death is probably a popular example. She just wanted to be praised and accepted, and in her final moments, those are the thoughts that go through her head. This was at one time a great moment of the show, as her death felt extremely impactful, and a horrible one, because it was so hard to watch, particularly since she died alone, and in such a brutal way.All in all, although it will never happen, I would wish for a season 2 where Akame uses the power of the remaining Imperial Arms, and harnesses them, not necessarily to resurrect her fallen comrades, but to perhaps peer into the afterlife and see if they are all together, just for a bit more closure (There is a short animated "theater" series that does kind of show this, however I personally don't consider it canon and would prefer to see an actual ova or animation of this).Otherwise, amazing show, but don't watch it if you ever want to feel that thing called "happiness" ever again.

If you never watch this, you might be doing yourself a favor. Should you decide to, be prepared. This is a story about death and sacrifice. It pulls you in and you become enveloped in a world of desperation. From the start, becoming attatched to all of the characters is easy, but the story never quits. It even makes you question which side you're really on. This story makes you involved. Guard your heart. Watch at own risk.

I hardly ever review anything, so believe me when i say i thought that this was a fantastic anime. It is a simple cliche story of a boy from a small village attempting to become a hero... or so it seems at first. In reality it is focused on an elite group of assassins fighting to protect the people of the kingdom that they all love and loath to see rot. The character development is incredible, you grow fond of many of the characters, and the lines between good and evil blur as the story progresses and each story of the past is revealed. I have never felt such pure frustration and anguish than during the course of this series and the choices made by the writers, but that is a large portion of why I loved it. It was incredibly original. The fighting is gratuitous, but not to the point of just being a gore-fest, and the animation is very well done.I have not read the Manga as of yet, so I cannot vouch that it holds up, since the storylines diverge partway through, but i think that each should be enjoyed individually.TL:DR Bloody combat, Great animation, Different than Manga, Incredible Characters, Frustrating as hell, Original, 10/10

Let's start with the good: I thought the very initial idea was great; in a world of huge monsters, the worst monsters are actually human? How profound! I mean, it's nothing original, many have done it before, yet I had thought it would actually revolve around that. It did...and it didn't. All the villains are completely one dimensional, and are unrealistically inhumane to a point where it just feels really super cliched. Spoiler Alert! Click to show or hide I'll give points to humanizing the Jaegers, a small group directly under Esdeath (errg...I'll get to her later), but that isn't enough to forgive the rest of this show's ridiculousness.  One of the first things that bothered me was the title: you'd think in a show named Akame Ga Kill, Akame would be the main character right? Nope. Barely a supporting character to cardboard cutout protagonist Tatsumi.So that was immediately a disappointment.Doesn't even matter that Akame's character and history are INFINITELY more interesting than Tatorsumi, he's still the focus of the show. He even starts developing a harem! And that's to my next biggest issue with the show  Spoiler Alert! Click to show or hide Esdeath doesn't make any sense! Here you have a genuinely terrifying sociopathic antagonist with OP abilities, and...make her fall in love with the protagonist. That's right folks, the dictionary definition of Ice Queen turned up to 11 falls in love with Titorsami at almost FIRST SIGHT! Besides the fact that they really aren't shippable, but the fact that it comes out of nowhere and is completely out of character with said villain! But I digress. ANOTHER issue I have:Spoiler Alert! Click to show or hideDeath. See that scissor girl? YOu know, the one with the glasses and purple hair you see on the cover to the right? Yeah, neither do I! She was kind of introduced, and then died. She really didn't have enough character for you to even care, but oh no! Anyone can die now! Doesn't matter if you don't have much reason to like them, they still die!  *sigh*I really had high hopes for this anime, but it's just another cliched shounen. If you don't mind any of the above issues (though it's more me ranting than anything), and like decent animation and fight scenes then go ahead, you'll probably enjoy it. Other than that...don't watch it. It's really not worth it. The manga is significantly better, if only for one ship  Spoiler Alert! Click to show or hide Wave and Kurome, you are the only reasons I still read it  you should read it instead. In the end, the only thing that differentiates this from any other shounen:  Spoiler Alert! Click to show or hide It's willing to kill off its main characters and humanize a handful of it's main villains. That's it  Watch it if you want your heart ripped out, but then have it concluded horribly.

I love this show. I loved it so much, was amazing. But the ending made me want to cry. No, it did not make me want to cry, it made me cry. I cried so many times during this. Spoiler Alert! Click to show or hide But the fact that literally everyone died, I was so sad. The entire show I was rooting for Tatsumi x Akame, and I mean, I genuinely hated the Tatsumi x Mine thing. I found it horrible. But idc that's my opinion. This show was amazing. If you want the perfect anime, this is it.-Aiz

“The reason does not matter. As long as tiny bit of hope exists, that is all that matter.”—Tatsumi.Akame ga Kill!  is a Japanese shounen manga series written by Takahiro and illustrated by Tetsuya Tashiro. It started serialization in Square Enix's Gangan Joker in March 2010. An anime television series adaptation of the main series premiered in Japan in July 2014. The story of the anime focuses on Tatsumi, a young villager that travels to the Capital, to become a soldier and to earn enough money to save his village. When Tatsumi reaches his destination point, he finds out that the country he wants to serve is rotten; however, one man cannot do anything against the whole country. Thankfully, Tatsumi encounters a group of assassin known as Night Raid. That group tries to assassinate all rotten politicians that do nothing but torture people, and to rebuild their country as a place, where all people have the right to live. Will the assassin group called Night Raid, together with Tatsumi, be able to change their rotten country? Find out the answer now. While the story line sounds intriguing, it has too many flaws to be good. To be more precise, it has three main flaws: it is rushed, it relies too much on death, and it is unclear whether the main focus of this series is comedy, drama, or action. Not only the anime suffers these three flaws, but also it does not explain enough: Akame ga Kill! does show characters’ backstories, but, at the same time, they are so short and sometimes do not make sense at all. The only explanation that I have is that the creators of Akame ga Kill! did not have enough resources, and so they decided to omit some scenes and to make the story of this series more rushed. All In all, this is one of the weakest parts on this series. The animation and sound are, perhaps, the reasons why this anime is actually watchable. But again, the animation is average and I would never call it unique. Yes, character designs are not bad and, yes, action scenes are fine, but it is still not enough to say that the animation is good. Some scenes are extremely beautiful, but some are just ugly. Anyway, luck of budget is obvious even here. The sound is more or less good: not only the ED and OP themes are good, but also the OST is very enjoyable. Also, good voice actors compensate for pale characters. The characters are,  not that bad and I would highly recommend you to only think about characters and about characters only, forget about the story. Anyway, let us discuss the characters. I will start with Akame (anime is called Akame ga Kill!, by the way). Akame is one of the main characters of this series, but despite having her name in the anime’s title, the anime does not pay enough attention to her persona; it does show us that she is always hungry, quite, and calm, her backstory is okay and it also makes sense, but it will be shown a bit too late. What I am trying to say is that when we first see Akame, the anime heavily implies that she will be the main protagonist of this series, this anime is called Akame ga Kill!, after all, but, for some reason, Tatsumi receives more screen time than Akame. The next character I would like to discuss is Chelsea. Chelsea is also a member of Night Raid, she is extremely beautiful, and her cheerful personality helps to make this anime less dramatic. However, the main problem with her character is that she does not do anything for the story, she is absolutely useless. She is a member of the Night Raid and this organization is the main focus of this anime, so, um, why not pay more attention to Chelsea’s character? The next character is Esdeath, the only Akame Ga Kill’s best girl. Not only she is interesting, but also she might be the only character you will have faith in. Yes, she might be called a plain villain, but her actions and her character overall, MAKE SENSE.  AND finally the last character I would like to discuss is Seryuu. While she is annoying sometimes, she is one of the characters that I like and you will probably like, as well. She does what she finds important to do and to achieve her goals, she is ready literally for everything. Anyway, I would not say that the cast of this series is extremely bad; it is average, but not bad: some characters do not receive enough development, some characters are absolutely useless, and so on. Again, the characters and the story are not the problem of this anime, the only problem of this anime is that it did not have enough resources. All in all, if you still have not seen Akame ga Kill yet, I would highly recommend you to either read the manga, or watch the anime. Of course, reading the manga will the best case scenario, it is just MUCH-MUCH better, but still, the anime is not that bad. Yes, it is far from being good, but just do not expect something good: be ready for an average drama with some action elements.

Personally, I thought this anime was fantastic. When you first begin watching this animated series, you are introduced to a young enthusiastic protagonist named Tatsumi. He quickly ends up teaming with a group of assassins known as the Night Brigade. At first, it appears that this team of assassins is unbeatable. However, while the story continues, this team encounters many difficult challenges and obstacles. As a viewer, I can guarantee you that you will tear up and ultimately feel distraught due to the outcome of this anime. Akame Ga Kill! has so much emotion involved within its dialogue and the story it makes me want to re-watch it all over again. To conclude my review, I give Akame Ga Kill! a much deserved 5/5.

its an action anime series with decent story telling while i will say that the anime took a completely different route than the manga the show itself was still enjoyable and was what introduced me to the akame ga kill series if your a fan of anime with lots of action this show has plenty of it but if you want more story i suggest reading the manga its still going and some people i wont name are still alive in the manga that arent in the anime.However the show itself is an enjoyable watch.

If you hate yourself and wish to punish yourself with soul crushing emotional warfare, then this is the show for you.A great show, some characters don't get developed much, but others have so much depth that you grow deep connections with them.It's about a group of rebel assassins that seek to take out the tyrant empire, they fight using a large arsenal of interesting and cool weapons, the plot keeps itself together well and you never feel like something happened just because.As far as the manga goes, I didn't read it so I am not sure how it crosses over, but you need not read the manga to understand this story.The ending sure is a surprise but I feel that it's a good way to close it out.

The thing that shocked me was how easily this anime just kills so many "main" characters. But only two of these all deaths was somewhat moving to me. The anime is cool with all the battles and weapons and some of the characters I really enjoyed watching, but the thing that this anime failed to do to me is to make me cry.I am a super crybaby and there were some dramatic deaths but I didn't feel anything.
