This is the 1st Anime that I've decided to write a review for. I read the reviews for the show before I started it, as I always do, and they all warned about a dissatisfying ending but I still wanted to watch the show because I loved the premise of the story.I wasn't disappointed. The story started of at a great pace with a fantastic 1st episode that did a good job of setting the tone for the series. The chemistry between the characters was good and they all had interesting backgrounds. The animation was fluid and the action wasn't overplayed. The MC is a relatable without being ridiculously overpowered and It has a good voice cast.I honestly thought the reviews were wrong...till around halfway to 3/4 into the story. Now I can't vouch for the source material, which people say varies from the manga in the later parts, but It just fell apart...completely. Characters were dying without meaning and reason. There were serious pacing issues and the story took a real turn for the worst. I forced myself to keep watch because I hate leaving a series unfinished but it was seriously the hardest anime for me to finish. It pains me to write this because the series had so much potential and it was just wasted. I want to be able to recommend this show but I just can't. If you can somehow forgive the horrible ending and wasted character development, then there is a fantastic half a series of Anime there.

I thought this anime was great, it has great animation, a good story line, something the viewer/reader can really get into. You get to know the characters and their stories and I really enjoyed that.BUT, I personally wish they wouldn't have killed off just about everyone. reason being is I want a second season let alone I wanted those characters to develop more and see them achieve something even higher than saving the capitol from corruption. Though, I do want to mention that I understand the need for some characters to die, i.e some main (but secondary) characters, but seriously all of them except like 2? You killed off the hero. THE PERCEIVED HERO. It does raise an idea, to me, that if they intentionally killed off everyone to reveal that there may be a second season because if you watch the last episode it leaves a small opening with akame seeming to maybe want to rid the rest of the world of possible corruption that could be left over. OR if we go back in the story to what Tatsumi was imagining, an Imperial Arms that can bring back the dead.Though, This is all speculation and the hopes of 1 fan.

Akame ga Kill seemed promising in the first couple of episodes, giving you the impression it will explore themes such as the corrupted nature of humans, the moral definitions of good and evil and the consequences of wielding weapons that come with a potentially huge cost.  What you get though is a series of one dimensional characters with a one minute backstory moving through a paper thin plot that's quickly forgotten as everyone faffs about.  Everything established in previous episodes quickly gets forgotten, especially the one rule that's supposed to make every battle poignant and meaningful since it stops applying about a third of the way through.  In fact, you could pretty much start watching from the middle and never need to know what happened beforehand.While it isn't the worst anime I've seen, Akame ga Kill just feels like a bunch of action looking for a plot to fill it out.  There are definitely some likeable characters that emerge from the soup of generic archetypes but for the most part they are conjured up for a specific thing then cast aside without ever really being developed.  There are some enjoyable moments when the anime remembers it started a plot in the first episode but for the most part it's a series of disjointed and contrived events with very obvious foreshadowing.  Check it out if you have nothing else to watch but there are many better alternatives to look at first.

Animation: Akame Ga Kill is beautifully animated throughout. I especially loved the raw looking aspect of certain scenes.  Characters: All the characters are unique, this anime really works at putting you in the characters' shoes, as they solve their problems in their own way. You'll really hate the antagonists, and you'll fall in love with the protagonists.Storyline: Akame Ga Kill's plot is detailed and doesn't drag on unnecessarily like a lot of other anime.Action: Prepare for edge-of-your-seat action starting from the very first episode, to the very last! The fights are well portrayed, as the Imperial Arms play an important role in making the action exciting and unpredictable.Voice-Acting: Some of the female characters sound quite similar, but overall the voice acting is decent.Dialouge: Amazing and deep. I often find myself using quotes from this anime.Music: The openings, endings, and score are all too perfect for Akame Ga Kill's genre. I found myself singing along to the opening after watching two episodes.Genre: Comedy/Action/Horror/Fantasy. The Imperial Arms also provide a sci-fi feel in much needed areas.Conclusion: Akame Ga Kill is a great anime and I recommend it to anyone looking for a thrilling, interesting anime.

Where do I start? Before I watched this anime, I believed that I had already seen the best anime I was ever gonna see ( which was A Certain Magical Index)  but I was wrong. When I first heard that Akame Ga Kill was GreenLit,I was shocked. The Main Male Character to me, Tatsumi matured and got stronger over the course of the series. The Main Female Character Akame acted like a very cold person but on the inside she was a very kind person that worried about her friends. I absolutely loved her character on the show. This anime had some of the most epic fight scenes I have ever seen in an anime. The action was great and fluid. But also this anime is very tragic, no one is safe in ths anime. The characters were awesome both Night Raid and the Jaegers. They all had their own reasons for fighting but they both fought for the sake of the friends they made/ their group.

Over the course of this animation, you will be moderately pleased by its semi-creative action-scenes. There is very little character development, and the social interactions between characters are somewhat cliché. Its hidden ruthlessness can pull emotional strings from the audience, but for the most part it seems a tad too forced. The setting is rather bland; a vanilla villain that demonstrates no originality comes up with rather shallow obstacles for the protagonists to quash. Overall, this animation is not a waste of time, but it will be forgotten due to its cookie-cutter characters and average plot.

This Anime is one of my favorite anime if not my favorite. The story fun and interesting, with hints of fan service and a god amount of humor that fits perfectly. This show is so brutal with it's fight style without including the art style, which is beautiful. If you want an amazing 1 season anime to get into, that wont keep going on and on. Then this is for you!!! I hope you try and enjoy Red-Eye Kill!

I have some mixed feelings about this anime. This was a good anime, with an interesting story, but seriously, this is the george r r martin of anime. Everyone gets killed off accept two, and even the paths they chose after the minister and others are defeated is lame. Pretty unhappy about the ending though. And dont get me started on Leone's lame death scene! 1) how does a flint gun have 10 rounds in it 2) why didnt she take the gun after the minister got down 3) how was she able to climb a tower to meet Akame, and roam the Capital, yet still die from bullet wounds.  BAH! The ending was bad. So much potential in this anime, but the ending made me feel like I wasted my time watching it.

This show was absolutely fantastic, until the final episode. Then it became an okay show. The ending completely ruined everything, in my opinion, but I’ll rant more about that later. Like I said, the show was pretty great up until that point, so it was obviously doing something right. I mean, I even stayed up till 4:30 in the morning on a school night to finish the show. It was addicting. Anyway, the show kept its focus on its characters and on the action, which is what a show like this should do. It didn’t focus on the plot, as it wasn’t original and it didn’t need to waste time developing it. A bunch a people trying to take down a corrupt capital? Seen that many, many times, so there was no point on focusing on it. These characters aren’t complex or anything, but they’re likable and enjoyable to watch. If you hated them, the entire show would be unwatchable, as you're supposed to be rooting for them to win. The action scenes are violently entertaining, beautifully animated, and plentiful. Once you’ve combined that with the likable characters, you have a pretty great show. Alas, the ending ruined it all. *SPOLIER FROM NOW ON* From here onward I’m probably gonna go into spoiler territory, so you’ve been warned. Ok, the final battle is happening, everything has led to this. Tatsumi dies from stopping the Emperor’s Imperial Arms from crushing everyone, Akame faces of with General Esdeath and wins, and Leone dies after being shot by the minister. That is what they go with. Now, I would have been ok with Tatsumi dying if he was a stronger, more complex character or if he and Akame would have had a stronger relationship. If he would have been more complex, I would have felt some emotion when he died. Instead I felt nothing to be honest. Since Tatsumi dies in Akame’s arms, them having a stronger connection would have also been a good way to make me feel sad. Alas, Tatsumi just dies and I didn’t really care. I have the same opinion about Leone’s death. I would have been fine with it, except for the fact that it came out of nowhere and felt incredibly rushed, sloppy, and all around stupid. After seeing her kick all sorts of ass, and survive having her arm cut off, seeing her die by gunshots was extremely underwhelming and stupid. The all powerful Leone was taken down by freaking gunshots. Lame. Those 2 things really made me angry and did take a lot away from the show quality wise. However, I don’t think they were enough for me to not recommend this show. It’s fun, addicting, and has plenty to appreciate, just has an awful ending. 6.9/10

It hooked me on the first episode! It has it's anime tropes like girl with pink hair, girl with giant D's, male protagonist who's scared of aforementioned D's, but it's got a really good story, enjoyable characters, cool action scenes, and some nice blood, gore, and dismemberment. It's also got an amazing art style, the animation is top quality, and it has some laugh out loud moments! 11/10 for Double D's!

I won't spoil the ending for anyone but i'm just going to leave it at being horrible in my opinion. But the anime itself was great, i often found myself on the edge of my seat in the action scenes, laughing my ass off at the humor, feeling disgust towards the "villains" and their actions, or crying at the tear-jerking moments this anime provides. Definitely worth a watch and would be 5 stars if it had stuck closer to the manga version and not had such a unfulfing ending. Well this is my opinion of the review so it's up to you whether or not you take it.

To be quite frank, I'm not sure how I feel about this. On one hand it's entertaining at times while on the other its writing is sub-par. I decided to watch it because of the kill the evil empire plot, which happens to be one of my favorite in literature, used in both Fullmetal Alchemist: Brotherhood and Code Geass; both to which I love. However, AGK doesn't live up to the supposed hype I've heard of. I figured there were various reasons why and I did everything I could to figure that out and came into some form of a conclusion.The storyline itself is fine but the pacing doesn't help it. There were moments when characters die off faster than I would expect. Some sections of the series could have been more effective if they were on earlier. Such as Chelsea's development(or flashback for that matter) could've been moved back a couple episodes. The majority of deaths are single episodes dedicated to a character that make us feel something for said character at the very last second. That is mediocre writing in itself. But I liked how it was always moving forward and everything, somehow, had a relation to progress the plot, rather than go on into a new story continuously.The tone is constantly conflicted with random humor. It was really bothersome so I decided  to check out the source material. The source material also had comedic moments but the use of paneling was clever and didn't bother too much with the drama the majority of the time. But with the anime format, everything has the same amount of focus. It reminded me of Fullmetal Alchemist or Soul Eater, which were also like that in their mangas and anime. But even in a manga, it doesn't look good all the time and that goes for the anime as well. It ends up looking edgy when moments contrast like that.At some point, it diverged from the source material. From there, it went on with a lot of illogical moments where the tension dies down because of it. There was a heavy amount of needless moments that seemed convenient more than anything else.The characters were one-dimensional but strangely sympathetic in a way. Perhaps that's just the deaths speaking but whatever. The characters lack deep thought but they followed their ideologies accordingly. However, they didn't come out as sincere to me because of how they don't seem serious about what they did. There were a few standouts such as Esdeath, who everyone surprisingly loves. Myself included for whatever reason. The characters aren't bad, but in general don't have much depth to them. It's the same problem I had with SAO. "Deaths and psychological themes don't make characters any better." was the initial response in my SAO review, and the same goes with this. In fact, I think I can copy and paste the section from that review and it'll fit. But whatever.The animation is okay. It looks good sometimes but it's not necessarily consistent. As a whole, it lacked good fight direction. The cinematography seems random and you don't really know the positions of the characters or location. A lot of the movement didn't flow well together. It looks cool but is lacking in dynamic viewing experiences. But at least it keeps its fight scenes isolated rather than have an extreme use of terrain destroying attacks. The artwork look cool. I like the designs of the characters even if they do look extremely generic. But then again, I'm a sucker for action, fantasy designs and I guess these fit the bill enough. Another plus is the gore, I love it. I can't deny my love for a fun blood bath regardless. It doesn't seem needless and the blood looked great. I could always expect White Fox to animate blood properly after seeing Kanatagatari.The soundtrack was nice. Despite her lack of experience, I really like Sora Amamiya's voice. Her singing on the first opening and second ending was great and had great flow to it. And the background music does tend to fit the tone despite the tone's continuous deviating. But I'll give it that.The voice acting had some strong points. Namely because there were a lot of emotional moments but that's just the script. Tatsumi's voice acting was probably the best right after episode 8. It was a nice scene and was actually subtle in how it was handled. Overall VAs were good throughout and had a good consistency.It didn't fall into a sh*thole I guess, but it wasn't amazingly good. Enjoyable as it was, the writing is meh-ish more than anything else.1.5/5 stars

This is Akame Ga Kill!, an anime adaptation of the manga. After the anime exploded and everyone was on the hype train, people found out what kind of anime it was and what to expect of it (similar, but less hyped than Shingeki No Kyojin). While you may expect me to say that it was an emotional roller coaster (and it was), I'm going to focus on the story aspect and why the story is the true roller coaster. Now, I watched the anime without reading the manga so I had no background information on what to expect or really what is going on. At first I thought it was a generic action anime about a bunch of people with super powers fighting other people with super powers. After the shocker of episode one, I was brought down to the ground and realized that  this is some hardcore sh*t. Being a lover of dark stories (SnK, Fate/Zero) this was an instant favorite for me. There are three best parts of the roller coaster, the climb, the sudden drop, and when it stops and you process whatever just happened to you. A good roller coaster will keep your mind blank from the drop to the stop. Now imagine a roller coaster that was over hyped - it is said to be the greatest roller coaster ever with the best drop in the world. A must have experience so to speak. The climb was great and the drop seemed like it was crazy, but only after stopping do you realize that it was sort of over hyped and they were feeding you total sh*t the whole time.Now Akame ga Kill is similar to the over hyped sh*t feeding roller coaster - while it may have been a great ride, it still does not live up to the expectation, probably because they built it a lot differently from the blueprints (the manga). While I haven't read the manga, I've studied it enough to know where the anime went wrong. Verdict: If the anime wasn't an adaptation of the manga, it would've rocked the socks off of people. But it is, and the socks are half-way rocked off of but suddenly the just can't leave the feet anymore.

Not my type so 3 is as high as I'll go.
