Definitely not my favorite anime but it wasn't a terrible waste of time.

maybe it was the fact i was watching it with someone who has read the manga or maybe it was the fact that it took me so long to really sit down and watch this anime even through it was in my queue but that the point after a couple of episodes i got bored with the anime. the ending was not very interesting i guess since i new that people was going to die it should have been more exciting for me to watch but it wasn't it was just a monster of the week. it seemed we were all set p to see one main character when we should have been reading the title an known better even though that is true why would i care about her after more episodes then not her story is told and it reads like a bad b movie really she supposed to carry this anime after all this time because i really care about her after nothing happens with her for so long. just read the manga i heard it good

This anime, overall, was pretty good. The story was interesting and the action was very thorough. However, that being said, I had a few reservations.Many of the characters, I want to say a majority, were rather black and white. There was a bit of depth to them but honestly they came across as a little basic. Definitely a lot more could have been done with this series especially in fleshing out some of these characters. The plot, at times, left a little to be desired. There was a few questionable developments and a couple plot holes but generally it was alright; nothing that ruined the show for me.If you're looking for an action-heavy story of rebellion with just a smidgen of romance and about a gallon of gore, I'd definitely give this one a go. It gets four stars from me.

Assassins. Political corruption. Sublime action and suspenseful plot twists. Akame Ga Kill has all of the ingredients of an elite anime title.  Its concept tackles political ideals that straddle the line of good and evil—what one would consider right and wrong. It isn’t afraid to take major risks to prove itself suspenseful and keep its viewers engaged. It incorporates shock value all the while maintaining a light-hearted easygoing identity. Despite this, AgK is a lot like a restaurant special that’s missing that extra kick that’d make you a regular customer: It just isn’t as engaging as its unique direction suggests.Take Tatsumi, a young villager who quickly discovers that the Capital—the central hub of Akame Ga Kill’s universe— is ripe with corrupt citizens and government officials that outwardly abuse their power to satisfy their inner desires. Not long after reaching the Capital on a pilgrimage to make money for their homeland, Tatsumi and his friends are taken in by a family with the intent to torture and kill.  He is fortunately saved by a notorious assassin group, Night Raid, and decides to embark with them on a mission to put an end to the Capital’s unjust corruption— by any means necessary. This is easily one of Akame ga Kill’s key strengths.  Night Raid’s methods to destroy the Capital aren’t exactly righteous; rather, they are almost as brutal as their adversaries. Occasionally, they’ll face an antagonist that has contrasting ideals that are very justifiable and make you begin to question Night Raid’s character as a group. Unfortunately, for every thought-provoking opponent are also a few maniacal, psychopathic and shallow opponents you’d expect from a children’s superhero TV short.The anime does make great, bold efforts to introduce characters that are engaging and appealing, albeit in a not-so-productive fashion. While still wholly embracing ultra-violent and somber themes, characters still spend their time—more often than not — engaging in lighthearted banter and fan-service scenes. This remains a very unique quality trait of AgK that viewers can surely appreciate; that is, until you realize that meaningful backstory and character development often take a backseat to such focus. This undoubtedly results in major plot and character development that are exhilaratingly daring in execution, yet feel fairly unmoving and formulaic. Nevertheless, when the risky decisions pay off, they pay amazing dividends in the form of rich, heavy, and suspenseful content.If there is one constant to the makeup of Akame Ga Kill, it’d surely be its combat scenes, which are incredibly solid throughout. Power in the Capital is largely influenced by Imperial Arms, ancient weapons with superhuman traits. From blades made of scissors to man-eating mascot characters, this concept lets the imaginations of the creators fly, leading to high-octane action that always proves itself unpredictable. It’s quite impressive what producers have done in the areas of presentation, especially in an industry where blockbuster action titles are given budgets that are far more exorbitant in value. From the animation and acting to the soundtrack, Akame ga Kill certainly delivers, even if it isn’t quite a jaw-dropping affair.This, coupled with the shock value and risky storytelling will keep you coming back each episode to eventually reach a conclusion that is both intriguing and a bit rushed. While the manga is still ongoing in Japan, producers for the anime adaptation took the tall task of devising its own original ending to the series, with mixed results. While it isn’t perfect, it is hard to ignore the many mature themes the anime unflinchingly explores while attempting to preserve its blithesome shounen identity. Even at its surface, it proves to be a fun, bloody, attractive action anime that I’d easily recommend to anyone looking for that next fix.

this anime kept me surprised. people were dying left to right like crazy, the animation was great it had awesome characters etc. i honestly enjoyed this anime to the fullest and recommend it to anybody who enjoys anime. one thing is for sure guys is you cannot get attached to characters. you'll find a favorite character but then they will die, you might think you wont watch it anymore but you will. akame ga kill will always keep you coming back no lie...

This, just this anime was everything that I thought it wouldn't be. The thing is I actually started the first episode and stopped two minutes in. Biggest mistake of my life, one day I had nothing to do and I finally wanted to know why this show was on the most popular. Boy did I find out. I never really review animes, but this one has really changed my perspective on things. DO NOT get attached to anyone, because your in a world full of heartbreak if you do. I caught myself almost crying after several episodes. You must, must watch this.

When I first saw this anime, the beginning met my expectations. They were not hesitating to take risks and push it. I am not one that likes my anime sugar coated and all that because it gets to a point that there is no point in watching something that meets your predictions on a regular basis, so something like this was a breath of fresh air...for a time.Keep in mind there are a few spoilers here so I would suggest just skipping over the blurb that isn't labeled if you want to keep your surprise, however they do have some major points in my argument. So read it at your own risk.Spoiler Alert! Click to show or hideOne of the main problems I had with the anime was the fact they decided to kill off so many characters when in the manga, they are clearly still alive and well. The anime itself not only kills the characters that are still alive in the manga, but they even kill off characters that makes you think the creators of the anime were all like "Cause why not!? Let's just kill them because we have no use for them!". The death of characters such as Mine and Leone were so incomplete and not within reason. Tatsumi I did not mind too much, since it is not everyday you see the main character die, but still there was no need when the manga is not even at that point.The animation is great and all, along with memorable and lovable characters that will stick with you through the whole thing. But the way it moves off from certain characters was rather disappointing for me. I wanted to see more of a certain few characters when they appear to have far more of a story than what is given to us. It basically feels incomplete.Even the build up to the point the final battle(s) felt underwhelming. We were suppose to believe that this major battle was going to go down and all that, but with the inconsistency in the actions along with reactions with both sides in the war made it feel that it was rushed to a point it was unbearable. Now I did enjoy it up to a certain point, do not get me wrong. But after the first half, it began to be tiresome and the end left me unsatisfied on so many levels. Especially when the anime creators decided to put their own version of the events (including the ending) when the manga does not mention them at all since it is still incomplete.I would not be surprised at all if we see a remake of this anime when the manga is complete because the major changes they made were not only unbearable from not only the manga-first person's perspective but the anime-first viewer as well.

(Disclaimer: I will be changing this review how I see fit as more episodes are released so my review might fluctuate within episodes on how I feel and leave it rated as). Currently I have found time to write a new review, I shall rewatch the whole season so I make sure I don't miss anything for my final review.I love how one episode is already out and someone already cried about it being too brutal which I'd say good job on that, means you're obviously doing things correctly over there pissing them all off!. It's lovely how people don't give a whole season a try before giving a review (Wish I can review those reviews to tell them to go more in-depth). Going back onto how I think about the first episode so far is that how it was executed which much to my amazement it PERFECTLY captured the first arc in the manga and that blown my mind, it was as dark in the anime as it was in the manga which I LOVE!!!! Props for so far following the first chapter flawlessly and not leaving anything out! Onto the art style and visuals, The cg can be horendous at times but other than those few times like parts where Goblin Slayer was cg instead of being drawn. Only at certain times you can tell something is cg but it's not like the third season of Overlord *cough* anyways I absolutely loved it and I plan on changing my review as the series goes on! All I can say is this is Doom Guy but with Goblins and the name is changed to Goblin Slayer. Also the music that played while he walked in was just bada**hopefully the rest of the soundtrack follows that direction which would be absolutely WONDERFUL since it matches what the anime's mood is about! This anime is really inspired by Doom and The Punisher...So episode two came out and it expands the history of who Orcbolg (Goblin Slayer) is and why he has a certain hatred for Goblins. Currently this has me waiting for the next episode since after the outro there was a little clip showing what the next episodes has to offer. So far I am enjoying the anime since it follows almost identically to the manga! Not to mention the opening is so epic! I'll probably will be listening to this on repeat for the next couple of days just for how good it is.Episode Three:  So far they are taking their time establishing lore and new characters in Goblin Slayer, this episode specifically was to introduce the Elf, Lizard Priest, and the Dwarf Shaman as Goblin Slayer's party (for now). Don't have much else to say until the fourth episode comes out.

This anime starts of as many fantasy adventure's do; light hearted with beautiful score. However things turn intense and graphic very quickly. If you are weak of stomach or faint of heart this anime is not for you. If you are itching for something with more edge than a warriors sword, que no further.Viewer discretion advised. Features intense violenceRapeNudityand the equalivent of the Punisher with a sword.

I am writing this review immediately after watching the first episode, so I hope my observations hold true.  But I am very impressed with Goblin Slayer so far!  For too long shows in the action/adventure and fantasy genres have treated combat as some glorified dance.  Even shows that portrayed real violence often downplayed the brutality that combat can engender.  Don't understand the difference I'm suggesting?  Gettysburg was violent; Iwo Jima was brutal.  Bayonets are violent; napalm is brutal.  This show is dark, ugly, and unsettling.  This show, despite being fantasy, is very real (and I understand that the source material depicts much worse brutality).  This was needed, and I'm happy to see it here.  I only hope that they don't try to lighten it.

WARNING! DON'T LET THE CUTE ANIME GIRL FOOL YOU! This show is not for those with fragile spirits! It is violent a gruesome! You have been warned!If the anime follows the Manga/light novel faithfully (and based on the first episode it probably will) Goblin Slayer is going to take you on a brutal, violent, and frequently tragic journey.The world is loosely based off of Dungeons and Dragons rule sets and there's absolutely no "POWER OF FRIENDSHIP" deus ex machina nonsense in this story. Our boy Gob slayer is just a man on a rage induced quest of revenge to completely eradicate all Goblins off the face of the world. He does so with experience, experimentation, creativity, determination, and above all, ruthlessness. He HATES goblins and shows no mercy to them.I won't bother with any more details about the story but I will say if you enjoy old school anime that never shied away from violence and horror on a realistic level, You're gonna like Goblin Slayer and watch the team RIP AND TEAR!

A lot of people are reviewing this writing "rah rah rah rape shouldn't be in an anime rah rah rah" or that the fact that rape was shown makes it a bad anime...first of all in any Lore about humanoid species and especially Chaotic evil types, rape is a common theme, this anime is supposed to tap into the absolute DARKNESS that is adventuring, I mean Grimgar of Fantasy and Ash was brutal (skipped on rape so many probably would prefer that)Watch the anime for what it is, don't hate on it because you find its storytelling disturbing, I'm betting each one of the nay sayers at one time watched an anime that had a sick or twisted scene and absolutely loved it where others turned green in sickness.Can't wait for the next episode of a more realistic world based on brutality and magic, a world comprised of people who actually risk something to get something, a more REAL take on what Grimgar of Fantasy and Ash delivered.

First off I'll say this is NOT for everyone. This is not even for MOST people. If you are easily disturbed do not watch this show. If debasement, rape, child murder, etc. is too much for you, do NOT watch this show.This show is as realistic as a fantasy anime can be, I suppose. In the real world, women in war get raped, disgusting as it is, this show has that. In the real world, people make mistakes in battle and die quickly. This show, at least in the first episode, is unforgiving in that. In the real world people piss themselves in fear of death and being raped. This show has that as well, some of you sick pervs will probably even like it. I've read reviews that people don't like this show because the characters in the first episode are inept, useless, etc, especially the main priest girl. Well, I say this is realistic. People who have never fought or killed before TEND to be USELESS in a fight to the death, especially a fight as brutal as shown in the first episode. Spoiler Alert! Click to show or hideI read a review where a person couldn't figure out that the reason she couldn't heal the wizard was because her healing magic doesn't cure poison despite the show explaining it to everyone who cared to watch. I imagine those people were too busy typing their one star reviews to actually pay attention to the plot  In this show, experience, pragmatism, and guile count for more than friendship, a plucky attitude, and refusing to give up. Or, at least, it would seem so from the first episode. I made update my review as the show continues.

It implied rape and dismemberment within the first 10 minutes. I can respect that, Doesn't shy away from blood but should really be showing the gore too. This feels like it should be brutal but I feel like its skating around showing it.Still the goblin slayer is an excellent professional character who treats the goblins like they are rats needing to be exterminated and he does not hold back or give them an inch. With him as the cornerstone character keeping this show together I feel like this will be a good show, just not great because they are too scared to really show the brutality they like to imply.

...brutal take on the dungeon crawler genre. It's a really good show. Really nice with a D&D show that's not just another dish on the same recipe. Better than Berserk (The animation, not the manga), almost as good as Drifters and Hellsing. Watch if you like shows like that. Skip if you prefer Danmachi and SAO. And that being said, it's really not that bloody. Berserk and Drifters are far worse. But it's not shonen either.

As a manga and light novel reader and fan, I was was ecstatic to see this series blow up like it did. With already four manga adaptions and an anime in its first two years of existence. However I was also very worried that the anime would shy away from what makes this series stand apart from its many peers. To my surprise this was NOT the case. Studio WhiteFox does it again with this adaptation. It captures the atmosphere of the manga and light novel shockingly well. The dark themes were rampant, the music was very appropriate, the art and animation are stellar and the CGI was acceptable so far. For new fans and watchers, I say give the first episode a watch. Unlike most shows you will know immediately if its for you. With that being said, the series actually gets better with time and is about much more than just the dark themes shown in that episode. If they keep this execution up, Goblin Slayer has the potential to easily be the show of the season.

There has been a bit of controversy about this show. And I can see why; it gives a more realistic depiction of violence than most other anime series I have seen.The main character hates goblins. I mean truly hates them; he is genocidal. In one particular scene he clubs to death a group of goblin children. And the narrative seems to support him in that. There doesn't seem to be any subversion of the character or situation whatsoever, it's straight up "Goblins are evil and deserve genocide".Combat is hectic and frightful, with the characters fighting not just for victory, but for their lives. Downed heroes are crowded on and brutalized.Some female combatants who are defeated, and female civilians, are raped by the goblins, both on and off screen. Nothing sexually explicit is shown, but it's clear what is happening.If you're an adult, and can handle it, it's a good show. Solidly written and animated. Younger viewers should not watch it.

Hands down the best anime of 2018. Great story as it takes a different look on the mmo adventurer anime,  its not the cheesy loot driven feel good game that you login with your buddies anime but a realistic take on what being an adventurer tasked with killing and putting their lives on the line would actually mean. The artistry and animation are top notch, the fights aren't based on the characters almighty strength or convenient power boosts that some other anime fights monotonously follow thru every episode. Overall great anime and certainly worth the time watching.

This anime is great! Halfway through, I couldn't take my eyes off the screen. I was so scared and anxious at the same time to see what was gonna happen next! Sure there are a lot of darkness and some people can't handle that, but that's what makes this unique compared to other anime. Ok maybe berserk has some similarities, but the way this anime started out was greatly executed. This anime got my attention and it's only the first episode. I hope this can continue to build up and not rush things. I definitely want to see more darkness since it plays around with my emotions a lot. For others, I don't recommend this anime to you if you can't handle this amount of blood and horror. However, this is a great anime.

It definitely is remenicsent of a DnD tabletop game, but with a several added in fantasy bits. The character is a bit of a trope, but it works as they don't try to expand his reach too much and grows his character slowly. The supporting characters are great for filling in as support, and each one of them covers the basic tropes and stereotypes so nothing new there.Overall, the story is great, its simple yet gives the complexities of how difficult something seemingly-insignificant can be. I will say that there are consistent fan-servicing parts, but as this plays into the theme and purpose of the main character, its accepted.

If you're a fan of Tabletop RPGs you'll like Goblin SlayerLet me start off by saying I read the first chapter of the manga and saw the rape and I immediately had the same kneejerk reaction that a lot of the anime community had in response to the first episode. But however I kept reading and now watching and the series is pretty great, though there are some minor things cutout of the anime in order to save time which is sad but understandable.The fact that the Protagonist Goblin Slayer uses inventive ways to handle various situations is reminiscent of playing D&D and how creative you can get with your actions and plans, also there are heavy handed references to D&D and other fantasy genres such as Lord of The Rings which is really fun to see.If you watched the first episode or know someone that watched only the first episode I heavily encourage you to watch an episode or two more to see that it's not always doom and gloom!

Four Episodes in and the series finally starts to feel it is finally finding its footing and pacing. Which is quite understandable with what needed to be phased out of the first two episodes of the series. Some of you may have guessed by now that one of the big things about the manga was it's vivid depicting of the shock factor. Which did not shy away from striking depictions of rape amongst other things. As disturbing as those moments were though, they did help set the pace, tone and narrative that is the Goblin Slayer series. They help elevator the dangers and horrors of Goblins, establishing not only the fear of a brutal death, but the terror of not dying. And set the tone of what makes Goblin Slayer the person, different from adventurers.By glossing over the first band of adventures (which ruins the fake out that these characters were more involved with the series) and entirely removing the 2nd group of adventures from ep. 2 as well as glossing over how dire and needed goblin slaying is; Goblin Slayer's overall presence comes off a bit diminished then in the manga. We don't get to see the clear difference in his experience not just compared to novices but even a band of experienced adventurers unfamiliar with Goblin tactics. These simple and understandable changes lead to some awkward pacing. Luckily the brutally of Goblin Slayer is enough to hold a fans attention and the series does its best to reintroduce some of the dialogue and ideas back in other ways but a bit of balance is lost when they skip over some of the dialogue and narrative as it originally was.Episode 3 is a bit awkward too since it also cuts some world and character building as well as crams in more of the manga into an episode then it probably should have, but the pay off comes in Episode 4. Episode 4 comes out untouched by censoring and the dialogue and narrative are allowed to flow at it's intended pace. We finally get into the more methodical nitty, gritty approach of the series then the hinted at or glossed over aspects of it from earlier episodes. We get a much better idea and feel of Goblin Slayer's experience and drive. The things that make him different from an Adventurer. The things that make what he does different from an adventure. The things that honestly make him better then the average Adventurer.Luckily at this point, the series will go into more and more in what makes Goblin Slayer who he is rather then showing off more shocking moments that need to be censored out and NOW is when I start to get excited for the series. Now that pretty much the porn is out of the way, we can get into the grit of the series. And honestly now that the series seems to have found itself, it makes the first 3 episodes a bit more understandable and bearable.

slay em all i say. goblins are always represented as funny little creatures that are just easy to scare off or defeat. if goblins were real, they would be like me. disgusting and slimy little creatures that have no regard for morality or ethics. cant wait for goblin slayer to kill all those repugnant green homunculi so the world will be a much better place. i can deal with the dark stuff as long as i one day get to see a goblin free world.

Waited for this anime for so long its dark gorish and a hint of rape like berserk well not hint many hints. Animation is slow in some parts, the does not matter as anime follows manga truthfully. Voice actors are really well selected especially  the goblin slayer great dsrk voice and great acting. Sound design has a really well place eerie sound and music.Summary of Story is just about a guy who hunts goblins only he never takes any other quests and people one by one take a liking to him as he hunts goblins.

To begin with, this not your typical adventure anime with the overused plot of an overpowered protagonist with a harem cast.This anime is gory and brutally realistic (in terms of how foes treat their enemies).The first episode introduces you with a adventurer group accepting a quest to hunt goblins.  Don't be fooled by the initial light-heartedness however. This is where the element of realism comes to play. Rookie adventurers who head into a battle half cocked and unprepared will surely suffer the harsh consequences. The goblins, all-male group have been known to kidnap young girls and women from villages thus adventurers are tasked with taking care of the menace. With that said, you can probably figure out what the goblins do to the young women in order to procreate. Unfortunately, some reviewers will give this anime a 1-star rating simply because of that. The wilderness of a medieval fantasy world is lawless and unfair. Murder and rape exists in these type of settings. If you can not handle that, don't watch this anime.Further into the anime we are introduced to the man simply known as Goblin Slayer. He is not the typical overpowered hero in the sense of just having "unproportionately bloated stats" but uses experience and tactics for the most part to outwit and trap the goblins as he combats them. It is a refreshing and thoughtful approach to introduce the protagonist.The anime also features amazing music and sound that draws you in and build a level of suspense, desperation, or hype.All in all, If you can't handle gore and rape done in a manner that is realistic and adds to the story (and not simply for the sake of doing so), then this anime is not for you. For those that want to enjoy more mature or seinen elements like Berserk in their adventure anime then this anime is right up your alley.

After watching the entire season for myself, I feel like many of the reviews that are scoring this anime low, never had much interest in it in the first place. They simply "watched" the first episode with the intent to be malicious. They harbored no intent of giving it a fair shake. All in the name of trying to potentially "shame" the creators/writers for using such dark themes. Others, however, may not of had such intent and I can understand that so long as the reviews were well thought out. However, I intend to provide my own opinion on the content within this show based solely on the overall basis of:- story- characters- deliveryStory: Governed by the gods, the world and it's denizens are shaped with every throw of the dice. However, there is one that goes unnoticed by the gods, for nothing is expected of him. To them, he is but a small pawn, in their game of chance. Spoiler Alert! Click to show or hideWhat they don't realize is that he, the unnoticed, defies the dice. Not letting the gods roll for him.Characters: Goblin Slayer - Instead of seeing this world through the eyes of the heroic hero(s), we are treated to witnessing the world through Goblin Slayer. A character that is more along the lines of what usually would be a side character to most viewers. He isn't all powerful, heroic, or virtuous like we see in things like Sword Art: Online, One Punch Man, etc.. Goblin Slayer is just another villager that witnessed a severely tragic event that shaped both his personally and his motivation for continuing to exist.  Spoiler Alert! Click to show or hideHis sole purpose in life has become the eradication of all goblins. Intent on killing them all down to the very last child, so that no one else will have to go through the pain of losing loved ones, their homes, everything, to a goblin attack like he did.  Priestess - A 15 yo magic caster that has come of age and decided to become an adventurer to better help people. Young and naive, she could be considered to have a heart of gold but learns quickly that the world is not a nice place. A partial "damsel in distress", you could say, that slowly grows along side Goblin Slayer. She really felt like missed potential to be a better overall fleshed out character. Often being considered a nuisance by viewers because of her inability to "grow a spine" per-say.  However, I feel like she is a good counter balance to Goblin Slayer. Spoiler Alert! Click to show or hidePlaying a part in helping Goblin Slayer slowly gain bits of his lost humanity back through their interactions, both in town and while on quests/adventures. High Elf/Dwarf/Lizardman - I'll mark this as spoiler simply due to precaution. Spoiler Alert! Click to show or hideA group of silver adventures that are hired to handle a goblin problem by the representatives of the great races. The group overall has a good dynamic of comedy in the form of the interactions between the Dwarf and High Elf. Meanwhile, the Lizardman is more mild tempered of the group, trying to keep the bickering down and be a voice of reason. They bring a nice finishing chemistry to the "main character's party in the anime. Delivery: The anime finds a balance of both drawn and CG that works out to a fair quality. There will be times that it can be clearly noticed but overall it doesn't feel as terribly relied upon in comparison to say, 3rd season of Overlord. The detail given to the backgrounds are a nice quality that helps build upon the setting that the characters find themselves in. Providing a good sense of depth and atmosphere for viewers. The music, oh lord, the music! The composition of the various tracks are breathtaking and so beautifully composed to fit what is happening during each episode. Selecting a good track to be played during key moments in a scene can be critical. In the end, I feel like people have too strong of an attachment to main characters of anime that fit the ideals of morality or society of real life. Even the themes seem to be expected to shy away from things that we may consider immoral or improper to show. However, not all anime are going to be written with the intention to fit these things. If they were then we'd end up with hardly any variety and potentially with lack luster anime to enjoy. I greatly enjoy when an anime delves into showing some darker themes. As long as these themes are needed for the story and this anime does much better with the darker theme in place. Not all stories are sunshine and rainbows. Neither do all main characters need to be virtuous champions of justice.

After watching the 11 episodes available, I have to say this is one of the more grounded fantasy series available.  There have yet to be attack moves being called out before their usage (aside from the mage types or clerics, but they are casting spells). The tactics used and reasons for the actions taken are very believable.  This is definitely not for the squeamish, because the consequences of thinking this is another lighthearted fantasy anime will have you thinking differently before the end of the first episode.

Anyone calling this a "Dark" and "Edgy" anime are, semi right but also partially wrong.This anime uses shock factor just to say "Fuck you this isn't some generic SAO bullshit if you can't stomach it then fuck off" And that's why i love it. The whole point of the anime is to be unique and different. Many people say that this is a Berserk rip off just because of the gore and concept, and i honestly do see the connection, Berserk was was most likely an influence on GS which is another factor about this manga and anime that i loVE!Also lizardman is a top tier waifu, up there with speedwagon

There hasn't been an anime in quite a while that has had the value that I believe Goblin Slayer has. The over the top violence, adventuring, and phenomenally written characters add to the beauty of this anime. It portrays a human character, who is only powerful because of his skill, wit, and ingenuity and though by episode 4 there hasn't been much touch up on it the viewer seems to be very connected to the internal struggle of the Goblin Slayer which is very present in the manga. It just is seems to fit the genre of Japanese anime it is categorized in very well. Compared to other current animes Goblin Slayer stands out as the one anime to truly derive from the current meta with a uniquely dark tone. Though some people find this to be a bad thing that hurts the show, it is exactly what gained its popularity. An amazing manga and the director not being afraid to follow the story no matter what people say. Plus also it's very much like Berserk which draws lots of fans from the manga to this animated series. Another derivative is the fact that so many people seem to connect it the way D&D is played, the whole over the top and creative direction some scenes take adding to the fan base and positive feedback.-A must watch if you're into a darker story (even though I could argue that it's not as dark as people think) or enjoy Doom, you'll love this anime. Great characters, interesting directive, phenomenal animation, and action that'll have your heart beating faster. Hope this review was helpful, or you at least enjoyed it. Thanks and have a good day my friends (｡◕‿◕｡)

I will start by saying this: THIS IS NOT A FANTASY SHOW FOR THE YOUNG OR IMMATURE! Of course, if you've seen ANY of White Fox's other anime (Akame ga Kill, Re:Zero in particular) You'll know that they're no strangers to over the top violence and brutality. There's moments that make you want to close your eyes and turn away because of how horrifying and disturbing they are. That said, it's a very good show so far. My only real complaint is the CG style in which the eponymous named character is sometimes animated in, is...not the best. There's a lot of people bashing this show online (I'm looking at you Twitter, Tumblr, etc.) and the raving criticisms are completely based on "triggering". Watch the show, that's my advice, BUT be warned that there are things you will see that aren't for the faint of heart. If you saw Akame ga Kill or Re:Zero though, you'll be fine.

Let me start out by saying this is not your typical happy go lucky fantasy anime. Its edgy and brutal and far more realistic than some have the tolerance for. However, I find that it stands out in an ocean of sappy mediocre anime's. I believe that you should reserve judgement for any new show for at least 5 episodes to establish its characters, plot, and story line.  As for me I was hooked at episode 1.

There is much controversion on social media regarding this anime, so I gotta also refer to that. We have some of those "We need to stop this rape culture" comments. To those I respond: "Dude, this is about a man who is trying to do just that"Rape scenes and brutality - yes, they are here. But not for the sake of controversy itself. Thanks to them you are able to understand Goblin Slayer motives. Have you ever seen your loved ones hurt? If so, you will understand it as well.For me this anime is about the fact that goodwill has many different faces. Here we have that in form of GS and priestess' faces. One is stern and focused on punishing evil as a concept, another is cheerful and just wants happiness of others. And regardless of side you are on, both those faces need to support each other.

Hey guys, manga reader here. I just want to start this review off by saying that I won't spoil any plot points. However, I will say that you will not regret watching this anime. The first episode was quite controversial, and there will definitely be depictions of rape and gore through the entire series. However, calling this anime a Bezerk clone is a gross misrepresentation of what this series is.For starters, the plot. The plot is pretty simple, and you get the gist of everything in the first few episodes. Goblin Slayer is a man who, as a child, witnessed the murder and rape of his family and the destruction of his village. He then devotes his entire life and being to killing every goblin he can. His party grows eventually, and he slowly begins to see more to the world than just killing goblins. You see, the meat of the plot comes from character development, and the interaction between the party members.The cast of characters are all loveable, as you will eventually get to meet them as the episodes progress. I find every character in interesting and entertaining, and I am seriously looking forward to meeting the cast in this anime adaptation. So far, the voice acting is very good, and they did well to capture the tone of all of the characters. Music is quite good, and I enjoyed the opening, even though I normally hate engrish in anime. Fits the tone of the show very well, however. Another note, there will definitely be dark moments in the show, but there will also be moments of humor, as well as cute girl moments. This really helps to balance out the anime really well. If you're still on the fence, trust me. You'll be glad to stick with this show. And while you're at it, give the manga or light novel a try. Some things that the anime just can't capture will be there, including some internal dialogue and character interaction.

It begins with a group of four giggling happy adventures off to make a name for themselves. They lack experience, but they wish to learn by doing. We see this a lot in anime. Just this false sense of strength, because the characters believe in themselves. The first episode shows what can happen if you don't prepare. It's good to be confident and it's good to want to learn. This group took up a task, and had no clue what it was they were getting themselves into. A prepared experienced adventure comes to the aid of the group. His actions highlight just how prepared one must be to live life as an adventurer. It's a life without easy choices.Edit: I've just started reading the Manga, and it's really good. Feels like it was very much inspired by DnD. There is always a strategy to all the fight scenes. It makes it more fun.

It is not for the faint of heart. If it continues to follow the source material it will be an amazing dark adventure. I look forward to more. It's hard to write a review without spoiling but be aware that the violence (of all types) continues. For those whining about the rapey goblins remember one of the ways they procreate is from kidnapping women. Also it serves a purpose and is a huge factor in backstory.

Please Note that this is an episode 1 review along with knowledge of the manga and I will try not to spoil anything that comes down the road.That said there a few things going for this anime. First - the light novel that's its based off of is good (so I hear) and the manga adaptation is fantastic. Based off of episode 1, I would say the anime will follow the same route. And second the animation of this show looks to have been done in the best possible route for it. There are a lot of points I could mention but the best easy to show comparison from episode one are the two lead characters were are introduced to. Goblin Slayer and The Priestess. The later is bright and cheery in both design and nature, what you would expect from your typical anime heroin, while the former, Goblin Slayer, is darker, depicted in more realistic tones and colors but still having the silver of steel to show that he is indeed the protagonist (I don't know if we can call him a true hero) of the story.Story Summery:Goblin Slayer follows an adventurer in a fantasy world that is known as, you guessed it, Goblin Slayer. He's a silver ranked adventurer, the highest rank you'll see in the field, but nearly exclusively hunts goblins. Hence, the name and this is his story. My Thoughts:Now this show is very gritty, it is dark to the extreme and goes over many troubling and disturbing themes, scenes, and aspects of life. Due to this, the anime and manga are what I would call a hard R, because of the subject matter involved. The story is still great and quite possibly is accentuated by this fact, however; if you do not want to see gruesome deaths, (and no, not your typical anime death, a more realistic and terrible death), rape, and other dark matters littered through your story, I HIGHLY advise you to pass over this show. If you are okay with seeing it, I HIGHLY recommend watching this show. It appears that the anime is using tools of the trade to not directly show some things that were in the manga, likely to have an easier time airing the show on television, but we will have to wait and see if that is true or not, since after all this is only an review of the show based off of episode 1.Summery: A great show to watch but is Hard R with disturbing themes so think carefully before you decide to watch it.

Warning, I'm going to be spoiling a little bit. not the plot or events that happen but the tone of the next few episodes.A lot of people came into goblin slayer expecting something way lighter and are calling it edgy for the sake of being edgy based on the first episode; But, that's the entire point of the first episode! it's to establish the cruel nature of this world's goblins and to show you how terrifying it is for the weaker inhabitants of this world to deal with them. the rape scene was to show what happens to the women who are captured by the goblins, they killed those characters off to make you HATE the goblins. And that's why when Goblin Slayer shows up and fucks them up it feels so damn good. The show isn't going to be nothing but gore and hard core stuff(it will still have a fair amount of it though) it has other elements to make it enjoyable, those moments will be interlaced in comedy and interesting character interaction. so before dropping it and writing it off as a berserk wanna be watch til the 2nd or 3rd episode.

I'm reviewing this having only seen the first episode, which is all that has been released to date, nor having read the manga.Plot - 10/10The plot appears to deliver on its promise, hence the 10/10 rating; the lynch-pin of the anime is the Goblin Slayer, who slays goblins in this episode and presumably slays more in those to come. It's clear the focus of the plot is to create grounded and hard-hitting scenes, rather than forge a story riddled with intrigue and nuisance, which I think is perfectly fine.You don't expect cordon bleu food if you visit a restaurant called Bubba's Flame Grille, you'll go there for big racks of tender ribs, so it's sensible to rate the food based on how well it delivers on its promise.Animation 10/10Looks good enough to meet my low standards, but I think it will suffice for most people.Violence 10/10Anything with "Slayer" in the title makes one anticipate scenes of extreme violence, and this show most certainly doesn't pull any punches. Nothing is censored, the gore is realistic, the swordplay is realistic and Mr Slayer isn't a pansy who turns the other cheek for seemingly no good reason, only to get burned by it later. He's climbin' in yo windows, he's snatchin' yo goblins up, and he won't leave until he's slain them all.Is This Show For Everyone? 5/10Definitely not for everyone, much as Berserk, Attack on Titan, Overlord, BTOOM!, Drifters, etc are not shows suitable for all audiences. People for whom this show might/will be unsuitable include:- Children- Millennials who demand for "trigger warnings" before seemingly everything ( Spoiler Alert! Click to show or hideThe goblins rape girls in this show, the purpose of which being to create emotional stress in the story rather than to titillate the viewer. )- People who are squeamish with regard to graphic violence and gore- People with Bogyphobia (i.e. "the fear of the bogeyman. People with this fear also dislike demons, goblins, spirits, etc")Overall Opinion: 5 starsIf you're looking for a brutal, emotionally hard-hitting show involving a dude who wrecks goblins and 1v9s, then this is the one for you. This show is what I hoped Berserk 2 would be like, but sadly that was not to be.

Absolutely brutal. If you were expecting a story about a group of newbie adventurers and how their bonds and experience grows until they are badass and save the world or something, then this is not for you. However if you are more into what reality would probably be like in that setting, then yes, it is. This story pulls no punches, and things go sideways right from EP1, in a very graphic way. SO buckle up, and hang on.

Seeing these filthy GAAAAWBLINS get goblinated, for all their filthy GAWBLIN lies, is incredibly satisfying. The characters are hilarious as well, as you watch you'll meet: Spoiler Alert! Click to show or hideOrc Bluge the elf, Shit-Dick the alcoholic Dwarf, Homeless the lizard tribesmen with an addiction to cheese, and the most important character of all...Table (Ok in all seriousness I've only watched the abridged version of Goblin Slayer, I have no idea what the actual show is like, I honestly just felt like shitposting. Please don't take this review seriously) I hope you enjoyed my review, now if you'll excuse I've gotten word that some filthy GAWBLINS are planning on goblinating the moon, and everyone knows that the only good goblin is a dead goblin, so I'm gonna go make those goblins good. Later.

Would like to leave a five star rating without commenting. Does this count? It`s about a guy who slays goblins, Violently and efficiently. Elsewhere is a huge conflict involving a demon lord and a hero who fights him to save the world: they get mentioned and get screen time for less than five minutes. Why? Because this show is about Goblin Slayer. Want to know why this show got five stars from me? Watch it.

I cannot begin to say how much I love this series. It is not afraid to go as dark as it needs to show the plight faced by the denizens of the show's world. Some may say that it is senseless perversion, but this show made goblins honestly a terrifying force, not because of their destructive strength but by the depths of their depravity. Goblins are the go to monster mob of choice for so many fantasy works and they all feel like jobbers with no real substance other than they are ugly and kill people. GS has given them a reason to be called monsters and driving force behind us,as the audience, wanting to see them destroyed for the vile deeds. That aside the references to table top games and other fantasy works were a huge plus and fun to spot. I especially loved the LOTR references. The CG could be a little jarring but nothing terribly egregious. All in all I am excited for the OVA and then season 2 on from that, hopefully.

With many viewers liking Goblin Slayer for not shying away from gore and having darker themes than the norm. I was encouraged to watch all the episodes except the recap episode which not only has a bogus summary but is completely pointless when there's only 2 episodes left. Though this story has potential by clinging to it's darker themes, no much of anything outside of committing acts of goblin genocide is interesting. With character interactions and memorable characters being mundane even when fantasy is it's niche, it's hard to keep watching til the end of each episode. I rate this a 3 mainly since there's still room to grow for the studio to have better direction with pacing (e.g. no more static moments such as the remainder of a supposed death scene being reflected from a birds eye for around 30 seconds), I'm not a fan of the story this anime is based on, there doesn't have be a harem to spice things up. Since it'll continue being wasted on a titular character that doesn't need one and no significant acts of romance has occurred yet, there's still a chance to put that effort towards giving more depth to these recurring characters that I could care less about because this story has no strong direction of emotional development towards anyone besides Goblin Slayer, the priestess, and the childhood friend. At this point there's not much to make the original story better, but the studio can still improve their presentation in further installments, lessening any awkward transitionings from scene to scene. This is a good show, but it became a far cry from its first episode as far as impressions go.

Goblin Slayer season 1: 7.0/10 DC points (Dylan Crunch Points)Umm, wow! Goblin Slayer has some of the most heart racing fighting scenes I have ever seen. They do a great job at keeping the plot moving in unexpected ways. You will have no idea what is about to happen... even when you think you do. In the first few episodes, the main character can sometimes be hard to watch, as he really doesn't say much and is very stubborn. But you can't help fall in love with what he is trying to do and how he does it. The warning about the viewing content is not a joke. I never thought an anime could make me so uncomfortable, but a few scenes did. Still, you just cant look away. The creativeness in the characters movements and dramatic facial expressions make it everything!

this is a well animated series to binge watch, but not made for small children! overall, I would watch this whole season again. it has a fitting last episode for the first season. this show sets up well for a season 2. if you are looking for a cute and fluffy anime, find something else. weapons, killing or bloody injuries, blunt scenes with violence towards women by goblins are included in this show.

Goblin Slayer starts off really strongly, playing up the brutality of its universe, but after a few episodes it starts to feel less and less like the main characters are in danger and the same plot elements begin to repeat. By the end, there is no trace of the original darkness left. It ends like any generic fantasy anime.It's a real shame the show didn't play to its strengths, instead falling into a repeating pattern of Goblin Slayer finding goblins, killing them off with a flashy move he just happened to have prepared just in case for this particular kind of situation and having everyone sing his praises afterwards. The ending was so far from the show's dark premise that I felt like I was watching Log Horizon, a fantasy anime with polar opposite rules in its universe.

I'm going to keep this  relatively  brief. The first season is average. It has some interesting ideas that might pan out in further seasons or the manga (which I might check out) but it didn't fully deliver on them. Once again, it might in the future, but as far as Season One is concerned the show sometimes feels a bit confused about where it wants to go or that it is holding back.Are we watching a journey of a man who MIGHT give in to his inner demons learning to open himself up to others and saving his 'humanity'? Maybe. But he starts the show with human connections and is already shown to be caring, in his way, to Cowgirl and strangers. Are we focusing on a band of heroes out to help 'the little guys', instead of seeking glory, by fighting goblins, an enemy looked down upon by 'true heroes' as not worth their time? Yes but the world building has some plot holes which hurts this a bit and leaves us with some head scratching moments. It is, however, exactly what the title says it is.I can see how people find it refreshing compared to recent anime trends, like people found Devilman Crybaby to be refreshing. Some episodes are great, Goblin Slayer isn't a bad character, most of the fights are fun and can even get creative, Lizard Priest is great, some of the fanservice can be a bit weird (I'm looking at you Sword Maiden during that spoiler scene), and other episodes range from ok to aggressively mediocre.It's average but your mileage will certainly vary. If you're just here to watch some goblins get wrecked, you'll probably have a fine time. I was just hoping to see more of some of the interesting ideas the show has to offer.

Goblin Slayer is not for the weak. But if you can handle some gore and tense situations, and enjoy fantasy adventure stories, then this show will entertain you. Goblin Slayer is a knowledgeable adventurer who only accepts guild missions that involve annihilating goblins. He knows exactly what to do in every situation due to his experience, and his back story provides him with a passionate drive. He is accompanied by a good cast of party members and they go on some pretty exciting adventures. One of my favorite Fall 2018 shows.

This anime has a darker tone than most but that doesn't mean that is all it has. The story is about as you guessed it an adventurer that slays goblins,  the story follows him on is daily life as an adventurer as well as give a glimpses of his dark past that tell you why he became this way.  the good balance between the action and his daily life as well as the interaction between his friends makes for an entertaining time.

holy hecking frick this was amazing cant wait to see the new seasonwell um gotta write more because crunchyroll wont accept a short reviewbut yes this is 10/10and uhhblonde girl = priestess -> coolestarmor bigman = goblin slayer -> thanos destroyerelf woman = mystery -> big angrywhite guy = dwarf man -> big smellydog dragon = some guy whos cool -> spawns minecraft skeletons|vnew avengers

Let me sum up.  This series is NOT for everyone.  But it has a great basic DnD story line.  I love how there is this world changing event going on and the adventurers don't really seem to care about it.  Because Goblins.   It has tons of humor, violence and ridiculousness.  These make it so very watchable.  If it never gets a sequel, that's OK because it ends well.  If one does happen, I'll be first in line to stream it.  Not often I can say this about a modern anime.  Yes there is some disturbing rape in the first episode, but lets be realistic about this, it was to prove a point.  It wasn't just for show.  Other shows have done it for lesser reasons.  So if you can get past the first episode, I really do recommend it. But, you may want to censor it for younger/less mature or sensitive viewers.

great first episode to pull the audience into the gruesome world this anime takes place in but rest of season can't fully recreate that feeling. throughout the season there is a looming evil that seems like the story can expand into, perhaps in a second season allowing growth for the characters but they end up uneventfully taking care of it with characters you aren't invested in leaving the end of the season with no real cliffhanger but also doesn't feel like the story is finished. still enjoyed watching very much though!

Every once in a generation, there's that one person, song or show that people will talk about for years to come. You know of them, might even watch their videos, you've heard them and for the most part you might even agree with them. But at the same time, they can be controversial and do things you may not like from time to time. That doesn't mean you hate them. Or you should turn them off or ridicule them into oblivion. Embrace them. Get to know them. Understand why so many people you know adore them or hate them, Instead of waving them off forever.Goblin Slayer is that for anime. Rather than taking time to understand the intense message being conveyed on the screen, a minority decides they don't like one scene. Thus the rest of the project must inevitably be garbage. Nothing could be further from the case. Goblin Slayer is visceral. He is intense, to the point of zealous fanaticism. He is the Avatar of goblin death. And for a damn good reason. I won't spoil the show. Not here.  But suffice to say: it is the definition of "Must Watch".I have never been so sure of anything anime-related before. Not FMAB, Not Erased, or Death note. Nothing that has come before prepares you. And everything after must compare.Enjoy watching the greatest show on earth. I did thoroughly. And I waited until the end to write this. What a ride it's been. Sayonara until next time!

*No Spoilers Review*Short Summary at EndWhen your character's vocabulary consists of "Ah", "I see" and "Alright" one would be hard pressed to find any significance of dialogue. This is where the studio practiced "Less is More" and proved that one or two words from a properly written main character can have far more emotional impact and character growth than a lengthy speech found in other animes.The protagonist, Goblin Slayer is a man who slays goblins. He's not a god, he's not a hero, he is a man that only knows one thing, that is how to slay goblins. His tactics, his gear, his knowledge and even his very identity all narrowly focus in on slaying goblins. He comes to town and simply asks for a quest that concerns slaying goblins. Hopefully by now you understand how much you'll end up seeing him slaying goblins.As the episodes fly by, you'll slowly start piecing together exactly why he's so obsessed. And the anime does this very well. Never revealing too much beyond what we can already guess, yet leaves some story on the fringes for us to guess at, but never goes into full detail, because, like Goblin Slayer, this anime has no time for exposition dumping. And this keeps the pacing of the anime exactly where it should be.The story is actually far better than I expected and you'll find yourself rooting for the aforementioned protagonist and his eventual group of fellow misfits and friends. The story gets dark at times, but also has some nice gritty humor to keep things from going over the edge. There's light-hearted moments and there's genuine heart-strings being pulled at times. It's weird, but this is one of the first times where I've watched an anime I've thoroughly enjoyed and *not* remembered any of the character's names and have not been bothered by this, I'd like to think that it's simply because the story is being told through the eyes of someone who doesn't care much about names, it doesn't detract from the story at all, in fact it actually is a relief that I don't have to memorize a billion and one character surnames. Through this review, you'll notice that I haven't mentioned the action, that's because it purely deserves it's own section, which we'll talk about now.Now, first off let me say, I've seen some people say it's far too embedded in realism and I guess that in their eyes it may be, but I can see why it needed to be. The combat, purely accentuates the fact that each of these characters, while being better, tougher or stronger than the average human, are not super-human. They have flaws, they have weaknesses, they cannot beat your heroes like Naruto or Alucard. They can easily die like you or me, and the best part is that the characters "understand" this. Goblin Slayer especially knows what he can and can't do... Though we'll touch on this later.So, combat in Goblin Slayer is gritty, realistic and very bloody within reason. The studio was not afraid of putting in some nudity and horrific deaths to bring their points across. Though, the combat is more thoughtful than most animes, as said before, Goblin Slayer *knows* what he's capable of, so he devises plans to get around these limitations. I will say that it's not Death Note level of mindgames here, but it goes without saying that with a one track mind and a hatred that is far more than mere obsession Goblin Slayer more than gets the job done, educating both his party and the audience of his world and why they should take heed.Though, with all thoughtfulness aside, the combat is quick, it's agile and it really is better than 9/10ths of anime out there fully in my own opinion. It's essentially the Dark Souls of anime, where death looms around every corridor and cave if one's not careful and it does the story justice, sticking around long enough to get some action, but leaving when plot needs to happen. Overall a pretty good balance.I'd rate the animation as a solid 8/10, not too shabby, though I expect the next season to rectify this. Speaking of, there are some parts that absolutely look stunning and will age very gracefully. There's some rare instances of 3D animation, though it's done mostly okay and doesn't distract from the presentation.Speaking for sound design, it's quite good, not a lot of stock sounds and the voices are clear and volumes are nicely done. The music on the other hand is beautiful and each track fits the anime quite nicely. I usually skip most intros to animes, I've never skipped a single one in Goblin Slayer. It's almost tribal hymns are quite different than what we usually hear and are ever-present through tougher and more dangerous scenes.Overall, I rate this a 8.5/10The story is great, not amazing though it's very well written.The animation is consistently good, though could be better.The characters are very well written, though need more backstory.Combat is quick and gruesome, though doesn't overstay it's welcome.Sound Design is above average.Music Design is excellent.If you want a great anime that delivers a simple premise of slaying goblins, while rooting for a great selection of characters and learning lore in the process. A show that doesn't pull punches yet still gives you light hearted moments and great character developments. Yet shows you the full capabilities of a strangely intelligent man that's obsessed with efficiently killing goblins, Goblin Slayer is a must watch."The Imagination is a weapon. Those who don't use it die first." - Goblin Slayer

After watching Goblin Slayer i can say its not the best anime but its not the worst and sits comfortably at the top, i can see why this is so popular. i was positively surprised the dark and gritty scenes where well made. The story is not the best but far from bad, its hard to build up the world and characters with only 12 episodes, Witch is what keeps this from 5 stars.hopefully as the series proved popular the next season will have more episodes to expand upon

Haven't read the LN, so I just thrown into it like most people. It started off in a way to set the tone for the rest of the series, which is good in my opinion. Loved most episodes and definitely the protagonist. Didn't dive into the harem category, which is great too. Still a little fan service but that didn't take away anything. Also the action was top notch! So if you like the first episode you will love it.

The shock and scare factors hook people into this anime as it is pretty graphic and disturbing to some, however goblin slayer does not go over the top it sure has it's fair share of horror especially during the first episode that really got the viewers attention. As well as them doing a great job keeping goblin slayers face a secret which is one of the main reasons i kept watching. 9/10 overall exited for season 2

This is my first review for any of the anime series I've watched. I have not really felt the need to write one before now, but this is just that good. I will make sure I don't spoil anything.While, at times, the animation can be less than perfect, it is barely noticeable when compared to any of the "greats" people regularly tout. The story starts out absolutely brutal, and for this reason, I would recommend no kids watch it. It then slows down a little bit, before building up to an incredible finale. The story-line is very well written, and watches like reading an epic. There are no annoyingly repeated catch phrases or cute (but worthless and again annoying) addon characters. Each character has his or her own depth and ties in with the story. Everything that happens either builds the characters, builds relationships, or builds the story. Based on what I saw, if this studio can keep making seasons like the first, or go even beyond what it has already, I think that this anime will become one of the greatest of all time.

Goblin Slayer: not your average fantasy anime with a main character from another world or with a lot of comedy/harem element (like isekai or taking place within a game). Instead, this is a dark fantasy anime that sticks out with gore, violence, and brutal murder unlike most fantasy anime today.When the first episode came out, a lot of viewers were disturbed with the first episode as a lot of them watched it without having proper knowledge of what they should have expected. Kumo Kagyu, the author of the light novel series, wanted to make a story that stood out among any other fantasy anime today; thus coming up with Goblin Slayer (anime adaptation by White Fox).The anime starts off with The Priestess joining an adventurer guild after receiving her training with light and holy magic. She gets asked to join a small group of porcelain ranked (lowest level) adventurers to join her group to go kill some goblins in a cave, and so she accepts.Everyone in the group seems happy, very eager to complete their quest, and truly do believe that it will be easy for them to get the job done... but this isn't a romanticized fantasy anime and things don't turn out as well as they expect it would.The goblins made a sneak attack from behind. They overwhelm the adventurers one by one and everyone but The Priestess gets slain; one of the girls, The Fighter, gets raped (not shown but is suggested from clothes being ripped off and her screaming as a shot is shown away from her).Just when the goblins were about to gang up on The Priestess, a man in a full set of armor arrives and slays them all; hence being the "Goblin Slayer" as said in the title of the show. And so he goes out to fulfill the quests the adventurers have failed to complete along with The Priestess helping him out with the remaining goblins.He shows to have true understanding of goblin psychology while never hesitating for each kill made. After completing the quest, the priestess decides to join him as his adventuring companion.Goblin Slayer Opening https://youtu.be/0i0z98M2y5U Goblin Slayer | GOBLIN SLAYER https://youtu.be/bMnriO4UWVI So let's bring this question up: why have such a gruesome anime filled with horror and violence? Why not have it be a much less horrific anime like Konosuba, Sword Art Online, or even No Game No Life?In today's world, isekai and video-game-based anime are what's trending for authors and anime studios to make. Kumo Kagyu, on the other hand, wanted to reinvigorate horror fantasy anime once again as it used to be back in the old days of anime.Kagyu talks about this in his interview hosted by TheAnimeMan on YouTube where he goes over the making of Goblin Slayer as well as his journey as an author.​​Interview With "Goblin Slayer" Creator Kagyu Kumo https://youtu.be/0sN0p3xsorkHe also talks about why the characters don't have particular names but are labeled with who they are such as Goblin Slayer, Priestess, Guild Girl, etc. He wants the audience to decide on how to perceive these characters; basically granting them the ability to view them by personal perspectives.Going with the anime adaptation, this is very perfect for the first group of adventurers seen and killed. Even if we, the audience, learn their names, they would eventually be forgotten. Instead, we are shown a couple of times with flashbacks in black and white but having their eyes being colored (something to differentiate all of them that have died).Also with the nicknames comes to use for some of the characters being well known to certain peoples. A lot from other lands have heard of The Goblin Slayer's deeds in taking on quests in killing goblins. And so the elves know him as Olcborg, the dwarves as Beard-Cutter, and the lizard men as Sir Goblin Slayer.Request | GOBLIN SLAYER https://youtu.be/yIVHv0uY5qU It does also bring great in depth mystery for the protagonist as we do not know his name but rather what he does and his past as we get to learn more about him through each passing episode. From first impressions, we can tell that his daily life is eat, sleep, and killing goblins with an added touch of 3D animations from time to time to show of his inclination to daily duties.Spoiler Alert! Click to show or hideA great example would be whenever he arrives at Cow Girl's place to eat, sleep, and rest, he always checks for tracks of goblins and any evidence left behind. Say if a fence got broken down a bit, then there were goblins lurking around (perhaps he has hidden care for Cow Girl to make sure she's not targeted; a thought to pass up).​​Daily Routine | GOBLIN SLAYER https://youtu.be/1ZcfSoaByr4 The only time we don't see him as a 3D animation is whenever he's having a close/intimate conversation with others. From those conversations, his appearance can easily level with the people he's talking with and be more than just somebody who's only desire is to kill goblins but be able to have more empathy towards him.​​Where do Goblins Come From? | GOBLIN SLAYER https://youtu.be/4rjufADdbW0 And from having more empathy for him, we begin to understand why he must feel to only kill goblins. Spoiler Alert! Click to show or hideAfter all, he had a sister once and saw the horror unfold before his eyes as she was raped and brutally murdered.It's very reasonable as to why Goblin Slayer only kills goblins not only by this scarring past he has but how other adventurers haven't been taking on these quests. The higher ranking adventurers don't go for these quests as they seem too easy for them to do.Not only that, but the lower ranking adventurers can barely stand a chance against them; most likely die just like the first batch of adventurers. And so, I perceive him as a sort of an uncelebrated hero for solely slaying goblins where hardly anyone would be able or even want to take on these quests.I also do appreciate that Guild Girl is happy for Goblin Slayer bravely taking on those quests as she understands how critical it is to slay as much as possible with even women being taken captive, raped, and mentally scarred.

It's visceral. Some might like it some might hate it, I love it. It's a good look at how a protagonist suffering from PTSD might function in a fantasy setting, something that seems to be overlooked way too much.Some parts of the manga which were cut - I wish they hadn't but, I can understand the desire to pave a smoother path for casual anime viewers.The story, plot, narrative and characters are fine and their development could be a tad better but, I think it's fine as presented.So, maybe it depends on what you are seeking or what your personal tastes are but, this is one of the few anime I look forward to watching this season and in fact, I'm hoping it gets another season, a full cour.

Goblin Slayer is basically a really good anime, even if it has its flaws.First, there's one important point to consider. The Anime is based on the design and adaptation of Kōsuke Kurose who's the artist and designer for the manga version. He made those based on the input from the Light Novel author who is Kumo Kagyu. What this means is that this anime is an adaptation that followed another adaptation and that's why, compared to the source material and, especially, the manga (since it also have the visual part to it), the anime hit and miss on some major points. (This is also why, on some part, those who have read the LN or even the Manga has to explains things about the anime to those who haven't.)In both the LN and the Manga, the subject surrounding the facts that goblins are truly evil creatures because they are openly raping, killing and eating humans as the biggest scums possible are displayed in a crude and efficient way. You don't feel any kind of empathy or sadness for every one of the killed goblins. Instead, you might even feel happy/proud that they get killed. In this anime, the violence and aggressiveness of the goblins was toned down a lot and this makes them feel a lot weaker and innocent than from the LN and manga. That, by itself, makes some part awkward. (They are holding onto someone clothes and a few moment later, that someone's is almost fully naked with not much of a wound as if she took a bath or something.) This is why I consider the anime great, but still a failure toward the original material. Not because I would prefer to see open scene of rape, violence and brutality, but because those part are a necessity to display how critical things are. (For example, in the manga and LN, the guy who gets killed in the start, he get chopped into pieces and gets eaten in front of the other girls. In the anime, you don't see or know much of what's happening of him other than that he bleeds, die and disappear.)In the light novel, more or less, everything is well described. In the manga, while some details are removed (for the sake of having a great flow in the panels), it's efficient at putting emphases on the important part in the discussions between the characters which gives roots to the great story. The anime lacks that kind of preparation and, on top of having part being cut off (or disordered), it slightly fails at giving the right view of how things really are.It's kinda like if you were to watch a series about Vikings' raid and all you would see are clean viking foot-warrior slapping captured women they have captured. You could say that, in Goblin Slayer, goblins are like underground vikings with a taste for human meat. Still, the anime, by itself, is great. The soundtracks are good. The Animation are also good, even if some CGI could have been worked on a bit more. (We got to understand that this is how it's done now. Either they use CGI or we get 1 episode per month and the anime would be cut off mostly to OAVs format.)

I`m going to keep it 100. I`ve been seeing some 1-3 star reviews saying its encouraging rape, that shouldn't be a reason you taint this anime with such low stars. this anime gives a splash of Fantasy and reality. This anime gives the perfect reality to the anime that i like to feel in my heart not no OP main character where you know nothing bad will happen. fucked up peddy shit happens in this anime is why i like it its makes you feel like why tf was that person so fucking stupid to go do that

Spoiler warning!!! I love this anime and what makes me give this series its stars on this review is 1st Star for the characters Like the Elf girl <3 and Goblin Slayer as well as the surrounding adventures that you normally wouldn't get back story on in a adventure guild type anime. 2nd star is for the dark scenes and unexpected potential that i wasn't expecting when i first clicked on this anime.3rd star is for the story and background character surrounding Goblin Slayer the 4th star being the way they show the combat as in some fantasy anime's the whole battle would have a couple of spells or the character war crying and beating the enemy's with brute force Goblin slayers way of combat are more realistic and show how much time and thinking goes thru the developers heads when thinking about fighting goblins in a cave as for the rope tactic and Goblin slayer showing the rookie priest how they focused there attention to a totem instead of the cave walls that had another direction which led to her team being attacked and ;( raped   the fifth star is over all its a great show that keeps me interested and always hyped to see the next episode. This is probably one of the first anime shows I watched, and one of the few shows that I have re-watched more than once. It has everything that you could want in a show good story, enjoyable characters, and good music.FMA Brotherhood will have you laughing, crying, and everything in between while providing you with a memorable story that will last a lifetime. You will not regret watching this show.That being said I highly recommend you watch this show, even if you have to put off other shows in order to watch it.

This one one of the few anime where I actually suggest watching the dub.The show is brilliant, the music is amazing, and the story is fantastic.Ideal Watching Guide:Watch "Fullmetal Alchemist" (the original)Wait a few monthsWatch "Fullmetal Alchemist: Brotherhood"While Brotherhood goes in a completely different direction, both works started with the same base, and the team behind Brotherhood assumes you've seen the original. This is why the original takes a little more time in the early years/training/qualification/story building stages (as they're establishing an entire world), while Brotherhood is able to build off what it already assumes viewers known and "gets right into it" a lot faster.The original FMA was really good, don't get me wrong, but Brotherhood is by far superior.. however, if you want to be able to enjoy both of them - watch the original first, otherwise it's like trying to read the book after watching the movie. It just takes the fun out of it, lol.Mild Spoiler Warning: Spoiler Alert! Click to show or hideAlso, when watching FMA:B after having watched FMA, you'll be casually enjoying the first dozen or so episodes going "yeah, this is similar, just trimmed a bit... I wonder when it'll start to - HOLY CRAP!!! That... er... um.. well, yeah.. that's one way to kill someone. I guess we've started with the new stuff 0.0

Just another 5/5 star rating, but honestly this series deserves it. I have not seen a show go for 50+ episodes and stay so engaging in regards to its plot and animation. The characters are memorable and their struggle is really felt. The animation never dips and to me that says a lot, for I have seen the occasional slip up episode here in there in other shows. Highly recommend both the dub and sub for this one.

This anime is simply one of the best shows I've ever seen. So the first thing I should clear up is that you must watch the dub. Nearly all of the English voices are spot on. Next, let's talk about story. I'll give you a brief summary without any spoilers. Edward and Alphonse Elric are two brothers whose father was an alchemist. Their father left them at a young age, leaving behind his family and research. The days went by as Ed and Al lived with their mother alone and played with the neighbor kid, Winry. They had a fondness towards alchemy, despite having bitter feelings towards their father. The boys poured over their fathers research, and with some talent and practice, were able to teach themselves to use the art. Eventually, a deadly illness comes, and with it takes many lives.
